of Divines, of Lawyers, of private persons. It concerns every man, that he may
not do, or suffer wrong. Use. Study this point. It is very comfortable for
soul, body, credit, and estate. Labor to know every ones right with a will to
preserve it in thy calling, and then all will be happy, if every one do it:
Wars and contentions will be prevented, and a quiet state recovered, Psalm.
85.10, 11. Glory will dwell in that land, where mercy, truth, and
righteousness meet, and abide together.

6. Doct. Extremity of justice is not always to be used: moderation sometimes
is to be exercised. As David did to Shimei, 2 Samuel 19.23. David said, and swear
he should not dye, though he well deserved it, and Abishai pressed David to do
it. God is content to lose his right in the Shewbread, when men are hungry.
Abiathar the High Priest gives it to David, and his hungry followers, Mar. 2.26
Much more should man. Gods own Law, Deuteronomy. 22.23, etc. might have been abused. A
Virgin in some places in a City might cry long ere any could hear her, yet if
forced, she must dye. A strumpet going willingly into the field, or seducing a
young man, there might be naught, and never cry out, and yet escape. Much more
need will there be of moderation in the execution of humane laws upon variety
of circumstances. Summum jus summa injuria. The strictest sentence, though
legal, may prove the greatest injury. Use. Take not all advantages against
others, that Gods, or man's law allows, but win men by moderation, where it will
prevail. A Chancery, or a Court of equity may do well in some cases.

Verse. 4. To give subtilty to the simple, to the young man knowledge, and
discretion.
The common good to be gotten by these Proverbs has been spoken of before in
the 2. and 3. verses. The good that may come to particular persons by reading
them follows. And that 1. To such as are unwise, in this 4. verse. 2. To such as
are wise, in the 5. and 6. verses.

For the 1. in this verse, It may be objected thus, these Proverbs coming from
Solomon's deep wisdom, are not for every one to read, and being brief, and
therefore the more obscure, had need of wise men to peruse them; simple men can
look for little good out of them. The answer is in this verse: Men of the
meanest capacity may get good by them, for though some of them are so deep,
that they may exercise the wisest heads; yet some are so plain, that simple men
may get profit by them. For the words.

To give. An elegant relation. Before he had showed what we might receive,
verse. 3. Now lest we should think the profit came from the Readers wit, and not
the Writers, as wise men will gather wit out of other men's folly, and
Physicians heal by poison, he shows, that the profit flows naturally out of the
Proverbs themselves, and so evidently, that simple men perceive it: These
breasts hold out milk for children. These Proverbs hold out an easy way for a
simple man to get subtilty. The Hebrew word (...) is used,

1. For delivering a thing into ones hand, as Genesis 39.4. All that the keepers
had he put (Heb. gave) into Joseph's hand. Not to possess, but to guide,

2. To put a thing in its place. God set them in the Firmament, Genesis 1.17.

3. To suffer. God will not suffer the destroyer to come in, Exodus 12.23.

4. To make. I will make the land desolate. Ezekiel. 61.4.

5. To set over. See, I have set thee over all the land of Egypt, Genesis 41.41.

6. To teach or give instruction. Give to a wise man. To wit, instruction, as
is added in little letters to fill up the sense, Prove. 9.9.

7. To account. The Lord of the land took us for spies of the country, Genesis
42.30.

8. To express wishing. Would God, Numb. 11.29. Heb. Who will give?

9. To bring forth. Who can bring a clean thing out of an ununclean? Job 14.4.
A good man is like a tree that brings forth his fruit in his season. Psalm.
1.3. Here it is taken in the sixth sense, for teaching or giving knowledge to
the mind.

(...) Subtilty. The word is taken sometimes in an ill sense, for a crafty wit
to deceive others. Now the Serpent was more subtle then any beast of the
field, Genesis 3.1. So God disappointeth the devices of the crafty, Job 5.12.
Sometimes it is taken in a good sense, for understanding to prevent dangers,
that crafty men might bring upon us. O ye simple, understand wisdom, chap.
8.5. So it is taken here. Such will not easily be deceived, or deluded.

To the simple. From this word (...) comes futuus in Latin, a fool. Such, who
being flexible like reeds, are carried about with every wind of doctrine,
Ephesians. 4.14. It comes from (...) that fignifies to allure or seduce one that
wants understanding of God truths, and will, and so is easily allured to any
error, or wickedness by good words, as giving credit to every thing, because
not able to examine things for want of judgment. He falls into danger for lack
of knowledge. The simple believes every word, or thing, chap. 14.15. It is
opposed to (...) subtilty, and healed by it, Prove. 9.4. Who so is simple, let
him turn in hither, says Wisdom. The word signifies also one, who wants
foresight to prevent danger. The Lord preserves the simple, Psalm. 116.6. Both
may be meant here. The Proverbs will bring wisdom to a simple man, showing him
how to prevent error, and danger.

(...) To the young man. Some understand it of one young in knowledge, spoken
of Ephesians. 4.14. But it may well be understood of one well in years, who for
want of instruction, and experience, (though of better capacity then the
former) is unskilful, and seldom troubled with serious thoughts. It comes from
(...) to shake out, I shook my lap, and said, So God shake out every man, etc.
Neh. 5.13. It signifies one, that has, as it were, cast off parents and
tutors, and yet is not well able to guide himself for want of experience, like
the childish King, that brings a woe to the land, Eccles. 10.16. It signifies
an infant also as one cast out of the womb into the world, until the child
be weaned, 1 Samuel 1.22. But here more properly it intends one free from
Governors, yet wanting experience to govern himself, and more fit to take,
then to give good counsel.

Knowledge. The principles, and beginnings of knowledge, such as first come
into young men's minds, when they are taught by others. Opposed to the next
word (...), Discretion. It comes from a word that signifies to conceive, and
agitate things in the mind, and upon deliberation to be able to conclude
aright, what is best to be done, or to be left undone. Not bare thinking, or
devising, as Psalm. 10.4. God is not in all his thoughts, or determining, as
Jer. 51.11. His device is against Babylon, for both these nature teaches, and
it is not worth pains to learn. But more acute and subtle thoughts are here
intended. Young men do things rashly without consideration, and therefore had
need of thoughtfulness, or advisement, or discretion. Sometimes it is taken in
an ill sense for plotting mischief, and bringing wicked devices to pass, Psalm.
37.7. So the root of it (...) is taken, Deuteronomy. 19.19. Ye shall do to him, as he
had thought to have done unto his brother.

Figures here are none. Note 1. the good that comes to men of mean capacity. 2.
The benefit that accrues to young men.

In the first note 1. the effect of These Proverbs. To give. 2. The object,
Subtilty. 3. The subject. To the simple.

In the second note 1. the subject. To the young man. 2. A double adjunct.
Knowledge by others. Discretion by pondering on these Proverbs read, or
expounded.

1. Doct. The Scripture contains store of heavenly knowledge sufficient to
inform simple persons.

In the prosecution of this point, note 1. The store of heavenly mysteries in
the Scripture.

2. The clearness of them. For the store, see 2 Timothy 2.15, 16, 17. The holy
Scriptures are able to make men wise unto Salvation, and are profitable for
doctrine, reproof, correction, instruction in righteousness, that the man of
God may be perfect, thoroughly furnished unto all good works. Two arguments are
here couched to prove it.

1. The various uses of it, To inform men's judgments, show them their sins,
bring them to amendment, direct their lives afterward.

2. The effect. To make men more then worldly wise, wise unto salvation. Wise
not to get wealth, but heaven. This requires store. Gods treasure mentioned, 2
Cor. 4.7. is laid up here, and hence Gods Stewards fetch enough to make
themselves, and others rich. In a treasury is much gold, and silver laid up.
The mouth of a righteous man is a well of life, Prove. 10.11. How much more Gods
Word? So here. Subtilty is to be had to prevent errors, and dangers. Knowledge
of things needful. Discretion to guide men in safe ways. There is then store
of heavenly truths in Scripture.

For the second, the clearness of them. It is compared to a light, and a
lanthorn, Psalm. 119.105. It gives light unto the simple, Psalm. 119.130. It
makes wise the simple, and inlightens the eyes, Psalm. 19.7, 8.

Reason. 1. Many things are as plainly set down, as any man can speak, as the
the History of the Creation, Genesis 1. Redemption in the Gospel. Precepts of
holiness in the Epistles.

2. Heavenly things are set out by earthly similitudes for our capacity, as in
many parables, Matthew. 13. These are spectacles to help our weak sight.

3. They are fitted by God to our capacity, not to his high wisdom in the
manner of delivery. And who can speak plainer then God, or teach better?

1. Use. See the difference between Gods Word, and men's. Though Gods Word be
much deeper, yet weak ones may draw water hence. A Lamb may wade, and an
Elephant may swim in this river. It was writ over Pythagoras his school doors,
(...). Let no man ignorant of Geometry enter. But God Iets ignorant persons,
and children come into his school and learn, 1 John 2.14.

2. Use. Be encouraged notwithstanding your natural ignorance to go to school
to Gods Word to learn knowledge. There is store of matter, and clearness of
delivery. If this book of The Proverbs, that is so deep, may serve to instruct
simple ones, much more other plainer books of Scripture. Peter Martyr in his
Epistle Dedicatory, before his Comment on the Epistle to the Romans, speaks
strangely, yet truly, Equidem scio multos esse, qui hoc non credunt, and non
paucos qui ea rideant, nosque insanire arbitrentur, sed istos rogatos velim,
etc. I wot well, there are many, that will not believe it, and not a few, that
will deride those things, and think, that we are mad in ascribing so much to
the Scriptures. But ^oh that they would be entreated, to make trial a while,
and to take to the reading of the Bible. Male mihi sit (itae enim in tanta
causa jurare ausim) nisi tandem capiantur: sentient denique quantum divina haec
ab humanis distent, etc. Let ill betide me, (for so I dare swear in so great a
cause) if they be not taken at length: they will perceive in the end, how far
Gods writings differ from men's. Add Erasmus his testimony in his Preface to
the Gospel of Luke. Expertus sum in meipso, I can speak it by experience, that
there is little good to be gotten by reading the Bible cursorily, and
carelessly: but do it duly, and diligently, with attention, and affection, and
you shall find such an efficacy, as is to be found in no other book that can
be named. Yet was Erasmus a great scholar, and knew the worth of books.

2. Doct. Subtilty for preventing of dangers is best learned out of Scriptures.
They teach us how to countermine, and go beyond our enemies plots, Psalm.
119.98. Serpentine wisdom is required, Matthew. 10.16. Serpents prevent real
dangers by folding the tails about the head to safeguard the chief part, and
keep life. They prevent verbal dangers by laying one ear on the ground, and
stopping the other that they may not be enchanted. August in Psalm. 57. that is,
58. with us. Also when they come to wholesome water, they drink not, till they
have cast up their poison, Epiphan. Haeres. 37. There are in Scripture
directions how to prevent evils that follow wantonness, Prove. 5.1. etc. that
follow suretiship, Prove. 6.1. etc. Examples also are here to be found. Joseph
would not be undone by his Mistresses daily solicitations, Genesis 39.10. Nor
would Esther endure to see the destruction of her people, Esth. 8.6. Here are
we taught the art of prevention of all sorts of dangers of soul, of body,
temporal, spiritual, eternal. Use. Despise all Politics in comparison of
Scripture. Let Machiavel sleep, and learn of Solomon. Let Aristotle go, and
learn of Paul, how to escape hell. Else all other evils are escaped to no
purpose. Good men had need to get policy from hense, because they have to do
with politic enemies, crafty men, and devils, who will else sorely wound them,
and quickly overthrow them.

3. Doct. We are naturally simple and easily led into error. Man is born like
a wild Asses colt, Job 11.12. Man that is in honor, and understands not, is
like the beasts, that perish, Psalm. 49.20.

It appears 1. by our falls into error. How easily does every light objection
draw us?

2. Into dangers. No warnings will keep us out.

3. By our ready hearkening to bad counsel, whereas good will hardly down with
us.

4. By the disparity of our condition. Men of great birth run as wild courses,
as other meaner of education. It argues a great stain in nature, that education
cannot rub out. Use. It lays us low. A generation of silly creatures. If
others will tempt us, we presently agree to undo our selves, like children of
great men, that make ill matches against their parents will. If none will tempt
us, we will undo our selves. We quickly err in judgment, or practice. Ill
opinions, or lusts will be sure to ruin us for ever, if we want grace, and if
God keep us not better, then we can keep our selves.

4. Doct. The way to keep us from errors, is the right understanding of
Scripture. From thence subtilty is gotten to prevent them. All errors, and
lusts come either out of want of a perfect rule, or misapplying that rule that
is perfect, or willingness to err, or do ill. Ours come not from the first.
The Scripture is a perfect rule, Psalm. 19.7. and able to make us perfect, 2 Timothy 3.16, 17. God neither wants skill, nor will to give a perfect rule, as men
do. There was enough revealed in the Old Testament to guide men of that age.
Therefore God forbids any to add to it, or take from it, Deuteronomy. 4.1, 2. or to
go aside to the right hand, or to the lest, Deuteronomy. 5.32. which they might have
done had they not been strictly tied to a perfect rule. It was impossible for
them to err then for want of a perfect rule, much more for us now, when it is
more fully explained, and the charge of not adding nor diminishing backed with
terrible threats of plagues to be inflicted, and the loss of eternal life,
Rev. 22.18, 19. To err by mispplying the rule is ordinary. Unlearned and
unstable men wrest the Scriptures to their own destruction, 2 Pet. 3.16. So was
Paul's preaching mis-interpreted to countenance lying and evil doing, Romans 3.5,
6, 7, 8. To err willingly is shameful. As for a man that has a true measure
and weight, willingly to shorten his neighbor of his due. Use. It shows us,
where the fault must be laid of errors, and lusts in our days; Not on God,
for his rule is perfect, though many now disgrace it blasphemously, which have
guided many thousands to heaven. The fault then must be in man's misapplying it,
or willingness to wander out of Gods ways.

2. Use. Study to apply the rule well, and rest satisfied with it. Leave it
once, and never go right.

5. Doct. Most danger of going astray is in the time of youth. Young men are
most subject to walk in the ways of their hearts, and sight of their eyes,
Eccl. 11.9. Remember not the sins of my youth, Psalm. 25.7. As this was David's
confession, so Paul seeks to keep Timothy from such errors. Fly youthful
lusts, 2 Timothy 2.2^.

Reason. 1. Because they are out of the conduct of Parents and Masters, that
could guide them well. Like young birds newly fledge, forsaken by the Dams, and
easily taken. Men's disposition is not known till then; Dum Aetas, Metus,
Magister prohibent; Age, Fear, Master keeps them in awe. Terence.

2. They want experience to guide themselves. When the bridle is out of the
Horse mouth, then he runs wild. Use. Young men hearken to me. The Devil lays
close fiege to you, and beleaguers you round about. Ye are not free from God,
though from Governors. Ye are strong to do evil, and have scarce learned to do
good. Oh! be watchful, lest like young prodigals ye run so far out, that ye
never can recover all your life long. Yea, worse. They die beggere, ye will die
damned wretches. Their debts are all paid by death, your greatest debt is to be
paid after death, and never discharged to eternity.

6. Doct. Bare knowledge is not enough, but discretion must be labored for
also. A good man will guide his affairs with discretion, Psalm. 112.3.
Discretion shall preserve thee, Prove. 2.11. For knowledge is imperfect, and
will need further augmentation by deliberation. And knowing men do things
rashly oftentimes, being disturbed with passion. Use. Add to your knowledge
discretion. Seek to learn both out of this and other Books of Scripture, and ye
will not study in vain.

Verse. 5. A wiseman will bear, and will increase learning; and a man of
understanding shall attain unto wise counsels.
The benefit that all men may get by these Proverbs, was set out before, verse.
2, 3. For simple men, and young men, verse. 4. Now for wisemen, whose gain is
set out, verse. 5. and their profit, verse. 6. For the first. Lest any man should
think, because these Proverbs bring benefit to simple men, and young ones,
therefore they are good for none but children, and fools, and may be contemned
by wise men, as too low for them; he shows that they are good for wise men
also, to increase their knowledge. Though one main end of writing this Book
were to instruct young ones, as appears by often repeating My Son, My Son, yet
here is excellent matter, worthy also for wise men to learn.

For the words. A wise man, or, That the wise man may hear. And so it may go on
to set out the true end of writing this Book, whereas your Translation carries
the event only, which may seem to some to come rather by the Readers care,
then the Writers aim. So that is justly added by the Translators, Psalm. 9.20.
That the Nations may know themselves to be but men. So we say, Know you are
men; that is, Know that you are men. Or, if ye read it as it is in the
Translation, it shows the readiness of wise men to make use of this Book for
increase of knowledge. Having invited simple ones, he makes no doubt but wise
men will hear and learn. A wise man is one that has already attained to a good
measure of heavenly knowledge, yet is willing to get more by this Book.

Will hear. The word (...), signifies,

1. To hear, as in hearing a report. I have heard, that there is corn in
Egypt, Genesis 42.2.

2. To mark what is said, or attend to it. The Lord has heard, that I was
hated, Genesis 29.33.

3. To understand what is spoken. They knew not, that Joseph understood them,
Genesis 42.23. Heb. heard them.

4. To grant what is asked. As for Ishmael, I have heard thee, Genesis 17.20.

5. To believe a thing reported, to be true. They hearkened not unto Moses,
Exodus 6.9.

6. To obey what is commanded. Abraham obeyed my voice, Genesis 26.5. So speaking
is put for commanding, Est. 1.10. Here the word is used in the second sense,
for marking and giving his mind to it. He will give heed to these Proverbs. To
such, a blessing is promised, Rev. 1.3. It signifies attending with ears of
mind and body. Wise men are willing to know more. Fools desire it not. They
know not the worth of learning.

And will increase. Heb. Add; to wit, to that which he had before, and make it
more, as an heap is increased by addition of stones or money. Hence Joseph had
his name, Genesis 30.24. And she called his name Joseph, and said, The Lord shall
add to me another Son. It may be understood of adding to others, as well as to
himself; that not only he will know more then he did before, but also be so
full, that he will run over to teach others.

Learning, (...). Received from others by hearing them, as the word imports,
and as it were taken out of their knowledge, yet without loss to them, as one
Candle takes light from another. Homo, qui erranti comiter monstrat viam, quasi
de suo lumine lumen accendat, facit, Nihilo minus ipsi lucet, cum illi
accenderit. Ennius apud Cicer. offic. l. 1. He that gently shows a wandering man
his way, does as if he lighted another man's candle at his. His shines
nevertheless when the others is kindled.

A man of understanding. He that understands these Proverbs well, or has a
better capacity then others, will gather very profitable Conclusions out of
them. Such were the men of Issachar, which had understanding of the times to
know what Israel ought to do, 1 Chr. 12.32.

Shall attain to. The word (...), signifies,

1. To get any thing by price or labor, or prayer, or any way of right. Thence
Cain had his name, I have gotten a man of the Lord, Genesis 4.1. And Genesis 25.10.
The field which Abraham purchased, Heb. got.

2. To possess a thing when a man has gotten it. The Lord possessed me in the
beginning of his way, Prove. 8.22. Here it is taken in the first sense. He shall
get by labor and industry in learning from others, and so have a right to it,
and use of it, as a labourer at night has to that which was another man's in
the morning.

Wise counsess, (...). We want a word to express it, and are forced to use a
Periphrasis, or circumlocution to set it out in two words, which is but one in
the Original. The derivations are two, but from the same root (...), to govern
a ship. Some derive it from the Governor that sits at the Stern, called (...),
who must guide the ship wisely, or else all must be lost that is in it.
Sapientia suam Gubernator torquet nabem, haud valentia. Titin. apud Nonium. The
Governor guides his ship by wisdom, not by strength. He is called the
Shipmaster, Jon. 1.6. As the Mariner long rouls up and down thoughts in his
mind, what to do in a storm; so this wise man to guide his actions, that he
may choose the best upon deliberation. The word imports any accurate way of
doing any thing, as Seamen accurately guide ships between rocks and
quicksands, especially in storms. Others derive it from (...), a rope. As
Seamen clime up and down the ropes perpetually, yet fall not into the Sea: so
wise men easily dispatch their affairs without damage, though dreadful to
others, as the former employment is to such as are fearful or unskilful. Or,
it may be of preferment to places of command, to guide others, as a Pilot
guides a ship by the stern, and tackling, and rudder. In this last word may be
a Metaphor taken from Ship-men, the rest are literal. In this verse. is first
the augmentation of wisdom by reading these Proverbs. Secondly, the height of
what is to be gotten.

In the first note, 1. The agent, or cause, A wise man. 2. The action, or
transitory effect, as building, will hear. 3. The thing made by action, as the
house, and will increase.
Set out by the object, learning.

In the second note, 1. The agent, A man of understanding. 2. The effect, shall
attain unto. 3. The object, wise counsels.


1. Dect. No man so wife, but he may learn more. And that both in Theoricall
and Practical knowledge, how to think, and how to do better. We are all
children, while we are here, and know but in part, 1 Cor. 13.11. Christ himself
increased in wisdom, Luke 2.52. Before the Law they had but a few Revelations
and Traditions. Under it, they had the truth in obscure shadows and sacrifices.
After it, the darkness of the understanding remained, though more light
appeared. Adam in innocence might know more by reasoning and occurrents. Angels
learn from Gods dealing with his Church. Unto the principalities and powers in
heavenly places, is made known by the Church the manifeld wisdom of God, Ephesians.
3.10. Which things the Angels desire to look into, 1 Pet. 1.12.

Reason, 1. Want of light. The Sun of knowledge shines not so clear here as in
heaven, clouds of ignorance come beween* There are few clouds in Egypt, whence
comes want of rain, and they are forced to water their gardens with their feet,
Deuteronomy. 11.10. Seldom a cloud seen in Japan. But there are many clouds in the
wisest men's brains, to keep them from understanding many truths.

2. Want of sight. We see here by the spectacles of Gods works. Invisible
things of God are seen from the creation of the world, Romans 1.20. We see by the
perspectives of Ordinances, and must so do till the day of judgment, Ephesians.
4.11, etc. We cannot see so clearly here, as we shall in heaven.

1. Use. Be not content with that measure of knowledge ye have, but labor
still for more. As men in trading finding the world come on them give not over,
but go on to get more riches. Youth must learn, middle age increase learning,
old age attain to wise counsels. Bodies grow old, Souls do not. Solon was wont
to say, (...): I grow old always learning many things. Platon. Dialog. de
Philosophia, and de Fortitud. and de Repub. l. 7. and in Cicer. de Senect.
Marcus Antoninus the Emperor went often to the house of Sextius the
Philosopher, saying, (...): It is good even for an old man to learn. Salvius
Julianus a most famous Lawyer was wont to say, Ets^ alterum pedem in sepulchro
haberem, adhuc addiscere vellem: Although I had one foot in the grave, yet I
would learn still. Pandect. l. 4. Nulla dies fine linea, said Apelles: No day
without a line. And Augustine acknowledges himself both a Writer, and a
Learner. Ego ex eorum numero me esse profiteor, qui scribunt proficiendo, and
scribendo proficiunt: I profess my self to be of the number of them who write
by profiting, and profit by writing. August. Epist. 7. Sapiens quamdiu vivit,
tamdiu addit: A wise man adds as long as he lives. Ambrose.

Use 2. It shows us what little hope we have of children and young men, that
think they know enough already, when old men and wise men may learn. Multi
potuissent ad sapientiam pervenire, nisi se putassent jam pervenisse: Many
might have proved learned men, but that they thought they were so already.
Senec. de Tranq. c. 1. (...), Opinion is the let of profiting. Diogenes
Laertius l. 3. de Bionis vita. Ego senex a juvene, and Episcopus tot annorum a
collega nec dum anniculo paratus sum doceri. August. apud Gratian. c. 24. q. 3.
I an old man, and a Bishop of so many years standing, am ready to be taught by
a young man, and a Colleague scarce of one years standing.

2. Doct. Much knowledge comes in at the ear. We have heard him our selves, and
know that this is indeed the Christ, Joh. 4.42. How shall they believe in him,
of whom they have not heard? Romans 10.14. Hearing and Seeing are by Aristotle
called the learned senses, because by these doors learning enters into the
soul. Yea, and life also. Hear, and your soul shall live, Isa. 55.3. David
Chytreus, when he lay a dying, lift up himself to hear the discourses of his
friends that sat by him; and said, that he should die with better cheer, if he
might die learning something. Unto you that hear shall more be given, Mar.
4.24. The ears are the Conduit-pipes of wisdom to convey it to us. Argento,
auroque non fiunt homines meliores, sed ditiores virtute ex sapientum dictis:
Men are not made better by gold, and silver, but richer in virtue by wise men's
sayings. Socrates apud Xenoph. l. 4. The Heathen man Cicero could say, Cujus
aures clausae sunt veritati, hujus salus desperanda est: He whose ears are shut
against the truth, there is little hope of his safety. A man may learn that
from another in an hour, which the other has been studying many hours, and it
may be himself could not find it out in many days. Therefore Christ bids not
his Disciples read, or tells them only where the Prophets speak of him, but
expounds those places to them, Luke 24.27. So does Philip to the Eunuch, Act.
8.35. This is the very end of preaching, and conference, that men might be
taught by the ear.

1. Use. Bless God for your ears. It is a great question, which is the greater
loss of Seeing or Hearing. I suppose of Hearing, for a man that wants it,
cannot reap any good by Sermons, Conferences, Discourses, nor converse
comfortably with others, nor have others to read to him. But a man may have all
these benefits, that wants his fight, and may have others to read to him also.
A blind man has all these helps. A deaf man has only Gods works to see, and
good books to read to help him to knowledge and comfort. The former may be
helped by others, the latter must do all out of her own head.

2. Use. Content not your selves with studying the Scriptures, but
acknowledging the weakness of your brain, learn of others also, even of men
that are meaner then your selves, whose pains or trials may acquaint them with
some particulars that ye need, yet know not. Semper mos est sapientum, ut
dictis majorum auscultent, aliquan do minorum: It is always the custom of
wise men to hearken to the sayings of their betters, sometimes of their
inferior. Beda in text. Not only the Queen of Sheba could learn of Solomon,
Paul of Gamaliel, and Nicodemus of Christ, but also Moses of Jethro.

3. Doct. The Scripture brings in increase of knowledge. Aquila and Priscilla
expounded unto Apollos the way of God more perfectly, Act. 18.26. Give thy self
wholly to them, that thy profiting may appear to all, 1 Timothy 4.15.

Reason, 1. Because it is the highest Book in the world. A Book of Gods own
making, who is most wise. When thou have learned all thou can out of men's
Books, thou may learn more out of Gods.

2. All heavenly wisdom in other books comes from thence, as water in rivers
from the fountain. Use. It taxes those that find more delight in reading other
good books, then the Scripture it self. It shows a double weakness, one in
judgment, the other in affection. Rivers are profitable, but fountains more.

4. Doct. Scripture learning is the best learning. Paul counted all things
loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ, Phil. 3.8. He buried his
other learning in his preaching. I determined not to know any thing among you,
save Jesus Christ and him crucified, 1 Cor. 2.2.

Reason, 1. It is the most profound knowledge. Above low Geometry, above high
Astronomy. Above Philosophy, for it reaches above all creatures, and aspires to
the knowledge of God.

2. It is most profitable. Other Arts show how to live here for a while, this
how to live in heaven for ever, through Christ. Use. It reproves our curious
spirits, who count Scripture learning nothing worth. Rhetoric and Politics
are great with them. Not many so wise are saved, 1 Cor. 1.20. What profit in
wisdom that will not keep from eternal misery?

5. Doct. Natural parts well used help much in Religion. Paul's learning was a
great help to him, and Solomon's high reach.

Reason, 1. They may learn the things of God more easily, which others hammer
long about, as dull ones in Schools.

2. They may get more in less time. Such a trade men generally look upon as
will make men speedily rich. Use. If your children be pregnant, put enough into
them. I remember I have seen a grave Doctor and a good Minister in this Nation,
much pleased with Nurses that would talk to the children, using this
expression, It puts much spirit and livelynesse into them, which the parents
may afterward turn to good. Men can be content to fill Houses, Tables, Barns,
Treasuries, Why not Children? Much ill may be kept out, much good put in, if
ready ones be instructed betimes, and constantly.

6. Doct. It is a wonder what may be attained by industry, and Gods blessing
upon it. See the great success of Paul's preaching at Ephesus. Curious Books
burnt, to the value of fifty thousand pieces of silver: So mightily grew the
Word of God, and prevailed, Act. 19.19, 20. The Churches were multiplied when
the storm of persecution was blown over, Act. 9.31. Ministers preaching much,
and peoples hearing, increased the graces, and number of Saints. As in worldly
things, men grow rich by Husbandry, or Merchandise. Use. It reproves the
sluggishnesse of Christians, who think a little knowledge and grace enough.
Such may justly fear, their grace is not true. Pictures are idle, and grow not,
living creatures feed, and grow.

7. Doct. Much difference between a wise man's course, and a fools. The one
orders his affairs well, the other carelessly. Their courses are often opposed
in Scripture. The wise in heart will receive commandments, but a prating fool
shall fall, Prove. 10.8. The way of a fool is right in his own eyes, but he
that hearkeneth unto counsel, is wise. A fools wrath is presently known, but a
prudent man covers shame, Prove. 12.15, 16. Every prudent man deals with
knowledge, but a fool lays open his folly, Pr. 15.16. The simple believes
every word, but the prudent man looks well to his going. A wise man fears,
and departs from evil, but the fool rages, and is confident, Prove. 14.15,
16.

Reason. Because they work from different principles. A wise man follows the
dictates of reason, a fool of will and affections. Use. Choose the wise man's
course, which is far the better. He steers the ship of his life among all the
waves of worldly troubles, and floods of worldly passions, to the heaven of
happiness. The World is like a Sea, up and down, rough and calm. So is man's
heart and soul. Basil. in princip. Proverb. A wise man like a skillful Pilot
looks on the Sun by day, and stars by night, his eyes are still toward heaven.
So he rids himself out of most intricate affairs, as Solomon did by wise
discerning the right Mother, 1 King. 3. And others oftentimes, as the Pilot
guides the ship safe to shore, when the rest sleep. Labor then for these wise
counsels.

Verse. 6. To understand a Proverb, and the interpretation; the words of the
wise, and their dark sayings.
The gain or increase of wise men in reading these Proverbs, was set out, verse.
5. The profit that comes by it, is set out here. It is sufficient for simple
ones to learn so much subtilty out of the plainest of these Proverbs, whereby
they may keep themselves from being deceived; but wise men will learn to
understand the darkest of them, whereby they may get much more knowledge. For
the words.

To understand. See on verse. 2. Not to read a similitude carelessly or
cursorily, but observing what is meant by it. Some read it, To make to
understand, or teach; and the word will bear it, and it suites well with what
went before. The man was wise before, and as he may get more wisdom to direct
his own ways, verse. 5. so also to teach others; in this verse. So Eccl. 12.9,
10.

A Proverb. See on verse. 1. Any Proverbial sentence, though difficult and
obscure to others. He that understands this Book, by reading it will be able to
understand other Proverbs propounded by others, and to propound some himself.

And the interpretation. How do the understanding of a Proverb, and the
interpretation ^^^er? He that understands it, can interpret it. Answ. The first
may be meant of understanding the words, or literal sense. The second of the
mystical. Or, And may be taken for Even, and so the latter be an exposition of
the former. To understand a Proverb; that is, to know the interpretation of it.
So to understand a dream is to be able to interpret it, Genesis 41.15. So And is
used, Gods wrath slew the fattest of them, and (that is, even) smote down the
chosen men of Israel, Psalm. 78.31. As the choice of the flock are the fattest
cattle.

The interpretation, (...). So (...), an Interpreter. One that can tell the
mind of God, Job 33.23. So here, to interpret a similitude, and show what is
included, more then appears at first fight. Not only to understand easy
Proverbs, but to know the meaning of hard ones. But especially to understand
the hardest of these Proverbs by the easiest, yet it may be understood of other
Proverbs also. To understand the sense of mysteries or eloquent speeches, such
as Ambassadors use; for so the word is translated, 2 Chr. 32.31. or such as
Scoffers use; for so the word is used for scorning, Job 16.20. Or it may be
read, And the sweetness thereof; for men find much sweetness in Proverbs,
when they know the meaning of them. Otherwise they are more harsh then other
sentences. From (...), to be sweet. Whence the learned Rivet derives (...) and
mel honey. See Trap.

The words, (...). 1. signifies a word. The word of the Lord, Hos. 1.1.

2. A thing; for that expresses a man's meaning when it is done. It came to
pass after these things, 1 King. 17.17. Here it is used in the first sense. He
speaks not of their actions, but sayings. Neither does it signify single
words, but words knit together in sentences. So the Ten commandments are
called Ten words in the Original, Exodus 34.28. For several words without
respect to others, do little good.

Of the wise. Of other wise men. Not only ordinary Proverbs that are in all
men's mouths, but the learnedest sentences that come from wisest men, and are
approved for the authority of them, that spoke them; like Achitophels counsels
esteemed as oracles, 2 Samuel 16.23.

And their dark sayings. Questions that can hardly be answered. Such as the
Queen of Sheba put to Solomon, 1 King. 10.1. Or, hard expressions, which often
contain high mysteries in them, not easy to be perceived, till they be
expounded, as Sampson's Riddle, and Sphinx hers to Oedipus of the creature that
went first on four legs, then on two legs, lastly on three legs. And such are
some speeches above the common reach. Such also were the Egyptian
Hieroglyphics, as a staff with an eye on it, to set out Gods providence,
looking over all the world, and ruling it. This is well added, to prevent an
objection. For it might be said, It needs no great skill to understand wise
men's sayings, for some of them are plain. Answ. But (says the Wise man) by
reading these Proverbs ye shall understand the hardest of them also.

Figures none, except a figure of the part for the whole. A Proverb, that is,
all kind of Proverbs, even the darkest and hardest. As an Horse, for any
Horse, Psalm. 33.17.

Note. 1. The act. To understand.

2. The fourfold object: 1. A Proverb. 2. The Interpretation. 3. The words of
the wise.


4. Their dark sayings. He shall gather from hence ability to understand not
ordinary sayings only, but the most difficult that can come from wise men.

1. Doct. That measure of knowledge is not sufficient for a man of greater
capacity, that may suffice one of meaner. Solomon that had so much knowledge,
yet thought he needed more, Eccl. 1.16, 17. Paul knew Christ well, yet desires
to know more of him, Phil. 3.8, 10.

Reason, 1. nI regard of God, an account of talents is to be given to him.
Greater account of greater talents, Matt. 5.15, 20.

2. In regard of himself. A great capacity carries a great defire of filling
it, else it were in vain.

3. In regard of others. There is a great expectation from men of great parts.
The eyes of all them that were in the Synagogue were fastened on Christ, Luke
4.20.

4. In regard of the things, which being known in part, allure us to know more.
Ignoti nulla cupido: No desire of what is not known. One profitable voyage eggs
the Merchant to another.

1. Use. It reproves such as have wit to know much, but use it not. Remain
Dunses, that might be Doctors, Heb. 5.12. More things are to be known, and what
we know, may be better known. Both afford more delight. Maxima pors eorum quae
scimus, est minima pars eorum quae ignoramus. Aug. The greatest part of the
things we know, is the least part of the things we know not.

2. Use. Put your capacity upon the tenters. The Clothier gets by it, and makes
more of the same cloth. Else ye shall not enter into your Masters joy, Matt.
25.21. but be shut out with the foolish Virgins, Mat. 25.10.

3. Use. Ye that be Ministers must stretch for it in point of knowledge. If ye
have not greater capacity then ordinary men, why take ye that calling? If ye
have, use it. It is enough for others to be full, ye must run over. It is
enough for others to save themselves from a crooked generation, Act. 2.40. Ye
must save your selves and others, 1 Timothy 4.16. That knowledge will not serve a
Lawyer, or Physician, that may serve a private Gentleman for his own state or
health. He enguges for no more. And I hope I shall need to say no more in this
Argument.

2. Doct. Reading Scripture without understanding, does a man no good. This is
the drift of Philip's Question to the Eunuch, Understand thou what thou
read? Act. 8.30. Else it will do thee no good. The Jews could not profit by
reading the Law, because the veil was not taken off their hearts, 2 Cor. 3.1, 4.

Reason 1. Because the words of Scripture are no charm, which works, whether
men understand it, or not.

2. Doing is required, which is more then understanding. If ye know these
things, happy are ye if ye do them, Joh. 13.17.

Use 1. It condemns the practice of the Papists, who read the Scriptures in a
strange language. They are sure beforehand the people cannot understand them,
nor get any good by them.

2. It condemns the negligence of some, who think they do enough, if they cause
their children to read sometimes a Chapter, but take no care that either they
or their children understand it. If they should set bread before them, and not
let it be broken, or cut, they might starve.

3. Doct. A man may get knowledge enough out of Scripture to teach others. The
32 Psalm was written to teach others, as appears by the title, David's Maschil,
or Instructor. Hence comes that solemn charge for parents to instruct their
children diligently at home and abroad, at up-fitting and down-lying, Deuteronomy.
6.7. See the like charge, Psalm. 78.5, 6. The Scripture is a fountain of
knowledge, we may drink our selves, and bottle up for others. A Sea wherein are
fishes innumerable to feed us and others, Psalm. 104.25. And ships, that
traffic for all men's good, verse. 26. there. A rich Storehouse of all
knowledge, and a wealthy Treasury. Joseph's Storehouses and Solomon's
Treasuries had enough for multitudes.

1. Use. Let us bless God for the store that is in his Word. Who would not
praise him for plenty of money and provisions, that might serve for him, his,
and many more; or for a Fountain or Mine in his garden?

2. Use. Let us draw daily out of this Treasury. Though there be store of
knowledge, yet few are so wise to draw enough for themselves. Most think a
little enough. But if thou have enough for thy self, draw for others. Men give
not over their Trades when they have got enough to keep themselves, and theirs,
but desire to have to give, Ephesians. 4.28.

4. Doct. Hardest things in Scripture may be understood by labor. Many things
are interpreted ready to our hands. An Angel interprets the Vision to Daniel,
Dan. 7.16. So are the Stars and Candlesticks, Revel. 1.20. Isaiah's prophecy
of Christ, Act. 8.35. The sum of the Gospel, Act. 10.36.

Reason, 1. Because it is Gods aim in writing it, that it should be understood.
For he writ it for the people. I have written to him the great things of my
Law, Hos. 8.12. Not to the Priests, but to the people of Ephraim. And if they
to whom it is written cannot by labor and pains understand it, the pen of the
writer was in vain, Jer. 8.8.

2. God has left means in his Word to understand the hardest places, as
searching the original, coherence, parallel places; and plainer ones to give
light to the obscurer.

Use, 1. It incourageth us to seek to understand the hardest things in
Scripture, and not to be content with the easiest. So do all good Scholars in
their Arts, and all that intend to thrive in their Trades.

2. It shows what a shame it is, if we understand not plain places, that might
by labor understand difficult ones. Sure we shall never thrive by our Trade of
Christianity.

5. Doct. Wise men's words carry great weight with them. The words of the wise
are as goads, and as nails fastened by the Masters of the Assemblies, Eccl.
12.11. Bow down thine ear, and hear the words of the wise, Prove. 22.17. The
lips of the wise disperse knowledge, Prove. 15.7. The ground is, because every
thing works by an internal principle, whether it be Natural, Artificial, or
Reasonable. A fool cannot speak wisely, unless overruled he speak not of
himself, Joh. 11.51. A wise man will not speak foolishly unless unadvised.
Use. It directs us how to choose our society. Choose those by whom ye may get
most. Worldly men do so in the Exchange, Markets, and other times. He that
walks with wise men shall be wise, Prove. 13.20.

6. Doct. There are difficulties to be found in Scripture that need exposition.
In Paul's Epistles there are some things hard to be understood, 2 Pet. 3.16.
Not only high matters and expressions, but also Parables, wherein is one thing
spoken, another thing meant. And that to exercise men's wits. They had need of
good heads to find out the meaning. The Disciples ask and are showed the
meaning of the Parable of the Tares, Matthew. 13.36, 37. Wise men speak darkly
sometimes, ut occultentur sententiae eorum desidiosis, aperiantur studiosis;
that their sentences may be hidden from sluggards, and opened to studious
persons. All Gods oracles are dark to natural men. As the Resurrection to the
Sadduces. Ye err not knowing the Scriptures, nor the power of God, Ma^^ 22.29.
Regeneration to Nicodemus. How can a man be born when he is old? Can he enter
the second time into his Mothers womb, and be born? Joh. 3.4. Living water to
the woman of Samaria. Sir, thou have nothing to draw with, and the well is
deep; from whence then have thou that living water? Joh. 4.11. The Gospel is
hid to them that perish, 2 Cor. 4.3. And in part unto godly men too. Now we see
through a glass darkly, now I know in part, 1 Cor. 13.12. The perfect
knowledge of them is reserved for them, till they come to the heavenly
University. But yet some things are harder then the rest. Use. Think no time
nor pains too much to understand Scripture. A Merchant spends store of both to
get pearls.

Verse. 7. The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge; but fools despise
wisdom and instruction.
In the former verses he had showed the uses, ends, and benefits of this Book,
and how much good the Reader may get by it, and commended it from the
excellency of the Work, and eminency of the Writer, to allure us to read it.
Now in this verse. he sets before us what this wisdom is, and who are capable
of it, and begins the first Proverb with the fear of God. After the
inscription, Solomon's counsel to his Son:

1. In general, in this verse.

2. In particular directions, to the end of the third Chapter.

For the words. The fear of the Lord. Fear of God [(...)] is used three ways
in Scripture.

1. For a fear of sinning against God, for fear of plagues here, and in hell.
This arises out of the consideration of Gods infinite power. It is called
servile or slavish fear, for slaves would offend, if they durst. So would
wicked men sin against God with an high hand, if his judgments did not scare
them. Thus the Israelites feared God, lest he should plague them, as he had
done the Egyptians, Exodus 14.31. And by this fear some of the Egyptians saved
their cattle in their houses, when other men's perished in the fields, Exodus
9.20.

2. For a fear (...) reverence, whereby a man sets up God in the highest place
of his heart, being willing to please him out of love, and more unwilling to
offend him then any other. This is called Fil^^l fear, and proceeds out of our
love to God, as childrens reverence to their Father does. So the word is used,
Mal. 3.16. Then they that feared the Lord, spoke often one to another.

3. For the true Religion, called by the Greeks (...) and (...), and by the
Latins, pietas; in English, piety or godliness. For it is a prime part of
Gods worship, that he be feared. It keeps the affections, thoughts, words, and
deeds in order. One of the Priests of Samaria, taught the people how they
should fear the Lord, 2 King. 17.28. that is, how they should worship him. That
which is called their fear toward God, Isa. 29.13. is styled their worshipping
of him, Mat. 15.9. In this place it is taken in the second sense.

(...), the Lord. That has his being of himself, gives being to all others,
and to his promises. It comes from (...), To be; and has a touch of all the
Tenses. Je of the Future, Ho of the Present, and Vah of the Preter-tense. He
that is, was, and is to come, Prove. 1.8. The eternal God.

(...), the beginning. It signifies,

1. A beginning in time, as the foundation is the beginning of the house. The
beginning of his Kingdom was Babel, Genesis 10 10. And therefore it signifies the
first fruits, because first gathered, though not always best. The first of the
first fruits of thy Land, thou shall bring into the House of the Lord thy God,
Exodus 13.19.

2. First in dignity. The chief of the things which should have been utterly
destroyed, 1 Samuel 15.21. Here it is taken in the second sense. The true fear of
God is the chief point of wisdom.

(...), of knowledge. See on verse. 2. Some interpret the passage thus: The
servile fear of Gods judgments makes men first look after knowledge, that
never cared for it before, as the needle makes way for the thread. August.
Others thus: The chief part of knowledge is that filial and aweful fear of God,
that makes men careful to please him, which tempers the servile fear with
love, as wine and water do well together for weak brains: Vinum nisi aqua
mixtum non bibit debile caput: A weak head drinks not wine unless mixed with
water. Beda. But I take Solomon's meaning to be, that all heathen wisdom is
but folly; but the choycest wisdom is the knowledge of the true worship of
God, that so he might make man to study the Scriptures where it is to be found.
All their former knowledge was but folly to this. The true Religion is better
then all of it.

But. This word is not in the Original, but added, to show an opposition to the
former part of the verse. which being not in direct words, must be supplied thus
out of each part. The chiefest wisdom is the knowledge of the true worship of
God, and therefore good men love it; but fools do not account it so, and
therefore despise it.

(...), Fools. Object. You set out this wisdom highly, but no body regards it.
Answ. None but fools despise it, who have no wit to judge aright of it. No
matter what account they make of it, unless they were wiser. Hence comes our
English word Evil. Fools here are evil men, and irreligious, as throughout
the Proverbs, and Psalm. 14.1. The fool has said in his heart, There is no God,
they are corrupt, etc. Either Idolaters that profess a false Religion, or such
as in show only profess the true. Such as want the chief part of wisdom,
though otherwise politic enough. He spoke in the singular number, verse. 5. A
wise man, etc. Here in the plural, Fools despise wisdom, etc. There are more
fools then wise men in the world. Men are naturally foolish.

Despise. The word (...) signifies,

1. To set light by a thing, or contemn it, or make little account of it. The
daughters of Zion have despised thee, 2 Ki. 19.21.

2. To scorn or highly disdain. Haman thought scorn to lay hands on Mordecai
alone, Est. 3.6. Here it is taken in the first sense, for all irreligious men
are not scorners, Psalm. 1.1. but all despise true wisdom.

Wisdom. See on verse. 2. It is excellent, yet fools make no account of it.

And instruction. See on v. 2. They neither know the excellency of wisdom, nor
the way of true safety in the true Religion, nor will learn it of others.

Figures none, unless a Metaphor in Fools taken for irreligious men, that want
the best wisdom.

In the words note, 1. A commendation of Religion. 2. A description of fools.
In the first note, 1. The subject, The fear of the Lord. 2. The adjunct, the
beginning of wisdom. In the second note, 1. The agent, Fools. 2. The effect,
Despise. 3. A double object, wisdom and instruction.



The former proposition is famous, as being often used in Scripture, chapter 9.10.
Job 28.28. Psalm. 111.10.

1. Doct. Religiousnesse, or a reverent fear of God is the best wisdom. Keep
therefore, and do them, for this is your wisdom, and your understanding in the
sight of the Nations, which shall hear all these statutes, and say, Surely this
great Nation is a wise and understanding people, Deuteronomy. 4.6. This is the wisdom
from above, Jam. 3.17.

Reason 1. Because it brings a man to acquaintance with God. Others acquaint us
with trees, beasts, men, this with God. We are naturally strangers from God,
and have most need of acquaintance with him. False Religions fet up creatures
openly, and worship them. They changed the glory of the incorruptible God into
an image made like to corruptible man, and to birds, and four-footed beasts,
and creeping things, Romans 1.23. Natural men not truly religious, though bred
in the Church, make their own will, or honors, or wealth, or pleasures, God.
Men truly religious know God aright.

2. It teaches us how to converse with God rightly by true worship and
obedience. How can a man bred among clowns, know how to converse with a King at
Court?

3. How to come to live with God for ever, which no Art else can teach. A trade
is most esteemed that is most gainful.

Use 1. To show us the vanity of all false Religions, in which men cannot
reverence the true God in their hearts aright, because they conceive amiss of
him. In vain they worship, and worship they know not what. A great Politician
was wont to say, The best policy is to be an honest man. So the best wisdom is
to be truly religious, and to fear God. Heathen Sages, as Seneca and Socrates,
were wise in their generations, and had many excellent gifts, but they missed
of the main; like Alchymists, who miss of their end, yet find many excellent
things by the way. These Merchants found goodly pearls, but the pearl of price
they failed of, Matthew. 13.45, 46.

2. Use. To acquaint our selves with the Scriptures, where this true wisdom,
how to fear and reverence God rightly, is taught, and no where else. We are
sure those were writ by no private spirit, but came from the holy Ghost, 2 Pet.
1.21. Private spirits and inward principles may be cross one to another, and
who shall judge then what is right? The Scripture. Hereby we know the spirit of
truth, and the spirit of error, 1 John 4.2. If they quote Scripture, they
confess the Scripture to be above them, as Marnixius justly derides the
Papists, who would prove by Scripture that the Church was above the Scripture.
If not, then it is so, because they say so; and all the world will laugh at
such a proof.

3. Use. To persuade Magistrates to set up, and to uphold true Religion, and to
encourage such as truly fear God, by continuing Ministers, and discouraging
such as oppose it. Such as quote Gallio's speech to shut Magistrates out of all
matters of Religion, may as well quote Rabshake's speech for a warrant to fight
against Gods people. Am I now come up without the Lord against this place to
destroy it? The Lord said to me, Go up against this Land to destroy it, 2 King.
18.25. For that is recorded in Scripture also. It is a poor proof that comes
out of the mouth of an Heathen man.

4. Use. Let all that would be truly wise, get the fear of God into their
hearts.

2. Doct. All being is from God. Therefore is he called Jehovah, hecause he
gives being to all creatures. Who else made the world, and all creatures at
first? Genesis 1. Of him, and through him, and to him are all things, Romans 11.36.
In him we live, and move, and have our being, Act. 17.28.

Reason 1. Because nothing can make it self, being must be before Working.

2. None had a being before the world but God, therefore he must give being to
all.

3. There was nothing to make any thing of, and no creature can work without
matter. It argues an infinite power.

4. No creature can put life into any thing. Therefore all living things must
be from God, and what can dead things do?

Use 1. To praise God for our being, as long as it lasts here, and in heaven,
where our being will last to eternity. While I live, I will praise the Lord
(says the Psalmist) I will fing praises unto my God, while I have any being,
Psalm. 146.2. All creatures attribute blessing, honor, glory, and power to God
for ever and ever, Rev. 5.13.

2. To use all our gifts and parts in Gods service; for as we have those parts
from him, so likewise our very being, without which we could have had no parts,
nor comfort.

3. Doct. Things of greatest worth should be of greatest account with us. Covet
earnestly the best gifts, 1 Cor. 12.31. Above all these things put on charity,
which is the bond of perfectness, Col. 3.14. These things speak and exhort,
Tit. 2.15. For the affections should ever follow the judgment well informed.
Use. It blames those that make most account of meanest things, and lose gold
for counters, eternal life for transitory pleasures. Such are worse then
beasts, who will not neglect grass and water for any thing.

4. D. Knowledge is a matter of great excellency. It is part of Gods image in
man. Col. 3.10. Husbands must dwell with their Wives according to knowledge, 1
Pet. 3.7. As light is in the world. What is all the world worth without the
Sun? What were all Aegypts pleasures and treasures worth in the three days
darkness? So is knowledge the comfort of the soul.

Use. Labor for it more then for riches. Spiritual things are more worth then
temporal.

5. Doct. Irreligious persons are in Gods account the fools of the world. For
they want Gods fear, as natural fools want wisdom. The foolish shall not
stand in thy sight, thou hate all workers of iniquity, Psalm. 5.5. And Gods
enemies are called foolish people, Psalm. 74.18.

Reason 1. Because they have not wisdom enough to escape hell.

2. Nor to attain to eternal happiness.

Use 1. Envy not the policies and sleights of great men, and Statesmen, that
have no religion in them. The world may chronicle them for wise men, but they
are fools in Gods book. Tamar tells Amnon, though a Kings Son, Thou shall be as
one of the fools in Israel, 2 Samuel 13.13.

2. Be not proud of wit, or learning. If you have no true Religion, your wit is
good for nothing but to carry you to hell. When one commended highly Julian the
Cardinal to Sigismund, he answered, Tamen Romanus est, Yet he is a Roman. So
may ye say of the greatest irreligious Politician, Yet he is a fool. Lo, they
have rejected the Word of the Lord, and what wisdom is in them? Jer. 8.9.

6. Doct. None despise heavenly wisdom, but such as know not the value of is.
Such as know not what they do, Luke 23.34. Had they known it, they would not
have crucified the Lord of glory, 1 Cor. 2.8. The preaching of the Cross is
foolishness to men, yet Gods wisdom most seen in it, 1 Cor. 1.18, 23. Because
the excellency of it is so great, that it would allure men to look after it,
had they spiritual eyes to see it. It is so in other Arts also. Scientia non
habet inimicum, nisi ignorantem. Knowledge has no enemy but an ignorant man.
Who is, Asinus ad lyram, as unfit for learning, as an Ass to play upon an
harp. Use. Think never the worse of heavenly wisdom, because so many slight
it. The fault is not in the thing, but in their shallow brains. Who would
slight a jewel, because a fool presers his babble before it? Such are carnal
men, like Esau. A Mess of pottage is better then Canaan to them. Such fools
were the rich man, Luke 12. Nabal, 1 Samuel 25.

7. D. Wisdom it self, though excellent, is despised by many. Fools hate
knowledge, verse. 22, 29. And no marvel, for both God and Christ are despised
by such. He that despises you, despises me; and he that despises me,
despises him that sent me, Luke 10.16. His wisdom is counted folly, 1 Cor.
1.25. Use. Let not us think much to be despised; Wisdom, Christ, and God are
despised, who have deserved much better of the Sons of men.

8. Doct. They that slight the means of knowledge, slight knowledge it self.
See v. 22, 23, 29, 30. We account so in outward things. We ask sick men
refusing physic, if they make no account of their lives? We tell idle persons,
they care not for riches. Use. It lies sore on the consciences of many, who
would be loath to think, they should answer for neglect of knowledge at the day
of Judgment, yet they must. Else why sit ye at home, and lose so many good
Sermons? your absence is a real sleighting of wisdom.

Verse. 8. My Son, hear the instruction of thy Father, and forsake not the Law
of thy Mother.
In the rest of this Chapter, and the two Chapters following, Solomon's words,
consisting of many exhortations and promises, do not well admit of any
division, but by the Chapters. In the rest of this Chapter, there is,

1. A commendation of domestical instruction, v. 8, 9.

2. A disswasion from hearkening to bad counsels, from v. 10, to v. 20.

3. Wisdoms exhortation to men, to follow her directions, from verse. 20. to
the end of the Chapter. In the first ye have,

1. An exhortation in this verse.

2. A promise in the next. For the exhortation, and first for the words.

My Son. See on v. 1. Hear. See on v. 5. Here it is taken for giving ear and
heart to parents instructions, believing or obeying them, according to the
nature of them. Instruction. The means to get learning. See on verse. 2.

Of thy Father, (...), a Father, from (...), to wish well; for parents
naturally bear good will to their children. Amor descendit, non ascendit. Love
descends, but ascends not. They are part of them, and their care is great for
them. The word is not always used for natural Parents, but sometimes for
Mosters, or elder persons, or men in authority, as Children for inferiors in
the fist Commandment, and elsewhere. Solomon was a Father, as a Ruler,
Teacher, natural Father. And it may be, that these Proverbs were written for
instruction to his own children, and so to be communicated by other parents to
their children, as King James writ his Basilicon Doron for his Son. Yet Solomon
chooses the name of a Father, rather then of a King or Master, to persuade
them to be the more willing to receive instruction from him, for Parents look
to their childrens good, when Masters and Kings, having not that natural band,
look to their own ends. Because Solomon took upon him principally to teach
young men, therefore he takes to him the name of a Father, showing withal that
he desires nothing more then their spiritual good.

And forsake not. Hearing and not forsaking, must be applied to the instruction
of both Parents, by the rule given in the last verse. For as a Child must not
refuse to hear his Father at first, so he must not be drawn away from the truth
or good learned by his Father afterward. And as he must not be drawn from his
Mothers counsels afterward, so he must not slight them at the first. Hearing
is to be given to the Father, because Children are more ready to hearken to
their Mothers, though the Fathers be for the most part best able to advise. And
not forsaking looks to the Mothers Law, because Children taken from the Mothers
care, and employed by the Father, are ready to slight her, and to forget what
she taught them in their childehood. (...) imports, not being drawn away by our
own corruption, or other men's persuasion from what we have learned of our
godly Mothers. Others read, pluck not up, but that comes of (...), and comes
short of the other, intending a man's own seduction by himself, and not so well
forbidding seduction by others also. Entisement is set down more plainly, verse.
10.

The Law. The teaching, (...), of (...), to shoot, or rain, or teach. Precepts
are dropped into young children, by pious Mothers by little and little, and as it
were sucked in with their milk, and fastened by often repeating. Such teaching
becomes Mothers and children. It is translated Law rather then teaching,
because it binds more, and children think themselves less bound to Mothers
then Fathers, because Mothers are more tender over them, and familiar with
them. Equals also may teach, but not command.

Of thy Mother. It is taken here for the natural Mother, for Solomon begins
with household instruction. Leave not the course of godliness wherein she bred
thee. Figures none.

Note 1. The Childs duty to his Father. 2. To his Mother.
In the first note, 1. The agent, My Son. 2. The act, hear. 3. The object, the
instruction. 4. The subject, of thy Father.


In the second note, 1. The act, and forsake not. 2. The object, the Law. 3.
The subject, of thy Mother.


He had begun with Religion and duty to God, verse. 7. next he requires duty to
Parents in this verse.

1. Doct. Next after the care of Religion, is the care of our duty to Parents.
Therefore God has placed the fifth Commandment in the beginning of the second
Table. Philo thinks it was written in the border of both Tables, Aben Ezra
places it in the first Table, but behind. Tindall conceives it was written in
the first Table, after the fourth Commandment; so that the first Table should
contain all duties to Superiors, God, and Magistrates, and Parents, etc. and
the second all duties to Equals. Diis and parentibus nunquam satis fit:
Aristotle. God and Parents cannot be sufficiently requited. The Heathen
punished injuries to God and Parents alike. Valor. l. 1. Qui dubitat, utrum
oporteat Deos revereri, aut parents, non indiget ratione, sed pari paena.
Aristot. Topic. l. 8. He that doubts whether God or Parents be to be
reverenced, needs not be confuted by reason, but by the same punishment. All
fatherhood is from God. Men are fathers of some, God of all in some sense or
other. Resisting them is in some sense resisting God, as resisting a Constable
is resisting the King or supreme Magistrate. Parents are chosen in the fist
Commandment to expresseall Superiors, rather then Magistrates or Ministers;
these are comprehended under Parents. The safety or ruin of Church and
Commonwealth depends upon them, for families are seminaries of both. Divine
right and natural, give Parents power over Children.

1. Use. To inform us of what great weight this duty is, both in the Text and
Decalogue set next after our duty to God.

2. To reprove disobedient Children. This sin is next to impiety against God,
and before sins committed against equals. Many have confessed at the Gallows,
that God justly brought them thither for disobedience to religious Parents. And
some have been troubled for their disobedience after their Parents death.

Object. Our Parents are testy.

Answ. Yet they must be born withal. Multa ex quo fuerunt commoda, ejus
incommoda aequum est far. Terent. We must bear with them by whom we get much.
Love thy Parent if he be kind, otherwise bear with him. Ames parentem, si
aequus est, aliter feras. Mimus. Servants must obey froward Masters, 1. Pet.
2.18. Much more Children froward Parents.

2. Doct. The beginning of Christian knowledge and piety arises for the most
part from domestical instruction. Hence Solomon had his. His Father taught
him, chapter 4.4. and his Mother, chapter 31. Timothy's says came by derivation from
his Grandmother, and Mother, 2 Timothy 1.5. He knew the holy Scriptures from a
child, 2 Timothy 3.15.

Reason 1. There are prayers and good examples used in godly families, which
are means of knowledge and grace, as well as the public Ordinances. Men that
fare well at home are fat, as well as they that feast abroad.

2. There be pull-backs from evil by discipline and correction, which bridle
our corrupt nature from evil, as godly exercises are spurs to good.

1. Use. It teaches us to live in good families, where godliness prevails.
Yea, and Children should be willing to leave irreligious Parents houses, to
live with godly Masters.

2. Parents should choose good Masters for their Children, and not altogether
look at trading. Place them where they may learn how to live in heaven as well
as here.

3. Bless God if he give you godly Parents or Masters. It is a great mercy.
Men do so for rich Masters, where they may live plentifully; or skillful ones,
where they may learn how to get an estate; how much more for such as teach us
true wisdom?

4. Make hay while the Sun shines. Make a good use of domestical instructions.
God has not given you good Parents or Masters for nothing. Ye may learn to be
wise your selves, and teach yours to be so, when God honors you with families
of your own.

3. Doct. Parents are bound to instruct their Children in piety. To bring them
up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord, Ephesians. 6.4. As Captains train up
their raw Soldiers, and exercise them in Arms. Train up a child in the way he
should go, Prove. 22.6. So did Abraham breed his Children, Genesis 18.19. And
David, Prove. 4.3, 4. Teach them thy Sons, and thy Sons Sons, Deuteronomy. 4.9. The
like is required, Deuteronomy. 6.7. and 11.19.

Reason 1. Because men are much drawn by authority to give credit to what is
spoken. Men look more, quis dicat, who says; then quid dicatur, what is said.
Children will believe their Parents sooner then Brethren or Servants, because
they exercise the first authority over them. Afterward, when they grow wiser,
they will hear reason from an equal or inferior. Hence it is that Children and
ignorant persons follow authority, but wise men follow reason. The Samaritans
believe at first for the Woman's words, afterward for Christ's own sayings,
Joh. 4.39, ^2. So Augustine at first believed the Scriptures for the Churches
authority, afterward for their own. Divine authority is above all Reason. But
among humane authority Parents is the first.

2. It is most prevalent, because Children see their Parents love from their
youth. Parents therefore must not lose that opportunity of improving their
Childrens good opinion of them.

3. Young years are fittest for instruction, and those they spend under their
Parents. They are then easy to be ruled, and of quick capacity, not taken off
with vices and cares. They are like young trees, easy to bow.

4. The good taught then may abide with them all their life long. Quo semel est
imbuta recens, servabit odorem, Testa diu, Horat. The vessel keeps the savor
of what it was first seasoned withal, a long time. When he is old he will not
depart from what he learned young, Prove. 22.6. It is harder to infuse truth or
piety, when error or fin has taken possession first. It is a double labor,
first to empty the glass of filthy liquor, then to put in clean: first to pluck
up the weeds, then to sow good seed.

Use 1. Woe be to those Parents that neither teach their Children themselves,
nor yet put them to school; only they labor to get money for them, which their
ungrateful heirs spend to their own destruction in finfull ways. Deus
disciplinam parents jubet thesaurizare filiis, non pecuniam: Perennia
praecepit, non peritura confer. Salv. contra avarit. God bids parents to
treasure up instruction for their children, not money: He commanded to bestow
on them lasting things, not perishing.

2. It reproves such as marry before they know the grounds of Religion, and so
may have children before they know how to breed them. I have heard, that Horn
Bishop of Winchester, in Qu. Elizabeth's days, upheld a Minister that was
complained of for refusing to marry a young Gentlewoman for ignorance of the
grounds of Religion, saying that he would have suspended him if he had done it,
though he had a license from his own Officers; adding withal, What, should we
have families of Infidels? For how can they instruct their Children, that are
so ignorant of the first principles of Religion themselves?

3. It calls upon Parents to breed their Children well. How can they hearken to
their instruction, if they have it not? Themselves would condemn Parents that
should starve their childrens bodies; what are they then if they starve their
souls?

4. Doct. Children are bound to give credit to, and obey their Parents good
counsels. Come ye children, hearken unto me, Psalm. 34.11. The Children of Eli
hearkened not unto the voice of their Father, because (or therefore, as Ps.
116.10. with 2 Cor. 4.13) the Lord would slay them, 1 Samuel 2.25.

Reason 1. Because they are the first teachers ordinarily, and therefore our
ears should be open to them. The Parliament hears and rewards the first
Messengers of good news.

2. They are the fittest teachers, for they seek the good of their children out
of natural love. Provide for them while they live, give them an inheritance
when they die, desire their salvation. They will commend good things to their
children out of love, Luke 11.13. Whereas Masters may do it out of respect to
their own peculiar profit. They require them not to lie or steal it may be,
but let them be profane or irreligious.

3. Parents can more commodiously instruct them, being still at hand to observe
their courses, and to resolve their doubts at any time.

4. They have experience, and know what is good for their children, who know
not what is good for themselves; and whom should they hearken to rather, then
to their own Parents?

Object. Parents may be Idolaters, and perswaders to be Papists. It is the
Popish argument to be of their Fathers Religion.

Answ. If they be such as Solomon was, wise and godly, they will not persuade
us to Idolatry. If they be Idolaters, we must not hearken to them.

Object. Parents may be wicked, and give ill counsel.

Answ. Yet it may be they may give good counsel to their children sometimes.
Parents that have been bad in their youth, may give good counsel to their
children in their age, for their own quiet. Etiam pudicam vult meretrix filiam:
A whore would have a chaste daughter. And we are bidden to follow their
precepts, not their examples, nor counsels neither, if they be naught.

1. Use. It shows the greatness of the sin of Children, that will not be
taught nor ruled by godly Parents.

2. Let Children hearken to such willingly, that they may obtain the Rechabiles
blessing, Not to want a man of their posterity to stand before God for ever,
Jer. 35.19. Children can hearken to their Parents worldly counsels, and
remember them, when they are dead and gone. Much more account should they make
of their spiritual advices.

5. Doct. Children must never be drawn from their Parents good instructions.
They must not forsake them if they live to be old, Prove. 22.6. Abraham's
Children and household after him, must keep the way of the Lord taught by him,
Genesis 18.19.

Reason 1. Because Parents good instructions are a treasure, and men are very
careful of their treasures. Not only to get, but to keep them till old age,
against a time of need.

2. There is much danger of losing this treasure. Thine own corruptions,
Satan's temptations, bad counsels, examples, like thieves, seek to rob thee of
it.

Use 1. Take heed of seducers, and all that would mislead thee. Too many now
have forgot their pious education, both by errors, and looseness of life,
whose Parents would scarce own them, if they were alive.

2. Ye that are children, lay up your Parents godly counsels, not in your
brains only, but in your hearts. Ye may have need of them in age and death.

6. Doct. Mothers must take pains to teach their children piety. Else how
should they obey their Mother? chapter 30.17. So did Solomon's Mother, chapter 31.1.
Mothers of good and bad Kings are named in Kings and Chronicles, as having a
share in their childrens goodness or badnesse, by their education. Our first
days are spent for the most part under our Mothers care, while our Fathers are
busied in their calling, about matters of the Church or Commonwealth. She
therefore should take advantage thereof, to teach us goodness.

Use. It condemns many fond Mothers, that are careful to provide all things
needful for their children, save only good education and instruction. They
lose an opportunity of doing much good to their souls. Children are more ready
to hear Mothers then Fathers, because they converse more with them, and they
are less stubborn, then when they are bigger, and come to their Fathers care.
We say, they speak the Mother Tongue.

7. Doct. Children must not slight their Mothers counsels. If they do, their
eyes shall be picked out by ravens and eagles, Prove. 30.17. Solomon records his
Mothers instruction, Pro. 31.1. as well as his Fathers, chapter 4.4. The fifth
Commandment requires honor to Mothers, as well as to Fathers, Exodus 20.12. A
foolish man despises his Mother, Prove. 15.20.

Reason 1. Because Mothers bear great affection to their children, and
therefore ought to be heard.

2. They endure most pain in breeding and bearing them, and take most pains in
nursing and tending them, in tender years, when they are least able to help
themselves.

3. Instruction is attributed to the Father, which is accompanied with
correction; but a mild law, such as good Subjects live comfortably under, or
gentle teaching to the Mother. She teaches more mildely.

Use. To blame children that will hearken to their Fathers for fear of
correction, but account their Mothers instructions as words of weak and doting
women, because they cannot or will not correct them. Though they be not so wise
as men ordinarily, yet love will teach them to give good counsel; and women
sometimes are wiser and better then their husbands, who may be won by the
conversation of their wives, 1 Pet. 3.1. And many are beholding to their
Mothers for their best instructions, who as sometimes they are better, so
oftentimes have more leisure then their husbands.

8. Doct. Mothers instructions agreeable to Gods Word, should be as a Law to
children. The same words are repeated, Prove. 6.20. Forsake not the law of thy
Mother. Disobeyers of Mothers must be punished as Law-breakers. She may
instruct well in precepts of life, though it may be not so fully in matters of
says. Now Laws concerning life are needful also.

Use. Let good children look upon their Mothers instructions, as Laws not to be
broken all their life long.

Verse. 9. For they shall be an ornament of grace unto thy head, and chains
about thy neek.
The reason to persuade Children to obey their Parents, and to encourage them,
follows. And Solomon being to teach children, or simple ones like to children,
takes therefore his argument from Garlands and Chains, that make a fair show in
the eyes of such persons, as suiting to their capacity and affections, to whom
he speaks. They are delighted in them, and they please the vulgar much. Thus
the Spirit of God accommodates himself to Childrens temper. They love shining
things.

For the words.

For. The word carries not always a cause with it, but a reason or motive for
the most part, and often by way of promise. So it is used, chap. 23.17, 18.
Fear the Lord, for surely there is an end, or reward. For so the word sometimes
signifies, and the sense requires it there. Know thou the God of thy Father,
etc. for the Lord searches all hearts, 1 Chronicles. 28.9.

They. The instruction of thy Father, and law of thy Mother, verse. 8. Mothers
may help to prefer their children as well as Fathers.

Shall be. It is not in the Original, and therefore is written in lesser
letters, yet needfully added, for children must not look for such preferment or
respect while they are young, but when learned and of years. Harvest follows
Seedtime presently.

An ornament of grace. As, the note of similitude is wanting. They shall be as
an ornament of grace. See the like, Job 7.7. My life is wind; that is, my life
is as wind. Heb. An addition of favor, or joining of grace. Hence Levi had his
name. Now at this time my husband will be joined unto me; therefore was his
name called Levi, Genesis 29.34. But it must be an addition of ornament, not for
nothing, nor for infamy, but for honor, or at least for acceptance. To make
