thee amiable or honorable before others, and comely in their eyes, as Noah
found grace in the eyes of the Lord, Genesis 6.8. As usemoney brings an increase,
and Conquerors had garlands given them.

Unto thy head, (...), to, or for thy head, as this particle is rendered. Psalm.
84. A Psalm for the Sons of Korah. This shows, that he means a garland or
crown, such as Kings and Priests used to wear upon their heads, the highest
member, and most looked at in token of honor, Zach. 3.5. and 6.11. The word
(...), signifies,

1. The head, which is the beginning or highest part of the body. Job 19.9. He
has taken the crown from my head.

2. The highest part of any thing which stands above the rest, as the head
above the other members. The top of the ladder reaebed to heaven, Genesis 28.12.

3. A Commander in war or peace, who is above the rest, and guides them by
reason, as the head does the members. Numb. 14.4. Let us make a Captain.

4. The beginning of a thing. In the beginning of the middlewatch, Judge. 7.19.

5. The chief part of any thing, as the head is in the body. Take thou also
unto thee principal spices, Exodus 30.23.

6. The sum of things, which is the head of number. When thou have taken the
sum of the children of Israel, Ex. 30.12. Here it is taken in the first
sense, for the head of the body.

And chains. Wise men were wont to wear chains, in sign of honor due to them
for their wisdom. Pharaoh put a gold chain about Joseph's neck therefore, Genesis
41.39, 42. Hence the Giants and Anakims had their names, from (...) Men samous
for strength, and either did, or were accounted worthy to wear gold chains, as
men of note used to do. Or it may be Anak their Father wore a chain, and they
might have their name from him. The Ishmaelites used to wear golden earrings
in token of honor, Judge. 8.24. And he says chains in the plural number, for
the more gold chains men wear, the greater is their honor.

About thy neck, Heb. for thy neck, as before, or throat, which is within the
neck, Heb. throats; that is, both sides of the neck or throat, or because it
consists of many roundels, like rings, one below another.

The sum of all is:

If for love to thy Father and Mother, and duty due to them, thou will not
hearken to their pious instructions, yet let this motive prevail with thee,
taken from that reward of approbation and honor, which good children attain
unto, that hearken to their Parents counsels. That will make thee excellently
adorned, like a man that has a crown on his head, and chains on his neck.

Figures: Two Metaphors. One taken from a Garland, or Crown on the head; the
other from a Chain on the neck, signifying popular approbation and preferment.
Thou shall be a man approved and honored.

Note 1. The coherence, by way of motive. For.

2. The sentence.

In it, 1. The cause, they shall be.

2. The effect, set out by two similitudes; one from a crown on the head, an
ornament of grace on thy head. The other from a chain on the neck, and chains
about thy neck. Both signs of approbation and honor.

1. Doct. Though God might always command, yet he often uses motives to
persuade. So in the preface to the Ten Commandments, and in the second, third,
fourth, and fifth Commandments, many motives are used from Gods power,
goodness, and promises. See the like Deuteronomy. 11. all over.

Reason 1. Because God deals with reasonable men, and so presses reasons.
Every thing is to be wrought upon in its own way, in ordinary course.

2. Because their own reason will condemn them, if they hearken not to God;
but if God gave no reason (as he need not) then must he condemn men out of
mere authority, which (though just) would seem harsh.

3. Because of Gods in finite goodness. He uses all means for the good of men.

1. Use. To show the justice of the condemnation of wicked men; they fin
against the light of reason.

2. To persuade us to hearken to God, who deals with us in so low a way, that
might have stood upon high terms, and given no reason for his command. Princes
use to say, Sic volo, sic jubeo, stat pro ratione voluntas: So I will, so I
command, and for a Law my will shall stand. Si regnas, jube: If thou be a King,
command. Senec. Med.

2. Doct. Though we owe God more then we can do for him, yet he woes us by
rewards. By temporal rewards, Deuteronomy. 28.1, etc. Delight thy self also in the
Lord, and he shall give thee the desires of thine heart. Commit thy way unto
the Lord, and trust in him, and he shall bring it to pass, Psalm. 37.45. Psalm.
128. all over. If ye be willing and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the
land, Isa. 1.19. Veluti pueris dant crustula blandi Doctores, elementa velint
ut discere prima. Horat. Sat. 1. As kind Teachers give little cakes to boys to
make them willing to learn their A. B. C. Eternal rewards are promised, Matthew.
10.41, 42. A crown of righteousness, 2 Timothy 4.8. A crown of life, Revel. 2.10.
A throne to sit on, Rev. 3.21. The Spirit of God here accommodates himself to
Childrens temper, who love rewards. So should men be taken with Gods promises.

Reason 1. To show Gods freeness, who though he might require more duty out of
debt then we can perform, yet is pleased to reward our imperfect services; as
if a Creditor should give a thousand pound to one that owes him an hundred
pound, and paid but five pounds of it; or a Master give to a Servant that
failed in many things (though he were honest) treble his wages.

2. To work upon our self-love. He knows that we look at our selves naturally,
and he is willing to make use of this disposition of ours to encourage us to
his service.

1. Use. This shows how great a sin it is not to hearken to Gods voice. If he
required all out of debt, and gave no reward, it were injustice to deny him.
How much more when he offers so liberally? In so doing we justly deprive our
selves of the good promised, and perish eternally.

2. Use. Let us willingly hearken to God, who deals with us upon so fair terms,
as a City besieged yields gladly in extremity upon fair quarter, much more upon
great advantage and rewards offered. Moses had respect to the recompense of
reward, Heb. 11.26.

3. Doct. Harkening to Parents instruction, is a means to bring us to public
approbation. So it fared with Solomon himself. He got approbation by attending
to his Parents precepts, and advises his Son to seek it by attending to his.

Reason 1. Because the people observe the carriage of other men's children, as
well as of their own; and if they find them respective of their Parents good
counsels, they expect much from them, but little from disobedient ones.
Obedient children are comely in other men's eyes befide their Parents.

2. Because wisdom is gotten by hearkening to Parents counsels, and that makes
men acceptable to others. Keeping Parents precepts is grace unto the neck, chapter
3.21, 22. Wisdom made David esteemed as an Angel of God, 2 Samuel 14.20. A man's
wisdom makes his face to shine, Eccl. 8.1. God who turns men's hearts
whithersoever he will, Prove. 21.1. makes wise men to be had in high esteem,
even of fools, as if they were crowns and chains.

Use. Let not children think themselves too wise, and despise their Parents
counsel, lest others set light by them. Whereas, if they hearken to it, men
will willingly cast their eyes upon them, and have an high account of them; as
Joseph pleasing his Father, had a parti-colored coat, that others might see
his Fathers great affection to him.

5. Doct. Hearkening to Parents instruction is a great means of preferment. As
in Joseph, who was the best, and best beloved Son of his Father. In well
ordered Cities all men may not wear crowns or chains, but Nobles, and
Magistrates, and men preferred for wisdom. Pharaoh put a gold chain about
Joseph's neck, Genesis 41.42. Belshazzar caused a chain of gold to be put about
Daniels neck, Dan. 5.29. And this wisdom comes often by Parents instructions.
Men will not prefer such to rule others, as would not be ruled by their
Parents. Wise men are Noblemen, they have God to their Father.

Use. Behold the reward of hearkening to Parents instructions, and be
encouraged so to do. Great honor follows it many times in this world, but sure
a crown of glory in heaven.

Verse. 10. My Son, if sinners entice thee, consent thou not.
The Wise man proceeds in a very fit method; for having exhorted young men to
hearken to their Parents, now in the ten verses following, he warns them to
take heed of seducers, whereof for want of experience, and pronenesse to evil,
they are in great danger. Such seek to extinguish the good counsels of Parents
at home, by drawing them abroad to wickedness. For man's natural corruption is
ready to break forth, especially being solicited by others. Therefore he warns
young men to take heed of wicked men's company, counsels, and ways: Young men
are more apt to hear other men's bad counsels, then their Parents good; by
reason of ill disposition more powerful in them then natural affection.
Therefore he bids them cleave fast to the one, resist the other.

For the words.

(...), My Son. For this word see on verse. 1. and verse. 8. Herein Solomon aimed
principally at the good of his own children, yet gives this counsel to every
young man that shall hear or read these Proverbs, calling him his Son, as if he
spoke to him in particular, out of a paternall affection.

(...), If. If such a thing shall happen. If you meet with seducers, as it may
be ye may. Or when, as it is translated, Amos 7.2. When they had made an end of
eating the grass of the land. For there is no question but young men will meet
with enticers one time or other. Or seeing, as it should be translated, Est.
6.13. Seeing Mordecai is of the seed of the Jews. For it is sure he was so.

(...), sinners. Object. All men are finners born, and good men sin every day.
There is no man that sins not, 1 King. 8.46.

Answ. By finners here are meant gross sinners, as Luke 7.37, 39. such as live
in a course of sin without repentance. Such are forward to draw others to be
like them, but godly men seek to draw others to piety. So the word is used,
Psalm. 1.1. Nor stands in the way of sinners. And Joh. 9.31. God hears not
sinners. Such as make a trade of sin, 1 John 3.9. and 1 Samuel 15.18. The word
signifies to miss the mark. Every one could sting stones at an hairs breadth,
and not miss, Judge. 20.16. And secondarily, to miss the mark that God sets
before us in his Word. Not to act according to his Law. But here it signifies
not such as in some one act differ from the Law of God, but in the course of
their lives, and that willingly, wittingly, and grossly, and so miss the mark
of eternal glory, Phil. 3.14.

(...), Entice thee. Seek to persuade thee with fair words and rich promises to
take part with them in their wickedness, to the hurt of others. Malus bonum
vult malum esse, ut sit sui similis. Plaut. A bad man would have a good man
bad, that he might be like him. The word is used sometimes in a good sense, to
persuade men to good, and for their good. So some translate Genesis 9.27. God
shall persuade Japhet. And from this word Japhet had his name. But it is taken
most commonly in a bad sense, as here. Hence (...), a simple man, easily drawn
away, verse. 4. And hence comes Fatuus a fool in Latin.

(...), Consent thou not. A prohibition or charge, not to hearken to enticing
sinners. The word signifies to bear good will. Such as parents bear to their
children. Thence comes (...), a Father. See on verse. 8. And because men are
willing to hearken to such as they bear good will to, it signifies also to
consent. Sometime to good counsel, as verse. 30. Sometime to bad, as here. Say,
I will not do what ye persuade me to. Give a short answer, give not the least
ear or liking to their flattering persuasions. Be not ready to hearken to them
with thine ear, much less with thine heart, least of all to admit them into
thine hand, or act them. Keep thine ears from hearkening to them at first, as
David kept h^s tongue, Psalm. 39.1. and Job his eyes, Job 31.1. Be so far from
acting with them, that thou give no consent to them, nor keep no company with
them, Prove. 4.14. Be not won with their fair words, and large offers, but
rather resist their solicitations. A Meiosis, as in the third Commandment, not
holding him guiltless that takes Gods Name in vain, is holding him very
guilty, and punishing him very severely.

The sum of all is, as Solomon should have said; Ye young men, whom I love as
children, I know that wicked men will speak you fair, and make you large
promises, to persuade you not to hearken to my good counsels here, or such as
your godly Parents shall give you, and to draw you to their wicked ways; but
trust not to their promises, nor hearken ye to their counsels, for in stead of
making you rich and happy, they will make you miserable. Figures none.

Note 1. A general prescription in this verse.

2. Particular directions, to verse. 20.

In the first note, 1. The party spoken to, My Son. 2. The dehortation. And in
it, 1. The danger. 2. The way of preventing it. In the danger,
1. The agent, if sinners. 2. The effect, entice. 3. The object, thee.


The remedy is, consent thou not.

For the coherence: He had persuaded the young man before to open his ear to
his Parents good counsels, now he persuades him to stop it against the bad
counsels of finners.

1. Doct. Parents good counsels should keep out the bad counsels of finners out
of childrens hearts. Compare chapter 2. v. 1. with v. 12. and v. 16. there, and ye
shall see that hiding Parents commandments within us, is a means to keep us
from being hurt by the bad words of evil men or women. See the like, chapter 4.4,
14, 20, 24. and 5.1, 3, 7, 8, 9. and 6.20, 24. and 7.1, 5.

Reason 1. Because their parents should be deerer to them, then any other
whatsoever. And men are most ready to hearken to them, that are dearest to
them. Men are more ready to take notice who speaks, then what is spoken. They
who slight others speeches will regard friends words.

Use. Let children, when they are tempted to fin by others, recall their
Parents good counsels to the contrary. It will be a great preservative. Arms
laid up in peace are produced in war for good.

2. Doct. Such as undertake to teach others, must show forth Parents
affections. So does Solomon here, and verse. 8. chapter 2.5. and 3.1. and 4.1. And
David, chap. 5.1. and 6.1. and 7.1.

Reason 1. It is a winning way. Love wins more then authority. Therefore Paul
uses it to win the revolted Galatians, Gal. 4.19. My little children, of whom
I travel in birth again, until Christ beformed in you. See the like in Paul's
dealing with Philemon, Philem. v. 7, 8, 9, 19. He entreats that might command,
and promises payment to him that was more indebted to him, yea owed him his
own soul. St. John often uses this loving title, My little children, 1 John
2.1, 12, 13. and 3.18.

2. It is a stopping way to prevent objections. If it be objected, we disgrace
others, and bear them malice naturally, therefore they will not hear our
counsels; we may answer, Parents bear no malice to their children, and are
therefore worthy to be heard. If it be said, we seek our own, and not others
good, the same answer will serve, Parents do not so, but seek their childrens
good, and their counsels are for that cause not to be rejected.

1. Use. For Teachers. Let Ministers season their reprooss with fatherly
insinuations of affection, as Physicians give sugar after bitter pills. So let
Fathers, Masters, Friends, teach with parentall love, if they would do any good.

2. Use. Let young men regard such Teachers as show such affection. Assuredly
they speak for their good, what ever their corruption suggests to the contrary.

3. Doct. Though all men be finners, yet some remain in a sinful estate, and
so carry away the name from others. These are of two sorts:

1. All in their natural condition. While we were yet sinners, Romans 5.8. In
the flesh, chapter 8.8. In darkness, 1 Thessalonians. 5.4.

2. Gross sinners, as the Sodomites, Genesis 13.13. The men of Sodom were wicked,
and sinners before the Lord exceedingly. The sinners in Zion are afraid, Isa.
33.14.

Use. Get out of such a condition, both of natural and customary sin, or
rather keep out of the latter. Preservatives are better then healing physic.

4. Doct. Wicked men desire to make others as bad as themselves. So Harlots
do, Prove. 7.13, 14. The strumpet kisses the young man, and inveagles him with
fair words. So do drunkards. Come ye, say they, I will fetch wine, and we will
fill cur selves with strong drink, and to morrow shall be as this day, and much
more abundant, Isa. 56.12.

Reason 1. Because some sins cannot be committed without company with any
content, as wantonness and drunkenness. Nemo facile peccat. No man will
easily sin alone. August Conf. l. 2. Infected persons are said to have a desire
to insect others.

2. That they may continue in sin the more boldly, when they have partners in
sin to side with them.

Use. When men tempt you to evil, look what they are. Ye will find them wicked
men themselves, and such as gallop toward hell, and would lead you thither with
them. This thought will dead their temptations.

5. Doct. Wicked men have a notable infinuating faculty to deceive others. See
the Harlots persuasions, Prove. 7.13, etc. and the Drunkards, Isa. 56.12. Both
cited in the former doctrine. So after the text, Thieves seek to draw in others
from hope of gain, and impunity.

Reason 1. They have oft-times ripe wits, and stretch all the veins of their
understanding to deceive.

2. They study how to be n^mble, and eloquent in deceiving. They make choice of
most alluring baits, as Fishers and Fowlers use to do. Fistula dulce canit,
voluerem dum decipit auceps: The pipe sings merrily, while the Fowler deceives
the bird. Flatterers like fishermen, and fowlers willingly set that before the
eyes of fishes and birds, which they think pleases them best. They know, that
otherwise they lose their labor. Petronius. The Serpent tempts Eve by fruit
pleasant to the eyes, Genesis 3.6. Sirens sing sweetly to deceive. The Dragon
bites the Elephants ear, and then sucks his blood. So wicked men hurt us by our
ears. Trap in v. 11.

Use. Labor to understand the drifts of tempters and deceivers, that ye may
not be carried away with their fair words and promises. Answer as Speusippus
Plato's Nephew answered a flatterer that praised him, Give over deceiving both
of us, draw not me from the knowledge of my self, and cease to heap cunning
maliciousness on your self. Nihil proficis, cum te intelligam: I understand
you so well that you cannot prevail. Elenard in Chron. Malum hominem blande
loquentem agnosce tuum laqueum esse: Take notice that a wicked man speaking
fawningly is a snare to thee. Seneca. So the strumpets words bring the young
man into a snare, chapter 7.23. Christ was offered all the Kingdoms of the world
by Satan, I yet hearkened not to him; neither do thou to Papists, nor gross
sinners, who offer offices or marriages to seduce. They are justly fooled, who
trust them.

6. Doct. Enticers will set upon such as have good education. Solomon was set
upon by his wives, 1 King. 11.4. His Son Rehoboam by his young counselors, 1
King. 12.8. And no marvel, for the Devil durst set upon Christ himself.

Reason 1. They trust to their own skill to deceive, as if none were metal
proof against it.

2. They judge others corrupt like themselves, though better bred. And they
guess shrewdly, for instruction cannot quite drive out natural corruption;
Tindar will take fire.

Use. Ye that have godly parents, expect seducers. They will soon set upon you,
to deprive you of your Parents good counsels. Churches and Families have such.
Praemoniti, praemuniti; forewarned, forearmed. Be not taken unawares.

7. Doct. Enticers cannot hurt us, if we consent not. Satan hurt not Christ,
Matthew. 4. Nor had hurt Adam and Eve, had not they consented.

Reason. Because thoughts of what is evil, are not evil thoughts, till some
delight or consent come. Ascending thoughts, to wit, from our corruption, are
sins; thoughts sent in, to wit, by Satan, are no sins, if they infect us not.
Andrews on the tenth Commandment. Christ could not but think what it was that
Satan tempted him to, yet sinned not.

Use. Deny consent, and no temptation can hurt thee; thou shall be free from
actual finning.

8. Doct. We must be firmly resolved against all solicitations to evil. So
Christ was, Matt. 4. and had Scripture ready.

Reason. Because they will else grow too hard for us. Trees are easiest pulled
up at first.

Use. Resist temptation at first, and then Satan will fly from you, Jam. 47 and
sin with him. Euticers are faeces Reipublicae, the dregs of the Commonwealth.
Cicero. The sooner swept away, the better. Majorem praedam in viduabus
blandimenta eliciunt, quam tormenta. Many proved unchaste by allurements, yet
many Widows and Maids endured the fire. August. de Verb. Dom. in Matthew. Hom. 19
fin. Avunculus tuus quaerit animam tuam, qui jam perdidit suam. Promisit magna,
sed ego majora; offert plura, sed ego plurima. Dimittes ergo pro terr^nis
coelestia, pro temporalibus aeterna? Bern. Epist. 2. ad Fulconem. Thy Uncle
seeks thy soul, who has already lost his own. He promises great things, but I
greater: he offers very many things, but I far more. Will thou then let go
heavenly things for earthly, eternal for temporary?

Verse. 11. If they say, Come with us, let us lay wait for blood, let us lurk
privily for the innocent, without cause.
The Wiseman contents not himself to give general warning to the young man,
but comes to particulars. In which you may note:

1. The Robbers speech, to verse. 15.

2. The Wise-mans antidote, from thence to verse. 20. In the first he sets down
the particular allurements that wicked men use to draw others to evil. And
that in the tempters own words, to affect the young man the more. Robbers know
that young men are much discouraged with fear of danger, and difficulty of the
work, and therefore they labor first to dispossess them of these prejudices,
before they acquaint them with the gain to allurethem. And the Wiseman to make
them the more careful to avoid evil counsels, sets before them no mean
sinners, but Thieves and Robbers, who use to draw others to them, that they may
be the stronger to work wickedness. Not that such things are usually
propounded by wicked men at first, but they will come to them at last, if they
see young men willing to leave their Parents good counsel, to follow bad. He
sets this example before them, because it is easy to conceive what ways
thieves use to draw others to them, which young men having prodigally wasted
their own estates, are ready to hearken to, that without labor they may live
plentisully, as they did before. In this robbers speech note:

1. The plot they would draw them to act in, with some close arguments to drive
fear and shame out of them, to verse. 13.

2. Gain set before them to allure them, to verse. 15. So the Husbandman first
ploughs up weeds, then sows seeds. In the first note,

1. An argument from the safety of the attempt, v. 11.

2. From the easiness of the accomplishing it, v. 12.

For the first. Solomon propounds not the thing as Thieves would do to Novices,
for such gross language at first would make Novices afraid to join with them,
but rather shows whereunto their plots tend, and what they should say, if they
would speak plain. Yet he interweaves their arguments of safety, and facility.
For the words.

(...), If. See on verse. 10.

(...), they say. If they declare their meaning unto thee in words. So the word
is taken, Job 3.2. And Job spoke and said. It is also taken for commanding or
speaking impariously, Est. 1.10. The King commanded Mehuman, etc. For speaking
proverbially. As it is said to this day, In the Mount of the Lord it shall be
seen, Genesis 23.14. For thinking, or speaking in heart. The fool has said in
his heart, Psalm. 53.1.

Come with us. The Hebr. word (...), or rather (...) (for (...) is never read
in the Preterperfect tense, and therefore it is likely (...) comes of (...))
signifies,

1. Going about something, although a man walk not. And his Sons went and
feasted, Job 1.4.

2. Going on in a continued way, or walking. Laban went to shear his sheep,
Genesis 31.19.

3. The passage of ships, and other livelesse things. There go the ships, Psalm.
104.26.

4. Passing out of the world, or dying. Thou shall go to thy Fathers, Genesis
15.15. And he passes, Job 14.20.

5. Constancy in a condition. I go childlesse, Genesis 15.2.

6. It imports a course of life good or bad. Blessed is the man that walks
not in the counsel of the ungodly, Psalm. 1.1.

Here it is taken in the second sense. Come with us, or go with us to rob
others, and live by stealing. They show their forwardness to sin, not being
content to sin themselves, but soliciting others also. Thou shall not go alone,
nor be the first, but we will lead thee, who are accustomed to such courses. So
they seek to drive away the young man's s^^ame^astnesse.

(...) Let us lay wait. They call upon him to join with them. The argument is
taken from secrecy, to put away shame, or from safety. We will lie in
ambuseado, as Soldiers do in Woods unseen to catch enemies, and wild beasts
watching for prey. No man can there hurt us, prevent us, or reveal us, to bring
us to punishment. We will not openly set upon them, but work craftily for their
hurt, and our security. Young men are shamefast, as not used to such
wickedness; therefore secrecy is promised. They are fearful to fight in open
wars, therefore craft is added. We may be killed our selves if we set openly on
them, but we will prevent that danger by ambushments.

(...), for blood. The word signifies,

1. The blood of living creatures. Ye shall not eat any thing with the blood,
Levit. 19.26.

2. Things like blood in color. The Moon shall be turned into blood, Joel 2.31.

3. Murder, or blood shedding, because the life is in the blood, and departs
when the blood is shed. The earth also shall disclose her blood, and shall no
more cover her slain, Isa. 26.21. So it is taken here. And Deuteronomy. 17.8. Psalm.
5.6. Let us kill them to get their goods, Mat. 21.38. And to make them sure
that they may not reveal us.

(...), let us lurk privily. The same thing in other words, to show their
earnestness in persuading, and confidence that their plot must take. If we
cannot meet with him conveniently in the high way, we will wait in secret till
we can, Psalm. 10.8. and 56.6.

(...), for the innocent. It signifies primarily one clear from sin, or guilt,
or pure, not filthy or defiled with iniquity. But here is meant one that
carries himself fairly, goes quietly about his own business, not seeking the
hurt of any, nor fearing hurt from any, and so self-wary, and the more easily
oppressed. But this innocent man must be rich, to v. 13. Else nothing is gotten
by killing him.

(...), without cause. It signifies,

1. Without pay or reward, or for naught. Does Job fear God for naught? Job 1.9.

2. Without success, or in vain. I have not said in vain, Ezekiel. 6.10.

3. Without cause, or wrongfully. Thou movedst me against him to destroy him
without cause, Job 2.3. And so here, we will kill them, though they have given
us no cause to hurt them. The young man might object, They have not wronged us,
why should we kill them? No matter for that (say the Seducers) we shall get
wealth by it, v. 13. They sin out of covetousness, rather then out of malice.
It cannot signify in vain here, or without reward, for that became not the
seducers to speak, nor would not encouaage, but rather discourage the young man.

Figures none, unless a Prosopopeia, wherein Solomon speaks to them, as if the
thieves themselves were present, and spoke these words to the young man. And
shedding of blood for slaying. A figure of the cause for the effect.

Note 1. A preface, If they say.

2. The counsel it self, in three exhortations. In the first note,

1. The act, come.

2. The company, with us. In the second note,

1. The act, let us wait.

2. The object, for blood. In the third,

1. The act, let us lurk privily.

2. The object, for the innocent.

3. The answer to a tacit objection, without a cause.

Although they have given us no cause, yet let not that discourage thee. We
shall get wealth, let that encourage thee. For this cannot be an argument, Let
us kill them, because they have done us no wrong. Therefore it is a prevention
of an objection. For the coherence. Solomon not only warns young men in
general to take heed of seducers, but also acquaints them with their
particular persuasions beforehand.

1. Doct. Young men are in great danger of being drawn away to sinful courses.
They have great need of clensing their way Psalm. 119.9. See how the young man
is encountered with the wily allurements of the strumpet, chap. 7.7, etc.

Reason 1. Because they have not that grounded experience that others have, nor
are so able to look through shows into substances.

2. Because they are wilful and headstrong, and will follow their own lusts,
notwithstanding good men's persuasions. Solomon does not give leave to the young
man to walk in the ways of his heart, and in the sight of his eyes, Eccles.
11.9. but by an iconicall concession foretells their inclination, and therefore
God may justly give them over to be seduced, 2 Thessalonians. 2.10, 11, 12.

Use. Young men look about you. Young birds are caught with chafe. Take heed,
lest for despising your Parents good counsel, God give you over to hearken to
bad.

2. Doct. Wickedness will not be kept in in the heart, but will break out. The
fool has said in his heart, there is no God. And his deeds show it: They are
corrupt, they have done abominable works, Psalm. 14.1. So the transgression of
the wicked in his heart appears in that the words of his mouth are iniquity and
deceit, Psalm. 36.1, 3.

Reason 1. Because fin is like fire, if any fuel come to it, it will break
forth.

2. The devil blows the bellows by temptations.

Use. Take heed of the company of wicked men. Though they carry themselves
never so civilly for a time, yet their wickedness will break out. Tum tua res
agitur, paries cum proximus ardet: Look to thy self when thy neighbors house
is on fire. Men flee from insected houses. So should we from sinners.

3. Doct. Secrecy is a great bait to wickedness. The good man is not at home,
he is gone a long journey. A shrewd argument for adultery. Joseph's greatest
temptation was when there was none of the men of the house within, Genesis 39.11.

Reason 1. Because shame is a bridle to keep men from open wickedness. Many
are kept in by it, whom no counsel will keep from evil ways.

2. Because fear of punishment is a bit that keeps others from fin. Things
openly done will be questioned. (...). Aster. Conc. de Filio prodigo. There are
two strong keepers of youth, fear, and shame. Duo sunt custodes domestici nobis
a Deo dati, pudor, and timor. August. God has given us two keepers at home,
shame, and fear. Timor Domini est janitor animae: The fear of the Lord is the
dorekeeper of the soul. Bern.

Use. Take heed of secret solicitations to secret evile. The fear of God must
keep thee from these, as it did Joseph. Genesis 39.9. Set God always before thee,
Psalm. 16.8. Walk before him, Genesis 17.1. Be not worse then eye servants, who
will not offend in their Masters sight. Take the Heathen man's counsel. Suppose
Socrates, or some grave man before thee, when thou art tempted to any secret
wickedness. Yea, suppose God before thee. Quaecunque capessi, testes factorum
stare arbitrabere. Pros. Silius. Bell Pun. l. 15. What ^re thou go about,
think God a witness of thy actions. In omnibus, quae agis, Deum prasentem
cogites. Bern. Med. c. 6. Think God present in all thou do.

4. Doct. Covetousness makes men cruel. They say not, Let us lay wait for
wealth, but for blood, yet wealth was their aim. We will kill rather then want.
Ahab's covetousness brought Naboth to his end, 1 King. 21.4, 13. And Judas his
desire of gain made him betray Christ, Matthew. 26.15, 16.

Reason. Many do not kill men out of malice, but 1. that they may enjoy their
prey without resistance. 2. That they may not be discovered, and so punished.
Mortui non mordent. The dead bite not. They would find them out if they should
live.

Use. Take heed of covetousness. Though thou intendest only to cosen men of
their goods at the first, yet thou may be brought to kill Naboth for his
vineyard.

5. Doct. Wicked men have many secret devices to bring their wicked purposes to
pass. Esau resolves to kill his Brother Jacob after his Fathers burial, Genesis
27.41. Jezabel can undo Naboth by calling a Fast, 1 King. 21.9. For it is
their study day and night, Psalm. 36.4. Prove. 4.16.

Use. It teaches not to marvel that wicked men's plots prevail sometimes
against better men then themselves. We should rather wonder they do not always
prevail, they are so restless, and have so many ways to the Wood.

6. Doct. Wicked men promise themselves success of their mischievous plots.
They think they lurk so, as they cannot be prevented. Esau made no doubt of
slaying Jacob, Genesis 27.41. Saul made sure reckoning to catch David in Keilab, 1 Samuel 23.7. They think their Mine too deep for men to countermine, and look not
to God that can go beyond them.

Use. To show us how deeply sin is rooted in sinful souls, so that they dare
promise themselves good success, not only in lawful, but also in sinful
affairs.

7. Doct. Wicked men promise themselves impunity. They lie so close, that they
will have no witnesses to accuse them. And then they say, The Lord shall not
see, Psalm. 94.7. And they say, How does God know, and is there knowledge in the
most High, Psalm. 73.11. They encourage themselves in an evil matter, they
commune of laying snares privily; they say, Who shall see them? Psalm. 64.5. Woe
unto them that seek deep to hide their counsel from the Lord, and their works
are in the dark, and they say, Who sees us? and, Who knows us? Isa. 29.15.
Security is the cause of it. They persuade themselves that God and men are
blind. As the Ostrich hides his head, and then thinks all the body safe.
Struthiocameli stoliditas mira, in tanta reliqui corporis altitudine, cum
collum frutice occultaverit, latere se existimantis. Plin. l. 10. c. 1. Great
is the foolishness of the Ostrich, who though his body be very high, yet when
he hides his neck under a shrub, thinks he lies hid.

Use. Let Magistrates put them out of that conceit by doing justice on
Malefactors. Impunitas maxima est peccandi illecebra: Impunity i^ the greatest
bait to sin. Sparing some is cruelty to others. Henry the Eighth his fool, when
the King denied a pardon to a Gentleman that had killed two men before, told
him, that the Gentleman had killed but one, the King had killed the other, for
if he had hanged him for the first, the second had been alive. Bonis no^et,
quisquis malis pepercerit. P. Syrus. He that spares the bad, hurts the good.

8. Doct. Rich men, though innocent, are in danger. As Naboth, 1 King. 21. The
inheritance made the heir in danger of his life, Mat. 21.38. Their riches breed
them snares, Cantabit vacuus coram latrone viator: An empty traveller may sing
before a thief.

Use. To condemn the immoderate desire of riches. Our throats may be cut for
them.

Verse. 12. Let us swallow them up alive, as the grave; and whole, as those that
go down into the pit.
The former argument to persuade our Novice to join in thest, and murder, and
unlawful surprise of other men's goods and lives, was taken from the safety of
the action. No danger. No man should see, to prevent it before, or to accuse
after. This argument in this verse is from the easiness of it. The Novice
might object, The work is difficult, the success doubtful. They answer, No.
It may be done without any trouble, with much ease, and little resistance. We
shall as easily overcome them, as dead men are put into the grave, or a sop
swallowed by a Dog.

For the words:

(...), Let us swallow them up, or we will or shall swallow them. Join thou
with us in the doing of it. They desire not only consent and approbation of
the work, but also assistance and help to effect it. Let us swallow them up as
wild beasts devour their prey, at a morsel; or as the greater fishes devour
the lesser, whole, and make no bones of them. Hereby is intimated,

1. The greedy desire of wicked men, to destroy others for their goods, as
beasts or fishes are greedy for their food, without which they cannot live.

2. The easiness they conceive of effecting it. They can destroy them as
easily as a Whale swallows a fish (as they think) that has power to resist or
escape.

3 The suddenness of the danger. The party shall be destroyed before he know
himself in danger, as a fish is suddenly swallowed.

4. The secrecy of it. None can tell what is become of that which is swallowed
up. No sign of blood shall be lest, nor any member, to avoid all suspicion of
murder.

5. The irrecoverablenesse of the loss. Things swallowed up are past recovery,
unless by miracle, as Jonas came out of the Whales belly. There will be then
no fear of revenge at all from them. By them he means the innocent parties, and
such as never did them any wrong, mentioned verse. 11.

(...), alive. This argues cruelty, to eat and devour living creatures, that
are sensible of their pain and loss. Dead carcasses feel not when they are
devoured. This cruelty is expressed lively, Psalm. 124.3. Then they had
swallowed us up quick, when their wrath was kindled against us. The word
signifies,

1. Life. God breathed into man's nostrills the breath of life, Cen. 2.7.

2. Living, or alive. I will walk before the Lord in the land of the living,
Psalm. 116.9.

3. Lively, or strong. The Hebrew women are lively, Exodus 1.19.

4. Men. Eve was the Mother of all living, Genesis 3.20. Not of beasts, but of men.

5. Beasts, for they live also. At the hand of every beast will I require it,
Genesis 9.5.

6. Moving things, that have no sense. A well of living watirs, Cant. 4.15.

Here it is taken in the second sense, for living or alive.

(...), as the grave. The word is sometime translated Hell. The wicked shall be
turned into hell, Psalm. 9.17. which is a receptacle for souls of wicked men
after death. Sometimes it is rendered the grave. I will go down into the grave,
unto my Son, Genesis 37.35. That is, the receptacle of dead bodies. And sure Jacob
meant not to go to hell, but into the grave, or state of the dead, for it is
likely he thought his Son was not buried, but devoured by wild beasts, as he
was told. It is taken directly for the Grave, Prove. 30.16. So it is taken here
for the Grave. We will not stay till they be dead. We will be their grave, and
hide them safe enough. It is not an allusion to Dathan and Abiram swallowed
alive by the earth, as some would have it, for thieves would not willingly
mention such a judgment. But the grave swallows dead men that they are no more
heard of, so will we swallow living men. And it may be an allusion to any that
are swallowed up quick, as multitudes have been upon breaches made by
earthquakes, and hanging hills overwhelming Towns, as lately in the Valtoline.
The name comes from (...), to crave or ask. For the grave is never satisfied,
but always craving for more carcasses. It never says, It is enough, Prove.
30.16.

(...). And whole. We will not hurt, nor maim them, nor cut off some members,
but swallow them all up at once. The word sometimes fignifies upright, or
undefiled. Blessed are the undefiled, or entire in the way, Psalm. 119.1. So
some read here. But that cannot be. For,

1. That is all one with innocent, verse. 11. And,

2. It suits not well with the words following, for most men go down into the
pit defiled.

(...), As they that go down into. That descend into the earth by burial; or
otherwise, by casualty, as some fallen into Marle-pits, and perished there, or
into Cole-pits, as Psalm. 140.10. It is true literally, for pits and graves are
in the bowels of the earth, and men are put down into them; or metaphorically,
because the estate of dead men is a lower condition, then of those that live on
the earth. A living dog is better then a dead lion, Eccl. 9.4.

(...), The pit. The word sometime signifies a pool dug to receive
rain-waters in those dry Countries, where water is wanting. A pit wherein there
is plenty of water, shall be clean, Lev. 11.36.

2. It signifies a pitfall dug to catch birds or beasts in. He made a pit,
Psalm. 7.15.

3. A hole or dungeon, whereinto offenders are cast. Unto the firstborn of the
captive that was in the dungeon, Exodus 12.29. Yet good men have been cast into
such places, as Jeremy into a dungeon, and Joseph into a pit.

4. A grave wherein dead men are cast. Thou have kept me alive, that I should
not go down into the pit, Psalm. 30.3. Some understand it the second way, of men
cast alive into some deep gulf, whence there is no recovery. Some in the fourth
sense of the grave. Either sense will serve, for the thing is the same. An
utter irrecoverable destruction is intended. They shall be like men cast into a
grave, or a deep pit, never to be seen any more. Mercer and some others
understand it of taking away their estates, not in part, but altogether, in the
midst of their prosperity. Which agrees (they say) with the verses following,
that speak of great riches to be gotten. But how does it agree with bloodshed
mentioned verse. 11. and v. 16? But our former interpretation suits well with
both. To kill them that they may have their goods. Figures. Swallow. A Metaphor
from great fishes swallowing the less. In the text note, 1. The actors, Let
us. 2. The act, swallow up. 3. The object, them. 4. The manner: 1. Alive. 2. As
the grave. 3. Whole. 4. As they that go down into the pit. Note from the
coherence.



1. Doct. Innocent persons are the object of bad men's wrath. Nocent Cain kills
innocent Abel. 1 John 3.12. Because his own works were evil, and his Brothers
righteous. Ishmael persecutes Isaac. He that was born after the flesh
persecuted him that was born after the Spirit, Gal. 4.29. Joab kills two men
better then himself, 1 King. 2.32. Pii ab improbis tanquam exprobrautes
aspiciuntur. Severus Sulpitius. The wicked look upon the godly, as upbraiding
them for their wicked courses.

Reason 1. Contraries seek to expel one another, especially the worst seek to
drive out the best, as darkness to expel light, and cold to drive away heat.
Wicked men are contrary to innocent persons in judgment, will, affections,
words, actions, use of creatures. They are both men, and the Logic rule holds
in them: Species to ti maxim sunt consentaneae, sibi dissentaneae. Particular
kinds agree very much in the general, and disagree as much among themselves
And therefore two contrary Kingdoms of Christ and Satan cannot agree.

2. Envy sets evil men on work to contemn inferiors, quarrel with equals,
hate superiors. Satan envyes God, wicked men envy good men's present state,
future happiness.

3. Shame sets them on work. Other men's good works shame their bad ones, in all
times, places, companies. Hoc tantum me male habet, quod justus ubique audit:
This only troubles me, that every one speaks well of him, and counts him a
just man. Spoken of Aristides by one that knew not his face, yet requested him
to write his name in a shell, to pass his vote for his banishment.

Use. Let us not marvel at insurrections against, and oppressions of good men.
If it be objected, that they give no cause, it is easily answered, Their
goodness or wealth is the occasion. Nec Milvo, nec Accipitri rete tenditur:
Men lay not nets for Kites or Hawks. Terent. But for birds that are harmless,
and good to eat. Da veniam corvis, vexat censura columbas: Men let Ravens go
free, and vex Pigeons with their censures. They often let go the offender, and
punish the innocent.

2. Doct. Wicked men's spleen is often against them that do them no wrong. What
wrong did David to Shimei or Saul? Mephibosheth to Ziba? Spleen overflows in
such, as poison in a Toad, that spits venom on him that treads not on it; and
fierceness in a Wolf, which sets on him that passes by, and thinks no harm.

Use. It shows a difference between wicked men and good. Ill men seek the hurt
of friends, good men forgive enemies. As dogs bite them that strike them not,
but sheep bite not them that strike them.

3. Doct. Evil men intend to go through with their plots. So did Jezabel in
the business of Naboth, without any thought of the danger of innocent blood.
So Judas betrayed Christ, without any thought of Christ's kindness in
preferring him to the Apostleship.

Reason 1. Their intention is frustrate else, as a Gardiners, if the tree bear
no fruit; or a Builders, if the house be not finished.

2. All their labor is lost also, if their plots take no effect.

Use. It shows us the corruption of our nature, that is not content to be
evil, think evil, plot evil, but is never quiet, till it act it. Joseph's
Brethren were never quiet till he was gone. They regarded not their Fathers
grief that would ensue.

4. Doct. Ungodly men are cruel men. Their very mercies are cruel, Prove.
12.10. A good man regards a beasts life, they care not for a man's, but kill
women and children, like Hazael, 2 King. 8.12, 13. They can dash the mother in
pieces upon her children, Hos. 10.14.

Reason 1. Because we are naturally so degenerate, that we are compared by God,
who best knows us, to the cruellest wild beasts. To Wolves, to Lions, and
Bears, Isa. 11.6, 7.

2. Because ungodly men have no fear of God to restrain their wicked
disposition. Therefore Abraham feared the loffe of his life in Gerar, because
he thought the fear of God was not in that place, Genesis 20.11. Therefore
Joseph's Brethren needed to fear no hurt from him, because he feared God, Genesis
42.18.

3. Because they are afraid to be revealed. (...). Mauritius de Phoca. Fearful
men are murderers.

Use. Marvel not then at insurrections, treasons, poysonings, cruel murdees.
There will be such as long as there be wicked men left in the world.

5. Doct. Wicked men could wish, that there were no footsteps left of their
iniquity. Such is the way of the adulterous woman, she eats, and wipeth her
mouth, and says, I have done no wickedness, Prove. 30.20.

Reason 1. Out of shame. They know others will condemn their wicked courses,
though they flatter themselves, Psalm. 36.2.

2. Out of fear, left they should be called to account, as many wicked men have
been strangely, and long after murders and wantonnesses committed.

Use. Let us be ashamed of those courses that wicked men themselves are ashamed
of, and will one day wish that themselves, and their sins were at the bottom
of the mountains.

6. Doct. Sinners want not patheticall expressions to draw others to sin. They
have honey words, and sugared baits. See the fawning speeches of the
Adulteress, Prove. 7.14 etc. and of the Drunkard, Isa. 56.12. For sin seen in
its own colors would be hated. Ill stuff will not off without a good gloss.

Use Do evil men want no pathetical expressions to move to sin? Let us then
bewail our barrenness to persuade to good. If sinners have their Come, verse.
11. should not Saints have their Come to the house of the Lord? Isa. 2.3.
Should we not incite, entice, whet, and provoke one another? Heb. 10.24.
sharpen, and extimulate? Prove. 27.17. rouse, and stir up each other to love,
and good works? 2 Pet. 1.13. God forbid. Yea, let us labor to go beyond them,
our cause is far better.

Verse. 13. We shall find all precious substance, and shall fill our houses
with spoil.
The Wise man having showed in the two former verses, how Thieves use to
dispossess Novices of fear of danger, and difficulty; now the train being
laid, they blow up the Mine, and set upon them with an argument of profit,
which they think is very prevalent with young men, and few have strength to
resist it. Men will hear no reason against their profit. When we have killed
the owner, we will enter into his possessions, and take away all he has,
Matthew. 21.38.

For the words.

(...). We shall find. The word signifies,

1. Finding without seeking. By accident, as we call it. I am found of them
that sought me not, Isa. 65.1. So did Saul find Christ, Act. 9.

2. Finding by seeking, or enquiry. Seek ye the Lord while he may be found,
Isa. 55.6. So Christ promises that seekers shall find, Mat. 7.7. Here it is
taken in the second sense. We shall find what we seek for, plenty of riches.
We shall not need to work hard for it, as they did. It will come easily, as
with one that finds eggs in a birds nest, Isa. 10.14. It is laid up already
for us, we need only to look it out, and take it. None will resist us when the
owner is gone. Finding here is obtaining by search. When we come into his
house, we shall find store of riches. They will offer themselves to us. What
other men wrought hard for, we shall get with little labor.

(...), All. Not all that is in the world, but of all sorts some. The word
imports variety with plenty. We shall have abundance of riches of all sorts. So
the word is used, Genesis 41.57. All Countries came into Egypt to Joseph, for to
buy corn. That is, some out of all or most Countries. So Mat. 4. Christ's
healing all sickness, is well translated all manner of sickness.

(...) substance Riches. Property of gold and filver. Wealth. So it is
translated, chap. 3.9. and 13.11. Honor the Lord with thy substanee. Wealth
gotten by vanity shall be diminished.

(...). Precious. The word fignifies,

1. Honor. The honor of his excellent majesty, Est. 1.4.

2. Precious, or rare. The Word of the Lord was precious in those days, 1 Samuel
3.1.

3. Precious in value, or of great price. With the precious stones, 2 Samuel
12.30. So it is taken here. We will leave mean things for poor thieves, and
seize upon the best for our selves. We will not take trifles, things of no
value, but the choycest things.

(...) We shall fill. When it is spoken of a vessel or place, it signifies
filling. Replenish (or fill) the earth, Genesis 1.28. When of a time, or word, it
signifies sulfilling. My days are fulfilled, Genesis 29.21. Here it it taken in
the first sense. We shall get store, not enough for necessity only, but also
to afford pleasure and delight.

(...) Our houses. The word comes from (...), to build. Houses grow no^, they
must be built b^ men's labor. We shall have enough to fill our houses with
utensils, and ornaments, and to keep us and all ours with ease, and without
that labor and pains that other men take. We will empty their houses to fill
ours with what we have taken out of them, and not leave stealing, till our
houses now empty be filled with good things. Every room shall have his stuff
and furniture. It is put sometime for a nest, the birds house. The sparrow has
found an house, Psa. 84.3. Sometime for the household, family, nation, or
posterity; as the house of Jacob, and of Judah. Ordinarily it is put for man's
dwelling place. Surely I will not come into the tabernacle of my house, Psalm.
132.3. Hence comes the Chaldee word (...), to lodge, or pass the night. The
King passed the night fasting, Dan. 6.18. For men go abroad about business all
day, but lodge at home all night.

(...), Spoil. Properly it signifies, spolia, exuvias, cloths taken off a man's
body, or the skin off from a beast. Put off thy shoes from off thy feet, Exodus
3.5. Figuratively, it signifies all things useful, taken from others by
violence, (as beasts take their prey) as household stuff, goods, etc. We will
not work for our living, but as enemies and wild beasts will live by prey.
Benjamin shall raven as a Wolf, in the morning he shall devour the prey, and
at night he shall divide the speyl, Genesis 49.27. And behold the servants of
David and Joab came from pursuing a troop, and brought in a great spoil with
them, 2 Samuel 3.22. The precious things mentioned before, might be silver, gold,
jewels. The spoil here may be other things taken out of the house, as
housholdstuffe, garments, cattle. Every word has an emphasis. We will take not
shadows, but substance; not ordinary, but precious; not a little, but enough to
fill our houses; not with some, but with all sorts to superfluity. And all this
got not by hard labor, but with ease, as things found. As conquerors, when
they take Cities, sack them, and carry away the spoil to enrich themselves,
Isa. 8.4.

It is as if they should have said, Thou art a young man, need many things
for thy pleasure. Join with us, and thou shall want nothing. Thou know not
how to labor, nor shall not need. We shall have abundance of all things with
ease, and without fear of loss of life, or credit, and without any fear of
danger. If an easy and free life do not move thee, yet think upon the
greatness of the prey, and that will certainly allure thee. This is the last
and greatest argument, the conclusion follows, verse. 14. Cast in thy lot among
us, etc.

Figures none. For Parts: Note two promises that wicked men make to themselves:
1. Of great things. 2. Of abundance. In the first note,


1. The subject, We. 2. The adjunct. And in it, 1. The act, shall find. 2. The
object. And therein, 1. The subject, substance. 2. The adjuncts, 1. Of quality,
precious. 2. Of quantity, all.



In the second promise note, 1. The subject, W^. 2. The adjunct. And in it, 1.
The act, shall fill. 2. The containing subject, our houses. 3. The object, with
spoil.



1. Doct. Gain is the cause of abundance of mischief in the world. Herein the
text it produces the loss of men's whole estates and lives. So are the ways
of every one, that is greedy of gain, which takes away the life of the owners
thereof, Chap. 1. Ziba's covetousness lost Mephibosheth half his estate, 2 Samuel 19.29. Gehazi's brought the leprofie on him, and his posterity, 2 King.
5.27. Judas his brought Christ to his death, and himself to hanging and hell,
Mat. 27.5. Act. 1.25. Simon Magus his brought himself to perish with his money,
Act. 8.20. Gain upholds idolatry, Isa. 41.6, 7. as making Images upheld the
Tradesmen of Ephesus, Act: 19.25. It upholds Sabbath-breaking, Neh. 13.15. As
also perjury, and murder of parents, at least in heart. Filius onte diem
patrios inquirit in annos: The Son thinks the Father lives too long to keep him
out of his inheritance. It is the cause of other murders also, as of heir,
Mat. 21.38. of adulteries, for whores are hired, Deuteronomy. 23.18. The Popes get
much by Stews at Rome. So theft and cousenage in the text are fruits of
covetousness. False witnesses are set on work by covetous persons, as against
Naboth, 1 King. 21.13. Desire of other men's goods proceeds from that root, 1
King. 21.1. So does idolatry. Matthew. 6.24. Ye cannot serve God and Mammon.

Use. Take heed you set not up the Idol of gain in your hearts. A man that
rides a journey must not overload his horse, nor he that runs a race overload
himself. Gain will make good men sordid. Dulce lucrum e re qualibet: Gain is
good out of a dunghill. The Emperor Vespasian imposed a tribute upon Urine.
Sueton. in Vespas. c. 23. And Michael Paphlago the Greek Emperor, upon the Air.
Cuiac. observe. 10. c. 7. Gain made Balaam forwarder then his Ass to curse Gods
people. Those that count all good fish that comes to the net, in the end will
catch the devil and all.

2. Doct. Worldly things are very precious to carnal eyes. They are counted
the only good. Who will show us any good? Psalm. 4.6. Nebuchadnezzar knows no
other heaven but Babylon. Dan. 4.30. Is not this great Babylon that I have
built for the house of the Kingdom, and for the honor of my Majesty? Agrippae
and Barnice came with great po^^, Act. 25.23.

Reason 1. Because there is some proportion between worldly eyes, and carnal
objects. Men are naturally covetous.

2. They know no better things. They are blind in spiritual and heavenly
matters. He that never saw the Sun, would think the Moon a glorious creature.

Use. It teaches us not to marvel that young men are carried a way with
worldly objects, when old men, if carnal, are taken with them. They have
little, and need much to satisfy their lusts. No wonder then if they be caught.

3. Doct. Plenty is desired by ill men, not caring how they come by it. The
love of money is the root of all evil, which while some coveted after, they
have erred from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many sorrows, 1 Timothy 6.10. Therefore must rich men weep and howl for the wiseries that come on
them, for their ill-gotten goods, Jam. 5.1, etc. The ways wicked men use for
gain prove it. They will swear, lie, put off had and light ware, use false
lights and measures, weights and witnesses, and cheating devices to deceive
others.

Use. Let us show that we are not such wicked men, by being content with a
moderate state, and not using ill means to get more. Else we shall consult
shame to our houses, by cutting off many people, and sinning against our souls,
Hab. 2.10. He that brings home a pack of plaguey clothes, has no such great
booty of it.

4. Doct. Wickedness will brag and boast. The devil offers all the Kingdoms
of the world to Christ, Matthew. 4.8, 9. Why boastest thou thy self in mischief,
O mighty man? Psalm. 52.1.

Reason 1. Wicked men hereby show forth the pride of their hearts, that are not
content to be evil, unless they boast and triumph over others.

2. That they may draw others to them, for great words and fair promises
prevail much with wicked men.

Use. Suspect bragging persons, that they intend to draw you to some evil.
Good men are modest. Bad men divide the Bears skin before the Bear be dead.
They often fall short of what they brag of, and lose life and all, when they
promise themselves and others great riches, as in the Powder Treason, and in
the invincible Navy in 88. and later Insurrections.

5. Doct. Wicked men care not, if all men be empty, so themselves be full.
Thieves will take away clothes and all, as from him that went down from
Jerusalem to Jericho, Luke 10.30. They crush the poor, Amos 4.1. They swallow
up the needy, and make the poor of the land to fail, Amos 8.4.

Reason 1. Because they have no love in them, but self-love. Like the
unrighteous Judge, that regarded no man, Luke 18.2.

2. As they know not what belongs to humanity, so much less to communion of
Saints. It is no Article of their Creed.

Use. It teaches us to look for little kindness from ungodly men. They are
strangers to their own blood. Friends can look for little from them, and godly
men for less.

^ Doct. Wicked men dream of no want nor crosses in their ungodly courses.
Satan's first temptation put such thoughts into Eves heart. Ye shall not die,
Genesis 3.4. Soul thou have much goods laid up for many years, take thine ease,
eat, drink, and be merry, Luke 12.19.

Reason 1. Because they have no sound forecast, but look only at the present,
as a foolish Merchant, having had one good Voyage, adventures all next time,
and loses all.

2. Because they are bewitched with lust and prosperity. Their eye is in their
heart, not in their head. They believe they shall not want, though they wasse,
because they would have it so.

Use. Build not on worldly prosperity. Least of all in bad ways, Psalm. 62.10.

Verse. 14. Cast in thy lot among us, let us all have one purse.
Ye have heard the Thieves arguments and allurements before, now follows the
conclusion: Cast in thy lot, etc.

For the words.

Cast in, Heb. make to foll, (...). There are diverse ways of casting lots,
which seem to be hinted in Scripture. The first was by the casting of a dart or
arrow into the air, and the parties or things being divided, that on which, or
near which it fell, was taken. So (...) is used Josh. 18.10. Joshua cast lots
for them. And (...), to cast or shoot, Joel 3.3. to show the casting of it up,
as (...) Ezekiel. 24.6. Let no lot fall upon it. To show the falling of it down,
which did determine the controversy. So Jonathan was taken, 1 Samuel 14.42.

A second way was by a rod, which the Tithing-man had in his hand to strike the
tenth sheep, as it came out of the fold, for the Lord, to avoid partiality,
Lev. 27.32.

A third way was by putting names or stones into a man's lap, or a pot, and he
that drew out the right had the prize, as in our Lotteries. The lot is cast
into the lap, Prove. 16.33. As there is used (...), to cast in; so (...), to
come out. In the place where his lot falls, Numb. 33.54. Heb. comes out. And
(...), to come up. On which the Lords lot fell, Heb. came up. Lev. 16.9.

A fourth was by setting a stick or an arrow on end, to see which way it would
fall, as the King of Babylon did to know which way he should go, to Jerusalem,
or to Rabbah; though others think it was the first way, by shooting an arrow
upright, as if he would ask God, and be resolved by the fall of the arrow which
way he should go, Ezekiel. 21.21. Much like our casting Cross and Pile.

These different ways are reckoned up by some learned Writers, let the Reader
judge of them as he please.

Thy lot. The word (...) is taken,

1. For the thing cast up, or in, or set to determine the controversy. The lot
is cast into the lap, Prove. 16.33. The paper or stone is put in.

2. For the thing obtained by lot, be it land, office, wealth, etc. As, the lot
of Judah, Josh. 15.1.

3. For an estate got by labor, or from Parents, or otherwise, because things
were anciently divided by lot. Thou maintainest my lot, Psalm. 16.5. And so it
is taken here. For the young man tempted had not his means by lot, but by gift
or labor.

Among us, Heb. in the midst of us. Thou shall be put to no worse then we are,
nor fare no worse. There may be much ods in setting one before or behind, in
war or robbery, the safest place is in the midst.

Some interpret the words thus: Bring in thy goods to us, to make a joint
stock. We will be Partners. But Thieves need no stock to set up withal. Others
thus: Thou shall take that share of the prey that falls to thee. We will east
lots to avoid partiality. But that crosses the common purse in the end of the
verse. It is rather to be taken for joining with them in their trade, which was
as their lot, and brought in living, as others lived on their inheritances,
which at first were divided by lot. So lot is taken for a joint trade or course
of service or living. His lot was to burn incense, Luke 1.9. He had obtained a
part of this ministry, Act. 1.17. Join with us. We will have one way of
living, and that an easy one too, and live well upon it.

Let us all have, Heb. there shall be 'to all us. It rather should be
translated, We will all have one purse. We have a common stock already. If thou will live as we do, thou shall have as good a share of it as any of us, and
never want, while we be worth an halfpenny. So that it is their offer of a
share in the common stock with them.

One purse. Some derive (...), a purse, of (...), to number, or gather tribute.
For Tribute-money and other moneys are first told, and then put into the bag to
be kept. Hence come our English word Chest, such as we put money into. When he
says one purse, he does not mean but one, to restrain it, as Mal. 2.10. Have
we not all one Father? But a common purse, in which he should have as good a
share as they. They would communicate out of it alike to all. Our expenses
shall all come out of one purse. We will live in common, we will never quarrel
about division of shares, but fetch thence what we want. One purse here is the
same purse. And by a figure of the subject for the adjunct, the meaning is, The
same money shall maintain us all. It is an answer to a tacit objection which
the Novice might make. Ye are more then I, and acquainted with the trade, and
ye will expose me to the danger, as much and more then your selves, and give me
but a small pittance of the gain, as the Captains in war expose their soldiers
to most peril, but take the greatest part of the spoils to themselves. No, say
they, thou shall venture no farther then we, and live as plentifully as we upon
the common stock. All this while they say nothing of punishment, or loss,
which must be borne equally in partnership, because they feared it not, nor
would not speak any thing, that might discourage the Novice, but all that might
encourage him. As if they had said: Forbear not our company, because thou art
young, and not used to fighting. Though raw soldiers use to have but a small
share in the spoils, thou shall fare as well as we, that are thy leaders.

Figures. Lot for a Share in in their course of life. The cause for the effect.
Purse for money. The subject for the adjunct.

In the words note, 1. An invitation. 2. A promise. In the first note, 1. An
act, Cast in. 2. The object, thy lot. 3. The adjunct, among us.



In the second note, 1. The subject, we will have. 2. The adjuncts, 1 of
number, 2 of gain, one purse.


1. Doct. There is a communion of wicked men, as well as of Saints. When thou
saw a thief, then thou consentedst with him, and have been partaker with the
adulterers, Psalm. 50.18. They assemble themselves by troops in the Harlots
houses, Jer. 5.7. Company of Robbers and Pirates trade as well as Merchants and
Citizens.

Reason 1. Because of likeness of nature and qualities. They are the seed of
the Serpent. Bad men combine with bad, as good with good. So wise men converse
with the wise, fools with fools, old men with old men, young with young. Birds
of a Father fly together.

2. Hope of gain unites them together. The more Partners drive a trade, the
more hope of large income. A cipher alone is nothing. A figure alone is little,
but figures and ciphers together make great sums.

3. Their common hatred of good men, and such as fear God. With this vice
ungodly men are tainted. The seed of the Serpent bears enmity to the seed of
the woman, Genesis 3.15. The rule is, Quae in aliquo tertio convenient, inter se
convenient: Those things which agree in some third thing, agree among
themselves. Husbands and Wives love their Children, and love one another also.
So wicked men hating Gods people, love one another the more.

4. Safety and impunity in wicked ways. They can the better bear out one
another in evil courses, because they are many. Vis unita fortior: Force knit
together is the stronger. Therefore hand joins in hand, that the wicked may be
unpunished, Prove. 11.21.

Use. Take heed with whom ye join in a league, or in society, for all
friendship is not good. There be brethren in evil, and they get a curse, Genesis
49.5, etc.

2. Doct. Evil doers are very ready to receive, yea to invite others into
their society. So did the Pharisees compass Sea and Land to make one
Proselyte, Mat. 23.15. So do Popish Idolaters, Drunkards, Adulterers.

Reason 1. That they may have encouragement in sin. Solamen miscris socios
habuisse dolores. It is a comfort to men in misery to have companions in their
grief. So it is a comfort to sinners to have partners in their sins. If their
sins be objected, Why? others (say they) are as bad as we. A yoke is easier
borne by two, then by one.

2. That they may have help to act sin. Some sins are not committed with
pleasure without partners, as drunkenness and adultery. Others not with ease
or safety, as theft and murder.

Use. It teaches us to bewail the wickedness of our nature, that are not only
naught our selves, but also content to spoil others at an easy rate. Merchants
will look for a joint stock, before they admit of partners. Sinners admit, nay
invite men to come in for nothing.

3. Doct. Much gain is gotten by unlawful means. Many men by covetousness set
their nest on high, Hab. 2.9. Riches are called Mammon of unrighteousness,
Luke 16.9. Because most commonly gotten by ill means.

Reason 1. Because of Gods forbearance, who suffers men's wits to work
strangely, and though by unlawful means, yet to raise a great estate.
Sometimes bastards prosper more then legitimate children, as Jephthah did,
Judge. 11.1. So ill means thrive sometimes more then good.

2. Out of Gods indulgence, who is pleased to give to bad men, who make no
conscience of bad means, a large portion, as intending them no more. Men of the
world have their portion in this life, Psalm. 17.14. The rich man in his life
time received his good things, Luke 16.25. So Abraham dealt with the Sons of
the Concubines, Genesis 25.6. And the Father with his prodigal Son, Luke 15.12,
13.

Use. Take heed how ye get riches. Tradesmen use once a year to cast up their
Books. Would they would then consider how they get the overplus. Thieves may be
rich. Little comfort in ill got goods. Children will spend it as fast. De male
quaesitis non gaudet tertius haeres: Ill gotten goods joy not the third heir.

4. Doct. There is sometimes not only just, but also liberal dealing in
robbers among themselves. Have they not sped? Have they not divided the prey,
to every man a damoselor two? Judge. 5.30. Though they be false to others, they
will be honest among themselves.

Reason 1. To allure others to their society. Who might object, We must venture
life and blood, What shall we get? Answ. As much as we. I, but how will you be
true to me, that are false to others? They answer, We are not so among our
selves. We will be just and free to thee. Thou shall fare as well as the best
of us.

2. To cover their sin. Their smooth dealing among themselves is a fair Visard
to cover their harsh dealing with others.

Use. To blame those that would be thought to be honest men, and yet will cheat
their neighbors, friends, and kindred. Better dealing then this is to be found
among thieves, and robbers.

5. Doct. They that draw others to sin, speak the best, and hide the worst.
Jeremiah's enemies tell others of hope to prevail against him by slander and
reproaches, but never tell how God will protect his Prophet, Jerem. 18.18.
David's enemies encourage one another to rejoice in his ruin, never telling
that God would raise him up again, Psalm. 41.8.

Reason 1. Because this would spoil all the plot, Bad purposes prevail not,
where the issue is foretold.

2. Because else they should bewray their own folly, that will do things
themselves, and persuade others to do them, the inconvenience whereof their
own hearts know, and their own tongues witness.

Use. Take heed of those counsels gilded all over with fair pretenses. They
that mean well will tell inconveniences as well as conveniences. So does Christ
promise salvation to all believers, Joh. 3.16. Yet requires taking up the
cross, and following him with self-denial, Matt. 16.24. Believe not them that
talk much of wealth, and nothing of hell. Paena non separet, quos crimen
conjunxit. Vna poena implicet, quos unus amor in crimine ligat. Bern. Medit. c.
3. Let not the punishment divide those, whom the fault has joined together.
Let one punishment fold them up together, whom one love knits together in a
fault.

Verse. 15. My Son, walk not thou in the way with them, refrain thy foot from
their path.
Ye have the Robbers reasons to allure the young man to their course, now
follow Solomon's reasons to dissuade him from joining with them. Herein note,
1. A dehortation in this verse. 2. The reasons, to verse. 20.


For the first, and first for the words:

My Son. See on verse. 1. and v. 8.

Walk not. A counsel just opposed to theirs. They say, Walk with us, v. 11.
(for it is the same word in the Original) he says, Walk not with them. Walking
argues a continued action. It is not taking a step or two. So in the literal
signification, Laban went to shear his sheep, Genesis 31.19. Ye shall go after the
Ark, Josh. 3.3. So in the figurative sense it signifies going on in a wicked
way. Blessed is the man that walks not in the counsel of the ungodly, Psalm.
1.1. Walking then is continuing. Have not converse with them. Go not in the way
of evil men, Prove. 4.14. Accustom not thy self to do as they do. Sometimes it
signifies the course of livelesse things, as of a ship. There go the ships,
Psalm. 104.26. Here it is taken for joining with them in their wicked courses.

In the way. As the former word signifies a continuance, so this word (...),
signifies a distinct course from others, as the way to one Town differs from
the way to another. So in a literal sense. We went up the way to Bashan, Deuteronomy.
3.1. And in a figurative sense, for a distinct course of life, good or bad. The
Lord knows the way of the righteous, but the way of the wicked shall perish,
Psalm. 1.6. Some take it here, for not joining with thieves and robbers in their
unlawful courses. Others, for not joining with them in company or friendship,
for fear of infection, though they be employed about lawful things. Not to
delight in their company, unless nature, or our callings bind us, or hope of
doing them good. Much less have one stock, or common table with them, as they
would have thee do. Here it is taken in the first sense, as appears by the
next verse. Walk not in their evil ways with them, for they go to shed blood.
It comes from (...), to tread, because ways that men commonly walk in, are
more trodden then other parts of the earth. A foot-path, or highway is easily
discerned.

With them. With those robbers, that seek to draw thee to ill courses of life.

(...), Refrain, Set not a foot in their wicked ways. Be so far from
continuing in them, that thou do not so much as enter int them. Chapter 4.14. Enter
not into the path of the wicked. Or, it may be the same with the former, and
the thing doubled, to make the disswasion the more vehement. It may be
understood literally, Go not with them to rob, no not once. But rather
metaphorically. Do not so much as try their courses. Forbid thy foot to enter.
Suffer it by no means to do so.

(...). Thy foot. It may be taken literally, not to go in the way with them to
rob. Or metaphorically, not to use their affections (which are as the feet to
carry the soul to any thing desired) to spoil and rapine. So verse. 16. Their
feet run to evil. See the like, chapter 5.5. and 6.18.

(...), From their path. From going in it. It is used sometimes of a path in
Woods, where snares are laid to catch wild beasts. Shel. Jarchi. So Job 18.19.
A trap is laid for him in the way. If thou enter into their way, thou will be
taken either into a course of theevery, or danger, or both. Therefore follow
not their steps. It may be (...) may here signify a highway, and (...) a
foot-path. Neither go in their highways, nor by-ways, for robberies are
committed in both.

The sum of all is, as if he should have said, O my Son! sinners will entice
thee with these or such like words and promises, and lay such snares for thy
unexperienced youth; but remember that thou art my Son, and not theirs, and
therefore have more reason to hearken to me, who speak to thee out of a
fatherly affection. Hearken not therefore to their counsels, flatteries, or
promises. Show thy self so strange to them, that thou will not so much as enter
into their way, much walk in it.

For figures. The verse. is wholly metaphorical, taken from travelers, that
walk in one way to one Mart or Country for gain, as Merchants used to do in
those Countries, Genesis 37.28. So thieves rob together.

For the division of the words, note, 1. The person spoken to, My Son. 2. A
double exhortation:


1. Not to walk with them, or use their trade. And therein, 1. The act
forbidden, Walk not thou. 2. The object, in the way. 3. The adjunct, with them.


The second exhortation is to keep out of their way. And therein observe, 1.
The act, refrain. 2. The object, thy foot. 3. The subject, from their path.


1. Doct. Children should rather hearken to their Parents good counsel, then
to others bad. They must attend to their Fathers wisdom, that they may not be
seduced by the strange woman, chapter 5.1, 3. To their Mothers, rather then to
wanton women's, Prove. 31.1, 3.

Reason 1. In regard of the efficient. We are more engaged to Parents, then to
any other, for life, education, pains, and means.

2. Of the matter. The counsels are good that come from godly Parents, but bad,
that come from bad men or women. I give you good doctrine, Prove. 4.2. So says
Solomon to his Son. But the strumpet solicits the young man to wantonness. Let
us take our fill of love, chapter 7.18.

3. In regard of the form, or manner. Parents good counsels are given in love,
and come out of natural affection; bad men's counsels do not so.

4. Of the end, The former are for our good. The latter for our destruction.

Use 1. Behold another glass to see the wickedness of our nature. We are
readier to hearken to others, then to our Parents, to bad men, then to good
Parents; to bad counsels from them, then to good from Parents. We violate the
bands of nature, and grace. If we fall into misery by bad counsels, how can we
look our Parents in the face, or look for comfort and relief from them whose
good counsels we have slighted?

2. Doct. Young men had need to labor for knowledge to discern between good
counsel and bad. If he will cleanse his way, he must take heed thereto according
to Gods Word, Psalm. 119.9. Rehoboam lost his Kingdom for lack of such
knowledge. He forsook the counsel of grave men, to follow the advice of young
giddy heads, 1 King. 12.8. The Rechabites flourished by preferring good counsel
before bad, Jer. 35.18, 19.

Reason 1. Because they shall be often put to it. Where God has a Church, the
Devil has a Chapel. If Parents give good counsel, youths of our age, and such
as live by sin, will give bad. Young men stand between both as Hercules in his
dream, between Virtue and Vice, solicited by both. They had need therefore
weigh whose reasons be best, as a woman having many Suitors, had need be
careful which she takes.

2. There are fair pretenses for all sins. Gluttony is called the free use of
the Creature; Drunkenness, Good fellowship; Prodigality is called Liberality;
Covetousness, Thrift; Lust is entitled Love; Pride goes for Handsomnesse. It
needs a good Touchstone to distinguish between Gold and Copper, well guilt
over. No less skill is needful to distinguish between true and apparent good.

Use. Ye young men, think it not enough to seek for knowledge when ye grow
elder, the Devil will set upon you when ye are young. If you know not good from
evil, your corrupt nature will certainly lead you into evil. Take two
directions:

1. Weigh things by the light of Reason left in you. That will acquaint you with
many things in morality, and tell you, that theft, adultery, murder are naught,
else have ye no assurance of your own goods, wives, lives.

2. Look higher to the light of Scripture. That will inform you in many higher
things; yea, thoughts themselves. In a dark shop men will not be content with a
candle, but bring things forth to the daylight. Those things are sincere that
can bear the light of the Sun. There is need of knowledge and judgment to
approve things, or to discern things that differ, or that are excellent, that
men may be sincere, Gr. (...), Phil. 1.10. judged by the Sun. So men try wares.
And so the Eagle tryes her young ones, if they look upon the Sun, else she
throws them down for bastards.

3. Doct. Allurements to sin are no excuse for sin. Eve cannot justly lay her
fault on the Serpent, nor Adam on Eve, Genesis 3. God will take it off, and lay
the curse on them. Readiness provocation by the people would not bear him out for
his sin against God. He must lose his Kingdom, 1 Samuel 15.15, 26. The young
man, though solicited by the Harlot, Pro. 7.14, 21. yet has a dart strike
through his heart, v. 23. there.

Reason 1. Because allurers have no power to compel. They may and ought to be
refused. The will may be inclined, by convincing or cousening the
understanding, but cannot be compelled by Angel or Devil. Debilis est
adversarius diabolus; nisi volentem non vincit: The devil is a weak adversary,
