he overcomes none but such as are willing to be overcome. God can alter it, but
not compel it.

It is a sign of folly in us to be allured by fair pretenses to that that
would undo us. He goes after her as a fool to the correction of the stocks,
Prove. 7.22.

Use. It condemns their folly, who lay their faults upon others, and look to be
pityed, because allured. As if a bird should say, I saw the corn, but not the
pit-fall; or a fish complain, that it saw the bait, but not the hook. Take heed
before ye fin. It is too late to complain after. Bought wit is deer.

4. Doct. Company excuses no man in his sins. This knew David, and therefore
would not come in company with ungodly persons, Psalm. 26.4, 5. And verse. 9.
there he prays, Gather not my soul with sinners. A good Gentlewoman troubled in
conscience when she was to die, cried out, O Lord, let me not go to hell, where
the wicked are, for Lord thou know I never loved their company here. God
objects it as a vice: thou have been partaker with adulterers, Psalm. 50.18.

Reason 1. Company cannot alter the nature of things. It cannot make good,
evil; nor evil, good.

2. There is choice of company, else were it a sore temptation to evil, if all
were bad, because man is a sociable creature.

Use. It blames those that lay the fault of their own naughtiness upon their
company. I had never been drunk or wanton, but that I fell into drunken or
wanton company. This is no excuse, yea although we have store of company in our
sinful ways. Thou shall not follow a multitude to do evil, Exodus 23.2.
Neither will company of great or wise men excuse us, for God has not chosen
many such, 1 Cor. 1.26. Nor of teachers. They may perish as workers of
iniquity, Matt. 7.22, 23. Nor of good men. It was no excuse to Barnabas his
dissimulation, that he had Peter's company, Gal. 2.11, 12, 13. Company may draw
our corrupt nature to sin, but cannot excuse us for sin. Take heed then of bad
company. Keep not company with bad men, no more then may be for thy good, or
theirs, or then Gods Law binds thee. Eagle, Hawke, and Raven, ravening fowls
might not be eaten in the time of the Law. It signified no incorporating into
wicked men's society. Their example will corrupt. Horses treading in the steps
of Wolves, catch much harm, and abate of their swiftness. Plin. Hist. l. 28.
c. 10. Claudum facit vicinus claudus: A lame neighbor may make a man lame. Dum
spectant oculi laesos, laeduntur and ipsi: Sore eyes make other men's eyes sore.
Ovid. Plato's friends did imitate his swelling or crookedness. Aristotle's
stammering was imitated. Alexander's shrill voice. Plutarch. Malus ipse fies,
si malis convixeris. Aristot. Moral. 9. Thou will be made evil, if thou
converse with evil men. Touch pitch, and be defiled. Sumuntur a conversantibus
mores, and ut quaedam in contactu corporis vitia transeunt, ita animus mala sua
proximis tradit. Seneca de ira. l. 3. c. 8. Manners are taken from those with
whom we converse; and as some diseases of the body are communicated by the
touch, so does the mind deliver her evil qualities to her neighbors.
Drunkards make more in love with wine, Wantons with women, covetous men with
money. As on the contrary, good company brings others to good, as a good soil
and air brings health. And wild beasts are tamed, being fed by men, and
conversing with them. If ye will sin with them, ye must suffer with them. Non
minus ardebit, qui cum multis ardebit. August. He burns no less, that burns
with company.

5. Doct. Continuance or walking in sin is dangerous. It brought destruction on
Priests and people, 2 Chr. 36.14, etc. and Hos. 11.2.

Reason 1. It is a sign of an hard heart to continue in sin. The mouth of the
conscience is stopped.

2. It makes the heart more hard still. Custom will make a man not start at
greatest sins. Consuetudo peccandi tollit sensum peccati: A custom of sinning
takes away the feeling of sin. They cannot cease from sin, 2 Pet. 2.14.

Use. Break off fin by repentance, Dan. 4.27. Time past was too much for
finfull ways, 1 Pet. 4.3.

6. Doct. The very entrance into finfull ways is full of danger, like a
downfall. No stay till ye come to the bottom. Prove. 4.14. The young man is
there advised to pass away, and not to come nigh it, as men go far off from
infected houses, Prove. 5.8. Ye will hardly ever get out again. Like suretiship
set out by a man entering into the wide end of a horn, and sticking in the
narrow end.

Use. Keep out of evil ways, or get out quickly. Non diu tutus, qui periculo
proximus. Cypr. He is not long safe that is near danger. Nolo vicino Serpente
dormire. Fieri potest, ut me mordeat; fieripotest, ut non me mordeat: I will
not sleep near a Serpent; perhaps she may bite me, perhaps she may not bite me.

Verse. 16. For their feet run to evil, and make have to shed blood.
The Dehortation was in the former verse. the Reasons follow. That it might
appear that he had more weighty reasons to dissuade them, then the Thieves had
to persuade. Wherein note, 1. The arguments, v. 16, 17, 18. 2. A general
conclusion out of them, verse. 19.


The arguments are very strong, not only in their own weight, but quoad
hominem, fit to convince them, as being all taken out of their own confessions.

1. From the cruelty of their intentions, verse. 16. out of verse. 11.

2. From the causelesnesse, out of verse. 11. also. For they sought innocent
blood without cause.

3. From the craftiness of their plots, verse. 18. out of v. 11. From laying
wait, and lurking privily.

The conclusion follows, verse. 19. that not only Robbers, but also Cheaters,
and all other sorts of covetous persons will fall to shedding of blood in the
end.

For the words.

For. See on v. 9. This the word of coherence, and ushers in a reason of the
former dehortation. They may give thee good words, and color over their bloody
intentions, as if they meant only to enrich themselves out of other men's
estates, and not to meddle with their persons. But these are but figleaves.
They will not stick at blood, rather then lose their booty. Therefore join not
with them, for they are not only covetous, but cruel also.

Their feet. See on v. 15.

(...), Run. The word running intends not only aiming at it, as at a goal, or
prize, but also making haste to attain it, 1 Cor. 9.24. It signifies out of a
readiness of mind, and great desire of the prey, to make haste to obtain it.
The same words (all but one) are used, Isa. 59.7. Here feet run, but Psalm.
68.31. hands are said to run, or soon to be stretched out to God, to show the
great hasse of those Nations to embrace Religion. Their mischievous intention
is here amplified by the haste they make to effect it, and by their violent
prosecution of it. They hasten with both feet.

(...), To evil. It is taken sometime for evil of sin. I have done this evil
in thy sight, Psalm. 51.4. Sometime for evil of trouble. And that,

1. To themselves. Woe be to him that coveteth an evil covetousness to his
house, Hab. 2.9.

2. To others. If it please my Father to do thee evil, 1 Samuel 20.3. So it is
intended here of evil to others, as appears by the words before, verse. 11. Let
us lay wait for blood. And by the words immediately following to the same
purpose. It may be meant either of rapine, or of murder. Both are evil.

(...), And make baste. This shows the meaning of the former word running.
Their feet are swift to shed blood, Romans 3.15. The word signifies,

1. To do a thing quickly, or speedily. Their sorrows shall be multiplied that
hasten after another God, Psalm 16.4.

2. To give a dowry to one. He shall surely endow her to be his wife, Exodus
21.16.

3. To do a thing rashly, as things done in haste lightly are. The counsel of
the froward is carried headlong, Job 5.13. Here it is taken in the first sense,
to set forth speed in accomplishing their evil designs.

(...), To shed. Not to let out some part of the blood for good, but to pour it
out abundantly, till one be dead; for the life is in the blood, Genesis 9.4.

Blood. See on verse. 11. Some understand it of their own blood. They rob, till
they come to the gallows. And sometimes falling out about dividing their prey,
they kill one another. Stobaeus tit. 10. de Avar. quotes Aristotle, saying,
that eight thieves falling out about the division of the prey, four of them
first killed the other four. Then two of them which were left, killed the other
two. Lastly, of the two yet left, one killed the other. There was no end of
slaughter, til one only was left. But here it is meant of others blood, as
appears by v. 11. and v. 18.

This is the first reason, and a strong and powerful one to dissuade the young
man from joining with them, or so much as entering into their way, because they
mind nothing that is honest, but breath out bloodshed, and horrible sins
against nature, which may make them and their courses justly odious to all men.
Few beasts will kill others of the same kind. Much less should men that have
reason. This is a very great wickedness. Therefore thou must not look so much
at the riches and spoils they promise thee, as at the gross evil they provoke
thee to, which even nature it self abhors.

Thus ye see the strength of Solomon's first reason to dissuade the young man
from joining with evil men in their sinful ways.

Figures. To shed blood. To commit murder. A figure of the cause for the effect.

Note 1. The coherence, For. 2. The sentence. And in it, 1. A general
accusation. 2. A particular. In the general, 1. The agent, their feet. 2. The
act, run. 3. The object, to evil.


In the particular, 1. The act, they make haste. 2. The object, to shed blood.


1. Doct. Good counsels must be backed with reasons. God must be praised by
righteous men, because it becomes them, and God deserves it, Psalm. 33.1, etc.
We must not fret at evil men, because they shall be cut off, Psalm. 37.1. So
Prove. 1.8, 9. and 3.1, 2.

Reason 1. To draw men's affections; for it is not enough to inform the
judgment. The will and affections are more corrupt then it. The Heathen woman
could say, Video meliora, proboque, deteriora sequor: I see and like the best,
but follow the worst. It is not the least work of a Teacher, to move the
affections. There may be light, but no life without this. What had the Sun been
good for, if God had made no living creature to behold it? Vela damus, quamvis
remige puppis eat. Ovid. Tide, and oars, and sails are needful on the water.
So are Doctrines, Reasons, and Uses in a Sermon.

2. To dead objections, and oppositions, as mud-wals dead bullets. The devil
will have something to object against all Theorical and Practical truths. We
must have some solid reasons to weigh down his seeming arguments.

Use. It shows the need, and justifies the practice of Ministers, in not only
laying down, but also backing truths with reasons, that they may work both on
head and heart.

2. Doct. There is no member of the body so vile or mean, but may be an
instrument of sin and mischief. Ye have yielded your members servants to
uncleanness, and to iniquity unto iniquity, Romans 6.19. So many use their
throat, tongues, lips, mouth, feet, Romans 3.13, 14, 15. As birds use their beaks
and talons; wild beasts, their teeth, claws, and tails; tame beasts, their
horns and hoofs to do hurt. And men have eyes for adultery. As David, 2 Samuel
11.2. and ungodly men, Having eyes full of adultery, 2 Pet. 2.14. Others have
eyes for covetousness, as I saw a goodly Babylonish garment, etc. Then I
coveted them. And Ahab had eyes to covet Naboth's vineyard, 1 King. 21.1. Men
have ears ready to hear wanton songs, slanders, etc. Tongues for swearing,
lying, flattering, backbiting, called the third tongue in Chaldee, because it
hurts the speaker, hearer, and person spoken of. Hands to strike, kill, steal.
Feet to carry the whole body to mischief.

Use 1. It teaches us to bewail the spreading of corruption in us. It cannot
be enclosed in the soul, but runs over every member of the body. No Physician
can tell all the diseases of the eye, much less the sins of it.

2. It shows us our great account, that besides secret sins, have so many to
answer for in every member.

3. It calls upon us for suspicion of, and watchfulness over every member. Not
of the Eye, or Ear alone, but of all.

3. Doct. Wicked men have a great affection, desire, and pronenesse to
wickedness. As men have to those things they run after, who yet hate those
things from which they fly. Wickedness is sweet in his mouth, he hides it
under his tongue. He spares it, and forsakes it not, but keeps it still within
his mouth, Job 20.12, 13. Why boastest thou thy self in mischief, O mighty man?
Psalm. 51.1. And sure men greatly affect what they boast of.

Reason 1. Because it is pleasing to their corrupt nature. The Iron follows the
Loadstone by a natural sympathy. So do wicked men pursue sinful courses.

2. Custom makes it dear to them. Men are pleased with customs without a
reason.

Use. Hence may we discern the vileness of our nature. It were a stain to it
to be drawn to sin, but to love that which is evil, and delight in it, and run
to it, without solicitation, argues a desperately corrupted nature.

4. Doct. Sin is truly evil and hurtful. I have done this evil in thy sight,
Psalm. 51.4. Evil shall hunt the violent man, to overthrow him, Psalm. 140.11.
Sin is evil by name, and evil by nature. For it is (...), a breach of Gods
Law, or an unlawful act, 1 John 3.4. It may be said of sin as Abigail speaks
of her Husband, Nabal (or fool) Is his name, and folly is with him, 1 Samuel
25.25. So evil is the name of sin, and evil is in it. It is the brood of that
evil one. It is evil before God whom it dishonors, and who cries out against
it. Before men, who make laws against it. Hurtful to others, as all fins
against the second Table, being hurtful to men's lives, wives, children,
states, liberty, credit. Sin will pull down Church and Commonwealth. It is
hurtful to our selves, bringing down many judgments on us. It is evil
privatively, depriving us of much good. Evil positively, inflicting much
sorrow. Evil spiritually, bringing spiritual judgments on the soul. Evil
corporally, bringing much pain to the body. Evil eternally, making soul and
body for ever miserable.

Use 1. Hate all sin, God is the object of love: Evil, of hatred. Ye that love
the Lord, hate evil, Psalm. 97.10. Amat Deum? debes odisse quod odit: Love
thou God? then must thou hate what he hates. August.

2. Beware of acting sin. It is a disgrace to thee, and matter of danger.

5. Doct. Sinners are very nimble and industrious about sinful actions.
Jezabel quickly finds a way to get away Naboth's vineyard, 1 King. 21.7, etc.
And Judas to bewray Christ, Mat. 26.15.

Reason 1. From an internal principle of love of sin. Men are very nimble
about what they love.

2. From an external principle of custom. It is their trade, and men are very
nimble about their trade, that go dully about other things. They are in their
element. Elementum in loco suo non ponderat: An element is not weighty in its
own place. How swift is water in the river? How dull out of it?

Use. Marvel not at sudden villainies, as robberies, murders, treasons. Wicked
men are quick at such things.

6. Doct. Great sins are readily swallowed by ungodly men. As murder, and
oppression. Ahab can swallow Naboth's vineyard and life at a morsel, 1 King.
21. And Judas can digest the murder of Christ, and thirty pieces of silver to
boot, Matt. 26.15. Some are so wicked they can murder Father and Mother, 1 Timothy
1.9. Cain killed his own Brother, Genesis 4.8.

Reason 1. They see not the evil of them.

2. They foresee not the danger of them.

Use. Marvel not at great wickednesses, while there be wicked men in the
world. Fire will burn down, water overflow all before it.

Verse. 17. Surely in vain the net is spread in the sight of any bird.
We come now to Solomon's second argument, to dissuade the young man from
joining with these sinners. And that is taken from the injustice of their
course. They wrong others without provocation by them, or merit of evil in
them. It may be the young man might object against the first argument,
peradventure they had just cause to take the rich men's lives, as well as their
goods. It may be that they have committed some great evil, or done them much
wrong. No, says Solomon, they had no cause at all to proceed so cruelly
against them neither for any wrong done to themselves, nor others. It proceeds
merely from their own covetous, and cruel disposition. They have given them no
more cause then the bird does to the fowler, to take away his life.

For the words.

(...), Surely. So it is translated. Surely we will return with thee, Ruth
1.10. And then it is an earnest asseveration of the truth of what is said. It
is as sure, thieves kill without a cause, as that fowlers kill harmless birds.
It may be read For, as it is, v. 9. and v. 16. And then it ushers in a second
reason, to dissuade the young man from joining with them, v. 15. because they
are unjust as well as cruel. For it cannot be a reason of the Thieves curelty,
mentioned v. 16. for they are not curel because they have no cause, but though
they have no cause.

(...), In vain. So our Translation and some others read it. Some take it to be
in vain in regard of the bird, which will take no warning, but will fly to the
meat, although it fall into the net. So will Thieves go on till they come to
the gallows, notwithstanding examples of others hanged before, or counsels of
friends. They will rob, though they be hanged, and for present content, they
will adventure suture ruin. Their eyes are dazeled with the fight of gain, so
that they see not the danger. Others take it to be in vain in regard of the
fowler, who is not always sure to catch the birds, for many times they spy the
net, and fly away. And this some apply to the Thieves alluring the young man.
They often miss the precious things they aim at, the owners espying their
evil intentions, and preventing them. Therefore join not thou with them, upon
hope of uncertain gain. Others apply it to the young man himself, as if Solomon
had said, If birds have wit to see and avoid snares, thou my Son being a
reasonable creature, should much more (especially being warned by me) see the
danger of these evil men's counsels, and not dare to join with them. But the
word should rather be translated without cause, as it is v. 11. As fowlers kill
birds taken in the net, though they never wronged them, that so they may feed
on them, so do these most unjustly kill them they rob, as ver. 11. and 19.
show. The one says, they lie in wait for them causelessly, and the other, that
they take away their lives. So the word is also used, chap. 3.30. Strive not
with a man without cause, if he have done thee no harm. Object not, that they
will not be so cruel, though they be covetous, for though men's riches may do
them good, yet they have given no cause to take away their lives. No more has
the bird to the fowler. But as the fowler cannot feed on the bird, unless he
kill it, no more can they rob sometimes without killing.

(...), The net. It is taken,

1. Literally, for an engine to catch birds, beasts, or fishes. Ye have been a
net spread upon Tabor, Hos. 4.1.

2. For network, made like a net. Thou shall make for it a grate of network
of brass, Exodus 27.4.

3. For devices to entrap men. In the net which they hid is their own foot
taken, Psalm. 9.15. Here it is used in the first sense, yet the third intended
in the application of the similitude, as appears, v. 18.

Is spread. Laid abroad at length, that it may catch the bird, if it come
within the verge of it.

In the sight. Heb. in the eyes, (...) signifies,

1. The eye, in which is placed the Sense of seeing. The eye is not satisfied
with seeing, Eccl. 1.8.

2. The sight which is by the eye. The heavens are not clean in his sight, Job
15.15. So here, where the bird either does see it, or may see it, if he will
look about him; or, where birds use to haunt.

(...), Of any. Not of every bird, but of any bird. So it signifies here, and
that without a negative particle with it. A thing not observed in Grammars and
Dictionaries. So Job 8.12. It withers before any other herb. For the word
see on v. 13. on the word All.

Bird. Heb. owner or possessour of a wing. That has a wing at command to fly
withal. Thus God distinguishes birds from beasts and fishes. A bird of the
air shall carry the voice, and that which has wings shall tell the matter,
Eccl. 10.20. So the Owner is in the Original called the possessour of riches,
v. 19. And the Ram that had two horns, is called, The possessour of two horns,
Dan. 8.6. The Hebr. word (...), signifies,

1. An owner or possessor of a thing. The Master of the house shall be brought
unto the Judges, Exodus 22.8. that is, The owner or possessour of it. He that
dwells in it.

2. A chief or honorable man. The Priest shall not defile himself, being a
chief man among his people, Lev. 21.4.

3. An husband. If he were married, Exodus 21.3. Hebr. if he were the husband of
a wife.

4. An Idol, called Baal. He brought him up into the high places of Baal, Numb.
22.41.

5. A Lord. Call me no more Baali, that is, My Lord, as in the marg. Hos. 2.16.

6. An inhabitant. So it is rendered, The men of Shechem, Judge. 9.20.

Here it is taken in the first sense, for the possessour of a wing, that is, a
bird. The word (...), signifies,

1. A wing. Every winged soul after his kind, Genesis 1.21.

2. It is put for the swiftness of the wind, which seems to fly, it is so
quick, and carries ships away apace. He did fly upon the wings of the wind,
Psalm. 18.10.

3. For the utmost part of any thing. As,

1. Of a garment. They shall make them fringes in the borders of their
garments, Numb. 15.38.

2. For the sails of a ship, which are spread like wings, and make ships as it
were to fly. Woe to the Land shadowing with wings, Isa. 18.1. That is, sending
forth ships with sails, as appears v. 2. there.

3. For the wings of an Army. The stretching out of his wings shall fill the
breadth of thy Land, O Immanuel, Isa. 8.8.

4. The farthest part of the earth. From the four corners of the earth, Isa.
11.12.

5. The springing of the morning light, which begins far from us. The Sun of
righteousness shall arise with healing in his wings, Mal. 4.2. Here it is used
in the first sense, for the wing of a bird.

Figures none, except eyes for sight. The cause for the effect.

Note 1. The manner of speaking, Surely.

2. The matter. And in it, 1. The subject, the net. 2. The adjuncts. 1 Is
spread. 2 Without cause. 3. The object. In the sight of any bird.


1. Doct. Variety of reasons are needful todisswade from evil. See how many
curses are threatened against it, Deuter. chapter 27. and 28.

Reason 1. Because of our privative unbeleef. We are hardly drawn to believe
any spiritual truth, and divine. O fools and slow of heart, to believe all
that the Prophets have spoken, Luke 24.25. A weak house must have many props,
else it will fall.

2. Because of our positive unbeleef. We are opposite to matters of faith and
holiness, and can reason strongly against our own salvation. We had need of
many bullets to beat down this sort.

3. Because of men's different dispositions. One affects wit, another credit,
another profit, another pleasure. All these must be wrought upon accordingly. A
fisher must have several baits for several fishes, worms for one, flies for
another, paste for another. One man is loving, another harsh; one stout,
another fearful; one fed with hopes, another affected only with things
present. Perswaders to good, or from evil, must proceed accordingly. Decet
veritatem, totis viribus uti suis, non ut laborantem: It becomes truth to use
all her forces, not as if it had much adce to uphold her self. Tertull. advers.
Marc. l. 3.

4. To confirm our selves in the truth, else we shall never work well upon
others.

Use. To persuade us to study the Scripture well, if we would be able to give
counsel to others to draw them to good, or from evil; for there is the
storehouse of truth, and abundance of reasons, and stronger then either nature
or art can afford, to work upon men's judgment, or affections.

2. Doct. Reasons brought to confirm truth must be solid ones. So Christ
confutes the Sadduces by a sentence out of the Law. I am the God of Abraham,
the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. God is not the God of the dead, but of
the living, Matt. 22.32. It is conceived the Sadduces believed only the five
Books of Moses, and therefore our Savior out of them brings his proof, that
could have brought plainer out of the Prophets, if he had pleased, as Dan.
12.2. Many of them that sleep in the dust of the earth, shall awake, some to
everlasting life, and some to shame, and everlasting contempt. So he confuteth
the Pharisees, who maintained that a man might swear by the Temple, but not by
the gold of the Temple, by an undeniable argument; Ye fools and blind, for
whether is greater, the gold, or the Temple that sanctifies the gold? Matt.
23.17. So Paul reproves fornicators, in that they make the members of Christ
the members of an harlot, 1 Cor. 6.15. So he confutes communion with Idolaters,
because therein they have fellowship with devils, 1 Cor. 10.20.

Reason 1. Because nothing but truth should come from an informer, else he may
be a blind guide, and fall, and lead others into the ditch.

2. Reasons ought not only to be true, but also to bear up other truths. All
stones in a building should be firm, but especially the foundation stones. What
is a lying witness worth, or a beggarly surety? The Rabbis say of a weak
argument, (...), Your surety wants a surety. And the Logicians cry out,
Incertum per incertius: Ye prove an uncertainty by a greater uncertainty.

3. Else we cannot satisfy our selves. And how should a man think to persuade
others by that which persuades not himself?

4. Our reasons should not only satisfy others, but be so strong, that they
may convince them, and stop their mouths. A minister must be able by sound
doctrine both to exhort and convince the gainsayers, Tit. 1.9. Therefore their
reasons had need be strong.

Use. Let us weigh our arguments well in our own souls, before we present them
to others. So men measure their corn at home, before they bring it to Market,
that it may not fall short. Else we cannot hope to persuade others to good, or
dissuade them from evil, if our arguments prevail not first with our selves.

3. Doct. There is a world of injustice in the world. As in Heathen Niniveh.
The Lion did tear in pieces enough for his whelps, and strangled for his
lionesses, and filled his holes with prey, and his dens with ravine, Nah. 2.12.
Woe to the bloody City. It is all full of lies and robbery, the prey departs
not, Nahum 3.1. So in idolatrous Israel, Ahab must have Naboth's vineyard, 1
King. 21. It is full of lying, killing, stealing, Hos. 4.1. In Judab also
professing Religion in David's old days. It is like Absalom had some color of
complaint, by reason of officers oppression. No man is deputed of the King to
hear thee, 2 Samuel 15.3. And in Israel, in Samuel's old days. His Sons turned
aside after lucre, and took bribes, and perverted judgment, 1 Samuel 8.3. Samuel
could say, Whose ox have I taken? or whose ass have I taken, etc. 1 Samuel
12.3. But his Sons could not say so.

Reason 1. Because men have different humors, and affections; some spleenful,
some fearful, some covetous, some ambitious.

2. They have diverse degrees. Some are great, and think they may do what they
will with mean ones. Some low, and do wrong for need. They are poor, and steal,
Prove. 30.3. Some of a middle rank, who envy superiors, slight inferiors, and
wrong both.

Use. Let us be just in the midst of an unjust generation, as Noah was, Genesis
6.9. and as Paul would have the Philippians to be, Phil. 3.15. and as the
middle region of the air is cold, being between the upper region hot, as being
nearer the Sun; and the lower hot by reflection.

The net is spread. Fowlers have nets, and spread them to take innocent birds,
that they may be sure they may not escape.

4. Doct. Wicked men have cunning devices to do mischief. As Absalom, to get
away the hearts of his Fathers Subjects by flattery, 1 Samuel 15.3. And Ishmael
by tears to call them to Gedaliah, whom he had slain before, and so to kill
them, Jer. 41.2, 6, 7.

Reason 1. To expedite the business the sooner, that they may quickly effect
their desires. They long to be rid of their mischievous designs, as a woman
with-childe of her burden. Behold, he travaileth with iniquity, Psalm. 7.14. As
the Mathematician that made an Engine to convey a Ship into the Sea with one
hand, which others could not do with much help, was a cunning man. So have
wicked men curious fetches to hurt others.

2. To remove all impediments, which requires much skill.

Use. Take heed of ungodly men's plots. Use the Doves innocence, but with the
Serpents subtilty, Matthew. 10.16.

5. Doct. God has put some visible distinction between visible creatures.
Birds are distinguished from Beasts by wings. He made birds to fly in the air,
fishes to swim in the sea, beasts to go on the earth, Genesis 1.

Reason. To show Gods wisdom, that has set a several mark on all creatures,
in their several kinds.

Use. Let us in beholding the variety of the creatures, give God the glory of
his wisdom, Romans 1.20, 21.

6. Doct. Creatures have a lawful power over their members. A bird is Master
of a wing.

Reason. God gives them this power.

Use. Honor God then with your members. Yield your members servants to
righteousness unto holiness, Romans 6.19.

Verse. 18. And they lay wait for their own blood, they lurk privily for their
own lives.
Here the Wiseman proceeds to a third argument, to dissuade the young man from
joining with these robbers. The first was from their cruelty, v. 16. The
second, from their injustice, v. 17. The third in this verse. from their craft
and indirect dealing, to bring their wicked ends to pass.

For the words.

And, or So. For thus this word is translated, Pro. 25.23. The North Wind
drives away rain, so does an angry countenance at back biting tongue. It sets
forth a reddition to a similitude. So it may do here. As the Fowlers without
provocation, lay wait to kill the harmless birds, that they may devour them,
so robbers without provocation lurk privily to kill men, that they may deprive
them of their riches.

They lay wait. See on v. 11.

For their own. It may be translated their, or their own. And therefore the
word own is in a little letter, as not necessarily included in the Original
word. They that take it for their own, understand it thus. These robbers, that
are so solicitous to draw thee into their society think to undo others, but
indeed undo themselves in the end. They come to the gallows. They do as it
were hold a pistol with a dark lantern in their hand, and when they think to
kill others, shoot themselves to death. Quae rapina sublata funt, raptorem
rapiunt. Ab Ezr. Things unjustly snatched away, snatch away the snateher. Some
hold on the comparison, and read it their, not their own, and understand it of
the birds, which the fowlers are not content to take, but kill them also. And
they make the reddition, v. 19. But the best way is to read it their, and apply
it to the rich men whom the thieves would rob. And so it is a part of the
application. As Fowlers lay wait to kill birds, so thieves to kill men. The
reasons to enforce this interpretation, are these.

1. They that are to be killed are those whose blood they laid wait for, v. 11.
which was not their own, but such as they would rob. And swallow up alive, v.
12. And find riches in their houses, v. 13.

2. Because the other interpretation agrees not with the similitude, v. 17. for
fowlers run no danger themselves in catching or killing birds. No law lays
hold on their lives. So it should be a dissimilitude rather then a similitude.
Though fowlers get no harm by killing birds, yet thou shall perish with
murdering thieves, if thou join with them. But this agrees not with the words.

3. Because it agrees not with v. 19. They seek the life of the owners of those
riches, and not their own lives. To conclude, the dehortation is not taken
from the hurt that might befall the young man, if he join with them, but that
might betide others by his joining with them in their crafty ways, which will
not only be the loss of their estates, but of their lives also sometimes,
which the young man, not used to blood and fraud, would startle at in
likelihood, though the seducers used to it could shed blood without remorse.

Blood. See on v. 11. They lurk privily. See on v. 11.

For their own. Rather for their. That is, for to kill those whom they rob.
See before in this verse.

(...), Their lives. Heb. Their souls. The word signifies,

1. The breath. His breath kindles coals, Job 41.21.

2. The life, which cannot be without breathing. But flesh with the life
thereof, shall ye not eat, Genesis 9.4.

3. The soul, the cause and fountain of life. Man became a living soul, Genesis
2.7.

4. A living body. Let the earth bring forth the living creature, Genesis 1.24.

5. A man. The souls, that came out of the loins of Jacob, Exodus 1.5. That is,
the men.

6. The body of a man. He was laid in iron, Psalm. 105.18. Heb. His soul came
into iron. As in the marg. of your Bibles. Yet it was the body of Joseph only,
for his soul could not be bound in iron.

7. A dead car^ase that had once a soul in it. Whosoever touches any thing, that
is unclean by the dead, Lev. 22.4. Heb. by a soul.

8. The heart, mind, or desire of a man. Ye know the heart of a stranger,
Exodus 23.9. Heb. the sul.

9. For God himself, as the soul of man was taken for the man himself, in the
fifth signification. The Lord God has sworn by himself, Amos 6.8. Heb. by his
soul.

Here it is taken in the second sense, for the life, because as the breath is
the sign of life, so the presence of the soul is the cause of life, and the
absence of it the cause of death. Faulkeners if they catch birds in the net,
kill them. If not, they shoot them. So do robbers with men. They kill them with
the sword, or with the gun. Thus the Adulteress seeks a man's life, chapter 6.26.
and 7.22, 23.

Figures. Blood for life, and soul for life. The cause for the effect. The same
thing is doubled in diverse words, to show the certainty of it, that this is
indeed the intention of robbers, what ever they pretend to the young man. So
Pharaoh's dream was doubled, to show, that the thing was established by God,
and God would shortly bring it to pass, Genesis 41.32. And Kimchi on those words,
Isa. 1.2. I have nourished and brought up children, says, The doubling of the
word is to confirm the thing in diverse words, though the matter be all one,
(...) And such is the custom of the Scripture in many places.

For the division:

Note 1. The efficient, They, the robbers.

2. The act, lay wait, lork privily.

3. The object, for their blood, for their lives. To murder such as they rob.
It agrees with the former verse. thus. As fowlers lie hid themselves, and lay
their nets, where birds come, to catch and kill them, though they never hurt
them; so these robbers lie hid privily to entrap them that hurt them not, and
to kill them for their goods.

1. Doct. Similitudes rightly applied are of great use. They are much used in
the Scriptures of the Old and New Testament. As by Moses, Deuteronomy. 32.11, 12.
Where Gods care of his is set out by the Eagles tender care of her young ones.
By the Prophets, Isa. 49.15, 16. which sets it out by the Mothers respect to
her young children. By Christ, Matt. 13. who take similies from Sea, Land,
Trade, Husbandry, to teach all sorts of men piety. By the Apostles, Jude v. 12,
13. where the like are taken from Bodies of men, Heaven, Earth, Sea.

Reason 1. Because they help the understanding much. For earthly things are
better known to us then heavenly. They are glasses, in which we may see better
things. The eyes convey much knowledge to the soul.

2. Similitudes help the memory, for things seen are tokens of things unseen,
as a thread on the finger of an errand. The act of memory lodges one thing in
one corner of the room, another in another.

3. They help the will. When we see the willingness of beasts to provide for
their young, it puts Parents in mind of their duty.

4. They help the conscience. A similitude helped David to see his sin quickly,
2 Samuel 12.1, etc. He could soon condemn him that killed his neighbors
Ewe-lamb, that would hardly else have condemned himself for killing his
neighbor, and abusing his Wife.

5. They help the affections. The attractive ones are helped by similies taken
from things liked; the abstractive by similies taken from things disliked.

6. They help to amend our lives. The Ant can teach the Sluggard to labor.

Use 1. Treasure up store of similitudes. All places afford plenty of them.
Sea, land, shop, house, streets, fields, are not barren. What can you do that
may not teach you some good lesson for your souls?

2. Be sure to apply them right, else they may do much harm. As that parable,
Mat. 18.23. where the Lords revoking his pardon, verse. 34. is applied to
falling away from grace, contrary to Christ's interpretation, verse. 35. God will
not forgive you, unless you forgive others. Simile non currit quatuor pedibus:
No similitude runs on four legs. If it agree in some things, it must differ in
others, else it were not the like, but the same. And what application can be
better, then that which leads to the scope of the propounder? Theologia
symbolica, non est argumentativa. Similitudes making nothing true, but
illustrate things that were true before. The absurdest thing in the world might
be proved by some similitude. As that Parents need take no more care for their
children, then the Ostriches do for their eggs, Job 39.13, etc. But what child
will allow of such a proof? Therefore apply similitudes carefully, lest ye run
into error.

Before, v. 11. they say, Let us lay wait, etc. Here Solomon affirms that they
do so.

2. Doct. A wicked man, as he persuades others to evil, so he acts it himself.
So Judah counseled to, and joined in the selling of Joseph, Genesis 37.26, etc.
Judas did the like in bringing Christ to his end, Matt. 26.14, 15.

Reason 1. To show their real approbation of the work. For it is pleasing to
their corrupt nature. They give bad counsel out of love to evil, as their
deeds declare.

2. To encourage others to mischief. For deeds draw more then words, examples
then precepts.

Use. To blame many, who give good counsel to others to be just, yet prove
unjust themselves; and to be patient, yet are impatient themselves. Like
Pharisees, they lay heavy burdens on men's shoulders, but they themselves will
not move them with one of their fingers, Mat. 23.4.

Fowlers have cunning pates to invent traps, and strong hands to lay them.

3. Doct. As wicked men have heads to invent, so have they hands to execute
mischief. So Ishmael contrived and executed Gedalia's death, and others, Jer.
41.1, etc. So did Joab, Atner's and Amasa's death, 2 Samuel 3.27. and 20.9, 10.

Reason 1. Because men's hands are naturally corrupt, as well as their heads.

2. Because else their plots will come to nothing, if their hands be not nimble
to execute, as well as their heads to invent.

Use. It reproves such as have good heads, and know well what they should do,
but find many rubs in the way, when they should go about any good duty. These
are sluggards, and cry, A lion in the way, Prove. 6.13.

New words come to be expounded in every verse.

4. Doct. Much pains is needful to understand Scripture aright. Continual
pains, Continue in them, 1 Timothy 4.16. Searching pains. Search the Scriptures,
Joh. chapter 5. verse. 39.

Reason 1. Because of the manner of writing Some things are plain, but other
things are figurative; as, I am the true vine, and my Father is the
husbandman, Joh. 15.1. Some direct, but others ironical; as, Rejoice, O young
man in thy youth, etc. Eccl. 11.9. Some like Islands and Promontories, as marks
of good example to guide; some like rocks, and quicksands, as stories of bad
example, to avoid.

2. Because Ministers which have more gifts then others, yet labor hard to
understand Scripture.

Use. Let us take pains to know the meaning of Gods Word, as Miners do, that
dig for gold, silver, or jewels; or men that draw water out of deep wells, even
out of the wells of salvation, Isa. 12.3.

If open opposing will not serve to rob and kill, ambushes must.

5. Doct. Many snares are laid for innocent men. As for David by Saul, that he
might be killed by the Philistines, or any other way. So for Daniel, by the
Princes of the Kingdom by enquiring into all his ways, and by new projects,
Dan. 6.4, 5.

Reason 1. Because of the malice of ungodly men against them.

2. Because of their subtilty. If they were not malicious, they would not lay
snares for good men. If not subtle, they could not do it, to prevail.

Use. Judge not them evil, that have many snares laid for them. Nets are not
laid for Kites, but for Pigeons.

For their souls; that is, for their lives. For they cannot come at their souls
to hurt them.

6. Doct. The natural life depends upon the presence of the soul, 1 King.
17.22. The soul of the child came into him again, and he revived.

Reason 1. Because there is no life in the infant in the womb, till the soul
enter into it. This we call quickening in the Mother, a distinct act from
conceiving.

2. Life continues not, if the soul depart.

3. It ends then. Souls departure from the body brings death.

4. Continuance of life in the soul after the death of the body, shows, that
the life of the body depends upon it.

5. The souls returning at the resurrection brings life to the body.

6. It brings eternal life to it also. The soul continuing with the body to
eternity, that body then can never die.

Use. Be most careful of your souls. Then your bodies will live also. Else both
perish. No life without the soul. The body will live if the soul live. And the
body will live as the soul lives, happily or miserably to eternity. If the soul
be damned, say, Farewell all bodily comfort for ever. What is a man profited,
if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul? Matt. 16.26.

Verse. 19. So are the ways of every one that is greedy of gain, which laketh
away the life of the owners thereof.
Solomon's three arguments being handled, whereby he seeks to draw the young
man from bad company, and ill courses; now he proceeds to raise a larger
conclusion, to keep him not only from robberies, but from covetousness, the
root of it. He tells him, that not these gross sinners only, but all that are
covetous, will be drawn to shed blood, rather then to lose gain. Here in a
patheticall conclusion, all that has been said before, is shut up, with a
vehement acclamation, and applied to more then robbers and murderers, even to
all covetous persons. See the like collections or conclusions, with
enlargements. Psalm. 128.4. Behold, thus shall the man be blessed that fears
the Lord. Not only with precedent blessings of success and children, but with
consequent also, of the Churches peace, and lasting posterity, verse. 5.6. And
Psalm. 144.15. Happy is that people that is in such a case; yea, happy is that
people, whose God in Johovah.

For the words.

(...), So. The word signifies,

1. The foot, or lowest part of a thing. The laver, and his foot, Exodus 30.28:

1. A place, or office. Pharaoh shall restore thee unto thy place. Genesis 40.13.
Me he restored unto mine office. Genesis 41. ver. 13.

3. Right or true. The daughters of Zelophehad speak right, Numb. 27.9.

4. So. And that sometimes in the reddition of a fimilitude. As the heavens are
higher then the earth, so are my ways higher then your ways, Isa. 55.9. And
sometimes without a similitude. And it was so, Genesis 1.7. God effected what he
spoke. Some take it here as a reddition to the similitude, verse. 17. but it is
rather a conclusion of Solomon's disswasion of the young man from joining with
robbers and covetous persons, not in regard of the unhappy event likely to
befall themselves, but in respect of their cruelty to others, whom they deprive
of goods and life.

(...), The wages. It signifies,

1. A way or path in which men walk. Dan shall be a serpent by the way an adder
in the path, Genesis 49.17.

2. A company of traveller a going together in the way for safety, as the
Turkish Caravan^ do. A company of Iskmaelites came from Gilead with their
camels, etc. Genesis 37.25.

3. A custom or manner of doing, in which men are as constant as travelers in
their way. It ceased to be with Sar^h after the manner of women, Genesis 18.11.
Lest thou learn his ways, Prove. 22.15. And so it is taken in this place for
the constant customs of covetous men.

(...), Of every one. He does not say, of some of them, but of every covetous
person. Not a barrel better herring. For the word, see on v. 13.

(...). That is greedy of gain, Heb. that gains gain. That makes it his
greatest employment to thrive, and makes truth and equity to yield to gain. The
word signifies,

1. To cut, or wound. Cut them in the head, or wound them, says the marg, Amos
9.1.

2. To be covetous, or greedy of gain; for such will cut and wound others in
their bodies sometimes, as robbers do. So the word is used. He that is greedy
of gain troubles his own house, Prove. 15.27.

3. To finish a thing. When the Lord has performed his whole work, Isa. 10.12.
for covetous or greedy men are very defirous to finish their work.

Here it is taken in the second sense, and it is observed, that in that
signification it is never taken in a good sense, for a lawful desire, or
lawful gain, but always in an ill sense, for being so greedy of gain, that
they use unlawful means to get it.

Which. This word is not in the original. It may be left out, and read, He
takes away the life of the owners thereof. That is, the covetous man does it.
Some would read, It. That is, gain, or riches, for many lose their lives for
their wealth. But it is rather to be understood of the robber, or covetous man,
who will not only deceive or cosen, but also kill men for their money.

(...), Takes away. See on v. 3. on the word Receive. The Hebrews have no
compounds, and therefore the word signifies to take away, as well as to take.

The life. See on verse. 18.

Of the owners thereof. See on v. 17. Some understand it of the thieves,
intimating, that when they had gotten wealth, they should be never the richer,
it would bring them to the gallows. But it is rather to be interpreted of rich
men, whom they would cosen or rob; and if they find them too strong for them,
or likely to reveal them, then they will kill them. This agrees with all the
former verses, especially the eleventh. The word sometimes signifies an
husband that has right to his wife: So here it signifies lawful possessors,
that have right to their goods, and have only authority to dispose of them.

The sum of all is: They take away that which belongs to others (which they
have nothing to do withal) and the owners lives withal.

Figures. 1. Ways for Customs. A Metaphor.

2. A figure of the cause for the effect. Soul for Life. Mark, 1. The note of
coherence, So. 2. The matter. And therein, 1. The cause. 2. The effect.



In the cause note, 1. The subject, He that is greedy of gain. 2. The adjunct
of number, Every one.


The effect is set out, 1. In general, The ways. 2. In particular. And
therein, 1. The action, He takes away. 2. The object, The life. 3. The
subject, Of the owners. 4. The adjunct, Thereof. Of that gain, or those riches:



He says not, So is the way. But, so are the ways.

1. Doct. There are many wicked ways in the world. Three are mentioned, Psalm.
1.1. The counsel of the ungodly, the way of sinners, the seat of the
scornful. Many, Hos. 4.2. Swearing, lying, killing, stealing, adultery.

Reason. 1. From particulars. There are ways of error concerning God, his
Word, Christ, the Sacraments. Ways of impiety, as swearing, blasphemy. Ways
of injustice, as fraud, robbery, false sentences, false witnesses. Ways of
uncharitableness, not giving, not lending to the poor, not setting them on
work, or giving them less then their work is worth. Ways of gluttony,
drunkenness, and uncleanness.

2. Because there are diverse corrupt principles within, and devices, which
break out in evil ways.

Use. Let us be circumspect and careful to keep the right way, having so many
by ways before us. As a bird that has many snares, or a fish that has many
baits laid for it, had need be wary. If the devil cannot draw a man to
Atheism, he will draw him to Idolatry; if not to Profaneness, then to
Superstition; if not to Pride, then to base Flattery; if not to Covetousness,
then to Prodigality.

Of every one, etc.

2. Doct. As there are many evil ways, so there are many that walk in them.
These evil ways are not like the highwayes in the days of Jael, unoccupyed,
Judge. 5.6. All flesh had corrupted their way, Genesis 6.12. Many there be which go
in the way of destruction, Mat. 7.13.

Reason 1. From particular evil ways. Many walk in the way of Idolatry. All
the world wondered after the beast, Rev. 12.3. In the way of covetousness. All
seek their own, Phil. 2.21. Of wantonness. Every one neighed after his
neighbors wife, Jer. 5.8. Of deceitfulness. With a double heart do they
speak, Psalm. 12.2.

2. Because there is no way so bad, but it is pleasing to any wicked men; and
what men delight in, that they pursue.

Use. It confutes the Papists, that make Universality a note of the true
Church. It may be a note of their malignant Church, for many follow evil
ways. Major pars meliorem vincit. Seneca. The greatest part overcomes the
better. Nunquam cum rebus humanis tam faeliciter actum est, ut meliora pluribus
placerent. Senec. de vita beata. Men's affairs were never in so happy a
condition, that the best things pleased most men.

3. Do. Many in the world are greedy of gain. For from the least of them, even
unto the greatest of them, every one of them is given unto covetousness, Jer.
6.13. her Prophets have taken the treasure and precious things. Her Princes in
the midst thereof are like wolves ravening the prey to shed blood, and so
destroy souls, to get dishonest gain. The people of the land have used
oppression, etc. Ezekiel. 22.25, 27, etc.

Reason 1. Because it is the means of a comfortable life. Rich men can command
plenty of the best food, apparel, dwellings, Eccl. 2.4, etc.

2. It raises men to honor, and makes others to attend and observe them like
demigods.

Use. To teach us to labor to be free of this common disease, as men fly from
infected Cities. Let us not follow the swinge of the world.

4. There is a propriety of goods in this world. It appears in the parable of
the Vineyard. Is it not lawful for me to do what I will with my own? Mat.
20.15. And in the parable of the talents, The Master delivers unto the servants
his goods, Matt. 25.14. And because Parabolicall divinity proves not, look into
Act. 5.4. While it remained, was it not thine own? Render therefore to all
their dues, Romans 13.7.

Reason 1. The Law of nature confirms it. Beasts that live promiscuously have
common pastures. It is not fit for men so to do, that may marry, and have
children.

2. The Law of Nations. The Barbarians have distinct dwellings, and cattle.

3. The Law of trading by exchange, or money, confirms it, Genesis 23.16.

4. The Law of God, else were there no eight Commandment. No man could be
guilty of theft, if there were no propriety of goods.

Use. It affords us comfort in what we enjoy by Gods law and man's. Propriety is
a great comfort. Luther was wont to say, There was much divinity in Pronounes.
Men love some children better then others, because they are theirs. It is the
great comfort of godly men, that God is theirs. My work is with my God, Isa.
49.4.

5. Doct. Wicked men seek to break this propriety of goods. Ahab would have
Naboth's vineyard, 1 King. 21.

Reason 1. Because they envy any good that others enjoy.

2. They would live easily and plentifully.

Use. It blames those that take other men's goods where they come, without any
order from God or man.

6. Doct. Deceitful and covetous persons will kill others rather then lose
their prey. Ahab will kill Naboth for his vineyard, 1 King. 21.

Reason 1. Because of inbred covetousness.

2. Because of inbred cruelty.

Use. Take heed of giving way to deceit or covetousness, lest ye end in blood.
Love of gain will draw blood. Some expound all Solomon's counsel by way of
hurt to the evil doers, thus. My Son, go not in, nay enter not into their
ways, for though they devise mischief for others, they will bring evil on
themselves, and as fowlers oft-times lay nets to no purpose for birds, so will
they for others. Their craft will tend to their own destruction. They are
greedy of gain, and when they have gotten it, it will procure their ruin. But
it rather aims at the hurt of others, thus, My Son, take heed of their courses,
for they are cruel, and seek the hurt and death of others, and that unjustly,
without any wrong done them, and by crafty and subtle means. So will all
covetous persons seek the life of others, that they may get from them with
ease, what they have gotten with much labor.

For the first interpretation it is objected, that the net is said to be laid
in the fight of any bird, and therefore the meaning is, in vain, not without
cause. That is, the bird sees the danger, and escapes.

Answ. The meaning may be, nets are laid, where birds are. As in the first
Commandment, Thou shall have no other gods before my face; that is, before me.

2. Object. There is no antecedent to tell whose lives are meant.

Answ. The antecedent follows sometimes in Scripture language. As Psalm. 87.1.
His foundation is in the holy mountains. Whose? A. v. 2. The Lords. So here,
For their lives; that is, For the lives of the owners of those riches, which
they would take away, v. 19.

For the second interpretation, the words are the same with v. 11. There they
are clearly spoken of the lives of others, not of the robbers. So v. 16. They
lust to shed other men's blood, not their own. And the owners, v. 19. are those
whose blood and life is sought, v. 18. The former intimates no success, this
fignifies a bad event. The former to themselves, this to others. There being
more difficulty in the former interpretation, less in the latter, let the
indifferent Reader judge which is the better.

Verse. 20. Wisdom eryeth without, she utters her voice in the streets.
Solomon like a good Physician, having first showed the danger of the disease,
to make willing to take physic; and like a good Surgeon, having used
corrasives, now gives curing medicines, and lenitive plasters. Or, having
before given antitodes to keep men from ill courses, now he gives cordials to
encourage them to good. Having forewarned the young man to take heed of bad
company, now he brings in Wisdom inviting him to her school. So the Psalmist
first disswades them from ungodly ways, and then invites men to delight in the
Law of the Lord, Psalm. 1.1, 2. First depart from evil, then do good, Psalm.
34.14. This is the way to dwell for ever^are, Psalm. 37.27. He had showed the
arguments of sinners before to seduce men, and answered them; now, that his
admonition might have the more weight, be by a Prosopopeia brings in Wisdom
her self to the confusion of foolishness and ignorance, soliciting him to good
ways. If the young man should say, that he desires nothing more then to avoid
the society of sinners, and follow the dictates of wisdom, but he is
discouraged by the difficulty of attaining it. No, says Solomon, it is easy
to attain, it is not hidden any where, nor far off to be sought after, but
offers it self to all, rich and poor, etc.

For the words of Wisdom note, 1. A preface, v. 20, 21. 2. The speech it self,
to the end of the Chapter.


In the preface note,

1. The beginning of Wisdoms proclamation. In the fields and villages, v. 20.

2. The progress of it in more public places, as in walled Towns and Cities,
v. 21.

For the words of this verse.

Wisdom, Heb. Wisdoms. For the word it self, see on v. 2. But why Wisdoms,
in the plural? Some think the reason to be, because it includes all true
wisdom in it, and all befide this holy wisdom is but folly. And because it
gives us diverse and many documents for the good of our souls. It contains many
things to direct us in faith and life. So seven Spirits are mentioned, Rev.
1.4. to set forth the manifold graces of Gods Spirit. Or, it is called
Wisdoms, because it is the most excellent wisdom, divine, heavenly wisdom,
which teaches us how to attain eternal life. So Behemoth is put for a great
beast, Job 40.15. Thus this word may be used here for principal wisdom. As
also chap. 9.1. Wisdoms has builded her a house. And Psalm. 49.3. My mouth
shall speak of wisdoms. Some would read, wisdom of wisdoms. So some read for
Behemoth, the beast of beasts, Job 40.15. And, Remember to remember to keep
boly the Sabbath day, in the fourth Commandment. And, The Song of Songs, Cant.
1.1. that is, the best Song, as appears by Gods choice, who preserved that when
all the rest were lost. Hereby is meant the highest wisdom, called by St.
James, the wisdom from above, Jam. 3.17. Wisdom is brought in here as some
great Lady or Princess, the word is feminine, calling on young men as her
growing Subjects, to hearken to her godly counsels. And the word is plural, as
God is called (...), and (...) in the plural number, to set out his state and
majesty, to may Wisdom. Others take it to be meant of Christ, the eternal
wisdom of God the Father. And so it is commonly interpreted, chapter 8.1. And may
be here. For he did cry before he was born, even in the days of Noah, 1 Pet.
3.19, 20. And he is called Wisdom here, because he is the eternal wisdom of
God, and also to fit the title to the matter. As God is called the Father of
mercies in promises, to comfort afflicted ones; and the just God in
threatenings, to scare sinners; and the Lord in commandments, to move to
obedience: so here, Christ may be called Wisdom, to counsel simple ones.

(...), Cries. The word signifies a strong cry, such an one as Soldiers use
to send forth in the beginning of a battle, or after a victory. Thus men cry
out in finging for joy, or weeping for sorrow; in prayer, or praise; in
teaching, or admonishing others, as here. She speaks not low, but loud, that
all men may hear, and to show forth her earnestness. It may be meant either of
this proclamation of Wisdom here, and in other places of Scripture left on
record to be published all the world over; or of Christ speaking by his
Ministers in all ages, and inviting men to look after saving wisdom.

(...), Without. Some take this to be all one with the words following, to
show, that Wisdom speaks, and that boldly to, in all places. But more
particularly the word signifies sometimes the streets of a City, which are
without in respect of the houses. Jeremy must have a piece of bread out of the
Bakers street, Jer. 37.21. Sometimes, the Country villages and fields, which
are out of the walled Towns, and lie open to all comers. The suburbs of the
City shall reach from the wall of the City, and outward, a thousand cubits
round about, Numb. 35.4. So here, for all other places are mentioned after.
Contrymen as well as Citizens may hear Wisdoms voice.

She utters, Heb. she gives. That is, she gives out, or puts forth her
voice. The Hebrews want compounds. For the word, See on v. 4. Wisdom, as she
speaks loud, that all may hear, so she speaks freely, plainly, and distinctly,
that all, even the meanest, may understand.

Her voice. The word (...), sometimes fignifieth a voice, or sound in general,
though not articulate. That there be no more thunderings, Heb. voices of God,
Exodus 9.28. Sometimes it signifies words distinctly spoken. In all that Sarah
has said unto thee, hearken unto her voice, Genesis 21.12. So is it used here.

(...), In the streets. The Hebrew word has its original from (...), to be
broad, as (...) in Gr. because streets of Towns and Cities are wide, for men,
horses, and carts to pass by one another. She cries not in a corner, or within
doors only, or in fields or villages alone, but in the streets of Towns and
Cities, where houses are nearer then in the Country, that so all men may hear,
City and Country ring of her instruction.

Figures. Wisdom, either a Prosopopeia, if it be meant of Wisdom it self: or
a Metonymie of the subject for the adjunct, if spoken of Christ, the fountain
of wisdom. Voice Heb. Sound. A Synecdoche of the general for the special. A
sound for a voice, which is the best sound. More is to be gotten by men's words
then by lowing of oxen, or bleating of sheep. The beginning of Wisdoms speech
in villages is in the beginning of this verse. The progress of it, 1. In
Streets, Cities, and Towns, in the end of this verse. 2. In other places there,
verse. 21.


In the beginning of the speech note, 1. The Crier, Wisdom. 2. The act,
cries. 3. The subject place, without.


In the Country Villages, and unwalled Towns. In her progress in the streets,
note, 1. The act, she utters. 2. The object, her voice. 3. The subject place,
in the streets.


1. Doct. Heavenly wisdom is worth the looking after. As things publicly
cried and proclaimed are worth taking notice of. Hence the search of it is so
much pressed, and the worth of it so much set out in this Book, chap. 2.2. and
4.5, etc. The hear, heart, voice must be used, as men do to get silver, and hid
treasures. This wisdom must be gotten, and not forgotten, and kept as the
principal thing.

Reason 1. In regard of the excellency of it. It excells all humane arts and
sciences, more then gold does iron.

2. In regard of the lasting of it. All objects of humane science perish, but
the object of heavenly Wisdom lasts for ever in another world.

Use. Choose these studies then. Discamus ea in terris, qua nobiscum maneant in
caelis. Hieron. Let us on earth learn those things which may remain with us in
heaven. It is a fools part to look after bables, and neglect serious things.
Wherefore is there a price in the hand of a fool to get wisdom, seeing he has
no heart to it? Prove. 17.16.

2. Doct. This heavenly wisdom is to be found only in Jesus Christ. In whom
are hid all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge, Col. 2.3. The only
begotten, which is in the bosom of the Father, he has declared him, Joh.
1.18. Neither knows any man the Father, save the Son, and he to whom the Son
will reveal him, Matt. 11.27.

Reason 1. Because as the Son of God he knew the Fathers will from eternity.

2. Because God spoke by him even before his incarnation, as in the delivering
of the Law. Christ's voice then shook the earth, Heb. 12.26. Therefore he is
called (...), the Word, or Speech, Joh. 1.1.

3. Because God has given him the Spirit beyond measure, Joh. 3.34. He has
more wisdom and holiness then any man or Angel. He is the most lively image
of God, Heb. 1.3. And a principal part of Gods image is knowledge, Col. 3.10.

4. All wisdom that others have in heavenly things is from him. Christ of God
is made unto us wisdom, 1 Cor. 1.30. No Philosophy can teach is. They had good
Moral precepts, but wild ones in Divinity.

Use. Go to the right shop for heavenly knowledge. To Christ's school. Search
not on earth, for it is vain. Neither man, earth, nor sea can afford it.
Neither gold, silver, nor precious stones can purchase it, Job 28.12. Seek it
then from the Lord Jesus Christ, who is the wisdom of God, 1 Cor. 1.24.

3. Doct. God is very desirous men should get heavenly wisdom. Therefore he
cries loudly, earnestly, affectionately, Understand, O ye brutish among the
people, when will ye be wise? Psalm. 94.8. God has written to the people the
great things of his Law, and will be angry if they be counted as a strange
thing, Hos. 8.12.

Reason 1. Because as he gives light natural in creatures, and arts, so
supernatural in Scripture revelations.

2. He gives sight of such things ordinarily by reason, extraordinarily by
illumination, and common graces.

Use. To admire why men are poor in this heavenly knowledge, seeing God is so
willing men should have it. Who would starve where a Prince keeps open Court to
entertain all comers?

4. Doc^^ This heavenly knowledge is offered to the meanest. It is preached in
villages. The poor have the Gosp^l preached to them, Mat. 11.5. God has hid
these things from the wise and prudent, and has revealed them unto babes, Mat.
11.25. Bring in hither the poor and the maimed, and the halt, and the blind,
Luke 14.21.

Reason 1. To show that God respects no persons, Act. 10.34. A thing that
brings much hurt in the world.

2. To bind them the more to God, as a begger-woman without blood, or portion,
married to a King, is the more engaged to him.

Use. To persuade mean ones to get this heavenly wisdom. They cannot get Arts
perhaps for want of means of breeding. This is offered freely. Ho, every one
that thirsts, come ye to the waters, and he that has no money: Come ye, buy,
and eat; yea, come buy wine and milk without money, and without price, Isa.
55.1.

5. Doct. The way to this heavenly knowledge is plain, and easy. It is cried
about the streets. It is taught in all languages. Knowledge is easy to him
that understands, Pro. 14.6. That is, that gives his mind to understand it.
Parthians, Medes, etc. We do hear them speak in our tongues the wonderful
works of God, Act. 2.9, 11. It is taught by earthly similitudes, as in parables
abundantly, Matthew. 13.

Use. Seek earnestly for it then. The way is easy, and the end profitable.

6. Doct. Means of salvation are offered to great Towns. To Chorazin and
Bethsaida, Mat. 11.21. To Capernaum, Mat. 11.23. To Corinth, Act. 18.1, 4.

Reason 1. Because much good may be done there, as much fish may be caught in
the Sea.

2. God may have much work to do there. Therefore Paul must preach boldly at
Corinth, because God has much people there, Act. 18.9, 10.

Use. Bless God for the means here. The Gospel is more plentifully preached,
then in other places. Walk worthy of it.

Verse. 21. She cries in the chief places of concourse, in the ^^^^ings of the
gates, in the City she utters her words, saying,
The text is a part of the preface of Wisdoms speech. Her beginning in the
Country villages was set out in the beginning of the former verse. And her
progress to the streets of walled Town in the end thereof. Now follows her
further progress in this verse. And that, 1. To Market Towns. 2. To
Shire-Towns, or places of Judgment. 3. To Cities, or chief places in a
Kingdom or Nation.


For the words.

Wisdom like some great Queen cries out, calling her Subjects from bad courses
to good. (...), It is a most fruitful word, having abundance of significations
in the Scriptures.

1. It signifies to cry, or make a noise. Isa. 58.1. Cry aloud, spare not, lift
up thy voice like a trumpet. From the Hebrew word (...), comes our English
word, Cry.

2. To proclaim or publish a thing. I will proclaim the Name of the Lord before
thee, Exodus 33.19.

3. To exclaim, or cry out. I lifted up my voice and cried, Genesis 39.15.

4. To read. He read all the words of the Law, Josh. 8.34.

5. To impose a name. She called his name Reuben, Ge. 29.32.

6. To call one by his name. The Lord called Samuel, 1 Samuel 3.4.

7. To call upon, or pray to God. Call upon me in the day of trouble, Psalm.
50.15.

8. To call one to him. As they called them, so they went from them, Hos. 11.2.

9. To invite to a feast. To morrow I am invited to her with the King, Est.
5.12.

10. To call into judgment, or call to account. And the Lord God called unto
Adam, Genesis 3.9.

11. To meet with one. Joseph went up to meet Israel his Father, Genesis 46.29.

12. To happen, or come to pass unexpectedly. As I happened by chance upon
Mount Gilboa, 2 Samuel 1.6. Here it is taken in the second sense, for proclaiming
or publishing, as appears by the speech following.

In the chief place, Heb. the head. For the word, see on v. 9. Here it is taken
for the chief place of meeting. Some would take it for an higher place, wherein
the Preacher stands above others, that he may be heard. But that agrees not
well with the rest, which all mention the place of the hearers, rather then of
the speaker.

Of concourse, Hebr. of tumults, or of such as make a noise, (...), In
Market Towns and Fairs, where great concourse of people is, and abundance of
noise and business. It is called a place of tumults and tumultuous persons,
because men speak not there by order, as in other meetings, but all will be
heard. The word is feminine, because women are frequent in Markets: But
principally, to hold on the Metaphor, and to make the hearers like the speaker,
for (...), wisdoms, was plural and feminine, v. 20 as (...), concourses, is
here.

In the opening of the gates.

1. Enquire what is meant by the gates. 2. What by the openings of the gates.
For the first, (...), of the gates. The word signifies,

1. The gate of a Town or City, where men go in and out for trading, and
therefore much people may quickly be gathered there to hear. And Hamor and
Shechem his Son came unto the gate of their City, and communed with the men of
their City, Genesis 34.20.

2. The Town or City that has gates, and lies not open to the fury of the
enemies. I will fan them with is fan in the gates of the land, Jer. 15.7. That
is, in the Cities, or walled. Towns.

3. The palce of Judicature, that used in those days to be near the gates,
that all comers in and out might be witnesses of the just proceedings there.
Thou shall bring forth that man, or that woman unto thy gates, Deuteronomy. 17.5. That
is, to be judged, as appears by the production of witnesses and execution of
justice there mentioned. So it is taken here, for places of justice, where many
meet to see justice done, and that both Citizens and Country people, goers in,
and comers out, and therefore should be ready to hear good counsel there. Seats
of Instruction may be where seats of Justice are.

For the second, (...), the openings. It signifies,

1. The opening of a gate, or door. Keep the doors of thy mouth from her that
lies in thy besome, Mic. 7.5. Reveal, not thy secret thoughts to her. The
entrance of thy words gives light, Psalm. 119.30. That is, the opening of them.

2. A door of an house or tent. Abraham sat in the tent door, Genesis 18.1. Here
it is taken in the first sense, for justice is done, when gates are open, that
all may hear; and not when the gates are shut, and the people kept out. As
soon, or when the gates are open, especially for judgment, Wisdom speaks, as
some would have it; but the place it self is rather meant, as in the rest of
the verse.

She utters her words, Heb. she says her sayings. She uttetereth what she
has to say, (...). What her words are, appears afterward; words of Reproof,
and of Instruction.

(...), In the City. The word comes from (...), to awake, or stir up, because a
City is a building awaked, as it were, or stirred up out of the dust, as a man
out of sleep. It is put,

1. For the City it self. The men of the City, even the men of Sodom, Genesis
19.4.

2. For the inhabitants of the City. The Lords voice cries unto the City, Mic.
6.9. Here it is taken in the first sense, for a City, or chief place in a
Kingdom or Nation. Some take it all to be meant of the same place. Wisdom
cries without in the skirts of the City, within in the Streets, Marketplaces,
Courts, and any other place in the City where people meet. But I cannot
restrain it to Cities alone, but rather take it to be an elegant gradation of
heavenly Wisdom revealing it self by several degrees, first in the Villages,
then in greater Towns, after that in Market Towns, then in Shire-Towns, and
places of Judgment; and lastly, in Cities, the chief places in Kingdoms and
Nations.

Figures. She. A Prosopopeia, bringing in Wisdom her self as some great Queen
speaking to affect the more. Men's own words affect far more then other men's
relations of them. So Judge. 9.8. the Trees are brought in speaking. Or the
adjunct for the subject. Wisdom for wise men, godly Prophets, Apostles,
Ministers, or Christ himself, as verse. 20. Head, for chief place. A metaphor,
for streets have no heads. Tumults, or tumultuous persons, for concourse; the
effect for the cause; concourse breeds tumults. Gates, for the places of
Judicature; the subject place for the adjunct business done there.

Parts. Note 1. The agent, She, Wisdom.

2. A double act, cries, utters her words.

3. A threefold place, in the chief place of concourse, in the openings of the
gates, in the City.

Saying, is added in other letters to usher in the speech.

1. Doct. Common reproofs should be public. Wisdom reproves in the chief
places of concourse.

Reason 1. That gross sinners may be ashamed. Private reproofs will hardly
work shame in them. Rebuke them sharply, that they may be sound in the faith,
Tit. 1.13.

2. That others may fear, even the stoutest of sinners. 1 Timothy 5.20. Them that
sin, rebuke before all, that others also may fear. It is good to strike the Dog
before the Lion.

Use 1. To reprove faint hearted Ministers, who are more afraid to reprove then
others are to sin. Wisdom reproves here openly, verse. 22. So did Elias reprove
King Ahab, and John Baptist King Hered. And the Prophets reproved sinful
people. So God commands, Show my people their transgressions, and the house of
Jacob their sins, Isa. 58.1. If Ministers reprove but faintly, and by the by,
sinners are so sound on sleep that they will not be awaked. Have no fellowship
with the unfruitful works of darkness, but reprove them rather, Ephesians. 5.11.

2. To reprove open sinners, that cannot endure open reproof. They would be
content that we should damn themselves and us by silence. When I say unto the
wicked, O wicked man, thou shall surely die, if thou do not speak to warn
the wicked from his way, that wicked man shall die in his iniquity; but his
blood will I require at thine hand, Ezekiel. 33.8.

2. Doct. Common instructions should be public. So are Wisdoms, v. 23. Jesus
went about all Galilee, teaching in their Synagogues, Mat. 4.23. I ever taught
in the Synagogue, and in the Temple, whither the Jews always resort, and in
secret have I said nothing, Joh. 18.20.

Reason. 1. To show that we are not ashamed of the Gospel, but profess it
openly, Romans 1.16.

2. That we are not afraid to suffer for it, if we be called thereunto. This
was Paul's resolution, I count not my self dear unto my self, so that I may
finish my course with joy, and the Ministry which I have received of the Lord
Jesus, to testify the Gospel of the grace of God, Act. 20.24.

Use. It condemns the enemies of the Gospel, that can bear any thing better
then a powerful preacher. These are Bats and Owls, that cannot endure the
light.

3. Doct. No place is unfit to do good in. Wisdom cries in City and Country.
Christ went about doing good, Act. 10.38. He taught at Jacob's Well, Joh. 4.6.
Among the Samaritans, Joh. 4.40.

Reason 1. Because God is in every place, and looks for some good from us there.

2. Because we are allowed to do evil in no place.

Use. It shows the folly of ignorant people, who think they may do what they
will, except they be in a Church.

4. Doct. Ignorant persons are inexcusable. For Wisdom cries to them in all
places. He that knew not, and did commit things worthy of stripes, shall be
beaten with few stripes, Luke 12.48. Christ will take vengeance on them that
know not God, 2 Thessalonians. 1.8.

Reason 1. Because Wisdoms voice is every where to be heard. In Villages,
Towns, etc. Yea, in places of greatest concourse to make men inexcusable. As
proclamations are made in great Cities to bind a whole Kingdom or Nation,
because all come there to Market, or may hear of them by such as come there, so
that no man can pretend ignorance.

2. Because no man is so ignorant, but acts sometimes against knowledge.

Use. It takes away the foolish plea of the people, that under means of
knowledge excuse all their sins by ignorance. Christ will say to them at the
day of Judgment, Out of thine own mouth will I judge thee, O thou wicked
servant; Luke 19.22. Thou heardest my word, but would be ignorant, therefore
thou art justly condemned.

5. Doct. Men may be known by their words. Wisdom utters her words, words
befitting her, savouring of wisdom. A good tree must bring forth good fruit,
and a good man speak good words, Matt. 12.33, etc. A treasure of wise thoughts
is in a wise man's heart, and he is willing to vent it, Mat. 12.35.

Use. Be wary of your words if you would be well esteemed. For by thy words
thou shall be justified, and by thy words thou shall be condemned, Mat. 12.37.

6. Doct. All opportunities must be taken to do good. Preach the Word, be
instant in season, out of season, 2 Timothy 4.2. Ester takes occasion at a banquet
to set on foot her Petition for the good of Gods Church, Est. 5.7, etc.

Use. Lose no opportunity of doing good.

Verse. 22. How long ye simple ones will ye love simplicity? and the scorners
delight in scorning, and fools hate knowledge?
Here begin the words of Wisdom, and last to the end of the Chapter. In which
there is, 1. A reproof or expostulation, in this verse. 2. An exhortation to
repentance, v. 23. 3. A promise to enforce it, Ibid. 4. A variety of
threatenings, from v. 24. to v. 33. 5. The conclusion, v. 33.


For the first, the reproof. Wisdom begins with a great deal of earnestness,
as willing to persuade. She out of a Motherly affection bewails men's continued
errors, and kindly invites them to reformation. See the like, Psalm. 4.2. O ye
Sons of men, how long will ye turn my glory into shame? How long will ye love
vanity, and seek after leasing?

For the words.

How long. Ye have continued too long in these wicked courses. It is high time
to think of returning to God.

Ye simple ones. Wisdom does not tell others of their simplicity, who may tell
them of it again, but falls directly upon them, and calls them simple ones to
their faces. Wisdom cannot flatter. She chides those that keep childish
manners, when they be men. The word signifies such as are easily drawn to
believe any thing that comes into their heads, or that others suggest to them,
though never so erroneous. The simple believes every word, Prove. 14.15. See
for the word on v. 4.

Will ye love. Will ye be carried away with worldly vanities, as men in love?
It is a weakness to be simple, one to be in love with ones own simplicity is a
madness. Mala sua amare malorum ultimum est: For a man to love his own evils
is the worst of all evils. Sen.

Simplicity. The same word as before. See on v. 4.

And the scorners. See on v. 6. upon the word Interpretation, where we showed
that the word signifies to interpret, to speak cloquently, and to scoff at one
in scorn.

(...), Delight in. Count it a thing very pleasing to them to scoff at
goodness. So the word is used, Genesis 2.9. Every tree that is pleasant to the
sight. It is a sport to a fool to do mischief, Prove. 10.23. or desire it for
themselves, as Josh 7.21. Then I coveted them, Heb. Then I desired them for my
self. As if they thought it portion or religion enough for themselves to be
able to scoff at others. The word may signify either way here, or include
both; for the things we desire, when we want them, we delight in when we have
them. Yet delight being a fuller affection then desire, it is well translated
Delight in.

Their scorning, Heb. scorning for themselves. The former is usually expressed
by the affix. And the latter sometimes is a Pleonasmus, so that scorning for
themselves is no more then scorning. As Genesis 12.1. Get thee out of thy
