Country, is no more then Go out of thy Country. Or it may be read, Delight
themselves in scorning* But it cannot be read, Desire themselves in scorning.
And the charge is then more full. Men may desire some things that they dislike
when they come to pass. But delighting in a thing, argues full content and
pleasure.

And fools. So (...) is translated. A foolish man despises his Mother, Prove.
15.20. Elsewhere it signifies a star, called Orion. Which makes Arcturus,
Orion, etc. Job 9.9. Because as fools are very inconstant, scarce an hour
together in one mind, so that star brings uncertain weather. Here it is taken
in the first sense. Fools are such as have an habit of folly or wickedness in
them, because they seek not after knowledge, as being above their capacity or
belief. Such as know not tre^ wisdom, though learned otherwise. Men that are
not righteous, that is, right wise, as the Saxons writ it. So Cicero, one of
the wisest of the Heathen, is reported to cry out at his death. O me nunquam
sapieutem! Alas! I was never wise.

(...), Hate. The word signifies,

1. To hate so as to seek ones destruction. Esau hated Jacob, Genesis 27.41.

2. To contemn, as men despise things hated. If the later husband hate her,
Deuteronomy. 24.3.

3. To love one less then another. When the Lord saw that Leah was hated, Genesis
29.31. that is, loved less then Rachel, verse. 30.

Here it is taken in the first sense, for hating knowledge. For threce sorts of
sinners are here reproved in three several degrees, like steps of a ladder,
where men step from the one to the other, and each step argues greater
wickedness then the former. It is bad to love simplicity, worse to scoff at
piety, worst of all to hate knowledge.

(...), Knowledge. See on v. 2. and 4. Figure none. Note 1. The charge of
simple ones. 2. Of scorners. 3. Of fools.


In the first note, 1. The persons accused, ye simple ones. 2. The act, will ye
love. 3. The adjunct of time, how long. Which also is understood in the other
parts. 4. The object, simplicity. A thing unworthy of any love.


In the second note, 1. The persons indicted, and the scorners. 2. The act,
delight in. 3. The object, their scorning. To wit, of goodness, which should
be honored.


In the third note, 1. The persons complained of, and fools. 2. The act, hate.
3. The object, knowledge, which deserves love.


Wisdom had long forborne them, before she did thus sharply reprove them.

1. Doct. Reproof must not be sharp at first. Such was Peter's reproof, 1 Pet.
4.3. The time past of our life may suffice us to have wrought the will of the
Gentiles. The servant of the Lord must not strive, but be gentle unto all, apt
to teach, patient, 2 Timothy 2.24.

Reason 1. To try if gentle means will prevail. So Phyficians give gentle
purges first. Of some have compassion, making a difference, Jude v. 22.

2. To show our love to the persons reproved, that our words may work the more
with them for their good.

Use. It blames them that are all vinegar, and cannot mingle kind words with
reproofs, that put no difference between weak, and obstinate sinners. Non sanat
qui vulnerat, non monet qui mordet: He heals not that wounds, he admonishes not
that bites.

2. Doct. Sharp reproofs must follow, if gentle ones will do no good. So here
Wisdom calls them simple ones, scorners, fools. The Pharisees are sharply
reproved by Christ, Woe unto you Scribes, and Pharisees, hypocrites, Matthew.
23.13. Elymas by Paul, O full of all subtilty, and all mischief, thou child of
the devil, thou enemy of all righteousness, etc. Act. 13.10.

Reason 1. Because of their long continuance in sin. A hand hardened by labor
must be struck hard, before it can feel. Custom in fin hardens.

2. Because they stop their ears against goodness. He that is in danger of
death, and will not open his mouth to take physic, must have it poured down
his throat by violence.

Use. It blames those that have no vinegar at all in their reproofs, that
mildely reprove greatest and longest finners. Eli broke his neck for dealing so
mildely with his Sons, that were so wicked.

Here are three sorts of finners mentioned one above another.

3. Doct. There be degrees of finners, some worse then others, though all in
their natural estate be in the way to Hell. There are ungodly, sinners,
scorners, Psalm. 1.1. There are empty clouds, withered trees, raging waves,
wandering stars, Jude v. 12, 13.

Reason 1. Because corruption spreads more in some then in others, by their
giving more way to it, as poison spreads in the body where the joints are not
bound.

2. Some are more restrained then others by outward objects of fear and shame.
A fierce horse may be kept in by a bridle.

3. Some are more violently tempted then others, and therefore sin more, as an
horse spurred will run fast.

Use. It reproves those that are Pharisees in religion, that thank God they are
not like other men, Luke 18.11. These have but Sodoms justification, they are
not so bad as Jerusalem, Ezekiel. 16.51.

4. Doct. We are by nature so simple that we love simplicity. Man is born like
a wild Asses colt, Job 11.12. The Laodicean Angel flatters himself in his
ignorance, Rev. 3.17. being spiritually poor, he thinks himself very rich.

Reason 1. Because our simplicity is our own, and men love their own children.

2. Because naturally we know no better. The Moon is a fine light to him that
never saw the Sun. Mantua was a brave City to the shepherds that never saw
Rome. Virgil. Eclog 1.

3. Because we look in a deceitful glass, that makes things look more
beautiful then they are. And so simplicity seems lovely to us.

Use. Let us bewail our natural condition, that not only are simple, but love
simplicity. To be sick is ordinary, to love sickness is unusual, yet we love
simplicity.

5. Doct. Some are so bad that they scorn and scoff at all goodness. So
Sanballat and Tobiah scoff at the Jews buildings, Neh. 4.2, 3. Peter
prophesies of scoffers in the last days, that should scoff at the very coming
of Jesus Christ to judgment, 2 Pet. 3.3, 4. Such scoff,

1. At good men, because the good lives of them condemn their bad ones. This
moved one to give his vote to banish Aristides, Hoc tantum me male habet, quod
justus ubique audit. This only troubles me, that every man counts him a just
man.

2. They scoff at good Ministers, because they reprove their sins, and so
perplex their consciences.

Use. Let us expect sco^^. Others had trial of cruel mockings, Heb. 11.36.
Isaac the heir of Abraham, and Son of the promife, could not escape. Ishmael's
mocking Isaac is called persecution, Gal. 4.29. No, nor Christ himself the Son
of God. They laughed him to scorn, Mart. 9.24. Scorners have a chair, Psalm.
1.1. but it is but a chair of pestilence, as the Vulgar Translation reads it.

6. Doct. Some grow worse yet, so that they hate knowledge it self. Every one
that does evil hates the light, Joh. 3.20. They say anto God, Depart from is,
for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways, Job 21.14.

Reason 1. Rati^ne acquisition is laboriose. Men are idle, and Ioth to take
panss for knowledge.

2. Ratione propriae impletion is venenosae. They are full of bad liquor, and
have no room for good.

3. Because they know not the worth of it, else would they love it, and choose
it, v. 29.

4. Because it will not let them sin freely, but raises whirlewinds in their
consciences. The evil doer comes not to the light, lest his deeds should be
reproved, Joh. 3.20.

Use 1. Wonder not if some will not be won by long and powerful preaching.
They hate knowledge.

2. Take heed of the height of evil. They shut reprovers out of doors, as
naughty boys do Schoolmasters. Glem. Strom. l. 7. This damns many. They have
both seen and hated both me and my Father, Joh. 15.24. Wisdom is accused by
bad men, but justified by her children, Mat. 11.19.

Verse. 23. Turn you at my repreof; behold, I will pour out my spirit unto you,
I will make known my words unto you.
Wisdom having searched into their sores, and discovered their diseases to
them in the former verse. does now apply plasters to them, which may heal them.
After a short rebuke of their folly and contempt, she administers good counsel
in an exhortation. Having showed them that they were out of the way, now she
shows them how to get in again. She had blamed them before for staying so long
in wicked ways. Now she bids them turn speedily. And this exhortation is
backed afterward with threats and promises.

For the words.

(...), Turn you, or return. The word signifies,

1. To return to a place from which one went away before. Abraham returned unto
his place, Genesis 18.33.

2. To return from anger, or to be friends with one. Surely his anger shall
turn from me, Jer. 2.35.

3. To repent or return to God, from whom we are all naturally gone astray. And
shall return unto the Lord thy God, Deuteronomy. 30.2.

4. To do the same thing again. Isaac dug again (Heb. returned and dug)
the wells of water which they had dug in the days of Abraham his Father,
Genens chapter 26. v. 18.

5. To make to return, or bring back. Then the Lord thy God will turn thy
captivity, Deuteronomy. 30.3.

Here it is taken in the third sense, for turning from the ways of folly to
the ways of true wisdom, from Satan to God. A similitude taken from
travelers that are gone out of their way, or from children, servants,
soldiers, or scholars, that run away from their governors, and undo
themselves. So Hagar fled from Sarah, and is bidden to return, Genesis 16.6, 9.

(...), At my reproof. The word signifies,

1. Verbal reproving in words. Thus she was reproved, Genesis 20.16.

2. Real reproving, that is, correcting. Oh Lord, rebuke me not in thine
anger; that is, as follows, chasten me not in thy hot displeasure, Psalm. 6.1.
Here it is used in the first sense for the words of wisdom in the former versi
or such like. Seeing years have not brought you to discretion, nor ye have wit
enough to return from your evil ways of your selves, do it at my reproof.

(...), Behold. She puts a note of admiration before the promise, because
abundance of grace, especially in them, who have lived long in wick ednesse, is
a thing worthy to be wondered at by all, as it is for a Virgin to bear a Son.
Isa. 7.14. Behold, a virgin shall conceive and bear a Son.

(...), I will pour out. It signifies abundance of grace to be given, as a
fountain poures out plenty of water. It notes great fullness in wisdom, and
great affection to others. I will willingly pour it out of a full heart, as
water out of a fountain. So abundance of folly and evil is poured out of a
wicked heart. The mouth of fools pours out folly, Prove. 15.2. The mouth of
the wicked pours out evil things, Prove. 15.28.

(...), My spirit. It signifies,

1. The wind. There came a great wind from the wilderness, Job 1.19.

2. Vanity, a thing of no substance, empty like the wind. What profit has he
that has labored for the wind? Eccles. 5.16.

3. A corner, or place, or quarter of the earth, where the wind may blow. In
four quarters were the porters, 1 Chronicles. 9.24.

4. The breath of a living creature, which is kind of wind. Neither is there
any breath in their mouths, Psalm. 135.17.

5. A Spirit or Angel. Then a spirit passed before my face, Job 4.15.

6. The soul of a man. The spirit of Jacob their. Father revived, Genesis 45.27.

7. The life. Thou have granted me life, Job 10.12.

8. The Holy Ghost the third Person in Trinity. The Spirit of God moved upon
the face of the waters, Genesis 1.2.

9. The gifts of the Holy Ghost. I will pour out my Spirit upon all flesh, Joel
2.28. So it is taken here for spiritual graces. All three Persons are closely
mentioned in this chapter The Father, called the Lord, verse. 7. The Son, called
Wisdom, v. 20. The holy Ghost, called the Spirit, in this verse. Some take it
for illumination only, and gifts of knowledge. So it agrees well with the
words, that follow. I will make known my words unto you. If ye hearken to my
reproof, I will tell you more of my mind. Ye shall know more of heavenly
truths. So that pouring out of the Spirit is emptying of the soul, declaring
what Wisdom thinks, which is worth the knowing. And I will declare it as
fully, as if it flowed out of a fountain. Others take it for sanctifying gifts
of the Spirit. The former agrees best with the words following.

Unto you. By making my mind known unto you. By my words.

(...), I will make known. By pouring out my spir it, and declaring my whole
mind unto you.

(...), My words. It signifies,

1. A word. Hear the word of the Lord, Isa. 1.10.

2. A thing. For things are revealed by words. The thing proceeds from the
Lord, Genesis 24.50. Here it is taken in the first sense.

Unto you, Heb. I will make you to know my words.

The sum of all is. If ye will turn from your foolish ways to hearken to me,
I will fill you with true wisdom.

Not that men have power to repent of themselves, but these exhortations of
Gods Ministers set home by Gods Spirit, are means to bring sinners to
repentance.

Figures. Turn. A Metaphor from men out of the way, that must return or never
come to their journeys end.

Pour out. A Metaphor from a fountain that poures out water abundantly.

My Spirit. A figure of the cause for the effect. The gifts of my Spirit, or
meaning of it.

Note. 1. An exhortation. 2. A promise to encourage them.


He begins with a promise here, and ends with another, v. 33. and fills the
middle with threatenings.

In the exhortation note, 1. An act, Turn you. 2. The motive to it, at my
reproof.


The promise is double,

1. Of the Spirit. 2. Of knowledge.

In the first note, 1. The word of admiration, Behold. 2. The agent, I. 3. The
act, will pour out. 4. The object, my Spirit. 5. The subject, unto you.


In the second promise note, 1. The agent, I. 2. The act, will make known. 3.
The object, my words. 4. The subject, unto you.


1. Doct. Ministers must show the way of healing, as well as the disease, Isa.
1.4. with v. 16, 17. Ab sinful Nation, etc. Wash you, make you clean, etc.
Hos. 10.9. with v. 12. O Israel, thou have sinned from the days of Gibeah,
etc. Sow to your selves in righteousness, reap in mercy, etc. Romans 3.9. with
v. 21. We have before proved both Jews and Gentiles, that they are all under
sin. But now the righteousness of God without the Law is manifested, 1 Pet.
4.3. with verse. 7. The time past of our lives may suffice us to have wrought
the will of the Gentiles, etc. The end of all things is at hand, Be ye
therefore sober, and watch.

Reason 1. Because else they should be like Job's friends, Physicians of no
value, Job 13.4. Who cares for a Physician, that only can tell him, he must
die?

2. They could else do no good to men by their Ministry. He that tells a man
he is in the wrong way, or that the enemy comes upon him, and cannot guide him
in the right way, or to a safe tower, does no good.

Use. Let Ministers teach men, as to cast off solly, so to hearken to Wisdoms
voice to come out of by ways and darkness, unto the right way, and light.
Else they are like him that snuffs a lamp, and puts in no oil.

2. Dict. Reproof may turn some, that would never turn of themselves. The
Angels speech made the Israelites weep, Judge. 2.1, 4. Peter's speech pricked
the Jews to the heart, and made them cry out, Men and brethren, what shall we
do? Act. 2.14, 37.

Reason 1. Because we are naturally in sensible of our dangers, as a man near
death ost-times feels no pain.

2. We are not inquisitive after ways of escaping, as a madman never seeks to
a Physician. No suspicion, no inquifition.

3. Reproof rouzes up men's consciences, and makes them look about them, as a
roaring canon wakes a man out of a dead sleep.

4. It enflames their affections, and makes them to look after salvation. As
pain felt makes a man look after a Physician, that slighted him before.

Use. Let us highly esteem of reproofs (it may be we should have gone on
sleeping to hell else) So did David, Psalm. 141.5. Let the righteous reprove me,
it shall be an excellent oil. Giving ear to reproof is the high way to wisdom.
The ear that hears the reproof of life, abides among the wise, Prove. 15.31.

3. Doct. Wonderful gifts are given by Gods Spirit. Therefore Wisdom faith,
Behold. See a catalogue of them, 1 Cor. 12.4, etc. Act. 2.17. etc. Gises of
knowledge, wisdom, healing, miracles, tongues, prophecy. See Abraham's
admirable faith, Heb. 11.9, 10. He had Canaan, yet like a stranger looked for
heaven. See Job's strange patience, Job 1. Wonder at David's hearty
thankfulness, whereof the Psalms are witnesses, and Solomon's vast wisdom set
out in his rare Proverbs. These could not grow in the Wilderness of corrupted
nature, and therefore must come out of a garden planted by Gods Spirit.

Use. Acknowledge God in the gifts of his servants. Nature, Art, Experience,
cannot produce those admirable effects, and gifts, which some men have
attained. Though days may speak, and multitude of years may teach wisdom.
Yet, there is a spirit in man, and the inspiration of the Almighty gives them
understanding, Job 32.7, 8.

4. Doct. Abundance of spiritual gifts are given to believers. A fountain is
poured out on them. The water that I shall give him, shall be in him a well of
water springing up into everlasting life, Joh. 4.14. This well is opened, Joh.
7.39. This spoke he of the Spirit which they that believe on him should receive.

Reason 1. Because the persons are many, yea many thousands. An hundred forty
and four thousand Israelites, besides an innumerable company of believing
Gentiles, Rev. 7.4, 9. And if every one had but one several gift, they must
needs be many.

2. Every one of these has many gifts, as knowledge, holiness,
righteousness, meekness, sobriety, patience, magnanimity, faith, hope,
charity, etc. All then must needs mount to an huge sum.

Use. Pray for abundance of spiritual gifts, they are the best treasure. Lose
nothing for asking.

5. Doct. They that will turn to God, shall not want the plentiful help of
Gods Spirit to direct them. If any man will do his will, he shall know of the
doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of my self, Joh. 7.17. The
Spirit of truth shall testify of me, Joh. 15.26.

Reason 1. Because they will pray for Gods Spirit, and God will give the Spirit
to them that ask it, Luke 11.13.

2. Because God is so free, that he gives the Spirit to them that go away from
him; as to Paul, Act. 9. Much more will he give it to them that return to him.
Christ that seeks the lost sheep, will give his Spirit to the returning sheep.

Use. It encourages men to turn to God, for then they shall have his Spirit for
their Instructor, Sanctifier, Comforter.

6 Doct. The Spirit and the Word must go together to guide. Both are joined in
this verse. The comforter shall bring all things to your remembrance, whatsoever
I have said unto you, Joh. 14.26. The Spirits must be tried, whether they be of
God, 1 John 4.1. How shall that be known? By hearing Gods Word. Hereby know we
the Spirit of truth, and the spirit of error, 1 John 4 6.

Reason 1. Because else contradiction, untruth, double dealing, is put upon
God. For if his Word say one thing, and his Spirit another, he contradicts
himself, and must needs speak falsely in one of them, for contraries cannot be
true. If it be day, it is not night. If a man bid his servant before men to do
one thing, and whisper the contrary in his ear, Is not this double dealing?

2. Because there is no other sure way to distinguish between a true speaking
and a false speaking Spirit.

Use. It reproves those that cross the Word under pretense of the Spirit, and
revelation, and so set God at daggers drawing with himself, and make him
inconstant to say and unsay. God in his Word bids read the Scriptures, hear the
Word, says, Paul the great Apostle knew but in part. Men deny all these by the
Spirit. A lying spirit must it needs be, that contradicts Gods plain Word. To
the law, and to the testimony; if they speak not according to this Word, it is
because there is no light in them, Isa. 8.20.

Verse. 24. Because I have called, and ye refused; I have stretched out my hand,
and no man regarded.
In the two last verses, Wisdom has persuaded wicked men to repentance by
expostulations, exhortations, and promises; now she declares the miserable
estate of wilful persons, with comminations, menaces, and threatening. Seeing
notwithstanding the plenty of means, many would not get knowledge, Wisdom
threatens great mischiefs to them, and shows the cause to be their rejecting
wholesome counsels, diligently given to them. Here is a threesold threatening,
and all very sore.

1. Wisdoms derision of them in their miseries, verse. 24, 25, 26.

2. Her denying audience and help to them in their extremity, verse. 27, 28.

3. Self-destruction, without hope of repair, verse. 29, 30, 31, 32.

In the first threatening note, 1. Their obstinacy in finfull ways, verse. 24,
25. 2. Their heavy punishment, v. 26.


In the first she opposes their unkindnesse to her kindness, in four
particulars. Two in verse. 24. The other two in verse. 25.

In the first opposition note, 1. Her call, and 2. their relusing to come in.

In the second, Her stretching out her hand, and their disregarding it.

In the third, Her giving good counsel, and their despising it.

In the fourth, Her reproving them for their-evill ways, and their rejecting
it. She had been every way kind to them, and they were every way ungrateful
unto her.

For the words.

(...), Because. This word does not give a reason of what went before, but of
what follows after, to wit, of the destruction of ungodly men, spoken of v. 26.
It is a word used only in retribution of good or evil. Because thou have done
this thing, etc. in blessing I will bless thee, etc. Genesis 22.16, 17. Because
thou have defiled my Sanctuary, etc. I will also diminish thee, etc. Ezekiel.
5.11. The cause of the judgment is set down first, that Wisdoms kindness to
them, their unkindnesse to her, and the justice of their destruction might the
more sully appear, and so God get glory. So David gives glory to God, Against
thee, thee only have Isinned, and done this evil in thy sight; that thou
might be justified when thou speekest, and be vleer when thou judge, Psalm.
51.4.

I have called. See on verse. 21. There it siguified crying, here it notes
out-calling or inviting to come to Wisdom, that they might be instructed by
her, and obey her precepts.

And ye refused. Ye refused to come to me, that ye might hear, learn, and obey.

(...), I have stretched out. The word imports,

1. Holding out, or stretching out a thing at full length. I will redeem you
with a stretched out arm, Exodus 6.6.

2. To decline, or go downward. My days are like a shadow that declineth,
Psalm. 102.11. For shadows grow longer in the declining of the day, and then
suddenly vanish away. The day goes away, for the shadows of the evening are
stretched out, Jer. 6.4. Here it is taken in the first sense, for stretching
out.

(...), My hand. The word signifies,

1. That member of the body so called. Thine hand upon thine head, Jer. 2.37.

2. Strength, or power. When he sees that their power is gone, Heb. their
hand, Deuteronomy. 32.36.

3. Counsel and advice. Is not the hand of Joah with thee in all this? 2 Samuel
13.19.

4. A stroke or plague. Withdraw thine hand far from me, Job 13.21.

5. A place. Thou shall have a place also without the camp, Deuteronomy. 23.12.

6. Power over a thing, or poffession of it. Behold he is in thine hand, Job
2.6.

7. Action, which for the most part is done with the hand. He that has clean
hands, Psalm. 24.4.

8. An instrument, for the hand is the instrument of many actions. From men
which are thy hand, O Lord; or with thy hand, Psalm. 17.14.

9. Bounty. Besides that which Solomon gave her of his royal bounty, 1 King.
10.13. Heb. hand. For men give with the hand.

10. Labor. Which is done by the hand. If a stranger wax rich by thee, Heb. if
the hand of a stranger get; that is, if he thrive by his labor.

The word is taken here literally, but the phrase is figurative. Stretching out
is literal, and hand is literal, yet stretching, out the hand is figurative.
So in the Sacrament of the the Lords Supper, This is my body, Mat. 26.26. This
is literal, and my body is literal, yet this is my body is a figurative
speech. The figure is not in the words severally, but in the joining of them
together in a sentence. Stretching out the hand imports,

1. To strike, or punish, for men stretch out the hand to give the greater
blow. I will also stretch out my hand upon Judah, Zeph. 1.4.

2. To call one to us. I stretch out my hands unto thee, Psalm. 143.6. As we
call on God to come to help us in our miseries, so Wisdom calls simple ones
here to come to her for help and instruction. As if she had said, Ye were as
deaf men, or men far off, that could not hear my voice; therefore I gave you a
figne to come to me. The meaning is, I left no outward means of calling you
uneffected.

And no man reguarded, Heb. and there was no regarder. Not, that none at all
did hearken to Wisdoms voice, but the generality did not. So Joh. 3.32. No man
receives his testimony. They that attended to it were as none in comparison of
the multitude who slighted it, or none of you regarded it.

Figures. Stretching out the hand, for beckening one to us. A figure of the
figne or adjunct, for the thing signified, or subject.

Note two charges in this verse.

In the first note, 1. The call. 2. The refusal. In the call note, 1. The
illative particle, Because. 2. The person calling, I. 3. The act, have called.



In the resusall note, 1. The persons resusing, and ye. 2. The act, refused.


In the second charge note, 1. The invitation. 2. The rejection.


In the invitation note, 1. The party inviting, I. 2. The act, have stretched
out my hand.


In the rejection note, 1. The party rejecting. And no man. Every one, or most
men rejected Wisdoms invitation. 2. The act, regarded. They gave no heed to it.


1. Doct. Threatenings follow lost exhortations and reproofs. Because Wisdoms
words are not regarded in this verse. therefore she threatens, verse. 26. This
method is observed, Deuteronomy. 8.11. with verse. 19. Destruction is there threatened
to those that forget Gods words. See the like, Deuteronomy. 11.26. where a blessing
and a curse is set before the people, according as they prove obedient or
disobedient.

Reason 1. Because God is willing to use many means of ture before he destroy
finners. The axe is laid to the root of the trees, before they be cut down,
Mat. 3.10. This is Gods method, to exhort, dissuade, threaten, before he
destroy.

2. He will not fight before he proclaim war, nor come as an enemy cowardly
before warning given, or behind a man's back. He threatens Nineveh before he
would destroy it, Jonah 3. Cur minatur Deus, antequam puniat? Sc. ne puniat.
Chrysostom. Minatur, ne caedat: He threatens that he may not strike. August.

Use. It is good to know Gods method or manner of proceeding in his Court, as
well as men's in their Courts. Men know not else how to prepare for trial, or
prevent danger, Threatening is the last help, if men slight that, the threatened
judgment will follow. Else God were not true, neither would his threats be at
all regarded.

2. Doct. Gods judgments never come without a cause. They never did so, as
appears,

1. In Gods letting man lose his image, who had so shamefully abused it. So
rebellious Citizens lose their privileges.

2. In laying the curse on man and his posterity. The ground is cursed for
Adam's fin, Genesis 3.17. So traitors and their posterity are tainted in blood,
and their lands confiscated.

3. In the destruction of the old world by the flood. The cause was, because
the earth was filled with violence, Genesis 6.13.

4. In the destruction of Sodom by fire and brimstone from heaven, because
their sin was very grievous, Genesis 18.20.

5. In Jerusalems destruction by the Romans, for killing the Prophets, Luke
13.34, 35.

6. In the ruin of the seven Churches of Asia, Rev. 2. and 3. Neither will
Gods judgments ever fall on any without just cause. The fall of Babylon will
be very just. Rev. 18.24. For in her was found the blood of Prophets, and of
Saints, and of all that were slain upon the earth. So will the destruction of
Antichrist and Popery be most just, for deceiving many, Rev. 19.20. The end of
the world, and loss of all worldly comforts, Luke 17.26, 27. Hell it self will
justly fall upon unmerciful men, that relieve not the poor, Mat. 25.41, 42.

Use. Let us give God the glory of his justice in all his judgments. So does
the Psalmist sing, Righteous art thou, O Lord, and upright are thy judgments,
Psalm. 119.137. So the Emperor Mauritius confessed in the same words, when he
saw his children murdered before his face, and was himself after them to be
slain by Phocas. Many can do it in general, and for judgments on others, that
are loath to do it in their own case in particular. But Gods people stick not
to shame themselves, to honor God. O Lord, righteousness belongs unto thee,
but unto us confusion of faces, Dan. 9.7. The Lord is righteous, for I have
rebelled against his commandment, Lam. 1.18.

3. Doct. God calls us to repentance many ways.

I. By verbal ways; as,

1. By admonitions, showing us, we are out of the way. Ye have not obeyed my
voice. Why have ye done this? Judge. 2.2.

2. By reproofs, chiding them for their fin^. He makes them worse then Oxen and
Asses, and calls them a sinful nation, with other opprobrious names, Isa. 1.3,
4.

3. By dehortations, calling them from their finfull ways. Wash you, make you
clean, put away the evil of your doings from before mine eyes, cease to do
evil, Isa. 1.16.

4. By disswafions, urging them by reasons to forsake their sins. I have no
pleasure in the death of him that dies, says the Lord God: wherefore turn
your selves, and live ye, Ezekiel. 18.31.

5. By threats terrifying them. I will not drive them out from before you, but
they shall be as thorns in your sides, Judge. 2. v. 3.

6. By promises alluring them. I should soon have subdued their enemies, and
turned my hand against their adversaries, Psalm. 81.14.

II. By spiritual ways. As,

1. By checks of conscience. Their conscience bearing witness, and their
thoughts accusing one another, Romans 2.15.

2. By monitions of his Spirit. Behold, I stand at the door, and knock: if any
man hear my voice, and open the door, I will come in to him, and will sup with
him, and he with me, Rev. 3.20.

III. By real ways. As,

1. By examples. I ^btained mercy for a pattern to them which should hereafter
believe, 1 Timothy 1.16.

2. By judgments on others. Aholah is delivered into the hand of her enemies,
that Abolibah might be warned, Eze. 23.9, 10, 11. So Gods judgments on the
rebellious Israelites in the Wilderness are examples to us, upon whom the ends
of the world are come, 1 Cor. 10.11. Belshazzar must be slain, because he knew
what befell his Father, yet repented not, Dan. 5.22.

3. By judgments on themselves. I have diminished thine ordinary ^ood, and
have delivered thee unto the will of them that hate thee, Ezekiel. 16.27.

4. By mercies. I drew them with cords of a man, with bands of love, and I was
to them, as they that take off the yoke on their jaws, and I laid meat unto
them, Hos. 11.4.

Use. Let us bewail the desperateness of our natural condition, whom none of
those calls will draw to God.

4. Doct. Many refuse Wisdoms call. Three grounds to one are naught, Matt.
13.4, etc. The invitation to the heavenly Kings Sons wedding is slighted by
those that were invited. But they made light of it, and went their ways, one
to his farm, another to his merchandise, Matthew. 22.5.

Reason 1. Because some are in love with their own inventions. This evil
people, which refuse to hear my words, which walk in the imagination of their
heart, Jer. 13.10.

2. Because others are in love with worldly pleasures, profits, or preferments.

Use. Let us not follow the multitude in refusing Gods call. Say not, I will
not be fingular. Why should I regard it more then they? I shall escape as well
as my neighbors. Consider who calls. God, who is great and good, can and will
prefer thee. He may say more truly then Balak, Did I not earnestly send unto
thee to call thee? Wherefore came thou not unto me? Am I not able indeed to
promote thee to honor? Numb. 22.37. Consider to what he calls. To holiness,
which is most commendable; to happiness, which is most profitable. Follow
holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord, Heb. 12.14.

5. Doct. We are by nature far out of Gods way. A call will not be heard, nor a
beck regarded. They are all gone aside, Psalm. 14.3. They are all gone out of
the way, Romans 3.12. The Ephesians were once without God in the world, Ephesians.
2.12. Yea, the Fathers of the Patriarchs were Idolaters, Josh. 24.2.

Reason 1. Because we are gone clean out of hearing. We regard not Gods Word.

2. We are gone clean out of fight, which is further out of the way, for men
cannot hear so far as they can see. We regard not Gods works.

3. We are gone far in the ways of the world. The further in a by-way, the
further out of the highway.

4. We are gone far in the ways of Satan. The further men go in a contrary
way, the further are they out of the right way.

Use. Let us bless God the more for bringing us into the right way, when we
look upon other men's dangerous errors. Such were some of you, 1 Cor. 6.11. Yea,
all of us: We our selves, also were sometimes foolish, disobedient, etc. Tit.
3.3. Such we should have been still, if God had not wonderfully reclaimed us.
Insult not then over others, but pity them, and pray for them, and thank God
heartily for reducing you.

6. Doct. The generality of men regard not the fignes, whereby God calls them
to repentance. They regard not outward means, as rain and fruitful seasons,
Act. 14.17. Jer. 5.24. nor the sending of Christ to save them. He was in the
world, and the world knew him not, Joh. 1.10. Not only strangers, but Jews
refused him. He came to his own, and his own received him not, Joh. 1.11.
Neither do the most receive the Gospel preached. The wise Athenians mock at it,
Act. 17.32.

Use. It informs us of the unsafenesse of following the generality. Most men go
in the broad way, and will lead their followers to hell. Wide is the gate, and
broad is the way, that leads to destruction, and many there be which go in
thereat, Mat. 17.13.

Verse. 25. But ye have set at naught all my counsel, and would none of my
reproof.
Wisdom proceeds in setting down the cause of the great judgment threatened,
v. 26. which was obstinacy and perverseness in them, illustrated by her kind
dealing with them, and their ingratitude toward her, and contempt. This was
set out in two particulars in the former verse. Her call, and their refusing to
come; her beckening, and their disregarding. In this verse. it is amplified by
two more. She not only calls and beckens, but also gives good counsel, which
they set at naught. And when that was slighted, she chid and reproved them, as
she had just cause, but they would none of that neither.

For the words.

(...), But, Heb. And. Yet it is often translated But, and carries with it an
oppofition to what went before, with an aggravation. As chapter 10.14. Wise men lay
up knowledge, but the mouth of the foolish is near destruction. See the like,
chapter 12.12. and in most verses of that Chapter. So here, though ye refused to
come to me when I called you, and would not hearken when I made fignes to you,
yet I neglected nothing fit for me to do. I might have let you go on and
perish. But I was mo^e careful of you, then ye were of your selves. I came to
you, and gave you good counsel, which ye despised. Yet, I went further and
reproved you, but ye would not regard it neither. See more on chapter 2.22.

(...) Ye have set at naught. The word signifies,

1. To reject a thing, as esteeming it not worth the looking after, or
receiving. Poverty and shame shall be to him that refuses instruction, chapter
13.18.

2. To go back from a thing spoken, as if it were not worthy to be performed. I
the Lord have spoken it, it shall come to pass, and I will do it; I will not
go back, etc. Ezekiel. 24.14.

3. To make one naked, and liable to shame, fit to be contemned. Aaron had made
the people naked unto their shame among their enemies, Exodus 32.25.

4. To revenge and destroy men, as esteemed not fit to live any longer. Praise
ye the Lord for the avenging of Israel, Judge. 5.2.

5. To make to cease, or to be idle Wherefore do ye Moses and Aaron let the
people from their works? Exodus 5.4.

Here it is taken in the first sense for rejecting a thing as vile. The Latins
call it despicere, to look down upon a thing as beneath us, lying on the
ground, and not worthy of a look from us; as on the contrary, suspicere, to
reverence, is to look up at a thing, as above us, and worthy of reverence from
us. We set a thing at naught, when out of contempt we never look after it.
Others press the word further, to the deriding of good counsel, but I doubt
whether the word will carry so much or no. And there be other words for that,
as (...), verse. 22. (...), verse. 26. Yet this implies more than bare refusing;
ye counted it of no value at all.

All. See on chapter 1.13.

My counsel. Some take it for advice, how to do well; and reproof, for
disswasion from evil. But Counsel here is to be taken for all the wholesome
precepts and admonitions given by Wisdom, whether to do good, or avoid evil.
And reproof is chiding men for not hearkening to counsel. I would by my
counsel have kept you from much evil, and done you much good. I showed you
how to escape hell, and attain heaven. But ye regarded not my counsel at all,
though given for your good. It is a fault to refuse good counsel given by any,
though by a simple man; but a greater fault to refuse Wisdoms counsel, which
always gives good counsel. It is a fault to refuse any of Wisdoms counsels, a
greater to refuse all.

And would none of, Heb. would not have. That is, ye rejected it, or ye
resolved not to obey it. Meiosis. Some stretch it further, to refusing to hear.
But the word properly signifies, to rest in a thing as well pleased with it,
and being willing to follow it. And here is intimated the not liking of
Wisdoms reproof, and resolving not to be amended by it. And this is more then
slighting it, or counting it a thing unprofitable.

My reproof. Neither counselling nor chiding would mend you. For the word see
on v. 23.

The sum is. Ye despised all my wholesome counsels which I gave you for your
good, and continued in bad ways that tend to destruction, that you might spend
your time unprofitably, and take no pains to get wisdom, and therefore ye must
needs perish.

Figures none. In the third charge note, 1. The note of oppofition, But. 2. The
parties accused, Ye. Ye simple ones, scorners and sools, v. 22. for all these
were guilty. 3. The act, have set at naught. 4. The object, counsel.
Aggravated, 1. From the giver, my. Wisdoms counsel. 2. From the extent, all.
Not some only. This is a great slighting of Wisdom, as if she spoke foolishly
always, and were not worthy to be heard at any time.



In the fourth charge note, 1. The note of conjunction, which shows it to be a
new charge, And. 2. The act, would none of. Ye utterly refused it. 3. The
object, my reproof.


1. Doct. Good counsel is profitable to men in it self. Else would not
Wisdom have blamed men for slighting it. Therefore Christ gives it to the
Angel of Laodicea. I counsel thee to buy of me gold tried in the fire, etc.
Rev. 3.18. David praises God for it, though given him by a woman: Blessed be
the Lord God of Israel, which sent thee to meet me this day; And blessed be thy
advice, and blessed be thou, 1 Samuel 25.32, 33. It is profitable,

1. To inform our ignorance. For no man knows always what is best for himself.
A stander by may see more then a Soldier, and give good warning.

2. To cure our heedlesnesse. Many of the faults of Gods servants come from
hence, and may by others good counsel be prevented.

3. To repair our falls; for we lie in sin sometimes till we be admonished by
others. Nathan tells David of his sin before he thought of repenting, 2 Samuel 12.

4. To comfort our souls. As it is an ease to let out our sorrows, like corrupt
matter, into our friends bosom, so to receive oil of consolation from them.

Use 1. It should make us willing to give good counsel. This they may give
that have no silver nor gold, and it is worth giving. And then may we say as
Peter in another case, Silver and gold have I none, but that which I have (good
counsel, which is better) give I unto thee, Act. 3.6.

2. It should make us willing to take good counsel. We would take good money
of any, why not good counsel, which is far better, though given by mean men?

3. It shows us the excellency of the Ministry, whose main end is to give good
counsel to miserable men, yea the best counsel. We love them that will show us
the way to live with comfort here, much more should they highly be esteemed,
that teach us the way how to live for ever. How beautiful are the feet of them
that preach the Gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things? Romans
10.15. It is also one of Christ's titles, he is called, Counselor, Isa. 9.6.

2. Doct. Though good counsel be very profitable, yet are some so bad, that
they will not take it. So Elie's Sons hearkened not to the voice of their
Father, 1 Samuel 2.25. So Rehoboam forsook the counsel of the old men, 1 King.
12.8.

Reason 1. Because of love of sin. Men love not them that speak against their
friends.

2. Because of custom in fin. This stops men's ears to good counsels.

3. For pride of heart. They think it a disparagement to be guided by others,
as if they were not wise enough to guide themselves.

4. For prejudice. Either they that counsel them are inferior, and so thought
not wise enough, nor good enough to advise; or such against whom they have
taken displeasure, and so think they speak out of ill will; or else they are
aged, and would have them grave before their time (as in Terence, Volunt nos
illico nasci senes; They would have us old men, as soon as we are born.) Or
lastly, they are Ministers, and would bring all under their girdle.

Use. Let us like good counsel the better, because many despise it. The
greater part are seldom good husbands for the world, much less for heaven.
Wicked men's despising Gods law, made David love it the more. They have made
void thy law, therefore I love thy commandments above gold; yea, above fine
gold, Psalm. 119.126, 127.

3. Doct. It is a dangerous condition not to hearken to good counsel. Elie's
Sons not hearkening to the good counsel of their Father, was a sign the Lord
would stay them, 1 Samuel 2.25. So says the Prophet to Amaziah, I know that God
has determined to destroy thee, because thou have not hear^ened to my counsel,
2 Chr. 25.16.

Reason 1. Because it lays a man open to spiritual evils, a^ to hardness of
heart. My people would not hearken to my ^^yce, so I gave them up unto their
own hearts lust; and they walked in their own counsels. Psalm. 81, 11, 12.

2. It ^ayce a man open to temporal evils. So says Jeremy to Zedekiah, If
thou will not go forth to the King of Babylons Princes, th^n shall this City be
given into the hands of the Chaldeans, and they shall burn it with fire, and
thou shall not escape out of their h^^^, Jer. 38.18.

3. It brings death here, as it did to good Josiah. He was warned to avoid the
danger, but would not, 2 Chronicles. 35.21, etc.

4. It brings eternal death, 2 Thessalonians. 1.8. They that obey (...) the Gospel,
must perish for ever.

Use. It reproves those that not only are naught of themselves, but also so bad
that they are past all good counsel. They lay themselves open to many rocks
and quicksands. Their condition is very bad, and well-nigh desperate.

4. Doct. Reproof, although it seem rough, is very profitable. David desires it
as an excellent oil, Psalm. 141.5. Paul requires it for a good end, Rebuke them
sharply, that they may be sound in the faith, Tit. 1.13.

Reason 1. Because it is a glass to show us our sins, when we cannot see them
our selves, nor admonition will not make us look into our selves. If a Fathers
telling will not serve, he must chide.

2. It is a bridle to keep us from sin for time to come, when no warning will
serve. For it carries anger with it in the reprover, and shame in the reproved.

Use. Let us not be offended at reprovers, but love them. Reproofs may work,
when promises, exhortations, admonitions will not.

5. Doct. Though reproof be very profitable, yet many regard it not. Vzziah was
wroth, when reproved by the Priest, 2 Chr. 26.19. The Jews regarded not
Isaiah's reproof, Isa. 1.4, 5. Asa was wroth with the reproving Seer, and puts
him into prison, 2 Chr. 15.10. They hate him that rebukes in the gate, Amos
5.10. Ahab cries out to Elijah, Have thou found me, O mine enemy? 1 King.
21.20. Nulli grata reprehensio. Reproof is a bitter pill, it goes down with few
men.

Reason 1. Because it is a kind of disgrace unto them, and an accusation of
folly. Had they done well, they needed not to have been reproved.

2. It crosses their decrest sins, and men cannot abide to be crossed in what
they love.

Use. Let us show our selves wise men, by looking rather, what is profitable
for us, then what is pleasing to us* Intemperate persons feed on ill meats, and
die; sober men forbear, and live. So must we in spiritual things. Look on
reproofs as profitable, look off the bitterness of them, and be amended by
them.

6. Doct. It is a dangerous condition to reject all reproofs. Poverty and shame
shall be to him, that refuses instruction, but he that regards reproof shall
be honored, chapter 13.18. If the ear that hears the reproof of life, abides
among the wise, Prove. 15.31. then he that rejects it, must dwell among fools.

Reason 1. Because then Gods Word has delivered them over to Gods sword, which
is very sharp. If Gods Word be sharper then any two edged sword, Heb. 4.12.
(which yet can kill a man) how sharp is Gods sword then?

2. Such a man may take David's oath safely, As the Lord lives, there is but a
step between me and death, 1 Samuel 20.3. Nothing but some heavy judgment
between him, and hell. Little else likely to recover him. He is like a man at
Sea, some three inches from death.

Use. It blames them that think they are safe, because no reproof will stir
their conscience. This is their misery, not their liberty. No Canon will make a
dead man afraid, yet a living man is far better. No danger will fright a mad
man; yet a man in his wits is in a far better condition. Hearken then to
reproof, that ye may live in safety.

Verse. 26. I also will laugh at your calamity, I will mock when your sear
comes.
The causes of their miseries were expressed before, the grievousnesse thereof
is expressed in these words, and those that follow. They should be
comfortless, helpless, and ruined. God would show himself righteously
unmercifull to them. They had despised calls, becks, counsels, reproofs, and
God would despise them in their miseries.

For the words.

(...), I. The Pronoune is added in the Original, for Emphasis sake, which
else needed not, as being included in the verb. I, even I will laugh. Not only
men your enemies, but (which is far more grievous) I the wisdom of God will
deride you.

(...), Also. It imports a proportionable revenge. Ye scorned good counsel, and
I will laugh at your calamity. This particle doubled, imports,

1. A distribution. Neither by Prophets nor by dreams, 1 Samuel 28.15.

2. A conjunction of two things together. Both the Prophet and the Priest, Jer.
14.18.

3. A comparison of things in a way of likeness or equality. As Babylon has
caused the slain of Israel to fall; so at Babylon shall fall the slain of all
the earth, Jer. 51.49.

4. An augmentation or increase of a thing. Neither heretofore nor since thou
have spoken unto thy servant, Exodus 4.10.

(...), Will laugh. The word signifies,

1. Slighting of a thing. He scorneth the multitude of the City, Job 39.7.

2. Smiling upon one in good will. If I laughed on them, they believed it not,
Job 29.24.

3. Jesting or being in sport. Whether he rage, or laugh, Prove. 29.9.

4. Dariding or laughing to scorn. He that sits in the heavens shall laugh;
the Lord shall have them in derision, Psalm. 2.4. So it is taken here. Some by
Gods laughing understand the pleasure that God takes in the execution of his
justice upon wicked men. But it rather intimates Gods strange carriage toward
them, then any content in God. The anger of Wisdom comes from upbraiding unto
threatening. Some take it for not pitying them in their misery, as men pity not
those whom they laugh at. For God has no face to laugh. Ridere Dei est nolle
hu^anarum afflictionum misereri. Greg. Moral. l. 9. c. 15. Gods laughing is not
pitying men's afflictions. A similitude from Men. It is a misery to be in
trouble, but a double misery to be laughed at by them who only can help. Others
take it for deriding or slighting their counsels or projects for delivery, and
leaving them helpless. Others take it for bringing them into so miserable a
condition, that they should be a derision, and made a laughing stock to all
men. But this is somewhat far fetched. It is taken here for forsaking them
utterly, and having no more compassion on them, then men have on one going to
execution, when they laugh at him, and make sport at his torments.

At, Heb. In. But sometimes it notes the object or cause of a thing. That they
die not in their uncleanness, Lev. 15.31. it, for their uncleanness. So here
God will laugh, not only in the time of, but at their calamity. Your trouble
shall be my joy.

Your. Your calamity, who refuse all good counsel.

Calamity, (...). The word literally signifies a cloud, or mist, as in a dark
day. There went up a mist from the earth, Genesis 2.6. Figuratively, it signifies
calamity and affliction, which is uncomfortable and troublesome, like a foggy
misty day. The calamity of Moab is near to come, and his affliction hastes
Jast, Jer. 48.16. So here it fignifies affliction so sore that it darkens men
like a cloud, and affords them no light of comfort, or hope of delivery.

(...), I will mock. The meaning is, that as he that mocks another casts his
former courses in his teeth with contempt, so God in their miseries will cause
them to think of all their evil ways with shame. This is a further addition
to their misery.

When, Heb. (...), in the coming of.

(...), Your fear. The word signifies,

1. Fearing, or the act of fear. The fear of the Lord fell upon all the
Kingdoms, 2 Chr. 17.10.

2. The person feared. Jacob swear by the fear of his Father Isaac, Genesis 31.53.

3. The thing or evil feared. Be not afraid of sudden fear, Prove. 3.25. So it
is taken here. Wicked men are afraid of trouble, death, loss of goods, and
life; and all these things shall come upon them. Which because it will be
terrible unto them, and make them sore afraid, it is called by the name of fear
it self. So Job 39.22. He mocketh at fear.

(...), Comes. The word signifies,

1. Coming to a place. When we came to the Inn, Genesis 43.21.

2. When it is spoken of the Sun, it signifies the setting of it. Because the
Sun was set, Heb. came, Genesis 28.11.

3. When spoken of a Woman, it signifies carnal copulation. A modest
expression. After David had gone in to Bathsheba, Psalm. 51. in the title.

4. When it is spoken of days, it signifies old age. Abraham was old, and well
stricken in age, Genesis 24.1. Heb. come into days. See the marg. there.

5. When it is spoken of words, it signifies the fulfilling of them. Where is
the Word of the Lord? let it come now, Jer. 17.15.

6. When it is spoken of Corn, and Fruit, it intimates the gathering of them.
Ye bring in little, Hag. 1.6. Heb. ye have made little to come.

7. When it is spoken of a congregation, or society of men, it notes admission
into, as a member to enjoy all the privileges of it. A Moabite shall not enter
into the congregation of the Lord, Deuteronomy. 23.3.

8. When it is spoken of a Covenant, it signifies making of it, or accepting of
it. Which had entered into the covenant, Jer. 34.10.

9. When of going to Fathers, it signifies dying. Thou shall go to thy Fathers,
Genesis 15.15.

10. When it is joined with going out, it signifies administering an office in
the Commonwealth, Church, or Family. Which may go out before them, and which
may go in before them, Numb. 27.17.

11. When it is spoken of a thing without life, it notes the coming to pass of
a thing. There came a great wind, Job 1.19. So here. When those things ye fear
shall come upon you.

Figures. Laugh at, a Metaphor taken from Scorners. Calamity, a Metaph. from a
Mist. Mock, a Metaph. Fear, a Metonymie of the adjunct for the subject. Comes,
a Metaphor from living creatures.

Note a double threatening in this verse.

In the first note, 1. The word of coherence, Also. 2. The agent, I. 3. The
act, will laugh. 4. The cause, or object, at your calamity.


In the second note, 1. The act, I will mock. 2. The adjunct of time, when your
fear comes. In the time of your misery.


1. Doct. God pays wicked men in their own kind. Ye slighted my counsels,
and I will slight your miseries. The old world was destroyed by a flood of
water, for a flood of sins. Sodom by fire, for fiery lust. Egyptians children
slain, for slaying the Israelites Children. Joseph's brethren hardly used for
using him so. So they confess that was the cause of their distress, Genesis
42.21. So Adonibezek that cut off the thumbs and great toes of threescore and
ten Kings, had his own cut off, and confesses, As I have done, so God has
requited me, Judge. 1.7. So Shallum and Pekah Kings of Israel, flew their
predecessors, and were slain by their Successors, 2 King. 15. As David defiled
Vriah's Wife, so Absalom defiles his Concubines, 2 Samuel 12.10, 11.

Reason 1. That God may clearly declare his own justice before all men.

2. That men may clearly see their own fin written, as it were in their
punishment.

3. That men in greatness and power may take heed of wronging others, lest God
should set up others to pull down them.

4. To set a pattern of doing justice before Magistrates, as God did in his
Law. Who so sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed, Genesis 9.6. Eye
for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot, etc. Exodus 21.24.

Use. It serves to teach men that complain of hard dealing from others, to look
back and see if they have not dealt ill with others in the like kind.
Ministers complain of peoples not hearkening to them: Have they hearkened to
God? Magistrates complain of Subjects breaking their laws: Have they not broken
Gods law? Parents complain of Children slighting their words: Have not they
slighted Gods Word? Masters cry out of the falsehood of Servants: Have not they
been false to God? Let such as are guilty, give glory to God, who has paid
them in kind. (...)? Euripid. Orest. Should not they that act heavy things,
suffer heavy things? Non est injuria pati, quod prior feceris. Sen. de ira, l.
2. c. 30. (...). It is fit a man should suffer what he does. Pindar. Nom. 4.
See Isa. 33.1. Qui praedam vult esse merito fit praeda: He that will eat the
prey, deserves to be made a prey. Aug. in Ps. 38.

2. Doct. God himself will show himself an enemy to ungodly men. His anger will
consume obstinate sinners. Deuteronomy. 29.19, 20. Upon the wicked he shall rain
snates, fire and brimstome, and a horrible tempest; this shall be the portion
of their cup, Psalm. 11.6.

Reason 1. Because God hates wicked men, and that heartily also. The wicked,
and him that loves violence, his soul hates, Psalm. 11.5.

2. He denounces a perpetual war against them. The Lord has sworn, that the
Lord will have war with Amalek, from generation to generation, Exodus 17.16.

3. Nothing will sat is fi^ him but their utter destruction. I will utterly put
out the remembrance of Amalek from under heaven, Exodus 17.14.

4. After their death he will never be reconciled to one wicked man, no not to
eternity. Who shall be punished with everlasting destruction, 2 Thessalonians. 1.7.

Use. To reprove such as flatter themselves in their wicked ways, under hope
of mercy from God, while they continue in those ways that God hates. Who would
have so wise and powerful an enemy? Nothing can follow but nertain
destruction. For our God is a consuming fire, Heb. 12.29.

3 Doct. God will take no more pity of wicked men in their sorrows, then men
that laugh at other men's miseries. I will dash them one against another, even
the Fathers and the Sons together, says the Lord. I will not pity, nor spare,
nor have mercy, but destroy them, Jer. 13.14. He bids his servant lay load on
Babylon: Reward her even as she rewarded you, and double unto her double,
according to her works; in the cup which she has filled, fill to her double,
Rev. 18.6.

Reason. 1. Because God is immutable. He hates wicked men, and cannot affect
them, if they live and die so. It is against his nature.

2. His decrees concerning the end of wicked men are for eternity. He has
preordained all their misery, and cannot alter.

Use. It shows the vileness and venomous nature of sin, and abominablenesse of
it, that provoken the great God, that has more pity in him then all Angels and
men, so to be displeased, that when the creature shall be in misery, he will
let it abide so for ever, and show it no more pity in hell then they that laugh
at men in their miseries. Quod Deus loquitur cum risu, tu legas, cum fletu: If
God laugh, thou have good cause to cry. August. It makes God merry at his
creatures misery, who otherwise delights in mercy, Mic. 7.18. Trap.

4. Doct. God will cast wicked men's sins in their teeth in their miseries. Ye
have forsaken me, and served other gods; wherefore I will deliver you no more.
Go and cry unto the gods which ye have chosen, let them deliver you in the time
of your tribulation, Judge. 10.13, 14. Whosoever shall deny me before men, him
will I also deny before my Father which is in heaven, Matthew. 10.33.

Reason 1. Not that God will vouchsafe to speak to them in hell, but will cause
all their sins to come into their memory; which is as much as if he from heaven
told them of them, Psalm. 50.25.

2. Not only their memories shall bring them to their remembrance, whether
they will or no, but God will also sit in their consciences, and check them to
eternity. The conscience shall never lose his force. Excuse it cannot in hell,
therefore it will accuse for ever.

Use. Think of this ye that live in sinful courses, your fins will never be
obliterated. God will upbraid you to eternity. Men are ashamed to be mocked a
few days; how much more for ever?

5. Doct. Wicked men live in fear. Through the fear of death they are all their
life time subject to bondage, Heb. 2.15. I will send a faintness into their
hearts, and the sound of a shaken leaf shall chase them, Lev. 26.36. A
dreadful sound is in his ears, Job 15.21.

Reason 1. Because they think every thing threatens death to them, which
besides the pain of it, is the Iosse of all good had and hoped for.

2. Their conscience tells them of, and makes them fear evil after death, even
hell it self.

Use. See now if many wicked men be not gross hypocrites. They speak stoutly,
and brag, as if they were the most fearlesse men in the world; yet God that
knows their hearts, pronounces them timorous creatures. Tuliius Hostilius
worshipped Fear and Palenesse. Lact. Institut. Cataline was afraid at any
sudden noise. Salust. Richard the third, after the murder of his Nephews, could
never sleep in quiet. Daniel Chron. Nor Charles the nineth after the Paris
Massacre. Thuan. These Tyrants became more terrible to themselves then ever
they were to others. Trap.

6. Doct. That which wicked men fear, will certainly come upon them. The Romans
did come and destroy Jerusalem, as the Jews feared, Joh. 11.48. The fear of the
wicked it shall come upon him, Prove. 10.24. I will bring their fears upon them,
Isa. 66.4.

Reason 1. Death will certainly come, which is most terrible to wicked men.

2. Hell will certainly come, with which their conscience frighteth them here.

Use. It shows the gross self-flattery that is in ungodly men. They make us
believe they fear not evils, and are confident they will never come on them,
but they are deceived in both. Because ye have said, We have made a covenant
with death, and with hell are we at agreement; when the overflowing scourge
shall pass through, it shall not come unto us: Your covenant with death shall
be disanulled, and your agreement with hell shall not stand, when the
overflowing scourge shall pass through, then ye shall be trodden down by it,
Isa. 28.15, 19.

Verse. 27. When your fear comes as desolation, and your destruction comes as
a whirlewind, when distress and anguish comes upon you.
Wisdom comes now to a second judgment to be denounced against fools, that
despise instruction. And that is helplesnesse. They shall cry to her for help,
but all in vain. She will not hear, v. 28. The judgment is set down,

1. By the cause of their crying, to wit, the greatness of their misery, and
grievousnesse of their punishment, in this verse.

2. By the fruitlesnesse of it. They should cry in vain, and to no purpose,
verse. 28. The cause of their cry, and grievousnesse of their punishment, is set
out by sour similitudes.

1. From an enemy or flood, that sweeps all away.

2. From a whirlewind, which none can resist.

3. From bands that gird in a man, and pain him so as he cannot get out, or
from a besieged City.

4. From a disease that cleaves to a man, so that he cannot be rid of it. For
the words.

When your fear comes. See on verse. 22. it is called their fear, because they
should have feared it, or did fear mischief in general, though they went not
the right way to work to prevent it. Hereby is meant especially death, for many
wicked men fear not hell, though that be most to be feared. See on verse. 26.

(...), As desolation. The word signifies an utter laying waste of a Country in
war by an Army of Soldiers, who lay heaps upon heaps, and leave not a stone
upon a stone, Matt. 24.2. or by a flood or storm coming with a great noise and
violence, and suddenly carrying all before it. Therefore shall evil come upon
thee, thou shall not know from whence it rises, and mischief shall fall upon
thee, thou shall not be able to put it off, and desolation shall come upon thee
suddenly, which thou shall not know, Isa. 47.11. They came upon me as a wide
breaking in of waters, in the desolation they rolled themselves upon me, Job
30.14.

And your destruction. The same word that was transsated calamity, v. 26.

Comes. See on v. 26. This v. expounds the end of the last verse. before.

(...), As a whirlewind. Suddenly, and irresistibly, and with a terrible noise,
and fragor. It comes from a word that signifies to be consumed, or ended. It
sets out a violent wind, that blows all away before it like chafe, and
consumes it. Hereby is intended death taking away all those lovely things,
which men have been so long working for, and gotten with so much sweat. Sudden
death like a grievous whirlewind will blow them out of the world. Some take it
for a tempest at Sea, that rises suddenly after a long calm, when men are
secure, and lifts the waves up and drowns the ship. Aquila takes it for an
earthquake; and that suddenly shakes the earth it self, and throws down
Houses, and Castles, and swallows up men alive in the bowels of the earth.
However, it sets out an unlooked for, and unavoydable judgment.

(...). When distress comes. It comes from a word that betokens to keep in,
straiten, or besiege a man or a City, so that men have not room enough to
breathe, or to get things necessary, Isa. 29.2, 3. It imports any great grief
or trouble of mind, whereby the heart is as it were straightened, and kept in,
and oppressed. When ye are so distressed with troubles, that ye are straightened
like men in a narrow way, in great danger, yet finding no way to get out.

(...), And anguish. It comes from a word that fignifies cleaving fast to one,
like a disease that cannot be parted from the body, though it pain a man sore.
An evil disease (say they) cleaves fast unto him; and now that he lies, he
shall rise up no more, Psalm. 41.8. It may be meant of bodily pain. Some think
that both these words signify the same thing, and two words of the same
signification are used to heighten the signification, and to signify extreme
trouble, great fear and grief shall accompany your Iestruction and death. As if
one word were not sufficient to set out the horror of it. See the like, Job
14.10, 11, ^^. Where death is set out in diverse phrases. So many words and
similies are used here to show the grievousnesse of their destruction. It is
called fear, because it will make them sore afraid. Desolation suriously
breaking in upon them. Destruction making an end of them. A whirlewind blowing
away not only light things, as chafe, but also blowing down trees, houses,
and strong buildings. Anguish and distress grievously afflicting both soul and
body, and all to show how sharply God will proceed against impenitent sinners.
As if an enemy came with a noise to destroy a City, or a great house fell by a
hideous earthquake, with a terrible noise, or a ship sunk in a raging storm, or
the corn were smote down with hail, or floods overran all the fields: So
terrible will the destruction of wicked men be.

Upon you. On you simple ones, scorners and fools, v. 22.

Figures. Comes, Befalls you. A Metaphor, attributing a living action to a
dead thing, as Job 1.19. There came a great wind from the wilderness.

The misery to come upon these wicked ones, is set out, 1. Literally. 2. By
similitudes.


In the first note, 1. The object, When your fear. 2. The act attributed to it,
comes.


The similitudes are taken, 1. From a Country laid desolate, as desolation. 2.
From things thrown down by a tempest. And in it, 1. The misery, and your
destruction. 2. The act, comes. 3. The manner, as a whirlewind.



The third fimilitude may be taken from a body straightened, or a City besieged,
when distress.

The fourth from a painful disease cleaving to a man, And in it, 1. The evil,
anguish. 2. The act, comes. 3. The object, upon you.


As if it came down from heaven by the hand of God, who will lay on load as an
enemy invading you.

The points we shall handle, shall be only of the conditions of wicked men's
destruction, as they naturally arise out of the former similitudes. Enemies lay
a place desolate quickly. Tempests soon throw down trees and houses.

1. Doct. The destruction of wicked men shall be sudden and unexpected. Sodoms
destruction was in a Sun-shiny morning when they expected comfort, but were
soon destroyed. Genesis 19.23, etc. The Israelites in the Wilderness were
destroyed while the meat was in their mouths, Psalm. 78.30, 31. So the old World
was unexpectedly destroyed. They did eat, they drank, they married wives, they
were given in marriage, until the day that Noe entered into the Ark, and the
flood came and destroyed them all, Luke 17.27. Nebuchadnezzar's casting down,
came suddenly, Dan. 4. and Belshazzar's death, Dan. 5. When they shall say,
Peace, and safety, then sudden destruction comes upon them, as travail upon a
woman with child, and they shall not escape, 1 Thessalonians. 5.3.

Reason 1. Because their sins hinder them, and blind them so, that they cannot
see the danger, till it be upon them.

2. Their businesses hinder them, and leave them no time to think of danger.

3. Their pleasures so content them, that no fear of alteration can sink into
them many times, and then lightly danger comes.

4. Their hearts will not let them think of danger, but soon cast out such
thoughts, lest they make them melancholy.

Use. 1. Let not wicked men flatter themselves. Danger may be nearest when they
think it farthest off. It is more terrible to perish suddenly then by degrees.
Trees, houses, ships, that are strong are suddenly overthrown by a rising wind.
As the whirlewind passes, so is the wicked no more, Prove. 10.25. Thou breakest
the ships of Tarshish with an East wind, Psalm. 48.7.

2. Let them prepare for a better condition. They know not how soon they may
lose this. Who would live a Tenant at will, that may get a Lease of years, or a
Fee-simple? Make sure of heaven quickly, and then all will be well.

2. Doct. The destruction of wicked men is irresistible. Who can refist a
strong invading enemy, or a whirlewind? And what will ye do in the day of
visitation, and in the desolation which shall come from far? To whom will ye
flee for help? and where will ye leave your glory? Isa. 10.3. Therefore shall
evil come upon thee, thou shall not know from whence it rises, and mischief
shall fall upon thee, thou shall not be able to put it off, and desolation
shall come upon thee suddenly, which thou shall not know, Isa. 47.11.

Reason 1. Because their destruction comes from God, whose power and wisdom no
man can resist.

2. He can go beyond all their power and wisdom, though the greatest that is
or can be in any or all the creatures.

3. He can disappoint all their friends, and all supplies.

4. He can set all creatures against them. And how can the strongest creature
resist all other in heaven, earth, and hell?

Use. It shows the great misery of ungodly men, they cannot resist destruction.
If an enemy come into a Land, or besiege a City, if there be force enough to
resist, destruction will not follow; else all will be laid waste. Wicked men
cannot resist God, therefore they must needs perish.

3. Doct. The destruction of wicked men shall be total, or universal. An
enemy lays all waste, Cities, Houses, Gardens. A whirlewind or flood sweeps
all away.

Reason 1. It appears in particulars. Their credit will be gone. Not only
their good name shall decay, but their name it self shall be lost, as a rotten
thing stinks and wears away. The name of the wicked shall rot, Prove. 10.7.
Their goods shall be gone. Thou fool, this night shall thy soul be required of
thee; then whose shall those things be, which thou have provided? Luke 12.20.
Yea, Cujus eris tu? Whose shall thou be? says Bernard. Their life shall be
lost. Whosoever shall save his life (by sinful ways) shall lose it, Mat.
16.25. Yea, their soul and all shall be lost. What is a man profited, if he
shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? Mat. 16.26.

2. By the causes of it. Their fins are universal. Their thoughts, words,
deeds, altogether sinful. Humors that run over all the body, make all the
body sick. They sin against all Gods commandments, and that wilfully and
constantly, and therefore must perish wholly.

Use. Let wicked men labor to get out of this condition. A man would be loath
to live in a trade wherein he should get nothing, more loath to live in a
calling wherein he were sure to lose all, and spend his stock. This is the
wicked man's condition, get out of it, else ye perish totally.

4. Doct. The destruction of wicked men will be irrecoverable. Such was the
destruction of those two rich fools, Luke chapter 12. and 16.

Reason 1. Because they are carried clean out of the world. Here a man may be
poor one day, and rich another; after this life, poor once, and poor for ever.

2. They are carried to hell immediately after death, and out of hell is no
redemption.

Use. Take heed of impenitency, lest it bring you to irrecoverable punishment.
Bajazet the great Turk could say, Resipiscentia sera nulli unquam profuit: Too
late repentance never did any man good. Men inclining to a dropsy or
consumption, will seek for cure before it grow incurable. Repent in time, lest
ye perish for ever. Ad Deum redeundum, aut per Deum pereundum. Return to God,
or perish by God.

5. Doct. The destruction of wicked men will be miserable. Such was the
destruction of old Babylon, Jerem. 49.25, etc. A sword upon men and beasts.
Such of new Babylon, Rev. 18.7, etc. Torment, death, mourning, famine, etc.

Reason 1. Because it is helpless condition. Evil men cannot help others, if
they would, for they are in the same danger, and need help themselves. Good men
would not help them if they could, because they are Gods enemies, devoted by
him to eternal destruction.

2. It is a comfortless condition. No ease or comfort will be afforded to
them. Not a drop of cold water to cool the tongue, Luke 16.24.

Use. Let us bless God, that frees us from so great a destruction, which we
have deserved as much, yea more then many that are in hell. Should not we
praise God for deliverance from so a great a destruction, who are in the same
condenmation? Luke 23.40.

6. Doct. The destruction of ungodly men is lamentable. Jeremy takes the
destruction of the people so to heart, that he wishes his head a fountain of
waters, and himself in a wilderness, to weep his belly full alone, without
interruption, Jer. 9.1, etc. Kings and Merchants must weep and lament for the
downfall of Babylon, Rev. 18.9, 11. See the truth of it in two glasses, one
here, the other hereafter. The one in the Egyptians, who had dominatered over
the Israelites, yet at last the Israelites see them swimming dead on the Sea,
Ex. 14. The other in hell, where their worm dies not, and the fire is not
quenched, Mar. 9.44. This causes weeping and gnashing of teeth, Mat. 8.12.

Use. Remember the woe to them that laugh now, their state shall be lamentable,
Luke 6.25. Wicked men's joy terminates in this world. Better weep for sin here,
then for punishment in hell.

Verse. 28. There shall they call upon me, but I will not answer; they shall seek
me early, but they shall not find me.
Wisdom having set out their misery before, now removes all help from them in
their misery. And their anguish is increased by the fruitlesnesse of their
prayers. A sad condition to be miserable and helpless, yet a most just
punishment, that they that would not hear God, should not be heard of God. Ye
heard the cause of their crying in the last verse, extremity of misery, now ye
have the fruitlesnesse of it in this verse.

For the words.

(...), Then, In that moment when they see their destruction coming upon them.
I called in their prosperity, and they would not hear. They shall call in their
adversity, and I will not hear. There is both an Emphasis in that particle, and
an Antithesis. Now I call, and they will not hear. Then they shall be glad to
call to me, but I will not hear. When their hearts are full of distress and
anguish, then their tongues shall be compelled through extremity of torment and
danger, to cry to me.

They. They, who have thus slighted me. Which slighting Wisdom takes so
unkindly, that she will no more speak to them in all the Chapter. Only, she
tells other men what shall become of them. She speaks not in the second person,
as before, but changes it to the third. No more ye, but still they; speaking at
a distance, as if they were unworthy to be spoken to directly any more.

Shall call. They shall pray for help. For the several significations of this
word, See on v. 21.

Upon me. Whom they would not hear before.

But. See on v. 25.

(...), I will not answer. This word signifies,

1. To speak, or begin a speech. And Job spoke and said, Job 3.2.

2. To cry out, or speak aloud. And the wild beasts of the Islands shattery,
Isa. 13.22.

3. To sing. Sing unto the Lord with thanksgiving. Sing praise, Psalm. 147.7.

4. To speak for or against one, or bear witness. Thou shall not bear false
witness, Exodus 20.16.

5. To hear what is said, or regard it. Behold, I ery out of wrong, but I am
not heard, Job 19.7.

6. To give an answer to what is said. Then answered Bildad, Job 8.1.

7. To grant what is desired, which is a real answer. They cried, but there
was none to save them; even unto the Lord, but he answered them not, Psalm.
18.41.

8. To be afflicted. I was greatly afflicted, Psalm. 116.10.

Here it is taken in the seventh sense. I will not grant what they pray for, so
that they shall pray to no purpose, and without success. And none else can
help them, therefore their case is desperate, and they must needs perish, being
forsaken both of God and men.

(...), They shall seek me early, Heb. They shall seek me in the morning. For
then comes the light, by the benefit whereof things sought for may be found
out. They shall seek me not coldly nor faintly, but as diligently, as men that
rise betimes in the morning, as soon as they can see, to seek somewhat lost.
The greatness of their distresses shall make them to seek me quickly, very
diligently and carefully, they shall spare for no pains, they shall break their
sleep in the morning to do it. So diligent men use to seek things they would
find. So the Israelites went early in the morning to seek for Manna. They
shall seek me diligently, as men that begin in the morning betimes, and hold on
till night.

But. See on v. 25.

They shall not find me. They shall not find me gracious and merciful unto
them in the time of their perplexities. Seeking here is praying, and finding is
speeding. Seek ye the Lord while he may be found, call ye upon him while he is
near, Isa. 55.6. Ask, and it shall be given unto you; seek, and ye shall find,
Mat. 7.7. For the word, see on v. 13.

Figures. Call upon me. A figure of the general for the particular. The
meaning is, Pray to me.

Answer. I will not grant what they ask. The same figure as before. For a man
may answer and deny. Seek me early, Pray earnestly to me, as men seek good
things lost. So shall they pray fervently to me to deliver them. A Metaphor.
Not find me, Not have their desires of me, nor be satisfied, as men are that
find what they seek for. A Metaphor.

Note a double threatening.

In the first note, 1. Man's call. 2. Gods refusal.


In man's call note, 1. The adjunct of time, Then. 2. The act, shall they call.
3. The object, upon me.


In Gods refusal note, 1. The person, but I. 2. The act, will not answer.


In the second threatening note, 1. Man's endeavoring. 2. Gods rejecting.


In man's endeavoring note, 1. The persons, They. 2. The act, shall seek early.
3. The object, me.


In Gods rejecting note, 1. The parties, They. They that seek me. 2. The act,
shall not find. 3. The object, me.


1. Doct. Affliction makes men seek to God, that slighted him before. So the
Israelites did, Their cry came up unto God by reason of the bondage, Exodus
2.23. When they were smitten down by their enemies they would pray, 1 King.
8.33.

Reason 1. Poena aperit oculos, quos culpa tenebat clausos. Greg. Men are dull
sighted in prosperity, and quick sighted in adversity.

2. Because they know not where to get help else. As the prodigal child, when
none else would relieve him, thought of returning to his Father, Luke 15.16,
17. Wicked men will try all ways ere they will seek to God, he is their last
refuge.

3. Suspicion begins to work when trouble begins to come. Wicked men are often
called Fools in this Book. Fools fear nothing, till they feel something, and
then they fear more then needs.

4. Conscience then begins to terrify them, setting fin before them in its
colors, with death and hell attending it, Rev. 6.8.

Use. 1. To mitigate our sorrows in our afflictions. They bring some good. They
have honey as well as a sting. They oftentimes drive men to God. Foelix
necessitas quae cogit ad Christum: Happy necessity that drives men to Christ.

2. To condemn those that keep aloof from God even in affliction. Men may keep
out at Sea in a calm, but they that keep out in a storm are desperate. So are
such as call not on God in trouble. Seamen will pray in a storm, that swear in
a calm.

2. Doct. Prayer is an invocation or calling upon God. Call upon me in the day
