of trouble, Psalm. 50.15. They call not upon the Lord, Psalm. 14.4. A man that in
want or trouble calls upon his neighbor for help, 1 sees that he needs help, 2
desires to be helped, 3 sues to another for it, 4 to one that is able. So do we
in prayer, confess our want, defire relief, sue to God for it, who is able to
deliver us, Heb. 5.7.

Use. It instructs us in the nature of prayer. It is not with Papists or
ignorant persons, mumbling over words we understand nor, but spreading our
wants before God, and suing for supply. O Lord, I am oppressed, undertake for
me, Isa. 38.14.

3. Doct. God will not give ease to them that never call on him but in trouble.
They cried, but there was none to save them; even unto the Lord, but he
answered them not, Psa. 18.41. Though they cry in mine ears with a loud voice,
yet will I not hear them, Ezekiel. 8.18.

Reason 1. Because they had no acquaintance with God before. Men look after
their acquaintance in time of trouble, not after strangers, that have no
dependence on them.

2. Because they look merely after their own ease for the most part, and have
no love to God, else they would have regarded his service in their prosperity,
Hos. 7.14.

Use. It teaches us to get interest in God betimes, even in prosperity, to
follow Solomon's counsel, Eccl. 12.1. Remember now thy Creator in the days of
thy youth. We would be glad to have God to hear us in the troubles of old age.
Let us then be mindful of him in youth.

4. Doct. Affliction makes men earnest in prayer. In their affliction they will
seek me early, Hos. 5.15. When he slew them, then they sought him, Psalm. 78.34.

Reason 1. Because affliction is compared to fire. When thou walk through
the fire, Isa. 43.2. and fire will heat. So does affliction heat men's
affections.

2. Because they find much need of help, which in their prosperity they felt
not. A beggar will pray earnestly.

Use. It condemns our cold prayers both in fasts and other times in these sad
days. If ye will not pray earnestly now, when will ye? Wicked men will rise in
judgment against you. They pray earnestly in trouble.

5. Doct. Prayer is a seeking of God. Neither do they seek the Lord of hosts,
Isa. 9.13. Seek ye the Lord, Isa. 55.6.

Reason 1. He is as it were lost when he does not help us. God is departed from
me, and answers me no more, 1 Samuel 28.15.

2. He may be found an helper upon entreaty.

Use. No marvel if many never found God. They never sought him by hearty
prayer in all their lives, and must quite lose him at their death.

6. Doct. There is a time when God will not be found of some men, though they
seek him earnestly. Though they shall cry unto me, I will not hearken unto
them, Jer. 11.11. When ye make many prayers, I will not hear, Isa. 1.15. Then
shall they cry unto the Lord, but he will not hear, Mic. 3.4.

1. For the time. 2. For the persons.
For the the time. That is twofold:

1. After a time of long calling on them to return, yet slighted by them. He
that turns away his ear from hearing the Law, even his prayer shall be
abominable, Prove. 28.9. Yea, true repentance then, though it may deliver from
the curse, yet sometimes not from the cross. God would destroy Jerusalem for
Manasses his sins, though he repented, and Josiah reformed, 2 King. 23.26.

2. After this life. It is too late to cry for mercy in hell. Not a drop of
water to be gotten, Luke 16. God hears not impenitent finners here, much less
in hell. Here is time of repentance, there none. The door of mercy is shut up
for ever by death, Mat. 25.10. When the golden time of life is gone, no trading
for souls health. No physic after death. For the persons, they are,

1. Impenitent sinners. God hears not sinners, Joh. 9.31. Prayer and
repentance must go together, else no audience.

2. Unbelievers. The Word without faith does no good No more does prayer. An
unbeliever must not think that he shall receive any thing of the Lord, Jam. 1.7.

3. Hypocrites, that have no religion, but in show, and pray accordingly. Will
God hear the hypocrites cry, when trouble comes upon him? Job 27.9. Sure he
will not.

4. Uncharitable men. A father will not hear them that are cruel to his
children.

Use 1. It teaches us to take heed of putting off repentance. We may be in
hell in a moment; or God may be so offended with our peevish ways, that he
will not give us true repentance, nor hear us. A great revenge. It would vex a
man that his friend would not hear him in extremity. If we follow not Gods
instruction in our prosperity, he will not follow us with help in our misery.
He that meant to say, Lord have mercy on me, cried out at his death, Horse and
man, and all to the Devil. Perkins government of the tongue.

2. Let us hearken to God in our prosperity, that he may hearken to us in our
extremity, else we perish eternally. Quid aequius? quid justius? non
respeximus, non respicimur; non audivimus, non audimur. Salv. What more equal?
what more just? we regarded not, we are not regarded; we heard not, we are not
heard. I speak unto thee in thy prosperity, but thou said, I will not hear;
this has been thy manner from thy youth, that thou obeyest not my voice. The
wind shall eat up all thy pastors, and thy lovers shall go into captivity;
surely then shall thou be ashamed and confounded for all thy wickedness, Jer.
22.21, 22. To conclude, God will hear a penitent sinner at any time; yea, even
at the hour of death, as he did the penitent thief; but he often denies true
repentance to those that slight the means of grace, and always denies audience
to those that cry not with their hearts to him, when they howl on their beds
for corn and wine, Hos. 7.14. Let not then an impenitent sinner ever presume,
nor a penitent despair.

Verse. 29. For that they hated knowledge, and did not choose the fear of the
Lord.
We are come to the third judgment denounced, wherein Wisdom first sets down
the causes of the judgment, v. 29, 30. Secondly, the judgment it self, v. 31,
32.

For the first, Wisdom repeats the former just causes, to justify her
accusation, yet with some elegant change of words and order, to affect the more
with the variety of them, and to drive the causes of their ruin the more home
to their hearts, that at length they might repent and prevent it. An usual
thing in humane judgments, that the sentence may appear to be just. The Clerk
reads the causes of the condemnation, and the Judge oftentimes repeats them.
Their plagues are fearful, therefore Wisdom would have the causes of them
well known. If any man should ask, Why Lord art thou so inexorable and hard
toward them? The answer may be in the text, For that they hated knowledge. So
the words may look backward and forward. Thus he shows that they did justly
perish, and were justly neglected. Four causes mentioned before are here
repeated. The two first in this verse. The two lastin v. 30.

The first in this verse. is hating knowledge, mentioned verse. 22.

The second in this verse. also, is not choosing the fear of the Lord,
intimated, v. 7.

The third in verse. 30. is rejecting Wisdoms counsel, mentioned v. 25.

The fourth in v. 30. also is despising Wisdoms reproof, mentioned likewise v.
25. And in an elegant order. For,

1. Knowledge is to be gotten.

2. The fear of the Lord.

3. Good counsel to be hearkened to, for direction of life.

4. Reproof to be regarded when we sin, that we may reform. For the words.

(...), For that, Heb. In stead of that. For their sin they shall be punished.

They hated knowledge. See on v. 2, 4, 22.

(...), And have not chosen. To wit, in their prosperity; when they might and
should have done it, they did refuse to do it, or despise it, as v. 24, 30.

The fear of the Lord. See on v. 7.

Figures none. Four causes of judgment are here set down. Two in this verse.
Two in the next.

In this verse. 1. Hating knowledge. 2. Not choosing the fear of the Lord.


In the next, 1. Refusing counsel. 2. Despising reproof.


In the first note, 1. The word of coherence, For that. 2. The act, they hated.
3. The object, knowledge.


In the second note, 1. The act; and did not choose, 2. The object, The fear of
the Lord.


The same things having been spoken of and handled before, verse. 7, 22, 25. I
shall only insist upon some generals.

1. Doct. Repetitions in Scripture are useful. Compare Phil. 3.1. with Phil.
4.4. Rejoice in the Lord, rejoice in the Lord always, and again I say rejoice. I
will not be negligent to put you always in remembrance. I think it meet as
long as I am in this Tabernacle, to stir you up by putting you in remembrance,
2 Pet. 1.12, 13. The same thing repeated in two verses.

Reason 1. They are great helps to the memory. Often reading imprints them deep
there. Therefore in the Gospels, the same Histories, Miracles, Precepts, and
Doctrine of Sacraments, are repeated. The same things are often found in the
second Epistle of Peter, and Jude.

2. They are great helps to the understanding, because of some different
expressions and additions. As in the doctrine of the Sacrament of the Lords
Supper some things are added, 1 Cor. 11. which are not in the Gospels.

3. They are great helps to the affections. Every new reading with delight
works more love, or joy, or sorrow, or fear. The oftener men view what they
love, the more they like it.

4. They are great helps to practice. The more we see things in Gods Book, the
more desirous we are to see them in our lives.

Use 1. It reproves the queasie stomachs of the people, that had rather hear
falsehoods under a glittering color of new truths, then the same things
inculcated on their souls, though never so sound. They like the same meat again
and again, especially if the sauce and dressing differ a little, and why not
then the same points of religion?

2. It calls upon Ministers to press the same truths. Religion follows not new
fashions, as Clothes do. Hence come errors, for want of a good foundation.
Plantas saepius adaquare conducit. Primas. Gardeners often water their plants
with the same water. God lays down the reasons now the second time, why he
destroys these ungodly men.

2. Doct. God cleers himself abundantly in his Word, of the destruction of
ungodly men. Had not God cause to destroy the old World? See Genesis 6.11. The
earth was corrupt before God, and the earth was filled with violence. God
examines the cause of Sodom, and condemns them justly, Genefis 18. So he deals
with Israel, 2 King. 17. with Judah, 2 Chr. 36. with the Church of Ephesus,
Rev. 2. with Laodicea, Rev. 3.

Reason 1. Because sin the cause of it, is from us, and not from God. He
neither compels, nor counsels, nor allures, nor consents to it, but forbids it,
and threatens to punish it. O Israel, thou have destroyed thy self, Hos. 13.9.

2. It is justice in God to punish sin, and not cruelty, as in a Judge to
condemn murderers.

3. God foretells their destruction in his Word, and by his Ministers.

4. He uses many means to prevent it. By mercies, judgments, ordinances,
checks of conscience.

Use 1. It blames those who lay their dishonor upon Gods head. He will lay it
back on theirs, as Solomon did Joab's murder, and Shimei's curse. Their blood
shall return upon the head of Joab, 1 King. 2.33. The Lord shall return thy
wickedness upon thine own head, 1 King. 2.44. God will say, as Paul, I take
you to record, that I am free from the blood of all men, Act. 20.26. In
Sin Offerings, the persons hand that brought it, was to be laid on the head of
it, and not the Priests, to show that God was not the cause of death, but the
sinner.

2. Give God the glory of his judgments public, or particular, on others, or
our selves. He smites not without a cause. Say with the Church, The Lord is
righteous, for I have rebelled against his commandment, Lam. 1.18. I will bear
the indignation of the Lord, because I have sinned against him, Mic. 7.9.
Knowledge is put before the fear of God as a foundation.

3. Doct. There is no fear of God where there is no knowledge. Who knows the
power of thine anger? according to thine anger, so is thy fear, Psalm. 90.11.
Who is the Lord, that I should obey his voice, to let Israel go? I know not the
Lord, neither will I let Israel go, Exodus 5.2.

Reason 1. Because knowledge is the light of the soul. Men cannot work without
light. Nor affections do their part without knowledge. Ignoti nulla cupido. Men
love not, desire not, fear not, hope not, without knowledge of the object.

2. Knowledge is the guide and mover of the soul. It shows arguments to fear
God, as well as whom to fear. So the great wheel of the Jack makes the rest to
go; if it be still, the rest are so. There is then no fear of God without
knowledge.

Use. No marvel that many are so destitute of the fear of God. They dare swear
and lie. They are Ignoramusses. They know not Gods power, else they durst not
do it; nor his goodness, else they would not do it.

4. Doct. Many care neither for the knowledge nor fear of God. Israel does not
know, my people does not consider, Isa. 1.3. The unjust Judge did not fear God,
nor regard man, as himself confesses, Luke 18.4.

Reason 1. Because knowledge and the fear of God are difficult to obtain. There
are so many things to be known, and so high above Nature, and Art, that they
are not easily reached. And the fear of God is harder to get then knowledge.
For many get the one, and never come to the other.

2. They cross our corruptions, and curb them. The fear of God keeps men from
many sins, to which their corrupt nature would lead them. Joseph would not
wrong his Brethren, for (says he) I fear God, Genesis 42.18. But so did not I,
because of the fear of God, Neh. 5.15. Joseph lacked not power nor opportunity,
only Gods fear kept him back. Knowledge flies in men's faces after they have
sinned. Ignorant men are quiet after sin, because they know not that they have
done amiss.

Use. Be not offended at hard usage from ungodly men. They want knowledge. Had
they known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory, 1 Cor. 2.8.
Sure they want the fear of God, and then no good usage is to be expected from
them. I thought surely the fear of God is not in this place; and they will slay
me for my wives sake, Genesis 20.11.

5. Doct. Knowledge should be the guide of our choice. Now we believe, for we
know that this is indeed the Christ, Joh. 4.42. We believe, and are sure, that
thou art that Christ, Joh. 6.69.

Reason 1. It appears in credendis, in things to be believed. How can men
without knowledge tell what to believe of the World, or of the Church, or of
the world to come?

2. In agendis. In things to be done. How can men tell what is to be done
toward God, men, themselves, if they have no knowledge?

Use. We see here the sad condition of an ignorant man. He must needs be an
Infidel, and injurious to God and man, for he knows not what to believe or do.
Knowledge is the eye of the soul. A blind man knows not, which way to take.

6. Doct. They that choose not piety must be damned, as well as they that hate
knowledge, and they that refuse Wisdoms counsels and reproofs as well as
either. My people would not hearken to my voice, and Israel would none of me:
So, I gave them up unto their own hearts lust, etc. Psalm. 81.11, 12. And what
could follow then but damnation? Christ will come in flaming fire, taking
vengeance on them that know not God, and that obey not the Gospel of Jesus
Christ, 2 Thessalonians. 1.8.

Reason 1. Because these things stop up the way to heaven. Want of piety and
the fear of God keep them out. So does refusal of good counsels and rebukes.
And he that goes not to heaven, must go to hell.

2. They shut them up in the way to hell, and leave them no breach, whereat
they may get out. Some men begin to be frighted with the fear of God, when they
think of his power, or judgments. Others, that have no such thoughts, are
drawn out by the counsel of others that are escaped. Others that slight
counsel, are moved with reproof. These slight all, and perish.

Use. Think not your selves in a good condition, because ye are not the worst
of men, and hate not knowledge. Such as fear not God, nor regard counsel, nor
reproof, must perish also. Though ye put not out the light, nor cast away
physic, yet ye get no good if ye use it not well.

Verse. 30. They would none of my counsel, they despised all my reproof.
The third and fourth cause of the following judgments are set down in this
verse. which was all, but one word, interpreted before in v. 25. And in the
translation there also is another word, the same in sense. Setting at naught,
and despising, intend the same thing, though they be different words in the
Original. A little alteration there is. There counsel is despised and reproof
refused; here counsel refused and reproof despised. To show that wicked men do
both refuse and despise both counsel and reproof, and so are in a desperate
condition. For the words, see on v. 25. Their sin is aggravated, and rises by
degrees, to show the justice of their punishment. They not only rejected
knowledge, but also the fear of God; and not that only, but also his counsels;
and not that only, but also his reproofs. What remains, but that they eat of
the cursed fruits of their own labors?

There is but one word new to be expounded, (...), they despised, which imports
a contempt of a thing upon a light account of it. They had a small estimation
of Wisdoms reproof, and therefore would not be mended by it, and so are
inexcusable. Let Wisdom chide, if she would, they cared not for it, but would
do as they list.

Figures none. Note 1. The third cause of the judgment. 2. The fourth.


In the third note, 1. The act, They would none of. 2. The object, my counsel.


In the fourth note, 1. The act, They despised. 2. The object, all my reproof.


The particular doctrines have been handled on v. 25. For the words are the
same in effect, and well-nigh in syllables. The general ones are to be seen on
v. 26.

Verse. 31. Therefore shall they eat of the fruit of their own way, and be
filled with their own devices.
The complaint was renewed in the two former verses. The commination follows.
The cause there, the effect here. In their misery note,

1. The effect, in this verse.

2. Another cause, v. 32. Seeing ye have such an obstinate mind, and hard
heart, that ye would admit of no cure, what remains, but that you be filled
with those evils which your sins have deservedly brought upon you? God cleers
his justice by a common proverb then in use. It is just that men should eat out
of their own work, and reap what they sow. This proverb by way of similitude
shows, that as it is just and equal that Planters or Plowmen should eat of the
fruit or grain which they have labored for, or sown; and if they have great
increase of fruit, or sown much corn, or taken much pains about either, that
they should be partakers of the labors of their hands plentisully; so it is
just with God, that these should feel much sorrow and confusion, which their
dissolute lives, and froward hearts deserve. They shall have plagues answerable
to their fins, and bear the punishment of their evil counsels. For the words.

(...), Therefore. So it is tranflated, Job 35.16. Therefore does Job open his
mouth in vain. And Prove. 6.34. Therefore he will not spare. Because they were
sufficiently admonished, yet would not hearken unto me, but followed their own
lusts, and walked in vanity, they shall see what they shall get by it, when
their sins have brought irreparable losses upon them, when they shall be
forsaken of me, as I was of them. As they have gone their own ways, so they
shall suffer the woeful issue of them, because they refused my counsels and
corrections.

(...), They shall eat. The word literally fignifies devouring of meat, as
Exodus 34.28. He did neither eat bread, nor d^ink water. Metaphorically it
fignifies devouring any thing else; even by senseless things, as by the fire,
The fire of God has consumed the sheep, Job 1.16. By the sword, Shall the
sword devour for ever? 2 Samuel 2.26. By the earth, The land eats up the
inhabitants thereof, Numb. 13.32. Also it is used for receiving things brought
upon men by their own ways, or procured by their works, be they good or bad. A
man shall eat good by the fruit of his mouth, Prove. 13.2. Thou shall eat the
labor of thine hands, Psalm. 128.2. So here. They shall receive a just reward of
their wickedness. They shall eat as they baked, drink as they brewed. They
that sow the wind of iniquity, shall reap the whirlwind of misery.

(...), Of the fruit. Not part of it, as this particle is used of the fruit of
the tree, ye shall not eat of it; Genesis 3.3. but feed upon it to the full, as
follows in this verse.

(...), signifies, 1. The fruit of a tree. Of the fruit of the tree, Genesis 3.3.

2. That which proceeds from, or comes forth out of another thing, or is caused
by it, be it good, as chapter 8.19. My fruit is better then gold. Give her of the
fruit of her hands, chapter 31.31. Or be it bad, I will punish the fruit of the
stout heart of the King of Assyria, Isa. 10.12. I will bring evil upon this
people, even the fruit of their thoughts, Jer. 6.19. And so here. They shall
have evil fruit of evil ways. They shall be abundantly punished for
forsaking my counsels, and following their own. They shall be left to
themselves till they perish, Psalm 81.12.

Of their own way. See on verse. 15. They have promised themselves much
pleasant fruit out of their evil ways, but they shall find themselves
deceived in the end, and find bitter and deceitful fruit far other then they
expected. They shall bring destruction upon themselves by following their own
counsels, that would not be saved by following mine.

(...), And be filled. The word properly signifies to be satisfied. In
satisfaction there are two things, fullness and content. Therefore the word
(especially when it is applied to evil things) fignifies fullness alone; for no
man is content with misery, but he may be as full of it to his endless sorrow,
as they are of good things, who are fully satisfied with them. They shall be as
full of those evils, their sins bring upon them, as a man well filled is of
meat. They despised the pleasant fruits of wisdom, and shall feed on the
bitter fruits of sin.

With their own devices, (...). It signifies devices, counsels, or
consultations. Though they could never make an end of inventing and practifing
evil, yet they shall be squatted at last, and surcharged with the evil
effects thereof.

Figures. Eat, Receive. A Metaphor from Meats.

Fruit, Effect. A Metaphor from Trees.

Way, Practice. A Metaphor from Travelers.

Be filled, Hebr. satisfied. A figure of the effect for the cause.

Devices, for evil devices. A figure of the general for the special. As,
Isa. 1.8. They shall be as wool. That is, as white wool.

Here are two similitudes to set out these men's miseries. The first is taken
from Eating. The second from Fullness.

In the first note, 1. The word of coherence, Therefore. 2. The persons, they.
3. The act, shall eat. 4. The object, of the fruit of their own way.


In the second note, 1. The act, Be filled. 2. The object, with their own
devices.


1. Doct. Sins bring miseries upon men. Ye have plowed wickedness, ye have
reaped iniquity, ye have eaten the fruit of lies, Hos. 10.13. He that sows
iniquity shall reap vanity, Pr. 22.8. And that,

1. In a moral way, when God punishes men according to their sins. The
Israelites are slain, while the meat which they Iusted for, was in their
mouths, Numb. 11.33. What more just, then that men should reap that they sow?

2. In a physical or natural way. And that,

1. When fins breed diseases, as drunkenness breeds dropsies; gluttony,
surfets; wantonness, foul diseases.

2. When God leaves men to their own foolish courses, which ruin them.

Use 1. Let no man accuse God or others for his troubles or condemnation. His
own sins bring them upon him. Nemo laeditur nisi a seipso: No man is hurt but
by himself. Qui nolunt regi a prudentia Dei, necesse est, ut regantur ab
imprudentia sua, and in multos errores, mala, damna labantur: They that will
not be ruled by Gods prudence, must of necessity be ruled by their own
imprudence, and fall into many errors, mischiefs, damages.

2. When troubles come upon us, let us look back to our fins, yea to the fins
of our youth, that we may be humbled for them, as David was, Psalm. 25.7.
Remember not the sins of my youth. And Job, chapter 13.26. Thou make me to
possess the iniquities of my youth. Harvest follows long after seed-time. So
may misery after sin.

The sins mentioned before were not about matters of Justice, or Morality, but
of Religion.

2. Doct. Sins in matter of Religion bring heavy judgments on men, yea on
whole Nations. How costly was Idolatry in the Judges days? It made Gods people
slaves to Canaanites, and many oath adversaries. What cost Jeroboam's Calves,
Ahab's Baal, Israelites Idolatry? Loss of the Kingdom, and Captivity, 1 King.
17. The like effect had Judas slighting Gods Prophets, 2 Chr. 36. The seven
golden candlesticks were ruined by impiety, Rev. 2. and 3.

Reason. 1. Because duties of Religion more nearly concern Gods glory,
therefore such sins more highly offend him, as being not against his image
only, but against himself, not mediately, but immediately.

2. Because Gods honor is of more weight then man's good; for God is far
greater then man, and we far more engaged to him, then to any man.

Use 1. It discovers how different men's judgments are now adays from Gods,
how little love they have to God, how much self-love, that would have the least
sin against man punished by the Magistrate, but not the greatest against God.
They are like the Turks, who whip men for speaking against God, and kill them
for speaking against Mahomet, saying, God can revenge himself, Mahomet cannot.

2. Take heed of impiety. Moral men may condemn injustice more, but God
condemns impiety most.

3. Doct. Constant and continual evils come on sinners. See variety of
judgments one in the neck of another, Lev. 26.18, etc. Gods hand is still
stretched out against them, Isa. 9.12, 17, 21.

Reason. 1. Because evil men are constant in sin. Now evil of sin is not
barren. It breeds evil of punishment. Raro antecedentem scelestum deseruit pede
paena claud^: Sin was never so quick-footed, nor punishment so lame, but that
the latter could overtake the former.

2. God is constant in justice. If they sin still, he will punish still. A thief
must be punished the second and third time, as well as the first.

Use. It shows us, that fools and wicked men are not in vain confounded in this
Book of the Proverbs, and the words promiscuously used. What are they but fools
that heap sorrows on their heads, by continuance in sin, and will not give over
till they perish eternally?

4. Doct. Wicked men drive a trade of sinning. They walk, stand, fit in wicked
ways, Psalm. 1.1. They commit sin daily, as working in a shop, 1 John 3.8.

Reason. In a trade are two things considerable. Constant labor, and
expectation of gain. Walking for health is no trade, nor expectation of gifts
is no trade. A wicked man labors constantly in sin. He may stumble on a good
action, as a good man on a bad, but his head and heart both labor in sin. Gain
he looks for from it. His Motto is, Dulcis ^dor lucri e re qualibet: Gold smells
well, though raked out of a dunghill. He can gain by wantonness, oppression,
lying, flattery, etc.

Use. Here is an help to judge of our estate. Is our way a way of sin, or of
goodness? We must not try our selves by one act, either to clear our selves
for one good act, or to condemn our selves for one bad one. Our course of life
must clear or condemn us.

5. Doct. Abundance of troubles shall come upon wicked men. The back-slider in
heart shall be filled with his own ways, Prove. 14.14. Many sorrows shall be
to the wicked, Psalm. 32.10.

Reason 1. Their fins bring on them store of spiritual evils, as shame, grief,
despair, wherewith the mind is overburdened, as the flomach overprest with
meat, and made fick of a surfeit.

2. Bodily evils, as diseases, pains, etc.

3. Their ill life brings an ill death, violent or despairing.

4. Wicked men cannot be filled with sin here, but they must be filled with
misery in hell. A way of sin here, and a way of eternal sorrow there.

Use. It declares to us what is the portion of sinners. They take great content
in sinful ways, as if they were the only free and happy men; but their end
will be misery.

6. Doct. Ungodly men have many devices to undo themselves. So Achitophel and
Judas were wise enough to hang themselves.

Reason 1. Because God overpowers them in their own way, and beats them at
their own weapons, and takes them in their subtilty. He countermines, and
voyds their mines. He takes the wise in their own craftiness, 1 Cor. 3.19.

2. Because their Wisdom is imperfect. They know not how to prevent all
dangers.

Use. See the misery of wicked men. Their wittends to self-destruction.

Verse. 32. For the turning away of the simple shall slay them, and the
prosperity of fools shall destroy them.
Wisdom having in the former verse. set out the effect; to wit, the destruction
of ungodly men; here she concludes her threatenings with another cause of it.
This verse. gives a reason why wicked men shall be so horribly and inevitably
destroyed. And therein both expounds the former verse, and gives answer to a
secret objection. It might be demanded, Who are they that shall eat of the
fruit of their labors? The answer is in the text, simple ones and fools, that
turn away from Wisdoms instructions. It might be further demanded, But how
shall they eat of the fruit of their labors? The answer is in the Text again,
They will slay them, and bring them to destruction. But then it may be
objected, Wicked men thrive most, and they that slight Wisdoms counsels, grow
richest. The answer is ready, It may be so, but yet it will turn to their
destruction in the end, as the Ox to be slain, goes in the best pastures. The
Sunshine of prosperity ripens the sin of the wicked. Bernard calls it,
Misericordiam omni indignatione crudeliorem. A mercy that he had no mind to;
as being worse then all cruelty. What good is there in having a fine Suit with
the plague in it? As soon may a man miscarry upon the soft sands, as upon the
hard rocks.

For the words.

For. It gives a reason of what was said before. See on v. 9. They cannot
justly complain of my severity, because they themselves are the cause of their
own ruin. They will not be taught how to escape it, though they have not wit
enough of themselves to do it. Others read it But, as it is translated, chapter
9.18. But he knows not that the dead are there. And then they understand the
former verse. thus, God will suffer wicked men to eat of their labors, and
prosper for a time, but will destroy them in the end by their own prosperity.
The former reading agrees best with the scope, which is near threatening.

(...), The turning away. Some take it to be meant of turning away from God and
goodness, to error, and wickedness of life. Others take it for their turning
away from seeking after heaven to look after the world. So Demas forsook Paul,
having loved this present world, 2 Timothy 4.10. Others take it for turning away
from Wisdoms counsels given before, which they are charged withal, v. 25.30.
An unwillingnesse to be taught by Gods Ministers. And that agrees well with
what went before. When men will not be taught by Gods Ministers, destruction
follows.

(...), Of the simple. See on v. 4.22.

Shall slay them. Shall destroy themselves.

(...), And the prosperity. The word fignifies quietness and abundance, which
uses to follow peace.

Of fools. See on v. 22.

Shall destroy them. Shall lay them open to death, temporal and eternal. This
is Scripture language. In the day thou eatest thereof, thou shall surely die,
Genesis 2.17.

Figures. Turning away. A Metaphor from a Traveller that misseth his way.

Shall slay them. Shall be the cause of their death. A Metaphor from an
Executioner. So also in Destroy them.

Wisdom sets down two causes of their destruction.

The first is an averseness to instruction.

The second is, love of prosperity. These two concur in most sinful men, and
had before punishment answerable set down, to wit, Gods not hearing them, and
their destruction.

In the former note, 1. The word of coherence, For. 1. The act, the turning
away. 3. The agent, of the simple. 4. The effect, shall slay. 5. The object,
them.


In the later observe, 1. The cause, And the prosperity of fools. 2. The
effect, shall destroy them.


1. Doct. God is content to give a reason of his judgments, though he need
not. Here are two things to be proved: 1. That God need not give a reason of
his judgments. 2. That God will give a reason of them nevertheless.


For the first. God need not give a reason of his judgments. Who shall say
unto him, What do thou? Job 9.12. O man, who art thou that replyest against
God? Romans 9.20. The Potter need give no reason why one piece of clay is made a
vessel of honor, and another of dishonor.

Reason 1. Because God is of supreme authority. Superiors need not give account
to Inferiors of their proceedings: Inferiors must to Superiors.

2. He is in infite in justice. No doubt but his judgments are all just,
though men do not always understand the reason of them. A man may be
misinformed, or judge amiss out of passion, but God cannot.

For the second. God will give a reason of his judgments, though he need not.

Reason 1. Because of his love to man, being willing to inform him of his
proceedings. God will not hide his proceedings about Sodom from Abraham,
because he shall have a great posterity, and will acquaint them therewith, and
so bring much glory to God, Genesis 18.17, 18.

2. For man's good, that he may bring him to repentance. How shall the Child
mend, if the Father tell him not why he strikes?

3. That God may clear his own justice.

Use 1. It ets out Gods goodness plainly before our eyes, who being above all,
yet is pleased to make men acquainted with the reasons of his proceedings.

2. Let us make good use of this information. Let us observe the reasons of
Gods judgments, recorded in Scripture, that we may avoid the like sins, and
prevent the like judgments, for God is as just now as ever. Did he punish Adam
and Eve for disobedience, Cain for murder, the old Word for violence, Sodom
for Iuxury? He will punish others for it now. They are examples to us, upon
whom the ends of the world are come, 1 Cor. 10.11. Did he not spare Noah, nor
David, when they sinned against him? neither will he spare his offending
children now. Let us then be wise, and be ware.

2. Doct. They are simple that do not hearken to heavenly instructions, v. 22,
23.

Reason 1. Because they are made acquainted with the greatest danger to their
souls, that can be, and yet will not avoid it. If a man were told of a pit in
his way, out of which there were no escaping, and would for all that run into
it, were he not a simpleton?

2. The way to attain greater good then all the world can afford them, and that
for eternity, is made known unto them plainly, so as they cannot deny it, and
yet will not look after it: As if a man were showed an easy way to get a
Kingdom, and yet would live a beggar. Is not such a man very simple?

Use. It shows the great distance between Gods judgment and man's. Many of
those that are of great account for wit and policy in the world, God accounts
to be very simple, and so they will prove in the end. They must prove so, that
will not hearken to the counsels of the God of Wisdom.

3. Doct. Not hearkening to good counsel brings destruction. They despised
Gods words, and misused his Prophets, until the wrath of the Lord arose
against his people, till there was no remedy. Therefore he brought upon them
the King of the Chaldeans, who slew their young men with the sword, etc. 2 Chr.
36. 16, 17. They east thy Law behind their backs. Therefore thou deliveredst
them into the hand of their enemies, Neh. 9.26, 27.

Reason 1. Because it brings many temporal judgments upon men. God will set
the brand of his displeasure, and their disobedience, upon them, in letters of
blood.

2. If it bring not viol nce upon their bodies, yet it brings both body and
soul to perdition for ever. No man can invent a way to heaven. If he will not
then go the way that God has revealed, he mustiperish.

Use. Let this drive men to hearken to good counsel. If the odious name of
simple ones will not do it, let fear of eternal wrath open our ears and hearts.

4. Doct. Men in prosperity will seldom hearken to good counsel. I spoke unto
thee in thy prosperity, but thou said, I will not hear, Jerem. 22.21. Woe to
them that are at ease in Sion, Amos 6.1. The Prophet had little hope to do
good on them.

Reason 1. Because they think they are good enough already.

2. They think they shall continue so, and look for no change. Because they
have no changes, therefore they fear not God, Psalm. 55.19. David said in his
prosperity, I shall never be removed, Psalm. 30.6.

Use. Let rich men take heed, and not think themselves too good to hearken to
good counsel. They are in more danger then meaner men. Their ears are stopped
with their wealth.

5. Doct. Prosperity and folly go often together. Rich Nabal was a fool both in
name and nature, 1 Samuel 25.25. God calls the rich man fool, Luke 12.20.

Reason 1. Because wealth is not always gotten by wisdom. It may come by gift
or favor of Princes, or by inheritance, or by painful servants, as Laban's by
Jacob's pains, Potiphar's by Joseph's.

2. Because rich men are from their youth cockered by parents, and flattered by
others, which keeps them from the knowledge of the truth. Therefore said the
Philosopher, Great men learn nothing so well as to ride well, because the horse
will not flatter.

Use. Do not imitate rich men because of their wealth. They may be fools for
all that, and then why should wise men be guided by them? An Ape of a Fool is
very ridiculous. Prosperity and folly are well joined together, for where is
most wealth, there often times is least wisdom.

6. Doct. Prosperity is the ruin of many. As of those two rich men, Luke
12.16. and 16.19.

Reason 1. It often makes men let go piety, and then as boys learning to swim,
they let go their bladders, and sink. Quando hoc incautis non fuit ad
disciplinam, quod ignis ad ceram, quod solis radius ad nivem, vel glaeiem:
Prosperity to unwary persons is like fire to wax, or the Sun beams to snow or
ice. Bern. de Consideratione, l. 2. c. 12. Magnus est qui incidens in adversa,
non excidit a sapientia, nec minor cui praesens faelicitas si arrisit, non
irrisit. Ibid. He is a great man, who falling into adversity, falls not out of
wisdom; and he is no less, on whom present felicity smiling, mocks him not.

2. It is harder to bear prosperity well, then adversity. The Dutch Proverb is,
The feet must be strong that carry prosperity. (...). Xenoph. Cyropaed. It
seems to me an harder thing to bear good things well, then bad; for the latter
make many a laughing stock, but the former makes all men wiser. Peacocks let
down their proud feathers when they see their black feet. Hannibal's Army
having overcome the troublesome Alps, was spoiled by the Italian dainties.
Tribulatio probat unam patientiam; prosperitas vero omnes virtutes examinat.
Anselm. in Sentent. Adversity tryes Patience only, but Prosperity examines all
virtues.

3. Prosperity lays men open to many sins. To injustice in getting it. Qui
agit semper faeliciter, inique agit. Euripides. He that does always
prosperously, does unjustly. Quam grave onus homo faelix insipiens! nam
stultitia germana est iniquitatis. Aeschylus. How great a burden is a rich
fool? For foolishnes is sister to iniquity Fortuna quem nimium fovet, stultum
facit. Whom fortune cockers, him she makes a fool. Mimus. And our Savior calls
riches the Mammon of iniquity, because hardly gotten without it, Luke 16.9. It
is often abused to sensuality. One rich man cries, Soul take thine ease, eat,
drink, and be merry, Luke 12.19. The other was clothed in purple, and fine
linen, and fared sumptuously every day, Luke 16.19. It makes men secure.
Living long in prosperity, they neither foresee, nor seek to prevent their
ruin. It hardens men in sin, as it did Pharaoh.

4. It brings Gods judgments upon them. Noverca virtutis prospreitas; sic
bajulis suis applaudit, ut noceat. Convivis suis ab initio propinat dulcia, ut
cum inebriati fuerint, let hale vulnus admisceat. Chrysol Prosperity is the
Step mother of virtue. She so applauds her porters, that she hurts them. She
gives her guests pleasant cups at the beginning, that when they are drunk, she
may give them a deadly wound. So Amnon was slain, when his heart was merry with
wine, 2 Samuel 13.28. Is he happy that is strong to kill himself, or that runs
fast, and climbes high to break his neck? Like those that eating of the juice
of some poy sonfull herbs, die laughing. It hastens and heightens judgment.

Use. Dote not on prosperity, lest ye desire your ruin. I may say to you, as
Christ to the two Disciples, with their Mother, Ye know not what ye ask, Mat.
20.22. Are ye able to bear that burden? Rather use Agur's prayer to God, Give
me neither poverty nor riches, feed me with food convenient for me, Prove. 30.8.
Many might have sailed safe to the shore, if they had not put out their top and
top-gallant. Keep then the golden mean, and be safer.

Verse. 33. But who so hearkneth unto me, shall dwell safely, and shall be quiet
from fear of evil.
Wisdom having sent forth three sore threatenings to terrify ungodly men from
following their vain and dangerous ways, now concludes her speech with a
comfortable promise to persuade them to hearken to her wholesome counsels.

For the words.

(...), But. It often signifies And, and joins like things together. But
sometimes it is a note of opposition, as verse. 25. See there. The prosperous
condition of those that hearken to Wisdoms wholesome counsels, is opposed to
the ruin of those that despise them.

Whosoever hearkeneth. See on v. 5. Here it is taken for regarding Wisdoms
counsel, and obeying it.

Unto me. To me Wisdom, and those counsels that I have given, or such like
other given in Gods Word, or by his Ministers agreeable to it.

Shall dwell. Shall perpetually abide in safety. As a man that lives quietly in
his own house.

(...), Safely. Free from danger, or confidently. Free from fear; as follows.
Knowing he shall be safer and therefore need fear no evil. After that he has
hearkened to my counsel, and gotten wisdom according to my advice, God will
keep him safe within the compass of his protection. He shall be out of danger
of destruction.

(...), And shall be quiet. The word signifies,

1. One that is quiet outwardly, and inwardly, in state, and mind. One dies
in his full strength, being wholly at ease and quiet, Job 21.23.

2. One that lives securely in sin, and fears no danger, though he have cause.
Woe to them that are at ease in Sion, Amos 6.1.

3. One that is proud and insolent, for prosperity and quietness makes men
secure and proud. The scorning of those that are at ease, and the contempt of
the proud, are joined together, Psalm. 123.4. Here it is taken in the first
sense, for a good security or quietness.

From fear. See on v. 26. He shall lead a most quiet life, being free not only
from evil it self, but from the very fear of it. He shall not need so much as
to fear adversity.

(...), of evil. Sometimes it fignifies evil of sin, which is committed by
man. Man's thoughts are only evil continually, Genesis 6.5. Sometimes evil of
punishment inflicted by God. Shall there be any evil in the City, and the Lord
has not done it? Amos 3.6. So it is taken here. He shall need fear no hurt at
all. Figures none.

Note 1. The condition required. 2. A double promise.

In the condition note, 1. The word of opposition, But. 2. The person, who so.
3. The act, hearkeneth. 4. The object, unto me.


In the first promise note, 1. The thing promised, Shall dwell. 2. The adjunct,
safely.


In the second promise note, 1. The good promised, And shall be quiet. 2. The
object, from fear of evil.


1. Doct. All men shall not be in a safe condition. There is no peace, says my
God, to the wicked, Isa. 57.21. When they shall say, Peace and safety, then
sudden destruction comes upon them, 1 Thessalonians. 5.3.

Reason 1. Because many remain yet in their natural condition, as children
unregenerate, and there is no safety in being born subject to Gods wrath, Ephesians.
2.3.

2. Many are drencht deeper in that estate of condemnation, by innumerable
actual sins, as young men who follow the lusts of their own eyes, and consume
the cream of their time in vanity.

3. Men are deeper in it then they, as men that have made some show of
goodness, and afterward either return with Demas to the world, 2 Timothy 4.10.
or with the dog to the vomit, or the sow to the mire, 2 Pet. 2.21.

Use. Let us examine our selves whether our condition be safe, or no. There is
no safety to be had, unless we be reconciled to God by Jesus Christ. It is not
wit, nor wealth, nor strength that can save thee, nor multitude of friends.
Only Christ can shelter thee from Gods wrath. He shelters none but his own
members, and that not in profession only, but in truth. Ciphers in his
Arithmetic, neither advance themselves nor other numbers. Try if thou be a
true member of Christ by these notes:

1. If thou have another heart, as Saul had, when God made him a King. That
heart becomes not a member of Christ, that became a limb of Satan.

2. What have thou done or snffered to honor Christ? This was the Philippians
mark. Your sufferings are unto you an evident token of salvation, and that of
God, Phil. 1.28. They must look for no spoils, that will not fight for their
General.

2. D^ct. Wisdoms counsels are worth hearkening to. Hitherto tend Wisdoms
earnest persuasions, verse. 22, 23. ch 9.4. In both which places simple persons
are earnestly solicited to give audience to Wisdoms precepts. Hitherto tend
her sweet promises of communicating excellent and right things, chapter 8.6. and
9.5.

Reason 1. Because they are safe. There may be danger in following other
counsels. None in following Wisdoms. It is in Religion as in the State; folly
ruling overthrows it, and not wisdom. The foolish Pilot overthrows the ship,
not the wise.

2. All safe things are not honorable, but Wisdoms counsels are like
Achitophel's, as if a man had enquired at the oracle of God, 2 Samuel 16.23. or
like Solomon's wise sayings, which men came from far to hear. And there came of
all people to hear the wisdom of Solomon, from all the Kings of the earth
which had heard of his wisdom, 1 King. 4.34.

3. All things honorable are not profitable. Many die honorably in fighting for
their Country, that get nothing by it; but Wisdoms ways are profitable also.
Godliness is profitable to all things, having promise of the life that now is,
and of that which is to come, 1 Timothy 4.8. Wisdom brings happiness, and many
particular comforts, Prove. 3.13, etc. We see wise men thrive in Trades, when
fools spend their patrimony.

4. All things profitable, are not comfortable, as Matches made for money, but
Wisdoms counsels are comfortable also. Her ways are ways of pleasantness,
and all her paths are peace, Prove. 3.17.

Use. Let us open both our hearts and ears to such counsels as these scattered
in the Book of God, the fountain of wisdom. We are too prone to hearken to
foolish counsels, as Absalon was to give ear to the unsafe counsel of Hushai,
2 Samuel 17.14. And to the sinful counsel of Achitaphel, to go in to his Fathers
Concubines, 2 Samuel 16.21, 22. The whole world foolishly hearkens to the
unprofitable counsel of some idle ringleaders at the Tower of Babel, Genesis
11.4. The Jews to the uncomfortable counsel of their Captains, to go back into
Egypt, Jerem. 43.5. Let us for time to come, rather hearken to Wisdoms
counsels, which are safe to the Soul, honorable to the Body, profitable to the
State, comfortable to the whole man. And of such counsel we shall never need
to repent. It is strange that the World should call, and men run; the Devil
call, and men fly; but when God calls, they will not creep.

3. Doct. Constant safety is prepared for good men. Trust in the Lord, and do
good, so shall thou dwell in the Land, and verily thou shall be fed, Psalm.
37.3. Great peace have they which love thy Law, and nothing shall offend them,
Psalm. 119.165. Thou shall see the good of Jerusalem all the days of thy life.
Yea, thou shall see thy childrens children, and peace upon Israel, Ps. 128.5,
6. For I, says the Lord, will be a wall of fire unto her round about, Zec. 2.5.

Reason 1. Because they have a guard of Angels set about them by God. He shall
give his Angels charge over thee, to keep thee in all thy ways, Psalm. 91.11.

2. God himself is their guard. He that dwells in the secret place of the
most high, shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty, Psalm. 91.1. Who are
kept by the power of God through faith unto salvation, 1 Pet. 1.5.

Use. Let us learn spiritual policy in these dangerous times. Who would not be
glad to be safe in these storms? Follow Wisdoms counsel. Labor for piety, and
thou shall be safe.

4. Doct. Quietness also is the portion of Gods servants. When he gives
quietness, who then can make troubles, Job 34.29. 1. Quietness outwardly, if
God see it fit for them. O that thou had hearkened to my commandments! then
had thy peace been as a river, Isa. 48.18.

2. Quietness inwardly. Being justified by faith, we have peace with God, Romans
5.1. Quietness in life. The meek shall inherit the earth, and shall delight
themselves in the abundance of peace, Psalm. 37.11. Quietness in death. Mark
the perfect man, and behold the upright; for the end of that man is peace,
Psalm. 37.37. In the grave, which is their bed. He shall enter into peace; they
shall rest in their beds, each one walking in his uprightness, Isa. 57.2.
After death for ever. None can pass the great gulf between them and hell, to
molest them, Luke 16.26. They rest from their labors, Rev. 14.13.

Use. Woe to those that seek to disquiet the people of God. They go about to
cross Gods will, and he will cross theirs.

5. Doct. A good man need not fear any trouble. Thou shall not be afraid of
destruction, when it comes, Job 5.21. Thou shall not be afraid of the terror
by night, nor for the arrow that flies by day, Psalm. 91.5. He shall not be
afraid of evil tidings, his heart is fixed, trusting in the Lord. This
fearlesnesse proceeds,

1. From some inward principles. A good man may be like a ship at Sea, in such
a storm, that he has no anchorroom abroad, nor haven near, all that sustains
him must be within: As,

1. An equal and proportionable ballancing by ballast, or goods. So a good man
may have peace of conscience, which may make him fearlesse. He that knows
himself at peace with God, what need he fear the wrath of all the creatures?
Such may glory in tribulation, Romans 5.3. and take delight in them, as in sweet
smelling roses.

2. The skill of the Ship-master makes them not to fear. God gives spiritual
wisdom to his, how to carry them in and get out of any trouble. Wisdom only
can teach men how to keep an eternal Sabbath of rest in the soul.

3. Labor of ship-men is needful to preserve the ship. Except these abide in
the ship, ye cannot be saved, Act. 27.31. So God gives spiritual courage and
grace to his, to hold up their heads in all troubles.

2. From outward helps: As,

1. Gods protection. I will give peace in the land, and ye shall lie down, and
none shall make you afraid, Lev. 26.6. They know that God who has undertaken
to deliver them, has many ways to do it, and they rest upon that, and are
quiet and fearlesse.

2. He has a guard of Angels about him. The Angel of the Lord encampeth round
about them that fear him, and delivers them, Ps. 34.7. But it may be
objected, that good men have a passion of fear as well as others, and at some
times are afraid of troubles. It may be answered, that because no man can
perfectly obey Wisdoms counsels, they best in infirmity may be perplexed, but
not quite overcome with fear; they will recover, Fides non tollit omnem
dubitationem, sed vincentem. Faith takes not away all doubting, but prevailing
doubting. Scotus in Sentent. He that walks uprightly, walks surely, Pr. 10
9. Perfect freedom from fear is reserved for them in heaven. Wicked men dwell
in fear, as strangers; good men in hope, as inhabitants. Further it may be
objected, Good men had need to fear troubles, for the world hates them, and
does often persecute them. Answ. Troubles may befall a good man, but he need
not fear any hurt by them. Surely in the floods of great waters, they shall not
come nigh unto him, Psalm. 32.7. They can detract nothing from his felicity. He
shall be happy in prosperity and adversity. Trouble shall not be evil to him,
but do him good, and lead him to good. For our light affliction, which is but
for a moment, works for us a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory,
2 Cor. 4.17. It may be God may sometimes try his servants, but ordinarily they
change their manners, before God changes their prosperity. Fortunam sui cuique
fingunt mores. Cornelius Nepos in vita Pompeij. Every man's manners carve out
his own condition. Fortune is a constant wife to good men, and an inconstant
strumpet to bad men, said Heathen Plutarch. Apophthegm. She is nailed to good
men, not well fastened to bad men. Evil men's troubles will be endless, good
men's not so.

Use. Behold a great encouragement to hearken to Wisdoms counsels, and to be
pious. We shall attain to a condition that need not fear any troubles. I will
not fear, though the earth be removed; and though the mountains be carried into
the midst of the Sea. Though the waters thereof roar, and be troubled, though
the mountains shake with the swelling thereof, Psalm. 46.2, 3. Si fractus
illabatur orbis, Impavidum ferient ruinae. Horat. A godly man's Ark is pitched
within, and without, tossed it may be, but not drowned; shaken, but not
shivered. No Kingdom in the world, no Empire has such a privilege.

6. Doct. Trouble is evil in it self. The years wherein we have seen evil,
Psalm. 90.15. Shall there be any evil in the City, and the Lord has not done
it? Amos 3.6.

Reason 1. Because it is evil to the body, helping to confume it by diseases.

2. It is evil to the soul, helping to vex it with grief and disquietnesse. It
makes a man cry out, Why art thou cast down, O my soul, and why art thou
disquieted within me? Psalm. 43.5.

Use. Let us bless God our heavenly Physician, that turns our troubles to our
good, and makes an antidote of poison.

CHAP. II.
Verse. 1. My Son, if thou will receive my words, and hide my commandments with
thee.
Solomon having before in the words of Wisdom threatened obstinate finners with
destruction, now in his own words falls to instruct such as are tractable. Now
that these things are spoken in the words of Solomon, and not of Wisdom,
appears by the title given to the young man in this verse, My Son. Which is
also given him by Solomon, chapter 1.8. But never by Wisdom in all this Book. And
by chapter 3. v. 13. He says, Happy is the man that finds wisdom. If Wisdom
had spoken, she would have said, that finds me.

In this Chapter the Wiseman shows,

1. How to get true wisdom, to verse. 5.

2. What good is gotten by getting it, to the end of the Chapter. And that, 1.
Positively, from v. 5. to v. 10. 2. Privatively, from thence to the end. And
this latter,


1. By preventing danger from bad men, from v. 10. to verse. 16.

2. From bad women, from v. 16. to the end.

For the first thing, the way to attain true wisdom, it is, 1. By getting a
docible mind, v. 1. 2. By learning it of them that are wise, v. 2. 3. By
prayer to God for it, v. 3. 4. By our own studies and endeavors, v. 4.


To return to v. 1. And first for the words.

My Son. See on chapter 1.1, 8. It is a title often repeated to beget attention and
obedience.

If thou will receive. See on chap. 1.3. If thou will bring with thee a willing
mind to learn of me, and to receive my words into thy understanding, will, and
affections. So Lira interprets it of a Scholar, docible, and willing to learn.
Hugo Cardinalis takes it for a Metaphor from the earth, which being plowed and
opened, receives the seed into it, and brings forth corn. So does a docible
Scholar. As on the contrary, Petrarch. Dialog. 41. speaking to a Schoolmaster
that had or might have an undocible Scholar, says, Discipulum indocilem babes?
Perdis operam, littus aras, semina projicis, natura non vincitur. Terrae aridae
colonus es? Solve boves. Quid te torques? Have thou an indocible Scholar? Thou
loosest thy labor, thou throwest away thy seed, nature cannot be overcome. Art
thou a tiller of a barren ground? Unloose thy oven. Why vexest thou thy self?
The word argues a greediness of hearing, as the dry earth gasps for rain, and
drinks it in greedily, Heb. 6.7. Others read it, If thou will buy my words. So
the word (...) is used, She considers a field, and buyeth it, Heb. takes it;
to wit, by purchase. For what men buy, they may lawfully take, chapter 31.16. Now
wisdom is bought by time and labor. Metrocles dicebat res alienas pecunia, ut
domum, and vestem, and alia; disciplinas autem emi tempore, atque labor.
Metrocles said, that other men's goods were to be bought with money, as houses,
and garments, and other things; but arts were to be bought with time and
labor. Laert. l. 6. c. 6. It argues a greedy desire of knowledge, sparing for
no cost, time, nor labor to attain it. Ab. Ezra expounds it thus, Thou shall
be my Son, if thou will receive my words. But it is better to draw the
coherence to verse. 5. thus, If thou will receive my words, etc. then shall thou
understand the fear of the Lord, etc.

My words. See on chapter 1.21. Some understand it of the words in the foregoing
Chapter. But it includes all spoken by him in this Book.

And hide. Lay them up safe in thy heart, and memory, as men lay up treasures,
v. 7. Or, at husbandmen hide their corn in the earth to fructify. Or, as men
lay up jewels they would have kept. There is no safer place to keep good
counsel in, then the chest of man's heart and memory. Then will it not be
forgotten.

My commandments. Such as I have received from God, and enjoined thee. These
they must hide in their memory, that Satan beguile them not of the knowledge of
them, but they may be ready for practice upon all occasions, as money in a
Treasury, or victuals in a Storchouse.

With thee. Not from others, for thou must teach them, but lay up the knowledge
of them for thy own use. Some things are so dear to us, that we will not trust
our chests with them, but carry them always about with us. So must we do with
wise precepts. Maximus reports that Euripides the Philosopher seeing a young
man buying many Books, said, Non arcae, O adolescens, sed pectori: O young man,
these are not to be put into thy chest, but into thy breast. Communium Sermonum
17. I have heard that famous Buchanan, King James his Master, when a Germane
Doctor coming into Scotland, desirous to see him, and observing his few books,
and great learning, saluted him thus, Salve Doctor sine libris: God save you
Mr. Doctor without books; going into Germany afterward, and seeing in that
Doctors Study a multitude of books, and thinking him little learned, retorted
bitterly, Salvete libri sine Doctore: God save you books without a Doctor.
Intimating, that few books well read, were better then many never looked upon.
He is the first in the ship of fools, that buys many books, and reads them
not. To this purpose Solomon seems to speak to the young man here, as if he had
said, I have and will do my part to fill thee with good instructions, see thou
do thine in receiving them into thine heart, and keeping them there.

Figures. My Son, a Metaphor. For Solomon meant others to be taught by him, as
well as his Sons.

Receive. A Metaphor from the earth receiving seed.

Hide, a Metaphor from treasures locked up.

In the text there is, 1. Avi ditas auscultandi. A greedy desire of hearkening.
2. Assiduitas memorandi. A daily care of remembering.


In the first note, 1. The person spoken to, My Son. 2. The act required, if
thou will receive. 3. The object, my words.


In the second note, 1. The act, And hide. 2. The object, my commandments. 3.
The subject place, with thee.


Observations. My Son. This word is often repeated, because good children use
readily to receive their parents counsels, as judging them always to come out
of love.

1. Doct. Men soonest hearken to counsels that come out of good will.
Therefore, your. cunning Orators, before they propound the matter they would
urge, make a plausible preface first, to catch the hearers hearts. See how
Abigails counsel wrought on David, 1 Samuel 25.24. He blesses God for it, and
blesses her, v. 32, 33. there. Paul's counsel to the Corinthians wrought in
them sorrow to repentance, 2 Cor. 7.8, 9.

Reason 1. Because all suspicion of malice (which taints good counsel like a
dead fly) is taken away.

2. All fear of disgracing us, is likewise gone. We conceive that these cannot
dwell in a loving heart.

3. Love has a sympathizing power. If it be in the heart both of the speaker,
and of the hearer, it draws as the Loadstone does the iron. Magnes amoris amor:
Love is the Loadstone of love.

4. Love has a creating or begetting power. It is a fruitful tree, and can
beget love where none was before.

Use 1. It shows us a reason why some men's counsels will not be swallowed.
There is too much vinegar in them, little sign of love.

2. Let Ministers like wise Physicians, temper their bitter pills of reproof
with sugared affections. Many look more at the good relish of physic, then at
the event of it.

2. Doct. A docible mind must first be got by him that will be wise. The
Apostles Christ's best Scholars show it, by asking much. Why speak thou to
them in parables? Mat. 13.10. Declare unto us the parable of the tares of the
field, Mat. 13.36. And Nicodemus asks, How can a man be born when he is old?
Joh. 3.4.

Reason 1. Because else the work will go on very difficultly, like plowing on
rocks, or as the Egyptian chariots, when the wheels were off. God took off
their chariot wheels, that they drove them heavily, Exodus 14.25.

2. The work is as good as half done, where a docible heart is. Pour in
knowledge, and the vessel will receive it.

3. Dociblenesse of heart will make a man painful. Desire of knowledge sets a
capable soul, and body on work.

4. It will bring a greater progress, then a greater capacity in one not
willing to learn, can produce. As in schools, boys of mean parts, and great
desires, get more learning then others of stronger parts, and less desires of
it.

Use 1. It shows us, why many get no good by many good Sermons, they have no
heart to it. It is hard rowing against the stream. Why is this? A price in the
hand of a fool to get wisdom, seeing be has no heart to it, Prove. 17.16.

2. Get a docible heart, else all your own pains and your Teachers is lost.

3. Doct. Good counsels not received do no good. The Word must be received with
meekness, Jam. 1.21. Else it profits not. The Corinthians had not been saved
by the Word that Paul preached, had they not received it, 1 Cor. 15.1, 2.

Reason 1. It appears in natural things. The earth bears no corn, if it
receive not the seed. In Civil things also. Men expect no gain where they put
in no stock. In Medicines, Physic cures not, if not received.

2. Because two things are required to make good counsel profitable, that it be
good, and rightly applied. Good meat not eaten nourishes no more then bad.

Use. Be careful to receive all good counsel, or look for no good from it. A
man that would learn to paint, or build, when he hears a good Workman discourse
well of such works, goes aside, and takes a tool, and draws a draught of it. Do
thou so in Divinity.

4. Doct. Knowledge is very necessary. My people are destroyed for lack of
knowledge, Hos. 4.6. Israel does not know, my people does not consider, Isa.
1.3. Solomon calls often on us to embrace it. Heathens prized it above all
outward things. Pro scientia emenda, omnia vendenda: All is to be sold to buy
knowledge. Plato. The wise Merchant sold all to buy the pearl of price, and
made no ill bargain, Matt. 13.46. All things prove unprofitable or hurtful to
him that knows not how to distinguish good from evil, as he that knows not
meat from poison, may soon perish. Woe unto them that call evil good, and good
evil, Isa. 5.20.

Use. Pity those blind souls, that prefer all things above knowledge. Their
money will perish with them.

5. Doct. Words of truth are worth laying up. Mary kept all these things, Luke
2.19. Let thine heart retain my words, Prove. 4.4.

Reason 1. Because they are precious like jewels, or seed hidden in the earth.

Because of the good that comes by them. They show the way to eternal
happiness.

Use. Let us bewail our loss that have lost so many jewels for lack of laying
up. We do not so with gold and silver. We leave them not on the benches, but
lay them up in chests, that they may be safe and forth coming when we have need
of them. To receive words of truth, and not hide them, is to take them with the
one hand, and throw them away with the other.

6. Doct. Man's heart is the best place wherein words of truth may be hid. Thy
Word have I hid in my heart, Psalm. 119.11. His Mother kept all these sayings in
her heart, Luke 2.51. For there they are safest.

Use. Lay not up then holy instructions in a chest of silver, but in the
cabinet of thy heart. So will thou find them when thou have need of them.

Verse. 2. So that thou incline thine ears unto wisdom, and apply thine heart
unto understanding.
We are now come to the second way of getting heavenly wisdom; namely, by
learning it of them that are able to teach it.

For the words.

So that. This shows a dependence on the former words. Thou must be so willing
to learn, and remember that thou employ both ear and heart to get knowledge.

Incline thine ear, Heb. to make thine ear to hear, or regard. So that there is
no color for Popish Commenters to descant of humility, as they do, and how it
fits men to get wisdom. The word has no such notion in it. And if it were
Incline, yet that were token of humility, but of careful hearkening. Here is
nothing meant but applying the ear, not to hear only, but also diligently to
hearken and attend to things taught. As a Musician bows his ear to tune his
Lute, and the hearer afterward, not in sign of any humility, but to hear the
better. Yet the following word, (...), may seem to look that way, but that also
signifies stretching out the heart to hear, rather then bowing it down. Others
think it imports lifting up the ear to attend, as wild beasts quick of hearing
do upon a sudden noise. It argues unwillingnesse to lose a word of Wisdoms
instructions, and quickness to hear. Others, as Piscator reads it, If thou
incline, taking If out of the former verse. and so carry the word straight on to
the reddition in the fifth verse. and make this verse. to have no dependence on
the first, and the things altogether several running into the fifth v. as
several rivers into the Sea, to be swallowed up there. But the first way
answers best to the Heb. text, yet may there be several means to attain
wisdom, although the first be an help to the second, as the lower steps in a
ladder help to mount up to the higher.

Thine ear. The word (...) in the Original, comes from a word that signifies
to hear, which is the proper function of the ear. And it signifies,

1. The ear, the instrument of hearing. Moses put of the blood upon the tip of
Aarons right ear, Lev. 8.23.

2. The act of hearing. Thou shall read this Law before all Israel, in their
hearing, Heb. in their ears, Deuteronomy. 31.11. Here it is taken in the first sense.

Unto wisdom. See on chapter 1.2.

And apply, Heb. Bow down. For man is naturally proud, and scorns to stoop to
instruction. Omnes nati sumus in monte superbiae: We are all born in the
mountain of pride. Eucherius. And as foolish as the wild Asses there, Job
11.12. Or, stretch out. For we are by nature far short of it, and unwilling to
hear of it. For the word, see on chap. 1.24. on the word stretched out. It may
import a willing attendance on instruction, rather then humility.

(...), Thine heart. The word is taken,

1. For that fleshly member, which we call by that name. Joab thrust three
darts through the heart of Absalom, 2 Samuel 18.14.

2. For the middle of any things, because the heart lies in the midst of the
body. Thou have cast me in the midst of the Seas, Jonas 2.3.

3. For the soul it self, which brings life, and resides first and last in
the heart. David's heart smote him, 1 Samuel 24.5.

4. For the thought of the heart. It may be my Sons have cursed God in their
hearts, Job 1.5.

5. For the affection. Is thine heart right, as my heart is with thine? 2 King.
10.15.

6. For knowledge or understanding. He that hears reproof, gets
understanding, Heb. gets an heart.

Here it is taken in the third sense, for the soul it self, which must be
applied in hearing, as well as the ear, and is more needful also for learning.

To understanding. The same thing in diverse words. Heavenly knowledge is set
out in many terms in this Book.

The sum is: That thou may enjoy this excellent treasure, thy ears both of
body and soul must be taken off from worldly and transitory things, and fully
set to get true wisdom. The one will do no good without the other. Both
together by Gods blessing may attain it.

Figures. Apply, a Metaphor from corporal things that are applied to their
objects by bowing them down, or stretching them out. So much the Hebr. word
imports. But the soul cannot be applied to learning in that corporal way; but
in a spiritual way, by giving heed to what is taught.

For the parts. Two means of attaining spiritual wisdom, are here prescribed.

1. An outward one. Inclining the ear. 2. An inward one. Applying the heart.
In the first note, 1. The act, So that thou incline. 2. The subject, thine
ear. 3. The object, unto wisdom.


In the second note, 1. The act, And apply. 2. The subject, thine heart. 3. The
object, to understanding.


1. Doct. The ear must be first employed in hearing, if we would get knowledge.
Ye men of Judea, and all ye that dwell in Jerusalem, be this known unto you,
and hearken to my words, Act. 2.14. As if he had said, All I shall speak will
do you no good, except ye hearken to it. Who has ears to hear, let him hear,
Mat. 13.9.

Reason 1. In general, because the ear is one fit instrument of learning from
others, what our eyes cannot teach us. Auris sensus disciplinae: The ear is the
sense of learning. Arist. Ethic.

2. In particular. It is a quicker way of learning by hearing, then by any
other sense, or any labor of our own. A man may teach that in a quarter of an
hour, for which he has studied many days. Else Schools and Sermons were
needless.

Use. Think not scorn to learn of others. Bless God for thine ears. Faith
comes by hearing, Romans 10.17. Man is like the Heart, of which Aristotle lib. 9.
de Histor. Animal. writes, that when he pricks up his ears he quickly hears the
least sound, but when he hangs them down, he is deaf, and taken and killed. So
men stretching out the ear to hear, hear quickly, and escape, when dull and
deaf ones perish.

2. Doct. The ear does no good, if the heart attend not. My Son, forget not my
Law, but let thine heart keep my commandments, chapter 3.1. Else hearing helps
not. Let thine heart retain my words, keep my commandments, and live, chapter 4.4.
God opened the heart of Lydia, that she attended unto the things which were
spoken of Paul, Act. 16.14.

Reason 1. Because it makes no change in man, if the word strike not on the
heart. And without a whole change, no salvation is to be expected. Except a man
be born again, he cannot see the Kingdom of God, Joh. 3.3.

2. Else there will be no belief of the Word, nor submission to it, without
which it does the soul no good. The Word preached did not profit them, being
not mixed with faith in them that heard it, Heb. 4.2.

Use. Be sure to bring attentive hearts, as well as attentive ears. Be not
hypocrites. Give not bodies without souls. Be not like the pillars of the
Church, to be present, and get nothing. If the heart be not drawn off the
world, no good comes by the Word.

3. Doct. We must not rest in hearing, till we come to complete wisdom. As
Preachers are to preach for the edifying of Christ's body, till it be perfect,
Ephesians. 4.11, etc. So are we to hear, till we have attained to perfection of
knowledge; that is, all our life long we must give heed to the sure word of
prophecy, until the day dawn, and the daystar arise in our hearts.

Reason 1. Because then, and not till then, ye understand things aright, 2 Pet.
1.19.

2. Else all your labor is lost.

Use. Be no more removed from Gods ordinances, then the Sun is from his course.
So Valerius Maximus, l. 5. commends Fabritius and Pyrrhus, that the Sun might
as soon be turned out of his way, as they out of the way of justice or virtue.

Verse. 3. Yea, if thou cryest after knowledge, and liftest up thy voice for
understanding.
The third help to get true wisdom follows, and that is, earnest prayer unto
God.

For the words.

(...), Yea. This word here adds an Emphasis to this means above the former. As
if he had said, A docible nature is good, and instruction of men; but both
these cannot beget knowledge without Gods blessing. Prayer therefore must be
added. So this particle adds increase. Yea, ten acres of vineyard shall yield
one Bath, Isa. 5.10. and Psalm. 21.3. where it should be rendered, yea thou
preventedst him. Thou not only gave him what he desired, v. 2. but much
more, verse. 3. See more of this word, chapter 1.9. on the word For.

If. See on chapter 1.10.

Thou cryest. See on chapter 1.21. Some understand this of an earnest desire of
knowledge, as a Child has of the breast, when he cries for it. Others
understand it better of prayer to God, which also includes the former.

After knowledge, or for knowledge, as it is translated in the end of the verse.
for understanding. And that is nearer to the Hebr. text. For the word, see on
chapter 1.2. on the word know.

And liftest up thy voice, Heb. give or utterest thy voice. See on chapter 1.20.

For understanding. See on verse. 2.

Figures. Cryest. Liftest up thy voice. Synecd. generis. If thou pray. For a
man may cry and speak loud, and yet not pray. Hereby is meant the particular
earnestness of a man in prayer for wisdom. The same thing is set out in two
several expressions. to show the necessity of prayer for wisdom, and
earnestness that should be in it.

In the first expression note, 1. The aggravation, Yea. 2. The act, if thou
cryest. 3. The object, after knowledge.


In the second expression note, 1. The act, And liftest up. 2. The subject, thy
voice. 3. The object, for understanding.


As if Solomon had said, Though humane instruction and a docible disposition be
needful to get wisdom, yet they are not sufficient to get it. God must be
fought to for a blessing.

1. Doct. There is more help from God to get wisdom, then from men. Every
good, and every perfect gift is from above, and comes down from the Father of
lights, Jam. 1.17. And sure wisdom is one. I have planted, Apollo watered, but
God gave the increase, 1 Cor. 3.6. I am the Lord thy God which teaches thee to
profit, Isa. 48.17.

Reason 1. Because God is the principal cause, men but isntrumental. The
chief builder in making a house, and the chief Pilot in guiding a ship, afford
most help, and deserve most praise. The Husbandman can cast seed into the
ground, but God must quicken it.

2. Because some grow wiser then their Teachers, therefore God gives them the
overplus of wisdom. Men cannot give what they had not. Such a Scholar was
David, I have more understanding then all my Teachers, Psalm. 119.99. And
therefore, David prays so often in that Psalm, that God would teach him.

Use. Give God the praise, if thou get much wisdom. Look not with the Swine to
the earth where the acorns lie, but up to the tree where they grow.

2. Doct. Prayer must be used for the getting of knowledge. So did Solomon,
Give thy servant an understanding heart, 1 Kin. 3.9. So St. James bids us. If
any man of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, Jam 1.5.

Reason 1. Because we are not able to root out the thorns, and dispel the
clouds of errors in our hearts, which will hinder the good seed of the Word.

2. We are not able to bring in the light of truth. Pray then to God to do it.
It grows not in Natures garden, else we need not ask it, nor God would not bid
us ask, if he meant not to give it, for he is not covetous to promise much, and
give little.

Use. Add prayer to diligence. Sine open divina vacillat humanum studium.
Without Gods help man's study faints. Valor. Max. Pray before Sermon, and after,
for a blessing.

3. Doct. Prayer for knowledge must be earnest. We must cry, and lift up our
voice, as if our voice were consecrated to that work only. We must ask, seek,
and knock for it, Mat. 7.7. The need is great and the benefit will be
answerable.

Use. Add fire of vehemence to your incense of prayer for wisdom. A cold
Suitor speeds not in the Court of heaven. Wilson.

Verse. 4. If thou seek her as silver, and searchest for her as for hid
treasures.
The Wiseman is now come to the top of the Ladder, which does bring us to true
wisdom. The lowest step was a docible heart, v. 1. The next, humane
instruction, v. 2. The next above that, prayer to God, v. 3. The last, study
and painful endeavor through Gods blessing to obtain it in this v. We must not
lie in a ditch, and cry, God help. We must not so trust to our prayers, that we
give over our endeavors.

For the words.

If. See on chap. 1.10.

Thou seek her. If thou use all diligence, labor, care and cost to find
wisdom, as men do to find things they have lost, or have need of. This word
intimates,

1. A loss or want of something. Else men seek not for it.

2. A knowledge of this want or loss. Else men fit still.

3. Some goodness indeed, or in our opinion, in the thing lost or wanting. Men
are or should be content to lose what is evil.

4. Some benefit to our selves in it. Else few will seek it, though good in it
self.

5. An earnest desire to find it. Else men have no heart to seek it.

6. A constant enqu^ry after it, wheresoever there is any hope to find it.
Else we seek in vain. So it is in seeking after wisdom, we must want it, and
know that we want it, and see good in it, and that to our selves, and seek it
earnestly and constantly, if we would find it.

As silver. The word (...), comes from a word which signifies to desire,
because all men desire money, and it can help them to all outward desirable
things, if they be to be had, as meat, drink, clothes, etc.

1. It signifies silver in the oar, or lump. The silver is mine, Hag. 2.8.

2. When it is joined with words of number, it signifies silver coined, or
money made of silver. Four hundred shekels of silver, Genesis 23.16.

Here it is taken in the first sense. For the seeking here spoken of, is not
taken from covetous men, toyling to get money, but from Miners digging for
silver oar, as the words following declare. This may be taken either for men's
care in digging in diverse places, till they find a vein of silver, or for their
labor in digging to the bottom, when they have found it. So when men want
knowledge, they will wander from Sea to sea, and from the North even to the
East, they will run to and fro to seek it, Amos 8.12. Many will run to and fro,
