that knowledge may be increased, Dan. 12.4. From one Book to another, from one
Sermon to another, and they will be diligent in the use of all good means, till
wisdom be found out. They know, that surely there is a vein for the silver,
Job 28.1. Yet they are not satisfied with that, but enquire further, Where
shall wisdom be found? Job 28.12. It may well be, that seeking for a mine may
be meant by this first part of the verse. Cunning men, when they see springs
issuing from the bottom of mountains, know by the sand, or by the taste of the
water, where silver mines are. So must men guess by goodness of doctrine and
life, where wisdom is likelyest to be gotten. Men are not content to seek in
one place for a mine, but if they speed not there, they dig in another. So must
we for wisdom.

And searchest for her. The word (...), signifies searching in general, which
yet is somewhat more then seeking. A man may seek that looks only in some
likely places, but searching is looking in every room and corner of an house.
They shall search thine house, and the houses of thy servants; and it shall be,
that whatsoever is pleasant in thine eyes, they shall put it in their hand, and
take it away, 1 King. 20.6. This was a through search indeed, so must the
search of knowledge be. Now there is no way to search for silver, but by
digging. Miners dig on, till they have got all the silver out of the mine. So
must we dig for wisdom as long as we live, for the vein of it is bottomless.

As for hid treasures. Not hid in the chests, which thieves hunt after, nor in
the ground, to be saved in times of war from the enemy, which Soldiers search
for, but in Mines, in the bottom of the earth, which men dig deep so. Such
pains should we take for wisdom.

Figures. Seek, Search. Metaphors from men that hunt up and down for things
missing. It intends to set out our continued pains, which we should take to get
heavenly wisdom.

Here are two similitudes.

The first taken from Miners care to find veins of silver.

The second from their pains in digging it out of the earth.

In the first note, 1. The act, If thou seek her. 2. The manner of performing
it, as silver.


In the second note, 1. The act, And searchest for her. 2. The manner, as for
hid treasures.


1. Doct. Heavenly wisdom is of great price. Like silver, and hid treasures.
More to be desired then gold; yea, then much fine gold, Psalm. 19.10. Yea, then
jewels, or precious stones, Job 28.16, etc.

Reason 1. Because as wisdom is more excellent then riches, or strength, so
heavenly wisdom far exceeds all other wisdom; yea, the most curious Arts. All
things that excel other in their kind, are of greatest price. Best books are
dearest: Scholars know it. Best food is dearest: Citizens know it. Best clothes
are dearest: Gentlemen know it. So should the best knowledge be of best
account. All the earth sought to Solomon, to hear his wisdom, 1 King. 10.24.

2. It is most useful. Other wisdom tends to, and ends in the comforts of
this transitory life, for to get houses, food, apparel, which must perish.
This wisdom looks after eternity.

Use 1. To prize this above all other Arts. Things of greatest price should be
most prized, and of highest account with us.

2. To take most pains for it, as men do for things that are of greatest price.
Scholars take great pains in the University for one Art. So do Tradesmen in
the shop for one Trade. How much more pains should we take for the chiefest
wisdom?

2. Doct. Heavenly wisdom is far remote and hidden from us. As mines buried
deep in the earth. It is hid from the eyes of all living, etc. Job 28.20. It is
to the Jews a stumbling block, and unto the Greeks foolishness, 1 Cor. 1.23.

Reason 1. Because it is beyond our invention. Many witty things have been
invented by men, but no man so wise, that could ever stumble upon the way to
heaven. No man has seen God at any time; the only begotten Son, which is in
the bosom of the Father, he has declared him, Joh. 1.18.

2. It is beyond our apprehension. Sense and reason without illumination cannot
conceive of divine truths manifested to us in Scripture. Thou have hid these
things from the wise and prudent, and have revealed them unto babes, Matthew.
11.25. The natural man receives not the things of the Spirit of God, 1 Cor.
2.14.

Object. The commandment is not hidden from us, neither far off.

Answ. It is near in regard of Gods revelation, though not in regard of our
acceptance, as the Sun shines on a blind man, that sees it not.

Use. Bless God for any measure of heavenly truth made known to thee. He gave
both light and sight.

3. Doct. We must search for the means of obtaining heavenly wisdom. As they
that will dig for silver, must get Mattocks, and Spades, and find out mines.
Come, and see, Joh. 1.46. The people follow Christ by shipping to be taught,
Joh. 6.24.

Reason 1. Because God does not work by miracle now, as he did, when he gave
tongues, and healing power, Act. 2.3, 4.

2. Because wisdom grows not every where. Non omnis fert omnia tellus.
Several Lands have several Herbs, Trees, living Creatures.

Use. Seek to live under godly Ministers, where Gods Word drops like dew from
Sion, to make the valleys fruitful. There are the Indies, where mines of
golden truth are to be found. And men spare for no cost to travel to the
Indies, nor fear no peril.

4. Doct. We must use the means when we find them. So men dig when they have
found a mine. Cornelius is at cost to send to Joppa for Peter to instruct him,
as God enjoined him, Act. 10.32, 33. The next Sabbath day came almost the whole
City together, to hear the Word of God, Act. 13.44.

Reason 1. Because God has appointed them. And his will is a law to us, to use
them, although we had no need of them, or thought other means better, as Naaman
thought his Syrian rivers better then Jordan, 2 King. 5.12.

2. Because we have great need of them, and cannot attain true wisdom without
them.

Use. It cries down those that cry down Gods ordinances. They had need put this
text out of the Bible. It will be a strong witness against them else at the
day of judgment. Men will dig in Gold mines, yea in Coal mines, while any
thing is left. They can never dig the Scripture dry. But men of this generation
are wiser for the world, then for heaven.

5. D. We must take pains in the use of the means of knowledge. So do men in
digging for silver. We must watch daily at Wisdoms gates, and wait at the
posts of her doors, chapter 8.34. Give attendance to reading, 1 Timothy 4.13.

Reason 1. Because worldly men take so much pains for wealth, which is not to
be compared to knoweldge. Miners take great care, study, pains, and are at
great cost; and spend much time to get gold and silver out of the earth, and
afterward to purge it from the dross. Merchants are at much cost, and run many
dangers by storms and Pirates to get gain. All their heart runs after it. So
should ours after wisdom. Omnis cupiditas in illam tendatur. We should seek it
with as vehement desire, as covetous men seek after money. Not that
covetousness is to be commended, but that we should be ashamed not to seek
after wisdom so earnestly, as they do after riches. See how patiently they
that love money, labor and sweat for it, forbear pleasure, and delight, take
all occasions of gain, avoid all occasions of loss. And we do not so much for
heavenly wisdom, which is far better. For riches diminish by use, wisdom
increases. So Christ's coming is set out by a theeve's in the night, 1 Thessalonians.
5.2. We are spoken to here after the manner of men, Romans 6.19. For wisdom
should be sought with more diligence then riches.

2. Because though God could give it us without our labor, yet he will not,
that we may the more esteem it, being hardly gotten. So Husbandmen, Shepherds,
Gardiners, Laborers, Inkeepers, Merchants, learn Languages, Arithmetic, incur
many dangers. Per mare pauperiem fugiens, per saxa, per ignes, Impiger extremos
currens Mercator ad Indos. Horat. The greedy Merchant runs to the Indies
through sea, rocks, and fires to avoid poverty. The unjust Steward cannot dig.
It requires no great skill, but is too great a labor for him, Luke 16.3.

3. Because we must not fodere only, but effodere; not only dig, but dig out.
All the Diggers labor is lost, if he dig not till he dig the oar out of the
ground. Yea, men dig till they dig it all out. So must we labor till we attain
the height of knowledge.

4. The pleasure and profit will answer all the pains. It brings happiness and
better profit then merchandise of gold and silver, chap. 3.13, 14. It will make
amends if a man sell all he has for it, Matthew. 13.44. The fruit is answerable
to the labor. The treasure answers the Miners pains, and fills him with joy,
when his labor is done. He fares the better for it all his life long.

Use. Let us be ashamed that we have taken no more pains in the use of the
means to get heavenly wisdom. We may say of Knowledge, as Simonides said of
Virtue, Fertur in rupibus aditu difficilibus habitare: It is reported to dwell
in rocks hardly accessible. Sudor ante virtutem positus: Sweat goes before
virtue. Clem. Strom. l. 4. A man must climb or dig for it, if he will have it.
Worldly men dig where they have hope of a Mine, though with much uncertainty.
We may be ashamed of doing so little, where there is certainty of finding
wisdom. Viscera terrae extrahimus, ut digito gestiatur gemma, quam petimus.
Quot manus afferuntur, ut unus niteat articulus? Simili studio, industria,
constantia, sapien iae inquisitioni incumbendum erat. Plin. l. 2. c. 65. We
draw out the bowels of the earth to get a jewel we desire to wear on a finger.
How many hands are worn out, that one finger may shine? The like study,
industry, constancy, should we use in searching for wisdom. We may then
marvel at, and bewail our slothfulness in seeking wisdom, who all our life
long are so diligent to seek for wealth.

6. Doct. We must be constant in our pains in the use of the means of getting
wisdom. So are men unweariable in digging for treasure. This Book of the Law
shall not depart out of thy mouth, but thou shall meditate therein day and
night, Josh. 1.8. The blessed man meditates in Gods Law day and night, Psalm.
1.2.

Reason 1. Because the Ministers are to preach constantly. Preach the Word in
season, out of season, 1 Timothy 4.2. And if Schoolmasters must keep hours, it is
fit Scholars do so also.

2. We shall not be perfect in knowledge while we live, no not if we had
attained to Paul's stature. We should know but in part, till that which is
perfect come, 1 Cor. 13.9, 10. And we must not give over means, till we attain
to a full measure of knowledge. As a sick man gives not over physic and diet,
till he be fully recovered.

Use. Let such take it to heart, who have found sweetness in Gods ordinances,
and now find none. Where is their constancy? Qui thesaurum effod^nt in mundo,
licet infinitas capiant divitias, non prius absistunt. quam totum exhauserint.
Non enim ut multa tollant, sed ut nihil relig^uant haec eos praecipue cura
tenere solet. Multo magis hoc nos in divinis facere thesauris opertet tamdiu
effodere quoad totum exhauserimus apparens. Apparens autem dixi, quoniam omnia
exhaurire non datur. Chrysostom. in Homil. super orat. Annae. They that dig out
treasures in the world, although they get infinite riches, yet cease not till
they have drawn the Mine dry: For this is their chief care, not to get out
much, but to leave none behind. Much more should we do thus, dig so long, till
we draw out all that appears. Now I say that appears, because no man has power
to draw out all. Arborem quam summa conspicis viriditate laetari, nisi fimo and
humore subterraneo foveatur, continue exarescet, nec viror corticis quicquam
valet, nisi virtus stipitis humorem continuum sibi trahat. Sic and homo,
quantumcunque in sapientia virescat, si novum humorem continue sibi non trahat
per studium, acquisita viriditas faciliter exarescit. Cassiodor. l. 2. The tree
which thou see enjoy the most greenness, unless it be continually cherished
with dung, and underground moisture, will be dried up; neither is the
greenness of the bark worth any thing, unless the force of the trunk draw
moisture to it continually. So a man, how green soever he be in knowledge, if
he draw not daily new moisture to himself by study, his greenness gotten will
easily be dried up. The cause why many get not saving knowledge, is, because
discouragement makes them give over labor. But seek and ye shall find, Matthew.
7.7. Plantin the curious Printers Motto was, Labor and constantia: By labor
and constancy.

But what are those means that we must use to get knowledge?

Answ. Light and sight. So in worldly things, light of the Sun, and our eyes
must be used to distinguish objects. The light is manifold:

1. Of Creatures, which must be used by observation of Gods power, wisdom,
goodness characterised in them. Romans 1.20. The invisible things of God are
seen from the creation of the world.

2. Of Scriptureused by reading. Nihil invenitur, nisi quod per viam suam
quaeritur: Nothing is found, unless sought in the right way.

3. Of the Word preached, used by hearing.

4. Of the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, used by receiving.

5. Of good parts given to others, used by conference.

6. Of principles in our selves, used by meditation.

The fight is twofold. As the body has two eyes, so likewise has the soul.

The first is Reason, whereby man must seek to understand all the former means
of knowledge truly.

The second is Illumination, whereby he is made able to understand such things
as Reason could not reach. This is the cleerer eye of the twain.

These must be continually poring upon the former grounds, that we may
understand the words of Wisdom. These are the means to attain true wisdom, a
docible mind, instruction by others, prayer to God, and diligent study. Where
all these are joined, there is no doubt of good success. Use them all then,
and fare well: one tool will never build an house.

Verse. 5. Then shall thou understand the fear of the Lord, and find the
knowledge of God.
The way to true wisdom has been set down before, now follow the benefits of
it, to allure us to take pains, and observe the former directions to get it,
and those are set down, 1. Pofitively, to verse. 10. 2. Privatively, to the end
of the chap.


For the first. It contains promises of good things to be gotten by searching
for wisdom. After the precepts and instructions, follows the promise of good
success to every one which is tractable, and persuaded to observe the
directions proposed. Here is promised, 1. Wisdom to direct us how to carry our
selves toward God, v. 5, 6, 7, 8. 2. Toward men. v. 9.


In the first part note, 1. The things promised, verse. 5. 2. The reasons why we
may expect them. 1. From Gods liberality, v. 6. 2. From divine instruction, v.
6. also. 3. From his plentiful provision, v. 7. 4. From his defense of them
against errors and follies, v. 7. also. 5. From his direction in matters of
truth, v. 8. 6. From his preservation of them that are his in practical duties
of Religion, v. 8. also.



The sum is: They shall understand how to know and fear God aright, because
God will give them light and fight, and store of it; and power to avoid errors
in judgment and practice, and to keep truth and piety. For the things promised
in this verse.

For the words.

Then. When thou have used all the former means. But if thou go any other way
to seek true wisdom, then God has appointed, thou art sure to go without this
heavenly treasure. For the word see on chapter 1.28.

Thou shall understand. See on chapter 1.6.

The fear of the Lord. See on chapter 1.7.

And find. See on chapter 1.13.

The knowledge. See on chapter 1.4.

Of God. The word (...), comes from a word that signifies power. For all power
is from God. It is used,

1. For the true God. In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth,
Genesis 1.1. And it is the first name that is given to God in Scripture.

2. It is attributed to Idol, and false gods, as the picture of a man is
called a man. So are they called gods, because they seem so to men, though they
be utterly unworthy of that name, and have no divine power in them at all. All
the gods of the Nations are idals, Psa. 96.3. They have cast their gods unto
the fire, for they were no gods, Isa. 37.19.

3. It is put for the images of the true God. These be thy Gods, O Israel,
Exodus 32.8. The Galf was made for an image or representation of the true God,
as appears by what sollows, which have brought thee up out of the Land of
Egypt. Such were Jeroboam's Calves, not Images of Bual, but of the true God, 1
King. 12.28.

4. For the Angels, which are nearest to God in glory and power, far excelling
all earthly and bodily creatures in both. Thou have made him a little lower
then the Angels, Psa. 8.5.

5. For men that come nearest to God in state and power, especially Magistrates
and Judges. I have said, Ye are gods, Ps. 82.6.

6. It is used to set out the greatness or excellency of a thing, though
unreasonable, in that wherein it excells all other things of the same kind,
and so comes nearer to God then they do. Nineveh was an exceeding great City,
Hebr. a great City of God. Here it is taken in the first sense for the true
God, for the knowledge of other gods will do us no good, without the knowledge
of him, but hurt rather. Their sorrows shall be multiplied that hasten after
another God, Psa. 16.4.

The sum of all is: That he which conscionably uses all the former means,
shall experimentally be acquainted with true piety and religion, and soundly
seasoned with an holy illumination, and made judicious in Scripture truths, and
matters of faith; so that he shall be well able to discern between light and
darkness, between truth and errors, in measure competent for his salvation.

Figures. The fear of the Lord Syneed. Speciei. Hereby is meant true religion
and piety, which besides the fear of God requires many other graces, but this
is one of the principal, and put for all the rest.

Find. A Metaphor from Seekers. The benefits to be gotten are two.

1. The fear of God. 2. The knowledge of God.
In the first note, 1. The time, Then. 2. The act, thou shall understand, 3.
The subject, the fear. 4. The object, of the Lord.


In the second note, 1. The act, And find. 2. The subject, the knowledge, 3.
The object, of God.


Here the Ifs end, and the sentence is completed thus: If thou do all the
former things, thou shall have heavenly knowledge.

Then, is to be taken,

1. Inclusively, when thou have used all the former means, thou may expect it.

2. Exclusively. Never look for it, till thou have used them all.

1. Doct. Men that conscionably use all means of getting true wisdom,
appointed by God, may expect good success from him. So did Solomon speed, who
records his Fathers instructions, from chapter 4.4. to chapter 9. end, and his Mothers,
chapter 31. He also used study, and gave his heart to it, Eccl. 1.13. He prayed for
it, 2 Chr. 1.10. and so got a great measure of it. Meditate upon these things,
give thy self wholly to them, that thy profiting may appear to all, 1 Timothy 4.15.

Reason 1. Because else Gods promise is void, and then his truth will be
questioned. Men may fail of performing promises, for want of wit to foresee
inconveniences, and power to effect what they say. But God wants neither.

2. The means appointed by God would be slighted. Who would ever study Law or
physic, if after all his pains he could not attain to the profitable knowledge
of them?

Use. Let this encourage you to study for true wisdom. Here is a fair promise,
God will not fail us, if we take pains to get wisdom. Many of the people
foolishly complain, that they cannot know the way to true wisdom. Great
Scholars cannot agree upon it. Sure if they sought as diligently by reading the
Scriptures and Prayer, and other good means, as they and others labor for
wealth, they would find wisdom. The rich young man came to Christ, as defirous
to learn, yet preferring his wealth before true wisdom, went without it. When
men see Merchants return home rich, and Husbandmen have great crops, they are
encouraged to those Trades. So should we be encouraged to seek wisdom by what
others have got. Try the means, and let what you get encourage you to seek for
more; as men work still, and harder in their Trades, when gain comes. Solomon
finding his Ophir trade for gold to thrive, 1 King. 9.28. sent thither every
three years, 1 King. 10.22. So let us be encouraged by what we have got
already, to get more wisdom.

2. Doct. There is no expectation of attaining true wisdom, without a
conscionable use of all good means. The Kings of Israel could not obtain true
wisdom, nor the wicked Kings of Judah, because they used not the means
prescribed to them to cause the Law to be written out for them, and to read
therein all the days of their life, Deuteronomy. 17.18, 19, 20.

Reason 1. Because God will not bless their labors, that go not his way. They
may as well expect strength without food, health without physic, warmth
without clothes or fire, crops without plowing or sowing.

2. God will cross those that go their own ways to get wisdom. For they
ascribe to themselves a power above God, and a wisdom suitable, that pull down
his way to set up another.

Use. It shows us a reason why many have not true wisdom, because they seek it
not in Gods way, and God will not give it in theirs. They have no mind to learn
it, hear seldom, pray seldomer, never study.

3. Doct. Much wisdom is needful to find out the true religion. Timothy from
a child had learned the holy Scriptures, which were able to make him wise to
salvation, 2 Timothy 3.15. The wisdom that is from above, is first pure, then
peaceable, etc. Jam. 3.17.

Reason 1. Because it is high above us; sense nor reason cannot reach it.

2. There are many shows of false religions to deceive us. As voluntary
humility, and worshipping of Angels; a show of wisdom in will worship, etc.
Col. 2.18.23. All is not gold that glisters.

Use. Marvel not that men are so ready to embrace false religions, Popery,
Idolatry, Herefie. It is for want of true wisdom. They think themselves wifer
then they are. Vainman would be wise, though man be born like a wild Asses
colt, Job 11.12. The name here given to God is Jehovah, which signifies being.

4. Doct. We must look upon God as the fountain of all being. In him we live,
and move, and have our being, Act. 17, 28. Of him, and through him, and to him
are all things, Romans 11.36.

Reason 1. Because this will be glorious to God when we see him in all things.

2. It will be pleasing to us, as to men, to read their genealogies; and to
children, to see their parents love in their clothes, victuals, etc.

3. It will be profitable to others, and keep us from wronging others. He who
made them, will right them.

Use. Let us, as see God in our being, so praise him while we have any being,
Psalm. 146.2.

5. Doct. The knowledge of God is worth the finding. Let him that gloryeth,
glory in this, that he understands and knows me, that I am the Lord, Jer.
9.24. I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of
Christ Jesus my Lord, Phil. 3.8.

Reason 1. Because Acquaintance with good men brings much good; much more with
God, who can do us more good then all the creatures can.

2. Heaven is not to be had without it. This is life eternal, that they might
know thee the only true God, Joh. 17.3. No admission to live in a palace
without the owners acquaintance. Heaven is Gods palace.

Use. Woe be to them that seek so much to get acquaintance on earth, but never
look after acquaintance with God. They may seek it when it is too late. When
they come to die, and would scrape acquaintance with God, he will say, I never
knew you: Depart from me, Matt. 7.23. Therefore acquaint thy self now with him,
and he at peace, thereby good shall come unto thee, Job 22.21.

6. Doct. We must look upon God as most powerful. God has spoken once; twice
have I heard this, that power belongs unto God, Psalm. 62.11.

Reason. Because we may have need of more then a created power, which is not to
be found but in God.

Use. When men overpower you, look up to Gods power. This may ease your
spirits.

Verse. 6. For the Lord gives wisdom; out of his mouth comes knowledge and
understanding.
Here are the two first reasons, why they which conscionably use all the former
means, shall attain true knowledge. And they are taken from Gods liberality in
giving wisdom inwardly to make the soul see the truth, and his outward
instruction of things fit to be discerned by that wisdom wrought in the soul
within. God gives fight and light. Both are necessary, and both from God.

For the words.

For. See on chapter 1.9. Some the these words to the third v. as giving a reason
why we should pray to God for knowledge; because he is ready to give it. Others
knit it to the sourth v. thus, by way of qualification. Though thou must use
all diligence to get heavenly wisdom, yet know, that all thy wit and labor
cannot reach it, but God must give it to thee, or thou will never have it. But
it is best to knit it to the verse. immediately before. If any man should say, I
despair of getting heavenly wisdom. My pains cannot reach it, and God will not
hear my prayers. Bolomon answers in the text, Despair not, for God is as ready
to give, as thou art to a^k it.

The Lord. See on chap. 1.7. God gives true wisdom inclusively. He can do it.
And exclusively. None else can do it.

Gives, Heb. will give; to wit, if thou pray and labor for it, as before. For
the word see on chapter 1.4.

Wisdom. See on chapter 1.2.

Out of his mouth. The word (...), or (...), signifies,

1. That member which we call the mouth of the body. They have months, but they
speak not, Psalm. 115.5.

2. The manifestation of ones mind by speech, or words which come out of the
mouth. According to thy Word shall all my people be ruled, Genesis 41.40. The word
is in Hebr. thy mouth.

3. The wound top of a well, or garment, or vessel, which is like a mouth. A
great stone was upon the wells mouth, Genesis 29.2.

4. The edge of a sword which devours or destroys men, as the mouth does meat.
And they slew Hamor, and Shethem his Son with the edge (Heb the mouth) of the
sword, Genesis 34.26.

5. The end or corner of a place. The house of Bael was full from one end to
another, Heb. mouth, 2 King. 10.21.

6. A part or portion, as the mouth is a part of the face. By giving him a
double portion, Heb. mouth, Deuteronomy. 21.17.

Here it is taken in the second sense for the manifestation of truth by God in
his Word, or by his Ministers.

Comes. It is not in the Original, but added by the Interpreters fitly to
make up the sense, and therefore it is printed in smaller letters.

Knowledge. See on chapter 1.4.

And understanding. See on verse. 2. of this chap. Some take wisdom, knowledge,
and understanding, to be all one here. As if the wise man bore so great
affection to it, that he could not name it often enough, nor find words
sufficient to express the worth of it. Baine distinguishes them thus, By
Wisdom is meant the knowledge of heavenly things; by knowledge, things
needful to be known here in the world; by Understanding, discretion to carry
our selves well among men. But it is most likely, that they are Synonymas, and
intend no more but knowledge of what we should believe, and how we should carry
our selves religiously, and so it answers well to the former verse. and gives a
good reason to confirm it. Thou shall understand, because God gives wisdom,
etc.

Figures. Gods mouth is put here for his revealing truth.

1. By a Metaphor, attributing a mouth to God, and speaking of him after the
manner of men, although he have no body, nor bodily members.

2. By a Metonymie of the cause for the effect. Hereby is meant Gods revealing
his will, as men do by their mouths make their mind known, yet in another way
more befitting Gods spiritual essence, by a sound from Heaven, or by Angels,
or by his Servants, Prophets, and Ministers; or inwardly, by his Spirit.

Note 1. Gods liberality. 2. His instruction.


In the former observe, 1. The word of coherence, For. 2. The person spoken of,
the Lord. 3. The act, gives. 4. The object, wisdom.


In the latter note, 1. The two gifts, knowledge and understanding. 2. The way
of bestowing by divine information, comes out of his mouth.


1. God gives the soul eyes by illumination.

2. He gives light by revelation. We shall see the fruit of our labor in
searching for heavenly wisdom, for God will give it.

1. Doct. What we cannot do in search of true wisdom, God will supply. So he
taught Moses and Daniel what Egyptian and Chaldean wisdom could not teach
them. So he taught David what his Teachers could not. So he confesses, I have
more understanding then all my Teachers, for thy testimonies are my meditation,
Psalm. 119.99. So he taught Solomon more then any of the children of the East,
or all the Wise men of Egypt knew, 1 King. 4.30. So he would teach the
Philippians, what they could not teach one another. If in any thing ye be
otherwise minded, God shall reveal even this unto you, Phil. 3.15.

Reason 1. Because of Gods mercy, He will not leave his servants in the suds.
If he will have birds fly, he gives them wings. If he give an heart to seek for
wisdom, he supplies by his Spirit where means fall short.

2. Because of Gods glory. He will perfect the work, that he may have the
honor of the whole. Jesus is the author and finisher of our faith, Heb. 12.2.
He will not lose his glory for men's imperfections, but will supply what is
wanting.

Use. This may encourage Gods people to labor for wisdom. If aboy willing to
learn had a Schoolmaster, that would say to him, Study hard; when you stick, I
will help you out. My head is better then yours. Would he not study? So do ye.
God will supply what ye want.

Use 2. When ye stick at difficulties, pray to God to resolve you. He will help
you out of the ditch.

2. Doct. Wisdom is a free gift: If a man ask wisdom of God, it shall be
given him, Jam. 1.5. I have given thee a wise and understanding heart, says
God to Solomon, 1 Ki. 3.12.

Reason 1. A part ante, from our condition before. We have no spiritual
wisdom naturally, nor strength that can get it, nor wealth that can purchase
it. We are born fools, and dead in sins and trespasses, Ephesians. 2.1.

2. A part post. We can give no requital to God, who gives it. We cannot
teach him wisdom. Who has known the mind of the Lord, or who has been his
counselor, or who has first given to him, and it shall be recompensed unto
him again? Romans 11.34, 35. Neither can we with all our wisdom, no not, when we
are in heaven, add any thing to Gods happiness, who is perfection it self.
Poor Apprentices, when they get skill in their Trades, may help to make their
Masters rich. We cannot do so to God.

Use 1. To teach us to receive wisdom being a free gift. There is none among
us, which would not only think himself to be out of his wits, if he should
refuse a thing, which he could not want, but also would judge himself most
unthankful, if he did not receive it with hearty thanksgiving, when it was
freely offered him. We would hardly purchase heavenly wisdom, if we will not
receive it of free gift.

2. To teach us humility. If we get true wisdom, let us not attribute it to
our own strength, nor crow over others. Fishermen got it, when Pharisees could
not.

3. Doct. Wisdom comes from the Lord alone. Hither the Apostle James sends us
to beg it. If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that gives to all
men liberally, and upbraideth not, Jam. 1.5. Solomon prays to God for it, and
obtains it of God, 1 Kin. 3.9, 12. If (as a learned man says) that all
profitable learning in the world came out of Adam's mouth at first, as from a
most wise teacher and fountain; how much better may the same be said of the
only wise God? Jude v. 25. who is wonderful in counsel, and excellent in
working, Isa. 28.29.

Reason 1. The Law, the most complete rule of life came from him. No Laws of
Solon, or of the wisest men come near it. No man could find out such.

2. The Gospel is from him alone. As he gave the Law by Moses, so the Gospel by
Christ, Joh. 1.17. Angels could not have found out a way to satisfy Gods
justice, and save us.

3. All prophesies are from him alone. The Word of the Lord that came unto
Hosea, Hos. 1.1. The revelation of Jesus Christ, which God gave unto him, Rev.
1.1. None can tell things to come, but God.

Use 1. Let us then not trust to the rivers, but go to the fountain for waters
of wisdom. You may learn humane wisdom from Plato and Aristotle, but divine
wisdom is not to be sought in the books of Heathen writers, and Infidels, but
in those books which come out of Gods own mouth. Solomon sends us thither for
it, from whence he had it himself. Origo fontium, and fluminum omnium mare est:
virtutum, and scientiarum, Dominus Jesus Christus. Bern. in Cant. Sermon. 13. The
original of all fountains and rivers is the Sea. The original of all virtues
and sciences, is the Lord Jesus Christ. Ad sapientem pertinet considerare
causam altissimam, per quam certissime de aliis judicatur, and secundum quod
omnia ordinari oportebit. Aristotle. It belongs to a wise man to consider of
the highest cause by which he may most certainly judge of others, and according
to which all things must be ordered. Non Chaldaeorum institutio, sed divina
gratia pueros intelligentes fecit. It was not the instruction of the Chaldeans,
but Gods grace which made the young men wise. Theodor. in Dan. 1.17.

2. Take notice that our wisdom is not from our selves, but from God. It is
not in our power to get it. Be not then proud of thy wisdom, as if God were a
debtor to thee for using thy wisdom to his glory. He has paid thee
beforehand, he gave thee thy wisdom, and if thou use it to his glory, he will
pay thee again with eternal glory. Proud persons then must be dumb, unless
they make Solomon a liar, who says, The Lord gives wisdom. What wisdom then
soever we have, we must not praise our selves for it, as if we were something
more then others, which are void thereof: but without advancing our selves, we
must confess with St. James, that every good, and every perfect gift is from
above, and comes down from the Father of lights, Jam. 1.17. Otherwise we
should well deserve to hear, Who makes thee to differ from another? And, what
have thou, that thou did not receive? Now, if thou did receive it, why do
thou glory as if thou had not received it? 1 Cor. 4 7.

4. Doct. All manner of heavenly knowledge is from God. God, who at sundry
times, and in diverse manners, spoke to our Fathers by the Prophets, has in
these last days spoken to us by his Son, Heb. 1.1, 2. Flesh and blood has not
revealed it unto thee, but my Father, which is in heaven, Mat. 16.17.

Reason 1. Because none can teach us to know God, but God himself. Who can
consider of the highest cause, but by influence from the highest cause? Who can
see the Sun, but by influence from the Sun?

2. We cannot know heaven but by Gods revelation. As we know not what is in the
Indies, but by relation of such as dwell or have been there.

3. We know not the way to heaven but by Gods direction. Men's brains may make a
ladder to climb to Kingdoms, but Jacob's ladder, where God stands at the top,
can only reach to heaven.

Use. Try your wisdom, whether heavenly or no, in divine things, by the
original of it. The conscience is troubled with the guilt of sin; God sets
Christ's blood alone before thee; Papists set merits, works of supererogation,
Popes pardons, to help cleanse it. Gods way is the best. The soul is oppressed
with filth of sin. God offers his Spirit to cleanse this soul stable. Papists
talk of whippings, abstinence from flesh, yet are many of their votaries,
homines, quos si vel foeno pasceres, lascivirent. Erasmi vita. Men that would
be wanton, if they eat nothing but hay.

5. Doct. Gods Word and Ministers must be regarded in the search of wisdom. To
the Law, and to the Testimony; if they speak not according to this Word, it is
because there is no light in them, Isa. 8.20. Search the Scriptures, for in
them ye think ye have eternal life, and they are they which testify of me,
Joh. 5.39. Quench not the Spirit. Despise not prophesyings, 1 Thessalonians. 5.19, 20.

Reason 1. Because the Scriptures are the fountains of heavenly wisdom.

2. They are the touchstone of divine truths. Spirits must submit to be tried
by them, 1 John 4.1, 2.

3. The Ministers are the conduit-pipes through which God ordinarily sends
forth the waters of heavenly knowledge.

4. They are Goldsmiths, that know best how to use the touchstone of the Word
to try truths. It is their study and their trade.

Use 1. To show us the vanity of those men who trust to revelations and their
own Spirits, in stead of Gods; and slight the Scriptures, and despise the
Ministers. Certainly they are far from true wisdom.

2. To exhort us to read the Scriptures diligently, and to hearken to Gods
Ministers reverently. For though men must use their own endeavors to get true
wisdom (else praying to God for it is but mocking of God) yet they cannot by
any labor of their own attain it. Therefore must our ears and hearts be
inclined to our Teachers, v. 2. By them does God open his mouth to give us
wisdom. We should then resort to the preaching of the Word, not slackly, or
for custom sake, as hypocrites, superstitious persons, and Idolaters do, but
to the end that we may receive and learn wisdom of God, through his grace and
goodness, whereby we knowing him, may walk in his fear. It is promised as a
blessing, Thine eyes shall see thy Teachers, Isa. 30.20.

6. Doct. Inward capacity, and outward discovery come both from God. He gave
Solomon wisdom to comprel^end many things, which others could not understand.
He gave M^ses knowledge of the Creation of the world.

Reason. He gave man eyes to se^ withal, else he could not have had any
comfortable view of the excellency of the creatures. He placed the Sun and Moon
in the firmament, else eyes would have done no good. Much more is there need of
Christ's help for spiritual light and sight. Quod lux est videntibus and visis,
id Deus est intelligentibus and intellectis. Thalasstus in Hecatontade. That
which light is to them that see, and to things seen, the same is God to
understanding men, and things understood.

Use. Seek both of God by his revelation of the truth in his Word, and
illumination to conceive it in the preaching of it by his Spirit. Else no sound
wisdom is to be gotten, nor no spiritual light nor sight.

Verse. 7. He lays up sound wisdom for the righteous, he is a buckler to them
that walk uprightly.
The two next reasons follow, why right searchers shall obtain true wisdom.
The one from Gods plentiful provision. The other from his protection from
errors.

For the words.

He lays up, Heb. he hides. He had said before that wisdom must be sought
like an hidden treasure, now he shows where it is hidden, not with men, nor in
the bowels of the earth, but with God. Men lay up treasure, God lays up
wisdom, and that in Christ, in whom are all the treasures hid of wisdom and
knowledge, Col. 2.3. And who is the wisdom of God, 1 Cor. 1.24. Now, God does
not hide it to deprive men of it, but that as a treasure he may keep it safe,
and bring it out to give to his children, as they need it. And it shows withal
that God has abundance of wisdom, enough to serve himself, and all creatures,
because he lays it up as men do riches, who have much more then they have
present use of. And he lays it up for the good of his, as he does goodness. O
how great is thy goodness which thou have laid up for them that fear thee!
Psalm. 31.19. So it is ready and at hand for them upon all occasions. So we keep
things carefully, that we lay up for our children. As the men of China do hide
matter to make China dishes, in the earth, to make portions for their children.

Sound wisdom. The word (...), signifies,

1. Essence, or being or substance of a thing. Hence may come the Greek word
(...). That they are double to that which is, Job 11.6. How have thou
plentifully declared the thing as it is? Job 26.3. Thou dissolvest my
substance, Job 30.22. And so it stands in opposition to that which is not. So
riches are described, Will thou set thine eyes upon that which is not? chapter
23.5. Heaven only has a foundation, earth has none, but is hanged upon
nothing. Abraham looked for a City which has foundations, Heb. 11.10. But God
hangs the earth upon nothing, Job 26.7. Wisdom has solid substance in it,
and true worth, whereas opinion only sets the price upon all outward things.

2. The word signifies working or operation, which is an effect of essence.
Things must be, before they can work, and are to small purpose, if they work
not. God i^ excellent in working, Isa. 28.29.

3. Wisdom, which is one of the most excellent things that have a being. Keep
sound wisdom, chapter 3.21. Other things pass away, when it remains and supports
many things besides. Sapientia essentiae appellationem sortita est, quod sit,
atque ad omnem aeternitatem duret. Ab. Ezr. Wisdom has got the name of
essence, because it is, and endures to all eternity. It is also learned from
things that have a being, and is excellently seen in them. Some take it in the
first sense, and interpret it of that glorious being which God reserves for the
righteous in heaven. But it is best to understand it of sound wisdom, which is
said to be Gods gift in the former verse. God is not like a bad Father, which
wastes his goods, but like a provident one, who lays up treasure for his
children.

For the righteous. He had showed before what God gave, namely, Wisdom. Now he
shows to whom he gives it, not to all, but to the righteous. He lays it up for
them that will make a good use of it. Rectus est, qui suam voluntatem divinae
conformat volens de omni re id quod Deus vult eum v^lle. Ambros. He is right,
who conforms his will to G^ds, willing in every thing that which God would have
him to will. It may be translated, For the upright. So, gladn^sse for the
upright in heart, Psalm. 97.11.

He is a buckler. The Lord, mentioned before verse. 6. Others read, which is a
buckler. To wit, sound wisdom, mentioned in the beginning of this verse. The
former is the better. God as a shield sets himself between his, and all
dangers, especially spiritual. It might have been objected, The godly are
subject to many dangers and errors. The text answers, God will be their buckler
to stand between them, and what might hurt them. The Hebr. word (...), comes
from a word that signifies to cover and defend. A Buckler defends men against
blows and weapons. It signifies,

1. A shield or buckler, literally, such as are used in wars. Was there a
shield seen? Judge. 5.8. There the shield of the mighty i^ vilely cast away, 2 Samuel 1.21.

2. By a Metaphor it signifies a protection or protector from dangers. I am thy
shield, Genesis 15.1.

3. Rulers, who are the protectors of the people. Her rulers (Heb. her shields)
with shame do love, Give ye, Hos. 4.18. The shields of the earth belong unto
God, Psalm. 47.9.

Here it is taken in the second sense, and so God protects his from innumerable
dangers, and so does Wisdom also. But it may better be understood according to
the coherence, that God will be a buckler to defend them against all sophistry
and errors that would wound their souls, and rob them of that wisdom which God
has laid up for them. There is no want with God, neither is he sparing in
giving wisdom to his. As he lays it up plentifully for them, so he will bring
it out plentifully to them, and make it a buckler to keep them safe from all
hurt of errors, especially such as might endanger their salvation.

To them that walk. See on chapter 1.15.

Uprightly, or aright. Whose lives and actions are sincere and agreeable to
Gods Word.

Figures. He lays up. A Metaphor from parents laying up treasure, or portions
for children, 2 Cor. 12.14.

A buckler. A Metaphor from War, wherein Soldiers use bucklers to prevent
wounding.

To them that walk. A Metaphor from Travelers, to set out a constant course of
piety.

Note 1. Gods provision.

2. Gods protection.

In the former note,

1. The person, He; that is, the Lord.

2. The act, lays up.

3. The object, sound wisdom.

4. The subject, for the righteous.

In the latter observe,

1. The benefit, He is a buckler.

2. The persons to whom, to them that walk uprightly.

1. Doct. God has store of wisdom. His understanding is infinite, Psalm.
147.5. O the depth of the riches, both of the wisdom and knowledge of God,
Romans 11.33. Men have store of gold that can spare it to treasure it up. So has
God of wisdom.

Reason. It appears,

1. By Gods works. Of Creation. In wisdom have thou made them all, Psalm.
104.24. Of Providence, in upholding the world, wherein there are are so many
contrary dispositions in all sorts of creatures, that threaten ruin to it.

2. In his Writings. The Law and Gospel, Old Testament and New, the best books
in the world, if men's eyes were open to see the mysteries of them. Open mine
eyes, that I may behold wondrous things out of thy Law, Psalm. 119.18.

3. In his Scholars. Bezaleel and Aboliab filled by God with understanding in
all manner of curious works, Exodus 31.2, etc. David by Gods Word made wiser
then his enemies, teachers, ancients, Psalm. 119.98, etc. The Prophets,
Apostles. We count them best Schoolmasters, and wisest, out of whose Schools
come rare Physicians, Lawyers, Divines. All learned men come out of Gods
School. His is the heavenly Academy.

Use. Let us admire at Gods infinite wisdom, and seeing our own small store,
let us submit our judgment to his in all things, for he is wisest. It seems
strange to flesh and blood to be saved by the Cross of Christ. It seemed so to
Jews and Greeks. Christ crucified is unto the Jews a stumbling block, and unto
the Greeks foolishness, 1 Cor. 1.23. That is, to all the wise men of the
world. For the rest of the world had little learning then, and were counted
Barbarians. Let us look for salvation no way else but from the Cross of
Christ. It seems strange to us, that death should be destroyed by death, yet it
is eafie to God. It seems no less strange, that God should work by contraries.
Yet he does so. He brings light out of darkness, and leads many to heaven
through an hell of conscience. It seems strange to us that we should be fick or
poor, when others are well or rich; but God in his wisdom sees some good in it
to us, which we see not. Let us therefore be patient.

2. Doct. God provides wisdom for others. Parents, as they provide food and
apparel, so also they lay up portions for their children. God has wisdom
sufficient for himself to guide the world, and lays up enough to make others
wise. He lays it up,

1. In the Creatures. The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament
shows his handy work, Psalm. 19.1.

2. In his Word. These. are written, that ye might believe that Josus is the
Christ the Son of God, and that believing ye might have life through his mine,
Joh. 20.31.

3. In the Sacraments. They are mysteries, 1 Cor. 11.23, etc.

4. In Christ. He is made of God unto us wisdom, 1 Cor. 1.30. And of his
fullness we all have received, and grace for grace, Joh. 1.16.

5. In the government of the World. He brings down great men, disappoints their
plots, delivers his people, Exodus 15.

6. In the government of the Church. He makes his people to increase under
persecution, as the Israelites did in Egypt, Exodus 1.12. Sanguis Mirtyrum
semen Ecclesiae. The blood of the Martyrs was the seed of the Church.

7. In Heaven. Eye has not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the
heart of man, the things which God has prepared for them that love him, 1 Cor.
2.9.

Use. Despair not of getting store of knowledge, if ye dig where and how God
appoints. We are ill keepers of wisdom. Adam soon lost it. Therefore God keeps
it for us. Otherwise it would soon be lost out of the world. Witness barbarous
times. Seek therefore for true wisdom in ^ste Creatures, by Observation; in
the Word, by Auscultation; in the Sacraments, by Meditation; in Christ, by
Supplication; in the World, by Contemplation; in the Church, by Consideration;
in Heaven, by Premeditation.

3. Doct. Upright men shall not want necessary wisdom. God has laid up store
for them. If any man will do his will, he shall know of the doctrine, whether
it be of God, or whether I speak of my self, Joh. 7.17. What man is he that
fears the Lord? him shall be teach in the way that he shall choose. The
secret of the Lord is with them that fear him; and he will show them his
covenant. Or, as your marg. reads, And his covenant to make them know it, Psalm.
25.12, 14.

Reason 1. Because God is liberal, and like to great Princes, uses not to give
one gift alone unto his Favorites. They give riches and honor. He gives
righteousness and wisdom. He blesses us with all spiritual blessings, Ephesians.
1.3.

2. Because he knows, that they will use it well. To such children as use
clothes well, and other gifts, Parents give more. So does God.

Use. It comforts Gods people. They have an heart to do well, but often
complain, that they cannot understand what is right in many particulars. Be of
good comfort, God that has given thee that heart, will give thee convenient
knowledge.

4. Doct. God will keep his from dangerous errors. So he kept the Antiochians
by the Apostles and Council at Jerusalem, Act. 15.1, 2, 31. The Galatians, by
Paul's Epistle, Gal. 1.8, etc.

Reason 1. Because God would not be dishonored, nor have his way nor himself
be evil spoken of by them. A Father had rather any should think ill of him then
his children.

2. He would not have them perish. Men may perish by damnable errors, as well
as by wicked lives, 2 Pet. 2.1. A Father would not have his children take such
courses as should lead them to the gallows. God has more care to keep his from
hell.

Use. Let us praise God for keeping us free from the damnable errors of the
time about God, his Word, Resurrection, into which others run greedily. It is
not our care, but Gods, that keeps us pure.

5. Doct. True wisdom is a great means to keep men from errors. So some read
it, which is a buckler, meaning wisdom. By them is thy servant warned, Psalm.
19.11. What to do? To take heed of errors, which himself sees not, verse. 12.
Beware, lest ye be led away with the error of the wicked. How shall we avoid
it? By growing in the knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ, 2 Pet.
3.17, 18.

Reason. Because wisdom takes away those things that make us go out of the
way. As,

1. Ignorance of the right way. This makes a Traveller take the wrong way for
the right. Ye do err, not knowing the Scriptures, Matt. 22.29. Wisdom removes
this, and shows us the right way.

2. Darkness. He that knows the way best, may err in the dark. So may Gods
servants in difficult things, not so clearly revealed in Scripture. Here also
wisdom helps them out.

Use. It discovers to us a way how to discover errors, and avoid them, which is
by getting wisdom. Verum est index sui, and obliqui. Truth discovers what is
right, and what it wrong. Men that have true weights at home, weigh things they
buy, and are not cousened by false weights abroad. So wise men weigh opinions
by the Scripture, and are not deceived.

6. Doct. Uprightness both of heart and life is needful for them that would
be kept from errors. Witness David's preservation, and Solomon's failing in
religion.

Reason. Because God takes no care of keeping such who deny him heart or life.

Use. Behold another means of keeping you from errors, that may endanger your
salvation. Get upright hearts and lives, and ye shall be safe.

Verse. 8. He keeps the paths of judgment, and preserves the way of his
Saints.
Here are the two last benefits, or reasons, why such as use the right means,
shall attain to the knowledge of God; to wit, Gods direction in matters of
judgment, and preservation in matters of practice. He not only shows that God
will give that wisdom to his servants, which he has laid up for them; but
also what good fruit it shall bring forth in them. God provides sound wisdom
for good men, which is a buckler to defend them, that they may walk safely in
good ways, and God preserves them therein.

For the words.

He keeps. Some understand it of God in regard of himself, that he always
does justly in what he does. Others, of God, in regard of his people. He keeps
them in right ways, and will not suffer them to err to perdition. But the
words are, To keep the paths of judgment; that is, God lays up wisdom in
store for them, and gives it them, and gives withal understanding to discern
errors, that they may judge rightly of divine truths, and not go astray from
them.

The paths. The rules of truth. See on chapter 1.19.

Of judgment. See on chapter 1.3. Yet to handle it more fully, the Heb. word
(...), signifies,

1. The Law, or Word of God, by which judgment is to be given. The judgments
of the Lord are true, Ps. 19.9.

2. The suit or case to be tried in judgment. Moses brought their cause before
the Lord, Numb. 27.5.

3. The sentence past in judgment. They gave judgment upon them, 2 King. 25.6.

4. The crime or cause of that sentence. They whose judgment was not to drink
of the cup, Jer. 49.12.

5. The punishment inflicted by virtue of the sentence. So shall thy judgment
be, 1 King. 20.40.

6. Justice, which ought to be in every sentence. Which executes judgment for
the oppressed, Psalm. 146.7.

7. The instruments of executing the sentence, or judgment. When I send my
four fore judgments upon Jerusalem, Ezekiel. 14.21.

8. The Judicial Law of God. Remember the Law of Moses, with the statutes and
judgments, Mal. 4.4.

9. Wisdom and discretion, which are very needful in judgment. The Lord is a
God of judgment, Isa. 30.18.

10. Moderation, which is very requisite in judgment. Else, Summum jus, summa
injuria: The highest Law, the highest injury. O Lord, correct me, but with
judgment, not in thine anger, lest thou bring me to nothing, Jer. 10.24.

11. Righteous promises. Quicken me according to thy judgments, Psalm. 119.156.

12. The rite, custom, or manner of doing a thing, which should be done with
judgment. How shall we order the child? Heb. What shall be the manner of the
child? Judge. 13.12. that is, How must the child be bred?

13. The form or show of a person or thing. What manner of man was he? Hebr.
What was the manner of the man? 2 King. 1.7.

14. Right or title to a thing. This shall be the Priests due from the people,
Dent. 18.3.

15. A pattern, according to which a thing is to be made. And thou shall rear
up the Tabernaele, according to the fashion thereof, which was showed thee in
the Mount, Exodus 26.30. Here it is taken in the first sense, God keeps his in
paths of truth agreeable to his Word.

And preserves. The word (...), signifies,

1. To preserve by keeping out of sin or trouble. Keep me from the snare which
they have laid for me, and the grins of the workers of iniquity, Psalm. 141.9.
Thy visitation has preserved my life, Job 10.12.

2. To keep in prison. Am I a Sea, or a Whale, that thou set a watch over
me? Job 7.12. Keep this man, 1 King. 20.39.

3. To watch exactly, what is done by our selves, or others. I will keep my
mouth with a bridle, Psalm. 39.1. All my familiars watched for my halting, Jer.
20.10. Here it is taken in the first sense, to keep from sin or danger.

The way. See on chapter 1.15. Here is meant the business, or undertaking, or
practical course of Gods Saints.

Of his Saints. It comes from a word that signifies mercy in the Original,
(...), from (...). Some gives this reason, because men come to be Saints by
Gods mercy, not by their own merits. Which is most true. But the word (...),
signifying actively such an one as shows mercy, as (...), such as do justly, it
may rather be that they are so called, because they are merciful like God. Be
ye therefore merciful, as your Father also is merciful, Luke 6.36. Hence
comes (...), a Storke, a bird kind to her aged parents.

Figures. Paths. Way. Metaphors from Travelers.

Note 1. Gods direction. 2. His preservation.


Note in the former, 1. The person, He. 2. The act, keeps. 3. The subject,
the paths. 4. The adjunct, of judgment.


In the latter note, 1. The act, And preserves. 2. The object, the way. 3. The
subject, of his Saint.


1. Doct. There is a certain path of truth. This is life eternal, that they
might know thee the only true God, and Jesus Christ whom thou have sent, Joh.
17.3. This path in Scripture is more sure, then if God should speak from
heaven. There was a voice from heaven. But there was a more sure word of
prophecy, 2 Pet. 1.17, 19. Written statutes are more sure directions then
words of Princes.

Reason. 1. Because else there is a necessity that all the world may be
deceived. If there be no certain knowledge in seeing or hearing, where there is
no obstacle, then no man can tell whether another man be a man or a beast.

2. There is no comfortable converse with God, if we know not what to believe
of his Mercy, Justice, and other attributes. He that comes to God must believe
that he is, and that he is a rewarder of them that diligently seek him, Heb.
11.6. There is no pleasing a man without knowing his qualities.

3. There is no escaping hell without a certain rule of truth; for our nature
being corrupt, and there being many ways of error leading to hell, no man can
escape damnation.

4. No more getting heaven then getting a Port at Sea, if there be no certainty
in the Compass.

Use. It shows the wildness of those that plead for liberty of conscience for
all errors. As if a man should inform the State that there were no certain way
to London, and petition that all men might go at all adventures, and no man be
tied to go the ordinary way, but every one go what way he thinks to be nearest,
over hedges and ditches, and over men's grounds and gardens. Ye will say this
were injurious to men. But are not heresies and blasphemies more injurious to
God? Are not men's consciences as corrupt as their wills and affections? Why then
should not others petition for liberty of will and affections, to love whom
they will, and hate whom they will? The best is, that the Text tells us, that
God keeps his in the way of judgment. If men will not keep theirs within their
bounds, God will keep his. However, there is a right way, and men ought to
labor to keep themselves and theirs in it.

2. Doct. Good men must keep in the sure way of truth. We have also a more sure
word of prophecy, whereunto ye do well, that ye take heed, 2 Pet. 1.19.
Beware, lest ye be led away with the error of the wicked, and fall from your
own steadfastness, 2 Pet. 3.17.

Reason. 1. Because of divine illumination, God shows the ways of error, that
we may avoid them, as Mariners take notice of rocks at Sea.

2. Because of divine direct on. He guides them in the right way, like a tender
Father. As many as are led by the Spirit of God, are the Sons of God, Romans
8.14. God gave the Sun that men should see to avoid wrong ways, and follow
right.

Use. It reproves all Gallio's followers, that look after right and wrong, but
not after truth and error; after the world, not after heaven. Sure if God give
light, he looks that men should make use of it.

3. Doct. Heavenly wisdom is given to men by God to that end, that men may
keep in the way of truth. To this end the Comforter (which is the holy Ghost)
shall teach you all things, Joh. 14.26. He is therefore called, the Spirit of
truth, Joh. 15.26.

Reason. So it is in all the senses. Eyes are given to distinguish colors,
Ears to distinguish sounds, Nose to distinguish smells, Palates to distinguish
tastes, Hands to distinguish hard things from soft. Much more is heavenly
wisdom given us to direct in the way of truth.

Use. To reprove such as boast of heavenly wisdom, illumination, revelation,
and yet maintain gross errors, contrary to Scripture, that set Gods Word and
his Spirit together by the ears. Woe be to those eyes that pronounce light,
darkness; and call darkness, light: and to those palates, that call bitter,
sweet; and sweet, bitter, Isa. 5.20.

4. Doct. There is a right way for the Saints to walk in. That thou may walk
in the way of good men, and keep the paths of the righteous, Verse. 20. I have
led thee in right paths, chapter 4.11.

Reason 1. Because else it were worse living in Gods Kingdom, then in any
other Kingdom. For all Kingdoms have rules of safety, and of living.

2. God should be in a worse condition then the meanest Master of a family. He
should have no certain service.

Use. Let us keep in the right way of the Saints. All other ways, though never
so specious, lead to hell. Therefore a cloud of witnesses that have walked in
this way to heaven is set before us, Heb. 11.1, etc. and 12.1.

5. Doct. God only can keep us in the right way. He will keep the feet of his
Saints, 1 Samuel 2.9. Hold up my goings in thy paths, that my footsteps slip not,
Psalm. 17.5.

Reason 1. Because he only can give light in his Word to discover the right
way.

2. He only can give sight to discern it by his Spirit.

3. He only can give might to walk in it, and to keep our feet from stumbling;
otherwise Gods people would soon go aside on the right hand, or on the left,
and soon fall into the way of sinners.

Use 2. When we are at a stand in the way for want of any of these, pray to God
for direction and help. When all our strength and friends fail us, God will
direct us. He sent food to Elijah, because the journey else would have been too
great for him, 1 King. 19.7.

2. Comfort your selves that have so good a guide, and so strong a keeper to
guide and keep you in the right way. Well may they walk uprightly, that are so
strongly supported. Gods hand is ever under his, they cannot fall beneath it.

6. Doct. Gods Saints are merciful people. So was Cornelius, one that feared
God, and gave much alms to the people, Act. 10.2. So was Zacheus, when he was
converted, The half of my goods I give to the poor, Luke 19.8. A strange
alteration, from covetousness to liberality, as well as from wickedness to
holiness.

Reason 1. Because of our renewed nature, that takes away hardness of heart in
part, and makes us pitiful, as the heaven is, that drops showers on the earth,
and looks for nothing back again.

2. They love to be like their God, who makes his Sun to rise on the evil,
and on the good, and sends rain on the just, and on the unjust, Mat. 5.45.

Use. I would make an use of trial, but I scarce dare. I am afraid, if every
one that hears me now, should faithfully try his estate, which he knows, laying
it in one balance, and his good deeds in another, and God should hold the
scales, as one day he will do, we should find but a few Saints. Many would be
found in Belshazzar's condition, too light, when they are weighed, Dan. 5.27.
Our abundance and finenesse in food and apparel, compared with the wants of
the poor, would condemn us. In the Law, the Ministers had the tenth of men's
profits: Now Ministers, Schools, Poor, Churches Education of our own children
in learning, have it not. Our note of Saints now is to rail upon carnal men,
and do duties outwardly, and hold fast our purses. God amend it. They are
hypocrites and no Saints, what show of holiness soever they make that are not
merciful. Pure religion and undefiled, is to visit the fatherless and widows
in their affliction, Jam. 1.27. The sentence at the last Judgment, is
according to men's merciful or unmercifull carriage, Matthew. 25. and they that
show no mercy now must look for none then, Jam. 2.13.

Verse. 9. Then shall thou understand righteousness, and judgment, and equity;
yea, every good path.
In this verse. the second benefit of Wisdom is set down, to teach us how to
carry our selses wisely toward men. Having spoken largely concerning the
former, and backed it with reasons, now he briefly propounds the latter, it
being more easy to know how to carry our selves toward men, then toward God.

For the words.

Then. See on chapter 1.28. These words must depend upon the first 4 verses, as the
former Then, v. 5. did.

The sum of all is, When thou have used all the former means, then thou shall
know how to carry thy self toward men, as well as toward God. Others knit it
to the words following, Then shall thou understand, etc. when wisdom enters,
etc. But that particle (...), uses to follow, as chapter 1.28. not to go before:
and there is another reddition to that, v. 10. understood, v. 11. Then
discretion shall preserve thee. Also, the mark in the beginning of v. 10. in
our Translation, shows that the Interpreters conceived the sentence began
there; and these words v. 9. depended on the words before.

Shall thou understand. See on chapter 1.6.

Righteousness, and judgment, and equity. For these words, see on chap. 1.3.
and for judgment, see on verse. 8. of this cha. We must do things lawfully,
discreetly, and equally.

Yea every good path. A genus to the rest, and sum of all delivered in the
conclusion, or an etc. as if he had said, In a word, if there be any good path
that comes not within the compass of these, yet thou shall understand it. That
I may comprehend much in few words, thou shall not only know the former
particulars, but all honest ways, how to carry thy self toward men. For wise
carriage to God was promised before, v. 5. Thou shall increase in knowledge,
and grow from the knowledge of those good things, to know all else needful of
that kind.

For the word Every, see on chap. 1.13. on the word All.

(...), Good. It signifies,

1. That which is right and just. See thy matters are good and right, 2 Samuel
15.3.

2. That which is profitable. Houses full of all good things, Deuteronomy. 6.11.

3. That which is pleasing. Do what is good in thine eyes. 2 Samuel 19.27.

4. That which is full, and complete. Thou shall be buried in a good old age,
Genesis 15.15.

5. That which is joyful and delightful. A festival. We come in a good day,
1 Samuel 25.8.

Here it is taken in the first sense, for right and just ways.

Path, (...). It signifies properly a Wheel-track, and because such are found
in paths or ways, therefore it signifies so too. In a Common the way is
discerned by wheel-tracks. Thou shall see the tracks wherein godly men have
gone before thee, as a man may see the track of a Cart-wheel. It may be read,
every path of good.

Figures. Path, or Wheel track. A Metaphor.

Note. 1. The adjunct of time, Then.

2. The act, thou shall understand.

3. Three particular objects, righteousness, and judgment, and equity.

4. One general object, containing all the rest of that kind, that may be
imagined, yea every good path.

Then. When thou have painfully and carefully used all the former means.

1. Doct. Pains must be taken to know how to carry our selves toward men.
Therefore the Apostle gives many directions to that end, Romans 12.15, 16, 17,
18. 1 Thessalonians. 5.14, 15. See the places.

Reason 1. Because there are many commandments which concern duty to men, as
all the second Table, wherein are more commandments for number then in the
first. So careful is God for man's good.

2. There are many duties in every commandment that concerns men, as fear of
offending unjustly, loving carriage, good example, counsel, liberality,
patience, etc.

3. There are many faculties of the soul, and members of the body to be
employed in every duty, as the Understanding, Will, Affection, Tongue, Hand,
Foot.

4. There are many objects of duty to man. All sorts of men, friends, enemies,
strangers. Men of all conditions, rich, poor, wise, foolish, whole, sick. In
all things that concern them, to help them in their souls, bodies, states,
chastity, good name, contentedness. And what pains is sufficient to understand
all these particulars?

Use. It serves, 1. To blame those who think all men should please them, and
take no care to give content to others. These shorten Christ's sum of the
second Table, and make it, Thou shall love thy self. And leave out thy
neighbor.

2. To reprove them that take no care to breed their children, so as they may
know how to carry themselves toward others, but rather bear them out in
wronging other men.

2. Doct. God will give such wisdom to those that seek it, that they shall
know how to carry themselves toward others. So God taught Joseph how to get
respect among strangers, in Potiphar's house, in the prison, and in Pharaoh's
Court, Genesis 39.4, 21.22. and 45 16. God taught David how to get the favor of
the people, 1 Samuel 18.5, 6.

Reason 1. Because God loves concord among men. See how he commends it, and
sets it out by excellent similitudes, of precious ointment, and dew, and
pronounces a blessing upon it, Psalm. 133. There can be no concord, where men
know not how to offer right, nor suffer wrong.

2. God would have the praise of it, both of giving it, and of the fruits of
it. Men agree not well whom God joins not in affection.

3. All the comfort of the Commonwealth depends upon men's good carriage one
toward another.

4. The Churches good depends upon the good carriage of every member, even of
the meanest, as the Bodies do, 1 Cor. 12. God would have Church and
Commonwealth to flourish, if men's sins hinder not.

Use 1. To reprove such as seek not this wisdom from God, but carry themselves
proudly, and look that all men should do duty, and more then duty to them, but
care not so much as to take notice of any respect they owe to others, or showed
to them by others. They are far from Job's mind, who did not despise the cause
of his Man servant, or of his Maidservant, when they contended with him, Job
31.13.

2. To blame such as have this wisdom given them from God, to carry themselves
wisely and well toward others, but bring up their children so fondly, that
they neither know what they owe to their parents, nor to any else. These ruin
their parents estates, and prove the ruin of Church and Commonwealth. Such
cannot look that God should give wisdom to them or theirs, nor look that any
man should regard them.

3. Doct. Nothing is better then wisdom, it is here promised as a great
favor, and blessing. It is worth asking, Jam. 1.5. It was Solomon's great
request, 2 Chr. 1.12.

Reason 1. Because it will help at a dead lift, when all humane power fails, as
the poor man's wisdom did help to save the City, Eccles. 9.14, etc. So a poor
wise woman delivered the City Abel, when all the strong men in the Town could
not do it, 2 Samuel 20.16, etc.

2. It will guide us to heaven, which no power nor force can reach.

Use. Let us with Solomon make it our great request to God to give us wisdom.
We have more need of it to get to heaven, then he had to rule a Kingdom already
gotten. Let other men pray for wealth, let us pray for wisdom.

4. Doct. Many things are required to good carriage toward men.
Righteousness, judgment, and equity. Some things required of the people, some
of the Pharisees, some of the Soldiers, Luke 3.10, etc. Some dues to
Magistrates, some to People, Romans 13.1, 7, 8.

Reason 1. In regard of different persons, which look for different duties.
That will not befit an equal, that fits an inferior; nor a superior, that
fits an equal; nor a stranger, that fits an enemy; nor a neighbor, that fits
a stranger; nor a friend, that fits a neighbor.

2. Knowledge alone serves not, but Will and all the Affections are to be
employed in counsel, observance, etc.

Use. It reproves such as never study Ethics, the Scripture is full of them.
How can they expect that others should behave themselves well toward them, when
they know not how to carry themselves as becomes them?

5. Doct. Men must grow from knowledge of some good duties to knowledge of
others. They must go on till they know every good path. Grow in grace, and in
the knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ, 2 Pet. 3.18. That ye may
grow up, into him in all things, which is the head, even Christ, Ephesians. 4.15.

Reason 1. Because else Gods ordinances are bestowed in vain upon them, as soil
upon Cornfieldsd, Gardens, and Orchyards, where nothing grows.

2. All our labor is lost in reading, hearing, meditating, and conferring; as
a Scholars pains are lost that grows not in learning.

Use. Look to your growth more then to duties performed. See if they bring
increase and profit. Else you drive a poor trade.

6. Doct. Our carriage to others must be just and right in every thing. That we
may say with Samuel, Whose Ox have I taken? or, whose Ass have I taken? or,
whom have I defrauded? etc. And may be like Ananias, who had a good report of
all the Jews that dwelt in Damascus, Act. 22.12. The grace of God teaches us
to live justly, Tit. 3.11, 12.

Reason 1. Because one spot blemishes a whose garment, or fair face. So one
wilful failing disgraces a man's whole life.

2. One miscarriage lays a man open to punishment, and all his former good
actions cannot free him; as one murder lays a man open to death, though free
every way else.

Use. Be watchful over all your ways all your life long. David is tainted for
his unkind carriage to Mephibosheth. Let good men take warning thereby.

Verse. 10. When wisdom enters into thine heart, and knowledge is pleasant
unto thy soul.
The Wiseman having formerly showed the good that Wisdom would do to us to
encourage us to get is; now he shows, what evil it will keep us from, when we
have got it. And that, 1. In general, v. 10, 11. 2. In particular.


1. To keep us from hurt by the society of bad men, from v. 12. to v. 16.

2. Of bad women, to the end of the chap.

For the general; note,

1. The persons that are to be kept from hurt by Wisdom. They are such as
cheerfully entertain it, v. 10.

2. The preservation it self, v. 11.

For the first. For the words.

When. Some read it Because. Intimating, the cause of their preservation to be
the ready receiving of wisdom, and so make the words to depend on the former.
Thus it is used chapter 1.9. But it is rather to be read when, and referred to the
latter, and shows the difference in point of preservation from sin, between
wise men and fools. So it is used, Deuteronomy. 7.1. When the Lord thy God shall bring
thee into the Land. And the reddition, v. 11. confirms it, Then discretion
shall preserve thee.

Wisdom. See on chapter 1, 2.

Comes. S^e on chapter 1.26.

Into thine heart. See on v. 2. of this chap. It must not enter into the head
alone, but into the heart also.

And knowledge. See on chapter 1.2, 4.

Is pleasant. It signifies such a pleasure as men take in beholding beautiful
objects, which ravish the soul, and carry it away captive. It is translated
beauty, Psalm. 90.17. Let the beauty of the Lord our God be upon us. Hence Naomi
had her name, Ruth 1.20. Call me not Naomi (that is, pleasant, or beautiful)
but call me Marah (that is, bitter) when knowledge shall appear so bright and
lovely to thee, that thou receive and retain it in thy heart and soul, with
wonderful pleasure and delight, as the palate delights in sweet meat.

Unto thy soul. See on chapter 1.18. upon the word Lives. For the word is the same
in the Original. But here it is taken for the soul, the fountain of life.

Figures. Enters. A Metaphor from a stranger coming into the house, and
joyfully entertained by the Master of the house, for his excellent parts, and
the good that may be gotten by his society.

Is pleasant. A Metaphor from the content the eyes take in beholding beautiful
objects, or the palate in pleasing meats. If so be ye have tasted that the Lord
is gracious, 1 Pet. 2.3. So it is with the soul, when it begins to see the
beauty of wisdom, and take delight in it.

Note 1. The similitude of a stranger entertained.

2. Of a delightful object fed upon.

In the former note, 1. The stranger, When wisdom. 2. The entertainment,
enters. 3. The entertainer, into thine heart.


In the latter observe, 1. The object, And knowledge. 2. The feeding on it, is
pleasant. 3. The feeder, unto thy soul.


1. Doct. Men are naturally void of heavenly wisdom. Man is born like a wild
Asses colt, Job 11.12. The Gentiles had their understandings darkened, being
alienated from the life of God, through the ignorance that is in them, because
of the blindness of their heart, Ephesians. 4.18. Neither are we any better, being
all by nature ( Paul and all) children of wrath, even as others, Ephesians. 2.3.

Reason 1. It appears in our carriage our thoughts are vain. The Lord knows
the thoughts of man, that they are vanity, Psalm. 94.11.

Obj. But his words are better.

Answ. No. Their throat is an open sepulcher, with their tongues they have used
deceit, the poison of Asps is under their lips. Their mouth is full of cursing
and bitterness, Romans 3.13, 14.

Obj. But their deeds are better. The Heathen man said, Musa jocosa mihi, vita
pulica tamen: Although my muse do jest and sport of chastily, my life's not
short.

Answ. Their lives are answerable to their thoughts and words. They are all
gone out of the way, they are together become unprofitable, there is none that
does good, no not one, Romans 3.12.

2. It appears in their business. In worldly things they are born foolish.
Nemo nascitur artifex: No man is born an artificer. Much more foolish are they
then in heavenly things, which are further above their reach.

Obj. But in things of God which most concern them, I hope they are wise.

Answ. No. The natural man receives not the things of the Spirit of God, for
they are foolishness unto him; neither can he know them, because they are
spiritually discerned, 1 Cor. 2.14.

Object. But in matters that concern their salvation, they are wiser. Sure they
will not damn their own souls.

Answ. They are no wi^er in such matters. All have sinned, and come short of
the glory of God, Romans 3.23.

3. In their several ages. In childehood they mind nothing but vanity.
Childhood and youth are vanity, Eccl. 11.10.

Obj. It may be for want of wit they may follow their pleasure then, but their
manly age will reclaim them.

Answ. No. Then the world takes them up, profit drowns them. There are many
thorny grounds in the world. In whom the care of this world, and the
deceitfulness of riches choke the Word, and they become unfruitful, Man.
13.21, 22.

Obj. But old age will surely teach them more wisdom.

Answ. They, will learn none but the wisdom of the flesh, which is enmity
against God, Romans 8.7.

4. The cause of it proves it. The loss of Gods image by Adam's fall, which
makes us born without that wisdom, which Adam had by Creation.

Use. Let this humble us. Let not fools be proud of wisdom that have none.
That have foolish thoughts, words, deeds, in worldly, spiritual, heavenly
things; in youth, manly age, old age. And cannot without grace be any thing but
fools, being born so. Remember Agur's speech, Surely I am more brutish then any
man, and have not the understanding of a man. I neither learned wisdom, nor
have the knowledge of the holy, Prove. 30.2, 3. Apply this to your selves.

2. Doct. We cannot attain to true wisdom by our own strength. We cannot
force it into our hearts, it enters of it self. Every good gift, and every
perfect gift is from above, and comes down from the Father of lights, Jam.
1.17. The wisdom that is from above, etc. Jam. 3.17.

Reason 1. Because those grounds that we have cannot reach it. Our ladder is
not high enough. Sense, reason, common principles, humane instructions cannot
attain unto it.

2. We have not the wings that should mount us up to this heavenly knowledge;
to wit, revelation and illumination. (...), dilabitur sapientia, non in hortulo
nostro nascitur. Plantam hanc implantet Pater coelestis necessum est, condus
promus, and thesaurarius coelestis in penum nostrum reponere debet. This
