wisdom slides down from abroad, from without, and from above, it grows not in
our little garden. It is necessary that the heavenly Father plant this plant in
us. The heavenly Butler and Treasurer must lay it up in our storehouse.

Use 1. This should lay us yet lower in our own eyes. Though we be born without
saving knowledge, yet if we could get it of our selves, it were something. Many
a man born foolish for the world, poor, mean, yet by Art improving Nature,
proves worldly wise, rich, great. But we cannot get heavenly wisdom so.

2. Get it of God by prayer, and go out of your selves, else ye will never
attain it, as being naturally blind and unable to see the way to heaven, Rev.
3.17.

3. Doct. It is not enough that wisdom come into the head, unless it come
into the heart also. So that thou incline thine ear unto wisdom, and apply
thine heart to understanding, verse. 2. of this chap. Let thine heart keep my
commandments, chap. 3.1. Let thine heart keep my words, chap. 4.4. His mother
kept all these sayings in her heart, Luke 2.51. God opened the heart of Lydia,
that she attended unto the things which were spoken of Paul, Act. 16.14.

Reason 1. Because else truths will not be regarded, nor affected.

2. They will not be remembered, nor retained.

3. Neither will they be applied nor practiced. In effect neither affections,
memory, nor life will do their part.

Use. Let us then receive heavenly truths into the heart with joy, that we may
be wise. Let us set open the doors of our hearts to let in the King of glory,
Psalm. 24.9. It is not enough that truth come into thine ears by hearing, or
touch thy heart by understanding, but it must enter into it by pleasing
admission, and be received in love, 2 Thessalonians. 2.10. Wisdom must enter into
thee, as a man into his own house. Ab Ezr. taking possession of all the
faculties of thy soul. Thou must not only conceive aright of truth, but
willingly receive it. There is an Emphasis in the word Entering, or coming in.
Man's heart is a dark labyrinth. It is hard for the light to come in, but very
useful. It is needful for all the corners of the soul. The Soul (says
Macarius Hom. 5.) is a great shop, wherein are many rooms and ware houses.
There is the Trade of upright dealing in justice, etc. Every affection keeps
shop by it self, and is very unruly. Much wisdom is needful to direct every
one, as much light in every corner of a shop. The outward light of the world
may serve to direct the body, but wisdom must direct the soul. Salazar.

4. Doct. Knowledge is better then all outward riches. He does not say, riches,
or honor, but knowledge is pleasant. This dying David especially commends to
living Solomon. Thou Solomon my Son, know thou the God of thy Father, 1 Chronicles.
28.9.

Reason. It will stand by us at death, when all outward comforts forsake us,
and must be left.

Use. Labor more earnestly for it then for riches or honor, for which worldly
men take so much care and pains.

5. Doct. There is much pleasure and delight in knowledge. Gods judgments are
sweeter then honey and the honeycombe, Psalm. 19.10. How sweet are thy words
unto my taste! yea, sweeter then honey to my mouth, Psalm. 119.103. Pleasant
words are as an honey comb, sweet to the soul, and health to the bones, Prove
16.24.

Reason 1. Because it gives wonderful satisfaction to men's expectation. And
such things are pleasing to men.

2. It eases a man's mind in the mids of worldly cares and businesses. It is as
a Noah to Lamech: This same shall comfort us concerning our work, and toil of
our hands, Genesis 5.29.

3. It sweetens all worldly crosses, which are very bitter to fools. It brings
in Christ to help bear the burden.

4. It sweetens all worldly blessings, by teaching us how to use them aright. I
know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound; every where, and in all
things I am instructed, both to be full, and to be hungry; both to abound, and
to suffer need. I can do all things, through Christ which strengthens me,
Phil. 4.12, 13.

Use. We may well wonder then, why knowledge, which is so sweet in it self, is
so bitter to many, and they will take no pains to get it. Surely it is not
entered into their hearts. They are yet carnal. To good men it is sweeter then
all worldly comforts. Fables and Tales are pleasing to others, but Gods Word
and knowledge to these. It is like honey to them, and outward comforts like
gall, in comparison of it. As when a man has taken honey, other things are
bitter to him. Exercise makes that sweet to one man, which is bitter to another.

6. Doct. Knowledge will raise up a drooping soul. The sight of the Sun much
rejoices dulled spirits; the knowledge of Gods Word much more. The Law of the
Lord is perfect, comforting the soul. The statutes of the Lord are right,
rejoicing the heart, Psalm. 19.7, 8.

Reason 1. Because trouble of mind comes from a double ignorance.

1. We are ignorant of our nature, as if we were not subject to change. Not
only Rivers, but Seas ebb and flow.

2. We are ignorant of the nature of things, who take things to be hurtful,
that are not. Non sunt omnia mala, quae hominibus videntur mala. Nauta queritur
silere ventos; mundum non laedit tranquillitas. Arnob. All things are not
evil, which seem evil to men. The Mariner complains, that the winds lie
still; yet still weather hurts not the world. Homines perturbantur non rebus,
sed opinionibus. Si mors malum esset, Socrati ita videretur. Epict. cap. 10.
Men are troubled, not with things, but with opinions. Had death been an evil,
it would have seemed so to Socrates. Me occidere possunt, sed ladere non
possunt. Ibid. cap. 78. They may kill me, but they cannot hurt me.

2. Knowledge gives grounds of comfort from the sugar of Gods promises, of
profit, strength, singular deliverances.

Use. Love this knowledge better then ever ye did. What good will all the world
do you, if ye have troubled spirits? Knowledge only can lay these storms.

Verse. 11. Discretion shall preserve thee, understanding shall keep thee.
Now for the preservation it self of those persons that receive and entertain
wisdom, in this verse. They shall be delivered from many spiritual and
corporal dangers, which foolish men fall into, and they themselves are subject
unto, by reason of the remainder of sin in them, and allurements of others,
both men and women. As if he had said, God shall give thee such wariness and
understanding of the true nature of things, that thou shall be careful to keep
thy self from all evils which would weaken thy whole life, by means of
pot-companions, and st^umpets, who will continually be ready to set upon thee
in thy young and slippery age, to undo thee, if they can. This preservation is
a great benefit.

For the words.

Discretion. See on chapter 1.4. It imports a careful examining things in the
mind before we do them, that we may avoid evil. The Syriack reads, a good
thinking; that is, to think well beforehand, whither thou go, and what thou
do, shall keep thee from going and doing amiss. Cogito, quasi coagito. Notat
sereitatem. Beeman. To think, is to bring thoughts trgether in the mind. It
notes seriousness. Such is the care of the Wife, how she may please her
husband, 1 Cor. 7.34. She casts this way, and that way, how she may give
content. So every wise woman builds her house, chapter 14.1. She studies in every
business how to set every thing in order. So the Carpenter studies how to set
every thing in joint.

Shall preserve thee. As a buckler keeps from wounds, v. 7. or as a guard which
Princes and great men are wont to have about them, for the safety of their
persons. Their souls shall be as safe as the bodies of those great ones, who
have a Band of men always waiting on them. Or, as Cities that have a strong
garrison to keep them from danger of assaults by the enemy. Discretion shall
preserve thee from all enemies and disasters.

Understanding. Careful examination will give thee understanding to see what
is fit to be done, and what to be avoided For the word, See on v. 2.

Shall keep thee. See on v. 8. It shall keep watch and ward over thee. It
brings del^ght and safety. The same thing spoken in the beginning of the v. in
other words, for assurance, and to enlarge our affections to wisdom, as if no
words could sufficiently set out this benefit of preservation by it, and to
urge us to entertain it, and rejoice in it, as in a most beautiful spouse. If
we so do, it will show us the way how to be free from sinful courses.

Figures Preserve thee. A Metaphor from persons or Towns kept by a guard. Who
are kept by the power of God through faith unto salvation, 1 Pet. 1.5. The word
signifies kept as with a band of Soldiers in a garrison. The same benefit is
twice inculcated.

Note 1. The preserver, Diseretion and understanding.

2. The act, shall preserve, shall keep.

3. The person preserved, thee. He that joyfully entertains it, and takes
pleasure in it, shall be kept by it.

1. Doct. Men are subject to many dangers till they get wisdom. He goes after
her straightway, as an Ox goes to the slaughter, or as a fool to the
correction of the stocks. Till a dart strike through his liver; as a bird
hastes to the snare, and knows not that it is for his life, chapter 7.22, 23.
Thou fool, this night shall thy soul be required of thee; then, whose shall
those things be which thou have provided? Luke 12.20.

Reason 1. Because their reputation is in danger, and men had as leeve lose
their life as their credit, if they be generous. Folly will give occasion of
disgrace.

2. Their goods and essate will be in danger, which is a great loss. How many
lose them by folly, breaking out into unseemly words and deeds?

3. Their body and life is in danger, which are dearer then credit and goods.
Skin for skin, yea all that a man has, will be give for his life, Job 2.4. Is
not the life more then meat, and the body then raiment? Mat. 6.25.

4. The soul is in danger, and lies open to eternal misery. Therefore sin
which damns the soul is called folly. He had wrought folly in Israel in lying
with Jacobs daughter, which thing ought not to be done, Genesis 34.7. And wicked
men that go to hell are chronicled for fools all over this Book of Proverbs.
And this is the greatest danger of all. What is a man profited, if he shall
gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? Matthew. 16.26.

Use. It discovers to us the cause of many troubles and calamities in the
world, want of wisdom to prevent the occasions. I say, not of all, but of
many, for Gods servants are often persecuted without a cause, and for trial of
their graces; yet we may do well to attribute our sufferings to our folly, as
David did. My wounds stink and are corrupt, because of my foolishness, Psalm.
38.5.

2. Doct. Young men are most in danger of allurement. For he speaks to his Son
all along, verse. 1, 2, etc. He that is seduced by the Strumpet, is said to be
among the youths, chapter 7.7. Such are most subject to walk in the ways of their
heart, and in the sight of their eyes, Eccl. 11.9.

Reason 1. Brcause they are more subject to be set upon by strumpets, riotous,
thieves, as having least gravity to keep such off. My Son (a young man) if
sinners entice thee, chapter 1.10. Old men they will not set upon so soon. Nay, the
thought of an old grave man present might keep men from secret sins; as the
Heathen man said, Think Socrates or Plato sees thee, and thou will not commit
folly.

2. Young men have least wit and experience to resist such temptations, and
therefore Solomon writ his Proverbs to teach the young man knowledge and
discretion, chapter 1.4.

3. Because old men want fuel for many sins to be kindled by temptations and
allurements. They cannot exercise wantonness, riotousness, robbing, killing,
for want of bodily strength. The grassehopper to them is a burden, and desire
fails, Eccl. 12.5. They cannot taste what they eat and drink, nor hear the
voice of singing men, or singing women, 2 Samuel 19.35. Old men have seen the
mischief that falls upon evil courses of life, and therefore are not easily
drawn to them. Old birds will not be caught with chafe.

Use. Take heed young men, you think your selves strongest, and you are
weakest, your strength and heat of blood will soonest draw you to folly: for
lust is strongest in young men, by reason of natural heat. Therefore Paul bids
Timothy, Fly youthful lust, 2 Timothy 2.22. Be not proud and careless, but
humble and watchful.

3. Doct. When men get discretion and knowledge, they will be free from many
enormities, into which others fall. So the prodigal Son, who fed on husks
before, when he came to himself, found bread enough in his Fathers house, Luke
15.17. So the Angel of Laodicea, might be freed from blindness, poverty, and
nakedness, if he would follow Christ's counsel, Rev. 3.17, 18. Truth has a
freeing power. Ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free, Joh.
8.32.

1. Because Satan is daunted by repulses, as he was by Christ. Then the devil
leaves him, Mat. 4.11.

2. Wicked men give over soliciting, when they see it cannot prevail, as
Joseph's Mistress did, who though she brought him to prison, could not bring
him to adultery, Genesis 39.

3. Because men seeing the ugliness of sin, grow more wary, and so escape
snares. A blind man sees no rubs in the way, but follows his guide carelessly.
He that sees, looks at stumbling blocks, and goes beside them.

4. God watches over such, and men that have a guard are free from many
dangers, into which others fall. If a Rulers word has power, Gods Word has
more.

Use. It shows a reason why some escape those sins and dangers, that lay hold
on other men, and themselves had formerly incurred; because they have got more
discretion and true wisdom. They were once in much danger, now they are more
free.

4. Doct. Wisdom is a great antidote and preservative against evil. When thou
go, it shall lead thee; when thou sleep, it shall keep thee; and when
thou walk, it shall talk with thee, chapter 6.32. Wisdom may keep thee from the
strange woman, chap. 7.5.

Reason 1. Because wisdom shows the right end we should aim at, the right
means to attain that end, and the fittest time to use those means. And all
these help to preserve us from sin, judgment, evil practices; from dangers,
corporal, spiritual, and from hell it self.

2. It teaches a man how to make use of all times; of time past, else you lose
your life; of time present, else ye live ill; of time to come, else ye lie open
to all dangers. Whosoever keeps the commandment, shall feel no evil thing; and a
wise man's heart discerns both time and judgment. Because, to every purpose
there is time and judgment; therefore the misery of man is great upon him,
Eccl. 8.5, 6.

Use. Make use of this wisdom in careful watchfulness for your own
preservation. Ye are encompassed with a thousand dangers. Ye are naturally
careless, watchfulness will keep ye out of them. Thinking often of peril, is
the way to prevent peril. Other virtues are armed soldiers in the field,
ready to fight for the souls safety. Wisdom is the Watchman or Sentinel of the
soul, to foretell danger. Salazar. Where wisdom enters not into the heart,
there are no saving thoughts, nor counsels, whereby men may be safe; for the
inconstancy of man's mind is wonderful, and the blindness and frailty of it
great. Men think more frequently of vain and pernicious things, then of honest
and godly, unless wisdom be present, which may supply hearty and heavenly
thoughts, which may shut up the entrance against our enemy; as follows in the
next verse. To deliver thee from the way of the evil man.

5. Doct. Preservation from sinful ways is a great benefit and blessing. So
it is promised here as a choice mercy. I withheld thee from sinning against me,
therefore suffered I not thee to touch her, Genesis 20.6. It was a great mercy of
God to keep Joseph from adultery, Genesis 39.10. David found not so much favor
from God, 2 Samuel 11. Tibi deputo peccata, quae non feci. To thee (O Lord) I
impute it, that I have not committed such and such sins. Aug.

Reason 1. In regard of good men's account, who set a great price upon it, and
pray earnestly for it. So does David, Set a watch (O Lord) before my mouth,
keep the door of my lips. Incline not my heart to any evil thing, to practice
wicked works with men that work iniquity; and let me not eat of their dainties,
Ps. 140.4.

2. In regard of evils prevented, as Gods frowns, pangs of conscience,
diseases, troubles, hell.

3. In regard of the cost of recovery. It cost Christ his heart blood to
recover Gods favor to sinners. It will cost us many prayers and tears, as it
did David, Psalm. 51.

4. In regard of the scandal of our sins, whereby others may be drawn to hell,
and which all our following good works will not wipe off.

Use. Let us bless God, if we see others fall into gross sins, and our selves
kept from them, as we would do if all the houses about us were infected, and
ours kept free. Rahab escaped when Jericho was destroyed. An antidote is better
then a cure. It saves much pain both of disease and healing. Men must be made
more sick ere they be healed. It is no small matter of little importance that
is here promised, but safety and rest, which all the world cannot give us,
though it stood armed round about us to defend us. Then give God great praise
for it.

6. Doct. There is need of understanding and care to keep us from evil. I
said, I will take heed to my ways, Psalm. 39.1. Thy word have I hid in my heart
that I might not sin against thee, Psalm. 119.11.

Reason 1. There is need of much understanding. Else we may think, that we do
very well, when we do very ill. I verily thought (says Paul) with my self,
that I ought to do many things contrary to the Name of Jesus of Nazareth, Act.
26.9.

2. There is need of great care, else knowledge is in vain. Knowing men will
sin negligently, or wilfully, if care be wanting.

Use. Provide these two wings still, and care to flee from evil. A watchman
must both wake and watch. So must we spiritually, if we will escape sin.

Verse. 12. To deliver thee from the way of the evil man, from the man that
speaks froward things.
Here begins the deliverance from dangers that may come to us by evil men's
society. The benefit is propounded in the beginning of this verse. The evil
man's way from which he is to be delivered, is set out by diverse effects.

1. In his words, in the end of this verse. 2. In his works, v. 13. 3. In his
affections, v. 14. 4. In his obstinacy, v. 15.
For the words.

To deliver thee. The Heb. word (...), signifies,

1. To spoil a man or take his goods from him. All the riches that God has
taken from our Father, Genesis 31.16.

2. To take away a man from trouble, or deliver him. And delivered our houses;
Exodus 12.27. So here.

From. So (...) is translated, From the hand of all his enemies, and from the
band of Saul, Psalm. 18. in the title. Sometimes it is out of. He has delivered
me out of all trouble, Psalm. 54.7. Here it may be understood either way.
Wisdom is good to deliver men from ill ways, that they fall not into them;
and to deliver them out of them, when they are fallen into them; to keep them
out, or bring them out. But it is best to understand it in the first sense, as
it is translated. For it is a greater mercy to be kept out of ill ways, then
to be brought out of them. As it is a greater favor to be kept in health, then
to be healed. It agrees also best with the scope of the place, which is, to
keep young men from entering into evil ways.

The way. See on chapter 1.15. It signifies their wicked courses of life, which as
a wrong way leads to a bad end. Wisdom will keep us from following bad
example, and delighting in the company of bad men, and so getting hurt by them.
From walking in their way with them, or after them. From joining with them in
sin, or doing the like sins.

Of the evil man; that is, of evil men. The singular for the plural; as is
expressed, v. 13. Who leave the ways of uprightness, or of evil; that is,
from all evil ways, or from the evil way; that is, from evil courses. As
appears by what follows by way of explanation in the words following. For the
word, see on chapter 1.16.

From the man. (...), signifies,

1. A man by kind opposed to a beast, either male or female. Whether it be
beast or man, Exodus 19.13.

2. A male, or a man opposed to a woman. There was a man in the Land of Vz,
Job. 1.1.

3. An Husband, opposed to a Wife. She gave also to her Husband, Genesis 3.6.

4. A great man, or a valiant man. Art not thou a valiant man? 1 Samuel 26.15.

Here it is taken in the third sense, for a man opposed to a woman, v. 16.

That speaks. That is, so full of wickedness, that he cannot keep it in, but
it breaks out in his words.

Froward things. Contrary to what he should speak. Cross things to truth,
holiness or righteousness. That gives such untoward counsel as is mentioned,
chapter 1.11. Come with us, let us lay wait for blood, etc. Whereby men are seduced
to evil. Words tending to the subversion of Gods honor, and man's good,
temporal and eternal, whereby men are perverted. Such as speak distorted
words, as if the upper lip stood where the nether lip should.

The sum is, as if Solomon should have said, Unless wisdom enter into thy
heart as a keeper, how can thou conversing amongst men, who for the most part
walk in an evil way, be freed from the grossest errors, or most corrupt
manners of them that speak perverse things, seeking to infect others by their
subverting persuasions. Thus some do in matters of opinion. Also, of your own
selves shall m^n arise, speaking perverse things, to draw away disciples after
them, Act. 20.30. Others do the like in matters of practice. Let us eat and
drink, for to morrow we die, 1 Cor. 15.32. Discretion then, and understanding
deliver us from evil men's ways, and words of perverse men; not by taking us
out of the world, but by not suffering us to believe their evil words, or to
follow their lewd courses.

Figures none.

Note 1. The deliverance. 2. The description of the person, from whom he is
delivered.


In the former observe, 1. The act, To deliver. 2. The object, thee.


In the description of the person from whom he is delivered; note, 1. The
danger, from the way. 2. The cause, of the evil man. 3. The effect, from the
man that speaks. 4. The object, froward things.


1. Doct. Young men are in danger of bad company. This lost Rehoboam his
Kingdom, 1 King. 12.8. He consulted with the young men that were grown up with
him, and which stood before him. This was the undoing of the prodigal Son. He
wasted his substance with riotous living, Luke 15.13.

Reason 1. In respect of the sociablenesse of their nature, which puts them
forth to seek for company, as soon as they are fit for action. Adam could not
be alone. Man loves to give, and to receive. Homo est animal politicum: Man is
a sociable creature. Arist. Now, most are bad, and that makes men for the most
part to light on bad company.

2. In respect of the necessity of their callings. He must buy, sell, trade
with others. His own calling cannot furnish him with all things needful. Now
many are bad in all callings, and the skilfullest workmen oftentimes most given
to drinking, by which others are spoiled that trade with them.

3. In respect of the band of their relations. Husbands, Wives, Parents,
Children, Kindred, may be naught, and with them they must keep company, because
they owe duty to them, and so may more easily be corrupted by them, then by
strangers, whom they less love. Jezebel A^ab's wife, stirved him up to work
wickedness, 1 King. 21.25.

4. In respect of the corruption of man's nature. The young man is corrupt
himself by nature. Therefore David calls on a young man to cleanse his ways,
Psalm. 119.9. So are all others. And like will to like.

Use 1. Choose good company at first. So did David. To the Saints that are in
the earth, and to the excellent, in whom is all my delight, Psalm. 16.3. I am a
companion of all them that fear thee, and of them that keep thy precepts, Psalm.
119.63. Much good may be gotten by the company of such, for soul, body, estate,
and credit.

2. Refuse all bad company, as far as thy calling and relations will permit,
else thou will burden them in their sins, and learn to be like them.
Constantius the Arrian Emperor, desired the orthodox Christians to join with
the Arrians, not only in worship, but also in society. They answered, Arriani
sunt mortui in delictis, and non possumus vivi cum mortuis conjungi: The
Arrians are dead in sins, and we that are alive may not be joined with the
dead. Scultet. in Lucif. Caral. p. 376. Nazianzen persuades his Brother
Cesarius to come out of Julian's Court, where he had an office, lest he did
(...), smell of the smoke, if not be burnt with the fire. He might be tainted,
though not perverted.

3. In conversing with such evil men as thou art tied to by calling or
relation, go not beyond thy bounds. Take heed of their sins. Be more ready to
do them good then to get hurt by them.

2. Doct. Young men are in danger of bad example. Joseph not old, had learned
in Egypt to swear by the life of Pharaoh, Genesis 42.15. Therefore old women must
be a pattern to young, and Titus in all things must show himself a pattern of
good works, Tit. 4.7.

Reason 1. Because there is a multitude of bad examples in the world, in young
men like them, in grown men, in old men. Among many snares one may take.

2. They are more ready to be won by examples, especial of great ones, then by
precepts, prohibitions, promises, threats. The other Jews dissembled likewise
with Peter, insomuch that Barnabas was also carried away with their
dissimulation, Gal. 2.13.

3. Young men are more ready to be led by example then others, because they
know their own want of experience, and presume upon the knowledge of the
ancient. I said, Days should speak, and multitude of years should teach
wisdom, Job 32.7.

Use 1. Be wary whom ye imitate. Do not imitate wicked men, nor civil men, but
men truly godly.

2. Be wary how ye imitate them. Not in their infirmities, but take St. Paul's
counsel. Be ye followers of me, even as I also am of Jesus Christ, 1 Cor. 11.1.
Follow them no further then the rule of Gods Word leads them.

3. Doct. Young men are in danger of bad counsel. Thus Amnon was drawn to
execute his wantonness by the counsel of Jonadab, 2 Samuel 13.3, 5. Therefore
Solomon advises his Son to take heed of bad counsel. My Son, if sinners entice
thee, consent thou not, chapter 1.10.

Reason 1. Because evil men will be continually provoking them to evil, for
they desire to make others like unto themselves; as some say, that infected
persons desire to infect others.

2. Wicked men are subtle, and can allure young men by flattering words, and
crafty speeches, which like sugar go down quickly.

3. Evil men can take all advantage of time, place, disposition, occasions to
seduce young men, and therefore are the more likely to prevail. They will
dissuade them from fearing God, or trusting on him; and then all fear and hope
being gone, young men may be easily drawn to any evil.

Use 1. Let young men labor to get heavenly wisdom, that they may be able to
distinguish good counsel from evil. Else they cannot be safe.

2. Let them take heed of being familiar with bad men. What can be looked for
from them, but bad counsel? What from a bad tree, but bad fruit? A corrupt tree
brings forth evil fruit, Mat. 7.17.

4. Doct. It is a great blessing to be kept out of evil ways. I withheld thee
from sinning against me, says God to Abimelech, therefore suffered I thee not
to touch her, Genesis 20.6. Blessed is the man that walks not in the counsel of
the ungodly, nor stands in the way of sinners, Psalm. 1.1.

Reason 1. Because it keeps us from all the danger of the way, as he that
scapes a theevish way, scapes robbing.

2. It prevents the danger in the end of the way. In the world, a man may have
a foul way to a profitable Market. In the sea, he may have a stormy passage to
a gainful Mart. Here the end is always like the way, good or bad.

Use. Praise God that ye escape errors and sins that others fall into. So ye
escape way-dangers, and end-dangers, that are eternal.

5. Doct. God sets characters on men whose ways should be avoided by us. Two
notes are set out in the text, evil Livers, and evil Teachers. Such as walk
in evil ways, and such as speak froward things. So bad men are described,
They are all gone aside, they are altogether become filthy, there is none that
does good, no not one, Psalm. 14.3. And so bad women are set out, She is loud
and stubborn, her feet abide not in her house. Now she is without, now in the
streets, and lies in wait in every corner, chapter 7.11, 12.

Reason. God does this,

1. For the good of his people, that they may not be deceived by them, whereof
they are in great danger. If it were possible they would deceive the very
elect, Mat. 24.24.

2. To make wicked men inexcusable. They might have known those that mislead
them, and have avoided them. For God gave them plain characters of such in his
Word.

Use. Let us study the characters of ungodly men set out in Gods Word, not to
imitate them, but to take heed of them, as Seamen seek to know rocks and
quicksands.

6. Doct. Some are so shameless, that they will give most lewd counsel. So do
thieves. Come with us, let us lay wait for innocent blood, chapter 1.11. So do
oppressors; Come, and let us cut them off from being a Nation, Psalm. 83.4.

Reason 1. Out of natural inclination to undo^ others, as Pirates are said to
hang out false lights on rocks and sands, to draw ships thither, that they may
have the spoil of them.

2. Out of pride of their own wit, that they may brag they have misled others.

Use. Take heed of such counselors, count them wicked men, and hearken not to
their words. Take Solomon's counsel, Crase my Son to hear the instruction that
causes to err from the words of knowledge, Prove. 19.27. Old men have been
drawn away by bad counsel, as Solomon by his Wives, 1 King. 11.4. Joash was
drawn to Idolatry after Jehojadah's death, 2 Chronicles. 24.17, 18. Julian is said
to be drawn to Aposta^^e by Libanius. Young men then, and unsettled, had most
need to take heed of bad counsel. Thoughts are not mentioned in this
description, because we know them not. We must judge of men by their words and
deeds, and embrace, or shun them accordingly.

Verse. 13. Who leave the paths of uprightness, to walk in the ways of
darkness.
The Wiseman now comes to the second note of wicked men, whose ways are to be
avoided, and that is wickedness of life. Neither does he set them out by any
one kind of sin, but by such general symptoms as are common to all wicked
men, that all wicked ways may be discovered. He shows his great care of our
salvation, in continuing still to show from what persons and from what dangers
God does deliver the children of wisdom.

For the words.

Who leave. He changes the number, and puts it into the plural, to show that
there are many such wanderers in the world. The word imports an utter forsaking
of good ways, and having nothing to do with them, as a Whore that forsakes her
Husbands house, and sets up a Stews, v. 17.

The paths. See on chapter 1.19.

Of uprightness. The known and beaten ways of equity agreeable to divine
Laws, and the Law of Nature. For the word, see on v. 7.

To walk. See on chapter 1.11. on the word Come.

In the ways. See on chapter 1.15.

Of darkness. Ways of uprightness are well opposed to ways of darkness,
because they are in the light, and ways of darkness are crooked. By ways of
darkness here are meant ways disagreeable to Gods Laws and Nature, whether
errors of judgment, or wickedness of life, as appears by what was said before
of the contrary ways of uprighenesse. The word (...), signifies,

1. Darkness of the night opposed to the light of the day. When it was dark,
Josh. 2.5.

2. The grave, the dark habitation of dead bodies. A land of darkness, Job
10.21.

3. A secret place, where men cannot see what is done, no more then in the
night. In a dark place of the earth, Isa. 45.19.

4. Afflictions, which make men sad, and fearful, and ignorant, how to get
out, as in a dark night. He believes not that he shall come out of darkness,
and he is waited for of the sword, Job 15.22.

5. Ignorance and sin, which is the night and darkness of the soul. The people
that walked in darkness, Isa. 9.2. So it it is taken here, as appears by the
opposition to the paths of righteousness.

Figures. A Metaphor from Travelers in the whole verse. who leave the
highways that are light some and right, to go through dark and crooked ways.
Now because many men are so cunning to hide their fins with fair colors,
therefore Solomon gives further marks by which these Imposters may be known,
that men may avoid them.

Note 1. The highway forsaken. 2. The by-way entertained.


In the former note, 1. The act, Who leave. 2. The object, the paths. 3. The
adjunct, of uprightness.


In the latter observe, 1. The act, To walk. 2. The object, in the ways. 3.
The adjunct, of darkness.


1. Doct. Many are out of the right way. Some have not the knowledge of God, 1
Cor. 15.34. The Apostle says more elsewhere. They are all gone out of the way,
Romans 3.12.

Reason 1. Because natural ignorance and corruption misleads many. Fire will
burn if it meet with fuel.

2. Worldly pleasures mislead them. Baits take the fish, though there be hooks
to catch them.

3. Profits will carry men away. Piracy thrives at a cheaper rate then
Merchandise. Pleasures last but our lives. Profits last to childrens children.

4. The Devils sleights mislead thousands. Swords may be kept off with
bucklers, bullets with mud-walls. No keeping off Miners. Satan works all under
ground. Countermining is uncertain, unless we could see where Satan digs.

Use. Take heed whom ye follow. Major pars meliorem vineit: The greater part
overcomes the better part. Most are bad, if ye look on Persons, Families,
Towns, Nations. Thou shall not follow a multitude to do evil, Exodus 23.2.

2. Doct. Some are so quite out of the right way, that they have clean lest it.
Rehoboam forsook the Law of the Lord, and all Israel with him, 2 Chro. 12.1.
Demas has forsaken me, having loved this present world, 2 Timothy 4.10.

Reason 1. To begin where we ended in the reasons of the last point. The
Proverb is, He must needs go, whom the devil drives. Satan (like a skillful
General in the War) if he once scale the walls, plunders the City, lays siege
to the Castle, gives not over, till he take it, that so he may command City and
Country.

2. Because God has forsaken them, when they leave the ways of
righteousness. He was wont to chastise them, while they kept the way, because
they slipped sometimes; but if they once go out of the way quite, then he will
chastise them no more, but let them have a joviall journey to hell. So he says
by his Prophet, I will not punish your daughters when they commit whoredom,
nor your spouses, when they commit adultery; the people that does not
understand, shall fall, Hos. 4.14. Why should ye be stricken any more? ye will
revolt more and more, Isa. 1.5. Nulla poena, maxima poena: No punishment is the
greatest punishment. Greg. Magn.

Use. Take heed of giving over the ways of piety. It is likely thou will never
return, God will forsake thee, and the Devil drive thee. If the sheep go out of
the fold, ten to one, he never returns. Wolves will devour him, or ditches
drown him.

3. Doct. Gods ways are right ways, in which men may walk safely. I have led
thee in the right paths, chapter 4.11. The opening of my lips shall be right
things, chapter 8.6. Therefore Gods way is called the way, Romans 3.12. And, the way
of peace, Romans 3.17. Intimating, that there is no other safe way, nay none
worthy of the name of a way.

Reason. 1. There is no way leading to the right end but this, to Gods glory,
and man's eternal salvation. Men's inventions lead to hell, not to heaven. All
such are lying ways, Psalm. 119.163.

2. It brings joy and comfort, when other ways bring sorrow and trouble. The
children of Israel said unto the Lord, We have sinned, Judge. 10.15. This
confession came from them when God had delivered them into the hands of their
enemies, for their Idolatry, v. 6, 7. there.

3. Gods servants have prayed to be directed in it; and they know best of all
the world, which is the best way. Teach me (O Lord) she way of thy statutes,
Psalm. 119.33.

Use. Let us keep in Gods way, else we lose much labor, and in the end are
disappointed of our hope, which is a double vexation.

4. Doct. Many prefer bad ways before good. They hated knowledge, and did not
choose the fear of the Lord, chapter 1.29. Brethren, be ye followers of me; for
many walk as the enemies of the cross of Christ, Phil. 3.17, 18.

Reason 1. It appears in particulars. Let us anatomize the world. Substract
Heathen, Turks, Jews, Papists; and among Protestants, Atheists, Heretics,
Blasphemers, Ignorant ones, Worldly profane ones, Hypocrited. All these prefer
bad ways before good. Tell me then what is lest.

2. It appears by the ground of it. All are naturally foolish, none wise but
those few that are enlightened from heaven. Turn a company of fools to seek a
way they know not, the most will take the worst ways, for they look at the
breadth and pleasure of the way, not at the end. They consider not that broad
is the way that leads to destruction, and many there be that go in it; but
narrow is the way which leads unto life, and few there be that find it, Mat.
7.13, 14.

3. Because there are more bad ways, then good, and it is hard to distinguish
them.

4. Because bad ways are more pleasing to our natural corruption then good.
As on the contrary, Gods ways are irksome to our corrupt nature, wherein a man
must as Hierom speaks, interficere in se radicem suam, and mortify his own
root in himself.

Use. Judge of your ways ye should walk in, not by your company, but by the
goodness of them. Keep not company with others in foul and sinful ways. Men
will not walk with their friends in the dirt, but in fair ways.

5. Doct. Wicked men do continue obstinate in evil doing. They walk in the
counsel of the ungodly, and stand in the way of sinners, and fit in the seat of
the scornful, Psalm. 1.1. So did Pharaoh till he was drowned in the sea. I knew
that thou art obstinate, and thy neck is an iron sinew, and thy brow brass,
Isa. 48.4. That cannot cease from sin, 2 Pet. 2.14. They wax worse and worse, 2 Timothy 3.13. So did Ahaz, 2 Chr. 28.22.

Reason 1. Because they are natural to them, and come out of internal,
corrupt, and fleshly principles, as folly is to a fool, which makes him
constant in foolish actions. Though thou should bray a fool in a mortar among
wheat with a pestil, yet will not his foolishness depart from him, chapter 27.22.

2. Because custom, which is another nature, hardens him in it. As many men
cannot sleep without a pipe of Tobacco at their mouths, so wicked men take no
rest till they do mischief, chapter 4.16. Yea, some care not for sleep, but are so
constant in their evil, that they fit up all night to game and drink. See the
power of custom. Can the Ethiopian change his skin? or the Leopard his spots?
then may ye also do good that are accustomed to do evil, Jer. 13.23.

Use 1. To call upon us to beware of lying long in any known sin. It will
harden the heart, recover thy self speedily by repentance. Shall they fall, and
not arise? shall he turn away, and not return? Jer. 8.4. Peccatum, quod per
poenitentiam non deletur, suo pondere trahit aliud: Sin not repented of, draws
on other sin. Greg. Mag.

2. To teach us constancy in good duties. It is a shame that wicked men should
continue in sinning, and we be inconstant in well-doing. We know that their
work is in vain, yea hurtful, but ours profitable, 1 Cor. 15.58. Other
creatures are constant in their ways; Sun, Moon, Stars keep their course;
Fishes swim in the water, Birds fly in the air, Fire burns, Wicked men sin.
Should we only be inconstant in good ways?

6. Doct. Ways of sin are ways of darkness. The fool walks in darkness,
Eccl. 2.14. They are called, the unfruitful works of darkness, Ephesians. 5.11.

Reason 1. Because men choose the night wherein to commit adultery, and to be
drunk, 1 Thessalonians. 5 7.

2. Because sinners fall into dangers before they be aware. In the day men can
see stumbling blocks, and avoid them; in the night they cannot.

3. Because they that walk in sinful ways, err and go out of the right way,
for want of spiritual light to direct them. He that walks in darkness
knows not whither he goes, Joh. 12.35. We would be angry with them that
should lead us out of the right way, more angry if they lead us into a Wood, to
be robbed by thieves. So sin misseads us into woody, shady, perilous ways.

4. Because they lead men into eternal darkness, into outer darkness, where
shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth, Matthew. 8.12.

Use 1. Take heed of sinful ways, they may seem good, but they are stark
naught. Wicked men, Noctem babent in oculis. Seneca. They have night in their
eyes. They are like Owls flying in the dark, whom all birds whoot at when they
see them in the day. So should we show our dislike of ungodly men in their
ungodly ways. Men love not to walk abroad in the dark night, then they lie in
bed and sleep. Sinful ways are worse then dark nights. Therefore set not a
foot out of door toward them, much less walk in them, but bid them adieu for
ever, that ye may be partakers of the inheritance of the Saints in light, Col.
1.12.

Verse. 14. Who rejoice to do evil, and delight in the frowardness of the
wicked.
The third note of a wicked man follows, which is the expression of his
affections in the content he takes in doing evil, and joy in sinful courses.
The Wiseman counts them wicked, who are grown to such an height of impiety,
that they take pleasure in the many and great sins they have committed; or do
commit and triumph in gross sins done by them, or by others at their
persuasion, or in their sight or hearing. This disorder of affections much
aggravates the naughtiness of their words and actions. They not only do
evil, but come to it with much desire, and practice it with much delight. Men
that have not only a disposition to do evil, but an habit also, and are
hardened in sin. This is the reason why they leave good ways to walk in bad,
because they delight in doing evil. In the former chap. verse. 10, etc. he
disswades the young man from sinning for profit; here he warns him to take heed
of sinful pleasures. He had before set out the pleasure wisdom brings to keep
us from the pleasures of sin. It is not enough that they do any mischief, but
they rejoice in doing those things that nature and reason forbid. They are in
the dark, v. 13. and see not their danger. Yet rejoice they in their deeds of
darkness. This aggravates their blindness, as well as their wickedness. For
the words.

Who rejoice, Heb. rejoicing. They plot, and practice sin with great delight,
and without control of conscience.

To do. The Heb. word (...), signifies,

1. To work, make or do a thing. God saw every thing that he had made, Genesis
1.31.

2. To bring forth corn or fruit, or buds, or branches, or the like. In the
seven plenteous years, the earth brought forth by handfuls, Genesis 41.47.

3. To dress or prepare. He took the Calfe which he had dressed. Genesis 18.8.
M^phibosheth had not dressed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, 2 Samuel 19.24. The
Priest shall prepare his burnt-offering, Ezekiel. 46.2.

4. To keep or observe. The children of Israel kept the Passover, Josh. 5.10.

5. To get or procure. Of that which was of our fathers Jacob has gotten all
this glory, Genesis 31.1. My power and the might of mine hand has gotten me this
wealth, Deuteronomy. 8.17. Here it is taken in the first sense for Doing.

Evil. See on chapter 1.16.

And delight. With so great delight, that they cannot keep it in, but show it
externally in gestures by leaping, dancing, etc. The former word rejoicing
intimates the inward joy of the mind: this word delighting sets out the
declaration of it outwardly in the body. Lira.

In the frowardness. See on v. 12. Heb. Frowardness, that is, Froward actions.

Of the wicked. Of the wicked man. For it is singular in the Original. Figures
none.

Note 1. Their internal joy in sin. 2. Their external triumph.


In the former note, 1. The act, rejoicing. 2. The object, to do evil.


In the latter observe, 1. The act, delighting. 2. The object, in the
frowardness. 3. The subject, of the wicked man.


1. Doct. Neither profit, nor pleasure should draw us to sin. Pleasure could
not draw Joseph, who slighted his Mistress her temptation, Genesis 39.9, 10. Nor
profit draw Peter, who despised Simon Magus his money, Act. 8.19, 20. Neither
the pleasures, nor treasures of Egypt could move Moses to forsake Gods people,
Heb. 11.25, 26.

Reason. Because all the pleasures, and profits of the world cannot
countervalle the miseries that follow sin.

1. In regard of measure. The pleasures and profits of the earth are small, not
great, short, not full. Never any man enjoyed all the world so, as to make use
of all pleasures and profits in it. And if he had all, and could use all, it
would not bring so much comfort, as there is misery in hell What is a thousand
pound to a thousand millions? What is a river to the Sea? What is a man
profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? Mat. 16.26.

2. In purity. These profits and pleasures are mixed with losses and sorrows.
Never any man found it otherwise. But there is no mixture of profit, or
pleasure with hell torments. Nothing but comfort for Lazarus in heaven: nothing
but torment for the rich man in hell, Luke 16 24.25. What is water intermixed
with wine to pure wine? or rather, what is it to deadly poison? What is gold
ore to gold purified by the fire? or rather, what is it to perpetual fetters
of iron?

3. In durance. These worldly comforts, and gain last but for a time. Finem
habent autuum, aut suum. Augustine. Either they have thy end, or their end. Hell
torments have no end. These shull go away into everlasting punishment, Mat.
25.46. Who would live a King for a year, to be in a cauldron of scalding Lead
ever after? What is a Lease to a fee simple? What is time to eternity?

Use 1. It condemns such as are bewitched with the pleasures of the world, and
seek to glut themselves with them in sinful ways. Sampson, whom no force
could overcome, was overcome by a Dalilah. This makes men careless of
themselves, and of all others. Let their souls, bodies, states, wives,
children, neighbors, sink or swim, be saved or damned; God be pleased or
displeased, all is one. What care they, so they may follow their pleasures? We
should remember that of Cyprian, De bono pudicit. Voluptatem vicisse volupt as
est maxima. Nec alla major est victoria, quam ea quae de'cuplditatious
refertur. To overcome pleasure is the greatest pleasure. Neither is there any
greater victory then that which is gotten over pleasure.

2. It reproves such as follow the world so close for gain, that they will have
it by hook or by crook, and so run themselves upon manny rocks of sorrows. So
they fill their souls with cares, and fears, while they live. Men's in terrenis
occupata semper est in angustiis. Bern. De modo been vivendi. Cap. 8. A mind
employed in earthly things, is always in straits. They fill their bodies with
labor day and night, trouble themselves, and all theirs, and go to hell for
ever. The world is the sea, profit the wind, the soul the ship easily drowned.

2. Doct. Delight in sin draws men from good ways to bad. As it did Sampson
the strongest man, and Solomon the wisest.

Reason 1. Because it drownes all pleasure men take in good ways, as water
quenches fire.

2. It sets men on fire to follow bad ways. So many go from thirst to
drunkenness. It is as a sport to a fool to do mischief, Chap. 10.23.

Use. It shows us the reason why some that have made a show of goodness grow
very bad scandals to Religion, grief to themselves, and to all their friends
that fear God. Delight in sin has made them cast off all goodness, and wallow
in all wickedness. Facilis descensus Averni; It is easy to go down to hell.
They that run down a steep hill, cannot stay till they come to the bottom.
When men cannot have their pleasure in a lawful way, it is but an easy step
over the bridge to unlawful things. Hircum lex non sacrificat, praeterquam
propter solam malorum ablegationem, quandoquidem voluptas est vitii metropolis.
Clem. Strom. l. 7. The law did not sacrifice a Goat, except only for the
putting away of evils, because pleasure is the metropolitan City of vice.

3. Doct. Pleasure of wisdom should kill pleasure of sin in us. Wherewithal
shall a youngman cleanse his way? by taking heed thereto according to thy word,
Psalm. 119.9. Thy word have I hid in my heart, that I might not sin against
thee, Psalm. 119.11.

Reason. Because wisdom affords us many daggers to stab sin to the heart. As
prohibitions, which if we regard God our Kings authority, are very prevalent.
Threatenings, which if we regard the power of God our Master, have great force
to kill sin in us. Promises, which if we regard the affection of God our Father
are very persuasive not to offend him. Directions how to avoid sin, which if we
regard God our Physician, will prevail with us to prevent sin, which is
hurtful to soul and body.

Use 1. It shows us why many take so much pleasure in fin. Because they have
no pleasure in wisdom. Therefore wicked men are called fools frequently in
Scripture.

2. Let us take so much delight in spiritual duties, that it may kill the
pleasure of sin in us. Carnis amor spiritus amore superatur, desiderio
restinguitur, Hieron. The love of the flesh is overcome by the love of the
spirit.

4. Doct. Many delight to do evil, and take fingular pleasure in committing
sin. They sleep not, except they have done mischief; and their sleep is taken
away, unless they cause some to fall. They eat the bread of wickedness, and
drink the wine of violence. Chap. 4.16, 17. Woe to them that devise iniquity,
and work evil upon their beds: when the morning is light, they practice it,
because it is in the power of their hands. And they covet fields, and take them
by violence; and houses, and take them away: so they oppress a man, and his
house, even a man and his heritage, Mic. 2.1, 2. It is a sport to a fool to do
mischief, Prove. 10.23. When thou do evil, then thou rejoycest. Jer. 11.15.
Some have pleasure in unrighteousness. 2 Thessalonians. 2.12.

Reason 1. Because of their great desire of sinning. They are like a woman with
child, at no case till they be delivered of their wicked projects by word or
deed. And then they are full of joy, when their lust is satisfied, like a
longing woman, that has what she longs for.

2. Because they find sin pleasing to their corrupted nature. In most sins
there is fleshly pleasure, earthly profit, or worldly honor, which delight
carnal men, as the bait does the fish.

3. Because of custom in sinning, which makes harsh things pleasant, and
brings a vicious habit which causes delight in sin. Signum habitus-generati
est delectatio in opere, Aristot. Ethic. 2. The sign of an habit gotten is
delight in the work.

4. Because of ignorance. They walk through dark ways, v. 13. and know not
whither they go. For if they did look upon the punishments to which their
sinful courses tend, they would stop their steps, and correct their harmesome
mirth by wholesome tears.

Use. Here is a note of trial to discern our spiritual estate. Wicked men
rejoice in sin; good men sorrow more for sin, then for troubles, as being more
offensive to God. Ahab is sick till he have Naboths Vineyard, 1 King. 21. Good
men rejoice in doing good, like their Savior, whose Meat it was to do the will
of him that sent him, Joh. 4.34. Wicked men are like them that are drawn in by
cheaters, and lose all their money at play: or like the Grasshopper, that sings
merrily a while, and then dies with hunger and cold. Of such an one says
Nazianzen, Oblectorque malis, mortemque in pectore fixam Rideo Sardonico risu.
I am delighted in evils, and laugh at death by a Sardonian (or deadly)
laughter. There is a certain herb, the juice whereof being taken makes a man
laugh till he dies; the like is also said of some touching certain poisonous
spiders, that the leap and dance till they die, Eusebius. Emisse. These cannot be
merry, unless the Devil be their play fellow. Sed-melior est tristitia iniqua
patientis, quam laetitia iniqua facientis, Augustine. But better is the sadness
of him, that suffers unjust things, then the gladness of him, that does
them. It ye be such, flatter not your selves, but be assured ye are wicked men.

5. Dect. Many triumph in their evil deeds, and brag of them. Many man's glory
is in their shame, Phil. 3.19. Why boastest thou thy self in mischief, O mighty
man? Psalm. 52.1.

Reason 1. Because they have no good to boast of. And men are naturally proud,
and would boast of something.

2. Because they go beyond others in wickedness. Simeon the Sorcerer gave
out, that himself was some great one. Act. 8.9.

Use. It teaches us to bewail the madness of those men, that brag of their
wicked exploits, how many they have made drunk, etc. They show their joy
herein by leaping, dancing, and other outward signs. How can they choose but be
mad, that boast of such things, as godly men are ashamed of? Tale est quod
facimus, quale cum rident phrenetici. Nulla verior miseria, quam falsa
laetitia. Bern. That which we do, is like the laughter of a frantic man. There
is no greater misery then false joy. Non dolere quod peccaveras magis offendit
Deum, quam quod ante peccaveras. Chrysostom. Not grieving that thou have sinned,
offends God more then that thou had sinned before.

6. Doct. Many love to have others take notice of their sins. Absolon went in
unto his Fathers Concubines in the sight of all Israel, 2 Samuel 16.22.

Reason 1. Because they think their sinful courses to be a credit to them,
showing, that they dare do that, which others dare not.

2. Because they would have others know, that they fear no punishment from God
or man, like the unrighteous Judge, Which feared not God, neither regarded man,
Luke 18.4.

Use. Of all men in the world take heed of those, Trust not them, that will
betray themselves to eternal wrath. They will not be afraid to ruin you to
eternity.

Verse. 15. Whose ways are crooked, and they froward in their paths.
It is no wonder, that wicked men go in crooked ways. Where else can they go
that leave the right way, which turns not aside to the right hand, nor to the
left? It is as if the wiseman should have said, Let no man think that he may
converse with them, and yet go aright in the ways of uprightness. It cannot
be wisdom only will free thee from hurt by wicked men, and from walking in
their crooked ways. The last mark of a wicked man is set down here in the
text, which is obstinacy in evil paths. Here is a gradation. Every step
exceeds the other. Ill words are naught, v. 12. Ill deeds are worse, v. 13.
Boasting of sin worse, v. 14. Obstinacy worst of all, v. 15. Such are
desperately incorrigible.

For the words.

Whose ways. See on chapter 1.19.

Are crooked. Swarve from the right rules of Gods word, and being compared with
it, are found not to be strait.

And they froward. The word signifies going backward, or out of the way.

In their paths. See on v. 9.

Figures. A metaphor from travelers, who obstinately go on, and persist in
wrong ways.

Note 1. The wickedness of their ways. 2. Their obstinacy in them.


In the former note, 1. The subject, Whose ways. 2. The adjunct, Are crooked.


In the latter observe, 1. The adjunct, And they froward. 2. The subject, In
their paths.


1. Doct. The Scripture delights much in metaphors. Cains sin is like a dog
lying at his door, watching for his going out to devour him, Gen 4.7. Jotham
sets out the unkindnesse of the Israelites to his father Gideon, in preferring
Abimelec a bastard before his lawful sons, by the trees setting a bramble to
rule over them, Judge. 9.14, 15. Jehoash compares Amaziahs proud desire, to a
thistles desire to marry his son to the Cedars daughter, 2 King. 14.9. The
progress, and profit of the Gospel preached, is by Christ compared to seed
sown in a good ground, corn among tears, fishes taken in the net, bread
leavened, treasure hid in a field, a pearl of price, Mat. 13. The difference
betwixt Gods people under the law and under the Gospel, is set out by
Allegories, of Sarah, Hagar, Sinai, Sion, Gal. 4.14. etc. The flying and
killing of Kings, and great persons under the similitude of Islands, and
mountains vanishing away, Rev. 16.20.

Reason 1. Because this is a great help to the understanding, as spectacles to
the eyes. By worldly things which we know, we are taught heavenly things, which
we know not.

2. It is a great help to the memory. Things that we forget (as we are very
ready to forget things belonging to the souls good) are brought to our mind
upon the fight, and hearing of those metaphors.

3. It works much upon the affections. Many outward things are very pleasing to
us. By comparing spiritual things to those things we love, and take comfort in
in the world, our affections are drawn higher. Therefore God is called a Father
and an husband.

4. It works upon the conscience. I am Gods servant, child, wife. When I see
the carfulness of mine to do duty to me, my conscience smites me, and tells
me, I am not so careful to do duty to God.

Use 1. It condemns the Papists, who in many points to confirm their
erroneous opinions turn metaphors into a literal sense. As to prove that
children, who die unbaptized, cannot be saved, they interpret that Joh. 3.5. of
outward water in Baptism, which is spoken of the Spirit washing away the filth
of sin like water. To prove the corporal presence of Christ's body in the Lords
Supper, they quote, This is my body, overthrowing the nature of the Sacrament,
taking the figne quite away, and destroying the nature of Christ's body by
making it to be in many places at once. So that there is neither Sacrament, nor
Christ's body. To establish their feigned Purgatory, they interpret 1 Cor. 3.13.
of natural fire, which is spoken of the trial of men's works by the judgment
of Christ at the last day, when all men's works shall be revealed, as gold is
tried by passing the fire, and when their Purgatory will be at an end, as
themselves confess. To establish prayer to Saints, they urge the custom of
Kings Courts, wherein men come to Kings by Nobles, not considering that Kings
are ignorant, and in danger, and soon wearied by many addresses, and therefore
must be informed, protected, eased by them, that are about them; but God need
not. Yea they drive men from reading Scriptures, because of these metaphors
taken from humane affairs, which God put in of purpose to draw men to it. So
Mr. Fox in Latimers life, mentions a Priour in Cambridge that dissuaded men
from reading the Scriptures, lest reading Luke 9.26. and 1 Cor. 5.6. Plow-men
looking back, and Bakers leavening the bread too little should despair. To
which Latimer answers, If a painter should picture a Fox in a Pulpit, in a
Friars coul, no Clown that should see it, would imagine, that the Painter
thought a Fox could preach, but intended to signify Friars did preach like
Foxes.

2. Let us labor to apply Metaphors aright, and then we shall profit by them.
When we read Joh. 15. see what sap we receive from Christ the spiritual vine,
and whether we be his sheep. And so in other parables.

2. Doct. The same thing is set out by diverse similitudes in Scripture. As the
progress of the Gospel, Matthew. 13. Our union with Christ by a Vine, Joh. 15. a
Graffe, Romans 11. a Body, 1 Cor. 12.

Reason 1. Because variety is very pleasing. Many different strings make good
music.

2. It is very profitable. A fisher had need of many baits. If one take not,
another may.

3. Man has many affections, and some outward objects work more upon love and
joy, others upon sorrow and hatred, others upon fear, others upon confidence.

Use. In every thing that concerns thy soul, make use of such similitudes in
Scripture as may most affect thee. As of the love of Mothers, when thou
doubtest of Gods favor. The store of sap the vine gives to the branches, may
comfort thee, when thou feel little grace in thee, and art grieved for it.
And so may thou make use of other similitudes, according to thy need.

3. Doct. Wicked ways are crooked ways. Such as turn aside to their crooked
ways, Psalm. 125.5. They have made them crooked ways, Isa. 53.8.

Reason 1. Because they differ from the rule of Gods Word, which is a most
straight rule for all men's actions, and from which men ought not to bow neither
to the right hand, nor to the left.

2. Men's own affections bow their ways and make them crooked. No wit of man
can decypher the innumerable crooked paths, to which men's crooked affections
lead them.

3. Men's minds are bowed by earthly things, and then their ways must needs be
crooked. Therefore the Apostle bids us, Set our affections on things above, and
not on things on the earth, Col. 3.2.

Use 1. Let us loath wicked ways because they are crooked. Many men go aside
like the Sea-crab. As the Wagoner seeks by-ways to avoid hillocks, lest he
overturn his wagon: so wicked men seek perverse ways to avoid dangers. Yet such
are self-condemned, for every man would have a straight way, that he may the
sooner be at his journeys end. We like not crooked arrows, measures, bodies.
The woman bound by Satan was bowed together till Christ made her straight. Luke
13, 11, 13. Satan has made many crooked in their ways. How justly may God say
to such as the Crab in the Fable did to the Serpent, when he had given him his
deaths wound for his crooked conditions, and then saw him stretch himself out
straight, At oportuit, sic vixisse: It is too late now, you should have lived
so.

2. Let us take heed of apostasy, and backsliding, for then we are sure to
walk in crooked ways. Such are all gone aside, they are altogether become
filthy, Psalm. 14.3. They are turned aside like a deceitful bow, Psalm. 78.57.
Some there are that go back from the good things which they have practiced.
They have heard the Word, now they are proud; and above ordinances. They have
prayed in their families, now they follow the world. They have been sober, now
they haunt Taverns. They have been just, now they have learned to cheat and
deceive. Others go from their former profession, and turn Papists, and
Separatists from Gods people, forsaking Gods ordinances, that were formerly
dear unto them. Others go from their promises, from their vow in Baptism, and
cleave to the world, and Satan; their National covenant, promising reformation
of themselves and their families, they are yet unreformed. Others go back from
the duties they owe to God, as the duties of piety, sobriety, justice, which
had they never practiced, professed, nor promised, yet are they due to God by
their Creation, and neither man's Fall, nor Redemption can free them from them;
nay, Heaven will not to eternity. Let gross wicked persons then (drunkards,
adulterers, swearers, etc.) view their ugly condition. If we should say, they
were turned Papists, Jews, Turks, Heathen, they would be angry; Apostata's and
backsliders are as bad, although they cast not off the vail of Religion. They
will continue in their crooked ways, unless God deliver them miraculously.
Thou have stricken them, but they have not grieved; thou have consumed them,
but they have refused to receive correction; they have made their faces harder
then a rock, they have refused to return, Jerem. 5.3. Evil men, and seducets
shall wax worse and worse, deceiving and being deceived, 2 Timothy 3.13. Custom
in sin hardens them. How hard a thing it is for men to do good, that are
accustomed to do evil, see Jerem. 13.23. No words will alter them. Some take
Gods covenant in their mouth, that hate instruction, Psalm. 50.16, 17. No blows
will mend them. When they are stricken, they will revolt more and more, Isa.
1.5. No kindness will reduce them. God used all loving means to reclaim the
Israelites, but they refused to return, Hos. 11.4, 5. No marvel then that Gods
Ministers lose many exhortations bestowed on many of their people. It is not
because they exhort not aright, but because the people are refractary,
resolving not to amend, though their courses be damnable, and they like resty
Jades, go backward when they are spurred; precepts, examples do no good,
Ministers and friends are disheartened from dealing with them, as finding them
incurable. So men thrust through the heart discourage Physicians and
Surgeons. Men had need have no society with backsliders, unless nature or
their vocation require it, and then also they had need beware of hurt by them,
for they are desperate.

4. Doct. Obstinacy in sin is a great height of wickedness. So God accounts
it. I knew that thou art obstinate, and thy neck is an iron sinew, and thy brow
brass, Isa. 48.4. So he punishes it. If ye will not for all this hearken unto
me, then I will punish you seven times more for your sins, Lev. 26.18.

Use. Repent of sin quickly, lest ye grow obstinate. Wounds not healed at first
grow incurable. Obstinacy in sin breeds hardness of heart, and that leads to
eternal destruction. Be warned, beware, and be saved.

Verse. 16. To deliver thee from the strange woman, even from the stranger which
flattereth with her words.
The deliverance from evil men was described before; now follows the
deliverance from evil women, which are as dangerous to him, if not more, in
regard of their crafty allurements. Men presented unlawful gain, chapter 1.11.
Women offer unlawful pleasure here.

Note 1. The deliverance, v. 16, 17, 18, 19.

2. A general application of good that may come, when counsels of evil men
and women are forsaken, v. 20, 21, 22.

In the deliverance there is,

1. A description of the party that endangers the young man, v. 16, 17.

2. Of the danger if they be overcome, v. 18, 19.

The party is described,

1. By her condition, v. 16. She was a strange woman, and a stranger

2. By her conversation.

1. In her flattery, v. 16. 2. In her falsehood to her Husband, v. 17.
For the first, and first for the words.

To deliver thee. The coherence stands thus: When wisdom enters into thine
heart, v. 10. understanding shall keep thee, v. 11. To deliver thee from the
strange woman, etc. To snatch thee out, as out of the hand of an enemy, or the
paws of a Lion, as David was delivered, 1 Samuel 17.37. or as a brand out of the
fire, as Joshua was, Zec. 3.2. For the word, see on v. 12.

From the strange woman, (...), a woman; from (...), a man. She shall be called
woman, because she was taken out of man, Genesis 2.23. Because she had her body
out of his, and therefore should be an helper to him in piety, and not an
hinderer. By a strange woman here is meant the adulteress, which being another
man's Wife, God has forbidden thee to touch or use as a Wife, and in that kind
should be a stranger to thee. So a strange God, Psalm. 81.9. is one whom we
ought not to worship. Strange fire was such as ought not to be used in
Sacrifices, Lev. 19.1. So men may dwell in a City, and yet be strangers for
trade, if they be not Free men.

Even from the stranger. This is another word in the Original, and often
signifies a woman of another Nation. For commonly strumpets were odious, and it
is likely that few Israelitish women would be such, being so branded. There
shall be no whore of the daughters of Israel, Deuteronomy. 23.17. It may be strangers
took the more liberty to be naught there, because Israelitish women durst not.
And if any of Israel lived so lewdly, they were esteemed as Gentiles, and that
was a good argument to move young men to avoid them. Some bring in unmarried
women that set up naughty houses for gain. But that is contrary to v. 17. which
speaks plainly of married women.

Which flattereth with her words, Heb. which makes her words smooth. Like
butter and oil, which will easily go down, Psalm. 55.21.

The sum is:

Heavenly wisdom, if thou embrace it, will give thee knowledge and strength,
not only to see and avoid the snares of evil men, but also to keep thee out
of, or bring thee out of the nets of wicked women, which are no less dangerous
to young men unexperienced, and prone to lust, through the corruption of
nature. Yea, and the more pernicious, because women are more skillful in
sugared words and have drawn away the wisest and strongest men, as Solomon and
Samson.

Figures none, unless a Metaphor in the word Making smooth. As in smooth paths
men stick not, but go on cheerfully, without any rub or let, so strumpets study
to compose their words, that the young man that has beauty to satisfy their
lust, may stand at nothing, but readily hearken to their Sirens Songs.

1. Doct. There is a medicine in Scripture for every disease of the soul.
Before there was a prescript against the venom of evil men, now, an Antidote
against the poison of evil women. The weapens of our warfare are not carnal,
but mighty through God to the pulling down of strong holds, casting down
imaginations, and every high thing that exalts it self against the knowledge
of God, and bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ, 2
Cor. 10.4, 5. The Word of God is quick and powerful, and sharper then any two
edged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of
the joints and marrow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the
heart, Heb. 4.12.

Reason 1. Because the Scripture is Gods Word, who is the catholic Physician
of the soul. Physicians keep prescripts for the cure of all diseases in a book.
Apothecaries have medicines in their shops for all maladies. The Scripture is
Gods book and shop. It is Gods Armoury, in which are spiritual shields,
swords, and all manner of weapons to deal with all manner of enemies. See the
whole armor of God described, Ephesians. 6.13, etc.

2. An induction of particulars will prove it. See a shield against the three
great Idols of the world. Love not the world, neither the things that are in
the world. If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him. For
all that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes, and the
pride of life, is not of the Father, but is of the world, and the world passes
away, and the lust thereof, 1 John 2.15, 16, 17. Against pride in particular.
God resists the proud, Jam. 4.6. And they cannot escape whom God will ruin.
Against covetousness. More is lost then gotten, if a man could get all the
world, which never any one yet did. For, what is a man profited, if he shall
gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? Or, what shall a man give in
exchange for his soul? Mat. 16.26. Against voluptuousness. See the rich man in
hell, Luke 16.23. All his wealth could not keep him out.

3. There is a fence against several degrees of sin. Against evil thoughts.
Men's thoughts will accuse one another in the day when God shall judge the
secrets of men, Romans 2.15, 16. Against evil words. Every idle word that men
shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of Judgment. For by
thy words thou shall be condemned, Matthew. 12.36, 37. Against evil deeds. This
Joseph knew, saying, How can I do this great wickedness and sin against God?
Genesis 39.9.

4. There are many remedies for the same sin. As, prohibitions, examples of
good men avoiding it, threatenings against, and judgments upon such as do it.
As, against Blasphemy. It is forbidden in the third Commandment, Thou shall
not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vain. It was avoided by Job. When his
Wife bids him, Curse God and die: Job said unto her, Thou speak as one of
the foolish women speaks, Job 2.9, 10. It was threatened and punished. He that
blasphemeth the Name of the Lord, he shall surely be put to death. And so was
the Blasphemer, Lev. 24.16, 23. Sabbath breaking is forbidden in the fourth
Commandment. In it thou shall do no manner of work, etc. It is avoided or
prevented by Nehemiah's care, Neh. 13.15, etc. He forbids it, and threatens
punishment. The like is, Ezekiel. 20.13. My Sabbaths they greatly polluted; then I
said, I would pour out my fury upon them in the wilderness to consume them. It
was punished by the Babylonian Captivity. Until the Land had enjoyed her
Sabbaths; for as long as she lay desolate, she kept Sabbath, 2 Chronicles. 36.21.
God made the land keep Sabbath, because the people would not. Murder is
forbidden in the sixth Commandment. Thou shall do no murder. Avoided by David.
He would not kill Saul when he had him in his power, 1 Samuel 24.4 6. Threatened.
Whosoever sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed, Genesis 9.6. Punished
in Joab, 1 King. 2.31, 34. Adultery is forbidden in the seventh Commandment.
Thou shall not commit adultery. Avoided by Joseph, Genesis 39.9. Threatened with
destruction, Prove. 6.37, etc. Punished in Zimri and Cozbi, Numb. 25.8.

Use 1. Let us observe our dispositions, and tentations, to seek for prevention
or fit cure. Else the medicine may be unfit for the sore, and do no good.

2. Observe those places of Scripture that make against those sins to which
thou art most inclined or tempted. So men in Gardens and Apothecaries shops
pick out what will cure their diseases.

2. Keep them in thy mind, as men do medicines for their own infirmities in
their houses, to be ready in time of need. A man may die that has his medicine
to seek.

4. Apply them when corruption or temptation works; as Christ did, Mat. 4. who
had a place of Scripture ready to repel every temptation of Satan.

2. Doct. As we are in danger of evil men, so likewise of evil women. So was
Joseph in danger of his Mistress, Genesis 39.7. And the young man in danger of the
Harlot, Prove. 7.7, 10.

Reason 1. Because of their loose and wanton carriage, which is a bait to take
men's natural corruption, and suell for that fire.

2. Because of their impudent solicitations, which may work on them that never
intended wantonness, as fire may take an house in which it was not kindled.

Use. If you see light and wanton carriage in women, come not in their company.
Hurt ye may get much, good ye can expect none. Either sin or a prison may
follow, as in Joseph's case.

3. Doct. It is good for men to know all things dangerous for their souls.
Therefore many fins are reckoned up, as Idolatry, adultery, cruelty, etc. Ezekiel.
18.11, etc. Swearing, lying, killing, stealing. etc. Hos. 4.2, etc.

Reason 1. Because they all are hurtful to the soul.

2. A man can never be safe else. If one seen sin be escaped, another unseen
will lay hold on him.

Use. Labor to know all sins, that thou fall into none. As a Mariner observes
all rocks and sands at Sea, and a Traveller marks all stones and holes in the
way, to avoid them.

4. Doct. The danger from evil women is great. By means of an whorish woman a
man is brought to a piece of bread; and the adulteress will hunt for the
precious life, chapter 6.26. Dalilah deprives Samson of the eyes of his body, Judge.
16.19, 21. Strange women deprived Solomon of the eyes of his mind, 1 King.
11.1, 4.

Reason 1. Because as good women are modest, so Whores are unsatiable in
filthiness. Witness the stews in other Countries, where men go in all the
day long to one woman.

2. As good women are most tenderly affected, so are wicked ones most cruel.
It is observed, that where-women are in company, murder follows robbery.

Use. Come not near women noted for wickedness. Be wise, and see danger in
their faces, and escape it. Foolish men fear no danger in adultery, till they
feel it. It is a trodden path, and therefore they think it safe. Why then should
the Wiseman tell us, that God gives us wisdom to keep us from the evil
woman, if there were no danger? Believe God, and escape the evil woman.

5. Doct. There is a propriety of Husbands and Wives one to another, which no
power on earth may violate. Therefore other men's Wives must be strangers to us.
So they are called, chapter 5.3. and 6.24. and 7.5. So Joseph accounted of his
Mistress. My Master has kept nothing back from me, but thee, because thou art
his Wife, Genesis 39.9.

Reason 1. Because else adultery were no sin, no more then theft, if there were
no propriety in goods.

2. Else no man had a right in his Children, or at least could not know his
right, if he had no propriety in his Wife.

Use. Infringe not this propriety. Remember that all but thine own Husband and
Wife are strangers to thee. To this end,

1. Refrain thy looks from thy neighbors wife. Adultery begins at the eyes. It
creeps into the heart at those windows. Say with Job, I made a covenant with
mine eyes, why then should I think on a maid? Job 31.1. Commit not adultery
with a woman in thine heart, by looking on her, to lust after her, Matthew. 5.28.

2. Keep thy tongue from soliciting her to sin. Say not as Amnon to Tamar,
Come lie with me, 2 Samuel 13.11.

3. Thy hands from laying hold on her, as Amnon did on Tamar, 2 Samuel 13.11.

4. Banish her out of thy thoughts, as the tenth Commandment bids, Thou shall
not covet thy neighbors wife. So shall thou not wrong thy neighbors bed, nor
infringe his propriety.

6. Dect. Strumpets are full of flattering speeches. See the Harlots alluring
words, chapter 7.14, etc. and Dalila's, Judge. 16.6, 10, 13, 15.

Reason 1. Because they liveidly, and have time to study fine words.

2. Because they seek by flattery to accomplish their base ends.

Use. Take heed of being overcome by their smooth language. They will tell
thee, they love none else, and that they cannot be hired by others, and that
they will die for thee. But they love thy wealth or beauty, and will leave
thee, when they fail. The Dutch Proverb is, The Vintner hangs not out his bush
for one guest. Balaam persuades the Midianites, Vt non viri sed multeres cum
Israelitis certarent, quae armorum vice corporis venustate, and verborum
illecebris essent praeditae. Theod. That not their men but their women should
fight with the Israelites, who in stead of weapons were endued with bodily
beauty, and entising words. And these got the victory, and made Israel to sin,
and brought the plague upon them, Numb. 31.16. Such women's lips are nets; their
hands, bands; words, cords to draw a man, as a fool to the stocks, or an ox to
the slaughter, chap. 7.22. Be wise, and fly from the strange woman, though her
lips drop as an honey comb, and her mouth be smoother then oil, chapter 5.3.

Verse. 17. Which forsakes the guide of her youth, and forgets the covenant
of her God.
We are now come to our second note, Her falsehood to her Husband. Lest any
Israelite should conceive that he did not offend, unless he dealt with
idolatrous Heathen women, now he expounds what he meant by a strange woman.
Another man's Wife, that dealt unfaithfully with her Husband.

For the words.

Which forsakes. The word signifies forsaking or failing one that is committed
to our charge, or to whom we are tied by any bands to be helpful. See on v.
13. upon the word Leave. She forsakes her Husband, either by taking other
Lovers to her privily, or seeking them abroad, or by leaving her Husbands
house, and living from him, that she may more freely follow her lusts.
Pot^^har's Wife, had Joseph hearkened to her, had forsaken her Husband in
affection, though she had stayed in the house with him. The Harlot ( chapter 7)
kept in her Husbands house, though she took advantage of his absence ( v. 19.)
there. Few so impudent, as quite to leave their Husbands, for then all the
world would take notice of their lewdness: but many deal falsely with them
underhand.
