(...), The guide. It comes from a word that signifies to teach, for teachers
are guides. A guide of the blind, and a teacher of babes go together, Romans
2.19, 20. And women are required to learn of their Husbands at home, who are
their guides, 1 Cor. 14.35. The guide here is the Husband. The head of the
woman is the man, 1 Cor. 11.3. Now we know, the head guides the body. Some
understand it of God, who is called the guide of Judah's youth, Jer. 3.4. And
so they draw the words to Idolatry, which rather set out adultery, as appears
by the words before and after the text. And this aggravates the sin of the
adulteress, showing that she is not only unfaithful, but also disobedient,
rebellious, and unthankful, in disobeying her ruler and guide.

Of her youth. The word contains infancy, childhood, youth, all our time till
25 years of age. But it is put for the time when they are first marriageable,
and married young. And the Husband is called the guide of her youth, because
she chooses him to guide her, and promises to be guided by him, which
guidance she has most need of in her younger years, and he is set over by Gods
appointment, as a guide, and therefore she ought to be guided by him. Here is
meant the first Husband, to whom she is first married, and first love uses to
be strongest. And she that will be false to him to whom she first gave her
heart, will make no scruple to be so to any succeeding Husband. So a Husband
loves the first Wife best commonly, being taught to rejoice with the wife of
his youth, chapter 5.18. Affection is hottest in youth. Virgins use to be more
ready to preserve faithful love, as Virgin-wax is purest. Yet this unchaste
young woman leaving her guide and Husband, to whom she was married being a
young Virgin, follows the adulterer. Magnum impudicitiae, and impudentiae
argumentum. Bain. A great argument of impudicity and impudence.

And forgets. Negligently, as the word imports.

(...), The covenant. It comes from a word which signifies to choose. It is an
agreement between two choosing one another, and tying themselves by covenant
one to another upon such terms as both parties like.

Of her God. Whom she professes to worship. For Solomon writes to the people
of God. For the word, see on v. 5. It is called the covenant of God,

1. Because God instituted marriage.

2. Because God is a witness of the mutual promise of fidelity which is made
in marriage, and takes especial notice of the breach of it, to punish it,
although the husband know it not. The Lord has been witness between thee, and
the wife of thy youth, against whom thou have dealt treacherously; yet is she
thy companion, and the wife of thy covenant, Mal. 2.14. The sin of the
adulteress is aggravated by every word. She not only fails in her duty to her
Husband, but forsakes him, and deals falsely with him. She forsakes her guide
that took care of her, and that in her youth, when she had most need of a
guide. She quite forgets not only a promise but a covenans, and that solemnly
made, not only in the sight of men, but of the great God, the instituter of
marriage, witness of the contract, whereby she bound her self to cleave to him
only so long as they lived together, the judge and the avenger of the breach.
But now without regard of the love and benefit past, or of the strong binding
covenant of God she breaks thus shamefully out, not only to the endangering of
her own soul, but of them also that are allured by her. The young man also is
here by strong reasons moved to take heed of her; for though she might flatter
him, and profess much love to him, yet questionless she that had been false
to her Husband, her first Love, and durst violate the covenant of her God,
would never be true to him, but make use of him, till she had wasted his body
and estate, and then leave him.

Figures none.

Note 1. Her sin. 2. The aggravation of it.


In the former note, 1. The act, Which forsakes, 2. The object, the guide. 3.
The adjunct, of her youth.


In the latter observe, 1. The act, And forgets. 2. The object, the
covenant. 3. The adjunct, of her God.


1. Doct. There is no trusting of them that will fail God and their near
friends. If Absolon abuse his God, and in duty fail his Father, 2 Samuel 15. the
people that follow him perish. So in Adonijah. What got Joab and Abiathar by
following him? 1 King. 2. Naboth is condemned by two false witnesses that dealt
unjustly with God and him, 1 King. 21.10.

Reason. Because they that have broken the greater bands, will not stick at the
lesser. If they fail God, they will fail men for their advantage. If they sail
friends, much more strangers or enemies. Qui semel verecundiae limits
transilierit, graviter fit impudens: He that once is gone beyond the bound of
shamefastness, becomes very impudent. Tully. If Samson can carry away the
gates of Gaza, he will make no bones of the beam and web, Judge. 16.

Use 1. It reproves such as keep company with those who are notoriously false
to God, and their parents, or nearest friends.

2. Those who employ such in businesses of weight. What good can they expect
from them? They will be left in the lurch.

3. Those that marry such persons. If they knew their falsehood to God or their
Parents before, it is in vain to complain afterward of their falsehood to them.
Who will pity them?

2. Doct. No bridle will keep in wantonness where it reigns. Neither fear of
God, nor loving Husband in this verse. None will serve Tamar but Judah her
Father in Law, Genesis 38. None will serve Amnon but his Sister Tamar, 1 Samuel 13.
None will serve Her^d but Hered^as his Brother Philip's Wife, Matthew. 14.
Neither Fathers counsel, chap. 5. nor Mothers, chap. 31. will keep Solomon
from strange women, 1 King 11. The incestuous person must have his Fathers
Wife, 1 Cor. 5.

Reason. Because where lust reigns, it overrules all civil and natural
bands, as a great river overflowing hides all the neighboring streams. Such to
satisfy their lusts, regard not friends, kindred, parents, children. See Pope
Alexander's strumpets Epitaph.

Conditur hoc tumulo Lucretia nomine, sed re
Thais, Alexandri filia, sponsa, nurus.
Within this Tomb Luerece by name,
Thais indeed, here lies,
Pope Alexander's Daughter, Wife,
Daughter in law likewise.
Use. We need not marvel then to hear of Adulteries, Incests, Sodomies in the
world, where lust is let loose it breaks all bands.

3. Doct. Many arguments may be given against Adultery. Two out of the text.
Unkindnesse to her Husband, and falsehood towwards God, which shall be handled
severally. Add the breach of the Marriage-band, which should be a strong band
to chastity. She should go to no man's bed, but to her Husbands. But Adulterium,
quasi ad alterum, or ad alterius torum. Beeman. To another man, or to another
man's bed. The wanton never wants one, though her Husband be never so near. Add
also the defiling of her own body, which is a great infamy; the diseases that
follow that sin, the wants when all is consumed upon lust, death by partners
rage, or others violence; the disgraceful name of Bastards stamped upon
children, and Hell it self in the verses following.

Use. Let these things scare men and women from Adultery, and bring such to
hearty sorrow and repentance in time, who are guilty of it, lest they eternally
destroy themselves and others. Many think adultery to be but a small sin, but
they forget these many arguments against it. Let us remember the dangers, and
take heed.

4. Doct. Adultery in a Wife is a great wrong to the Husband. Every one neighed
after his neighbors wife, Jer. 58. The wrong done to God by Idolatry is set
out by this similitude. Thou have gone a whoring from thy God, Hos. 9.1.

Reason 1. Because it wrongs him in his greatest propriety, dearer to him then
friends or children.

2. It breaks the greatest obligation, for he is her guide. If he leave her,
she is in perpetual danger. Her lovers having satisfied their lust will leave
her.

3. It may put the Husband to labor to provide for other men's children, and is
not that a great injury?

Use. Let women when they are tempted to wantonness, think what wrong they do
their Husbands. So great, that though they may repent, and be pardoned by God,
yet they can never make their Husbands amends. This is a sovereign antidote
against Adultery.

5. Doct. The Wise should be guided by her Husband. Wives submit your selves
unto your own Husbands, Ephesians. 5.22. See the same words, Col. 3.18.

Reason 1. Because the Husband is the guide, as in the text.

2. He is the head, and the body must not rule. It were a monster in nature to
see the body placed above the head

Use. Let Wives be content to be subject. A man that being sober overturns the
ship, and drowns the passengers, is not fit to guide it when he is drunk. If
innocent Eve missed Adam, Wives now in the state of corruption are not fit to
guide, but must be guided.

6. Doct. An adulteress sins against God, as well as against her Husband. She
breaks the seventh Commandment, where God forbids it, and separates those whom
God the author of marriage has joined together, and join them together, and
joins them together whom God has separated.

Use. Let Wives think of this, and of Joseph's carriage to prevent adultery;
saying, How can I do this great wickedness, and sin against God? Genesis 39.9.
And if they be guilty, let them say with David, Against thee have I sinned,
Psalm. 51.4. And repent, that they may be saved.

Verse. 18. For her house enclineth unto death, and her paths unto the dead.
The Wiseman proceeds to show the greatness of the mercy of preservation from
evil women by the greatness of the danger, from which men are kept thereby.
That is, from death it self, which is most terrible in the thoughts of wanton
persons, and which, if often thought of, would keep them from wanton courses.
This danger is set out,

1. In the kind of it, in this verse. Death. omnium terribilium
terribilissimum: The most terrible of all terrible things.

2. By the irrecoverablenesse or hardness to return, v. 19.

For the first. That the young man might see Solomon's counsel was not in vain,
he sets down the great mischief that befalls such as follow the Harlots ways,
and enter into her house. And how great evils he shall escape that comes not
there; is set out by the disorders of her house, and deadly ways of them that
live there.

For the words.

For. This is no reason of the last verse. why she wrongs her Husband, and sins
against God. She did not do it that she might perish her self, and undo
others, but that she might satisfy her own lust and covetousness. But those
words depend upon the beginning of v. 16. to show the young man what a great
mercy of God it was to keep him from the strumpets acquaintance, and by
consequence from utter destruction. The Genevah translation reads surely. As
the same particle (...) is translated, Surely in vain the net is spread, etc.
chapter 1.17. And then it is an absolute sentence; as if he had said, Make account
of nothing else, but utter ruin, if once thou enter into her house, and join
in her ways. Bain reads, seeing. And so ties it to the following v. as giving
a reason why few return; to wit, because her house leads to death; as if he had
said to the young man, If thou will not hearken to me, but wilt enter into the
Harlots house, thou will find death there, and a great difficulty of returning.

Her house. The filthy manners, and wicked conversation used in her house. For
the word, see on chapter 1.13. Some understand it of the strumpet her self, which
leaving her husbands poor house, lives with some adulterer in a stately house,
or hires one to entertain her lovers, and thinks to live gallantly there; but
leaving her Husbands house, hastens to the grave, the house of darkness; and
forsaking the covenant of her God, goes to eternal darkness. But it is rather
a caution to the young man to take heed of coming into her house, because he
shall find nothing there but death and destruction.

Enclineth, Heb. boweth downward. Not only tends that way, but with a descent
and humiliation, and laying low. There is in her house a road-way to death and
hell, and that downward, as men go down an hill apace, not staying till they
come to the bottom.

Unto death. It brings speedy death unto men, both of soul and body.

And her paths. See on v. 9.

Unto the dead. It comes from a word that signifies to heal, or cure, by an
Antiphrasis, because the dead are past skill and cure of the Physician. So a
mountain, mons a movendo, because it moves not. And a Wood, lucus a lucendo,
because it wants light. Wantonness takes men away from among the living, and
brings them to the dead in body and soul, which have dyed before them, either
by a natural death, or by such like wanton courses as these men take. Death
and the dead here must include both spiritual and temporal death, the grave,
and hell. For it seems not a sufficient reason to keep men from adultery, and
from Harlots houses, that they must die, for this is common to all men. A man
may say, as mockers do, Let us commit adultery without any fear, for nothing
shall befall us which does not befall the chastest men. They must die as well
as we. It must needs therefore include hell also, unless we should interpret
it of a violent or early death, which often befalls adulterers, and may scare
others more then hell. For the one they see; the other, they believe not. Many
murders attend on adultery, and ruin of whole families. Others translate it,
unto the giants. As the word is used, Deuteronomy. 2.11. which also were accounted
giants. And then it comes from (...), to heal, because they are strong and
stout, and need no Physician; or (...) to be faint or weak, because the very
sight of them makes others faint as if they had the pangs of death upon them.
And by these giants some mean the devils, the tormentors of adulterers in hell;
others understand men of great might, and great rebels against God, such as
those in the old world, who abused their strength to wickedness and
wantonness, whose bodies are now in the grave, and souls in the deepest place
of hell. To both which places adulterers must descend, to keep such wicked
wretches company in eternal misery, whom in their life they have imitated in
sinful courses.

The sum is: That all the courses that are used in the house of the
adulterers tend to death both of body and soul; that so the young man, if he
love the safety of his own soul and body, should take heed of coming there.

Figures. Her house. The sins committed in her house. The subject for the
adjunct. Her paths. A Metaphor from Travelers, often used in this Book.

Note 1. The hurt gotten in her house. Death.

2. The bad company it brings men to. Dead, and damned men, worse then to bring
men among Lazars in the Hospital.

In the former observe, 1. The word of coherence, For. 2. The cause, her house.
3. The effect, inclines. 4. The object, unto death.


In the latter note, 1. The way, And her paths. 2. The end, unto the dead.


1. Doct. Much hurt is gotten by conversing with lewd women. If Samson were
alive, he would tell you how by Dalilah's acquaintance he loft his strength,
liberty, sight, lise, besides the danger of his soul. Solomon would inform you,
how he fell from God to Idolatry by such company, and how thereby his posterity
lost the greatest part of their Kingdom.

Reason 1. Because nothing can be expected from creatures but what their nature
yields. Fire will burn, Seas drown, Ravenous birds feed on carcasses, Wild
beasts devour them. Evil women are naught. Evil trees bring forth bad fruit,
not good, Mat. 12.33, 35. All the household of the adulterers, and all her
ways, tend to death temporal and eternal, as in the text.

2. All men and women speak according to their disposition and employment.

Navita de ventis, de tauris narrat arator,
Enumerat miles vulnera, pastor eves.
Of Winds the Seaman, of his Bulls
The Plowman speaks, his Wounds
The Soldier reckons, of his Sheep
The Shepherd talk propounds.
A covetous man speaks of bargains, a voluptuous man of games, a proud man of
titles, an angry man of injuries, a strumpet of wantonness. Evil communication
corrupts good manners, 1 Cor. 15.33.

Use. Letus observe the carriage of women, and if we evidently see wantonness
in their words and deeds, set a cross upon their houses, with Lord have mercy
upon them, as over houses infected. Cum foemina semper esse, and non cognoscere
foeminam plus est, quam mortuum suscitare. Bern. in Cant. Sermon. 65. To be
always with a woman, and not to know a woman, is more then to raise up a dead
man. Touch not pitch, lest ye be defiled. Ye have fire enough in your own
natures, seek not fuel abroad. The young man when he grows acquainted with
strumpets, hopes to spend his days merrily in fine houses, and is suddenly
carried to death and hell. He looked for a storehouse of pleasure, fine
gardens, etc. and behold desolation. The Heathen man could say, Nolo tanti
poenitentiam emere: I will not buy repentance so deer. And the Proverb is,
Caveat emptor, Let the buyer beware. It serves then to admonish us to take heed
of haunting the company of Harlots, lest we defile our selves, and consent to
their filthiness. We would not willingly come near a rotten and ruinous house,
lest it should fall, and bruise or kill our bodies. There is more reason to
avoid the company of Harlots, whose society may not only break our bones, but
eternally damn our souls.

2. Doct. Many miseries attend upon adultery. It cost the Israelites and the
Benjamites deer, the loss of many thousand lives, and almost the destruction
of an whole Tribe, Judge. 19. and 20. and 21. It cost David deer, 2 Samuel 12. The
loss of his child, the abuse of his wives, a lasting sword on his house,
besides the rape of Tamar, and rebellion of Absolon and Adonijah, with the
murder of Amnon.

Reason 1. Because it was death by Gods Law, and so it is now by ours. Lose
life and lose all comfort.

2. It is infamous all the world over. No modest persons care for joining with
adul torous families.

3. It breeds many quarrels between the Husband and the Adulterers, Wives, and
Strumpets, Adulterers one among another, and Strumpets also.

4. It brings many murders. The adulterers will hunt for the precious life,
chap. 6.26. The Husband enraged will kill the Adulterer, chapter 6.34, 35.

5. It brings bastards, which is a disgrace to posterity.

6. It procures disinheriting of Children, when men suspect their Wives want of
chastity.

7. It breeds diseases in the body, and shameful ones too, as characters of
that wickedness.

8. It brings poverty on the state, by Gods curse, or the Whores covetousness.
For by means of a whorish woman, a man is brought to a piece of bread, chapter 6.26.

Use. Think of the many mischiefs that attend upon adultery, when thou art
tempted to it. A needful theme, for we naturally look not at sin, as it is in
it self, but as it is to us, not in its odious and filthy nature (as we should
do, though no danger followed it) but in its hurtful effects, which is to
fear the smoke more then the fire. Yet so to look at it, may be profitable to
keep us from the fin; if not, for hatred of it, yet for fear of the ensuing
mischiefs. Think with thy self, there is great danger and much wickedness in
adultery, else God, which is so merciful, would never punish it with a double
death, temporal and eternal. Remember that all conversing with strumpets tend
to destruction. And though she speak flattering words, yet shameful death
follows adultery, as well as theft or murder. In Adrian's Gymnasium, or place
of exercise, Venus is set forth as the ancientest of the Destinies, not
spinning the thread of life, but cutting it asunder.

Quid Venus est quaeris? est antiquissima Parca,
Filaque mox resecans, at neque nens eadem.
Thou ask what Venus is? She is
The ancient'st Destiny,
That quickly cuts the threads of lise,
But knits them not truly.
Plutarch writes of a Temple inscribed, Saerum Veneri homicidae: Sacred to
Venus the Man-stayer, Chrysostom on Psalm. 50. says What is an whorrsh woman,
but a sepulcher? and the common burying place of mankind is her house. And in
Rome, because old Harlots were not permitted openly, they harbored in caves of
earth, called Fornices, from whence the word Fornication comes; and in this
regard, it is fitly sald in the text, Her house enclineth unto death, and her
paths unto the dead. To the grave, an hole in the earth, where the dead are
laid. A dark place fit for sin, and fit for punishment. Terence calls Harlots
Cruces, because they crucify men. Venery is deaths quickest Harbinger. Pope
John 12. being taken with an Adulteress, was stabbed to death by her Husband.
A^xander the Great, and Otho the third lost their lives by their lusts. But how
many (alas) by this means have lost their souls? fleshly lusts do in an
especial manner fight against the soul, 1 Pet. 2.11. And nothing has enriched
hell so much (says one) as beautiful faces. Let the young man think on these
great examples, and tremble.

3. Doct. Wantonness shortens men's dayer. Give not thy strength unto women,
nor thy ways to that which destroys Kings, Prove. 31.3. The adulteress will
hunt for the precious life, chapter 6.26.

Reason. 1. Because it wastes a man's strength, and when strength fails, life
will fail. If fuel decay, the fire goes out. And thou mourn at the last, when
thy flesh and thy body are consumed, chapter 5.11.

2. It breeds noisome diseases, which oft-times prove incurable.

3. It has gluttony and drunkenness for companions, which alone can shorten
men's lives, much more accompanied with wantonness. Plures gula, quam gladio
periisse certum est. It is an undoubted truth, that more perish by the throat
then by the sword.

4. Strumpets kill men in private, either for their money which they have about
them, or for want of money, when all is spent, lest they should be a burden to
them on whom they have spent it.

Use. Let us quench lust with this water. If our life be gone, all is gone. Men
are at great cost to preserve life by physic. They forbear many pleasing
meats, and keep a diet. But no physic nor diet will keep an adulterer long
alive. Strumpets will waste more then those helps can do good. If they do not,
yet may the Magistrates sword, or Gods judgment do it. The King of Babylon
caused Ahab and Zedekiah to be roasted in the fire, because they have committed
villainy in Israel, and have committed adultery with their neighbors wives, Jer.
29.22, 23.

4. Doct. He that will escape an Harlot must keep out of her house. Had not
Joseph been in Potiphar's house, he had not been in his Mistrisses danger, Genesis
39. Joseph scapes by getting him out of the house. The young man (Prove. 7.) is
undone by going into the Harlots house.

Reason 1. Because her house is full of baits, chapter 7.16, 17. Fine fare, and
ornaments.

2. It has locks, and keys, and private opportunities of sinning.

Use. If ye know such houses, keep out of them. Strumpets like Cocks, crow on
their own dunghills. They count all their own that comes within their doors.
Keep out then, and be safe.

5. Doct. The house of uncleanness is the gatehouse of death. Come not near
the door of her house, lest thou give thy years unto the cruel. chapter 5.8, 9. Her
house goes down to the chambers of death, ch 7.27.

Reason 1. In respect of spiritual death. For what life of grace can be
expected in a stews?

2. In respect of corporal death, and that many ways, as ye heard before. The
Strumpets house is the Devils armory, wherein are weapons of all sorts to
destroy men, for the devil was a murderer from the beginning, Joh. 8.44.

3. In respect of eternal death both of soul and body. Her house is like Sodom.
If Lot go not out of it, he must be burned with fire and brimstone. His
condition that converses there, grows still worse and worse. His soul is dead,
his body will be soon dead, and then no space for repentance, and so he dies
eternally.

Use. Pity those gallants that pity not themselves, that go from their own
houses into naughty houses, and from thence to the grave and hell. Out of a
lesser and temporary fire into a greater, and eternal.

6. Doct. Adulterers go downward. Her feet go down to death, chapter 5.5. And
questionless her adulterer goes down with her. Let not thine heart decline to
her ways, for she has cast down many wounded, chapter 7.25, 26.

Reason 1. Because they go downward in their strength, as was showed before.

2. In their estates. For much is spent upon strumpets, to the impoverishing of
themselves and theirs.

Use. Let such repent quickly, lest they go so low that they never get up again.

Verse. 19. None that go unto her return again, neither take they hold on the
paths of life.
The wounds gotten in the Harlots house which are deadly, were set out in the
former v. The ordinary neglect of them, and irrecoverablenesse, is set out in
this v.

For the words.

None. Not only her self, but also all her customers are in danger of
perishing. Hebr. not all, which in Scripture language is none. As Psalm. 143.2.
In thy sight shall no man living be justified, Heb. not every one living. See
more on chapter 1.24. on No man. Some of the ancientest have hence concluded, that
adultery is an unpardonable sin. But they forget, that all manner of sin and
blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men, save only the sin against the holy
Ghost, Mat. 12.31. Not none of any condition, or none of all simply (though the
word be used both these ways in several places) but none in comparison, or
very few. So few return from adulterous courses; that in respect of them which
do not return, they are as none. So, None calls for justice, Isa. 59.4. There
is none that calls upon thy name, Isa. 64.7. That is, very few do so. He
compares them which are given to adultery, to Soldiers that go into the war,
and there place and thrust themselves so forward, that they are slain. We say,
All the City went to see such a sight; that is, the most of them. It may be
some could not, and others would not. We know that David did repent of
adultery, but we read of few more that did it. Some understand it, that none do
or can return by their own wit, or strength, have they never so good natural
parts; but by Gods extraordinary grace some may and do return. But the former
interpretation is better.

That go unto her. That go in unto her to commit adultery with her. A modest
expression of a secret or foul action, frequent in Scripture. Jacob went in
unto Leah, Genesis 29.23. David had gone in unto Bathshebab, Psalm. 51. in the
title. Or, that go into her house to converse familiarly with him. Or, that go
into an untimely death by wantonness. Or, figuratively, that fall into her
sinful ways, and so are spiritually dead. She that lives in pleasure is dead
while she lives, 1 Timothy 5.6. That interpretation of few returners from
adultery, is best, because he had spoken before of the sinful and deadly
courses used in her house, v. 18. And now he intimates that her snares are like
lime-twigs, they hold fast all that converse with her in her house, and so
fast, that very few or none think of returning. So that this verse. is an
explication men, because they are so bewitched with the unlawful pleasure ^ of
her house, that they scarce ever think of leaving those finful ways while they
live. For the word Go, see on chapter 1.26. on the word Comes.

Return again. Some understand it of returning to prosperity. Gods judgment
follows them for the most part, and wastes them, and their estate, to the
consumption of both. But it is rather meant of returning by repentance, leaving
those sinful paths of death to walk in the good ways of life, as follows in
this v. For the word, see on chapter 1.23. on the word, Turn.

Neither take they hold of; or, touch. They come not near them, or at least
will not cleave inseparably to them.

The paths. See on chapter 1.19. on the word Ways of life. That lead to life. To a
prosperous life here, or an happy one in heaven. This v. answers an objection
that might have been made against the precedent verse. Some may say Adultery is
not so deadly a sin, as you would make it. You threaten death, but we will
repent before we go out of the world, and so help all. This is a common
objection. But who does so, says the Wiseman? Ye shall find very few or none
that repent, if ye observe their courses, for commonly Adulterers go on
impenitently till death.

Figures. None. That is, very few. Hyperbole.

Take hold. A metaphor from such as lay fast hold on a thing to keep it, for
men lay not hold on ways with their hands, but walk in them with their feet.
It argues seriousness, and constancy.

Paths. A metaphor from travelers.

Of life. A metony my of the effect or adjunct, that bring life or are signs
of it. with a Synecdoche of the general for the special. Life for eternal
life.

Note 1. Their not returning.

2. Their inconstancy, if they begin to look back, they fall into a relapse.

In the former note, 1. Their easy entrance, None that go in unto her. 2.
Their hard returning, return again.


In the second part observe, 1. The act, Neither take they hold. 2. The object,
of the paths of life.


1. Doct It is an hard thing for an Adulterer to repent. The prodigal son
leaves not his harlots, till all be spent, nor returns to his Father, till
swines meat be denied him. Luke 15. Sampson and Solomon very hardly returned,
if ever.

Reason 1. Because of the flattering tongues of strumpets, who have fine words
at command to keep young men with them. The harlot has such arts, and arms to
hold them in, that her prisoners seldom break prison. They are so bewitched
with the flatteries, and Sirens songs of Adulteresses, that they cannot see
their own filthiness: or if in part they do see it, yet the harlots flattering
charms are so strong, that they cannot leave them, as many have confessed, The
harlots heart is snares, and nets, and her hands as hands. Eccl. 7.26. An where
is a deep ditch, and a strange woman is a narrow pit. Chapter 23.27. It is as hard
then for the Adulterer to get out, as for a man fallen into a narrow deep pit,
out of which it is as difficult a thing to come up, as for a dead man to come
out of the grave. So says Chrysostom, It is as hard a thing to convert an
whoremaster, as it is to raise one out of the grave, that is dead and buried.

2. Because of those carnal delights wanton houses afford, as dainty fare,
pleasing music, lascivious pictures, decked chambers, etc. Such baits as they
that have tasted of them, by reason of their corrupted nature, stick so fast to
her, that they know not how to leave her. They so glut themselves with the
thoughts of their unlawful pleasures, that no reproves can sink into their
heads. They are like unto the deaf Adder, that stops her ear, which will not
hearken to the voice of charmers charming never so wisely Psalm. 58.4, 5.

3. Because of man's natural unsatiablenesse in finne, which drives him from
one degree of wickedness to another.

4. Because they are become slaves of sin, boared, as it were, through the ear
to serve sin for ever. The Devil still stirs them up to to the remembrance of
their former sinful pleasures to lead them to further flavery.

Vt ferrum magnes, sic carnalem trahit Agnes.
As loadstone is by iron drawn,
So carnal men by strumpets taken.
5. Such are dead in sins and trespasses. The harlots house is a grave. It is
an hard thing to come out from thence. The resurrection of the dead is a
miracle. So is it for a man entangled to get out of an harlots house.

6. Because Gods curse follows such men, women and courses.

Use. Take heed then of Adultery, and lewd houses. The strumpets house is like
the Lions den.

Onmia te adversum spectantia, nulla retrorsum.
We see all footsteps forward go
To thee ward, none returning fro.
Amor celerem habet ingressum, tardum regressum. Love (or rather, lust) has a
quick entrance; but a slow return. Theophrastus. Thou will be so bewitched,
that when thou art old, and past acting such sins, thou will delight thy self
with thinking and speaking of such things as thou haft done, and so die in thy
fins without Repentance in a contemplative Adultery, which is a kind of acting
over their former fins. Thou will have thy sins still sticking in thy bones,
and they will be like a wood burnt down, the smoke and stink whereof still
remains. This sin makes men sottish like brute beasts, Whoredom, and wine, and
new wine take away the heart, Hos. 4.11. Who so commits Adultery with a
woman, lacks understanding, Chapter 6.32. Seeing then there is so great peril in
Adultery, and so much difficulty in returning, it is safest to keep out at
first. Who would go that way out of which scarce ever any man returned?

2. Doct. Few return from adulterous courses. Most go on till a dart strike
through their liver, Chapter 7.23. It may be one man of a thousand may return,
Eccles. 7.28.

Reason Because of the hardness of returning proved in the former doctrine.
Few men adventure on hard things, as to travel to remote parts, to be
excellent in Arts and Sciences.

Use 1. If any have entered into this course, let them think of a speedy return.
The further men travel in dirty ways, the worse to go back. Burning and mad
lusts will in time so blind thy heart, that without great and rare grace, thou
can not repent. Better then to be of the number of the few, that repent; then
of the many, that perish.

2. Let such as have returned from Adulterous courses, heartily bless God for
his especial grace and favor in reducing them. Thou could not return of thy
self, but by Gods helping and restoring grace, so great was the weight of thine
in quity to keep thee under in impenitency. Attribute not therefore the praise
of thy return to thy self, but to Gods grace. Only see that thy repentance be
true. For many will profess repentance when they think they shall die, that
prove as bad as ever when they recover. Such repentance is far from a true
repentance.

3. Doct. The destruction of Adulterers without repentance is certain.
Whoremongers must have their part in the lake which burns with fire and
brimstone. Rev. 21.8.

Reason 1. Because all sin is mortal, and without the cure of repentance will
bring men to hell.

2. Because God will be avenged for the abuse of his image, and Temple by
wantonness, unless men submit and reform.

Use. Here is a cooling card for wantons. They look at their presant pleasure,
not at their future pain. Fools look at things present in the way: wisemen
foresee things future in the end. A green way to a robbing place, a calm
passage to a rock, or quick sand is perilous. A riotous person wallowes in
pleasure, and dies in a prison. Let Adulterers think of their end, and they
will have little pleasure in their sin.

4. Doct. The destruction of impenitent adulterers is general as well as
certain. Wheremongers and Adulterers God will judge, Heb. 13.4. That may he
said to them, that is said to impenitent sinners, Except ye repent, ye shall
all likewise perish, Luke 13.3, 5.

Raason. Because the destruction of such is certain, as was proved in the
former point. And then it must needs be general. If it be certain, that man
must die, then all men must die, except God extraordinarily dispense with some.
But this he never did to any impenitent sinner. If it be true, that man has a
reasonable soul, then every man has so, though fools and mad men make little
use of it. So if it be certain, that impenitent adulterers perish, then it is
general, and all such must perish.

Use. Let no man stand upon privileges of birth, wit, wealth. If he be an
impenitent Adulterer he must die. Let no man presume upon repentance. He may be
killed in the act, as Zimri and Cosbi were, Numb. 25.

5. Doct. No hope of comfort from God here, or hereafter for wanton persons
till they repent. Not here, They were as fed horses in the morning: every one
neighed after his Neighbors wife. Shall I not visit for these things? says
the Lord, and shall not my soul be avenged on such a Nation as this? Jer.
5.8.9. Not hereafter, 1 Cor. 6.9, 10. Fornicatours and Adulterers shall not
inherit the Kingdom of God. And God accounts them such till they repent of
their filthiness.

Reason. Because they live in a way of rebellion against God; and by
consequence make themselves Gods, following their own will in all things.

Use. Let Adulterers give over their trade. Who will follow a course of life,
that he were sure to have no comfort of in life or death?

6. Doct. There are cross ways in the world, paths of life and paths of
death. Crosse-wayes and gates Wide is the gate, and broad is the way that
leads to destruction. But strait is the gate, and narrow is the way which
leads unto life, Mat. 7.13, 14. There is a way of sinners, and a law of the
Lord, Psol. 1.1, 2. Some walk in the one, and some in the other.

Reason. Because the ends are fully opposite. Eternal weal, eternal woe.
These shall go away into everlasting punishment: but the righteous into life
eternal, Mat. 25.40. And sure the same ways cannot lead to so different ends.
They are not suitable to them.

Use. Let secure persons take heed. They think all shall go to heaven, none to
hell. But they are deceived; most go to hell. The strait way is hardly found,
and by few: the broad way easily, and by many. Mat. 7.13, 14.

Verse. 20. That thou may walk in the ways of good men, and keep the paths
of the righteous.
So much for the deliverance: Now for the general application of all for the
good that will come to those that avoid the society of evil men and women.
Which is,

1. Set out in this verse to be a preservation in such ways.

2. Illustrated, 1. By the benefit of such ways, verse. 21. 2. By the miseries
that contrary ways bring, v. 22.


For the first in this verse. This is the last part of the Chapter, wherein
Solomon having before exhorted the young man to the study of wisdom, now
shows the last benefit of it. The end of our study of wisdom should be to
walk in good ways. The benefit of all spoken before is here summed up
together. So that this verse depends upon v. 11, 12, 16. in this manner wisdom
will deliver thee from all evil ways, words, men, and women, that thou may
more freely converse with good men in good ways, whereby much good may be
learned.

For the words.

That. It teaches us, that Solomon's end in teaching men how to get Wisdom to
avoid all the former inconveniences, was not that they should be idle, but that
they should go on in good ways without interruption or encumbrances. So the
word is used, Josh. 4.24. That all the people of the earth might know the hand
of the Lord, that it is mighty: that ye might fear the Lord your God for ever.

That thou may walk. See on chapter 1.15.

In the way. See on chapter 1.15.

Of good men. That thou may follow the godly, and virtuous examples of
Patriarchs, and Prophets, and others that fear God and walk in his ways.

But, Where shall we find these good men? Our blessed Savior tells us, There
is none good but one, that is God, Mat. 19.17.

We answer, God'y men though they be not perfectly good, but have many
imperfections, yet being sincere are good in Gods account. For men are counted
good or bad in Scripture language, not according to some particular act, but
according to their constant course and scope.

And keep. See on v. 8.

The paths. See on chapter 1.19. on the word ways.

Of the righteous; or, Of the just. The word is taken,

1. For one perfectly just, that is not guilty of any sin before God. How
should man be just with God? Job 9.2. God has made man upright, Eccl. 7.29.

2. For one just or righteous in his own opinion, or the opinion of other men.
He that is first in his own cause seems just, chapter 18.17.

3. For one truly just, though not perfectly, who intends in all things to deal
justly and righteously with God and man. And this is the common acception of
the word in Scripture, for there are none perfectly just upon earth. So Neah
was a just man, Genesis 6.9.

4. For one just in some particular cause. They turn aside the just for a thing
of naught. Isa. 29.21. She has been more righteous then I, Genesis 38.26. Here it
is taken in the third sense, for one truly just and righteous, though not
perfectly.

Figures. Walk, ways, paths, Metaphors from travelers.

Keep. A metaphor from Watchmen, arguing care and constancy in walking in Gods
ways. For men do not use to stand still to look upon ways, but to go on in
them. Therefore the same thing is set down in two different expressions of
walking in, and keeping Gods ways.

In the former note, 1. The act, That thou may walk. 2. The object, in the
way. 3. The subject, of good men.


In the latter observe likewise, 1. The act, and keep. 2. The object, the
paths. 3. The subject, of the righteous.


1. Doct. Men cannot walk in good ways, unless they leave bad. It is as hard
for men accustomed to do evil, to do good, as for an Ethiopian to change his
^kin, or a Leopard his spots, Jer. 13.23. No man can serve two Masters. Ye
cannot serve God, and Mamnon. Mat. 6.24.

Reason 1. In general. Because good and evil being contraries the one will
keep out the other. So cold keeps out heat, and heat keeps out cold till it be
overcome. Foul water in a bottle keeps out good wine, till it be poured out.

2. In particular. Evil thoughts keep out all thoughts of doing good. The mind
like the Smith can hammer but one iron at once.

3. Evil words draw from good actions, and corrupt good manners, 1 Cor. 15.33.

4. Evil deeds, and practices keep from good courses. They give a double
impediment,

1. By satisfying corrupt nature they steal away the affection from all good.

2. By employing it in evil they leave no time for good, for men by nature
never have pleasure enough in fin.

Use. 1. For discovery. It shows us a reason, why many are strangers to all
good ways, because they are verst in evil, and cannot leave it. Can an
husbandman look for a crop if he plow not up thorns and thistles? Can a
Gardener look for good herbs, if he weed not his Garden? Will not Ivy, if it
be let grow, overtop and kill trees? No marvel then, if evil doers follow not
that which is good.

2. For direction. Let us by leaving evil ways seriously show, that we intend
to do good. When one pulls down an old house, men think he means to build a new,
not else, though he talk often of it. Who will believe, that a man means to
live soberly, or chastely, that daily haunts Taverns, and wanton places?
Pythagoras his letter Y showed, that men going alike in their childhood,
afterward, if they followed evil, forsook good; (...). Ceasing from evil is
the beginning of motion to virtue, Chrysostom. (...). Alienation from evil is an
appropinquation to good, Chrysostom.

2. Doct. It is not enough to avoid evil, but we must also do good. Cease to
do evil, learn to do well. Isa. 1.16, 17. Depart from evil, and do good.
Psalm. 34.14.

Reason 1. Because forsaking evil is but a foundation for a greater building,
and no man can dwell in a foundation.

2. Justice in all Commonwealths requires as many good offices, as doing no
harm. So also in Gods Church.

3. God gives us wisdom as to direct us how to avoid evil, so to do good: and
that is the principal office of wisdom; else none should be the better for it.

4. The reward for avoiding evil is but privative, escaping misery: but the
reward of doing good is positive, eternal happiness. A beast, nay a stone
goes not to hell.

Use. Here is a lesson of spiritual ambition to teach us not to be content
only to leave sin, but to be in love with good ways. Not to be not miserable,
and avoid hell, but to lay up for our selves treasures in heaven, Mat. 6.20.

3. Doct. One chief and principal end of wisdom is weldoing. Keep therefore,
and do them, for this is your wisdom, Deuteronomy. 4.6. These Commandments the Lord
commanded to teach you, that ye might do them. Deuteronomy. 6.1.

Reason 1. Because else no blessing attends upon our knowledge, no more then
upon a man that knows what is good to preserve his life, and by neglect
thereof dies. So do knowing, and not doing men lose heaven. If ye know these
things, happy are ye if ye do them, Joh. 13.17. Not else.

2. Because a curse follows upon knowledge without practice. Cursed is he that
confirms not all the words of this Law to do them, Deuteronomy. 27.26. That servant
which knew his Lords will, and prepared not himself, neither did according to
his will, shall be heaten with many stripes, Luke 12.47.

Use 1. To blame those, that use their knowledge to do evil, they can never
get good by it, but the more harm. They only know how to undo their souls.
So the Adulterer has wit to b^naught, which others want. (...). Apollodorus.
And let the door be shut with bars. But no workman can make the door so
strong, that a cat, or an Adulterer cannot enter. So the Adulterer takes
advantage of day and night. In the dark they dig through houses, which they
had marked for themselves in the day time, Job 24.16.

2. To exhort us to make the best advantage of our knowledge for well doing.
Then we hit the mark, otherwise we miss it. This is the conclusion of this
Chapter, and shows the end of the former Precepts of avoiding hurt by bad men,
and women, that we might do good. Artium omnium finis est been viverdi
disciplina, quam vita magis quam literis nobiles sunt secuti. The end of all
arts is the discipline of living well, which noble personages have followed
more in life, then in learning. Tusc. qu. l. 4. Optimus quisque maluit facere,
quam dicere. Every excellent man had rather be doing, then talking, Salust. At
Athens a grave man coming into the Theater, no man rose to give him place,
though they knew, they ought to have done it by the City law. The Lacedemonian
Ambassadors being there, the old man coming toward them, they rise, and give
him the chief place. At which the people gave a great shout, and one of the
Lacedaemonians to their shame spoke thus, Ergo Athenienses, quid sit rectum
sciunt: at illud facere ex toto negligunt. Belike then the Athenians know, what
is right: and yet altogether neglect to do it, Valor. l. 10. c. 5.

4. Doct. Wisdom not only shows a man how to avoid evil, but also how to do
good. If thou incline thine ear unto wisdom, then shall thou understand
righteousness, and judgment, and equity, yea, every good path, Chapter 2.29. I
have set before you life and death, blessing and cursing; therefore choose life,
that both thou, and thy seed may live, That thou may love the Lord thy God,
and that thou may obey his voice, etc. Deuteronomy. 30.19.20.

Reason 1. Because it perfectly shows us the difference between good and
evil, that we may not mistake the one for the other. So cannot natural
principles, civil education, nor moral Philosophy.

2. It shows us the means of escaping the one, and pursuing the other, what
occasions are to be avoided, or taken, what help to do both is to be had from
Gods word and Spirit.

Use. Let us labor to get this true wisdom. Men give much money with their
children, and children serve many years to learn a Trade to avoid poverty, and
get wealth. We then should spare for no cost nor labor to get true wisdom to
direct us to fly all evil, and do all good.

5. Doct. It is safer to imitate good men, then bad. Looking unto Jesus the
author, and finisher of our faith, who for the joy that was set before him,
endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of
the throne of God, Heb. 12.2. Follow the faith of your teachers, considering
the end of their conversation, Heb. 13.7.

Reason 1. Because the way of good men, is better then the way of bad men. A
fair way of piety excels a dirty way of licentiousness.

2. Their end is better. Heaven is far better then hell. Remember, There is no
condemnation to them that are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh,
but after the spirit, Romans 8.1.

Use 1. To condemn those that follow the worst persons, where they live. If
but one drunkard, or strumpet in a parish, others will follow them, not
regarding such as live better, whose conversation is in heaven. Phil. 3.20.

2. Show that ye have the same spirit by following godly men, and walking in
their ways, that so ye may come to the same blessed end the salvation of your
souls. And why should thou not rather follow the example of Abraham, Job,
Joseph, David, then of Ishmael, Esau, and other profane persons? Sheep will not
follow wolves, but they will follow one another. So do thou follow good men to
heaven, rather then bad men to hell.

6. Doct. Good example sometimes prevails to draw others to piety. The people
served the Lord all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the Elders that
outlived Joshua, Judge. 2.7.

Reason 1. Because shame is taken away by good examples going before.

2. Fear is taken away. If a man see another go over a frozen river, he dares
go over the ice.

Use. Set the best examples before you to imitate. Prudentis viri est magna
mensurase metiri, atque ad excellentium virorum imitationem se componere.
Nazianzen Epist. ad Nicobul. It is the part of a wiseman to measure himself by
a great measure, and to compose himself to the imitation of excellent men.
Ignari locorum cum solertibus viarum iter adoriri gestiunt. Ambros. Offic. l.
4. c. 47. They that know not the places desire to travel with such as are
skillful in the ways. Columbam avolantem sequuntur omnes, equum generosum totum
armentum, ovem totus grex. Chrysoft. de continent. Josephi. All the doves
follow one, that flies away, all the drove follows a generous horse, all the
flock follows one sheep. So should we follow the choicest examples for
goodness.

Verse. 21. For the upright shall dwell in the land: and the perfect shall
remain in it.
The Chapter is concluded with the reward of good and bad men. In this verse is
set out a gracious promise to encourage men to walk in upright ways. In the
next a threatening to discourage them from bad ways.

For the first.

Here is a motive to follow the righteous, and not the wicked, by an argument
taken from that which men naturally most desire, long life upon earth, together
with an establishment in our possessions, and not through Gods judgments to be
wasted, and decay in our estates, and so come to poverty, or to die
ignominiously, and not to live out half our days. Withal he shows that we are
not good and righteous, except we walk uprightly and sincerely.

For the words.

For. See on chapter 1.9.

The upright. See on v. 7.

Shall dwell in the Land. Solomon speaks after the custom of the Old
Testament, wherein God purposing not so fully to reveal spiritual and heavenly
things and blessings to his people, as now, did secretly shadow them under
earthly comforts, and encourage his people to obedience by such promises. As in
the fist Commandment long life is promised to those that honor parents. So
many temporal blessings are promised to such as obey Gods Law, Deuteronomy. 11. and
28. By dwelling in the land, is meant long life, and health, and strength, and
plenty of all good things in that Land of Canaan that flowed with milk and
honey. It is not bare dwelling there that is promised, but accompanied with all
things fit, commodious, comfortable and profitable. This is that safe dwelling,
promised chapter 1.33. And this God performed to the Jews, while they worshipped
him aright; and when they fell to. Idolatry, he sent them captives to Babylon.
So that this v. shows who shall be kept from evil; to wit, just and upright
men. Yet some enlarge this promise to fignifie grace here, and glory in heaven,
shadowed under the type of the Land of Canaan. Others take it more largely then
for that Land, intimating, that ordinarily in any parts of the earth, where
godly men live, God usually blesses them, unless he please to correct his
people for their fins, or to try their graces, or to call them out to bear
witness to his truth. If it be objected, that godly men suffer hardship and
hunger here; it may be answered, that in that estate they enjoy great
tranquillity, content, and felicity, as seeing God in all, and depending upon
him for help. It is well with them for the present, and it will be better
hereafter. Heaven will make amends for all. If it be further objected, that
good men sometimes live less while on earth then others; it may be said, that
God makes them abundant amends in heaven, in the land of the living. If it be
further urged, that this is no encouragement to godliness, because wicked men
have as much, and oftentimes more in the earth, then godly men have; I answer,
that these may have more comfort in what they have, as having not only a
civil title, but a spiritual one also, and so shall never be indicted as
usurpers at the day of judgment.

(...), The land, or earth. Which laft word may well come from it, the letters
are so like. It signifies,

1. That part of the world, which is opposed to heaven, containing Sea and
Land, wherein men dwell, and beasts and fishes lodge. The earth is given into
the hand of the wicked, Job 9.24. The earth is the Lords, and the fullness
thereof, the world, and they that dwell therein, Psalm. 24.1.

2. The dry part of the world, opposed to sea and rivers. The earth is full of
thy riches, so is this great Sea, Psalm. 104.24, 25.

3. Some particular Land or Country. In the Land of Vz, Job 1.1.

4. For the inhabitants of the earth, or of some Land or Country in it. The
earth also was corrupt before God, and the earth also was filled with violence,
Genesis 6.11. For the transgression of a Land many are the Princes thereof, Prove.
28.2.

Here it is taken in the third sense, for the dry land, or more particularly
for the Land of Canaan, wherein Solomon dwelt, and of which he spoke; the
plenty and comfort whereof they well knew to whom he spoke, and might be much
encouraged thereby to obedience.

The perfect. See on chapter 1.12. on the word whole. Hereby is meant such as are
perfect in heart, and sincere; and also perfect in parts having all needful
graces in them, as a child has all members, that a man has, though not so
large. For as for perfection of degrees, none on earth has attained to it.
Shall remain in it. They shall not only find an abiding place there, but also
when adulterers, and other wicked livers shall waste their estates, and shotten
their days by their sinful courses, and so be gone out of the land by death
or exile, they shall live quietly and prosperously in it. An opposition to v.
18. and 22.

Figures none.

Note. 1. A comfortable dwelling promised to the righteous.

2. A constant abiding, even when others are cut off.

In the former note, 1. The word of coherence, For. 2. The persons, the
upright. 3. The act, shall dwell. 4. The object, in the Land.


In the latter observe, 1. The persons, And the perfect. 2. The act, shall
remain. 3. The object, in it.


1. Doct. The Scripture gives many encouragements to men to walk in good ways.
As,

1. Precepts. All the ten Commandments, the most exact rule of a godly life,
that ever was.

2. Exhortations. I beseech you therefore Brethren, by the mercies of God, Romans
12.1. Who would not be persuaded, when God himself exhorts by his Ministers,
that might command?

3. Examples of the excellentest men that ever lived on the face of the earth.
See store of them recorded and commended, who lived before Christ's incarnation,
Heb. 11. Apostles afterward. Yea, Christ himself the example of examples. Be
ye followers of me, as I also am of Christ, 1 Cor. 11.1.

4. Rich promises. If ye be willing and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the
Land, Isa. 1.19. Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth, Mar.
5.5.

4. The Gospel, which shows us a second and greater ground of of godly life,
then the Law or Creation did. The grace of God, that brings salvatien has
appeared to all men, teaching us, that denying ungodliness, etc. Titus 2.11,
12.

6. It sets out the help of the Spirit. Some walk after the Spirit, and are led
by the Spirit, Rom 8.1, 14. Without this help we might utterly despair of
walking in good ways. We could no more do it, then a man could choose, or walk
in a fair way in the world, that had not a soul or spirit in him to direct him.

7. Gods acceptance is there set out. Our best actions are sinful. God likes
not such. And if they may not be accepted, who would lose his labor to do
them? Cornelius his prayers and almsdeeds, were come up for a memorial
before God, Act. 10.4.

8. Gods commendation. This is more then acceptance. When a Father proclaims
to others what a good Son he has, it shows abundance of love in him, and
encourages the child to please him. So God does animate us, I know thy works,
Rev. 2.2, 9, 13, 19.

9. Gods preservation of us in good ways, when our hearts are set upon them,
and we are ignorantly in danger. So he kept Abimelech from touching Sarah, Genesis
20.6.

Use. It should encourage Christians to be more careful of their ways then
all the world besides. We should be brighter then others, as the stars are
brighter then the firmament. Heathen have few encouragements in comparison of
us. Turks have not much more. Jews want the New Testament. Papists may not read
the Scriptures. We have all encouragements to good ways. Let us therefore say
with the Psalmist, I will run the way of thy commandments, when thou shall
enlarge my heart, Psalm. 119.32.

6. Doct. When wicked men are cut off, God sometimes spares the good. The truth
will appear, if you compare this v. with the next. And also in Noah's
deliverance from the Flood, and Lot's in Sodom. When the wicked are cut off,
thou shall see it, Psalm. 37.34.

Reason 1. To show Gods special care and providence over them. Joseph's
parti-colored coat, and Benjamin's large mess, were signs of special love.

2. To draw men to piety. We are in part carnal. Abraham has Canaan and a
numerous posterity promised him, to encourage him in piety.

Use 1. If we be preserved when others perish, let us acknowledge Gods favor
to be the cause of it. We had sins as well as they, and deserved to be cut off
as well as they.

2. Let us be encouraged to piety. If there be any way in the world to escape
judgments, this is it. Landlords do not use to turn their tenants out of
doors, while they keep covenants. Good men are said to inherit the earth, bad
men only to possess it.

3. Doct. Uprightness is expected of those that expect Gods blessing. Mark the
perfect man, and behold the upright, for the end of that man is peace, Psalm.
37.37. Light is sown for the righteous, and joy for the upright in heart, Psalm.
97.11.

Reason 1. Because God hates hypocrifie. It is most contrary to the God of
truth.

2. He hates evil ends.

3. He hates self ends in men, who should all serve his ends.

4. He hates by-ends, when men aim at any thing that tends not to his glory.

Use. Try if ye be sincere. Else your hopes are like spiders webs, Job 8.13,
14. Try it by these notes. An upright man is he,

1. To whom nothing is displeasing that God has done.

2. To whom God is pleasing in all the good the man himself does.

3. To whom God is not displeasing in any evil, that he suffers.

4. That does not resist God his Father, when he goes about to mend him.

5. That baleeves God his Father in all he promises.

6. That lays all his sins upon himself.

7. He that attributes all his good deeds to God.

8. He that directs his will by Gods will, as the Clock is ordered by the
Sun-dial.

9. He that does all good from the heart.

4. Doct. Perfection is expected of them that look for Gods blessing. Be ye
therefore perfect, even as your Father, which is in heaven is perfect, Mat.
5.48. I will behave my self wisely in a perfect way, O when will thou come unso
me? I will walk within my house with a perfect heart, Psalm. 101.2.

Reason. Because all perfections are required of such as expect happiness. As,

1. Perfection of sincerity. This was proved in the former point. A fincere man
is a perfect man. An hypocrite is but a picture of a man.

2. Perfection of parts. Every saving grace must be had and used. So a child
is a perfect man. A defective monster is not.

3. Perfection of integrity. When our obedience is universal to all Gods
commandments.

4. Perfection of degrees. That is required intentionally, and shall be given
us actually, before we come to heaven. So a child is not a perfect man, till
he come to his full growth.

Use. Be like good trees, sound within and without, in root, body, branches,
and grow higher toward heaven still. Else look for no blessing from God.

5. Doct. God often gives good men a comfortable and quiet continuance in their
habitations. As to David, after his troubles from Saul and Absolon. To Solomon,
for a long time.

Reason 1. That they may have the more time to serve God, and do good. A
breathing time, that the Churchet having rest, may be^ed fied, and walking in
the fear of the Lord, and in the comfort of the holy Ghost, may be multiplied,
Act. 9.31.

2. That they may have the more encouragement to do it. Men's spirits are down
in trouble, and have enough to do to suffer patiently. They are freer for
action in quietness. Where God looks for suffering, he puts not to action.

Use. Bless God for the quietness and comfort we have had in this City in all
these dangerous times, both for soul and body. Other parts, both beyond Sea,
and in this Land, have not been dealt so bountifully withal. He shows his
word unto Jacob, his statutes and his judgments unto Israel. He has not dealt
so with any Nation; and as for his judgments, they have not known them. Praise
ye the Lord, Psalm. 147.19, 20. We have also had so much agreement between godly
men of different judgments, as is scarce any where else to be found. Let God
have the praise, as we have the comfort.

6. Doct. God many times makes good men thrive upon earth. As Abraham, Isaac,
Jacob.

Reason 1. That it may appear that God does not grudge earth to those to whom
he will give heaven. He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for
us all, how shall he not with him also freely give us all things? Romans 8.32.
Seek ye first the Kingdom of God, and his righteousness, and all these things
shall be added unto you, Mat. 6.33.

2. That they may have the more means to glorify God, having the larger
talents.

Use. If God give any good man wealth and prosperity, let him use it well, that
he may give a good account of it. He is but a factor. He must honor his Master,
if he will enrich himself. This Gods bounty requires, and he that does so, may
look for comfort from God.

Verse. 22. But the wicked shall be cut off from the earth, and the
transgressors shall be rooted out of it.
If fair means will not serve, foul must be used. The Wiseman having given a
promise to allure, now concludes with a threatening, to drive such as will not
be drawn. The Writer proceeds in a right method; and having spoken many things
of the differing ways of godly and wicked men, now he concludes with their
different ends. So he does, chapter 1. only he puts the end of wicked men first.
The turning away of the simple shall slay them, and the prosperity of fools
shall destroy them. But who so hearkeneth unto me, shall dwell safely, and
shall be quiet from fear of evil, chapter 1.32, 33.

For the words.

(...), But, Heb. And. It is used sometimes as a figne of connection.
Righteousness, and judgment, and equity, verse. 9. Sometimes as a sign of
opposition. But ye have set at naught all my counsel, chapter 1.25. Sometimes of
assimilation. As a man pleads for his neighbor, Job 16.21. Sometimes of
augmentation. I am their song; yea, I am their by word, Job 30.9. A proverb or
byword is more, and goes further then a song.

Here it is taken by way of opposition. Good men shall flourish, and bad men
perish in the end.

The wicked. Restless and unquiet people. Such as are always doing mischief.
The Heb. word (...), comes from a word that fignifies motion, or unquietness.
Who then can make trouble? Job 34.29. The wicked are like the troubled Sea,
Isa. 57.20. Ahab, and such like wicked men, accuse Gods people for troublers of
Israel, 1 King. 18.17. and of the City, Act. 16.20. and of all the world, Act.
17.6. But they may answer with Elijah, that wicked men are indeed the troublers
of themselves, and of the world, 1 King. 18.18.

Shall be cut off. As a bough from a tree, so that it shall grow no more.
Adulterers, and such like evil doers shall be destroyed. It signifies an
untimely death, as a bough cut off before it withers. They shall be taken away
in the midst of their prosperity, and that suddenly.

From the earth. Not only out of that Land, but out of all the world. For the
word see on, v. 21. on the word Land.

And the transgressors. The word signifies treacherous dealers. They have dealt
treacherously with thee, Jer. 12.6. So it is also translated, Isa. 21.2. and
24.16. For transgressors, that go beyond the bounds that God has set them,
deal treacherously with God, to whom they owe all subjection.

Shall be rooted of it. If cutting them off will not serve to terrify others,
God will root them out, or pluck them quite out of the earth, and destroy their
posterity also.

Figures. A Metaphor from a Tree, in the words cutting off, and rooting out. If
a wild tree, and offensive grow in a garden, and the Gardner cut off the top
of it, if it send forth new sprouts, as bad as the former, he digs up the root
it self. So does God deal with wicked men. He takes them away; and if their
posterity follow their courses, he proceeds to root out the whole name and
family. Cut off, Rooted out, Metaphors from Trees.

Note 1. Gods judgment on wicked men. 2. On their memory and posterity.


In the former observe, 1. The word of opposition, But. 2. The subject, the
wicked. 3. The adjunct, shall be cut off. 4. The object, from the earth.


In the latter note, 1. The subject, And the transgressors. 2. The adjunct
shall be rooled out of it.


1. Doct. God will sometimes in this world, put a difference between good men
and bad. Then shall ye discern between righteous and the wicked, Mal. 3.18. So
God made a difference between the Israelites and the Egyptians, in the
darkness, and death of the firstborn, and at the Red sea, Exodus 10. and 12.
and 14. So did he distinguish between the Israelites and Canaanites in rooting
out the one out of the Land, and planting the other in it, Josh. 10, etc. So he
put a difference between Micaiah and Zedekiah, when the one durst show his
face, and the other hid his, 1 King. 22.24, 25. Between Jeremiah and Pashur,
when one was a comfort to himself and his friends, and the other a terror to
both, Jer. 20.4. Between Ahaz and Hezekiah; the one made a prey to the enemy,
the other delivered from Senacharib, 2 Chronicles. 28.5. and 32.21.

Reason 1. That men may see that there is a God. While they see no difference
between good and bad men, they think there is no overruling God. The Heathen
man confesses it. Solicitor nullos esse putare Deos: I am solicited to think
there is no God. Ovid. In a Commonwealth, or in an Army, where no difference
is made between good and bad people and soldiers, men think there is no
Magistrate or General there. So in the Church. But when God puts a difference,
they cry out, Verily he is a God that judges in the earth, Psalm. 58.11.

2. That men might see by this fore-running providence, a pattern and proof of
the general judgment to come.

Use. When God shall do so with us, let us acknowledge Gods mercy to us. He
might destroy us like wicked men. Are there not with you, even with you, sins
against the Lord your God? 2 Chr. 28.10. See Gods distinguishing mercy in it,
and proclaim it.

2. Doct. Wicked men are restless in evil. The wicked are like the troubled
sea, when it cannot rest, whose waters cast up mire and dirt, Isa. 57.^0. He
devises mischief upon his bed, he sets himself in a way that is not good,
he abhors not evil, Psalm. 36.4.

Reason 1. Because they have a body of sin in them, which has many active
members upon earth, fornication, uncleanness, etc. Col. 3.5. A fountain will
run, and fire will burn.

2. They have objects of sin in the world in abundance, in all places, to feed
their eyes, ears, and all their senses. A fountain will run, if it find a
river. Fire will burn, if it meet with fuel.

3. God has not healed wicked men by his sanctifying Spirit: Bad humors will
work in men's bodies, till they be purged away. And the more purged away, the
less they work.

4. God is pleased sometimes not to restrain wicked men, but to let them run on
to their own perdition, and the hurt of many others. So an unruly horse with
the bridle out of his mouth runs furiously, till he overthrow himself, and his
rider.

Use 1. Marvel not, that men are never weary of sinning. The drunkard is never
weary of the Alehouse. The adulterer of places of wantonness. Is it marvel
that birds fly, or fishes swim? why else have they wings or fins?

2. Let us be provoked to be restless in good. Else wicked men the children of
this generation restless in their ways to give themselves content, are wiser
then we, that profess our selves to be the children of light, Luke 16.8. And
the Queen of Sheba, who came so far to hear Solomon's wisdom, will condemn us
at the day of judgment, Matt. 12.42.

3. Doct. Wicked men lives are often cut short by their wicked courses. Bloody
and deceitful men shall not live out half their days, Psalm. 55.23.

Reason 1. Drunkenness breeds dropsies, gluttony breeds fevers, wantonness
foul diseases, all murderers, and shorten men's lives, as the flood drowned many
young men in the world. When the strength of the body is worn by drinking and
whoring, men must die. All the Physicians in the world cannot put in new marrow
into dead bones.

2. Trouble of conscience sometimes ends their days. Sin of betraying his
Master made Judas hang himself. Spira would have killed himself, and did waste
his body to death for his Apostasy. Some in our times have ended their days
in pangs of conscience for sin.

3. By Gods just judgments, who like a Gardener pulls up weeds, roots out
unfruitful trees, and like a wind blows out the candle; or like a storm,
lodges the corn before it be ripe.

4. By enemies, and those often of their own stamp. One drunkard kills another
in his drink, even his nearest friend, as Alexander murdered Clitus. One
adulterer kills another, because the strumpet loves him better.

Use 1. Gaze not too much at the prosperity of sinners, lest thou be tempted to
do like them. The common people are like boys, who when they see knaves upon
the stage, gorgeously apparelled, and acting Kings, think them happy, and could
wish to be like them; but they consider not the poverty and misery that may
befall them, when they are stripped of their gay clothes. So the common people
are bewitched with the riches of sinners, not confidering they may die, or lose
all before their age.

2. Grudge not at their prosperity. They may die sooner then meaner men. Every
plant (says our blessed Savior) which my heavenly Father has not planted,
shall be rooted up, Mat. 15.13. Who would be a flourishing tree, to be rooted
out? or an ox fatted, to be killed? A brutish man knows not, neither does a
fool understand this. When the wicked spring as the grass, and when all the
workers of iniquity do flourish; it is that they shall be destroyed for ever,
Psalm. 92.7. They shall be cut off certainly, suddenly, utterly. Tum fere
auferuntur a terra, cum maxim velint vivere. Then are they for the most part
taken away from the earth, when they are most desirous to live in it. Baine.
When they have feathered their nest, and reckon upon long life, as the fool in
the Gospel, Luke 12. God will destroy them, when they least look for it.
Therefore, Fret not thy self, because of evil doers, neither be thou envyous
against the workers of iniquity. For they shall soon be cut down like the
grass, and wither as the green herb, Psalm. 37.2.

4. Doct. Transgressors deal treacherously with God. The treacherous dealer
deals treacherously, Isa. 21.2. The treacherous dealers have dealt
treacherously; yea, the treacherous dealers have dealt very treacherously, Isa.
24.16. They are all adulterers, and an assembly of treacherous men, Jer. 9.2.

Reason 1. Because they fail in the trust committed to them, as a Servant or
Steward deceiving his Master is treacherous. So was he that had received one
talent, though he had not spent it, because he did not improve it. Thou wicked
and slothful servant, etc. Mat. 25.26.

2. Because they act against their trust, which is an higher degree of
treachery. As if a Servant or Steward should rise up against his Master, in
stead of obedience. So Judas is called the traitor, Luke 6.16.

3. Because they betray Gods honor, as much as in them lies. An Ambassador is
treacherous, that dishonors his Prince in stead of honoring him.

4. Because they labor to undo Gods Church. Is not a servant treacherous,
that should go about to poison all the family? So are wicked men, endeavoring
to ruin the Church by bad counsel and example.

Use. Let us hate all sinful courses. Treason is odious. Men that love the
Treason, hate the Traitor. God hates both it and them. Many fair promises are
made by men to Traitors, but an Halter or an Axe is their end. So Satan
promises much to sinners, but will bring them to hell.

5. Doct. Sin roots out the posterity of wicked men. He shall neither have Son
nor Nephew among his people, nor any remaining in his dwelling, Job 18.19. So
it did Jeroboam's. His posterity must lose the Kingdom, and his good Son must
die, 1 King. 13.34. and 14.10, etc. So Ahab's numerous posterity must die for
his Idolatry, 2 King. 10.7, etc.

Reason 1. Because sin goes by propagation; and no wonder then if the Serpents
brood be cut off. We kill young Snakes for the poison they have from the old
ones.

2. Sin goes by imitation. If children of godly parents will imitate other men
in evil, rather then their parents in good, no wonder if children of ungodly
parents be evil like their parents, and perish with them. We read not of one
good among all the Kings of the ten Tribes. All were idolatrous, like their
predecessors.

Use. Hate sinful courses, which God so much hates, that he will punish them
in children to the fourth generation; as in the second Commandment. And no
wonder if God hate finfull courses, as being contrary both to his nature and
will. Let us therefore show our love to God, in hating what he hates. Ye that
love the Lord, hate evil, Psalm. 97.10.

6. Doct. If men will not for their own sakes forsake sin, they should do it
for their childrens sake. God promises good to children, if their parents be
obedient. O that there were such an heart in them, that they would fear me, and
keep my commandments always, that it might be well with them, and with their
children for ever, Deuteronomy. 5.29. Therefore they must take heed they bring not
evil on their children by disobedience. Manasseh brings destruction on
Jerusalem after his death, though he repented in his life. Surely at the
commandment of the Lord came this upon Judah, to remove them out of his sight
for the sins of Manasseh, according to all that he did, 2 King. 24.3. And Ahab
brought Gods judgment on his posterity, though he humbled himself. See thou
how Ahab humbles himself before me? Because he humbles himself before me, I
will not bring the evil in his days, but in his Sons days will I bring the
evil upon his house, 1 King. 21.29.

Reason 1. Because much evil may come on our posterity for our sins; as
hereditary diseases, poverty, losses, crosses.

2. Our affection is great to our children. We prefer them before friends, and
many times before our selves. Why then should we do any thing to hurt them?

Use. It teaches us to bewail the madness of those parents, that are so fond
of their children, that they love the ground the better they tread on, and yet
live in those sins that shorten their childrens days, and lay them under
ground before their time by nature. They give them bad examples, and no
correction for their sins, and so are accessory to their ruin. Let us be
wiser, and give good example and correction to our children, and then may we
look to see much good of them. Which God grant to all godly parents, through
Jesus Christ our only Lord and Savior, Amen.

CHAP. III.
VER. 1. My Son, forget not my law, but let thine heart keep my commandments.
THe order of Solomon is to be observed; he had formerly exhorted the young man
to seek after Wisdom, and showed him what evils it would preserve him from;
now he gives him some directions how to practice what he should be taught, and
shows what good he should get by it: He had dissuaded him from cruelty in the
first Chapter, and from adultery in the second; now he persuades him to piety
and equity in this Chapter: and lest the keeping of so many precepts imposed
upon the young man, should trouble him, he promises in general, and afterward
interlaceth in particulars, diverse promises of good and sure rewards, to allure
him to audience and obedience. Solomon had a flood, or a wood of words, a Sylva
Synonymorum, and therefore urges the same things with elegant variation of
phrase, as a Father often inculcats the same things daily in other words to
affect his child the more, that so, what works not upon him at first, may at
last. The two first verses are a general preface to the rest of the Chapter,
wherein is, 1. an exhortation in the first verse: 2 ly. a promise to set it on,
Verse 2.

For the words, My Son, see on Chap. 1.18. He often uses the amiable name of a
Son; intimating, that he speaks not as an Enemy, nor a Neighbor, or Friend, or
Master, or King, but as a loving Father to his beloved child: And well might he
call the hearer or reader his Son, on whom he had bestowed so many godly
instructions, and whom he goes on to instruct still, like a Father.

Forget not. See on Chap. 2.17. Let my law stick fast in thy memory; whatsoever
thou forget, either children, business, or whatever else is deer unto thee, be
sure thou forget not my Law: sooner forget music and singing, as the godly
Jews would rather forget them, then Jerusalem. Psalm. 137.5.6.

My Law. See on Chap. 1.8. Here it is taken for those good instructions Solomon
gave, and which are written in this book; therefore he calls it his Law, which
being agreeable to Gods Law, his children were tied to observe. So Gods law is
called Moses Law, Mal. 4.4. This book is a Law how to guide our life,
containing many excellent practical instructions.

But. See on Chap. 1.25.2.22. an opposition between keeping and forgetting.

Let thine heart. See on Chap. 2.2. The heart here may be taken for the memory,
which is the chest of the soul; or rather for the will, which is King in the
Soul, and to which the understanding is councellor, and the affections are
servants.

Keep. See on Chap. 2.11. Keep them both in memory, and life. He speaks not of
a bare remembering, but of a practical keeping also, showing, that it is not
profitable for us to have them in our heart, unless we also exercise them in
our conversation. The sum is, that we must remember these precepts to keep and
do them, Deuteronomy. 7.12. For remembering the law in the heart without practicing it
in the life, will not bring the blessing annexed, Ver. 2. Length of days, etc.
Thou must remember them so, that thou hearcily practice them, and that thy
heart not only have the knowledge of them ready upon all occasions, but also be
ever studying for occasions, and how to do them.

My commandments. See on Chap 2.1. Thou must not only look to this book in
general, but have respect to every particular direction in it, that concerns
thee; then shall thou be like Zechariah and Elizabeth, walking in all the
commandments and ordinances of the Lord blamlesse, Luke 1.6. And may conclude
with the Psalmist, Then shall I not be ashamed when I have respect unto thy
