commandments, Psalm 119.6. The sum is, as if Solomon had said, Thou have
heard, O my Son, that thou art not able by thine own pains and study to get
Wisdom, but thou must get teachers, and accommodate the ears both of thy soul
and body to their words; yet is not this enough to make thee wise, but thou
must also retain those instructions in thy memory, ready for practice when
opportunity shall be offered.

Figures none. Note. 1. A prohibition. 2. An Exhortation.


In the former note. 1. The person spoken to, Myson. 2. The thing forbidden.
Forget not. 3. The Object. My Law.


In the latter observe.

1 The opposition, or rather augmentation. But, Or, it may be read, Yea, See on
Chap. 2.22. Be so far from forgetting, that thou remember to practice my
Commands on all occasions.

2. The agent, Let thine heart.

3. The Act. Keep.

4. The object. My Commandments.

1. Doct. Great affection ought to be in a teacher. He must look upon his
hearers, as upon his Children. This is Paul^ tone, My little Children Of whom I
travail in birth again. Gal. 4.19. Wherefore? Because I love you not! God
knows. 2 Cor. 11.11. I will glad^y spend, and be spent for you, though the
more abundantly I love you, the less I be loved. 2 Cor. 12.15. Spoken as by an
indulgent Father. This is John's tone, My little Children, these things write I
unto you, that ye sin not. 1 John 2.1. This is Christ's own tone, O Jerusalem,
Jerusalem, how often would I have gathered thy children together, even as an
hen gathers her chickens under her wings, and ye would not. Mat. 23.37. Like
a tender Father complaining of an unthrifty son, We were gentle among you, even
as a nurse cherishes her children says Paul. 1. These. 2.7.

Reason. 1. Because else his Ministry shall never do any good. His directions
will be slighted, his promises thought flatteries, his reproves disgraces, his
threatenings, fruit of malice.

2. He does else not imitate God, who has more reason to take state; yet
teaches his with his abundance of sweetness.

Use 1. To reprove such teachers, as seldom converse with those, whom they
take charge of, and show small affection to them. It is fit Ministers should
study. They can never dispense the bread of life well, if it be not well baked.
A Physician must study: Yet if the one visit not, nor converse lovingly with
his people, nor the other with his patients, they will do little good.

2. It blames the critical sort of the people, who say, if a Minister be
familiar, and cheerful with those, whom he teaches, he loses repute,
discredits himself, and his calling. At indignus tu, qui diceres tamen. But yet
it becomes not you to say so. Would you have your teachers strange to you? what
comfort then can ye take in them, or what good will ye get by them.

2. Doct. Great respect in an hearer ought to be toward a teacher. As in a son
to a Father. Solomon spoke Proverbs, as well as writ them, and so had teachers,
as well as readers. He spoke three thousand Proverbs. 1 King. 4.32. That of
Paul proves it, cited out of the Prophets, as being the Doctrine of the old,
and new Testament. How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the Gospel
of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things! Romans 10.15. Such good respect
Paul found from the Galathians. Ye received me as an Angel of God, even as
Christ Jesus. I bear you record, that, if it had been possible, ye would have
plucked out your own eyes, and have given them to me. Gal. 4.14, 15.

Note. 1. The end, why such respect should be showed to our teachers.

2. The manners how.

For the first. The reasons are.

1. For Gods cause, because they are his Ambassadors, and for the time of
teaching represent his person.

2. For our sake, we will else not regard, nor get good by their words.

3. For their sake, that they may not be discouraged in their office.

4. For others sake, that our example may draw them to learn of them.

For the second. The manner how we must respect them.

1. By due respect to their persons, by reverencing them, and esteeming them
very highly in love for their works sake. 1 These. 5.13.

2 To their preceps by obedience; Obey them, that have the rule over you, for
they watch for your souls. Heb. 13.17.

3. By speaking well of them, I ought to have been commended of you. 2 Cor.
12.11.

4. By dealing kindly with them, Let him that is taught in the word,
communicate unto him that teaches in all good things, Gal. 6.6.

Use 1. For complaint of neglect of teachers, by their hearers. An heathen
Prince seeing Gods Ministers set at the bottom of the Table by a Christian
Emperor, said, He would never be of that Religion, where the teachers were
contemned.

2. Let men show all due respect to their teachers, especially in st^nding fast
to truth taught by them, that they may be encouraged to teach Gods truth still.

Doct. 3. Precepts of Parents and Teachers, agreeable to Gods Law, ought to be
regarded. Solomon spoke and wrote both as a Father, and as a teacher, and he
did regard his fathers instruction, Chap. 4.4. his Mothers, Chap. 31.1. and
Agurs, Chap. 30.1. It seems he regarded them well, that left them in writing
for us.

Reas. 1. Because Parents should be teachers, and not breed their children like
brute beasts.

2. Because teachers supply the defect of Parents, taking upon them to instruct
us, when our parents cannot, for want of time or ability.

Use 1. It reproves ungracious children, that slight the wholesome counsels of
their own Parents; sure they will never regard any others instruction.

2. It blames unprofitable scholars, that make their parents cost, and teachers
labor in vain.

Doct. 4. Such precepts ought never to be forgotten. Let thine heart retain my
words, decline not from the words of my mouth. Chap. 4.4, 5. Remember the Law
of Moses my servant. Mal. 4.4

Res. 1. Because Oblivio Matter, aut proles ingratitudints Senec. de beneficiis.
Oblivion is the mother or child of unthank fullness. Men remember what they
think worthy of thanks, and forget other things; and thankfulness will cause
them to remember benefits. 2. It is the stepmother, or hinderer of spiritual
profit: No good is gotten by things forgotten. Sicut in unoqu^ que opere matter
est constantia, ita universae doctrinae invenitur oblivio noverca. Boet. do
discipline. Scholar.

Use Think it not enough to learn good things, unless you remember them. It
availes little to hear good instructions, except ye keep them in memory: it is
not sufficient to talk of Gods word with the mouth, unless we remember it in
the heart. Who among you will give ear to this, who will hearken and hear for
the time to come? Isa. 42.23. Say as Cenis to her Lady Antonia, Frustra Domina
jussisti, haec enim, atque caetera ^mnia, quae mihi imperas, it a semper in
memoria habco, ut ex ca deleri non possint. You need not, Madam bid me do your
business, for these things, and all other which you command me, I have them
always so in my memory, that they cannot be blotted out of it. Deo or as
another, Jussa mihi tam velle sequi, quam posse, necesse est. It is as
necessary for me to be willing, as to be able to keep your commands. As the Ark
kept the two Tables, and the Pot, the hidden Manna; so should we keep godly
precepts in our hearts; else are we like many cunning Artists, that get much,
yet live poorly, because they can keep nothing.

Doct 5. Such precepts ought to be put in practice. All the commandments which
I command thee this day, shall ye observe to do, Deuteronomy. 8.1. The words of
Jonadab the son of Rechab, that he commanded his sons, are performed. Jer.
35.14.

Reas. 1. Because they are good seed for a spiritual crop; and men will be
careful to preserve seed corn, else they may starve. 2. Because they are
lights to direct our steps, not only to see the way, but how to walk in it. Thy
word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path. Psalm. 119.105. Men go
not in the dark without a lanthorn.

Use. Draw out into practice what ye have learned by your parents and teachers.
If a man had the Philosophers stone, if he used it not, he would have no gold.
A known medicine helps not, if not taken; keep then good precepts actually, as
well as cordially: in deed, as well as in heart; they that do not so, forget
them, or at least keep them not: delight thy self with keeping them in thine
heart, and honor thy God with observing them in thy life.

Doct. 6. Such precepts must be practiced heartily. Thou Solomon my son, know
thou the God of thy father, and serve him with a perfect heart, and with a
willing mind. 1 Chronicles. 28.9. Servants, obey in all things your Masters
according to the flesh, not with eye service, as men-pleasers, but in
singleness of heart, fearing God: And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to
the Lord, and not unto men. Col. 2.22, 23. Ye have obeyed from the heart the
form of Doctrine, which was delivered you Romans 6.17. (...) Reason. 1. Because
the heart is the fountain of life. Dead services please neither God, nor men.
It is like the speaking of Parrots. Acceptable service to God must be
reasonable service. Romans 12.1.

It is like the Fountain of joy, and comfort, and therefore where it is not,
men can have no comfort in any thing they do.

Use. See where your hears are, when ye do what Parents, and Teachers advise
you. If ye do it unwillingly, it is not thankworthy.

VERSE 2. For length of days, and long life, and peace shall they add unto
thee.
THe Exhortation was in the former Verse. The promise to encourage us to
obedience is in this. That men might with more courage endeavor to obey
Solomon's wise directions, God joins the reward to the work, and promises those
things, which all men, but especially young men most of all desire, and long
for, and are most dear to men of tender years, to wit, a long, quiet, and happy
life. Some distinguish the three things promised thus, That by length of days
should be meant a life on earth as long as may be drawn out by any strength of
nature. By long life, or years, of life eternal life in another world. By
peace, peace of conscience. But they may rather be understood thus, By length
of days may be understood a life that lasts long. By long life, or years of
life an healthful life. By peace a prosperous life.

For the words.

For. See on Chap. 19. A reason of the former Exhortation.

Length of days. They bring a long life to a man, not beyond the time
appointed by God, but as God has determined, so by his blessing he gives long
life to those that obey him. This is understood of bodily life here which the
Law also promises in the first commandment. The word (...) Day in Scripture is
used.

1. For a natural day, confisting of 24 hours. Neither eat nor drink three
days. Est. 4.16.

2. For an artificial day opposed to the night. The greater light to rule the
day, and the lesser light to rule the night, Genesis 1.16.

In the plural for a long day, and circular, till that day come again a full
year. This man went up out of his City (...) From days to days: which ver.
7, is (...) year by year.

4. For a certain time, especially to come. In that day shall this song be sung
in the land of Judah. Isa. 26.1.

5. For a time of trouble. Remember, O Lord the children of Edom in the day of
Jerusalem: who said, Raze it, Raze it, even to the foundation thereof. Psalm.
137.7. Their day is come, the time of their visitation. Jer. 50.27. Here it is
taken in the first sense for natural days.

And. See on Chap. 2.9.22. on the word But long life. Heb. Years of life. For
life see on Chap. 2.19. Lest any man should think, that long life may be
miserable, he says not years of sickness, or weakness, which are but
puttings off, or rather years of death, but years of life, that is of health,
and strength. Non est vivere, sed valere vita. It is not worthy the name of a
life barely to live, but to be in health, and strength. So a life in Heaven is
called eternal life, whereas a life in Hell which lasts as long, is called the
second death.

And peace. Lest any thing should be wanting to a long, and healthful life,
peace is added. And well too, for the shortest life is best without peace? By
peace is meant prosperity, riches, liberty. So the Hebrews use the word. And he
said unto them, Is he well? And they said, He is well, Heb. Is there peace to
him? There is peace. Genesis 29.6, Go see, if it be well with thy brethren? Heb.
See the peace of thy brethren. Genesis 37.14. And indeed prosperity is the fruit
of peace: adversity of war.

Shall they add to thee. They shall prolong the years of thy life, health, and
wealth. Not forgetting, but observing Gods commands will do all this. The sum
is, If thou slight not my commands, but observe them, thou shall have a long,
healthful and prosperous life. Long life without health is troublesome, and
health without other comforts of life cannot give content.

Observe.

Figures none. 1. The word of coherence. For.

2. The benefits. Length of days, and long life, and peace. A long,
healthful, and prosperous life.

3. The means of procuring these is obedience. Shall they add unto thee.

1. Doct. God might have required full obedience without rewards, yet he
promises large ones. That he might require it without reward, appears in the
preface of the commandments. Obey, for I am Jehovah, that gave thee thy being,
Thy God, in covenant with thee, That brought thee out of the Land of Egypt. A
great benefit. Out of the house of bondage. A great deliverance. That he will
give full rewards, appears in the end of the second, and fifth Commandments.
Forsake Idolatry, and worship me aright; For I show mercy to thousands of them,
that love me and keep my Commandments. Honor thy Father, and thy Mother, that
thy days may be long in the land, which the Lord thy God gives thee. So he
promises Abraham to be his shield, and exceeding great reward. Genesis 15.1. For
the first part, That God may require obedience without any reward, appears

1. Because he is not any way indebted to us for our obedience. He has all of
himself, and nothing from us. Nor gets no addition of happiness by our
obedience.

2. We are indebted to him for all the good things we have, as Life, Health,
Food, Goods, World Heaven; we have all from him, and that of free grace. And it
is strange for a debtor to require money of his creditor; we cannot then merit
any thing from him, that cannot add any thing to him; neither does he need any
thing. He that merits of another, must some way supply his wants. Sacrifices
could not do it. And if they could do it, he need not take them of us that owes
all the cattle of the World. Psalm. 50.9. etc. And if God did need, how should
we supply his wants, that cannot supply our own for soul or body? He that
cannot keep his own Family, cannot relieve others.

3. Because God is absolute Lord over all, and may command what he list
without rewarding any creature in Heaven or in Earth. For the second, that yet
he will give a full reward, appears.

1. Because he is merciful, and stands upon his honor. And where justice will
give no reward, mercy will. So Fathers promise many things to their children,
to encourage them to do their duty: Here is long, and healthful years, and
prosperity; and what needs a man more in this life?

2ly. Because God is faithful, and has promised a full reward to every good
action, so that mercy and truth appear in it, though justice require it not.

Use 1. To acknowledge, that if God bless us in soul or body, it is of his
free grace, not of the merit of our obedience. He might by his right over us,
require service without pay: yet he is so merciful, that he will not. So a
father may look for duty freely from a child, yet he provides for him, and
gives him an inheritance,

2ly. Let this encourage us to duty: we owe it to God, therefore do it; we
shall have a full reward, therefore do it cheerfully: this is a double band,
kindness uses to work more upon men's spirits, then duty; so let it do with
us toward God. This encouraged Moses, he knew he deserved nothing, yet, had
respect unto the recompense of reward. Heb. 11.26

Doct. 2. Gods rewards are such, as men like well, ordinarily. He gives his
people a land of brooks, fountains, wheat, barley, wines, fig trees, etc. Deuteronomy.
8.7. A land that had goodly houses, many herds of greater cattle, many flocks
of lesser, much silver and gold, etc. Deuteronomy. 8 etc.

Reas. It appears, 1. in the particulars in the Text, God promises long life,
peace, and plenty, what would man have more for his body? who loves not all
these? Men love long life; for that end they are choice in meat, drink,
apparel, baths, physic, they spare for no cost; so do worldly men dote on
peace and plenty. These God promises. 2ly. it appears by the prayers of men; no
doubt they pray for what they love best, and God often gives it, as he gave
wisdom to Solomon to guide a great Kingdom, when he prayed for it. 3ly. By
Gods aditional gifts to Solomon, as honor, and riches, which he asked not, yet
could not but like well, when God gave them. So he gives a comfortable earthly
passage to them, that seek for heaven: seek ye first the Kingdom of God and
his righteousness, and all these things shall he added unto you. Mat. 6 33. Who
likes not a good way, to a good end? It is a double mercy.

Use. Be careful to please God, and trust him for rewards; he will give such as
thou likest, and can no where else get: Gods precepts well kept, will be in
stead of Diet, Physic, Guard, and other means of preserving life: If other
means fail, God will preserve by these.

Doct. 3. Long life is a blessing. God gave Abraham a good old age, Genesis 25.8.
The hoary head is a crown of glory, etc. Chap. 16.31. It is a sweet mercy, and
generally desired. What man is he that desires life, and loves many days,
that he may see good? Psalm, 34.12. As if he had said, every man naturally does
desire it. Men love life, and abhor death! With long life will I satisfy him,
Psalm. 91.16.

Reas. 1. Because life it self is a blessing, therefore the continuance of it
is so.

2ly. Because God promises it to his servants, as in the fifth commandment;
and God uses to promise good things, and threaten bad: And this promise Wisdom
uses, as conceiving it will much work upon the spirits of men; for by me thy
days shall be multiplied, and the years of thy life shall be incrcased. Chap.
9.11.

3. It is a type of heaven, which had it all the perfections of joy it has,
yet were it not lasting, it could not afford full happiness.

4. It is a resemblance of Gods eternity, who is called The ancient of days,
Dan. 7.13.

5. Short life is accounted a curse. God theatens Eli, that there should not be
an old man in his house, 1 Samuel 2.31. Sure then the contrary is a blessing.

1. Obj. How is it a blessing, when wicked men often live long.

Ans. It is a blessing in it self, and to good men, who have the more time to
serve God; though it may be none, yea, a curse to wicked men, who may sin the
more, and have the more pain in hell.

2. Obj. Good men often have it not, but die soon, as Josiah.

1. Ans. It is in perilous times, when it is better to die, then to live. From
henceforth, blessed are the dead which die in the Lord, Rev. 14.13. It might
have been a blessing to live long, before in the time of the Churches
prosperity, but not then, in the time of her persecution, then the righteous
are taken away from the evil to come, Isa. 57.1.

2. If in other times God take them away, they lose not, but get by it; they
get by death a longer, and an happier, yea, an eternal life.

3. Obj. Men may live long in misery, and that is a curse rather then a
blessing.

Ans. God will give his servants prosperity with their long life, if he see it
fit for them; if not, he will turn their afflictions to their good. We know that
all things work together for good to them that love God. Romans 8.28. A
Physician can make an healing medicine out of poison, so can God make
afflictions profitable to his.

Use 1. It shows the folly of many men, who would have long life, yet look not
after heavenly wisdom, the means of continuing life: Such show themselves to
be fools, as by adultery, drunkenness, quarrels, kill themselves, or are
killed by others, because they follow not wisdom, and holy directions; they
might live longer, if they lived wisely, and godlily: Such complain in vain of
shortness of life, which they bring on themselves.

2. It teaches us not to complain for the troubles of old age, but to bless
God for the comforts we have seen, more then others in the length of our days.
Remember that God has set the one over against the other. Eccles. 7.14. Sicut
nun hirunde non facit ver, nec una linea Geometram: sic nec una dies, vel breve
tempus reddit hominem foelicem. Recuperus. As one swallow makes not a spring,
nor one line a Geometrician, so neether one day, nor a short time makes a man
happy.

Doct. 4. Health in our days is a great blessing also. So it is promised, It
shall be health to thy navil, and marrow to thy bones. verse 8. They are life
unto those that find them, and health to all their flesh, Chap. 4.22.

Reas. 1. Because it gives a man much comfort in body, business, and society
of friends; yea and in Soul also, for the Soul has a fellow-feeling of the
bodies joy or sorrow, in regard of the near conjunction of them.

2. From the contrary, because sicknesses, and diseases are threatened as
crosses and sometimes as curses. See Deuteronomy. 28.29. etc. The leprosy of Naeman
shall sleave unto thee, and unto thy seed for evers. 2 Kings 5.27.

3. Because health fits us for duty to God and men, sickness makes us
unserviceable to both.

Use. To inform us, that we may lawfully pray for health; because in it self it
is a blessing. Spiritual blessings are best worth asking, yet temporal not to
be despised.

5. Doct. Prosperity also is a blessing in it self, the Devil confesses it to
be so to Job. Thou have blessed the work of his hands, and his substance is
increased in the land. Job. 1.10. Abraham's servant confesses it in his Master.
The Lord has blessed my Master greatly, and he is become great: and he has
given him flocks, and herds, and silver, and gold, and menservants, and
maidservants, and Camells, and Asses. Gen, 24.35.

Reason 1. Because it is a gift of God. I will give thee riches, and wealth,
and honor. 2 Chronicles. 1.12.

2. He has given it to some of his choicest servants, as to Abraham, Joseph,
David, Solomon.

Use. Abuse it not to luxury, or oppression. To be naught thy self more freely,
or to hurt others more powerfully. Remember outward prosperity is Gods gift,
use it then to Gods honor, and bless him for it. Take heed it proves not as
Tertullian calls it, Campus quo ambitio decurrat. A field, in which ambition
may run his course.

6. Doct. Long life, health, prosperity are sometimes the rewards of well doing
and obedience. If ye be willing, and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the
Land. Isa. 1.19. O that thou had hearkened to my Commandments? then had thy
peace been as a river. Isa. 48.18 That is, thy prosperity; as was showed in the
exposition of the Text.

Reason. 1. Because of Gods bounty, who besides Heaven often gives comforts to
his here.

2. Because of man's frailty, who is by prosperity much encouraged to obedience,
and discouraged by the contrary.

1. Object. Godly men oftentimes live but a while, and in much pain, and and
poverty.

Answ. Besides what was said before on the third Doctrine,

I answer. 1. That their obedience is but in part, and the reward is answerable.

2. Promises of outward things are but conditional. And God by short life, or
sorrows keeps them from corruption, or persecution, and trouble.

3. God gives them a longer, and better life in Heaven. So God verifies his
promise with advantage. As if a man should promise twenty shilling a week for a
year, and at the first months end void the bargain, and give the party a
thousand pound. What cause had the receiver to complain, either of falsehood in
the promiser, or of loss to himself.

4. Their short life have more sun-shiny days, and true, and spiritual
comforts there, then any wicked man's long life. Summer fruit may be as ripe as
winter fruit, though gathered some months before.

Use. 1. It blames those, who think, that the study of wisdom and piety,
shortens their childrens days. They say, they are too wise, or too good to
live long. Such bring up their children foolishly, and impiously, and so
shorten their days, which they would prolong.

2. It encourages us to get wisdom and obedience. Ungodly men think, there is
no better way in the world to make them live long, then to be merry, and to put
away sorrow by letting slip the bridle to all manner of concupiscence: but let
us remember, that a long, healthful, prosperous life is the reward of
obedience, and live accordingly.

VERSE 3. Let not mercy and truth forsake thee: bind them about thy neck, write
them upon the Table of thine heart.
NOw follow particular duties to be performed to God and Man, enterlarded with
many excellent promises and rewards for encouragement to obedience. And first
the wise man begins with two duties to men, setting the Exhortation to mercy
and truth in this Verse, and the encouraging promise in the next.

For the words.

Let not mercy and truth. These two are often enjoined together in Scripture: and
it is pity, that they being so nearly joined in themselves should ever be
separated. Sometimes they are jointly attributed to God. His mercy is
everlasting, and his truth endures to all generations. Psalm. 100.5. His
merciful kindness is great toward us, and the truth of the Lord eudureth for
ever. 117.2. Sometimes to man. Mercy and truth preserve the King. Chap. 20.28.
When they are attributed to God, then Gods mercy is showed in promising or
giving man any good, that deserves nothing but ill of him. His truh is showed
in performance of his promises: When they are spoken of man, then is mercy seen
in giving freely to the poor, who deserve nothing of us, yea to enemies, who
deserve ill of us. Truth is manifested in doing what we owe by promise, or debt
to men. Misericordia est gratia, qua ex nostro libero animo benefacimus alteri,
non ex debito, non ex passione. Veritas, qua exclusa omni fictione adaequamus
facta dictis, verba cordi, cordebitis: Gratia, qua gratuita, veritas, qua
debita exhibemus. Cajeetan. Mercy is favor, whereby out of our own free mind
we do good to another man, not out of debt, not out of passion. Truth is that
virtue, whereby shutting out all feigning, we do equal our deeds to our words,
our words to our haart, our heart to our debts. Grace (or mercy) is, whereby we
give free things; Truth, whereby we pay (or restore) things due to others. Some
interpret the Text here of Gods mercy and truth, and that two ways.

1. So carry thy self, that God may deal mercifully, and truly with thee. But
this cannot be the sense. For though a man may so carry himself, that God will
not deal mercifully with him; yet he cannot carry himself so badly, that God
will not deal truly with him, for that were a blemish to God. If he be upright,
God will perform his promises to him: if not, God will execute his threatenings
upon him: whichsoever God does, he shows forth his truth.

2. By way of promise, not of exhortation. And they read it, Mercy and truth
shall not forsake thee. And they tie it to the former words, if thou forget not
my Law, etc. then God will deal mercifully with thee, and perform all his
promises to thee. But

1. This crosses the ordinary sense of (...) for a prohibition, and that
without need.

2. The words following are imperative.

3. In the first and second Verses ye have a prohibition, and promise. This
method is also observed in the verses following: and most likly so here in this
Verse, and the next. The word (...) signifies.

1. Mercy or favor, All the paths of the Lord are mercy and truth. Psalm. 25.10.

2. By the contrary it is taken for reproach, or dishonor. Sin is a reproach to
any people. Chap. 14.34. So (...) signifies to bless, and curse: and other
Hebrew words admit of contrary significations. (...) Truth comes from a word,
that signifies to be firm, and stable; for truth will abide, when all lies
fail. And the Hebrew word for believing, comes from the same root, for truth is
worthy to be believed, and relied upon. This is a faithful saying, and worthy
of all acceptance, 1 Timothy 1.15.

Forsake thee. See on Chap. 2.17. An Hypallage. Forsake not thou them, for then
will they forsake thee. A great elegancy in it, intimating.

1. That their forsaking us is more then our forsaking them. Our forsaking them
may come out of our weakness, but their forsaking us comes out of our
wilfulness, and hardness of heart, in not entertaining them.

2. It sets out the easiness of the loss of them through our corruption.
Fugax est natura boni, Good things naturally fly away.

3. It sets out our great need of them. Neque vero dixit, ipsas ne deseras, sed
ne deserant te, ostendens nos esse, qui illarum egea^us, non ipsas nostri,
Chryso^t. Hom. 1 in Philip. For he does not say, Forsake not thou them, but let
them not forsake thee, showing, that we have need of them, but they have no
need of us.

4. It imitates our great care, and pains needful for the retaining of them.
They are easily lost, but hardly kept. An Hawk must be well tamed, before he be
let fly: else he will return no more. These graces must be as carefully kept
as providently gotten, like riches. Non minor est virtus, quum quarere, parta
tueri. It is no less virtue to keep wealth, then to get it. Non dicit, semel
facias, aut secundo, aut tertio, neque decies, neque centies, sed perpetuo, Non
deserant te Chrysostom. He does not say, Be careful once, or twice, or the third
time, no nor ten times, nor an hundred times, but take care perpetually, that
they forsake thee not. And both mercy, and truth must be kept for ever.
Difficile est simul nos misereri, and sapere. Sen. It is an hard task for us to
pity, and be wise both together. Else mercy may lie to do good, and truth may
reveal without cause, what may do hurt. Therefore join both, as God does, Mercy
and truth are met together. Psalm. 85.10. Else Gods mercy would save all, or his
truth damn all.

Bind them. The word (...) signifies.

1. To bind one thing to another, as a yoke is bound about an Oxes neck. Thou
shall bind a stone to it. Jer. 51.63.

2. To bind men together in love. His life is bound up in the lads life. Genesis
44.30.

3. To bind them together in a plot, or conspiracy. The servants of Amnon
conspired against him, 2 King. 21.23. Here it is taken in the first sense for
putting them, and the neck together, yet not without a figure, as will appear
anon. By them is not meant the Law, and Commandments. ver. 1. But Mercy and
truth, as in this.

About thy neck. See on Chap. 19. Hereby is meant.

1. To have them fast, so that they may not be lost; as men tie their Jewels
about their necks.

2. To have them ready to use, when occasion is offered, as a jewel about the
neck, that has virtue in it, is at hand for use.

3. To keep some external memorialls to put us in mind of these virtues upon
the beholding of them, as jewels on the neck, may put us in mind of
businesses, being ever in fight.

4. To delight in them, as men do in jewels which they hang about their necks.

5. To count it an ornament to us to deal mercifully, and truly with others.
The children of Nobles, when they were little, were wont to wear some jewel
about their neck, that they might be known to be of high birth. So should we
make our heavenly parentage known by works of mercy, and truth.

And write them upon the Table of thine heart. Have them in perpetual all
remembrance, as things not written in Tables of stone, as Moses Law was, but in
thy heart, as in a Table of perpetual memory, as Gods Law was written at first
in Adams heart, and as we write in our Tablebooks those things, of which we
would keep a precise memorandum. They should be most dear unto us. So Queen
Mary said, They that should rip her, should find Callis at her heart. Some have
the images of their dearest friends in form of an heart, which they hang upon
their breast the seat of the heart. So mercy and truth should have so deep an
impression upon the understanding, that they never go out of the memory. Some
understand by binding them about the neck, speaking of them, and teaching them
to others, for the throat is the instrument of speaking. And by writing them on
the Table of the heart th'inking of them, and remembering them. But the former
interpretation is more solid.

For heart. See on ver. 1. and on Chap. 2.2. Here is one thing set out by
diverse similitudes in an eminent gradation like three steps of a ladder one
above another. Mercy and truth are compared.

1. To companions, that must not depart from us.

2. To a chain about the neck, which is nearer then a companion.

3. To a thing written in a Tablebook, which is nearer to the book, then a
chain, that hangs loose about the neck.

Figures. A double metaphor, wherein keeping mercy and truth, or exercising them
outwardly is compared to tying a gold chain about the neck for Ornament. And
retaining them in the heart is compared to things written in a Tablebook, that
they may not be forgotten.

Note 1. The duty set down plainly. 2. Figuratively.


In the former note.

1. The double subject. Let not mercy and truth. 2. The adjunct. Forsake thee.
In the latter note.

1. The fimilitude from a chain. 2. From a Tablebook.
In the first observe.

1. The act, Bind them. 2. The object, about thy neck.
In the second, note

1. The act, write them. 2. The object, upon the table of thy heart.
Doct. 1. Duties to men are to be made conscience of, as well as duties to God:
See the first enjoined, the second conjoined. Thou shall love the Lord thy God
with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind. This is the
first and great commandment, and the second is like unto it, Thou shall love
thy neighbor as thy self. Mat. 22.37, 38, 39. Though the Pharisees did duty
to God, yet are they blamed for neglect of duty to men. Woe unto you Scribes
and Pharisees hypocrites, for ye devour widows houses, and for a pretense make
long prayer; therefore ye shall receive the greater damnation. Mat. 23.14.

Reas. 1. Because God has a care of the preservation of his Image; In all the
world, no creature so like God, as man.

2. God made laws to that purpose, as good rulers make laws, not for their own
honor only, but for their subjects peace and wealth also.

3. God appointed Magistrates to execute those laws, to be custodes utriusque
tabulae, keepers of both tables: And he gave to them more honor and power then
to other men, for that purpose.

4. He himself will punish those wrongs done to men, at the day of judgment,
which his deputies do not punish here, and will punish them also for not doing
it.

Use. To condemn hypocrites, who profess religion, but want humanity: of such
the beloved Apostle says, If a man say I love God, and hates his brother, he
is a liar. And this commandment have we from him, that he who loves God, love
his brother also. 1 John 4.20.21.

Doct. 2. Mercy and Truth should always go together. If ye will deal kindly and
truly with my Master, tell me, Genesis 24.49. Lie not one to another. Put on
bowels of mercies. Col. 3.9.12.

Reas. 1. Because both are ornaments to us: Men wear lace on good clothes, so
does mercy adorn truth.

2. both are profitable to others: sometimes truth alone ties us to do good to
other men, when we are by duty or promise, engaged to them: but certainly
mercy will supply others wants, where no particular engagment is.

3. The want of the one, buries the commendation of the other; such an one is a
merciful man to the poor, but there is no truth in him, no man can build upon
his word; such a man is very just in all his dealings, but as hard as flint; he
has a good estate, but the poor fare never the better for it.

4. Both are together in God, else could we look for no favor from him, nor
expect the performance of any promise made by him for we daily give him cause
to break them all.

Use 1. To blame such as brag of one of these, but want the other; one brags of
his charity to the poor, and thinks at his death he must needs go to heaven for
it, though he got all his wealth by fraudulent dealing: Another boasts of his
just dealing, no man can say, black is his eye, though no poor man ever tasted
of his cup: One is no sign of salvation, when the other leads to hell. In
Logic, Conclusio semper sequitur partem debiliorem, The conclusion always
follows the weaker part. So here, hell claim her own.

Use 2. Be not content with one of these alone, make a marriage of them in your
heart, and life: Those whom God has joined together, let no man put assunder;
then may you say with David, I will sing of mercy and judgment, unto thee O Lord
will I sing. Psalm. 101.1.

Doct. 3. Good must be done to them to whom we owe nothing. This is to be a
true neighbor in Christ's judgment, and men's; Which now of these three think
thou says our Savior to the Lawyer) was neighbor unto him that fell among the
Th^eves? And he said, he that showed mercy on him. Then said Jesus unto him, go
thou, and do likewise, Luke 30.36.37. Give to him that asks thee, and from
him that would borrow of thee, turn not thou amay. Mat. 5.42. This must be done,

1. For the creatures sake, we are Gods creature, so are they, God would not
have us neglect them, we should not do it.

2. For man's sake, they are not beasts, but men, as well as we; and while we
are men, we may need others: no man can stand wholly on his own bottom.

3. For Gods sake, who requires it, and to whom we can show no other real
requital, for he needs not us, nor ours, but enjoynes us to do good to others
freely, for his sake.

4. For pitties sake, every faculty of the soul must be exercised, else it is
in vain placed there.

Use. To condemn hard hearted persons, who say to the poor, What do I owe you?
These are Cains generation, who taught them their lesson long since. Am I my
Brothers Keeper? Genesis 4.9. And they may expect Cains reward, A fugitive, and a
vagabond shall thou be in the earth. Genesis 4.12.

4. Doct. Truth is required in all our dealings. Abimelech expects it from
Abraham. Swear unto me here by God, that thou will not deal falsely with me.
Genesis 21.23. God likes it, and abhors the contrary. Lying lips are abomination
to the Lord, but they that deal truly, are his delight. Chap. 12.22.

Reason. 1. Because then we shall be like God, who never breaks his word,
though those he deals withal, deal falsely with him, as the best of men do.
This is his glory, let us imitate him, and it will be our credit.

2. All men will be willing to deal with us, if they find truth in our words,
and deeds. Else they will more willingly deal with poorer men.

Use This serves to cry up the forgotten trade of truth, when men seek evasions
to avoid contracts, and if themselves see but a finger of gain, care not for a
handful of truth.

5. Doct. We should have outward mementoes of our duties to men. This heap be
witness, and this pillar be witness, that I will not pass over this heap to
thee, and that thou shall not pass over this heap, and this Pillar to me for
harm. Genesis 31.52. Paul's chain put him in mind of Onesiphorus his kindness.
He was not ashamed of my chain. 2. Tim. 1.16.

Reason. 1. The creatures may put us in mind of it. See how kind Heaven i^to
Earth, that affords it shine, and showers to ripen the fruits of it; yet gets
nothing by it. Grass feeds beasts; beasts feed us.

2. Men's faces, and habits put us in mind of true, and merciful dealing with
them. The poores rags, and pitiful words, other men's kind looks and
carriage mind us of both.

Use Make use of such glasses, as these. How can ye look up to the Heaven, or
down to the Earth, or the rags of the poor, or faces of the rich, and yet
deal falsely, or harshly with others.

6. Doct. We must be hearty in duties to men. Is thine heart right, as my heart
is with thy heart. 2 King. 10.15. The soul of Jonathan was knit with the soul
of David. 1 Samuel 18.1.

Reason. 1. We would have men deal so with us: we care not for their outsides.

2. We can then give a good account, not to men only with whom we deal, but
also to God, who knows, how we dealt with them.

Use. To blame such as do good offices, but unwillingly, grudgingly, and as it
were by constraint. These are dead, and heartlesse kindnesses. Such forget,
that God loves a cheerful giver. 2 Cor. 9.7. And therefore must not look for
any reward from him.

VER. IV. So shall thou find favor, and good understanding in the sight of God
and man.
THE wise man having pressed two duties, that go against the hair in our
corrupted nature, mercy, and truth, now he urges them with promises of rewards
often inculcated elsewhere, and suitable to the things required. He that
shows mercy to men, shall find mercy with God. And he that deals truly with
men, shall have understanding, how to manage his affairs wisely in the world:
or to join them together. He that deals mercifully, and truly, shall be loved
of God, and esteemed wise among men. These are two spurs to the former two
duties. For the word

So. Heb. And. See on Chap. 2.9. and on ver. 22. there on the word But.

Shall thou find. Heb. Find thou. The imperative for the future. The commanding
phrase for the promising. So, Keep my Commandments, and live. Chap. 4.4. That
is, And thou shall live. For where God promises, mercy, there he commands a
blessing. Psalm. 133.3. And all creatures must help to bring it. Thus the Poets
speak also, Si faetura gregem suppleverit, aureus esto Virgil. If thy flock
bring forth abundantly, be thou a golden (or, rich) man. That is, thou shall be
so. So on the contrary the future, or promising tense is put for the
Imperative, or commanding. Thou shall have no other Gods. That is, Have not.
For Gods command ties us, as much as man's promise ties him. For Find. See on
Chap. 1.13. Some read it, And find favor. As if wisdom did admonish men to
seek for favor by those virtues.

Favor. See on Chap. 1.9. on the word, Grace. Thou shall find comfort,
kindness, liking, good acceptance. As men by their comely personage, or wise
carriage, or good offices find savor with Princes.

And good understanding. Thou shall be esteemed a wise man. The Nations shall
say, surely this great Nation is a wise, and understanding people. Deuteronomy. 4.6.
For Good. See on Chap. 2.9. For understanding. See on Chap. 13. on the word
Wisdom.

In the sight. Heb. In the eyes. See on Chap. 11.17. Of God. See Chap. 2.5.

And man. (...). Signifies.

1. A man in general. Man that is born of a woman. Job. 14.1.

2. It was the name of the first man, that ever was. Adam knew his wife. Genesis
4.1. Here it is taken in the first sense, yet collectively, man for men; as
often else where. The last words admit of a threefold sense. Some understand
them thus, Thou shall know how to carry thy self well in all offices to be
done to God, or man. But that is only toward God, and man. In the sight of
them is more. As in the first Commandment, Thou shall have no other Gods in my
sight. It is a greater fault for a woman to lie with an adulterer in her
husbands sight, then else where. Others thus, God, and man will favor thee,
and acknowledge, that thou have carried thy self wisely. Others thus, Thou
shall have good success: For that the word will also bear. God will be so
gracious to thee, and men so friendly, that thou shall thrive wonderfully, and
men shall take notice, and bear witness of it. The second way is best, and
most agreeable to the common use of the original word. The sum is, if thou
exercise mercy and truth toward men, God, and men will favor thee, and
approve, and bear witness of thy great understanding.

Figures. A metaphor in Find. Thou shall obtain it, as men get things they
find. Another metaphor in the eyes, or sight of God. For God has no eyes, yet
will he take notice of it, as men do of what they see. In the eyes of men, that
is, in their sight: for men take notice of those things that come within the
reach of their eyes. The meaning is, they will look upon thee with delight: a
metonymie of the cause for the effect.

Note. 1. The things promised which are two. 1. So shall thou find favor. 2.
And good understanding.

2. The large extent of them, in the sight of God and man. Some things please
men, that offend God; other things please God, that offend men: thy ways shall
please both. This is a great, but a rare blessing.

Doct. 1. Good things cannot be too often inculcated. This is familiar with
Solomon in this book of the Proverbs, to urge the same things, though with some
variety of words. My son, hear the instruction of thy father. Chap. 1.8. My
son, if thou will receive my words, and hide my commandments with thee. Chap.
2.1. My son, forget not my Law, but let thine heart keep my commandments. Chap.
1.3. This course is approved by Saint Paul. To write the same things to you, to
me indeed is not grievous, but for you it is safe. Phil. 3.1.

Reas. 1. Because of the dullness of our apprehension; matters of truth and
holiness may be spoken often, before we understand them.

2. Because of the deadness of our affections, that have no love to either,
naturally.

3. Because we are more forgetful of good things, then of other.

Use. It condemns the niceness of men, that cannot endure to hear old
fundamental truths often pressed, but are so pleased with new things, that they
run into old errors: a Minister must bring forth old things for matter, new for
manner. Every Scribe which is instructed unto the Kingdom of Heaven, is like
unto a man that is an house-holder, which brings forth out of his treasure
things new and old. Mat. 13.52. Brethren, I write no new commandament unto you,
but an old commandment, which ye had from the beginning: the old commandment is
the word, which ye have heard from the beginning. Again, a new commandment I
write unto you, which thing is true in him, and in you, because the darkness
is past, and the true light now shines. 1 John. 2.7.8.

Doct. 2. God gives fit rewards. For good carriage to men, he gives favor with
men: For Nebuchadnezzars service in taking Tirus, God gives him the land of
Egypt. Son of man, Nebuchadnezar, King of Babylon, caused his army to serve a
great service against Tyrus. Every head was made bald, and every shoulder was
peeled: yet he had no wages, nor his Army for Tyrus, for the service that he
had served against it. Therefore thus says the Lord God, behold I will give the
land of Egypt unto Nebuchadnezar King of Babylon, and he shall take her
multitude, and take her spoil, and take her prey, and it shall be the wages of
his army. I have given him the land of Egypt for his labor, wherewith he
served against it, because they wrought for me, says the Lord God. Ezekiel.
29.18, 19.20. Those that honor God with their increase, God will give to them a
greater increase. Honor the Lord with thy substance, and with the first fruits
of all thine increase, so shall thy barnes be filled with plenty, and thy
presses shall burst out with new wine. verse 9, 10. of (...) Chap.

Reas. 1. To allure men the more to do good offices; suitable wages makes a
servant diligent.

2. To show Gods great approbation of them, by the likeness of the rewards to
the duties.

Use. Observe the proportion of your rewards to your duties, see Gods mercy and
wisdom in it, and give him glory.

Doct. 3. Mercy and truth find favor with God. So did Joseph, Moses, David,
Christ.

Reas. 1. Because they are a part of Gods image, and that he likes, where ever
he finds it: God does good to all, he keeps his word, and likes them that do so.

2. Though God get no good by them in us, yet his Church does: sometimes his
people need mercy from men, sometimes truth in performances, and upright
dealing in those with whom they have to do. This God counts as done to
himself. In as much as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my
brethren, ye have done it unto me. Mat. 25.40.

Use. Let us be encouraged to deal mercifully, and truly with all men: If
others, or they with whom we deal regard it not, God will, we shall have great
need of his favor in death, and judgment, if we will not see what need we have
of it now.

Doct. 4. Mercy and truth will find favor with Men. The former examples prove
it.

Reas. 1. In regard of men, they love to be dealt mercifully and truly with all
themselves, even they that deal not so with others, and therefore they commend
it in others, and think well of them, and wish well to them out of self-love,
as many an Adulterer likes a chaste Wife: And as other men, so especially they
that get good by our merciful, and just dealing, will favor us, and speak well
of us.

2. God will incline men's hearts to favor such, as deal mercifully and truly;
yea, oftentimes God, who gives credit, and fashioneth men's opinions, and
enclines men's hearts as he please, makes strangers, heathens, yea enemies, that
use to hate all religion and goodness, by nature, and have particular quarrels
with the persons of godly men, makes them, I say, to commend godly men, for
their mercy and truth, and sometimes to do them much good. Thus Sau^^ ^lents,
and confesses David's innocence. Thou art more right^ous then I, for thou have
rewarded me good, whereas I have rewarded thee evil. 1 Samuel 24.17. This Ezra
blesses God for; Blessed be the Lord God of our fathers, which has put such a
thing as this into the Kings heart, and bath extended mercy unto me before the
King, and his counselors, and before all the Kings mighty Princes. Ezr.
7.27.28.

Use. Behold a second motive to merciful and true dealing: O, say they, men will
not do so to us. We answer, they should do so, and if God see it fit, he will
make them to deal so with you.

Doct. 5. Mercy and truth teach a man how to direct his ways before God. It is
seen in the Centurion, He loves our Nation, and has built us a Synagogue.
Then Jesus went with him. Luke 7.5.6. And in Cornebus, who was a devout man,
and one that feared God, which gave much alms to the people, and prayed to God
always. Acts 10.1, 2.

Reas. 1. Because these things are pleasing to God, though done to men, and
therefore he teaches such, how to carry themselves wisely before himself also.

2. Because there is a chain of graces, and they love to go together. Like will
to like.

Use. Lo a third motive to be merciful, and true dealing: wise carriage before
God is to be got, as a reward of it. And that is a great mercy, such an one, as
all people may wonder at, and and say, Surely this great Nation is a wise and
understanding people. Deuteronomy. 4.6.

Doct. 6. Mercy and truth teach a man how to direct his ways before men also.
So they taught David. They taught him to behave himself wisely, so that He was
accepted in the sight of all the people, and also in the sight of Saul's
servants. 2 Samuel 18.5. So it taught Joseph. When they heard that Joseph's
brethren were come, it pleased Pharaoh well, and his servants. Genesis 45.16. His
good carriage got this respect to himself, and his. So did Abraham's among the
Canaanites. Thou art a mighty Prince among us: in the choice of our Sepulchers
bury thy dead. Genesis 236.

Reason. 1. Because they conduce much to direct us in our carriage in the world.

2. The want of either makes men noted for folly in their affairs.

Use. See a fourth argument to merciful and true dealing. They that care not
for obeying God, yet would with Saul be honored before the people. Mercy and
truth will be a good means to bring this honor from men, as giving us the
serpents subtlety with the doves innocence.

VERSE 5. Trust in the Lord with all thine heart: and lean not unto thine own
understanding.
HEre follow certain precepts concerning our carriage to God, with promises
annexed to some of them. In this Verse trusting in God, is commended to us: and
self-confidence the contrary to it, is forbidden. For the words.

Trust. Put confidence in God, and rest on him, and repose thy self on this
fatherly providence for deliverance from all evil, and the fruition of all
good here, and hereafter. Trust may be opposed to doubting, and fear, and so
may intimate not only relying on God, but waiting with assurance of a good
event, especially if we wait upon the right person, and that upon good grounds.
Some writers make a coherence here. Some of them tie it to the first verse, as
if it had respect to the keeping of the Law, thus, Do not be afraid, that by
reason of thy weakness thou can not keep Gods commandments; neither think on
the other side, that thou can know them by thy natural wit, or do them by
thy natural strength: but trust in the commander, and he will make thee able
in some good measure to do what he enjoines: others knit these words to the
third Verse. Because thou art not able to keep mercy and truth, trust in God,
and he will make thee able: others tie it to the fourth verse. Show that thou
have good understanding indeed by trusting in God, and not in thine own
wisdom. Others to the words following, If thou trust in God, and not to thine
own wit, thou will wisely and readily perform all the duties following to God,
and man. But it is better to take the words without any coherence according to
the former interpretation. Believe that God will not fail thee in any
necessity; but thy own wit may; and act accordingly. Some restrain this
trusting in God to matters of salvation, but that is too strait, for we must
trust in God for earth, as well as for Heaven.

In the Lord. Heb. on the Lord. Not in any creature. Faith, and confidence
shoud have no meaner object, then God. For the word see on Chap. 1.7.

With all. See on Chap. 1.13.

Thine heart. Not in word only, but in truth: not in part, but wholly. Not
partly on Gods care, and partly on thine own wit; but altogether on him. For
Heart, see on Chap. 2.2.

And lean not. As a man leans upon a staff to support him from falling.
Presume not upon thine own wit. Trust not to it.

Unto thine own understanding. Think not thy self so wise, that thou know
all means of providing good things, or freeing from evil. Some restrain it to
carnal wisdom, which is corrupt, and sinful. But it reaches also to natural
wit, deep reach, and policy: which though it may lawfully be used, ye^ must it
not be rested upon, so as to disparage Gods overruling providence. He mentions
only wisdom, or understanding, because men are more ready to lean to that,
then to strength or riches. Yet these are excluded all so figuratively here,
and expressly in other places of scripture from being objects of our confidence:
neither must a man rest on any of them any more, then on understanding. And
less reason to trust on them, for wit can do no more in war, or peace, then
strength, or riches. For the word see on Chap. 1.2. The sum is, Take heed thou
be not high-minded, because of men's favor, nor arrogate too much to thy self,
because of thy subtle pate: but think meanly of thy self, and trust in God, not
faintly, nor in part, but with thy whole heart, and soul.

Figures. 1. A metaphor from an old, or sick man leaning on his staff, who
else must fall intimating, that if all our trust be not in God, we are sure to
perish. Lean not, etc.

2. A figure of the part for the whole, The understanding for all things, that
men use to rely on, besides God.

Note. 1. An injunction.

2. An inhibition.

In the injunction observe.

1. An act. Trust.

2. An object. In the Lord.

3. The manner, With all thine heart.

In the inhibition note.

1. The act prohibited. And lean not.

2. The Object. To thine own understanding.

1. Doct. Our happiness is not from our selves, but from God. Else needed we
not trust in him. O Israel, thou have destroyed thy self, but in me is thy
help, Hos. 13.9. So then it is not of him that wills, nor of him that
runs, but of God, that shows mercy. Romans 9.16.

Reason. 1. It is not from our selves.

1. Because our unhappiness is from our selves, therefore our happiness is
not. No Foun tain can both yield falt water, and sweet. Iam. 3.12. A bad
husband that wastes all, cannot make himself rich.

2. We irrecoverably undo our own selves in regard of our own help. We are not
like a man, that makes himself lame, or sick, and may heal himself again, but
like a man that puts out his eyes, or kills himself, who cannot recover his
sight or life. It is from God.

1. Because no earthly creature can give happiness. Nil dat, quod non hab^t.
Nothing can give what it has not. If the conduit pipe has no water, it can
give no water.

2. No heavenly creature can give it, for they are like standing pooles,
top-ful of water, not like well-springs running over. Therefore God must give
it, or we can never have it.

Use 1. Seek not for happiness in any thing in your power, as in honor,
wealth, pleasure: this is but to wash a black. Moor.

2. Seek to God for it, if you desire it, you must mount above earth and
heaven, and sue to the throne of Grace for it, or never have happiness.

Doct. 2. God is the only object of safe confidence. O Lord of hosts, blessed
is the man that trusts in thee. Psalm. 84.12. Put not your trust in Princes,
nor in the son of man, in whom there is no help. Happy is he that has the God
of Jacob for his help, whose hope is in the Lord his God. Psalm. 146.3, 5.

Reas. 1. Because all other confidence may fail us in some cases; as in
deliverance from sin, pangs of conscience, hour of death and hell: put men or
angels to it, they are at a stand, they can go no-further then natural
strength, fense, or reason will reach, and all these are infinitely short in the
former cases: if they had power, yet would fail sometimes, they might be so
provoked, they would not do what they could, nor what they promised.

2. There is no case, in which God cannot, or will not help his: He need not
fail his, because he is omniscient, and omnipotent: He will not, because he is
merciful and true; we are certain, that God will not, nor cannot go against his
promises of provision, and protection, and deliverance, made to his, for he is
the infallible truth, and no power can let him to keep promise: He is the
Almighty, who says, My counsel shall stand, and I will do all my pleasure. Isa.
40.10.

Use 1. Let us not trust in wit, wealth, strength, friends, good intantions,
merits; all these will fail us in things that concern this life, or a better:
As no man can pass the Sea, without a light ship, that can sail over the
waters, for if he walk on them, he will be drowned; so no man can escape perils
of soul and body by his strength, he must have Gods spirit to make him light,
that he may walk on these waters. Macar. Hom. 44.

2. Let us take notice, that all our strength is in God, in whom we may
securely trust, and not in our own prudence, or ought else. Among the first
precepts of wisdom, humility is commended, and confidence in God, whom to
have always before our eyes, and to call for his help is the highest wisdom,
as on the contrary, to lean to our own prudence is the greatest folly. For what
have thou that thou did not receive? 1 Cor. 4.7. Let us use means, but place
all our trust in God, when all means in heaven and earth fail us, he will supply
us. If a man had a ship with sails, mariners, all provisions needful, yet if
the wind fail, he cannot go on in his voyage. If that serve, worse tackling will
serve. So nothing can do good without Gods blessing, any thing will do good with
it. Basil. Hom. de spirit. Sanct. Deo dante nil potest livor, eo negante nil
potest labor. Greg. Naz. If God give, envy cannot hinder, if he deny, labor
cannot further. Elinandus, Lib. 4. mentions a tree, which protected creatures
from Dragons while they were under the shadow of it, but when they went out,
they were devoured. An emblem of Gods providence. He that dwells in the most
secret place of the most high, shall abide under the shadow of the Almighty.
Psalm. 91.1. Valerius Maximus, lib. 3. c. de fiducia, reports, that one telling
a soldier, going to war against the Persians, that they would hide the Sun
with their Arrows, he answered, We shall fight bast in the shade. Trust God
for deliverance from troubles, and supply of help, when all means fail, he
never fails his: confidence is the least, and yet the best we can render to the
Lord; for hereby we acknowledge his sovereignty, and as it were, set the crown
upon his head, if we put trust in his shadow. Judge. 9.15. Remember then that of
the Prophet, In quietness, and in confidence shall be your strength. Isa.
30.15. And that of the Psalmist, They that trust in the Lord shall be as mount
Sion, which cannot be removed, but abides for ever. Psalm. 125.1.

Doct. 3. God must be rested on heartily. My heart trusted in him. Psalm. 28.7.

Reas. 1. Because God knows the heart, which men does not.

2. If we only make shows of trusting in him, he will only make shows of
helping us, but fail us, as we do him. He will do to men as they believe. Mat.
8.13.

Use 1. To show us that there are but a few that trust in the Lord as they
ought, for the greatest part of the World, set their hearts on other things, by
reason of their ignorance of the insufficiency of all creatures, and contempt
of Gods word, which abundantly sets forth the sufficiency of the Almighty. The
heart rules our words and deeds, and therefore an heartlesse profession of
trusting in God is to no purpose.

2. Look that your confidence in God be hearty, and sincere, else look for no
good from God; if you question his sufficiency, or fidelity, you shall get no
good by either.

Doct. 4. God must be rested on entirely, and universally. Blessed is the man
that makes God his trust. Psalm. 40.4. Thou art my hope O Lord God, thou art my
trust from my youth. ^^al. 72.5. To such as trust in God wholly, God is made
their trust, and is their trust.

Reas. Because God will have all or none, as in our love, which must be with
all the heart, all the soul, and all the mind. Mat. 22.37. And with all our
service, Ye cannot serve God and Mammon. Mat. 6.24. So with all our confidence,
and in all things: He will allow no partner, but will be trusted in alone, and
will not give kis glory to another, Isa. 42.8. nor have his sole-sufficiency
questioned.

Use. See your confidence be not divided, part on God, part on men; such a
confidence may keep you from the Lions, 2 King. 17.25. but it cannot keep you
out of hell. An house built partly on firm ground, partly on sand, or propt on
one side, not on the other will fall. To trust on God then, is to be unbottomed
of thy self, and of every creature, and so to lean upon God, that if he fail
thee, thou sinkest.

Doct. 5. Selfe-confidence cannot stand with trusting in God. Solomon makes an
opposition here between leaning on our understanding, and trusting in the Lord.
Say not in thine heart, my power, and the might of my hand has gotten me this
wealth. But Thou shall remember the Lord thy God, for it is he that gives
their power to get wealth. Deuteronomy. 8.17.18. Cursed be the man that trusts in
man, and makes flesh his arm, and whose heart departs from the Lord. Jer.
17.5.

Reas. 1. Because it undermines our trust in God. For while we think we have
help in our selves sufficient, we think it needless to look for help from God.

2. It opposes trusting in God; selfe-confidence is an act of pride, trusting
in God is an act of humility. We conceive God an enemy naturally, and who will
trust in an enemy?

Use. It shows us the way that ruins many, that we may avoid it; they trust
in themselves, and cannot help themselves; and God will not help them, because
they trust not in him.

Doct. 6. It is a dangerous thing for the wisest man in the world to trust in
his own brain. Witness Achitophel, whose policy brought him to hang himself, 2 Samuel 17.23.

Reas. 1. Because it is a staff of reed, which will both fail and hurt; as a
man, or house falling, when staff or props fail, are left helpless, and hurt
themselves or others.

2. This was the great cause of Idolatry, leaving scripture direction, and
leaning to selfe-understanding. A refined Idolatry, Saint-worship came in from
Court-state.

Use. Take heed of this Rock of being selfe-conceited, as if thou thoughtst thy
self the wisest man in the world, and all events of thine actions depended on
thy brain: What a vanity, madness, dangerous error is it, for a man, mortal,
subject to a miserable life, changeable in Soul and body, laden with so many
sins, in danger of so many temptations, and corruptions, and eternal pains, and
by nature destitute of understanding, to trust to his own skill? He must needs
fall, the fairest blossoms of men's endeavors wither, and the unproblablest
things come to pass, where men trust to their own wisdom: One says of
General Counscels, they seldom were successful, because men came with
confidence, leaning to their own understanding, and seeking for victory rather
then verity. Take then the Apostles counsel, Become a fool that thou may be
wise, 1 Cor. 3.18. A purse full of counters must be emptied, before it can be
filled with gold: A vessel must have water powered out that is in it, before it
can be filled with wine: a Table Book must be cleared of all unprofitable
scriblings, before learned observations can be written in it. Thou must cast
off all self-confidence, before thou can depend on divine providence: Thou
must pull down thy proud sails of self-confidence: else they will sink thee in
a sea of misery.

VERSE 6. In all thy ways acknowledge him, and he shall direct thy paths.
COnfidence on God was required in the last Verse, and that in the heart. Here
homage to God is required, and acknowledgement of him in all our ways. And an
encouraging promise is added of better success, then we could otherwise
expect. God will direct our paths to a better end, then we look for. For the
words.

In all. See on Chap. 1.13. Not in some one way, but in all.

Thy ways. See on Chap. 1.15. Here is meant the actions of our life, in which
we continue, and go on, as travailers in their way. It is seldom used for
thoughts, which are internal, or words, but for deeds, or courses of life in
scripture phrase; Yet is God to be acknowledged in them also.

Acknowledge him. See on Chap. 1.2. on the word, Know. For those whom we will
not acknowledge, we make the world believe, we know them not. Some understand
it of acknowledging God in the beginning of our works, or in the contriving of
them. To acknowledge him, as a Catholic enjoyner, or director, and not to dare
to go about any thing not agreeable to his word, nor in any way disagree able.

To take notice what God appoints to be done, and how, and to what end, and to
proceed accordingly, and commit the success to him, as a servant, or
letter-carrier does his business appointed, not taking care whether it be
likely to prove well or ill. Others understand it of acknowleding God in the
progress of our works. And that either as a perpetual overseer, which will
keep us from evil, and encourage us to good. So God bids Abraham, walk before
me, and be thou perfect. Genesis 17.1. Or as an enabler, without whom we can do
no good, nor get no good by what we do, and therefore pray to him for strength
to do what we undertake, and a blessing upon it: others interpret it of the
success of our works, if it be good, then to acknowledge God the giver of it,
or rewarder. If bad, then to acknowledge God the revenger, if we did ill, or
trier of our graces, if we did well, and speed ill. Under these heads come the
many interpretations of commenters. It is hard to say precisely, which is
intended. I conceive, Not the first, because he speaks not of the preparations
for our journey, but of the journey it self. Nor the last, for that is the end
of the way, not the way it self. Nor the first part of the second
interpretation taking God as an overseer. But the second part of it, looking to
him for all strength, which is a greater acknowledgment of him, as it is more
to enable one to do the work, then to look on, while he does it. Also it
agrees well with what went before. Trust in him only, and no way to thy self,
and so acknowledge all strength to be in him, and seek to him for it. It agrees
well with what follows.

And. That is, Then, when thou have so done, thou may boldly expect a good
issue from him of all thou do according to his will. So this particle is
translated, Then he is gracious unto him. Job 33.24.

He shall direst thy paths. For paths see on Chap. 1.19. on the word ways.
Some understand this of informing men, what they may lawfully do, and what
not. But it is better interpreted of relation to the end. He will make thy
ways to prosper, and give a comfortable success: So that here is not a bare
reward, but a suitable one. Acknowledge thou all thy strength to come from God,
and pray to him to assist thee, and he will bless thy labors, that thou shall
effect more then thou could expect.

Figures. Direct thy paths. A metaphor from a guide, that leads an ignorant man
in a right way to the place, to which he would go, but knows not, how to get
thither.

Note. 1. A precept.

2. A promise.

In the precept observe.

1. The Act. Acknowledge.

2. The Object. Him. The Lord mentioned, ver. 5.

3. The Adjuncts.

1. Of quality. In thy ways.

2. Of quantity. In them all.

In the promise note.

1. The blessing, Gods direction. And he shall direct.

2 The objects, Man's ways. Thy paths.

1. Doct. A good man's life is a journey. It appears by Peter's charge. Dearly
beloved, I beseech you, as strangers and Pilgrims, abstain from fleshly lusts,
which war against the soul. 1 Pet 2.11. It appears also by Paul's profession,
Brethren I count not my self to have apprehended: but this one thing I do,
forgetting those things, which are behind, and reaching forth unto those
things, which are before, I press toward the mark, for the price of the high
calling of God in Christ Jesus. Phil. 3.13, 14.

Reason. 1. In regard of the beginning of it. It begins as soon as grace is
wrought in the heart. Then comes the first step of our spiritual journey; Paul
converted went immediately about this journey, and conferred not with flesh and
blood to delay him.

In respect of motion. He is ever moving from one good duty to another, as a
traveller from one Town to another.

3. In regard of progress. He grows in knowledge, and grace, as a traveller
daily shortens his journey.

4. In respect of strangeness. Men marvel at a strangers habit, and carriage,
and he at theirs. So in piety. Wicked men think it strange, that godly men run
not with them into the same excess of riot. 1 Pet. 4.4. And godly men marvel
as much at the extravagant courses of wicked men. Paul and Barnabas seeing the
indolatry of the Lystrians rent their cloths, and cry out, saying, Sirs, why do
ye these things? Act. 14.14, 15.

5. In regard of peril. Strangers are exposed to dangers every where. So are
godly men. The Lystrians, that would have worshipped Paul as a God, presently
after at the persuasion of the Antiochians, and Iconians stone him. Act. 14.19.
He might well then by experience say, We must through much tribulation enter
into the Kingdom of God. Act. 14.22.

6. In respect of the aimed-at end, which is some rich, fair, or mart by the
traveller, Heaven by the godly man.

Use 1. Let us resolve to bear all the inconveniences of the way, wants, and
affronts. The end will pay for all.

2. Let us mind our end, and be diligent in our way, that we may be at rest,
and in happiness. So a merchant labors and travells in his youth to have
rest, and wealth in his' age.

2. Doct. A good man has many good actions of several good kinds to do. So a
traveller has fair paths, and foul, green, stony ways, and good store of
each to travel over. Rem. 12. All over contains several duties. The Gospel
teaches us to live soberly, righteously, and godlily in this present world.
Tit. 2.11.12.

Reason. 1. Many duties to God are to be done, as praying, hearing Gods word,
etc.

2. Many to our selves, as ruling our appetite, and anger.

3. Many to our fellow-travellers the Saints by the use of our spiritual, and
temporal talents.

4. Many to strangers, as worldly men, through whose Country we travel. We
must observe the rules of equity, and charity.

Use 1. Make no account of an idle life on earth. Many actions admit little
rest, as in Governors in War, and peace. An husbandman plows, harrows, sows,
gathers corn, threshes it, finds somewhat to do all the year long.

2. Please thy self with variety of employments. Go from private duties to
public, from common to holy. Thou shall have rest enough in Heaven.

3. Doct. A good man must look up to God for strength in his actions. Make me
to go in the path of thy Commandments. Incline my heart unto thy testimonies.
Psalm. 119.35, 36. Set a watch (O Lord) before my mouth: keep the door of my
lips. Psa. 141.3.

Reason. 1. Because the Fountain of all strength is with God. We are too weak
to think of a good work, much more to effect it. This is to acknowledge God in all our ways, when we confess we can do nothing without him, and therefore
must in all things depend upon him, pray to him, and trust in him. Iansenius.

2. Because then we may look for good success, and not else. for God being
neglected will cross and blast our strongest endeavors.

Use 1. Be frequent in prayer to God for a blessing, though thy businesses be
never so well contrived. Else thou will not thrive. If God drive not the
Chariot of the soul, the horses the affections will be too unruly for any man
to guide.

2. If any thing succeed well upon thy hearty prayer, and faithful endeavors,
acknowledge help found from God. So Paul; when he looks upon any good done by
him, straitway cries out, Not I, but the grace of God, which was with me. 1
Cor. 15.10. Let such thoughts be the ballast of the ship to humble thee in
great atchievments. So the Be carries what she gathers, or else little stones
upon her wings, that the wind blow her not away. So Paul and Barnabas call men
off from worshipping them to worship God. Act. 14.15. Ambros. Gregory on Revel.
3.10. sets out well the humility, and thankfulness of the Elders, Sibi
victorias non attribuunt, sed totum Deo ascribunt, qui vires ipsis ad vincendum
suggessit. They do not attribute their victories to themselves, but ascribe all
to God, who, gave them strength to overcome Pliny reports, that the Roman
General after a Victory, brought in his Garland, and laid it in Jupiters lap
in the Capitol. David does the like, speaking of his great preparations for
the building of Gods Temple, Who am I, and what is my People, that we should be
able to offer so willingly after this sort? for all things come of thee, and of
thine own have we given thee. 1 Chronicles. 29.14. He ascribes all to the true God.
Non magnum est humil^m esse in abjestione, sed magna prorsus, and rara virtus
humilitas honorata. Bern. in Cant. Ser. 33. It is no great matter to be humble
in a low estate, but it is certainly a great, and a rare virtue for men in
honor to be humble. Non mirum est, si ventus pulverem secum ferat, and rapiat;
Nos pulvis sumus. Anselm. de solitudine. No wonder, if the wind carry and
snatch away the dust with it. We are dust.

4. Doct. A good man must seek for strength from God, not in some of his
actions alone, but in all, even in the least. Without me ye can do nothing.
Ioh. 15.5.

Reason. The strength to do the least things is from God, even to breath. He
gives to all life, and breath, and all things. Act. 17.25. And he can take it
away, when he please, and so spoil all our actions. His breath goes forth, he
returns to his earth: in that very day his thoughts perish. Psalm. 146.4.

Use. It reproves those, who pray not to God for a blessing on their ordinary
labors. Only they seek unto him in difficult cases, when they are at their
wits end, as Seamen pray in a storm. Psalm. 107.27, 28. It may be they pray not,
before they work, and therefore God lets them be forty years, as the Israelites
in the Wilderness, about that which might be done in forty days.

5. Doct. Such as seek for Gods help may expect Gods blessing. Cail upon me in
the day of trouble. I will deliver thee. Psalm. 50.14. Jabez called on the God
of Israel, saying, Oh that thou would bless me indeed, and enlarge my
coast, and that thine hand might be with me, and that thou would keep me
from evil, that it may not grieve me. And God granted him, that which he
requested 1 Chronicles. 4.10.

Reason. 1. He will make thy ways right.

2. He will make them full, and complete.

3. He will make them successful.

Use. See the reason, why many men's ways prosper not. They go on in their own
strength. God is not in all their thoughts. Ps. 10.4. So Pharaoh went
desperately into the Sea, and was drowned. Ps. 136.15. They seek not for
strength from God, and God will not bless them.

6. Doct. The chief director of our ways for good is God. I have raised him up
in righteousness, and I will direct his ways: he shall build my City. Isa.
45.13. I will direct their work in truth. Isa. 61.8.

Reason. 1. Because the wisest man in the world cannot direct his own ways so,
as to make them always succeed well. O Lord I know that the way of man is not
in himself: it is not in man, that walks, to direct his steps. Ier. 10.23.

2. God has wisdom enough to guide us through all difficulties.

Use. Do nothing without Gods direction in his word. A man that had an house to
build, would in all things follow the direction of a skillful workman, lest he
lose his cost. So let us follow Gods guidance. Else all our labor is lost.
None desires to go astray out of his way, except he be first gone out of his
wits. Every man will rather take a guide to directhim the right way, and give
money to that end. If we be careful to acknowledge God in our ways, we shall
not wander out of them, for we shall have a trusty guide, who offers himself
freely in the Text, to direct our paths. God led the Israelites through the
wilderness, not the shortest but the safest way; So will God do for all them
that make him their guide. The Athenians conceived that their Goddess Minerva
turned all their evil counsels into good to them: the Romans thought their
Goddess Videlia set them again in the right way, when at any time they were
out. All this, and more then is undoubtedly done by the true God, for all that
commit their ways unto him, and depend upon him for direction and success.
Then may we conclude, This God is our God for ever and ever, he will be our
guide even unto death. Psalm. 48.14.

VER. 7. Be not wise in thine own eyes, fear the Lord, and depart from evil.
IN this verse is a scale of duties, consisting of three steps, Man's forsaking
his own wisdom, leads him to the fear of God; and the fear of God keeps him
from sin. A promise of health follows in the next verse; for the words, Be not
wise, See on Chap. 1.5. In thine own eyes. See on Chap. 1.17. on the word
sight. For the phrase, being wise in our own eyes, is being so in our own
conceit, as the Doway Bible reads it; and it comprehends these particulars
under it, that a man should not think himself sufficiently wise, so as by that
he should be able to guide himself in all his actions, to know what is right,
what wrong, what success will follow, good, or bad, and that he has a deeper
reach then other men, and is able to dive into the greatest matters. Solomon
does not say, be not wise, for then should he contradict other scriptures, and
himself too, that bid us labor for wisdom; his meaning is not then, that we
should not seek to understand scripture, and to be able to give a reason of all
we do, and know, when we judge aright of things, and when not; for that were to
make a man a beast, but that he should not think himself wiser then other
godly men, nor at any time oppose his own wisdom to God, and take heed always,
