praise of wisdom simply without comparison, it brings long life. Object. what
is a long poor life worth? Ans. She brings riches withal, Obj. Many a rich man
is sordid and despised. Ans. She brings honor also. Object. Many have all
these, yet live sadly by reason of sickness and pain. Ans. Her ways are
pleasant. Object. war spoils all comfort. Ans. All her paths are peace.
Object. yet death will take away all these. Ans. She is a tree of life.
Therefore I conclude as I began, with the happiness of the man that finds
wisdom: only I add this qualification, if he retain her, when he has found
her. For the words.

Happy. Or O the happiness of the man, etc. He begins his commendation of
wisdom with an exclamation, and admiration of the good it brings to men, which
Gods people wonder at, though others be blind and Iee it not: he had spoken
great things of the benefits of wisdom before, ver. 2. as bringing along
comfortable and peaceable life; but here he speak in higher language, it will
bring happiness, which is an affluence, or rather confluence of all good
things, and that for eternity. A man that has some good things may want other
to content him. If a man had all things that are good for him, but for a time,
fear of loss will afflict him, while he has them, and his grief will be the
greater when they are lost, by reason of his former experience of the
sweetness of them. A wise man is happy here, spe, in hope, he shall be happy
hereafter, re, in deed. He does not say, blessed is the wise man, but speaks by
a circumlocution, blessed is the man that finds wisdom, and the man that
gets understanding. So he compares the wise man to a man not left rich by
his parents, but grown rich by Gods blessing on his labors. Men count them
happy, that are grown rich by their own industry; God counts them happy that
labor for wisdom and do obtain it.

Is the man. Heb. Adam. For the word see on Verse 4. It is taken from the Earth
to put man in mind of his base Original.

That finds. Though the word sometimes signify to find a thing by accident
without looking after it, yet here it rather signifies getting it by labor, as
was noted before, and appears by the end of the verse. And Solomon's scope is to
persuade men to labor for it, because of the worth of it in it self, and the
good it brings to us. For the word, see on Chap. 1.13.2.5.

Wisdom. True, and heavenly wisdom, not humane acts, and sciences: they cannot
make a man happy. One may have much insight in them, and yet go to Hell. For
the word, see on Chap. 1.2. By wisdom here may be meant Jesus Christ the wisdom
of the father, as Chap. 8.

And the man. The same word in the Original, that was before.

That gets. The Hebrew word (...) signifies to draw out a thing, that lay
hid before, as desires out of the heart by effecting them. Further not his
wicked device. Heb. Draw not out. Psalm. 140.8. Or corn out of a Granary. That
our Granaries may be full affording all manner of store. Psalm. 144.13. or
drawing forth good will in the heart to plentiful relief with the hand. If
thou draw out thy soul to the hungry. Isa. 58.10. Some understand it here of
increasing knowledge, and drawing out some further truths out of those grounds
we know, by reason, or consequence. Others of drawing it forth into words to
instruct others. Others of drawing it forth into deeds by practice. But it is
rather to be understood of bringing it forth by study out of Gods word, and
works, wherein it is hid, as water in a well, or a treasure in the earth.

Understanding. See on Chap. 2.3.

Figures. Two Metaphors. One from finding a thing by enquiry, the other from
getting a thing by labor. Both show, that travail, and pains are to be used
to get wisdom. It will quit cost, nay, bring great advantage.

Note. 1. The Adjunct. Happy. Happinesseis a thing that all men desire, but
most men miss.

2. The Subject, set out.

1. In General. Is the man. 2. In particular by two similitudes. 1. From
seekers.
And therein note 1. The Act. That finds. 2. The Object. Wisdom. 2. From
traders. And therein see. 1. The Act. And the man that gets. 2. The Object.
Understanding.


1. Doct. Wisdom may be gotten out of Gods corrections. It is good for me, that
I have been afflicted, that I might learn thy statutes. Psalm. 119.71. Blessed
is the man, whom thou chastenest, O Lord: and teach him out of thy law.
Psalm. 94.12.

Reason. 1. Because it teaches us many things concerning God. And therefore it
is called by Patianus in Paraen. ad poenit. Re pertorium divinorum, and
inventarium cognitionis Dei. It is an Index of divine things, and an inventary
of the knowledge of God.

1. It is a repertory, or index of a Book, whereby the good things in the book
are readily found. Else men may seek long enough, and turn over the whole book,
and yet miss what they seek. So affliction brings to us many things of God, of
which in prosperity we take no notice. An Almanac also is a kind of repertory,
whereby men on the Earth see the Eclipses, and course of the Sun and Moon in
Heaven. So we in affliction see many things of God.

2. It is an Inventary. Lawyers require an Inventary of men's goods, wherein all
particulars must be written, that they may the better judge of their estates.
Afflictions make us look out, what good things there are in God for us to make
use of, in time of need. And

1. They show us Gods wisdom, and omniscience, that can find out our secret
fins, and chastise us for them. This Judah confesses, God has found out the
iniquity of thy servants. Genesis 44.16.

2. They show us Gods holiness, that cannot endure iniquity, but will chastise
his dearest children for sin.

3. Afflictions show us Gods justice, that will punish men for sin.

4. His power, that can punish the greatest sinners.

5. His mercy, that brings many to repentance by afflictions, that they may be
saved. So the prodigal son was brought home to his sathers house. Luke 15.1.

6. His truth, that so makes good all his threatenings by his judgments.

2. Affliction teaches us some good things concerning our selves. As

1. That we are sinful: We think our selves very good in our prosperity for
want of examination, Affliction is a glass, that makes us see the ugliness of
our sins, and to loath, and leave those sinful courses on which we formerly
doated.

2. That we are foolish, and like unwise children, that will not leave doing
evil, till we be whipped. They make us say with David, My wounds stink, and are
corrupt, because of my foolishness Psalm. 38.4. And so afflictions compel us
to go to God, in prayer to teach u^, what he would have us to do, and to
enable us to do accordingly.

3. Afflictions teach us some good things as in regard of others. As

1. That they must not be condemned for wicked men, because they are afflicted,
for then must we go to Hell for company

2. That they shall be pitied, and relieved in their sorrows, as we would be
in ours.

Use 1. It teaches us to bear afflictions patiently, looking more at the good,
that comes by them, then the pain, that comes from them. No chastening for the
present seems joyous, but grievous: nevertheless afterward it yields the
peaceable fruit of righteousness unto them which are exercised thereby. Heb.
12.11. So sick men, and wounded bear pills, and incisions in hope of recovery.
Although we be afflicted, yet if we be withal instructed, it is well. Vexatio
dat intellectum. Bought wit is dear. It may then be best prized. Schola crucis
schola lucis. Gods house of correction is his school of instruction. They do
well together, though seldom joined by men. (...). Correptiones correctiones.
Passions are instructions. Chastisements are corrections.

2. Let us take special notice, what good we get by afflictions: what we know
more of God, of our selves, or of others, and sin no more lest a worse thing
come unto us. John 5.14.

Doct. 2. Wisdom is to be admired. In God, O the depth of the riches both of
the wisdom and knowledge, of God. Romans 11.33. In men. When the Queen of Sheba
had seen Solomon's wise orders in his house, there was no more spirit in her. 1
King. 10.4. etc.

Reas. 1. We admire things for their nature, if it be more excellent then other
things, it takes off our eyes from them to view it, and our mind to consider
it: So the shining. Sun is more excellent then grass or flowers, we can see no
beauty in them but by it. Thus wisdom is admirable, it can do more then wealth
or strength, in taking towns, finding out secrets, guiding Souls to
happiness.

2. We admire things for their species or kind, if they be more excellent then
other things of the same nature: so we admire heavenly lights, Sun, Moon,
Stars, more then earthly, as Fire, Glow-worme, Candles: So we must admire
heavenly light in Gods word, more then all skill of Arts, though they also be
good, and useful in their kind.

3. We admire things more then others, according to their degree, though they
be of the same kind: among heavenly lights we most of all admire the Sun,
because it exceeds the Moon and Stars in brightness: so must we admire true
wisdom most, where there is most of it, as in ancient Professort, grave
Ministers, godly Magistrates, etc.

Use. It reproves our folly. We admire to see a poor man to have wit to get a
great estate, or a mean man to get honor by the wars, but we make no accouut
of such as abound in heavenly wisdom, therefore we get little or none of it
our selves, for intelligentiasapientiae admirationem ciere solet, and admiratio
desiderium ejus investigandae, et investigatio adeptionem parit, et adeptia
fruitionem, et ista fruitio beatos facit in suprem^ sort humani fastigit
constitutos. Recuperus, Understanding uses to stir up admiration of wisdom,
and admiration breeds a desire of searching for it, and searching breeds
obtaining, and obtaming brings forth fruition, and this fraitton makes men
happy, being placed in the highest condition of human preferment. Let us no
longer then measure a man's worth by his wealth, but by his wisdom: praise not
him that sells lead, and buys gold, but praise him that parts with money for
heavenly wisdom.

Doct. 3. What ever men think, God thinks wise men happy. Who so finds me,
finds life, and shall obtain favor of the Lord. Chap. 8.35. Finding wisdom,
is like finding treasures, yea, like finding life, without which treasures are
nothing worth; yea like finding Gods favor, without which, life is nothing
worth.

Reas. 1. Because Adam was both wise and happy before his fall, and foolish and
miserable after it.

2. Because there is no way to get true happenesse again, but by getting true
wisdom.

Use. See the folly of men; some count rich men happy, that enjoy such
treasures, as come within the compass of the senses; but happy is that people
whose God is their Lord. Psalm 144.15. Or rather, as it should be read, whose
God is Jehovah; For other Gods cannot make them happy. Si quid in opibus beatum
foret, illis dii carere nollent. If there were any happiness in riches, the
Gods would not want them. Seneca p. 74. Si ad naturam vivas, nunquam eris
pauper, si ad opinionem, nunquam dives, idem ep. 61. If thou live according to
nature, thou will never be poor, if according to opinion, thou will never be
rich. Others place happiness in honor or pleasure, but God places it in true
wisdom. Si honor beatos efficit, ubicunqu: est dignitas, ibi esset beatitudo.
At hoc falsum. Boet. de consol. l. 3. pros. 2. If honor make men happy, then
wheresoever dignity is, there should be happiness: But this is false. The
conclusion easily follows, therefore honor brings not happiness.

Doct. 4. Man should often think of his base beginning. God rubs up his memory
so soon as he had sinned, Dust thou art and unto dust shall thou return. Gen
3.19.

Reas. 1. Because it is a means to humble us, whereas looking upon us in our
height, will make us proud. A beggar extolled, and forgetful, will easily lift
up himself above others.

2. It is a means to make us thankful. A man raised from great poverty to great
wealth, is the more thankful, if he look upon his former wants.

Use. It reproves those, who neither of themselves are willing, nor that others
should mind them to think of their mean original. What! tell a strong man he
was once as weak as dust; or a beautiful woman, she was once as foul as dirt.
This is petty Treason. But they shall know it, when they come to die, though
now they will not.

5. Doct. Wisdom is hid from u^naturally. Professing t'emselves to be wise,
they became fools. Romans 1.22. This was spoken of the wise Philosopers among
the heathen.

Reason. 1. Because it is a punishment of the fall: We lost our wisdom, as we
did our holiness.

2. It appears by the variety of worships in the world, and the foolishness of
many of them: some worshipping storckes, and stones, and some the Devil, that
he may not hurt them.

Use. Pity poor ignorant creatures, that are wise to the World, and can get
great estates, but are fools to God. Luke 12.20, 21. And such were once not
some, but all of you. Therefoe have compassion on others.

6. Doct. Much pains must be taken to get wisdom. See much to this purpose on
Chap. 2, 3, 4. and on Chap. 4.1.

Reas. 1. Because of the worth of it. Impiger extremos currit mercator ad
Indos. The diligent Merchant runs to the utmost Indies for Gold. But wisdom is
more worth then all treasures, as will appear, when we come to the following
verses.

2. Because of the difficulty of attaining it. Which appears in that, there are
so few truly wise in the word.

Use Double your files. Be diligent in study of heavenly wisdom. And because
your strength cannot reach it, draw it out of the Fountain of Gods word by
study, and beg it earnestly of God in prayer. So shall ye be both wise and
happy.

VER. 14. For the Merchandise of it is better then the Merchandise of silver:
and the gain thereof then fine gold.
THE good that comes by wisdom is set out.

1. Comparatively by preferring it before the best trading and commodities in
the word. ver. 14, 15.

2. By the effects of true wisdom. ver. 16, 17, 18. In the former it is
preferred.

1. Before silver and gold. ver. 14.

2. Before rubies, ard all desirable things. ver. 15. The men of the world
think their happiness to consist in store of gold, and silver. But God
accounts it to be in wisdom, to which merchandise being compared, whereby pure
silver, and shining gold is gotten, ought to be had in no account.

For the words. For. See on Chap. 1.9.

The merchandise of it. The profit, that is gotten by it, or with it, as
Merchants lay out their money to get gain by it, and by the commodities
purchased with it. Merchandise is one of the most profitable trades in the
World, and the dearer the commodities, in which Merchants trade, the greater is
the gain. Therefore the gain gotten by wisdom here is compared to the richest
merchandise, yea, preferred before it to draw men's affections to pursue more
eagerly after spiritual, and heavenly wisdom. Ths word (...) fignifi^s a going
about or compassing of Sea or Land to get wisdom, as Merchants do for gain. So
the Pharisaicall Merchants did to get a Proselyte. Math. 23.15.

Is better. See on Chap. 2.9. on the word. Good.

Then the Merchandise. See before in this Verse.

Of Silver. See on on Chap. 2.4.

And the gain thereof. It is translated, Increase. ver. 9. For Merchandise
brings greater income, or increase, or benefit, then husbandry.

(...) Then fine gold. The word comes from cutting in the Original, either
because gold is, as it were, cut out of the Earth at first, or else because
after it is purified by the fire it is cut to make rings or Coin.

Figures. Two Metaphors. One in Merchandise: The other in gain. Merchants lay
out their money for gain: so may wisdom be improved to singular benefit.

Note. 1. The Trade.

2. The gain of it. Both set out by a comparison from precious things. A silver
trade is very profitable; a trade of wisdom is more profitable. Gold is
excellent; yet more is gotten by wisdom.

1. Doct. Men naturally seek still for increase of what good things they have.
So it is intimated in the text, that they who are wise, having obtained some
wisdom desire to increase it, as he that has gotten some worldly wealth by
Merchandise, desires the same way to increase it. God shows it by Parables
taken from men, as of the Vineyard. Isa. 5.1.1. etc Good fruit was looked for
from it. Of the talents Luk 19.11. Gain was expected thence.

Reason. 1. Because God has put into all living creatures a natural principle
of desire of increase, and growth, as in trees, and beasts.

2. Man has more help to put this principle in practice by the benefit of
reason.

Use. It condemns those that care not for increase in heavenly wisdom. It is an
ill sign, that nature is strong in them, and grace weak. We would grow in the
world, but not toward Heaven. We cross Solomon's scope here, which is to
persuade us to labor for increase in true wisdom.

2. Doct. Wisdom drives the greatest trade in the world. More to be desired
are (wisdoms precepts) then gold, yea, then much fine gold. Ps. 19.10. Wisdom
is better then rubies: and all the things, that may be desired, are not to be
compared unto it. Prove. 8.11.

Reason. 1. Because it trades in greater commodities, then any Merchant. In
souls of men, the last, and greatest commodity mentioned, Rev. 18.12, 13. one
whereof is more worth then a world, and the loss of it not to be recovered by
the gain of the whole world. Math. 16.26. when the quintessence, and spirits
are drawn out of herbs. and flowers, what are they good for? and how
comfortable and profitable are those extracted spirits? So men's souls are
immortal, their bodies without them are but dead carcasses.

2. This trade extends it self further, then any trade in the world. Silver
will pass in all Countries, Trades, Professions: Merchants can trade with it
by sea, and land, and all the world over. But wisdom trades in Heaven, and
Earth. We by it trade with God by prayer, he with us by heavenly inspiration.

Use. To persuade all to become wisdoms scholars. If any man could tell you of
a trade, that would in time put down all other trades, every man would be for
it. This trade will do it. Jesus Christ will put down the four great Empires of
the world, and wisdom will put down all worldly affairs in the end.

Doct: 3. Wisdom brings more profit then any worldly riches. My fruit is
better then gold (says wisdom) yea then fine gold, and my revenues then
choice silver. Chap. 8.19.

Reas. Because it brings better things then riches can. We esteem the goodness
of things by their own worth, or our esteem, or desire, or their effects. The
profit of wisdom is better then of riches.

1. In its own value. Nil aliud sunt aurum, et argentum, quam terra rubra and
alba. Gold and silver are nothing else, but red and white earth. Bern. Wisdom
is as much better then these things, for which men fight so stoutely, and which
they seek to obtain with such huge labor, as the good things of the soul are
better then outward things.

2. In men's esteem and account it is better, if they be wise. A dunghill Cock
may prefer a barley corn before a pearl, a Jeweller will not.

3. In regard of desire: it is more desirable, and should be more desired then
any thing in the world.

4. In regard of the effects of it.

1. It can quiet a man's mind, which no wealth can do. Rich men have many cares,
and griefs; Crowns are crowns of thor^^s, nothing but wisdom can give
tranquillity of spirit, and poize the ship of the soul in all tempests.

2. It affords a ladder to climb to eternal things, like Jacobs ladder, that
did reach from Bethel on earth, to Bethel (Gods house) in heaven. Men with
their money may perish, Act. 8. so may houses, stuff, fields, friends; but
unperishable things may be gotten by wisdom, no possession then, how large
soever, no store of gold or silver is comparable to wisdom.

Use. To engage us yet further in the search of true wisdom. We shall be rich
in God. Et quem ille divitem fecerit, nemo pauperem faciet. Cyprian. Epist. ad
Donatum. And whom God makes rich, no man shall make poor. Si aliqua amisistis
ga^dia, negotiatio est aliquid amittere, ut majora lucremini. Tertul. ad
Martyrs. cap. 2. If ye have lost some joys, it is a good trading to lose
somewhat, that ye may get greater matters. If men undergo so many labors,
griefs, wants, dangers of life for seeming riches, and gilded pearls, what
should we do for true riches? Si tanti vitrum, quanti verum margaritum? Tertul.
in Scorpiac. cap. 4. If glass be so dear, what is the true pearl? Sure that is
worth much more. We should think it no labor to take pains for wisdom. (...),
says a Father, while we gain, we feel no pain. Sing a song of profit, and men
will hearken. The Jassians in Strabo, delighted with the music of an excellent
harper, ran all away as soon as the marken bell rang, save a deaf old man, and
he went away also as soon as he heard of it. What is gold and silver, but the
guts and garbage of the earth? And what is all the pomp and glory of the world,
but dung and dogs meat? Phil. 3.7, 8 labor then more for wisdom, then for the
choicest silver, or for the finest gold, and be rich to eternity.

VER. 15. She is more precious then Rubies, and all the things thou can
desire, are not to be compared unto her.
THe wiseman in the former verse had preferred wisdom before silver and gold.
But some man might object, precious stones may be better then wisdom. No,
says Solomon, wisdom is of greater price then they. It might be further
objected, there may be more desirable things in the world then Rubies, though
we know them not, and they may be better then wisdom. He answers, nothing can
be more desirable then wisdom, of all things that can be imagined. For the
words.

She is more precious. Of greater value. For the word, see on Chap. 1.13.

Then Rubies. A precious stone of great price, and account, of a ruddy color.
It is likely our english word Ruby, comes from rubedo, redness in Latin. Her
Nazarites were more ruddy in body then Rubies. Lam. 4.7. If the mountains were
pearl, the huge rocks, rubies, and the whole globe a shining chrysolite, yet
all this were not to be named the same day with wisdom.

And all the things thou can desire. Heb. And all thy desires. That is, all
that thou can desire; or, any thing that thou can desire, be it the
choicest thing in the world. So (...) is used without a negative particle added
to it, though not observed by any Grammarian, or dictionary, that I have met
withal. Surely in vain the net is spread in the sight of any bird. Prove. 1.17.
It withers before any herb. Job 8.12. So that it is a climax from one
particular thing desirable to another still better, and better; but not a
general sum of all things desirable. By desire here is not meant the act of
desiring, but the thing desired, as the translation intimates. So faith is put
for the thing believed, and hope for the thing hoped for: What is the faith
once delivered to the Saints, Jude ver. 3. But the Doctrine of the Gospel, the
Object of faith? And what is the hope laid up for us in Heaven. Col. 1.5. but
the glory of Heaven, the object of hope?

Are not to be compared unto her. They are not equal to her, much less of
greater value. The value of things is best known by comparing them together.
Wisdom will appear to be better then whatsoever is laid against it. Figures.
Desires. Things desired. A figure of the adjunct for the object. Wisdom is
preferred

1. Before jewels.

2. Before all other desirable things in the world, if there be any thing
better then jewels.

1. Doct. Jewels and pearls are of great account among men. One may be better
then a merchants estate. The merchant sold all he had to buy one pearl of
great price. Mat. 13.44, 46. Therefore are they called precious stones. Rev.
18.12.

Reas. 1. Because of their beauty. They are of diverse colors, and very
specious.

2. Because of their virtue. They are good to stench blood, and heal diseases.

3. Because of their price. A little silver is worth more then much coin. A
little Gold then much silver. A precious stone then much Gold.

Use. Let us see and admire Gods power, and wisdom, that has put so much
beauty, virtue, value into a little stone. A fly is more wonderful then an
Elephant. It has eyes, wings, body, feet in a little compass. In artificial
things many faces in a cherry stone are most admired, and such like other small
things. It is a wonder to see so much virtue within a little glass of strong
waters. Give the great God all the glory.

2. Doct. The best things in the world are not comparable unto wisdom, How much
better is it to get wisdom then gold? and to get understanding rather to be
chosen then silver? Chap. 16.16. See Job 28.15, 16, 17, 18, 19. verses.

Reason. 1. Because wise men have really so esteemed wisdom, and parted with
all for it, as in the parables of the treasure, and pearl. Math. 13.44, 45,
56. and in Paul's account, and practice, who had suffered the loss of all
things for it. Phil. 3.7, 8. They would not cast away outward comforts, if they
looked not for better in so doing. Ye took joyfully the spoiling of your goods,
knowing in your selves, that ye have in heaven, a better, and an enduring
substance. Heb. 10.34.

2. Because it loses nothing by communicating to others. The more money we
give, the less we have: but it is not so in communicating wisdom. It is like
the Sun, that has given light to all men since the world began, and is as
bright still, as ever it was. Hence comes the Arabian Proverb, Get Wealth in
measure, but wisdom without measure. Get as much wealth as may serve for this
life, but get wisdom in infinitum.

3. Because it cannot be taken away from us, as wealth, honor, pleasures may:
and therefore while we have it, we are both rich and happy. Omnia mea mecum
porto. All mine I carry with me, said Bias, giving a reason, why he carried
none of his goods out of his Country, as counting nothing his own, but his
wisdom, which the Enemies could not take from him.

4. It alone can satisfy the soul. Wealth, and all worldly comforts cannot
give content. He that loves silver, shall not be satisfied with silver, nor he
that loves abundance with increase. This is also vanity. Eccl. 5.10. Wisdom
contains all treasures virtually in it self. Rich men have not all good
things. Concupiscentia plus long stimulatur ab his, quas nondum peperit, quam
parts expletur. Salazar. Concupiscence is more stung with the things it has
not gotten, then satisfied with what it has. But men may say with David, I
have rejoiced in the way of thy testimonies, as much as in all riches. Psalm.
119.14.

Use. To condemn the folly of those men, who endanger life, and soul for
transitory wealth, and neglect that which is far more precious then any riches.
This argues blindness, and blockishnesse. For such men see not that wisdom is
more worth seeking, then all sublunary comforts. Delights, and riches are
perishing comforts, and nothing in comparison of heavenly wisdom.

Doct. 3. Nothing can be imagined that is comparable to wisdom. So Solomon
thought, who being put to his choice, desired nothing else of God. 2 Chronicles.
1.7. etc. So Paul thought, who desired not to know any thing save Jesus Christ
the wisdom of the Father. 1 Cor. 2.2. A man may desire meat, drink, silver,
gold, yea his fancy can imagine new worlds, but all is not comparable to true
wisdom.

Reas. 1. Because none of those things man can imagine, or devise, or desire,
can free him from Hell. No ransom can do it, nor force. It is a warning from
Heaven must direct us how to escape Hell: Who has warned you to flee from the
wrath to come? Math. 3.7. Sure none but God.

2. No such thing can show us the way to Heaven. Only true wisdom out of Gods
word can do it. The scriptures only can make a man wise unto salvation. 2 Timothy
3.15.

Use. Cease desiring, and imagining how to find out means of happiness in the
World, and labor for true wisdom, which only can make thee happy. A diver
that stops his breath longest, gets most pearls; so he that breaths least for
the world, gets most wisdom.

VER. 16. Length of days is in her right hand, and in her left hand riches and
honor.
LEst any man should think, that wisdom were needy and beggarly her self, and
could not bestow upon her fellows the riches promised, she shows now, that she
knows, what humane infirmity most needs, and what men most desire, and has in
a readiness to bestow on them. Thou fear death, poverty, dishonor. Wisdom
has long life, riches, honor to bestow upon thee, if thou entertain her.
Wisdom, or the Lord Jesus Christ is here set out unto us like some stately
Queen, sitting on a Throne with both hands full of good things to reward her
faithful servants. The particular rewards shall be expounded in the words.

Length of days. A long life, see on Verse 2. This is the first thing
promised, because it is the principal; and riches and honor are but
accessaries, and can afford no comfort, if life be taken away, and but little,
if life be short. And therefore also it is said to be in the right hand, as the
principal gift she has to bestow. Men most of all desire long life, and
riches and honor in the second place; they could be content to live, though
poorly, though in pain, rather then to die; they desire long life more then
riches, and fear death more then poverty. There is no merchandise in the world,
how good soever, nor pearls, how precious soever they be, that can assure us
of long life. But the greatest traders are most afraid to die, as having more
to lose then other men; and their death is more desired then other men's: yea,
many lie in wait to kill them, for their riches: But wisdom will bring long
life with it.

Is in her right hand. This is said to be in the right hand, because the right
hand is preferred before the left, and that for these reasons.

1. Because it is ordinarily, and in most men the strongest, and nimblest.

2. Motion begins at the right hand. Porters lay their burden on the left
shoulder, because the right leg moves first. Aristot. de gressu animal.

3. The right hand is for defense, we fight with it.

4. It is the place of honor. Bathshebah was set on Solomon right hand. 1.
King. 2.19.

5. It is used as a token of faithfulness, we give it in marriage and
contracts.

6. It is used to set out good success, as the left hand for bad. Saepe
sinistra cava praedixit ab ilice cornix. The Raven often fortold left handed
(that is, bad) things from the hollow Oak. Though in the Greek (...) the left
be used, for good success. It seems the fashion of those countries was to
prefer the left hand, as Xenophon reports, who says, they used to place their
guests at the left hand, as being nearest the heart. Now in the Law, earthly
comforts were types of heavenly: So was long life to an obedient child in the
fifth commandment a type of heaven, else it were but a small blessing to live
long here, and then go to hell for ever. Longitude dierum ^ter^itas est, Non
enim hic aliquid longum esse potest in tanta brevitate. Length of days is
eternity. For nothing can be long here in so much brevity. Recuperus. With long
life will I satisfy him, and show him my salvation. Psalm. 91.16. In senseless
creatures, long continuance is but a continuance of being,, not of comfort, as
in man, but not in rocks; the one is aeternitas, the other aeviternitas. (...),
Isid. Pelus. l. 3. ep. 149 Eternity is eternal life. (...) is used.

1. For a right hand. Though Coniah were the signet upon my right hand. Jer.
22.24.

2. For power and strength, which is exercised commonly with the right hand.
Thy right hand, O Lord, has dashed in pieces the enemy. Exodus 15.6.

3. For the South; because a man standing with his face to the rising Sun, has
the south on his right hand: And southern countries are more fertile, northern,
on the left hand more barren. Omne malum ex Aquilone. All evil out of the
North. The North, and the South, thou have created them. Psalm. 89.12.

4. For Oaths or Covenants, which were confirmed with the right hand. Their
right hand is a right hand of falsehood. Psalm. 144.8. That is, they kept no
covenants. Here it is taken in the first sense.

And in her left hand. Riches and honor are said to be in wisdoms left hand,
because though useful, yet not so useful, or good, as life it self. The word
(...) signifies

1. The left hand. Toward Isreal's left hand. Gen 48.13.

2. The North, because it is on the left hand, if ones face be toward the
rising Sun. On the left hand of Damascus. Genesis 14.15. that is, on the North
side of it. Here it is taken in the first sense.

Riches. Money, and lands, and temporal possessions. These also are types of
all sufficiency in heaven, as Canaan, the land flowing with milk and honey was.

And honor. The word (...) signifies respect from others: it comes from a word
that signifies to be heavy, or weighty, for honor, as it arises from the
weight of good qualities in men, so it adds weight to men persons, and makes
them of greater account then others; and this also may be a type of heavenly
glory. Yet good men oftentimes neither have long life, riches, nor honor.
Temporal promises are conditional, and to be performed, as they may stand with
Gods glory, and our good, and what is wanting, shall abundantly be made good in
heaven. Wisdom does not bestow these earthly blessings always on her
followers, yet oftentimes she does: wisdom is the ready way to obtain these,
and many thereby come from a poor and low estate, to a plentiful and high
condition, and enjoy it long in this world. The sum of all is, God rewards
his with both hands, promising eternal life, and competent means in this life.
Christ, the wisdom of the Father is immortal, he has overcome death, and
with his immortal hand, holds forth immortality to us. If thou will have
riches and honor, be wise, and he will hold out his left hand and bestow them
on thee, if they be fit for thee.

Figures. The whole verse is metaphorical in the principal scope of it, though
verified literally to some wise and good men: It intimates, that as a Queen
has greater or lesser rewards for her servants, so has wisdom for hers: For
she has no right hand nor left, but diversity of gifts, some greater, some
lesser, some in this world, some in the world to come.

Note. 1. The greater gift.

2. The lesser.

In the former observe

1. The gift. Length of days. Long life.

2. The worth of it, Is in her right hand. It is a right handed gift.

In the latter, note

1. The gift it self, which is double, And riches, and honor.

2. The value of it, In her left hand. It is a left handed gift, useful, but
of lesser value then the former.

Doct. 1. Many good things attend upon true wisdom. This is proved in this
Chapter, from Verse 14. to verse 18.

1. Comparatively, it is better then silver, yea then fine gold, yea then
Rubies, yea then any thing imaginable, or desirable.

2. Particularly, she brings long life, and riches to sweeten that, and honor
to make it more acceptable, and pleasantness to comfort against crosses, and
peace for quiet enjoyment of what we have; and life after death, when all
worldly comforts fail.

3. Summarily. It brings happiness, which contains all good things in it. So
he concludes. ver. 28. as he began. ver. 13. with happiness attending on true
wisdom, if it be not only laid hold on, but retained.

Reason. Many good things attend on wisdom.

1. By way of concomitancy. As beads, and pearls hang many on one string, and
many lesser attend upon one greater, so other good things are joined with, and
attend upon wisdom.

2. By what way of efficiency. Wisdom has a plotting head. If any good thing
be to be had, it will find it out, and reach it.

3. By way of remuneration from God. So God rewarded Solomon's desire of wisdom
with riches, and honor. 2 Chronicles. 1.7. etc.

Use. Who would not enjoy many good things? Go then the nearest way to the
wood: get true wisdom. He that knew, what would be dear, need be a Merchant
but a year. If one told you of a commodity would make you rich, ye would get
store of it quickly. Do so of wisdom.

2. Doct. Wisdom brings long life. See on ver. 2. and on ver. 8.

Reason. 1. Because wisdom foresees, what is profitable to prolong, or
hurtful to shorten men's days, and carefully provides the one, and avoids the
other.

2. Because it rules our unruly passions of fear, grief, anger, which overrule
many men, that want wisdom, and bring them early to their grave, by murderers,
robberies, wantonness, gluttony, drunkenness, surfets, palsies, gouts,
plurises, Apoplexies, and afterward send them to Hell for ever. But wisdom
makes men stout, cheerful, patient, which virtues help to prolong men's days.

3. Because it teaches a man temperance, and moderation, in the use of meat,
and drink, which keeps men from surfeit, and is the mother of health, and long
life. Experience shows, that temperate men live longest.

4. Because of Gods promise of long life to such as are wise, as in the text.

Use. Let this particular mercy also stir us up to seek after true wisdom.
Long life is a sweet mercy, and generally desired Seek it in the ways of
wisdom. Folly brings many to untimely ends.

3. Doct. Wisdom brings riches also. Abraham Isaac, Jacob, Joseph, David were
both wise, and rich.

Reason. 1. Because wisdom teaches a man to make conscience to labor in his
calling, which is the high way to riches. He knows that God requires it, and
his family, the Church; and the Commonwealth.

2. Gods blessing follows it. For when he gives one blessing, he gives another.
If he give wisdom, he can afford riches.

Use. To blame those, that would be rich, but care not for being wise. Wisdom
can make men rich; but riches cannot make men wise. It is often observed, that
the elder brotheri carry away the land, and the younger the wit. So God divides
his gifts, when he please. They that seek money before wisdom, count learning
the way to beggary. But God reckons otherwise.

4. Doct. Wisdom brings honor also. We see it in Joseph, who for his wisdom
was made ruler over the land of Egypt. Genesis 41.38, 39. And Daniel for the same
reason was made ruler over the whole Province of Babylon. Dan. 2.48.

Reason. 1. Because God has cut out such, and stamped them for honor, which
he will not give to fools, that know not how to use it, or to carry themselves
suitably. Honor is not seemly for a fool. Prove. 26.1. He will do hurt with it,
as a stone in a sling. Prove. 26.8.

2. God causes great men, and states to advance such, for they know, they will
be fit instruments for their service, and the public good.

3. Good men will honor wise men, who know best, what belongs to honor.

Use. To blame those who look not after that honor, that wisdom brings, but
seek to get honor by baseness, flattery, and humouring others in sinful
ways. This honor hangs on a rotten bough. It will surely fall. Seek rather by
wisdom to get honor, which will last for ever.

5. Doct. Long life is better then riches, or honor. Therefore it is mentioned
as the greatest promise. With long life will I satisfy him, and show him my
salvation. Psalm. 91.16. This crowns all the former mercies mentioned in that
Psalm. This is commended in good men at their death, when no mention is made
of riches, or honor: Abraham died in a good old age, an old man, and full of
years. Genesis 25.8. It is there doubled, yea, trebled in different expressions as
a singular mercy, never to be fogotten.

Reason. 1. Because long life is the basis, and foundation of the comfort of
both the other. Riches and honor do little good, or bring little comfort,
where life is short. Life is an internal principle, without which there is no
comfort in external things, no more then to a jewel set in gold.

2. Because long life may be comfortable without either riches or honor. Many
live very cheerfully too, and in old age, that never had any great means, or
preferment.

Use. To comfort us against the crosses, and infirmities of old age. Many are
dejected, because they are not so much respected, nor so rich as others. Think
with thy self, long life is better. These could do thee no good, if life were
gone, and thou may have comfort without them.

6. Doct. Riches and honor are blessings in themselves, though by many abused.
They are wisdoms gift. Riches, and honor are with me. Chap. 8.18. They are
Gods gift. I will give thee riches, and wealth, and honor. 2 Chronicles. 1.12.

Reason. 1. Because they are reckoned up amongst those blessings, that God
gives to them, that obey him. Them that honor me I will honor. 1 Samuel 2.30.
It comes in among blessings promised to Gods obedient people. Deuteronomy. 28.2. etc.

2. The contraries are reckoned amongst Gods curses. See Deuteronomy. 28.17.33.44.

Use. To reprove those, that turn blessings into curses: Of whom we may say, it
had been good for them, if they had never been rich, nor honorable. There is a
sore evil which I have seeen under the Sun, namely, riches kept for the owners
thereof to their hurt. Eccl. 5.13. And the like had Solomon observed concerning
honor, There is a time', wherein one man rules over another to his own hurt
Eccl. 8.9. Such riches and preferment be far from Gods people. Amen.

VER. 17. Her ways are ways of pleasantness: and all her paths are peace.
HEre is another motive to get wisdom: would thou go in pleasant ways, and
live in peace, and quietness? All wisdoms ways are such. The man who gets
wisdom, gets true happiness, and delight. When Merchants go by Sea, or
passengers by land, they are glad, when they find fair way, and a quiet
passage. They desire not to be staid, nor hindered in their journey, but to go
at ease without any disturbance, which yet sometime they miss. But such as
walk wisely, find ways of pleasure, and peace. These words are fitly knit to
the former, for long life, and riches, and honor are not sufficient to make a
man happy. He may meet with many occasions of sorrow, and of War, and trouble,
which may make his life very uncomfortable. Here therefore Solomon adds to the
former blessings, pleasure, and peace, to show, that nothing is wanting to a
wise man. He had commended wisdom before ex part termini, from happiness in
the end: now he commends it ex part medii, from the comfort of the way. The
allective power of wisdom is set out in this verse, the conservative in the
next.

For the words.

Her ways Her precepts, or the walking in them. For the word see on Chap. 2.13.

Are ways of pleasantness. Very pleasant ways, and such as men may walk in
with delight, like green fields full of flowers, the pleasure whereof makes a
man forget his weariness, and come to his journies end, before the be aware.
They are no way tedious, though they be never so long. Wisdom is the true Naomi
(for so the Hebrew word sounds) whose beauty may allure all to it: but never
will be turned into a Marah, bitterness, as she was. Ruth 1.20. For the word
see on Chap. 2.10.

And all. Secon Chap. 1.13. Or Any. Take which of them you will, even the
hardest, you cannot choose amiss: it will bring peace. See on Verse 15.

Her paths. See on Chap. 1.15.

Are peace. Are paths of pea^^, that a man may walk in peaceably, and that lead
to true and lasting peace; thereby is meant, that they are not only pleasant,
but also safe and prosperous. Many pleasant ways on earth may be unsafe, as
robbing ways, and many safe ways unpleasant, as dirty ways; but wisdoms
ways are pleasant and safe. Kabvenaki. For the word, see on Verse 2.

Figures. A metaphor in ways, and paths, which signify a constant course.

Note 1. A promise of comfort.

2. Of peace and prosperity.

In the first note.

1. The subject, whose ways are comfortable. Her ways. Wisdoms ways, not
follies.

2. The adjunct showing what they are, Are ways of pleasantness. Not
profitable only, but delightful also.

In the second observe.

1. The Subject. And her paths. That is, the paths of wisdom.

2. The Adjunct of quantity. All of them.

3. The Adjunct of quality. Are peace. They are peaceable, and prosperous.

1. Doct. Nothing is wanting to a man truly wise. This text with the coherence
proves it abundantly: what would a wise man have? would he have long life? Here
it is. If riches, here also. If honor, it is ready for him. If pleasure, it is
at hand. If peace, it is prepared for him. If health, lo here it is. If
happiness it self, the wise man offers it first and last. Verse 13.18.

Reason. 1. Because of Gods favor. Wise men are Gods favorites. And what may
not Princes favorites have in a Nation.

2. Because of Gods promise to such as walk uprightly, as wise men do, that no
good thing shall be withheld from them. Ps. 84.11. To such as fear him, There
is no want to them. Psalm. 34.9. And that wise men do. The fear of the Lord is
the beginning of wisdom. Chap. 1.7. Lions, strongest creatures shall lack and
suffer hunger; which if the world afford food, they will not do: but they that
seek the Lord (as all truly wise do) shall not want any good thing. Psalm.
34.10. They can lack nothing that can God give.

3. Because of their capacity, and industry to get good things. If any know
how, and be willing to take pains to get good things, wise men do. They lie
not in a ditch, and cry God help. They know, that will not do it.

Use. Here is a further encouragement to labor for wisdom. Who would not be
in such a state to want nothing that is good? Jacobs condition is better then
Esaus in the original, and better then your translation makes it, which makes
them both alike, for in it both say I have enough but in the Hebrew. Esau
says, (...) I have much, Jacob says (...) I have all. Genesis 33.9.11. And so he
had indeed for he had God, and all. An unwise man may have many good things; a
wise man has all.

2. Doct. Wisdom has ways of her own. So had wise Solomon strange ways to
the Queen of Shebah. She admires them. 1 King. 10.5. And Christ had strange
ways to the Jews, who much strange at them. Matthew. 11.9.

Reason. 1. It appears in humane wisdom. The ways of Lawyere, Physltians,
Mathematicians, Archiects, are strange to others.

2. And principally in heavenly wisdom. Her ways are strange to Philosophers,
whose rules reach but to morality. Strange to Heretics, who set up themselves,
not God by all their practices, and opinions. Strange to carnal Gospellers,
who must have pleasure, or profit with profession of religion. Strange to
Hypocrites, who would be accounted godly, though they be Atheists in heart.

Use. Here is a touchstone to try, whether we be truly godly or no. Are our
ways sinful, and worldly, or holy, and heavenly. This will try us. We must
not be watermen in religion, loook one way and row another.

3. Doct. One wise action suffices not, but all must be guided by wisdom;
Else we shall shame our selves. Dead flies cause the ointment of the Apothecary
to send forth a stinking savor: so does a little folly him, that is in
reputation for wisdom, and honor. Eccl. 10.1. It was Jehus shame, that when he
had destroyed Baal out of Israel, he departed not fnom the sins of Jeroboam the
son of Nebat, who made Israel to sin. 2 King. 10.28, 29.

Reason. 1. Because no man shall be tried at the day of judgment by any one
act, but by the course of his life: so good men judge of men's estates here. An
Hospital built cannot save a murderer from the gallows.

2. Many foolish actions outweigh one wise one; a fool may speak or do wisely
sometimes, yet is not therefore deemed wise.

Use. Here is a second trial of true wisdom, if it appears not sometimes, but
in the course of our lives, not in some one action, but in all, or in the most:
one Swallow makes not a Summer, nor one good Apple, a good Apple Tree.

Doct. 4. There is much true delight in wisdoms ways. My yoke is easy, and
my burden is light. Mat. 11.30. More to be desired are they then gold, yea then
much fine gold; sweeter also then honey and the honey comb. Psalm. 19:10. Some
ways are pleasant in the passage, but bitter in the end, others foul in the
passage, but comfortable in the end; wisdoms ways are pleasant in both.

1. In the way, and that 1. Spiritually. And therein.

1. Because they are wrought in God, and by Gods strength all along. John 3.21.
Principium, vector, dux, semita, terminus idem. God is the beginning, carier
on, guide, way, and end of good men's actions: No marvel then if he give them
comfort in them.

2. They are lovely in themselves, and have in them all things that may afford
true delight, but nothing loathsome to raise dislike; sinful foolish courses on
the contrary, have much in them to affright, nothing to delight.

3. They have nothing truly difficult in them, though they may seem to men to
have. Smooth ways have nothing in them to make men stumble, yet men may slip
by carelessness in the smoothest way. Here is no offering up of children in
Gods ways, which the heathen did to false Gods: yea, it is now smoother then
the Jews way was in the old Testament; no painful Circumcision, nor extreme
costly Sacrifices, no thousands of Rams, nor ten thousand rivers of Oil. Mic.
6.7.

4. They have pramium ante praemium, a reward beforehand. Much comfort in wise
actions, while they are in doing them, as in praying, singing, giving, etc.
some degree of comfort follows every good action, as heat follows fire, as
beams of light, and influences come from the shining Sun. The heathen found
some comfort in moral actions, Christians may find more in spiritual
employments. In keeping of them there is great reward. Psalm. 19.11.

2. As in spiritual, so in temporal things, wise men find much comfort in
their ways, when fools bring sorrow upon themselves. Likewise in the end, as
well as in the way, wise men find comfort; yea, more in the end then in the
way: the hope of heaven makes the way comfortable, although it should be
tedious in it self, and meet with many rubs.

Use. This should encourage us, not only to seek to know wisdoms ways, but
also to walk cheerfully in them, in despite of all discouragements.

If any object, it is difficult to get the knowledge of those ways, and much
more difficult to walk in them.

The answer is, there is pleasure in them as well as profit, and that will make
them easy and delightful. Omne tulit punctum, quimiscit utile dulci. Join
profit and pleasure together, and men will never talk of difficulty. Now wisdom
makes a marriage of profit with pleasure; her ways may seem difficult at
first, by reason of the corruption of the flesh, but when the first brunt is
over, they prove easy and pleasant, whereas the ways of folly are pleasant at
first, and bitter at last. Let us therefore admire at wisdoms ways, get the
knowledge of them, practice them, and rejoice in them.

Doct. 5. Peace attends upon wisdoms ways. Mark the perfect man, and behold
the a pright, for the end of that man is peace. Psalm. 37.37. Now none but men
truly wise, are perfect, and upright.

Reas. 1. They bring inward peace of mind, and quietness: Men's own follies do
more distract them, then other men's malice, or plots against them. God gives
wisemen quietness of mind, both in prosperity and adversity; it is contrary
with worldly men, they have no rest in their minds, nor are not pleased in any
condition, but godly wisemen are quiet in every estate.

2. They bring outward peace: wisdom teaches men how to avoid occasions of
quarrels, by which foolish men are ruined.

3. They bring peace with God, which is best of all, for it brings men to the
knowledge of Christ, the only reconciler of God and man, and so affords that
peace, which the world cannot give. Ioh. 7.27. and which passes all
understanding. Phil. 4.7. and so drives all storms out of the conscience,
assuring believers, that they have peace with God. Romans 5.1. And that there is
no condemnation to them. Romans 8.1.

4. Peace with our neighbors. For it teaches us to give every one their own.
And what ground have they then to quarrel with us? yea, if they do us hurt, it
teaches us to do them good. And this is the way to quench all fire of
contention.

5. It shows us the way to eternal peace by Christ our Savior, that we may
walk on quietly to Heaven, while others contend for inheritances on Earth. Thus
it brings peace external, internal, eternal, and makes not only the end
pleasant, but also the way. And as travelers in their weary journeies comfort
themselves not only with thoughts of rest at night, but also with comfortable
objects in the way, so do men truly wise joy here in the thought of Heaven
hereafter.

6. They are ways prescribed by God, who is, The God of peace. Heb. 13.20.

1. Object. How can wise, and godly men have external peace, when all that
will live godly in Christ Jesus must suffer persecution. 2 Timothy 3.12.

Answ. 1. They have not always times of persecution, but sometimes peace.

2. God gives them such a valiant spirit, that they overcome all opposition, as
the Martyrs did the fire.

2. Object. How can they have internal peace, when as long as they live, they
have civil wars within? The flesh lusts against the spirit, and the spirit
against the flesh: and these are contrary the one to the other, so that ye
cannot do the things that ye would. Gal. 5.17.

Answ. 1. These wars tend to peace: yea, they are a sure token of eternal
peace, in the end: for there is no such combat in the souls of wicked fools.

2. In the midst of these wars there is peace with God: and then these
conflicts may be counted as nothing, as when a man has peace with Giants, and
is at war with Pigmies.

3. Ob. But how can they be sure of eternal peace in the end; when God
sometimes frowns upon them, and they are forced to cry out, Has God fogotten
to be gracious? Psalm. 77.9.

Answ. This is but sometimes, when God will correct, or try them. But he brings
them back again, and makes them to say. This is mine infirmity, O the years of
the right hand of the most high! Psalm. 77.10. This is more passionate, and
emphaticall, then to add, But I will remember, as the Translation do.

4. Ob. But we are always in danger of temptations. We walk between two
extremes of sin, and are waylaid by Devils, and ungodly men, like travelers,
that pass between two Countries at war one with another, where the ways are
full of robbers. How can our ways then be peaceable, walk we never so wisely?

Answ. They are peaceable, not that they free us from all opposition; But

1. Because they keep us safe in the midst of all opposition. Country-Villages
are subject to plundering in war, but strong Castles are safe, so long as they
want not provision, not ammunition.

2. Because they lead us to a quiet end for ever, when these storms are all
gone, and over; who ever perished in these ways? A whole world died by foolish
ways, as in the flood, when Noah walking in these ways escaped. Genesis 6.13, 14.

Use. To show us the vast difference between godly, and fleshly wisdom. The
former brings lawful pleasure, and certain peace. The latter brings sorrows,
and troubles upon men's minds, bodies, estates here, and for ever by their own
plots. True wisdom goes no where, but all her ways are strowed with pleasure,
and walled in with peace.

6. Doct. No way of wisdom breeds trouble in it self. See David's wisdom in
ordering his for the preventing of trouble in his family, in the City, and in
the Land. Psalm. 101. It may be by accident trouble may attend on the wisest
ways by reason of corruption in others, and our selves, for wisdom is
imperfect in us, and them, but that comes not from wisdom, but from lack of it.

Reason. 1. Because the ways of wisdom are just ways

2. They are merciful ways. Justice and mercy bring not troubles naturally,
but injustice and cruelty.

Use. See the cause of all our troubles, want of wisdom. Bewail it, and beware
for time to come.

VER. 18. She is a tree of life to them, that lay hold on her, and happy is
every one, that retains her.
SOlomon goes on to set out the commendation of wisdom, that he may allure men
to seek the more earnestly after her. He had set out her excellency by silver,
gold, pearls, She is silver to poor men, gold to Noble men, and Pearls to
Princes. Aeneas Silvius. See Acts and Monuments in the end of the reign of
Henry 6.2. Edit. Now he sets out wisdoms excellency

1. By comparing her to the tree of life.

2. By promising happiness to them, that get, and keep her. For the words.
She. Wisdom spoken of ver. 13. and compared to a rich, and beautiful Queen.
ver. 16.

Is a tree of life. Like to a living tree, that brings forth store of pleasant
fruit to delight and preserve the life of the eaters. Or more particularly, as
most writers agree, it is an allusion to the tree of life in Paradise. Genesis
2.9. which was a sign to Adam, that he should live for ever. Genesis 22. and that
in health, strength, and comfort upon Earth, if he sinned not. So wisdom
restores us to that we lost in Adam, eternal life, but in a better place in
Heaven. The word (...) signifies.

1. Dry wood, such as we burn. Behold the fire and the wood. Genesis 22.7.

2. A tree, from which wood uses to be cut. He shall be like a tree planted by
the rivers of water. Psalm. 1.3.

3. A stick, or table of wood to write on. Take thee one stick, and write upon
it. Ezekiel. 37.16.

4. An Idol of wood. Saying to a stock (or, wood) thou art my Father. Jer. 2.27.

5. A pair of gallows. Pharach shall hang thee on a tree. Genesis 40.19.

6. A wooden vessel. In vessels of wood. Exodus 7.19.

7. The staff of a spear. The staff of whose spear was like (...) a weavers
beam. 2 Samuel Sam. 21.19. Here it is taken in the second sense for a green and
fruitful tree. (...) Life is the d^all number, for there is a life here, and a
life in heaven, as (...) waters above the firmament, and below, and (...) the
heavens starry and aerie.

To them that lay hold upon her. The word (...) signifies a fa^ laying hold on
a thing, as ones own, and as not willing to let it go.

And. Or Then. Or Therefore. A conclusion drawn from the former words. If she
bring eternal life, then without question all that retain her are happy.

Happy. He shall walk on prosperously, for so much the word imports.

Is every one that retains her. Heb. They that retain her, he is blessed. A
participle singular, with a plural. That is, every particular man of them is
happy. See the like, Numb. 24.9. Blessed is he that blesses thee. Wisdom does
not only preserve men's lives, as a tree of life, but also makes men happy: but
this happiness is not to every one, as fruit does not do good to them that
that look on it, or touch it, or smell to it, but that gather, cat it, and
digest it: So wisdoms fruit does no good to them that seek it slightly, or
think a little enough but to them that take pains to get, and care to keep it,
that will not let her go till they have sound out the depth of her creasure,
that observe all her commands, even the least, and persevere in so doing to the
last. The word (...) signifies sometimes to lay fast hold, so as not to part
with a thing. Judgment and justice take hold on thee. Job 36.17. Sometimes to
uphold a thing. Thy right hand upholdeth me. Psalm. 63.8. Here it is taken in
the first sense, for laying fast hold on wisdom, as meaning never to part with
it: It cannot be taken in the second sense for upholding wisdom, for it upholds
us, not we it.

Figures. A metaphor in the Tree of life. Wisdom is like it in the good fruits
thereof. As also metaphors in laying fast hold on it, and retaining it, or
locking it up fase, that it may not be lost, as men lock up fruit and treasures.

Note. 1. A description of the excellency of wisdom: 2. The happiness of the
possessore of it.


In the former note.

1. What she is, She is a tree of life. 2. To whom she is so, To them that lay
hold on her.
In the latter, observe

1. The adjunct, And happy. 2. The subject, Is every one that retains her.
Doct. 1. Scripture must be understood by Scripture. Wisdom is not only a
living tree, but a tree that not alone signifies continuance of life, as the
tree of life did, Genesis 2.9. but also brings eternal life. So the one text
gives light unto the other. A wise man is as it were restored into Paradise in
this life, Erat Adae in lignis caeteris alimentum, in ligno vitae sacramentum
sapientiae, Adam had aliment in the other trees, but in the tree of life he had
a Sacrament of wisdom, says a learned writer.

Reas. 1. Because they were written by an infallible spirit, and therefore the
writers could not err in giving their own meaning, or the meaning of one
another.

2. None have an infallible spirit now, and therefore the best may err in
interpreting some place of Scripture.

Quest. How can we interpret Scripture by Scripture?

Ans. 1. By consulting with the original. As if children differ about their
fathers legacy, Non itur ad tumulum, sed curritur ad Testamentum, They go not
to the Tomb, but run to the Testament. Optat.

2. By observing the coherence with what goes before, and what follows; as we
pick out the meaning of a friends letter by the Scope of it, and by the rest of
the words.

3. By parallel places, as by comparing diverse letters to one purpose.

4. By plain places or grounds of religion, to interpret the rest, that are
built thereupon, as we do in Logic and other Arts.

Use 1. To blame the Papists, who submit the sense of the Scriptures to
Fathers, Councels, and to the Pope singly.

2. To teach us to use this help in difficult places, and not to allow of any
sense of any place of Scripture, not agreeing with other Scriptures. So about
Baptism, Go teach all nations. The original is, Make Disciples of all
nations, Mat. 28.19. And that by Baptizing, as follows in the words, and
Teaching follows afterward, verse 20. So that this place makes nothing
against Infants baptism. So about the resurrection, 1 Cor. 15.50. is pleaded
against it, yet all the Chapter before and after pleads for it. The Apostle
says there, Flesh and blood cannot inherit the Kingdom of God: His meaning
is, mortal, and corruptible flesh and blood cannot come to heaven, till it be
changed: so he expounds himself in the end of that Verse, and the Verse
following, Neither does corruption inherit incorruption. And, We shall all be
changed. Thus John 14.28. is brought to disprove Christ's divine Nature Christ
says, My father is greater then I: This must be understood of his human
nature, for in regard of his divine, the Apostle says, He thought it no
robbery to be equal with God. Phil. 2.6. The Jews understood this, that He
made himself equal with God. John 5.18. which had been blasphemy indeed, had
not he been true God. So for excluding bread out of the Lords Supper, Mat.
26.26. This is my body, is cited by the Papists; but it must be understood
figuratively, not literally: The meaning is, this is the sign of my body; for
Paul calls it bread, when it is eaten, 1 Cor. 11.26. God cannot contradict
himself.

Doct. 2. Wisdom affords true nourishment: Not for a time, as fruits of trees
do, but for ever; therefore it is compared to milk for babes, and strong meat
for men. Heb. 5.12, 13, 14. And to milk again. 1 Pet. 2.2.

Reas. 1. Because it shows how to get, and dress food for the body.

2. How moderately to exercise the body, without which food will not digest.

3. How to keep a cheerful mind, without which, food will not be profitable to
the body, nor nourish it.

4. It shows how the soul may be nourished by justification, through the blood
of Christ, without which it pines away under the sense and of guilt of sin, and
of the wrath of God.

5. How it may be nourished by sanctification, that so all sins, which are as
obstructions, being killed, all the graces of Gods Spirit may be increased in
us.

6. How it may be fullfed to glorification, where it shall need no more food.

Use. Labor for this true wisdom, as men do for food to nourish them: This
is to be found in the word of God. Let others despise the scripture (as Aenaeas
Silvius speaks of councills) so may we say of Gods word, call bread stones, if
you will, so you give it me to nourish me. Acts and Monuments, in the end of
the reign of Henry the sixth. All the labor of man is for his mouth. Eccles.
6.7. Men plow, sow, plant, work, for bodily food; why should we not labor more
for wisdom, that will feed the body here, and the soul to eternity? Praeclare
Plato beatum ait, cui etiam in senectute contigerit, ut sapientiam, verasque
opiniones assequi possit. Cic. 5. de finibus. Plato excellently says, He is
happy that in his old age can attain wisdom, and true opinions.

Doct. 3. Wisdom makes a perfect cure. The leaves did heal the nations. Rev.
22.2. The Scriptures are able to make us wise unto salvation. 2 Timothy 3.15.

Reas. 1. Because it cures hereditary diseases, which Physicians cannot, as the
darkness of the mind, perverseness of the will, crosnesse of the affections,
received from our Parents.

2. It cures infectious diseases, as sinful courses received from others, by
bad counsel or example.

3. It cures the thoughts of the heart, which no law of man, nor Physic can do.

4. It cures the tongue and words, and teaches how to speak wisely and
profitably.

5. It cures the life, and teaches how to avoid temptations, and provocations
to sin.

6. It cures the body too from some diseases here by Physic, and other good
means, and perfectly at the Resurrection: Then, God shall wipe away all tears
from their eyes, and there shall be no more death, nor sorrow, nor crying,
neither shall be any more pain, for the former things are passed away. Rev.
21.4.

Use. Praise God for communicating this wisdom to you in his word, especially,
if ye have found good by this course of spiritual Physic already, it is Gods
work, and he will finish it.

Doct. 4. Wisdom does good to none, but to those that get it fully, and firmly.
As fruit of trees does no good to them that seek it only, or touch it; so the
fruit of wisdom to none but those that eat, that is, obtain it; that seek it
not slightly, or think a little enough, but that take pains still for more:
not that look over the precepts as men look over an Almanac, but as men
seriously study good books, John Baptists, and Christ's preaching did no good,
but to them, that regarded it. We have piped unto you, but ye have not danced,
etc. Mat. 11.17. Paul's Gospel is hid to them that are lost. 2 Cor. 4.3.

Reason. 1. Because there must be a conjunction of things, before there can be
an operation of the one upon the other. The soul must be infused into the body,
before it can work on the body to make the tongue to speak, the foot to go,
the hand to work. A man must be married to a woman before he can take care for
her, as for a wife. So must wisdom be joined to the heart, before it can work
on heart, soul, or body.

2. Because it is so in all other gifts of God. A man cannot be liberal, to
whom God gives no riches, nor fight stoutly, to whom God gives no strength, nor
do any good with wisdom, or get any good by it, to whom God gives it not.

Use. See the cause, why many get no good by the word of wisdom so long
preached to them; Because they lay not fast hold on it. They hear many sermons,
but regard them not. The word preached did not profit them, not being mixed
with faith in them that heard it. Heb. 4.2. Seed grows not, if the ground
receive it not. Rain does no good, till the earth be softened.

5. Doct. Wisdom must not only be received into the heart, but retained there,
as seed in the ground, till it bring forth fruit. They are the good ground, who
having heard the word, keep it, and bring forth fruit with patience. Lu. 15.
Many showers, and sun-shines must come, before the Corn be ripe: The word must
abide like a graft in a tree Jam. 1.21.

1. Reason. Because things work not at first. Trees must grow before they bring
fruit. Meat must be digested before it nourish. So must wisdom be retained, and
gotten to a habit, before it can work well.

2. Because when it is left, it leaves working, as meat when it is ^^st out
upward, or downward.

Use. To blame those, that entertain wisdom, but retain it not, give it a good
countenance, and reject it, use it as a stranger, afford it a good meal, and
turn it out of doors. So do the Heretics, Apostates, Worldlings, men above
ordinances, for sure Gods ordinances are full of wisdom.

6. Doct. Such as not only receive wisdom; but retain it, are happy indeed:
Blessed is the man, that hears me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the
posts of my doors. For who so finds me, finds life: and shall obtain favor
of the Lord. Chap. 8.34, 35. Happy are thy men, happy are these thy servants
which stand continually before thee, and hear thy wisdom. 1 King. 10.8. Wisdom
does good to them, that will not let her go, till they find out the depth of
her treasure.

Reason. 1. Because true wisdom, and happiness are inseparable They are so in
God. They are so in the Creature. Adam, while he was wise, was happy, His folly
did undo himself, and the world. Solomon was happy, till he dealt unwisely,
and was gulled by silly women. When Solomon was old, his wives turned away his
heart after other Gods. 1 King. 11.4. Therefore God rent his Kingdom from his
Son, verse 11, 12. there.

2 Because such are Gods instruments to make others happy, and that not by
accident, but out of an earnest desire in themselves. And God will reward them.

3. They have Gods word for it. They that be wise, shall shine as the
brightness of the Firmament. Dan. 12.3. That Word that made a world of
nothing, and all the comforts wise men have in it, can make wise men happy.

4. They have God himself for their portion, who is the Fountain of all
happiness. How can he want water, that has a perpetual fountain? David was
wise, and claimed this portion. O Lord I said, Thou art my portion in the Lord
of the living. Psalm. 142.5.

Use. 1. To reprove such as lay a claim to happiness, but without a ground, as
they that despise wisdom, or that brag of it, but have it not, or have cast it
off. They may be rich; they cannot be happy.

2. To exhort us to take the right way to true happiness. Studiously to seek
true wisdom, and carefully to keep it, as the richest jewel in the world.
Though thou be despised by the world, as a poor snake, or contemptible
caitiffe, yet God counts thee wise, and will make thee happy.

VER. 19. The Lord by wisdom has founded the Earth, by understanding has he
established the heavens.
IN this Verse and the next, Solomon flies high, and commends wisdom from
working by it, and from the things which he wrought. As if he had said, what
need I say more in commendation of wisdom? The whole world, which ye see, was
made by it. Here he shows, how it comes to pass that wisdom makes men happy.
It was that, whereby God made the World, and therefore he can make men happy by
it. Great things were attributed to wisdom before, but greater here. As if
Solomon had said, O young man, thou have heard many things in commendation of
wisdom, now hear more, and greater, that thou may be the more inflamed with
the love of it. It is not a wisdom found out by men, as the Philosophers
imagined, who thought all wisdom depended upon their precepts, and might be
gotten by humane industry. The wisdom, whereof I speak, is far antienter then
the world, for the very foundations of the world were laid by it. Think not
then this wisdom a thing feigned in the brains of men, and perishing with
them, and therefore to be despised, but look upon her, as upon Jesus Christ the
eternal son of God and Creator of the World together with God the Father.
Solomon does not now set out wisdom by benefits to us, as before, but by the
majesty thereof, and the greatness of the works, that God does by it. Among
which the making of Heaven, and Earth, and all things therein is exceeding
commendable: But it may be objected: Solomon had before commended wisdom, as it
is in men: why does he now sore so high from wisdom in men to wisdom in God,
there being so vast a difference? The wisest man on Earth is but a fool to God,
and must never expect by his wisdom to do such great things, as God has done.

I answer. 1. Because Solomon's intention was to commend wisdom in general, be
it in the Creator, or in the Creature.

2. Because wisdom in man has some resemblance of that wisdom, that is in
God, though it be far short of it.

3. Because it is a little stream coming from that infinite fountain of wisdom
that is in God, yet not materially, for God has never the less, but
effectively, as wrought in us by it. When a man has commended the stream, and
showed the virtues of it, it adds to the credit of it to show the fountain,
whence it comes, and the admirable effects thereof: So it is a commendation to
man's exquisit wisdom, to show, that it comes from the infinite wisdom of God,
by which heaven and earth were made.

4. To prove it may well guide a man in all his affairs in the world, and make
him happy (as Verse 18.) seeing it comes from that wisdom by which God made all
things, the settling of solid things, as heaven, and earth, are set down in this
verse, and of liquid things, as waters, and rain, Verse 20.

For the words.

The Lord. See on Chap. 1.7.

By wisdom. See on Chap. 1.7. Wisdom may be understood as of an attribute of
God, for his infinite wisdom was used in the creation of the world: But it is
better to understand it of Jesus Christ, the wisdom of the father, By whom all
things were made, and without whom, was not any thing made, that was made. Joh.
1.3.

Has founded. Has laid the foundations of the earth so sure, that though it
hang in the midst of heaven, yet it subsists of it self, remains unmovable,
and upholds the rest of the world. It is like the rock upholding the house.
Mat. 7.24, 25. The earth is the lowest of all the elements, the center of the
rest, upholding them all without any thing under it, to uphold it. Thus men and
beasts have room, where they may live and breath: though it have no foundation,
yet it stands as fast, as if it had a strong foundation, answerable to the
greatness of it. The words may admit a double sense, either that God did at
first by his infinite wisdom, so justly poise the earth, that it should be
upheld by its own equal weight, and have no inclination to move upward,
downward, or aside; or else, that Gods power immediately still without any
thing wrought in the earth at first, upholds it, as a sure foundation, and
makes it a lasting foundation to uphold all the visible world. God by his
infinite wisdom so placed the earth as a foundation, that should never remove
out of his place, lest the foundation failing, the rest of the building should
fall and perish.

The earth. Not only the body of the earth, but also all the creatures that
are, or live in it: for it is opposed to the heavens. He mentions the earth
first, because it is the center of the heavens, and therefore says, he has
founded it: But he is said to stablish the heavens above, which have the earth
for a foundation beneath. For the word, see on Chap. 2.22.

By understanding. God uses diverse words to the same purpose, to show, that
all kind of wisdom is in God, and his Christ. For the word, see on Chap. 2.2.

Has he established. So fitted all the parts of heaven, that they continue
fast together, and each observe their several motions, as Planets, fixed
Stars, first mover in their places, Orbs, or Spears. This must be
understood of the visible Heavens, the beauty whereof we see, and admire at
Gods wisdom in it. For unto us, The heavens declare the glory of God, and the
firmament shows his handy work Psalm. 19.1. This word (...) is translated,
fashioning. Did not one fashion us in the womb? Job 31.15. To wit, by fitting
and framing all the members of the body in the womb: He covered the earth as it
were with a roof, the heavens he adorned with many Stars: He has not made
the heavens unmovable like the earth, but unweariable in their motion, and not
subject to diminution, or dissolution. This shows Gods infinite wisdom, for
palaces built by men fail.

(...) The heavens. The starry heavens, so it is used, Genesis 1.14. Let there be
lights in the firmament of the heaven. Though sometimes it be put for the Air,
for there are fouls of heaven mentioned as well as stars of heaven, Genesis
1.20. I find not the Hebrew word used at any time in the old Testament, for the
invisible heaven, which was not then so plainly made known, although the Greek
word in the new Testament be so used, Our conversation is in heaven. Phil.
3.20. That is, heavenly, like the carriage of Saints, and Angels there: It
has its name in Hebrew from (...) and (...) There are waters. And it intimats
two kinds of waters, one in the heavens above, the other in the earth beneath,
which also may be intimated by (...) being the duall number, and by (...) of
the duall number also, two visible heavens, Starry, and Airy.

Figures. Founded. A metaphor, for the earth has no foundation under it, but
God has made it as fast, as if it had a strong foundation to uphold it. Earth.
For the earth and all things in or on it. The part for the whole. So likewise
in the word Heaven. The part put for the whole, comprehending stars and all.

Note. 1. The foundation of the earth. 2. The establishment of the heavens.


In the first observe 1. The Agent. The Lord. 2. The instrument. By wisdom. 3.
The Act. Has founded. 4. The Object. The Earth.


In the second note 1. The Agent. He. 2. The Instrument. By understanding. 3.
The Act. Has. established. 4. The Object. The Heavens.


1. Doct. The world had a beginning In the beginning God created the Heaven and
the Earth. Genesis 1.1. Through faith we understand, that the worlds were framed
by the word of God. Heb. 11.3.

Reason. 1. Because the world could not make it self, and the refore the maker
must needs be before it. Causa prior causato. The cause is before the thing
caused. A builder must needs be before a house in time.

2. Because it is compounded of Heaven, Air, Earth, Sea, Stones, Trees, Beasts,
Men, Angels. Bodies are compounded of the Elements. Souls of faculties.
Empires of diverse people. A garment sewed together, had a beginning.

3. Because the world is mutable in all parts of it. Sometimes the Sun shines
in Heaven, sometimes the Moon, sometimes the stars, sometimes none of them are
seen. The air is sometimes clear, sometimes stormy. The Sea sometimes calm,
sometimes tempestuous. The Earth sometimes dry, sometimes wet. Kingdoms one
while in peace, another while in war. Living creatures one while well, another
while sick. All mutable things had a beginning: Who can change that which is
eternal?

4. Because it will have an end, as appears in the parts of it. Fishes, Birds,
Men die. Sea eats up Earth, Beasts; Earth expells Sea by man's art, and labor.
Some things had a beginning, which by the mercy, wisdom, and power of the
Creator shall be kept from having an end, who gives to all Creatures durance
long or shorter, as he please. To men for their generations. To stars to the
worlds end, to Angels, souls of men, and their bodies also after the
resurrection for eternity. But nothing that has an end, was without a
beginning It could not be at first without him, that can take the being of it
away, when he please. If it were from eternity, it can keep it self to
eternity.

Use. 1. It confutes those, who think the world to have been from eternity.
Their own bodies may teach them the contrary.

2. It confutes those that think not the world formally, but materially to be
from eternity. I say with Tertullian, Quod non lego, non credo. What I read
not, I believe not. Of it self it could not be so, being a dead thing: By God
it could not be made so; For every thing has his being before it produce any
other thing. It were dishonorable to God to have any thing eternal beside
himself. It would take away from him the credit of making the world, or at
least of making it out of nothing, which is a divine privilege. Singular
