privileges are chiefest ornaments. It is some derogation, that others can do,
what we can. The Magicians were put to filence by lice, and confessed, This is
the finger of God. Exodus 8.19. And this opinion will help to bring in the form
from eternity too. For? some form it had, if it had a being: and who can alter
the form of that which is eternal. And so by consequence God made not the
world. And scoffers will grow more bold, and say, All things continne, not as
they were from the beginning of the Creation. 2 Pet. 3.3, 4. But as they were
before the Creation from eternity.

2. Doct. The wolrd was made by God. Where wast thou, when I laid the
foundations of the Earth; Job 38.4. By the word of the Lord were the Heavens
made: and all the host of them by the breath of his mouth. Ps. 33.6.

Reason. 1. Because it was not from eternity, as appears by the changes in it.

2. It made not i^ self. That were a contradiction. It could not be in fieri,
and facto; made, and to be made both at one time. It must then work before it
be.

3. There was none else before the world was, to make it but God only. If an
house be found in an Island, wherein never any man, but one was, he must needs
build that house.

4. None else had wisdom enough to do such a work, if there had been men, or
Angels before the world. As no beast could build the foresaid house, if there
had been many in the Island.

Use. Give God the glory of it, and of all the comforts ye enjoy here, or shall
in heaven.

3. Doct. God shows wonderful wisdom in making the world. O Lord, how
manifold are thy works! in wisdom have thou made them all. Psalm. 104.24. To
him, that by wisdom made the Heaven. Ps. 136.5.

Reason. 1. Because he made this spacious world out of nothing. The wisest man
in the world, or Angel in Heaven cannot work without matter. But God made the
whole world of nothing; Only his infinite wisdom could do such a work.

2. That excellency, that is in the world shows the Makers infinite wisdom.
What is the most curious picture of a man, beast, tree, star to the thing it
self? Like a dark shadow to the shining Sun. So low do men's best works lie
below Gods. This shows, that the foolishness of God is wiser then men. 1 Cor.
1.25. For that work of God, in which he shows least wisdom, argues more, then
that wherein the wisest man in the world shows most.

3. Because of the variety of these excellent works, both of several kinds,
and of several dispositions in each kind. Stars, Rivers, Trees, Beasts, Men,
Angels, Hills, Valleys, what thosands of each? No created wisdom can number
them, much less make them. How many thousands of men are in the world? yet
every face differs from one another.

4. Because of their excellent order. The stars are above our heads to give
light, the air about us to breath in, the Earth under us to tread on. Several
grounds for corn, pasture, gardens, orchards. What not?

Use. 1. Let us in the view of the creatures not only take delight in the
fight, and use of them, but also take notice of the wisdom of the Creator,
and praise him for it. The Earth is a College built by God, that in it we may
study his wisdom The Heavens a Commonwealth or Kingdom established by him. The
Sun the King, the Moon the Queen, the Stars the Nobility, Clouds the commons,
Spheres the Provinces. So we see a man's wisdom in his works and books, and God
shows us his in the Heavens, and in his Law. Psalm. 19.1, 7. Comparata omnia
creata ad Deum, sicut artificia ad artificem. Recuperus. All created things
compared to God, are as artificial works to the cunning workman. As they show
the workmans wisdom, so do these Gods, Yea, much more. For if we admire a watch
made by the art of man for the rare workmanship, and frame of the wheels and
their motions, how much more should we admire the wisdom of God in making the
glorious lights of Heaven with their revolutions, without which no watch could
exactly measure time? And in the variety of earthly creatures, without which
our lives could afford us no comfort?

2. Use. Take heed of finding any faults in the works of God. They were all
made in wisdom, though thy shallow brain cannot reach them.

4. Doct. God upholds the Earth strangely. The world is established, that it
cannot be moved. Ps. 93.1. No man can tell whereupon the Foundations of the
Earth are fastened. God poses Job with this question. Job 38.6. and may pose all
the world. They must answer with him, God hangs the Earth upon nothing. Job.
26.1.

And that 1. Because there is nothing above it, or under it to uphold it. It is
the lowest Element: and the Heavens above cannot uphold it.

2. Because it is above the power of nature to do it, or to know how it is done.

Use. When we tread on the earth, let us take notice who upholds it, and makes
it able to uphold us. No creature can do it The earth would sink under us, if
God did not strangely uphold it for us. Give God the glory then of your
sustentation.

5. Doct. God preserves the heavens, and heavenly creatures in their motion. It
is God, that in them has set a Tabernacle for the Sun to run a race. Psalm.
19.4, 5. Thou make the outgoings of the morning, and of the evening to
rejoice. Psalm. 65.8.

Reason. 1. Because the Heavens, and the Sun, Moon, and stars have no principle
of life in them, whereby to move themselves, much less of reason to direct
them in their various courses.

2. Because no creature, either man or angel, has wisdom or power enough to
do it.

Use. Take occasion from the daily motion of the heavenly bodies to bless God;
our spirits are comforted, and bodies directed by them, they are watches to
keep time for us, God keeps them in their motion, else would they deceive us,
and deprive us of their light and comfort.

Doct 6. All manner of wisdom is in God. It is expressed by diverse words in the
Text, Wisdom, and Understanding. We may well cry out with the Apostle, O the
depth of the riches, both of the wisdom and knowledge of God. Romans 11.33.

Reas. 1. His word shows it to us, in which are the grounds of all arts and
sciences, and higher things then they.

2. His works show it, none has wisdom to do the like.

Use. Be humble, and see thine own folly: be thou never so wise, thou art but a
fool in respect of God, thou want some wisdom, he has all: Thou may say
of thy wisdom, as David of his age, Psalm. 39.5. My wisdom is nothing before
thee. Verily every man at his best state is altogether vanity. Selah.

VER. 20. By his knowledge the depths are broken up, and the clouds drop down
the dew.
GODS infinite wisdom was set out in the former verse, by the higher parts of
the world, the heavens, and by the lower, the earth; or, as was mentioned in
the former verse, by settling solid substances there, and liquid ones here, and
by ordering the two middle elements, air, and water.

For the words.

By his knowledge. Not by our knowledge of God, as the word is taken for our
knowledge of Christ, Isa. 53.11. By his knowledge shall my righteous servant
justify many. But by Gods own wisdom. The words are varied, to show the plenty
of scripture language. Here is Gods wisdom, understanding, knowledge. For the
word, see on Chap. 1.2.4.

The depths. Some understand this of the springs and rivers, that break out of
the earth continually, and run into streams, through many countries, and those
oftentimes are strangely brought out of rocky hills, God wisely and wonderfully
opening a passage for them, being of themselves weak, and unable to pass
through such difficult places, others understand it of the flood, which indeed
was not a work of nature, but of God, who cause all the fountains of the great
deep to be broken up. Genesis 7.11. But it is best to understand it of the works
of God at first, Genesis 1.9. in making room for the Sea, and for the rivers, that
men might live on the dry land: for he speaks here of works of creation, as
founding the earth, establishing the heavens, making the sea, rivers, and
clouds: all this was done at the beginning of the world. It is a description of
the great channels made at first, to hold all the waters, and the waters of the
sea and rivers are included. So Gods wisdom is set out in stable and remaining
things, as the earth, heaven, waters, clouds, which abide, and do not succeed
one another, as men, beasts, trees do, whereof we may see the same that Adam
did (...) signifies

1. The whole inferior globe of earth and water. Darkness was upon the face
of the deep. Genesis 1.2.

2. The waters in the sea, or sea it self. The fountains of the great deep
were broken up. Genesis 7.11.

3. Great misery and trouble, which drownes men in despair, as it were in the
bottom of the sea. Deep called unto deep. Psalm. 42.7.

4. A thing that cannot be found out, no more then the bottom of the sea can be
found out. Thy judgments are a great deep. Psalm. 42.7. Here it is taken in the
second sense, for the sea and channells of waters.

Are brokon up. Heb. Cleft. So that it seems at first the earth was circular,
and fully round under the water, till God made, as it were, clefts for the sea,
and rivers.

(...) And the clouds. They have their name from thinness in the Original,
because they are so, and therefore Gods wisdom is the more seen in them, in
that they hold the rain, till God send a commission to power it down upon the
earth: Yet sometimes the word is put for the skies, wherein the clouds are. 2 Samuel 22.12.

Drop down Or Which drop down. See the like addition, Psalm. 104. Bread which
strengthens man's heart. And the sense requires it: for Gods wisdom is not
here commended for causing the clouds to rain now, but for making them at
first, which are still so useful to us, as well as heaven, earth, sea: An act
of creation, not of providence. The clouds supply the dryness of unwatered
places; vapors drawn up from the waters, or moister places of the earth, fall
down in rain to moisten the drier parts of the ground; and they are said to
send it down by drops, for the comfort of the earth, and not to power it down
in streams to drown it, as in the deluge. So the Hebrew word (...) signifies to
drop down like a still.

(...) The dew. It has its name from covering, because it covers the earth: It
is taken for moisture falling from heaven. As the dew of Hermon, and as the dew
that descended upon the mountains of Zion. Psalm. 133.3. It may comprehend
moderate rain also, and gentle showers, that do good to the earth.

Figures. Two figures of the part for the whole, one in Depths, for all waters
below, the other in Dew, from all profitable moisture coming from above.

Note 1. The making of these.

2. Of the clouds.

In the first note 1. The efficient, By his knowledge. 2. The effect, The
depths are broken up.


In the second observe

1. Another effect of Gods wisdom, And the clouds. Lest earthly moisture should
be wanting, God has provided a storehouse above, to supply the dryness of
the earth.

2. The effect of these clouds, which are yet profitable in dropping down the
rain gently, for the grouth of herbs, trees, etc. Which drop down the dew, for
so it should be read, as was observed before.

Doct. 1. The scripture often presses the same things by various expressions.
At Christ's Incarnation, God was manifested in the flesh. 1 Timothy 3.16. The word
was made flesh. John 1.14. Of whom concerning the flesh, Christ came, who is
God over all, blessed for ever. Romans 9.5. In him dwells all the fullness of
the Godhead bodily. Col. 2.9. So in the sacrament of the Lords supper, Take
eat, this is my body. Mat. 26.26. The bread which we eat, is it not the
communion of the body of Christ? 1 Cor. 10.16. As often as ye eat this bread,
ye show the Lords death until he come. 1 Cor. 11.26.

Reas. 1. To show the plenty of wisdom, and great variety of words, which are
in the scripture, we much commend Orators, that can express themselves
variously to the same purpose.

2. To show the truth of Scripture-principals, not only in their concord, but
also because they who understand not one expression, may understand another.

3. To work upon men's affections, we are so dull, that once speaking will not
raise them up, neither will often speaking in the same words do it, but rather
dull us more, as meat often dressed the same way, pleases not the palate, but
in different ways, and diverse sauces, it pleases well: so do diverse
expressions, for somewhat more may be perceived in the one, then in the other.

Against 1 Timothy 3.16. God manifested in the flesh, it may be objected, so it
may be, though Christ were not incarnate.

The answer may be out of John 1.14. The word was made flesh.

Ob. So it may be, though Christ be not God.

Ans. Romans 9.15. He is God over all, blessed for ever.

Ob. It may be he is not essentially God for all this.

Ans. Col. 2.9. In him dwells all the fullness of the Godhead bodily.

So for the Sacrament. Ob. 1 Cor. 11.26. it is called bread, and bread will do
our souls little good.

Ans. Mat. 26.26. It is Christ's body spiritually.

Ob. Then belike the bread is turned into Christ's body.

Ans. No, it is but a remembrance of it. 1 Cor. 11.26.

Ob. A remembrance of a thing past does little good.

Ans. It is a communication of his body, and the benefits thereof. 1 Cor. 10.16.

4. To affect several men, which have several tastes; that dressing of meat
pleases one man, which pleases not another, that bait takes one fish, which
takes not another, that expression prevails with one man, which prevails not
with another.

Use. Let us read the Scriptures with delight, in which is so much consent in
truth, with so many various expressions. Diverse men, at diverse times, and in
diverse places, writing in diverse expressions, yet delivering the same truths.
Here is utile dulci profit mixed with pleasure to alure the understanding reader.

2. Doct. God parted the Earth, and the water at the beginning. The one was
within the other, till God separated them. Let the waters under the Heaven be
gathered together into one place, and let the dry laud appear: and it was so,
Genesis 1.9. Thou coveredst the Earth with the deep as with a garment: the waters
stood above the Mountains. At thy rebuke they fled, etc. Psalm. 104.6, 7.

Reason. 1. Because Earth and Water being dead things, could not part
themselves so as to be confounded no more.

2. There was none else living then to make that separation. Light only was
created, and that might drive away darkness, but could not drive away waters.
Neither had it heat sufficient to dry it away, that cannot now dry up the
Sea, though gathered into the body of the Sun.

3. Had there been Angels, or men then created, they had not had strength
sufficient to drive away the waters from off the face of the Earth.

4. Neither had they had wisdom enough to know where to imprison them, and keep
them from returning.

Use. Let us acknowledge Gods goodness in this separation. It is long since it
was done, but we enjoy the benefit of it this day. As may appear by villages
drowned in the Sea.

3. Doct. Gods great wisdom appeared in this separation of the waters from the
Earth. O Lord how manifold are thy works! In wisdom have thou made them all.
Psalm. 104.24. When God had divided the waters from the earth, God saw that it
was good. Genesis 1.10. There is a particular acknowledgement of the goodness of
that separation there.

Reason. 1. Because God shows great wisdom in all he does, yea, when men think
he works foolishly. The foolishness of God is wiser then men. 1 Cor. 1.25.

2. Because thereby he provided a subsistence for men, and beasts, which cannot
walk upon the waters without a miracle, as Christ did on the Sea. Math. 14.25.

3. He provided for their breathing in the air, which they could not do in the
water.

4. For their continuance of life, which the water would soon have taken away.

Use. Let us admire at Gods wisdom, that could find a way to do that, which
neither men nor Angels could do, to disperse such huge waters, and to make
places to receive them, and keep them in, that they turn not again to cover the
Earth. Ps. 104.9. The Philosophers themselves were forced to confess this to
be a work of Divine wisdom. Much more should we cry out with the Apostle, O the
depth of the riches, both of the wisdom, and knowledge of God! Romans 11.33.

4. Doct. God made the clouds to be receptacles for ascending vapors. They are
Gods clouds, as an house is his that builds it. He binds up the waters in his
thick clouds. Job 26.8. They are the bottles of Heaven, that hold the rain
there. Job 38.37.

Reason. 1. Because God made all other parts of Heaven: and who then should
make the clouds but he? So he that builds the walls of the house, lates the
cross beams to bear up chambers.

2. Because we see the clouds dark, and full before rain, like a woman with
child, and after it a clear Heaven, like a woman delivered.

Use. Bless God, that befides the waters below has provided another
storehouse above, that may supply the earth, when moisture fails it. Else were
it a great labor to water the earth with our feet, as they were forced to do
in Egypt. Deuteronomy. 11.10. Else must the corn and herbs perish.

5. Doct. God makes the clouds to send down rain: Who canseth it to rain on the
Earth, where no man is? Job 38.27. Thou visitest the Earth, and waterest it;
Thou makst it soft with showers. Ps. 65.9, 10.

Reason 1. Because he provides it, and lodges the afeending vapors in the
clouds; as in the former doctrine.

2. Because he only has the key to open the clouds, as well as to shut them.
Optatus finding fault with the Donatists for swearing by men, bids them to call
upon those men by whom they swear to bring rain. Hereby it might appear,
whether they were Gods or no, and might be sworn by, or no.

Use. Bless God, that unlocks his storehouse, and gives rain in time of need,
and does not keep his treasure to the hurt of others, as covetous men do.

6. Doct. God shows his wisdom in sending seasonable rain. He gives both the
former, and the later rain in his season. Ier. 5.24. I caused it to rain upon
one City, and caused it not to rain upon another City. Am. 4, 7.

Reason. 1. In the regard of the thing it self. He knows the Earth to be dry
and cold, and therefore he causes the Sun to warm it, and the rain to moisten
it. Math. 5.45. Therefore is God said by his knowledge, or foreknowledge to
send the rain, or make the clouds, that send it, as knowing what need the earth
has of it.

2. In regard of the time. He sends it, when the Earth most needs it. Former
rain to bring forth the corn out of the Earth, and latter rain to bring forth
the latter crop, hay, or grass. An hermit being asked why his little ground
thrived more then another greater, who prayed for rain, and fair weather,
when he thought it needful, answered, because I pray to God, who is wiser then
I, to send such weather, as he please.

3. In regard of the manner. That it should drop down softly like water out of
a still. For if it should come violently, it would not refresh, but destroy the
fruits of the Earth, as sometimes at Sea it has fallen so violently, that it
has sunk ships.

4. In regard of the measure of it, in sending what is needful. Else lasting
rain is a judgment, and causes dearth.

Use. Pray to God for rain when ye need it and praise him, when ye have it in
convenient time. As the key of the womb, of the grave of the earth is his, so
is also the key of the clouds. He gives rain wisely. Trace his wisdom by steps
in the former Verse, and this. See how steadfastly the earth is settled, so that
it upholdeth great buildings, and high Mountains without removing. See how the
heavenly bodies keep their course without shaking or weariness. See how the
sea keeps her bounds without drowning the land. See how the clouds drop down
rain yearly, and make fruitful seasons. Then say with the Psalmist again, O
Lord how manifold are thy works! in wisdom have thou made them all. Psalm.
104.24.

VER. 21: My son, let not them depart from thine eyes: keep found wisdom and
discretion.
SOlomon having before mentioned the great effects of wisdom, now renews his
exhortation, to remember all her precepts. He would not have men to have a low
opinion of wisdom, whereof he had given so large commendations before, and
gives more afterward in this Chapter, propounding more benefits, that will
come hereby. Wisdom is a treasure inestimable, wonderful, profitable, and full
of pleasure, as we have heard, and still may hear out of this book, when we see
that Solomon is not content with the former praises, whereby he has declared
unto us the profit, and pleasure, that they have, which are possessed with
wisdom, but does admonish us in the text carefully to keep it.

For the words.

My Son. See on Chap. 1.1.8.

Let not them. Some carry it back to the words foregoing, and conceive that
Solomon charges the young man to be careful to think often of Gods wisdom
appearing in the Creation of Earth, Heaven, Water, and Air, ver. 19.20. But it
is rather to be referred to the words following in this verse, requiring him to
remember such precepts of wisdom, and discretion, as Solomon had or should
teach him in this book. His end being to bring the young man to get wisdom, he
urges this as a principal means. Thus the antecedent follows. Psa. 87.1, 2.
His foundation is in the holy Mountains. The Lord loves the gates of Zion.

Depart. Be forgotten. For things forgotten by us, are departed from our minds.

From thine eyes. From the eyes of thy mind. Let them never step out of thy
memory, no more then jewels, that hang in thy sight. ver. 3. Do not think of
them only at leisure times, but meditate of them continually. Keep wisdom once
gotten as charily, as men do things, which they affect so much, that they will
never let them go out of their fight, but watch them perpetually, as God does
Zion, Behold I have graven thee upon the Palms of my hands, thy walls are
continually before me. Isa. 49.16. Let them be as the delight of thine eyes, on
which thou can never look enough, as the Prophets wife was to him, I take
away from thee the desire of thine eyes. Ezekiel. 24.16.

For eyes, see on Chap. 1.17. on the word sight.

Keep. Constantly in thy memory, and ready for practice. For the word, see on
Chap. 2.8.

Sound wisdom. H^b. Essence, or Being. See on Chap. 2.7.

And discretion. See on Chap. 1.4.

Figures. A metaphor in Eyes, taken from the eyes of the body, and applied to
the soul. Let thy heart look upon them by meditation.

Note 1. The negative part.

2. The affirmative.

In the negative, or prohibition, observe

1. The person spoken to, My son.

2. The action forbidden, Let them not depart from thine eyes. Wisdoms
precepts must not be forgotten, as if they were out of sight, and out of mind.

In the affirmative, or injunction, note

1. The act, Keep.

2. The object. Sound wisdom, and discretion.

Doct. 1. Wisdom once gotten, must never be forgotten. This is one of the last
lessons of the old Testament, Remember the Law of Moses my servant, etc. Hos.
4.4. It is required in the new, Remember how thou have received, and heard, and
hold fast. Rev. 3.3.

Reas. 1. Because of the excellency of wisdom showed before, we do not easily
forget things excellent, either for beauty or use: Who forgets the virgin he is
in love withal? or the medicine that heals him?

2. For the profit of them: we easily forget things that bring no gain, but who
forgets his gold, or trade, though he be old? Sirs, ye know that by this craft
we have our wealth. Acts 19.25.

3. Because of the loss, that follows on the loss of wisdom, which is very
great, the loss of all those good things, which wisdom would procure for us,
temporal, spiritual, or eternal; besides, the loss of memory it self, that
when it has unburdened it self of that which is good, will easily forget
meaner things.

4. Because of the danger that follows this forgetfulness, it will bring all
those evils in the world, which wisdom retained might prevent. He that
forgets his medicine, must bear his pain. It will also bring eternal misery in
another world.

Use 1. To reprove such as have lost more knowledge, then they have left, whose
blossoms were fair, but are fallen off: they are like many witty tradsmen,
that spend money as fast as they get it.

2. To exhort us to remember the good things we have gotten.

Motives 1. Wisdoms precepts cost us much pain to get, and should not then
easily be lost; we strove against natures streams to get it.

2. We look for much good by it, which will be lost with it.

Means. 1. Think often of wise instructions, especially the principal. So
Archers think often of the mark, Pilots of the guiding star, travallers of
the marks of the way. The Jews wore Phylacteries to keep Gods commandments in
their memories, Numh. 15.38.39. The way is hard to hit, and dangerous to miss.

2. Set your affections upon them, else other things will take you off from
thinking of them. Children easily forget what they learn, play takes them off.
Men are serious in what they like. As the stone on the still waters makes
circles one after another, and so the former perish, so does business put out
wisdoms precepts.

3. Speak often of wise things. A Master learns by teaching scholars.

4. Practice them. No man forgets his trade, while he is able to work in it. To
conclude this point, think how careful worldly parents are to call upon their
children to keep transitory riches; and take notice how gently, and often
Solomon calls upon us in this book, not to forget wisdoms precepts, lest we
lose spiritual profit here, and eternal glory hereafter offered to us, and so
perish eternally, and then forget wisdom precepts if thou can.

Doct. 2. Wisdoms precepts must be dear to us. As dear as silver, and as
precious as hid treasures. Chap. 2.4. Dearer then silver, gold, rubies. Chap.
8.10, 11.

Reas. 1. Because they have been so always to Gods people, as the delight of
their eyes, without which they could not be satiated, nor satisfied. So they
were to David, O how I love thy Law! it is my meditation all the day. Psalm.
119.97. So to Paul, I count all things but loss for the excellency of the
knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord. Phil. 3.8.

2. Because they are so to them in all conditions: the pleasures of prosperity
cannot take off their affection from them, nor the crosses of adversity.

Use. To reprove those who set light by wisdoms precepts: many books will down
with them, and human histories, but Gods word is slighted by them.

Doct. 3. Wisdoms precepts must be carefully laid up by us. So did David, Thy
word have I hid in mine heart, Psalm. 119.11. So did the Virgin Mary, His Mother
kept all these sayings in her heart, Luke 2.51.

Reas. 1. For direction in time of prosperity, for then our ways have much
danger in them.

2. For consolation in time of adversity, of which we have much need.

Use. Let us do with wisdoms precepts, as worldly men do with needful
instruments, not throw them about the house, but lock them up, that they may be
ready in time of need. Keep by meditation what is got by study.

VER. 22. So shall they be life unto thy Soul, and grace to thy neck.
UNto the former exhortation are added many gracious promises of life and
honor in this Verse, and of safety, Verse 23.24. He shows hereby what good
wisdom brings to the soul, body and estate: it brings life, honor, security:
He had said as much before, verse 18. but in a similitude, She is a tree of
life: here he speaks more plainly, she is life it self, and that to the Soul
also. For the words.

So shall they. To wit, wisdom and discretion, well kept and followed. Verse
21.

Be life. Be the means to bring spiritual life into thy soul, and to keep it
there. For life, see on verse 2.

Unto thy Soul. See on Chap. 1.18. on the word lives.

And grace to thy neck. See on Chap. 1.9. Only take notice of the strange note
of the Popish English Doway Bible, which reads, Grace to thy jaws, and in the
margin thus, Merit for the words of thy mouth. So willing are Popish writers
every where to take a slight occasion to set up man's merit, and pull down Gods
grace; forgetting, that these two are contrary. If the reward be of grace, then
not of works, if of works, then not of grace. Romans 11.6. So if of grace (as in
the Text) then not of merit (as in the Popish note.) However, it is very
strange to call grace merit.

Figures. Life. The cause or means of life unto the soul, the cause for the
effect.

Note 1. What they bring to the soul.

2. What to the body.

In the former observe

1. The cause, So shall they. To wit, Wisdom, and discretion.

2. The effect. Be life.

3. The object. Unto thy Soul.

In the latter note

1. The gift. And grace.

2. The subject of it. Unto thy neck.

Doct. 1. A foolish Soul, is a dead Soul. Having the understanding darkened,
being alienated from the life of God through the ignorance that is in them,
because of the blindness of their heart. Ephesians. 4.18.

Reas. 1. Because there is no life in the Soul, till knowledge come into it.
There was no living creature in the world, till light was made. God clears the
understanding before he rectify the will, and affections; he keeps the same
method in the little world, that he did in the great world. We are no better by
nature then the Ephesians, of whom the Apostle speaks in the place newly cited.
As the body is dead without the soul, so the Soul is dead without wisdom,
which is the soul of the soul: Though the Soul be the life of the body, yet it
self is dead, if without knowledge, and such a man differs not from a beast,
unless it be in being subject to eternal misery. That a man then may live
spiritually, and not sensually like a beast, it is the gift of heavenly wisdom;
and thy soul has life with God if thou keep wisdoms precepts, although thy
flesh be pressed down under the discipline of correction, or of the fear of
death it self.

2. Because as the foolish soul has no life, being without justification, so
it can have no health nor strength, being without sanctification. Health is a
second life, without which, the first is a burden: Better not to live, then to
live in pain, or weakness.

3. It has no spiritual breath, and without breath, no life; It cannot breath
out prayers nor praises to God.

4 It has no spiritual motion, and all living things move in one way or
another; dead things do not. No motion to any spiritual duty, till wisdom
take possession of the soul.

Use 1. Pity those thousands of poor souls, that walk in the world, yet are
spiritually dead. Ignorant men think dead bodies walk, but we know dead souls
walk. Many are like scpulchers, that have only the names of living men written
on them.

2. See if thy soul be not one of these dead souls. If thou have not true
wisdom, thou have a name that thou live, and art dead. Rev. 3.1. It is not
thy great birth, wealth, nor strength, that can make thee alive, it must be
wisdom.

Doct. 2. Wisdom makes the soul live. Keep my commandments and live. Chap.
7.2. Hear, and your soul shall live. Isa. 55.3.

Reas. 1. From the confession of the heathen. Is proprie, vereque homo est,
cujus omnis in anima rationali substantia existit. Qua propter quicquid extra
hunc hominem sit, id ad se minime pertinet. Plato in Alcibiade. He is properly
and truly a man, all whose substance is in the reasonable soul; wherefore
whatsoever is out of this man, that belongs not to him, in his own account.

2. From the contrary. Folly is the death of the soul; sin that kills it, is
commonly called folly in Scripture.

3. From the beginning of life. Wisdom is, as it were, the seed of spiritual
life.

4. From the Progress; it maintains the life of the soul, as meat does the
life of the body.

Use 1. Take pains to get true and heavenly wisdom. What pains does the
Husbandman take, to get his seed into the ground? he plows, and sows. What
pains do poor men take for food? they work hard early and late, and all, or
almost all for the belly. So do thou for wisdom: And as the merchant runs
through pain and peril for wealth, so do thou for understanding.

2. Spare for no cost to get it. The husbandman, Tradseman, Merchant, drive on
their trades with great cost; wisdoms trade is better. It concerns eternity.
Spare then no cost to get, and keep it.

3. Doct. Wisdom is a great grace to any man. The wise shall inherit glory.
ver. 35. of this Chap. They shall be an ornament of grace unto thy head, and
chains about thy neck. Chap. 1.9.

Reason. 1. Because it is a sign of worth and dignity in a man. Men nobly born,
or in great place wear gold chains, and jewels. Wise men are Gods children of
the highest birth, and more honored with spiritual graces, and holy
behavior, then any other can be with gold and silver, though never so rich and
costly. They need not fear coming into Gods presence, nor disgrace from men,
for good men will reverence them, though they be never so mean, and none will
contemn them, but wicked men, which are themselves the most contemptible of all
the creatures.

2. Because it does adorn men as gold-chains do. Such as are beautiful
themselves, are more beautiful in costly dressings. A wise man is more worthy
to be looked at, then Agrippa with all his pompous train, that was but a fancy,
as the Greek text calls it, He came (...) with much fancy. Act. 25.23. A wise
man's honor is real.

Use. It discovers the blindness of worldlings, who cannot see this heavenly
wisdom, as moles and earthworms see not the Sunshine. Let us then account those
most honorable, that have most of this heavenly wisdom, though they want
worldly honor. Paul was truly honorable with God, though made as the filth of
the world, and the offscouring of all things. 1 Cor. 4.13.

VER. 23. Then shall thou walk in thy way safely, and thy foot shall not
stumble.
NOw the wise man shows, how wisdom brings to a man security from all evils,
and that at all times, and in all places, in this verse and the next. For all a
man's time is spent either in business in the day, or rest in the night, at
home, or abroad: and wisdom secures him in all these from evil of sin and
punishment. Man's actions are waking, or sleeping. Having spoken of life before
he goes on in the same way. Thou shall neither be blind, nor carelessly stumble
in the way. Wisdom secures a man waking, or sleeping. It makes him do his
business quietly in the day, and afterward to sleep securely at night.

For the words.

Then. When thou have gotten, and while thou keep and obeyest wisdom and
discretion.

Shall thou walk. Go on constantly. For the word see on Chapter 1.15.

Safely. Confidently and boldly. Not only without hurt, but without fear of
hurt shall thou go about thine affairs. See on Chap. 1.33.

And thy foot shall not stumble. No stumbling block shall be in thy way.
Nothing to hinder thee or hurt thee. Thou shall comfortably effect all thy
business. For Foot, see on Chap. 1.15.

Figures. Walk in thy way. Do all thy business A figure of the part for the
whole. For man has many works to do besides traveling. And it is opposed to
sleeping in the night: and therefore must comprehend all the business of the
day. Else the enumeration is unperfect; and a wise man might be unsafe in some
of his lawful ways. Thy foot. Thou thy self. A figure of the part for the
whole expressed by that member, which uses to stumble. As the eye is said to
see, and the ear to hear; yet the man does it by them. The eye is not satisfied
with seeing, nor the ear with hearing. Eccl. 1.8. Stumble, A metaphor. Thy
business shall not be hindered.

Note. 1. The safety of the way.

2. The preservation in it.

In the former observe

1. The Agent. Then shall thou.

2. The Act. Walk.

3. The Object. In thy way.

4. The Adjunct. Safely.

In the latter note

1. The Agent. And thy foot.

2. The Act. shall not stumble.

1. Doct. A godly wise man may be quiet in all conditions. I laid me down and
slept; I Awaked, for the Lord sustained me. Psalm. 3.5. God is our refuge, and
strength: a very present help in trouble. Therefore will we not fear, though the
earth be removed. and though the Mountains be carried into the midst of the
Sea. Though the waves thereof roar, and be troubled, though the Mountains shake
with the s^elling thereof. Selah. Psalm. 46.1, 2, 3. And well might he put his
Selah to it, for the least of these might make an other man tremble.

Reason. 1. Because he knows the worst, that can befall him, as sickness,
poverty, death, and the like.

2. He knows how to bear all these, and to make a good use of them.

3. He knows they will have an end, and therefore is not afraid of them that
kill the body, and after that, have no more that they can do. Luke 12.4.

4. He knows much good will come after, and that his light affliction which is
but for a moment works for him a far more exceeding, and eternal weight of
glory. 2 Cor. 4.17.

Use. To show us the vast difference, that is between the condition of the wise
man, and the fool, the godly, and the ungodly. The one is like a flourishing
tree that bears fruit in summer, and keeps leaves and greenness all the
winter: the other not so, but like chafe scattered by every wind. Psalm. 1.3,
4. The one has prosperous days, and quiet nights, in this verse and the next:
the other has troublesome labor in the day, and unquiet rest in the night. It
is vain for you to rise up early, to sit up late, to eat the bread of sorrows.
For he rightly gives his beloved sleep. Psalm. 127.2. So it should be
translated, as the same particle (...) is used else where. The daughters of
Zelophchad spoke right. Numb. 27.7. The one has peace of conscience to quiet
him within, and Gods protection to secure him without. Being justified by faith
he has peace with God. Romans 5.1. And he is kept by the power of God unto
salvation. 1 Pet. 1.5. The other has no peace within, nor safety without. The
wicked are like the troubled Sea, when it cannot rest, whose waters cast up
mire, and dirt, There is no peace, says my God, to the wicked. Isa. 57.20.21.
And if he say so, it must needs be so; choose your condition. None but fools
will prefer the worser.

2. Doct. A wise man may boldly go about all his affairs. I am continually with
thee, thou have holden me by my right hand. Psalm. 73.23. Why should not Asaph
then go on boldly? Thou shall tread upon the Lion and Adder, the young Lion and
the Dragon shall thou trample under feet. Psalm. 91.13. Why should such an one
fear any danger?

Reas. 1. His integrity toward God and man gives him peace and comfort within,
and so makes him bold in his ways; he goes on, like the water of a clear
fountain, that has no dirt mingled with it. A foolish soul is like a pudly
stream, it finds many impediments.

2. Lest any should say, though he give men no cause, yet wicked men may do him
hurt, he has God to protect him: so he has a double guard, Gods peace within
to keep his heart and mind. Phil. 4.7. And Gods power without. 1 Pet. 1.5. And
his faith in these promises of God, confirms him against all doubtings, and
againg all fear of dangers; and by staying him, self upon this word of God, he
overcoms all lets, and rubs that the flesh, the world, or the devil can cast
in the way.

3. He has a guare of Gods Angels, and though in unknown ways men fear many
evils, yet he need not fear so much as the dashing of his foot against a
stone. Psalm. 91.11, 12. If devils and ungodly men encamp against them, they
need not fear, for the angel of the Lord encampeth round about them that fear
him, and delivers them. Psalm. 34.7.

4. He has a smooth way, no rubs in it, while he keeps in wisdoms way. The
way of the righteous is made plain. Chap. 15.19. The enemy lays rubs close by
the way, if he go never so little out of it, but there are none in the way: And
therefore the promise of safety in the Text is made to us, while we keep in the
right way, and if we go but out of that, it belongs not unto us.

5. He is in league with all creatures, defensive, and offensive. At
destruction and famine thou shall laugh, neither shall thou be afraid of the
beasts of the earth. For thou shall be in league with the stones of the field,
and the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee. Job 5.22.23. What need
he then be afraid to travail any where about his lawful business?

6. He knows nothing can hurt him; for he has such a command over all the
faculties of his soul by Gods grace, and the wisdom given him from above, that
he can make them harken unto reason.

Use. To encourage good men in troublesome times, to go about their affairs
without fear. He that has so many, and so strong guards, why should he fear?
Let Adam's children fear, who are yet in their naked condition; but let the
righteous be bold as a Lion. Chap. 28.1.

Doct. 3. Nothing can hinder a godly wise man from good success. Whatsoever he
does shall prosper. Psalm. 1.3. He shall eat the labor of his hands. Ps. 128.2.

Reas. 1. In regard of the things themselves, there is great probability of
good success; for wisdom is of more force then power to effect any great
design in peace or war. And diligence is not wanting to a godly wise man, who
studies practical divinity, as well as theoricall; and Gods blessing attends
him, which crowns every good action.

2 In respect of the person; he is he unto whom God has engaged himself to do
good in the end, though he afflict him in the way. Speed well in the end, and
speed well ever.

Use. to teach us a lesson of policy. Who would not have good success in what
he undertakes? Riches, strength, power, friends, carnal policy, may fail him,
but godly wisdom will never fail him. Strange things have been effected by
human policy, what may not be effected by heavenly wisdom? Good success in
the way may be crossed again, what is crowned with good success in the end can
never be crossed. Be therefore godly wise, and prosper to eternity.

VER. 24. When thou lie down, thou shall not be afraid; yea, thou shall lie
down, and thy sleep shall be sweet.
A Man awake walking, or working, can look to himself, and use means to avoid.
danger; he has most need of a guard for safety, when he is laid down to
sleep, wisdom will watch over him then also, and keep him safe. For the words.

When thou lie down. As he had promised the wise man security in motion in
the former verse, so here safety in rest. The particle (...) ordinarily
signifies If: but here it sets not out a condition, but a time, and is well
translated When. So When the Jubilee of the children of Israel shall be, Numb.
36.4. (...) Lying down here is to sleep, or take rest; it is understood
sometimes of the sleep of death, When thou shall sleep with thy Fathers. 2 Samuel
7.12. but here of natural sleep: for it is opposed to the motion and travells
of the day in the former verse; and a man need not fear trouble, nor cannot
feel sweetness, when he is dead, and laid in the grave.

Thou shall not be afraid. See on Chap. 1.26.

Yea. This word not only couples things together, but augments. Thou shall be
so far from being afraid, that thou shall sleep continually, and sweetly
without interruption, or frightings. Thou shall lie down, and none shall make
thee afraid. Job 11.19.

Thou shall lie down. See on this verse before.

And thy sleep. This shows, that the former lying down was for sleep.

Shall be sweet. Shall be very pleasing; no sudden accidents, nor dreams shall
fright thee.

Figures. Sweet. A metaphor. It shall be as pleasing to thee; as sweet meat, or
drink is to the taste.

Note 1. A promise of safe sleep.

2. Of sweet sleep. Excludit timorem, includit saporem. He excludes fear, he
includes favor. Holcot.

In the first, note 1. The adjunct of time, When thou lie down. 2. The
subject, Thou shall not be afraid.


In the second, note 1. The adjunct of time, Yea, thou shall lie down. 2. The
subject, And thy sleep. 3. The adjunct of quality Shall be sweet.


Doct. 1. God affords us rest after labor. Man goes forth unto his work, and
to his labor, until the evening. Psalm. 104.23. For so (or rightly) he gives
his beloved sleep. Psalm 127.2.

Reas. 1. Because God is not an hard Master; as he requires store of work, so
he affords sufficient time for rest, which covetous men do not to their
servants.

2. To make men the more willing to serve him, every man is willing to offer
his service to a kind Master.

3. Because he knows his service cannot be done, unless he allow his servants
competent rest. Life and strength will fail for want of rest, as for want of
food.

4. It would be uncomfortably done, and neither give content to him, nor to his
servants, as drousie work gives no content to men.

Use 1. Let us bless God, that takes care as well for our rest, as for his
work.

2. Let us do his work with the more cheerfulness in the day, being refreshed
with comfortable rest the night before, so may we the night following
comfortably betake us to our bees gain, not to fall to immoderate sleep, but
expecting good sleep from God, who allows it, and can only give it, and we
must thereby be fitted for the service of so good a Master day by day.

Doct. 2. A godly wise man may go to bed without fear. Thou shall lie down, and
none shall make thee afraid. Job 11.19. Ye shall lie down, and none shall make
thee afraid. Levit. 26.6.

Reas. 1. Because he carries himself so inoffensively when he is awake, that
he gives no just occasion to any man living to hurt him, when he is asleep.
Neminem laedens neminem timebis. Senec. Hurt no man, and fear no man. Metus cum
venit, raro lo um habet somnus. Mimus. Fear will seldom give way to sleep. He
that is quiet in his mind, by reason of the hope of a good conscience, treads
underfoot cares and vexations.

2. Because God, who is his keeper, is always awake, and watches to defend
him, when he cannot defend himself. Behold he that keeps Israel shall
neither slumber nor sleep. The Lord is thy keeper. Psalm. 121.4, 5.

3. Because he is a member of Jesus Christ, and he will lose none of his
members. The Shepherd wakes, when others a^e asleep, that he may keep his
sheep from the woolfe. So the heathen man describes a good Prince, he is one
who wakes that others may sleep. Securus dormit, et vigilat, et quiescit, et
ambulat, qui se innocent^m ante Deum meminit. He sleeps, wakes, rests, walks
securely, who remembers that he is innocent before God. Gloss. Ordin. Every
member of Jesus Christ is so through faith in him. Obdormit in Deo, et in statu
salutis. Lyra. He sleeps in God, and in the state of salvation.

4. Because if they be hurt, Christ accounts himself hurt. Saul, Saul, why
persecutest thou me. Acts 9.4. So does God the Father also. He that touches
you, touches the apple of his eye. Zach. 2.8. In all their afflictions he was
afflicted. Isa. 63.8.

Use. Labor for godly wisdom. Who would not be in such a condition, that he
may, when he has done his work, go to bed without fear! Such may sleep
quietly, when the wind blows abroad, when it thunders, and all the world is
affrighted, as if the end of the world were at hand, they need not be frighted,
as others, that know not what will become of them. So Peter feared not to sleep
in prison, Acts 12.6. so Master Rogers, our first Martyr in Queen Mary's days,
could scarce be waked, when the keeper came to warn him to prepare for the
fire, which warning he could but expect being condemned to be burnt alive. This
shows the Philosophers observation to be false, that happy men differ not from
miserable men half their time, to wit, when they are asleep. For a godly wise
man is happy, when he is asleep: a foolish sinner is then miserable: wicked men
always fear that other men are laying snares for them for the evils they have
done them. They know that enemies then are most ready to lay snares for them,
and have most hope to prevail against them, when they are asleep. Also their
covetous mind runs upon their treasure, being in continual fear of losing
their riches. Hence comes terrible affrighting fancies into their minds, and
fearful dreams by reason of their ill conscience, and wickedness, whereas
godly wise men sleep quietly, being kept by wisdom which they have embraced.
Pertranscuntibus autem a vigilia, scilicet, ad somnum, meliora sunt phantasmata
virtuosorum, quam quorumcunque. Aristor. Ethic. 1.1. When men go, to wit, from
waking to sleeping, the imaginations of virtuous men are better then of any
other.

3. Doct. The sleep of a godly wise man is sweet, and pleasing. So Jacob sleeps
sweetly on the cold ground. Genesis 28.11. And had a pleasing dream. ver. 12, 13.
there. Such was David's sleep. I will both lay me down in peace, and sleep: for
thou Lord only make me dwell in safety. Ps. 4.8.

Reason. 1. Because they meditate of Gods word in the day time, which is a
great comfort to them. And those things, that men muse on in the day, they
often dream of in the night.

2. They are diligent in their callings, and so being wearied in the day, they
sleep sweetly in the night. Dulce sopor fessis. Sleep is a sweet thing to weary
men.

3. Because they empty themselves before they sleep, of all that troubles them.
Pythagoras his rule to his scholars was, Non te prius somno tradideris, quam
diurna operater mente revolveris. Betake not thy self to sleep; till thou have
in thy mind gone thrice over the works of the day.

Use. See the difference between godly wise men, and foolish wicked men. The
ones sleep is sweet: the others troublesome. Richard the third after the murder
of his two nephews had fearful dreams, and would leap off his bed, take his
sword, and seek an enemy. Charles the ninth after the French Massacre was laid
to sleep every night, and wakened by Musicians. Take heed of such wicked
actions. Be wise, and fear God, and your sleep shall be sweet.

VERSE 25. Be not afraid of sudden fear, neither of the desolation of the
wicked, when it comes.
THE wise man having showed the benefits of wisdom before, now exhorts the
young man to make such use of it, that though fearful things, such as are most
horrid to mortal men, as hostile incursions that lay all desolate and wast,
all by fire and sword, to the great consternation of men's minds, should come
suddenly, before wisdom could foresee them, yet he be not shaken thereby, and
although such things should not only come, but also prevail over wicked men,
yet he startle no^ at it, as if he thought, he should be ruined by it also.

For the words.

Be not afraid. Some read, Thou shall not be afraid. These make it a promise,
and join it to the former words, intimating that wisdom will keep such fears
away. But the common, and safest signification of (...) is imperative, not
indicative: and that is to be followed, where it will stand well. Neither does
God here attribute it directly to wisdom, but charges us to use wisdom to that
end, when we have gotten it. Nature will make a good man afraid of evils, and
troubles; but he must by wisdom so recollect his spirits, that he be not
overcome by that fear, as if it should ruin him, but expect a sure deliverance
from God. For the word, see on ver. 7.

Of sudden fear. Of troubles that come unexpectedly, and therefore affright men
the more. For the word, Fear, see on Chap. 1.26. The word (...) Sudden, comes
from a word, that signifies a fool, for such do all things suddenly without any
deliberation, as not having wit to forecast conveniences or inconveniences
arising from their actions.

Neither of the desolation. Such troubles as lay all things wast, See on Chap.
1.27.

Of the wicked. For the word, see on Chap. 2.22.

When it comes. Some understand it actively. Be not afraid, when wicked men
lay all things wast, and seek to destroy thee. So the Doway Bible reads, Dread
not at sudden terrror, and the power of the impious falling upon thee. But it
is better understood passively, when wicked men are destroyed for their sins,
fear not thou, that thou should perish with them. So the word used, is Chap.
1.2. It may be read, That it should come, to wit, on thee. So (...) is used,
what is my strength, that I should hope? and what is mine end, that I should
prolong my life? Job 6.11. Figures; Fear, For the thing feared. The adjunct for
the subject. Comes. A metaphor form living things, for troubles come not of
themselves, but are brought on us by others.

Note. 1. An Assertion.

2. An Explication. The desolation of the wicked is that, which a good man
should not need to fear. In the assertion note

1. The Act forbidden. Be not afraid.

2. The Object. Of fear, or terrible things.

3. The Adjunct. Sudden. That comes unexpected. In the Exposition note

1. The Adjunct of quality. Neither of the desolation.

2. The Subject. Of the wicked.

3. Another adjunct of time. When it comes. Thou need not fear the like,
not only when it is threatened, or hangs over the heads of wicked men, but when
it actually, and unexpectedly falls upon them.

1. Doct. A godly man ought not to fear ruin. Thou shall be hid from the
scourge of the tongue, neither shall thou be afraid of destruction when it
comes. Job 5.21. Thou shall not be afraid of the terror by night: nor for the
arrow that flies by day. Nor for the pestilence, that walks in darkness:
nor for the destruction, that wastes at noon day. Psalm. 91.5, 6.

Reason. 1. Because those things, that ruin men, come from God. And he will so
order things, that whomsoever they undo, they shall not ruin his. A good
child fears not ruin by any thing, that comes from his father. Gods children
know, that their enemies can go no further, then God permits, and therefore
they fear nothing.

2. God will keep his children out of those troubles, that ruin others, if he
see it fit, as he did Noah, and Lot: and that oftentimes strangely, and
miraculously, as he did the three Jews out of the fiery furnace, which devoured
their enemies. Dan. 3. And Daniel himself from the Lions, which consumed his
adversaries. Dan. 6.

3. If God suffer them to come on thee, he will keep thee, that they shall not
ruin thee, though they undo wicked men. He will take away the poison of those
snakes, and then we may play with them.

4. He will bring the out of them, when thou art nearest to ruin, and when
they fall thickest upon thee. Though thou fall seven times, yet shall thou rise
up again. Prove. 24.16. And when they are gone from thee, they cannot hurt thee.

5. If thou die by them with wicked men, yet thou art not ruined with them.
Their troubles are a gulf sinking them down into Hell: thine are a ladder
mounting thy soul up to Heaven Saeviant perse quendo, nihil in me moritur, nisi
mortale: erit in me aliquid, ubi persecutor pervenire non possit, ubi Deus meus
habitat. August. in Psalm. 26. Let men be sharp in persecuting, nothing dies in
me, but what is mortal: there will be something in me, at which the persecutor
cannot come, where my God dwells.

Use. It serves to uphold the hearts of godly men in sad times. Ye may be
troubled, ye cannot be ruined. Be not then cast down in thy spirit, but stand
upright in all storms, like the Mount Zion, which cannot be removed but
abides for ever. Ps. 125.1. Sabeans rob Job, yet he fears not, but blesses
God, and God gives him more then he lost. Let a David walk through a valley of
the shadow of death, ye he will fear no evil. Psalm. 23.4. Dreadful things in
the Heavens will appear in the end of the World, yet they need not fear, whose
redemption draws nigh. Luke 21.28. Quia dum finitur mundus, cujus amici non
estis, prope sit redemptio quam quaesistis. Greg. Hom. 1. in Evang. Because
when the world is ended, whose friends ye are not, the redemption draws nigh
which ye have sought. It is not so with ungodly men, they may well fear ruin
when troubles come; for fear is due unto them which have not the fear of God:
they think themselves safe, because God forbears them for a time, but they
shall be overtaken with evils, which they cannot escape, and this is the
sudden fear that good men need not be afraid of, but will overtake wicked men,
as follows in the Text, The desolation of the wicked, when it comes.

Doct. 2. Troubles often come unexpectedly. Your destruction comes as a
whirlewind. Prove. 1.27. So shall the eternal destruction of ungodly men come
at Christ's second appearing. The day of the Lord comes as a thief in the
night, For when they shall say peace and safety, then sudden destruction
comes upon them, as travail upon a woman with child, and they shall not
escape. 1 These. 5.2.3. This appears

1. In invasions by enemies, who come before looked for, and suddenly lay wast
a whole country: and foes come often out of ambushes, and destroy stout men,
overpowring them with multitudes, before they be aware. Thus the old world, and
Sodom and Gomorrah, and Corah, Dathan, and Abiram perished.

2. In Gods judgments, as in the three former examples.

Use. In the Sunshine of your prosperity, get God to be your refuge, lest a
sudden storm destroy you, then need you not fear any storm, else every storm
will ruin you.

Doct. 3. Sudden troubles are very terrible to wicked men. So Jobs friends
speak of him, conceiving him to be a wicked man. Therefore snares are round
about thee, and sudden fear troubles thee. Job 22.10. When Nabal heard of the
mischief intended to him, his heart died within him, and he became as a stone.
1 Samuel 25.37.

Reas. 1. Because they come unexpectedly; for wicked men are fools, and
neither look nor prepare for changes, as godly men do, who are wise.

2. Because they have no sure refuge to fly to at hand, as godly men have.

Use. Wonder not that wicked men suddenly sink in troubles: they are neither
forewarned, nor fore-armed.

VER. 26. For the Lord shall be thy confidence, and shall keep thy foot from
being taken.
IT being a great matter, and hard for a good man to do, to expect deliverance,
when he sees wicked men ruined, in regard he has natural fear in him, as well
as they; Solomon adds a strong reason, and very sufficient, to wit, the
assistance of the great God, who, according to the hope of a wise man, resting
upon him, will keep him from falling into snares; and well may such a man be
confident, that it cannot be otherwise then well with him, as the first word of
the Text intimates, For, which carries a strong reason with it. For that word,
see on Chap. 1.9.

The Lord. See on Chap. 1.7.

Shall be thy confidence. Heb. Shall be in thy confidence. So (...) is
translated In, Chap. 1.20. In the streets. Or, For thy confidence. So it is
translated, For an inheritance: Numb. 36.2. The word (...) signifies Folly, or
Foolishness. This their way is their folly. Psalm. 49.13.2. Because they that
want wit to order their own affairs, had need to trust others, it signifies
confidence or hope of good from another. That they might set their hope in God.
Psalm. 78.7. 3. It signifies the flank. He makes collops of fat on his flanks.
Job 15.27. Some take it in the first sense, the Lord shall be with thee in thy
foolishness, when thou have brought thy self into trouble, and know not how
to escape, God will deliver thee. Others in the third sense; the Lord shall be
at thy flank, or side, as soldiers in the flank in battle, or as a guard to
secure a man. Hence latrones, anciently soldiers of a Princes guard, quasi
laterones. Sidemen. And the vulgar reads it, in latere tuo. Doway, at thy
side. But the second sense is best, and the word is frequently so, used in
scripture, The Lord shall be thy confidence. That is, one in whom thou may
safely confide in all dangers: He shall be to thee in stead of a shelter.

And shall keep. See on Chap. 2.11.

Thy foot. See on Chap. 1.16.

From being taken. He shall keep thee from the danger of the secret plots of
thine adversaries; for wicked men are fowlers, and hunters, always laying
snares in the way to catch Gods people, like birds, and beasts, by the feet.
The grin shall take him by the heel, the snare is laid for him in the ground,
and a trap for him in the way. Job 18.9.10. Which, though there spoken of
wicked men, is often true of good men. So David prays, Keep me from the snare
which they have laid for me, and from the grins of the workers of iniquity.
Psalm. 141.9. But God keeps his out of those dangers they see not.

Figures. Confidence. A figure of the adjunct for the subject. God is he on
whom thy confidence may safely repose it self.

Thy foot. A metaphor from beasts, or birds, taken by the foot in a snare.

Note 1. The ground of a godly man's safety.

2. The means of it.

In the first observe

1. The subject, For the Lord.

2. The adjunct, Shall be thy confidence.

In the second note

1. The act, And shall keep.

2. The object, Thy foot from being taken.

Doct. 1. The safety of Gods people, is not in their own power or care. The
name of the God of Jacob defend thee. Psalm. 20.1. Their own arm did not save
them, but thy right hand, etc. Psalm. 44.3.

Reas. 1. Because in some cases, no man in the world can help, as Jonah in the
whales belly.

2. Because God can cross the wisest man's cares, and the strongest man's
diligence.

Use. To teach us to acknowledge our own weakness, and insufficiency to
preserve our selves. What need the Lord be our confidence, if we had power to
keep our selves from sudden fear, and misery? But if we be left unto our
selves, we are like unto feeble beasts, which run into the net, and are taken
in the snare, out of the which they cannot escape. Let us not then, being
conscious of our own weakness, trust in our wit, strength, wealth, nor brag of
kindred, leagues, castles; all these are but castles in the air, and may fail
us. Put not your trust in Princes, nor in the son of man, in whom there is no
help. Psalm 146.3.

Doct. 2. The sure confidence of a godly man is in God. The Lord sustained me.
Psalm. 3.5. Thou Lord only make me dwell in safety Ps. 4.8.

Reas. 1. Because of Gods great care of them. He bears them on eagles wings.
Exodus 19.4. The eagle carries not her young ones in her claws, as other birds
do, but on her back, that they who will kill her young ones, must shoot through
her. Perirent justi, nisi Dominus inter eos et hosts se interponeret. Shel.
Iarchi. in Exodus Just men would perish, if God did not interpose himself
betwixt them and their enemies.

2. Because of Gods infinite power: they that put their confidence in man, or
Angel, may be deceived and perish; but Gods power is infinite, He is the
Almighty, as appears in making the world out of nothing, with a world of
creatares in it. When David's father and mother could not help him against Saul's
cruelty, God could, and did so: he says, When my father and mother forsook me,
then the Lord took me up. Ps. 27.10.

3. Because of Gods infinite wisdom, who both knows the mischiefs intended
against godly men, and how to prevent them: He is a complete Physician for soul
and body; He is the Lord of hosts, and a wise General, to find out mines and
to countermine.

4. Because of the experience Gods people have had of Gods delivering them
before, as Jonah out of the whales belly, David from the Lion and the bear,
Paul from dangerous sickness, when he had the sentence of death in himself,
that he should not trust in himself, but in God, which raises the dead. 2
Cor. 1.9. Yea, that we our selves have had in many sicknesses, journeys,
troubles every one of us, more or less.

Use. 1. To comfort Gods people that have so sure a refuge: Not only Solomon
tells us so, but the holy Scriptures are full of such witnesses, and examples.
Having then so many proofs, that this help is so ready at hand, that God is our
refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble. Psalm. 46.1. an that this
help surmounts all heavenly, earthly, and infernal powers, we must in no wise
fear, but hold an invincible assurance against all the afflictions of the
world; otherwise we do not believe that God is on our fide, and belly the
scriptures, and do count the examples thereof to be but fables. Seeing the Lord
is thy confidence, he will keep thee, who ever trusted in him, and was
forsaken? He can keep thee from temporal and spiritual evils. Certainly this
ought to be great consolation to godly people, that they have not only Angels,
but God himself for their keeper, not far absent from them, but always
present with them, as being in every place. Therefore their heart may rejoice
with David, and say, I have set the Lord always before me: because he is at my
right hand, I shall not be moved. Psalm. 16.8, 9.

2. To teach us if we be assured against sudden fear, and the miseries, that
happen unto wicked men to attribute all to God, and to confess it comes of the
only help of God, and not to give any part of the glory to men, to means, to
our selves.

3. Doct. God will prevent private plots against his people, as well as public
oppositions. Surely he shall deliver thee from the snare of the fouler, and
from the noisome pestilence. Psalm. 91.3.

Reason. 1. That it may appear to be Gods work, when no finger of man is in it,
as the lice in Egypt made the Magicians to consesse, This is the finger of
God. Exodus 8.19. So the discovery of the Powder Treason, and the discomfiture
of the Spanish Armado were Gods work: for we had no knowledge of them, nor
preparation against them.

2. That it might appear to be a work of mere mercy in God, where man could
not prevent the evil. As for a man to give to one, that never asks, or to
heal one past his senses.

Use. Here is a cure for our jealousies. We fear invasions from abroad,
insurrections at home. O that we would all fear God; and then he that has,
will still deliver us from the most secret plots of all our enemies.

VER. 27. Withhold not good from them to whom it is due, when it is in the
power of thine hand to do it.
SOlomon having encouraged the young man to search for wisdom by setting out
the great benefits it brings, now returns to give him particular rules of
wisdom to direct him how he may carry himself in the course of his life. As he
had in the beginning of the Chap. instructed him how to carry himself toward
men, Verse 3. and toward God, Verse 5. etc. so now he teaches him how to
forbear injurying men.

The words are variously read. The vulgar thus. Forbid not him to do good, that
can; but if thou caust, do good also. And this way run the Popish writers,
but far from the Hebrew words.

For the words in particular. Withhold not. Keep it not unjustly in thy hands,
that belongs to another against the owners will. For the word see on Chap.
1.15. on the word Refreine.

Good. Any thing profitable, which thou owe him. For the word, see on Chap.
2.9.

From them to whom it is due. Heb. From the Masters thereof. That is, from them
that have a right to it, and power over it to dispose of it. Most interpreters
understand it of giving to the poor, and trouble themselves much to know, how
the poor are owners of other men's goods. An hard phrase, and not to be found in
Scripture in this sense, which usually calls it giving freely, and Alms, and
poor men are taught to ask for mercy, not to demand it as due. And they who
make them owners of other men's goods open a great gap to them to take it by
foul means, if they cannot have it by entreaty, and to say, May I not take mine
own goods, where I find them? what should hinder? Some say, poor men have an
interest in other men's goods, because of their goods, because of their wants;
others, that they have it by nature, being men as we are; others, because God
bids us relieve them. But these titles will hardly make them to be masters of
what is not theirs. The interpreters run this way, because the next Verse
mentions giving to the poor. But as this interpretation answers not well to the
Hebrew words, so it confounds two duties, paying debts in this verse, and
giving to the poor in the next. Neither will it serve to say, This Verse
requires giving, and the next doing it speedily, for the word, of not
withholding in this Verse requires speedy payment: especially joined to the
words following, when it is in the power of thine hand to do it. I conclude
therefore, that paying of debts to creditors, or laborers is here meant, who
ought to have, what others injuriously keep from them. And this is a work of
justice, not of mercy. For the word see on Chap. 1.17. on the word Bird. Heb.
Master of a wing.

When it is in the power of thine hand to do it. When thou art able to pay it.
For if God lay losses, and poverty on a man, he cannot pay his debts then:
neither is it his sin, if his losses came not by his own negligence. Others
understand it, when thou have power to keep it away from him. Do not cosen thy
creditour, though thou could do it by force, or fraud. The hand in the Heb.
is used

1. For the member of the body so called. The one put out his hand Genesis 38.28.

2. For power, and strength, for the hand is used in strong actions. Whom God
had delivered from under the hand of the Egyptians. Exodus 18.9.

3. Help, and assistance, which is often afforded by the hand. Their hand also
is with David. 1 Samuel 22.17.

4. A blow, or plague inflicted by the hand. My stroke. Heb. hand, is heavier
then my groaning. Job. 23.2.

5. A place. Thou shall have a place also without the camp. Deuteronomy. 23.12.

6. The man himself, whose hand it is. He leans on my hand. 2 King. 5.18. So
here In the power of thine hand, that is, in thy power.

To do it. The word signifies

1. To do a thing. What have thoudone?

2. To make a thing. God saw every thing, that he had made, Genesis 1.31.

3. To bring forth. The Earth brought forth by handfulls. Genesis 41.47.

4. To prepare, or dress. He hasted to dress it. Genesis 18.7.

5. To advance, or make great, It is the Lord that advanced Moses. 1 Samuel 12.6.

6. To Get. The souls, that they had gotten in Haran. Genesis 12.

5. Here it is is taken in the first sense for doing.

Figures. Hand. For the man. A figure of the part for the whole.

Note. 1. An Act forbidden. Withhold not.

2. The Object. Good.

3. The subject. From them to whom it is due.

4. The Adjunct of time When it it in the power of thine hand to do it.

1. Doct. Outward comforts are good in themselves. It is reckoned as a great
favor for man to have dominion over the creatures, Thou madst him to have
dominion over the works of thine hands. Psalm. 8.6. Sure it is then a blessing.
And Psalns 104. begins, and ends with praising God for outward provisions. This
is best proved by particulars. Ask a hungry man if meat be a blessing? He will
tell you it is, otherwise he must die: Ask a thirsty man if drink be a
blessing? He will say, he must choke else: So for clothing, cattle, fruits of
the earth, and of trees.

Use. To blame those, that by abuse of these comforts, turn blessings into
curses; so does the glutton, and the drunkard. It is a sad thing for a man to
go to hell for those comforts, which he may have and go to heaven.

2. These outward comforts may be lent, and convayed from one man to another;
lending is a Christian duty as well as giving. The righteous man is ever
merciful, and lends. Psalm. 37.26. Do good, and lend. Luke 6.35. So is
trading, exchange, buying, and selling lawful; Abraham bought a field, and the
trees of it. Genesis 23.17. The father of the faithful thought it lawful, and
knew how to drive a bargain.

Reas. 1. Because we may have something to spare, that other (...) may need,
and they may have somewhat we may need, which may be communicated from one to
another without loss: And then, both humanity, and communion of Saints, teach
us to communicate to others.

2. Men may want that at present, which afterward they may repay, or requite,
and need not to receive of gift.

Use. It teaches us a willingness to lend to others, and to trade with
others; the time may come, we may need to borrow of them, or trade with them;
so we may help both them, and our selves.

Doct. 3. Conscience is to be made of paying debts, and restoring things to the
right owners. If a man borrow ought of his neighbor, and it be hurt, or die,
the owner thereof being not with it, he shall surely make it good. Exodus 22.14.
Render to all their dues. Owe nothing to any man, but to love one another. Romans
13.7.8.

Reas. 1. Because nature teaches, that debts must be paid. Why do we look for
duty from children or servants, but because it is a debt?

2. Because else we prejudice others, with whom we have to do, and expose them
to want, who have by trading, or lending relieved our wants, which is to do
evil for good.

Use. It serves to ery out against unconscionable men, that make no conscience
of paying debts; it will stick as a spot upon our religion; many among the
Turks are said to be more just in this particular: I have heard a Turkey
merchant of good Note say, that when he was to come away from Constantinople,
some of the Turks came to him, not sent for, to pay their debts: And a Morocco
Merchant affiming, that when the King died there, who traded much with the
English Merchants, the Queen sent for them to Court, and paid them every penny.
But especially, this should trouble their consciences, who, though rich, and
able, yet detain poor laborers wages; they would be loath to be so dealt
withal themselves, if they were in want. Behold the cry of the laborers which
have reap^d down your fields, which is of you kept back by fraud, cries, and
the cries of them which have reaped, are entered into the ears of the Lord of
Sabbath. I^me. 5.4. Conscience also is to be made of restoring things found,
committed to our trust, or borrowed; and that with speed, without delaying men:
for justice requires not only due payment, but in due season also, lest
deteriment come to the owners; and the Text requires it presently, if there be
power in thy hand to do it.

VER. 28. Say not unto thy neighbor, go, and come again, and to morrow I will
give, when thou have it by thee.
IN the former verse, Solomon had stirred up the young man to a work of
justice, to pay his debts; now he stirrs him up to a work of mercy, to do good
to the poor, if he be able, and that speedily. When men are in want, pitiless
men turn them away with the unprofitable alms of vain breath, that need speedy
succor, saying, Friend, I cannot help you now, go away and come another time:
yet they have no mind to help at any time, but only to put off at this time:
this delay is here forbidden. For the words.

Say not. See on Chap. 1.11. Put him not off with so vain an excuse.

Unto thy neighbor. The word (...) comes from feeding, and signifies such as
are known one to another, as cattle that feed together; it is sometimes
translated a friend, O friends drink. Cant. 5.1. Sometimes a neighbor, If I
have laid wait at my neighbors door. Job 31.9. Yet it is not to be restrained
to acquaintance, as if we were tied to do good to them only, but extends to all
in need, although strangers: So it is used in the ninth commandment, Thou
shall not bear false witness against thy neighbor.

Go. Depart for the present. See on Chap. 1.11. on the word, come; it is the
same in the original.

And come again. Return another time. See on Chap. 1.23. on the word Turn, the
same word is used for turning, returning, and turning away. The Hebrews have no
compound verbs.

And. See on Chap. 2.22. on the word, But.

To morrow. Another time. But the nearest time is named to make him more
willing to go away, in hope of speedy payment. Sometimes the word (...)
signifies the next day punctually. Tomorrow get you early on your way. Judge.
19.9. Otherwise it signifies time to come, long after. When thy son asks thee
in time to come. Exodus 13.14. Here it is used in the first sense for the next
day, else were it no encouragement for the man to go away, nor no direction,
when to return.

I will give. I will relieve thy wants. For the word, see on Chap. 1.4.

When. Heb. And. But it is thus translated else where. When as yet the^e was
none of them. Psalm. 139.16.

Thou have it by thee. Heb. It is with thee. Thou have that in thy power, which
he needs and desires; for it is no sin to deny that a man has not to give.
Some make these words a part of the denyers speech, Go, and come again, and to
morrow I will give, for thou have it by thee. As if he had said, why do thou
trouble me now? thou have enough to keep thee at present; come another time
when thou want, and I will relieve thee.

Figures none. Note 1. An uncomfortable repulse. 2. A requiring of a double
labor: 3. A frivolous promise.


In the first, observe 1. The act prohibited, Say not. 2. The object, To thy
neighbor. 3. The injunction, Go.


In the second, note, a reinvitation, including a double labor, And come again.

In the third, a ready offer, and therein

1. The time. And to morrow.

2. The act, I will give.

3. His hypocrisy, When thou have it by thee. He might do it now, and should,
but will not.

Doct. 1. There is an unwillingnesse in able men to give to the poor. It
appears by this man's delaying here, and by Nabals churlish answer, Who is
David, and who is the son of Jesse? 1 Samuel 25.10. Lazarus, ready to starve,
could not get the crumbs that fell from the rich man's table. Luke 16.21.

Reas. 1. Because we love the world too well, and would gladly keep as much of
it as we can, and more then we need.

2. Because we love our lusts, and they are very costly; Nature is content with
little, Grace with less, but gluttony, drunkenness, wantonness, cost much,
and hinder us from relieving others.

3. Because we think it is enough to provide for our own, especially, if we
have great families, then we think we are not tied to supply others wants.

Use. Marvail not at rich men's backwardness in relieving the poor, it is a
weed that grows in corrupted natures Garden, and will hardly be rooted out.

Doct. 2. We are ready to flatter our selves, and to excuse this our
unwillingnesse. So does he in the Text. The wicked man flattereth himself in
his own eyes. Psalm. 36.2. This is true in general of all wickedness, but in
particular, Nabal thinks he does right in denying David's suit, else he should
maintain runawaies, and fail his own laborers. 1 Samuel 25.10, 11. The excuses
of covetous men will prove the point; one, though rich, objects the weakness
of his estate, such an one worth much more then I, gives little or nothing; as
if the others greater neglect could excuse his lesser. Another says, the poor
are idle, and he will not give to maintain them in their idleness; He forgets,
that it is better to give to two that need not, then to deny to one that needs.
Another says the times are naught, trading is dead, and he may live to want
himself: as if he durst not trust God for the future, who never failed him in
all his life. These things argue self flattery.

Use. Away with fond excuses. Flatter not thy self to maintain thy
covetousness. Say with Paul, Neither at any time used we flattering words, as
ye know, nor a cloak of covetousness, God is witness. 1 Thessalonians. 2.5.

Doct. 3. We are tied to relieve others speedily, according to their wants, and
our abilities. To do good, and to communicate forget not, for with such
sacrifices God is well pleased. Heb. 13.16. Christ, the great judge, at the
great day, will commend, and reward liberal givers, and condemn the contrary,
Math. 25.34. etc.

Reas. 1. We are tied to relieve them, because we are Gods stewards; He gives
us more then we need, that like conduit pipes, we might power out to others.

2. We must do it speedily, for thou may suddenly die, or they, and then
thou can not do it. Thou know not what a day may bring forth. Chap. 27.1.
Or, they may be relieved by others, and that is no thanks to thee, and thou
may perish for thy neglect. So Mordecai tells Hester, that if she neglected
to help Gods people, God would set up others to do it, and she, and her fathers
house should be destroyed for neglecting so fair an opportunity of doing good,
put into her hands by God. Est. 4.14. A gift in season is best, and double
worth to that which is long deferred. Qui cito dat, his dat. Give quickly, and
thou give twice. Gratia tarda ingrata est. Ingratum est beneficium, quod diu
