inter manus dantis haefit. Seneca. Slow favor is no favor. It is an
unpleasing benefit that sticks long between the hands of the giver. As we have
opportunity, let us do good to all men. Gal. 6.10.

3. We must do it comfortably according to their wants; to give a dying man one
meal, or a naked man one hose, will not keep him alive.

4. We must do it liberally, according to our ability. Plentiful fountains,
give plenty of water. To whomsoever much is given, of him shall be much
required. Luke 12.48.

Use. It condemns unwilling givers: For such 1. Put off all till death, like
hogs good for nothing till they die. 2. They give sparingly, and with long
entreaty, if at all. Often drawing makes the Well fuller, and sweeter. Standing
still makes it stink. So in giving alms: Basil. Opportunity lost may be
irrecoverable. Thou may be as poor as Job to morrow, and have nothing to
give. God gives the creatures their meat in due feason. Psalm. 145.15. Job did
not withhold the poor from their desire, nor cause the eyes of the widow to
fail. Job 31.16. His alms was always ready when they needed it. They need not
wait long for it. Go thou, and do likewise. So may thou expect, that God in
mercy will not make thee wait long, but will soon answer thy prayers.

VER. 29. Devise not evil against thy neighbor, seeing he dwells securely
by thee.
THE wise man having persuaded before to the payment of debts, and speedy
giving to the door, now he disswades from evil offices, as from mischievous
plots in this verse, from contentious suits. ver. 30. From envy. ver. 31. Then
gives reasons both why these good offices should be done, and why the bad ones
should be avoided; and that to the end of the Chapter. The words run so, as if
a man were allowed to plot mischief against a stranger, or enemy, because it
forbids it only against a neighbor. But this is set out as a grievous sin
with its aggravations: yet the other not permitted. He does not tolerate small
sins, but set out greater, to make them the more odious. As if he had said,
Though thou must not devise evil against any man, yet especially not against
such as live near thee, and expect no ill from thee; Deceive not their
expectation.

Fore the words.

Devise not. Plot not evil against him in thy mind. The word (...) signifies
to plow, or fit the ground for the seed.

They that plow iniquity. Job 4.8. And secondarily to imagine, and plot
mischief in the mind, by thinking and studying, that so it may be ready for
execution, when occasion is offered. Sometimes, but rarely, it is used for
devising good things. Mercy and truth shall be to them that devise good. Chapter
14.22. It signifies also to be silent. O Lord keep not silence. Ps. 35.22. Here
it is taken in the second sense, for plotting and devising. Bain tells us, that
one of the Hebrew writers interprets this word of suspicion of evil in a
neighbor. But himself likes it not. The Doway Bible reads it, Practice not.
But I find not the word any where so used.

Evil. See on Chap. 1.33.

Against thy neighbor. Devise nothing, that may tend to his hurt. For the
word, see on ver, 28.

Seeing. One cause why thou should not hurt him, is, because he suspects no
harm from thee, and therefore cannot prevent it. This particle. I is
translated thus elsewhere, Seeing he judges those that are high. Job 21.22.

He dwells. The word (...) signifies

1. To sit. He that sits in the Heavens. Psalm. 2.4.

2. To abide or remain. He that abides of old, Psalm. 55.19.

3. To dwell. He that dwells in the secret place of the most high. Psalm.
91.1. So here.

Securely. Fearing no hurt from thee, but rather expecting a good, as from a
neighbor. See on Verse 23. on the word safely.

By thee. Near thy dwelling.

Figures none. Note. 1. A prohibition.

2. The reason thereof.

In the prohibition note 1. The Act forbidden. Devise not. 2. The Object of the
thing. Evil. 3. The Object of the person. Against thy neighbor.


In the reason note 1. The subject. Seeing he dwells by thee. 2. The Adjunct.
Securely.


1. Doct. Plotting to hurt others is a great sin. It is made a note of a wicked
man. He devises mischief upon his bed. Ps. 36.4. He devises wicked devices
to destroy the poor. Isa. 32.7.

Reason 1. Because it is an abuse, and ill employment of the most noble faculty
of the soul, as of reason, and affections, which should be used to do good to
others, and not to hurt men; But are often used to plot evil against men
contrary to Gods command.

2. It is a concatenation of diverse sins, as of malice, craft, voluntary
iniquity, and wilful contempt of Gods Commandment.

Use. To condemn those who think there is no sin, where there is no hurt done
to others, but place all sin in outward actions. This was the Pharisees
religion. Math. 5. yet Christ shows there; that though a man, or woman have not
hurt, yet anger, and lust are sins. If we ought to study, how to do men good,
though not desired, then is it a sin to devise evil against them, though not
executed.

2. Doct. It is a greater sin to devise evil against a neighbor. Let none of
you imagine evil in your hearts against his neighbor. Zech. 8.17. He must go
to Heaven, that does not evil to his neighbor. Psalm. 15.3.

Reason. 1. Because of cohabitation. If he like thee so well, that he choose to
live by thee, do not thou devise evil against him. Continual converse should
keep thee from doing it.

2. Because thou may get good by him, more then by strangers, that are
farther off, when thou should need their help. Aliquid boni propter vicinum
bonum. Some good comes by a good neighbor. An heathen man being to sell, or
let his house, put in this commodity among the rest, that it stood among good
neighbors.

Use. Banish all ill causeless thoughts against thy neighbors good out of thy
heart. This is the way to live with comfort.

3. Doct. It is yet a greater sin to devise evil against such as take us for
their friends, expecting no hurt, but good from us It was not an enemy, that
reproached me; But it was thou a man, mine equal, mine guide, and mine
acquaintance. Psalm. 55.12.13. If I have rewarded evil to him, that was at
peace with me; Psalm. 7.3, 4.

Reason. 1. Because such suspect no evil from us; and therefore may more
easily be ruined by us. Natures Law will teach us not to imagine evil against
them that trust to us, and suspect it not. The Italian Proverb is, God keep me
from them I trust; and I will keep my self from them I trust not. Antigonus,
when he sacrificed, prayed to be kept from counterset friends, and being asked
why he did so, answered, Because I can my self take heed of known enemies. Bona
fide agendum est cum iis, qui nobis been fidunt. We must deal faithfully with
them, who faithfully put trust in us. It is a shameful thing to lay snares for
them, that suspect no evil from thee, and think thou love them. Thou do
egregiously dissemble, that under a fai: face, and countenance to them, hidest
a foul heart against them.

2. Because they deserve no evil of us, and those ill offices are worst, that
are done to such as neither deserve, nor fear ill from us.

3. Because such expect good of thee: and what can be worse, then to deceive
him, that expects good from thee?

4. Because they deserve good of thee; and therefore thou should not so much
as cherish a thought of evil against them.

Use. It condemns those that plot evil against their nearest friends. These
are traitors. 2 Timothy 3.4.

Judasses, that betray with a kiss. Such are dangerous enemies. Such we had
need take heed of, as the Prophet warnes. Trust ye not in a friend, put ye not
confidence in a guide: keep the doors of thy mouth from her that lies in thy
bosom. Mic. 7.5. These are the plagues of all meetings, societies, feasts,
which are upheld by love, and faithfulness. Nulla pestis gravior ad nocendum,
quam familiaris inimicus. Lyra. There is no plague more hurtful, then a
familiar enemy.

VERSE 30. Strive not with a man without cause, if he have done thee no harm.
IN the former verse, sinful plots against others were condemned: here sinful
words and actions are blamed. In a word, all unlawful contentions are
forbidden. Here is a prohibition of all manifest violence, and secret
deceitfulness.

For the words.

Strive not. Neither in judgment by suits of Law, nor by harsh words out of
judgment.

With a man. See on ver. 13.

Without cause. Being provoked by no injury. This forbids not complaints or
suits upon just grounds, but rash and causeless ones: For the word, see on
Chap. 1.17. on the word, In vain.

If he have done thee no harm. The word (...) signifies to do good or evil,
as well without desert, as with it. To begin, as well as to repay. Our
translators take it in the first sense, as an exposition of those words,
without cause. That is, if he have not first wronged thee. Bain a great
Hebrician, and a learned Commenter takes it in the second sense, for requiting,
and reads it thus, If he do not requite thee. And makes it the form of an
oath, understanding these words, Then say, I am a liar, or believe me no more.
Meaning, he will certainly be revenged on thee, and do like for like. Thou
pickest a quarrel with him without a cause, and must expect the like measure
from him. See the like expression, If he do not curse thee to thy face. Job
1.11. Then say, I am a liar. The meaning is, as it is well translated there,
And he will curse thee to thy face. So it may be here, Strive not with a man
without a cause: then, or, else he will do thee harm. To wit, if thou vex him
causlesly. For harm, see on Chap. 1.33. on the word Evil.

Quest. May we then strive with a man, that has done us harm?

Ans. Yes lawfully before a Magistrate, and without sharp words. The sum of
this Verse then is, Contend with no man, if thou can choose. But if necessity
or public profit require it, thou may do it, yet take heed, thou exercise
not public or private contention with any man, that has not offended thee, or
done thee wrong.

Figures none. Note. 1. The Act forbidden. Strive not.

2. The Object. With a man.

3. The Adjunct of qualification, set out

1. Generally. Without cause.

2. Particularly. If he have done thee no harm.

1. Doct. Man's nature is very apt to contend causlesly. What cause had Ahab, or
Jezebel, or the elders to contend with Naboth? 1 King. 21. What cause have
wicked men to contend with Gods people? Just as much, as Wolves have to contend
with sheep. Math. 10 16, 17.

Reason. 1. Because men are naturally proud: and pride causes contention. Yea
there is some pride and defire of victory in every contentation. Only by pride
comes contention. Chap. 13.10.

2. Because we are naturally covetous: and we know, that earthly mindedness
breeds a world of suits, and contentions.

Use. It teaches us not to wonder, that men love to go to Law without cause,
especially with simple men, whom they think they can easily overcome. Such men
are proud of their wit, and brag, that they can easily bring under others,
though their cause be never so unjust. An Abbat, being asked, why he went to
Law so often, especially knowing his cause was not always just, answers, that
he did as boys going by a nut-tree, who fling stones and sticks at it, to see
what nuts will fall. It is as natural for sinful men to contend, as for birds
to fly, or for worms to creep. And therefore it is no matter of admiration.

Doct. 2. Causeless contention is not allowed by God, or wise men. If I have
rewarded evil to him that was at peace with me, let the enemy persecute my
soul and take it. Psalm. 7.4, 5. Without cause have they hid for me their net in
a pit, which without cause they have dug for my soul. Psalm. 35.7. The
Assyrian oppressed them without cause. Isa. 52.4.

Reas. 1. Because they know the iniquity and unfitness of it, and that there
is no just ground of causeless strife.

2. They know the danger of it, and neither God nor wise men will allow that in
others, that brings them to utter ruin.

Use. To reprove those that are still in contentions, whether they have cause
or no: they are like Salamanders, that cannot live out of the fire, they forget
that Consilium malum consultori pessimum, ill counsels are worst for the
counselors. They think to ruin others, but are ruined themselves: As if a man
should throw a stone at another, and it should recoile, and wound himself; or
dig a ditch for another, and fall into it, Psalm. 7.15, 16. or hide a net for
another, and himself be caught in it Psalm. 35.8. How many have been undone by
needless lawsuits? How can they thrive, whose courses are abhorred by God, and
all wise men?

Doct. 3. Contention without just provocation is a great sin. David complains
of it, False witnesses did rise up, they laid to my charge things that I knew
not. They rewarded me evil for good, to the spoiling of my soul. Psalm. 35.11,
12.

Reas. 1. Because it is against the law of charity, which requires good to be
done to others freely, much more not to hurt them by causeless contentions.

2. It is against the law of equity: for such not only do not, as they would be
done by, but do not as they are done by: they trouble others that trouble not
them.

3. It is against the law of humanity, and society, which is preserved by
concord, and destroyed by discord.

4. It is against the law of piety, which bids do good for evil, and then much
more forbids doing evil without a cause. A Christian should abhor nothing
more, then unprofitable contentions. Non contentio, sed collatio debet esse
inter christianos. There should be no contention, but communication among
Christians. Recuperus. Insont is tutor, aut vindex est judex, ant certe Deus.
The tutor, or revenger of the innocent man, is the Judge, or certainly God.
Lapide. If the Judge will not right them, surely God will.

Use. Take heed therefore for time to come of causeless contentions.
Continuance in known sins certainly damns men. The heathen man could say, Cum
pari contendere anceps est, cum superiore furiosum, cum inferiore sordidum.
Seneca. To contend with an equal is a doubtful business, to contend with a
superior a mad prank, to contend with an inferior is sordid. It is madness
for a man to delight in needless contentions. It may become Papists to do so,
as Cardinal Wolsey, when he was Lord Chancellor, paid home Sir James Paulet
without any provocation then, only because he had laid him by the heels,
when he was a schoolmaster. Cranmer would not strive with them, that gave him
cause, when he was Archbishop. It was a proverb then, Do the Bishop of
Canterbury a shrewd turn, and you shall have him your friend ever after. And
Robert Holgat Archbishop of York, though he was a Papist, being, when he was a
Priest, sued by Sir Francis Askew; when he was Lord President of the North,
showed him all lawful favor in a suit, saying, He was much beholdden to him,
for had not he been, he must have lived a poor hedge-Priest all the days of
his life: yet may a godly man by lawful means keep off injury, maintain his
right, and punish sin. This is not causeless contention.

VER. 31. Envy thou not the oppressor, and choose none of his ways.
THE Dehortation is not needless. It comes to pass sometimes in the world,
that many men thrive, and grow very rich by wicked plots. Then proud men envy
them. Why should not I thrive, as well as they? They were of as mean Parentage
as I, and it may be, of meaner. Covetous men imitate them. If these ways will
make them rich, they will make me rich also. I am not a fool, I can paly my
game as well as they to go beyond others. There was need therefore to warn the
young man, that he err not on the right hand out of pride, nor on the left
hand out of covetousness. This precept is fitly joined to the former. For as we
must not abuse other men's simplicity, nor innocence to do them hurt, so we
must not abuse their prosperity to envy them, nor imitate their wicked ways of
gain. For the words.

Envy thou not. The word (...) is taken sometimes in a good sense, and then it
is construed with (...) for. He was zealous for his God. Numb. 25.13. And then
it signifies to grieve, that a person, or thing dear unto one, should be abused
by another, and to seek to defend, or vindicate him, or it. Then it is
translated zealous. Sometimes it is taken in a bad sense. I the Lord thy God am
a jealous God. Exodus 20.5. And then the verb is ordinarily construed with
(...). Rachel envied her fister. Genesis 30.1. And it imports a grieving, and
envying, that another should enjoy what we desire, or think to belong to-us.
Then it is translated to be jealous, or to envy. And so it is taken here for
envying, that others are richer then we.

The oppressor. or, Be not envious against the oppressor. So (...) is
translated. Surely there is no enchantment against Jacob, Numb. 23.23. Heb. The
man of violence. That is, an ungodly man, that grows rich by oppressing others.
Men may dislike him for his cruelty, but they would not envy him, unless he
were rich. Invidus alterius rebus macrescit opimis. The envious man grows lean
to see other men's estates grow fat. Be not troubled, that wicked men thrive by
wicked ways. Look not on such as happy men to be envied, nor applaud the
courses they take, nor follow them to get wealth by those unlawful ways. The
word (...) is used.

1. For a man by nature, whither male, or female, as opposed to a beast. I am
God, and not Man. Hos. 11.9.

2. For any man. None shall deliver out of my hand. Heb. Not aman. That is, not
any man. Hos. 2.10.

3. For a male opposed to a female. The male, and his female. Genesis 7.2.

4. For an husband. She gave also unto her Husband. Genesis 3.6.

5. For an excellent man for strength, or nobility. Art not thou a valiant man?
1 Samuel 26.15. Heb. Art not thou a man? Here it is taken in the first sense for
a man opposed to a beast.

And choose none of his ways. Do not do wickedly, as he does, that thou may
be as rich as he. Although some of his evil ways may be fairly covered over
with vizards, that the evil of them may not be seen, or be more gainful then
other, yet show, that thou have more wisdom, then to prefer any way above good
ways, or to choose one wicked way, though thou refuse other, for they are all
to be refused. Regard not worldly wickedness joined with greatness, neither
be wicked as they are, that thou may be great as they are. Be not allured by
the ungodly man's example, however he speed in the world, to follow him in the
same steps. For as wicked men's prosperity makes other men to envy them at the
first, so it makes them to imitate them at last, that they may be rich also.
For choose, see on Chap. 1.29. For None, or Not any, see on Chap. 1.13. on the
word All. For Ways, see on Chap. 1.15.

Figures. A Metaphor in the word ways. Men that oppress, do not now and then
do an unjust action, but walk on constantly in such courses to their death, as
travelers do in their way; till they come to their journies end. Two sins are
here forbidden 1. Envying of evil rich men. 2. Imitating of them. In the
first, note 1. The Sin forbidden. Envy not. 2. The Object. The oppressor.


In the second observe 1. The Sin forbidden. And choose not. 2. The Object. Any
of his ways.


1. Doct. Many live by oppressing others. So vild beasts and great birds and
fishes live on the weaker, and smaller; By reason of the multitude of the
oppressions they make the oppressed to cry. Job. 35.9. I considered all the
oppressions, that are done under the Sun. Eccl. 4.1.

Reason. 1. Because it is an easy way of living, when men need not work
themselves, but make others to work for them, as men go easily in a Coach, or
by water, where they sit still, and others work: but it is harder, and more
wearisom to go on foot.

2. Because it is a profitable way, for many things may be gotten by indirect
ways, that cannot by lawful means. There may be cousenage in Wares, Weights,
Titles, and many other ways, that few can prevent, for ^o man is exercised in
all trades. And it is an easy thing for a skillful seller to cosen an
unskilful buyer. It is the ones trade, not the others. And trades are called
mysteries, as having many secrets in them concealed from others.

Use. Marvail not, that so many complain of injuries, and wrongs. Where there
are many suits, there is much injury. And where there are many oppressors,
there are many oppressed. There are many worshippers of Mammon in the World,
and all his worship is false worship.

2. Doct. Men may grow rich by oppression. They covet fields, and take them by
violence, and houses, and take them away: so they oppress a man, and his
house, even a man, and his heritage. Mic. 2.2. Some remove the landmarks, they
violently take away flocks, and feed thereof. Job 24.2. etc.

Reason. 1. Because they quickly get away a great part of other men's estates. A
poor man may labor long to get a little. An oppressor sweeps a way much at
once.

2. They get all away from others, and great heirs are oftentimes wiped by them
of all they have. That which is true of poor oppressors, is also true of many
rich ones, who never think themselves rich enough, Like a sweeping rain, they
leave no food Chap. 28.3.

Use. Take heed of oppression. If there were no bait, no bird, nor fish would
meddle with an hook. If no gain, no man would oppress.

3. Doct. Such as grow rich by oppression must not be envied by us. David the
Father, and Solomon the Son join in this instruction. Solomon here in the text.
David in the Psalms. Fret not thy self because of evil doer, neither be thou
envious against the workers of iniquity. Psalm. 37.1. Asaph confesses his fault,
I was envious at the foolish, when I saw the prosperity of the wicked. Psalm.
73.3.

Reason. 1. Because hereby we shall wrong God, and censure his proceedings, as
dealing better with bad men, then with good, whereas we should acknowledge
Gods wisdom in it, who gives the best things, as the graces of his spirit to
good men, and riches, which will perish, he gives often to bad men. Heaven he
gives to godly men, and the world to ungodly. Fathers make them fare harder
then strangers, for whom they provide an inheritance. Hereby he shows, that
grace is good, sin evil, and riches of a middle condition, good, or bad, as
they are used. Haec bona ne putentur mala, dantur and bonis, ac rursus, ne
putentur summa, dantur and malis. Item auferuntur ista bonis, ut probentur, and
malis, ut crucientur. August. Epist. 7. These good things, that they may not be
thought evil, are given to good men also, and that they may not be thought the
chiefest good things, are given to evil men also. Again, these things are
taken away from good men, that they may be proved, and from bad men, that they
may be vexed. And what art thou, that by thy envy, and discontent censurest the
deep wisdom of God?

2. We shall condemn the generation of the righteous, and think wicknesse
better then goodness. Psalm. 73.15.

3. We do not consider the end of these men, that God does set them in slippery
places, and will cast them down into destruction. Psalm. 73.17.18. Gods curse
will eat out all their substance. Male parta, male dilabuntur. Ill gotten goods
are ill spent. De male quaesitis non gaudet tertius haeres. Of ill gotten goods
the third heir never joys. If they that get them, spend them not, their
children will. The world runs upon wheels. A covetous Father begets a
prodigal Son. He that knows not with what pains it was got, knows with what
ease it may be spent. Had thou rather have riches, that will end in poverty,
or poverty, that will end in riches? No great witneedfull to choose, yet envious
persons show themselves fools in choosing the worst.

4. We look not at the great account they have to give for getting their goods
by oppression, for deteining relief from the poor, or for prodigal spending
what they have gotten by oppression.

Use. Let this pull down our spirits, that they rise not up against rich
oppressors. Nature thrusts us forward to envy. Do ye think the Scripture says
in vain, The spirit that dwells in us, lusts to envy? Jam. 4.5. We think
we are as good as they, and why should we not fare as well? The Heathen man
could see this fault in moral men: Socrates being asked, what was most
troublesome to good men? answered, The prosperity of wicked men. And grace
cannot keep this envy always out of good men, as was showed before out of
Asaphs case in Psalm. 73. who shows by his own experience, what force there is
in bad men's prosperity to trouble good men's minds; and how perilous this
trouble is to pervert their ways, as appears in that Psalm at large. It is no
easy thing then for good men to behold the prosperity of bad men without
vexation. Take heed therefore of this envy; will thou envy a Porter, or an
Ass, that carries heavy burdens of gold and silver, but is never the better
for it in the end? will thou envy a viper, or a serpent, that is full of
poison? So riches prove to wicked men through their corruption. Chrysostom. in
Romans Hom. 7.44.

4. Doct. The Devil has more ways then one to undo us. If he cannot get good
men to envy at the prosperity of rich men, he will get bad men to follow their
evil ways. He had three temptations for Christ. Math. 4. Many snares of
persecution for Paul. 2 Cor. 11.

Reason. 1. Because he works according to men's predominant affections. He draws
proud men to envy others, covetous men to imitate the ways of rich worldlings,
angry men to revenge, loose men to wantonness. So he puts fuel to the fire,
which quickly takes.

2. Because of his long experience in temptation for five thousand years. If a
soldier could live so long, he would be very skillful.

Use. Be always suspicious, and watchful. He that goes where many blocks
are, or snares, had need look to his feet. A snake may be among roses. A snare
amongst the best things.

5. Doct. Men are ready naturally to follow bad examples. So bad men do. From
the sins of Jeroboam the Son of Nebat, who made Israel to sin, Jehu departed
not. 2 King. 10.29. So good men do. Peter's dissimulation carries away the other
Jews, and Barnabas also. Gal. 2.13.

Reason. 1. Because of the corruption of nature, which remains in the best.
Many dispositions not so bad as others are ruined by following others.

2. Because in those ways there is gain, pleasure, or safety. And all men look
after some of these.

Use. Let us (...) set good examples before us, even the best, and be ashamed
to follow those, that are worse then our selves.

6. Doct. None of the oppressors ways must be imitated, no not the most
cleanly, pleasurable or profitable. One would think, it were safe to follow a
multitude in evil; yet that is forbidden. Exodus 23.2. He that follows vain
persons, is void of understanding. Prove. 12.11.

Reason. 1. Because their ways, though never so pleasing to themselves, are
perverse, and cross to all men. They care not whom they wrong, so they
satisfy their own lusts.

2. Because their ways are destructive. They undo many, and will lead us
closely to hell, though men may approve of them.

Use. Regard not worldly greatness joined with wickedness, and be not wicked
as others are, that thou may be great as they are. Those ways may bring
pleasure, or gain, and be cunningly carried, so that no man can see the
iniquity of them, but God sees it, and will take pleasure to ruin them, whom
men cannot ruin.

VER. 32. For the froward is an abomination io the Lord: but his secret is with
the righteous.
THE reasons that follow to the end of the Chapter are by some writers applied
to the former precepts. ver. 27. etc. To wit, that we should not any way wrong
our neighbor, because God will revenge it. Others tie them to ver. 31. as
reasons why we should neither envy nor imitate oppressors, because God hates
them. Rather follow good men, whom God loves, and to whom he reveals his
secrets, and shows them, what misery he will bring on rich oppressors. In this
verse and those which follow there is a fourfold opposition between good men,
and bad set forth by diverse names, curses, and blessings. The names, Froward,
opposed to righteous; Wicked to just; Scornrs to lowly; Wise to fools; The
curses, and blessings. Gods abominating to reveiling his (...). His curse on
the family; to his blessing on it; Scorning, to giving grace; Inheriting glory
to shame.

For the words.

For. A reason of what went before. Envy them not, nor follow them, for theirs
is but seeming felicity, God abhors them, and will certainly punish them. Do
not thou lose thy labor. God will break them to pieces. Therefore thou had
more need to pity them, then to envy them, or choose any of their ways. For
(...) see on Chap. 1.9.

The froward. For the word, see on Chap. 2.15. Here it may well be understood
of the oppressor mentioned. ver. 31. For such are contentious persons, and
common barators.

(...). An abomination. Extremely hated, as hatred it self. Not only hated,
but abominated, as a stinking carcass, that we cannot endure near us. It
signifies a thing, which offends the senses, from which men turn away ears,
eyes, nose, etc. It shows Gods utter dislike of the ungodly. Lo, shall we
sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes, and will they not
stone us? Exodus 8.26.

To the Lord. Heb. Of the Lord. For the word, see on Chap. 1.17.

But. See on Chap. 2.22.

His secret. Some understand it of that secret, that God intends to destroy the
oppressors, though he let them thrive for a time. Others of the way to Heaven,
which is a secret to the world. Others of secret consolation. Though they meet
with troubles abroad, God gives them store of comfort within. Others of Gods
protection in times of trouble. They have Gods secret place, wherein to hide
them, till the storm be over. Psalm. 91.1. But the beginning of this verse by
way of opposition, and the next verse by way of exposition shows, that it is a
description of friendship, and that God is spoken of after the manner of men,
who dislike some men so much, that they will not admit them to secret
familiarity, nor trust them with any private business: but they love others so
well, that they will often converse in private, and communicate their secret
intentions to them. So God hates and curses evil men: but loves, and blesses
good men. The word (...) signifies

A secret. A thing kept from others. The secret of the Lord is with them that
fear him. Psalm. 25.14.

2. A plot devised privily to bring mischief on others, which is commonly kept
secret, lest it should be prevented. O my soul come not thou into their secret.
Genesis 49.6.

3. An assembly of men, that lay their heads together to consult, for such
consultations use to be carried in secret. I will pour it out upon the assembly
of young men together. Ier. 6.11. Here it is taken in the first sense. He
acquaints them with what he keeps secret from others.

With the righteous. Such as fret not at the prosperity of wicked men, or
rather such as do not imitate them in oppressing others, but deal justly with
all men. For the word see on Chap. 2.21.

Figures. An abomination for an abominable thing. The adjunct for the subject.

Note. 1. The portion of the wicked.

2. Of the godly. In the former observe 1. The word of coherence. For. 2. The
Subject. The froward. 3. The Adjunct. Is an abomination. 4. The Object. To the
Lord.


In the latter note. 1. The word of opposition. But. 2. The Adjunct. His
secret. 3. The Object. Is with the righteous.


1. Doct. There is a great difference between the condition of a good man and
of a bad. This is showed at large. Psalm. 1. and Psalm. 33. all over. It is also
proved by the particulars in the text, and after it.

1. Because God loves the one, and hates the other. And this appears in that he
communicates his secrets unto the one, as to friends, but conceals them from
the other, as from enemies in this verse. And

2. Because he curses the wicked, and blasts all their endeavors, and blesses
the other in all they do enjoy. ver. 33. wicked men's comforts are cursed, and
godly men's crosses are blessed to them.

3. Because he scorns, and contemns ungodly men; but he favors all that are
godly. ver. 34. Now his favor is better then life, his anger worse then death.

4. He prefers godly men to glory, that will last for ever: but he sends the
wicked ashamed to Hell. ver. 35.

Use. Labor with Mary to choose the better part. Who would not rather be in a
low condition with his Princes favor, that can raise him, then in an high one
with his anger, that can pull him down, when he will?

2. Doct. God hates ungodly men. They that are of a froward heart, are an
abomination to the Lord. Chap. 11.20. The way of the wicked is an abomination
to the Lord. Chap. 15.9.

Reason. 1. Because though men flatter, and commend them, yet God always
speaks ill of them, and their ways, and he always speaks, as he thinks. He
will not speak ill of them he likes, nor well of them he likes not. He cannot
dissemble.

2. Because he is resolved to ruin all that live and die wicked. Men prefer
and set up wicked men for their own ends: but if God do prefer them in the
world, it is but to ruin them for ever. Tolluntur in altum, ut lapsu graviore
ruant. They are lifted on high, that they may have the heavier fall.

Use. Contemn the prosperity of wicked men, for God will certainly ruin them,
notwithstanding their wealth.

3. Doct. God intimatly loves godly men. The mercy of the Lord is from
everlasting to everlasting upon them that love him. Psalm. 103.17. The Lord
loves the righteous Psalm 106.8.

Reason. 1 Because he communicates his secrets to them; as in the text. Where
Gods secret is, there is his heart, yea himself. He makes them of his privy
counsel. I have called you friends, for all things, that I have heard of my
father, I have made known unto you. Ioh. 15.15.

2. Because he will have them with him for ever in Heaven: and we love them
well, whom we desire never to part withal.

Use. Let us be godly, that we may be great in Gods books. No matter then,
though the world count us base, afflict, and oppress us. God will make us of
his counsel here, and happy for ever. Psat. 73.24.

VERSE 33. The curse of the Lord is in the house of the wickeed: but he
blesses the habitation of the just.
IT might be objected against the former ver. that it does not appear, that God
lothes wicked men, and loves good men, for he makes evil men rich, when better
men are poor. Solomon answers in this verse, that it may so come to pass
sometimes, but yet, the plenty of evil men carries Gods curse with it, which,
like a moth, eats it up, and the want of good men carries Gods blessing with
it, which brings comfortable supply. So he confirms the former proposition by
the effects of Gods hatred, and love.

Fore the words.

The curse. His plagues, and judgments are threatened, and prepared, and in
time shall be executed on them. Some understand it of want, and the blessing,
of plenty; for the one is threatened to the wicked, the other promised to the
godly in the Law. Gods curse will bring the wicked rich man to poverty, and his
blessing will bring the poor godly man to plenty. This God often does, but not
always: therefore the former interpretation is better.

Of the Lord. Sent by the Lord. For the word, see on Chap. 1.7.

Is in the house. Though it be never so stately a Palace: yea, on all in his
house, as wife, children, goods, etc. For the word, see on Chap. 1.13.

Of the wicked. See on Chap. 2.22.

But. See on Chap. 2.22.

He blesses. His good providence watches over it for good. The word (...)
signifies

1. To bow the knee. Solomon kneeled down upon his knees. 2 Chronicles. 6.13.

2. To bless. Bless the Lord, O my soul. Psalm. 103.1.

3. To curse. It may be, that my sons have sinned, and cursed God in their
hearts. Job 1.5. Here it is taken in the second sense for blessing, as it is
translated. Yet not for Verbal blessing, as we bless God; but for a real
one, as he blesses us. I will bless thee, and make thy name great, and thou
shall be a blessing. Genesis 12.2.

(...). The habitation. The word signifies a shepherds Cotage, and is used
also for any house. If a godly man have but a poor Cottage, yet Gods blessings
shall be on him, and on all his in it.

Of the just. See on Chap. 2.20. on the word Righteous.

Figures. House, and Habitation for the dwellers in them. As, The Lord blessed
Obed Edom, and all his household. 2. Sam. 6.11. The subject place for the
adjunct.

Note. 1. The extent of Gods curse.

2. Of his blessing.

In the first observe 1. The Author. Of the Lord. 2. The Action. The curse. 3.
The Object. Is in the house of the wicked.


In the second note 1. The Author. But he. 2. The Act. Blesses. 3. The Object.
The habitation of the just.


1. Doct. Gods curse is on wicked men, in all their ways. See Levit. 26.14.
etc. Deuteronomy. 28.15. etc.

Reason. 1. Because their poverty, losses, and crosses are not trialls as the
afflictions of Gods people are, but beginnings of sorrows, and an earnest of
Hell, assurances, that they shall have no true comfort here, nor hereafter

2. Because their wealth and outward comforts are turned in to curses; In
enjoying them they meet with many crosses in wives, children, servants; and are
forced sometimes to wish their wealth in the bottom of the Sea. In losing them
they meet with much sorrow, and cannot bear want so well as they that never
were rich. Gods curse consumes wealth, house, meat, drink, etc. Strumpets never
are rich, though they have great gifts. Deceitful tradesmen often break. The
uses may be taken out of ver. 31.

1. Use. Envy not thou their worldly prosperity. Would thou have their riches
with Gods curses? It will weigh thee down to Hell.

2. Use. Imitate not their wicked courses to get wealth. They may enrich you
before the world; but they bring with them the sting of Gods curse to ruin you
for ever.

2. Doct. Gods blessing is on godly men in all their doings. See Levit. 26.3,
etc. Deuteronomy. 28.1. etc.

Reason. 1. Because if they have but little, yet they have content with it,
which wicked rich men have not with all their wealth. And he that has content,
has enough in a journey. He may look for plenty when he comes home.

2. Because God will turn his poverty into plenty, if he see it fit for him.

Use. Embrace good ways. What can thou have more, then Gods blessing, which
brings content in the way, and happiness in the end?

3. Doct. Whole families may fare better, or worse for good, or bad Governors.
Obed-Edom was a godly man, and entertained the Ark of God, and the Lord blessed
Obed-Edom, and all his household. 2 Samuel 6.11. The Lord give mercy to the house
of Onesiphorus: for he often refreshed me, and was not ashamed of my chain. 2 Timothy 1.16. David had like to have destroyed all the males of Nabals family for
their Masters churlishness. 1 Samuel 25.22.

Reason. 1. Because under good Governors they have good example to encourage
them to do well, and good instruction to show them, how to do well. Happy are
thy men, happa are these thy servants, which stand continually before thee, and
that hear thy wisdom, says the Queen of Sheba to Solomon. 1 King. 10.8. And
under bad Governors they have bad example, and counsel.

2. Because although they should not regard either the one, or the other, yet
God prospers them outwardly for their Governors sake sometimes, as Cham fared
well in the Ark for Noah's sake, and the prisoners fared well, while Joseph
guided there. So did they that lived in Abraham's, Isaacs, Jacobs, David's,
Solomon's family. And on the contrary, servants may suffer for bad Masters, as
Nabals innocent servants had done, if God in mercy to them had not pacified
David's rash anger by Abigails wise counsel.

Use. Take heed of living in bad families, and get into such, as have godly
Governors. There is a blessing in it, as in the cluster on the Vine. Isa.
65.8. (...): The Gods are within also, said the Philosoper of his poor cottage.
Much more may the servants of the true God say, in whose houses God himself
dwells, and in whose houses are Churches of God. Philem. ver. 2. Their cottages
are better to dwell in, then royal Palaces. Dwell then in such with comfort,
and expect Gods blessing.

VER. 34. Surely he scorneth the scorners: but he gives grace unto the lowly.
GODS severity against all kind of sinners was declared before. Now he shows,
that God has a special quarrel against scorners, and mockers at Gods word,
and admonitions, his promises, and threatenings, his service, and servants.
Wicked men deride those, that trust to Gods promises, or fear his threats:
therefore God scorns them. Here are many names for wicked men; Froward,
wicked, scorners, fools. Many for good men; righteous, just, lowly, wise. Many
evils threatened to the one, abomination, curse, scorn, shame. Many good things
promised to the other, as knowledge of Gods secrets, his blessing, favor,
glory.

For the words.

Surely. The word (...) signifies

1. If. If it be before. Exodus 1.16.

2. It notes a question. Am I a Sea? Job 7.12.

3. It signifies when. When he went in unto his brothers wise. Genesis 38.9.

4. Though. Though thou detain me. Judge. 13.6.

5. Seth, or, Seeing. But fith ye say. Jer. 23.38.

6. Surely. Surely your turning of things upside down. etc. Isa. 29.16. So
here. And then it may come from (...) truth, the last letter being lost. And so
our Savior says in a like word made Greek. Amen, Amen. Verily, verily Ioh.
1.51.

He scorneth the scorners. See on Chap. 16. upon the word, Interpretation. God
lightly esteems of those, that set light of his Ordinances, and scoff at
religion. And sometimes he shows them, that they are deluded by punishing them
openly, and giving them over to bescorned by others, as he pours contempt
upon Princes. Job 12.21.

But. See on Chap. 2.22.

He gives. See on Chap. 1.4.

Grace. Respect from himself, and men, as on the contrary, he scorns proud
persons, and makes men contemn them also. For the word, see on Chap. 1.19.

Unto the lowly. These are fitly opposed to scorners, who are proud. Proud and
haughty scorner is his name. etc. Chap. 21.24. Some read, to the poor. For such
are often lowly, when rich men prove proud scorners. Our soul is exceedingly
filled with the scorning of those, that are at ease, and with the contempt of
the proud. Psalm. 123.4. But the former reading is better, for poor men are not
always lowly, nor rich men proud scorners.

Figures none. Note. 1. Gods opposition to the scorners.

2. His favor to the lowly.

In the first observe 1. The word of assurance. Surely. 2. The person. He. God
scorns them. 3. The Act. Scorneth. 4. The Object. The scorners.


In the second note. 1. The word of opposition. But. 2. The Act. Gives. 3. The
Object of the thing, Grace. 4. The object of the person, Unto the lowly.


Doct. 1. Wicked men are called by diverse bad names in scripture, and good men
by diverse good. It appears in the last verses of this Chapter, where ungodly
men are called froward, wicked, scorners, fools, names of disgrace, and good
men are called righteous, just, lowly, wise, names of credit: So in other
places, ungodly men are called Goats, Math. 25.33. Dogs, Swine, 2 Pet. 2.22.
Foxes, Cant. 2.15. Good men are called Gods peculiar treasure, Psalm. 135.8. His
jewels, Mal. 3.17. His Sheep, Math. 25.33. His sons, Genesis 6.2.

Reas. 1. Because God thinks no one name bad enough to set out his dislike of
wicked men, nor good enough, to set out his delight in good men.

2. Because there are many vices in evil men, and many virtues wrought by God
in good men; yet one is predominant: we say, one man is choleric, though he
have other humors, because that prevails: So among wicked, some are froward to
men, others are impious toward God, others scorners of piety, others foolish
in their ways: Among good men, some are more righteous and just, some more
lowly or wise then others, and some of these names may fit one good man, and
some another.

Use. Seeing God declares his hatred of sinners, and love of Godly men by so
many several names, let us learn to show our dislike of the one, and love of
the other, by several ways. In our eyes let a vile person be contemned, but
let us honor them that fear the Lord. Psalm. 15.4. It becomes a Citizen of the
heavenly Jerusalem, to be affected like God. If Ahashuerosh honor Mordecas, he
expects the people should do it too, and therefore shows him in state to the
people, with a proclamation* Thus shall it be done to the man whom the King
will honor. Es^ 6.9. If he will disgrace Haman, his servants at the first word
cover his face: As the word went out of the Kings mouth, they covered Haman 's
face. Est. 7.8. So should we honor those whom God honors, and lightly esteem
of others.

Doct. 2. God sets light by proud scornful men. If thou scornest, thou alone
shall bear it Chap. 9.12. He that sits in the seat of the scornful, God
will make him like the chafe, which the wind drives away. Psalm. 1.1, 4.

Reas. 1. Because God has more reason to scorn them, then they to scorn
others: There is more difference between God, and the wisest, richest,
strongest man in the world, then is between him, and the foolishest, poorest,
weakest creature in the world.

2. Because nothing is more just, then lex talionis, the law of requital. It
was the Magistrates rule in the Law, Life for life, eye for eye, tooth for
tooth, etc. Exodus 21.22, 23. Adonibezeck acknowledges it, As I have done, so
God has requitted me. Judge. 1.7. So with the froward, thou will show thy self
froward. Psalm. 18.26. And by proportion God will scorn scorners. This is a
glass to show scorners how ill it becomes them.

Use. Take heed of scorning: If men dare not set you as light as you set them,
God will. If your height make you despise others, God will either bring you low
in this world, or take you out of it, and send you to hell, to show, that he
sets as light by you, as you do by others.

Doct. 3. God shows great respect to humble men. He gives grace unto the
humble. Jam. 4.6.1 Pet. 5.5.

Reas. 1. He gives to such grace and favor in his own sight. I will look to
him that is poor, and of a contrite spirit. Isa. 66.2. Nihil est tam Deo gratum
quam seipsum in postremis numerare. Chrysostom. Nothing is so pleasing to God, as
for a man to reckon himself among the meanest.

2. Because he makes them to find favor with men. Mansuetude reddit hominem
gratiosum non solum coram Deo. sed etiam coram hominibus. Meekness makes a man
gracious, not only before God, but also before men. Lyra.

Use. Banish all proud thoughts, and labor for true humility; such are
pleasing both to God, and good men, and therefore though evil men scorn them,
they shall be no losers. Humility is both a grace, and a vessel to receive
grace. Men let the vessel down into the water to fill it in a river: so must
he that will find favor with God, lie down in the dust, and cry, Non sum
dignus, at sum indigen^. I am not worthy, but I am needy. He shall then have
cause to say, I am poor and needy, yet the Lord thinks on me. Psalm. 40.17.

VER. 35. The wise shall inherit glory, but shame shall be the promotion of
fools.
HEre is the last motive to stir us up to get wisdom, and forsake the ways of
wickedness, because the one brings glory, the other shame; and it is fitly
knit to the former: for the humble, who are the only wise ones, go from grace
to glory: and the proud scorner, who is the greatest fool, shall fall from
honor to shame. Seeing humble men are counted simple, and proud men wise, and
sin prefers many, and grace makes many contemned in the world, he therefore
raises up the dejected heart of the one, and casts down the proud spirit of the
other, by pronouncing the lowly wise, and the scorners fools, and by promising
honor to the one, like to men in a rising condition, and threatening disgrace
to the other, as to men going down the wind. Glory follows fitly after grace,
and shame after scorning; for men honor those they favor, and put them to
shame whom they scorn.

For the words.

The wise. Godly men, who are wise indeed. For the word, see on Chap. 1.5.

Shall inherit. Shall firmly enjoy it for continuance, as children enjoy their
inheritance left them by their parents: they shall not have glory for a moment
of time, but for ever, by an hereditary right. The Papists bring merit out of
this word, but it rather concludes the contrary, for no child deserves his
inheritance.

Glory. They shall be honored by God and men. Lyra tells us, that the
commentator on the first book of the Ethics (I suppose he means Aristotle's)
says, that reverence, honor, glory, exceed one another. I may reverence a man
for any cause; yea, though it be but out of fear: but if I reverence a man for
his virtue, then I give him honor, though it be in secret, and before a few:
But when I commend him, or prefer him for virtue openly before many, then I
give him glory, which is a clear acknowledgment with praise: He adds, Wisdom
makes a man honorable before a multitude, not only in earth, but also in his
heavenly country. For the word, see on verse 16. on the word Honor.

But. See on Chap. 2.22.

Shame. Contempt from God and man, which may make them hold down their heads
for shame. As the word (...) that signifies glory, comes from a word that
signifies weight, So the word (...) that signifies shame, in the original Text
comes from a word that signifies lightness: For as there is weight in true
honor, so nothing but emptiness in disgrace:

Shall be the promotion of fools. Shall be the greatest honor wicked men can
attain: They look for great honor by their wicked devices, but they shall end
in infamy. Others read, Fools carry away shame: they bear it away for their
portion. And then it is a Noun plural, with a Verb singular, intimating, that
it is the portion of every fool. Others thus, Shame takes away fools. That
is, destroys them, and all their hope of good. Others thus, The exaltation of
fools is shame. That is, their honor ruins them, because they know not how
to use it: The filthiness of their foolishness most appears when they are
exalted, as the deformity of the Apes buttocks appears most, when he climbs up
on high. For fools, see on Chap. 1.32.

Figures. Inherit. A metaphor: they shall have it as surely, as children their
inheritance. Promotion. An hard metaphor, as sperare, to hope, for timere, to
fear. Promotion for punishment. Note 1. The wise man's portion. 2. The fools.


In the first, observe 1. The heir, The wise. 2. The act, Shall inherit. 3. The
object, Glory.


In the second, note 1. The portion, But shame. 2. The bestowing of it, Shall
be the promotion. 3. The object, Of fools.


Doct. 1. God counts godly men wise, and wicked men fools. Fools because of
their transgression are afflicted. Psalm. 107.17. The righteous shall see it,
and rejoice. Who so is wise, and will observe those things, etc. Psalm. 107.42
43. A wise man will hear, and will increase learning. Chap, 1.5. Fools despise
wisdom. Chap. 1.7.

Reas. 1. Because good men walk in the right way, which is a sign of wisdom:
and wicked men miss the way to happiness, which is a sign of folly.

2. Because the former speed well in the end, and that for ever, whereas wicked
men like fools, undo themselves eternally.

Use. Let not us think our selves wiser then God. Let us esteem simple good men
righteous, or right wise men, for so the Saxons write it, and wicked men
fools, as Christ does, though never so worldly wise. Thou have bid these
things from the wise and prudent, and have revealed them unto babes. Matthew.
11.25.

2. Doct. Honor is the wise man's inheritance. They that be wise shall shine,
as the brightness of the Firmament. Dan. 12.3.

Reason. 1. He has a proper right to it, as the heir has to his inheritance.
Laws of men settle the one: Gods word who can perform it against all the world,
settles the other. The Scriptures are able to make thee wise unto salvation. 2 Timothy 3.15.

2. They have a perfect, and unquestionable right given them by God, who is
possessor of Heaven, and Earth. Genesis 14.19. And Gods gift is a sure title. No
creature can question it: with this argument Jepthtah pleads against the King
of the Ammonites, Wilt not thou possess that which Chemosh thy God gives thee
to possess? so whomsoever the Lord our God shall drive out from before us,
them will we possess. Judge. 11.24.

3. They have it by perpetual right, not for term of life only, but for
eternity in another world. Wicked men may get honor here, but they lose it for
eternity when they die.

4. They have a right to make use of all good respect from God, and men, both
here, and hereafter.

Use. Which of you would not have glory both in this world, and that which is
to come? He that would not, let him live, and die with shame, like a fool. He
that would, let him show himself wise in knowing, and coming to God, and
walking according to his will. Then will eternal glory follow him, as the
shadow does the Sun.

3. Doct. Shame is the fools preferment. My servants (who are wise) shall
rejoice, but ye (foolish sinners ( shall be ashamed. Isa. 65.13.

Reason. 1. Because if they do get promotion, it is but a shame to them,
because they know not how to use it: Stultus in gloria, simia in purpura.
Lapids. A fool in glory is an ape in purple.

2. Because their glory ends in their temporal infamy sometimes, but always
in eternal misery. There shall not be one fool in heaven.

Use. Envy not wicked fools. Shameful promotion is good enough for them,
unless they were better. Honor here is a gibbet to send them to Hell
hereafter. Fret not thy self then because of evil doers, neither be thou
envious against the workers of iniquity. For they shall soon be cut down like
the grass: and wither as the green herb. Psalm. 37.1, 2.

Thus ends the Exposition of Solomon's Preface to his Proverbs. To God alone
be glory through Jesus Christ for ever, and ever. Amen.
